name: El Presidente. –
text: The first item on the agenda is the debate on the Recommendation for second reading, of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, on the Council position at first reading with a view to the adoption of the Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 98/70/EC on the quality of petrol and diesel, directive 2009/28/EC on the promotion of the use of energy from renewable sources (10710/2/2014 - C8-0004/2015 - 2012/0288(COD)) (Speaker: Nils Torvalds) (A8-0025/2015).

name: Nils Torvalds
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, first of all I would like to express my deeply felt gratitude for the work of my fellow rapporteurs – the shadow rapporteurs. There is a very interesting group dynamic. We come from different parties and have different opinions, we come from different countries and have different priorities but, despite all these differences, we build something. We band together in the process and actually we end up being fairly good friends, despite all the differences.  Even though the Presidency is not here at the moment, I would also like to express my gratitude for the way in which the Presidency has worked, because they made a substantial contribution. I knew that they had had a very bad start in the Council but they did the best they could and, after going left and right, up and down, we eventually succeeded in bringing this very technical, technological and ideological report to the goal.  But there are two things which disturb me. We set out to reduce greenhouse gases and to open up Europe for technological progress. After all the votes in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (ENVI) we have to ask ourselves whether we actually achieved what we set out to achieve. The honest answer is that actually we did not. We had much higher goals. We had set higher goals to be able to reduce greenhouse gases, to get Europe into a position where we could meet our goals for 2020, 2030 and even for 2050. I am very worried – and I think my fellow shadows are also worried in the same way  – about our ability to reach these goals.  We also set out to open up Europe for technological progress. We found that this was probably a very important goal because, if Europe does not move forward in technological means, it will end up being left on the back burner and being relegated to second, third or fourth place in the world. In this respect we have a systemic shortcoming. We have a blocking minority in the Council and this blocking minority sometimes develops into a dictatorship of the minority where we have Member States that are afraid of the future. When they are afraid of the future, they do not dare to make the right decisions and they therefore put on the handbrake and try to run Europe on the handbrake.  I think this systemic shortcoming in the way in which the Council works is one of the biggest challenges we have. If the Council is not able to see the future and if they are not able to see the light on the horizon then we will not reach our goals. I will be glad to come back after hearing the shadows.

name: Miguel Arias Cañete
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is a satisfaction for me to take part in this debate on the indirect change in land use, or ILUC, as it is known by its acronym. We are faced with a possible agreement that mitigates ILUC while protecting existing industry. In addition, it also shows a clear path for advanced biofuels. This is a significant achievement, and I am aware that it has not been easy. I hope that you will support this agreement and that we will be able to conclude the negotiations. I would like to express my sincere thanks to all members, including those who worked on this dossier with such conviction during the last term, and I am particularly grateful to Mr Torvalds and his negotiating team and Mr La Via for their efforts to get the dossier forward at this final stage. The compromise package is the result of very close negotiations. Thank you also for the excellent cooperation and for giving the Commission many opportunities to share and explain your views.  The compromise package before us today is much stronger than the Council's position at first reading thanks to the determination of this Parliament.  Let me say a few words about the key elements of the engagement package. I shall begin by limiting the contribution that biofuels produced from certain crops can make to the objectives of the Renewable Energy Sources Directive. This is known as the 'roof of biofuels obtained from food crops'. The Commission had initially proposed that this ceiling should be 5%, or half of the target for renewable energy in transport. This level was chosen to protect existing production levels and would mitigate the impact of ILUC while protecting existing industry. The level in the commitment package is set at 7%. It is higher than the European Parliament initially proposed, but it could still mitigate the ILUC. In addition, other elements have been added to strengthen this ceiling. The compromise package seeks to encourage the transition to advanced biofuels, which is very important for our future, as set out in the Communication on an Energy Union. Member States shall set a target for advanced biofuels with a reference value of 0.5 %.  It is true that it is not a binding objective, but it is also true that Member States have a tight deadline to be explicit and to define their level of political ambition in relation to advanced biofuels, and this provides industry with a clear signal, while still being realistic to the Member States. I hope that, together with existing initiatives such as the NER300 and Horizon 2020 Programme, it will help to continue the development of this industry in the European Union. In addition, the commitment package will improve the greenhouse gas performance of biofuels by raising the greenhouse gas savings threshold for new facilities, which must operate with 60% savings compared to fossil fuels. The commitment package also requires fuel suppliers and the Commission to report on estimated ILUC emissions, indicators based on the best available scientific information, which will improve greenhouse gas reporting and increase transparency. And the compromise package also removes one element of the Council's position to which the Commission and Parliament opposed it. I am referring to the extension of multiple accounting for advanced biofuels to the overall objectives of the Renewable Energy Products Directive. This would have weakened the 2020 package, and its elimination is a significant achievement. As a whole, all of these elements contribute to the package being effective in mitigating ILUC, while preparing for a transition to advanced biofuels. Today's biofuels industry is protected, while the advanced biofuels industry in development receives encouraging signals for its future. I know that not everything in the European Parliament's first reading position is reflected in this proposal for a final agreement, but, given the difficulties of this complex dossier, I believe that Parliament has achieved very important achievements.

name: Christofer Fjellner
text: On the other: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr I would also like to take this opportunity to thank Mr Torvalds for his excellent work on this report.  I remember when I was new here in the European Parliament almost 11 years ago. At the time, many people said that the targets for renewable energy were too low. There was talk of the EU doing too little and too slowly to promote ethanol. At that time, ethanol was described as the way to heaven, and in Sweden the Green Party/Social Democrats decided that each gas station would have to have a special petrol pump that you could refuel ethanol with. But that was then, because now there's another sound in the bark.  Today, ethanol is described rather as the way to hell, and when we have worked on this report, it is clear that green Members in particular, but also the Socialist Group, have done everything possible to water down the EU's renewable fuel targets. The ethanol, it's going to go away, and the faster the better. Back home, those gas pumps are about to rust.  But biofuels are neither heaven nor hell, and we do not have to choose between food or fuel. You can do both. Biofuels are a necessary part, I would say, of a successful climate policy, especially in all the countries, such as The Hague. sweden, where we have great need for transport.  But one thing is certain, that is that we need stable and long-term rules of the game for renewable fuels, and that is what was at risk if this legislative report had gone wrong. I am therefore pleased that we managed to stop the demands that came from large parts of this house, especially from colleagues on the left and in the Green Group, to phase out this goal and create strict restrictions on the possibility of creating new advanced biofuels. This would have made it very difficult to make biofuels from the forest, but I think that if we succeed in this, we have created a stable playing field. I therefore hope that all Members, especially those who dare to call themselves greens, will vote in favour of the new rules, because if you do not do that, you really only support fossil fuels.

name: Seb Dance
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, I would also like to extend my thanks to the rapporteur Mr Torvalds for his work in what has often been quite difficult circumstances. We got here in the end, we got a compromise, and I am very grateful to him for all his work.  I think it is very important that we take a moment to consider why we are having this debate and why this issue has been such an area of contention, because we have for many years now seen the effects of particularly bad policy from the European Union when it comes to biofuels. I have seen some of these effects for myself in my previous role working for an NGO in areas of the world, particularly in sub-Saharan Africa, where communities have been suffering from some pretty bad effects of the policies that we have been adopting here. In particular: the proliferation of crops for biofuel production for fuel consumption there on land that could and should be used for food production; the betrayal of some local communities whose livelihoods have depended on that land; and of course the unintended consequences of indirect land use change that have resulted from the replacement of ecosystems that would actually have contributed to solving the problem of climate change.  The package that we have now is imperfect and I make no bones about the fact that we have serious reservations, certainly about the target for first-generation production which, as we know, we wanted to be much lower. I think this package certainly reflects the intransigence of Member States, and that has been particularly apparent in the position adopted by the Council when it came to the negotiation process – and also reflects a lack of ambition, if I may say so, from the Commission. However, this is a step forward and we should acknowledge the significance of this, because the impasse that we have had for so long now has not been beneficial for the communities that I have mentioned. It has not been beneficial for the industries that have, with the very best of intentions, set us down this path on the investments that they made so many years ago.  I think that in this package we are choosing, at last, to recognise the existence of indirect land use change and we are giving the Commission the platform to enable itself to apply the science that the blockers have for so long denied.  There are some in this Chamber who would deny some of the bad impacts of biofuels that I have mentioned, and there are others that might choose to play politics and score points on this deal. I think this deal represents a step forward, imperfect as it is, and that is why I shall be supporting it. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Εμμανουήλ Γλέζος (
text: GUE/NGL), "blue card" question. Mr President, I would like to ask my colleague if he knows that the last earthquake in the Himalayas is related to climate change, which is the result of any human intervention in nature, particularly in relation to fuel.

name: Seb Dance (S&D)
text: blue-card answer. – I think there are many causes of earthquakes, but I think plate tectonics might be the principal cause. I am willing, though, to hear evidence on the contribution of biofuel policy in the European Union to the devastating earthquakes in Nepal. If such evidence is forthcoming I would like to hear it. I have an open mind, let us put it that way.

name: Gerben-Jan Gerbrandy
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Let me also begin by thanking our rapporteur, Nils Torvalds, for his excellent work, especially in view of the stalemate he found here in this House, and given the stalemate with the Council he inherited from his colleague Corinne Lepage, who had done the first reading. Let us be honest: this stalemate with the Member States does not bode well for the future, because we are only talking about the climate targets for 2020. If we can already create a stalemate over that 20%, and if you consider that we will have to go to 80 to 95% CO2 reduction in 30 years' time, that promises very little for the future. The steps we are taking now are really small steps and yet every millimetre is already being fought over. That promises something if we have to take the real big steps. With the current attitude of the Member States in particular, I am convinced that we will not get very far with our climate policy. We are telling ourselves in Europe that we are going to meet the 2020 targets. If I just look at my own country, the Netherlands, I see that now that economic growth is picking up a bit, co2 emissions are suddenly increasing again rather than falling. I therefore think that we need to take a very good look at our policy. Let us now be the subject we are talking about: this small adaptation of the directive on the quality of petrol and diesel fuel and the directive on energy from renewable sources. Making good policy requires courage, especially in today's changing world and especially if it turns out that the existing policy is being overtaken by science, because that means that we have to adapt our policies. We must realise that biofuels are not the holy grail that we held them to a few years ago. These may be advanced biofuels, but we must link sustainability criteria to them and not make the same mistake as in recent years. Because that's what we're threatening to do now. Again, I will vote for this result, but it is a very meag haven.

name: Kateřina Konečná
text: on the part of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, when I thought about how to vote on the final document before me after the trilogue, I was overcome with a great sense of hopelessness and sadness. We all know today that the promotion of first generation biofuels has been extremely difficult, that the European Union has made a nasty mistake and overlooked several fundamental factors in the design of the original directive, which has been reflected in considerable damage to the landscape and the environment, a reduction in food self-sufficiency and an increase in food prices. As shadow rapporteur, I approached the forthcoming change with hope and great anticipation, but the opposite has happened. The first alarming indication that something was not quite right was the constant pressure that was exerted on us on a daily basis by European lobbying, which was more interested than the environment in what raw material or fuel would be supported and where it would count. Nevertheless, thanks to the excellent work of the rapporteur and the work of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, we have entered into final negotiations with the Council and the Commission with a very strong document. But what ultimately emerged from it is nothing more than a major defeat for both the European Parliament and, above all, the environment. We have yielded to pressure from the Council and, above all, the Member States, and have resigned to everything essential that the new regulation was supposed to represent. We lost the 6% threshold for first generation biofuels, which was the maximum at the beginning. We have failed to ensure sufficient support for second- and third-generation biofuels by admitting that their share will not be binding. The European Parliament has simply failed to push through almost anything that was originally voted on in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. The resulting text is then basically only a slightly improved version of the original design from 2009. It can be said in good conscience that after almost five years of negotiations, we have achieved nothing substantial. For this reason, I would like to say here that the GUE/NGL Group does not mean to participate in any way in this charade, which at its core means the preserve of the status quo, which is very much disguised as a huge change.  Ladies and gentlemen, the plundering of our landscapes will continue, the current producers will still benefit greatly from this, and we have not been able to prevent this.

name: Bas Eickhout
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, first of all I would like to thank the rapporteur, Nils Torvalds, for his work on this file which indeed, as has been stated before, was not an easy file at all. Certainly it was not easy to build up a majority in this House and then undertake negotiations with the Council, and I think we have to thank the rapporteur for all his work in that.  Having said that, I am disappointed with the result but I am more disappointed that the Council is not even present at this discussion. It somewhat shows the problem we are having here, that within the Council the Member States do not really see the problem at hand. That is, I think, a very bad signal they are giving here: that again they are just not showing interest. That was also very clear during the negotiations and I think that is a problem. Why are we discussing this? We set a target of 10% for biofuels in the transport sector, but we all know that, if you look at how it has been developing, it mainly concerns the development of agri-fuels, of first-generation biofuels, which are not delivering the climate benefits that they are supposed to do. That is why we had to do something about it.  The Commission came forward with a proposal trying to cap the first generation at 5%. In Parliament we managed at least to get a deal for a cap at around 6%, but the Member States wanted this to be at 7%. Unfortunately, in the negotiations, we lost this. In the end, we as a parliament, agreed also with the 7% cap which is, from my perspective, way too high, because this is just filling up the target with the bad biofuels which are not the ones that we want to stimulate; we want to stimulate the more advanced ones. That was the second demand of Parliament, that we want advanced biofuels in order to really have innovation in Europe.  Unfortunately, here also the Council did not want anything. In the end, we have a non-binding target for advanced fuels, so that means that there is a very weak signal for stimulating innovation within the European Union. And if you look at the definitions, this term is also poorly defined and now we will probably have a debate where everyone will call his own product ‘advanced biofuel’. Suddenly everyone will be part of that new hype but not really delivering innovation.  The third problem relates to indirect land use change. We wanted clear accounting of indirect land use change and we lost that too; we only have reporting, not accounting. In that sense, from my perspective, we lost too much. We just lost too much as a parliament, and therefore I cannot support this deal.  But the Commissioner is here and I would like to ask what are we going to do after 2020? Are we going to learn from this problem and not set a very inflexible new target but to put the Fuel Quality Directive at centre stage: setting a target on reduction, and not specifically targeting a technology when we do not know exactly how it will develop? Therefore the question: will we continue after 2020 with the Fuel Quality Directive?  If we continue with the directive, we will have a new debate and then I hope that the Council will be present because this is a very important topic. If we do it right we can really have decarbonisation in the transport sector, but if we do it wrong we are stimulating bad technologies and that is what we would like to prevent. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. - Dear Mr Eickhout, I would like to ask whether, although I very much agree that it is necessary to negotiate further, if we cannot decide whether it is first, second or multi-generation fuels, we will not, in fact, inadvertently give way to fossil fuels continuing to advance?

name: Bas Eickhout (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card answer. – First of all, biofuels are not the only alternative in town. That is one of the biggest problems; we are now stimulating just one technology in the transport sector that can decarbonise the transport sector, whereas there are many other options. So I think that what we have done in our policies is focus too much on one technology, which is a very stupid thing to do from a political perspective.  So you have to set your central objective, your decarbonisation, and then have different options for how to play this game. In that sense, what we have been doing now is really focusing on one bad technology that does not deliver; does that mean that we are fixating ourselves on fossil fuels? No, the problem is that now some of these alternatives are even worse for the climate than the fossil fuels, and then we are really stimulating the wrong one. That we really need to fix, and unfortunately we are not fixing that enough in this case.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Christofer Fjellner (PPE)
text: blue-card question. – You said that we are focusing too much on biofuels in the European Union. Would you agree that this is the fault of the Greens and their actions 10 years ago?  Secondly, you said that agri-biofuels are not delivering. Are you aware of the fact that we have ethanol produced in Europe that is third-party certified as having 90% CO2 reductions? Are you willing to agree that there are differences between different first-generation biofuels?  Thirdly, if Parliament were to vote, as you will vote today, against this legislation, and if you had EUR 1 billion, would you dare to invest that in the production of second-generation advanced biofuels if Parliament decided, as you want, to kill the rules and definitions of how they should be produced?

name: Bas Eickhout (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card answer. – First of all, Mr Fjellner, I am voting in favour of the ENVI mandate. I know you were against. You did not want anything on indirect land use change. You want a higher cap for the first generation. You have been taken in by the agriculture lobby for a long while. We know that.  If you really wanted to have some change then you would have joined the ENVI deal. You were not part of that deal. In the negotiations you were ready to give up everything and we know that. Now you are pretending that you are suddenly on the good side. Maybe you should have joined us a bit earlier on instead of not even participating.  Secondly, if you want to distinguish between the good and the bad you need to take indirect land use change into consideration, because that is the key point. If we do not take indirect land use change into consideration, you do not know which is good and which is bad. That is why I am advocating taking indirect land use change into account. You did not even want that. So you are the problem, in that you just want one target, stimulating agriculture instead of only stimulating the good biofuels.  As to your third question, if I were a producer of second-generation biofuels at this moment and considering this deal I would not put my money in Europe because this non-binding ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Piernicola Pedicini
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, I too would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Torvalds, for the efforts that have been made so far.  Unfortunately, however, we do not like this compromise at all, but it is difficult to call it a compromise because it was indeed an act of imposition by the Council, which did not even want to take any account of Parliament's position and therefore of the position of the citizens of the European Union. We have fought to defend all those companies that are an example of a circular economy, but perhaps the circular economy is no longer of interest to the European Union. I am talking about those companies that use woodworking waste, for example, to produce furniture. With this directive, these same wastes will be encouraged to be used in the production of advanced biofuels.  The Council has irreparably watered down Parliament's proposal and now these companies will be without their raw material and will face unfair competition from the advanced biofuels industry. Do you know how many companies I'm talking about? I'm talking about a lot of companies. I'm talking about companies that are closing now. Do you know how many more unemployed there will be because of this competition on the raw material?  We therefore call on the Commission in its revision legislation to move quickly towards the decarbonisation of the transport sector, but above all to make biofuel legislation truly green and truly sustainable. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: Question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure.  – Dear colleague, in your speech you said that if this proposal were to be voted on, there would be competition for those who produce energy, for example, from wood. Do you consider that there should be no competition and competition in a market economy?

name: Piernicola Pedicini (EFDD)
text: Answer to a blue card question. Of course we need competition, but we do not need unfair competition. We are talking about companies that use this waste as a raw material and therefore participate in a circular economy process, which we should give priority to.  It's a matter of priority. If we remove the raw material from these companies, which are already dying because they already have difficulties due to the crisis, but we also remove the raw material, we will have a deterioration in terms of employment and a deterioration in the quality of the type of companies that we are going to promote.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we would be wrong to give up first-generation agrofuels abruptly. Numerous studies, including the Ecofys report, published on 12 November, challenge the method of calculating indirect changes in land use, a method on which the Commission relied to abruptly change its 1998 and 2008 directives. If further research on advanced biofuels is needed, we must take into account the heavy investments already made - I am thinking in particular of our farmers, who have relied on these energies of the future to emerge from the serious crisis in their sector. Their efforts cannot be ruined with the stroke of a pen, even though the second generation of biofuels does not yet seem able to take over from the first. The 7% ceiling proposed by the Council therefore seems to me to be more reasonable because it is more respectful of investments that have been made over the long term, for the long term. Since the Barthe Act of 1923, my country, France, has played a pioneering role in biofuels. I believe in the know-how of our farmers and industrialists to continue to lead by example, provided you do not cut the grass under their feet.

name: Peter Liese (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I would like to thank all those who have contributed to this compromise, the PPE-DE rapporteur Nils Torvalds and, above all, the negotiator Christopher Fjellner. I think it is a good compromise. And the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats will vote in favour of this compromise. We need to change direction moderately. But we don't want to throw the baby out with the bathwater. It is not a good signal to the economic operators, to the farmers, to others who have invested when, a few years after we have introduced the target, we say that everything was totally wrong. There is also protection of trust. I am not one of those who say that EU biofuel policy is the cause of all the problems in the world. There is a lot of dramatised. Much of what is being done in this area is sustainable – at least more sustainable than traditional oil production. That is why it is good that we are re-directiond here. I particularly welcome the fact that we have a target for the second generation. But it is also good that we do not completely question everything that has been invested. The second-generation target for modern biofuels seems modest. But we have to implement this legislation first. Businesses need to invest, and 2020 will come very quickly. Then there will be a new Commission proposal for the period after 2020. Then, hopefully, we will also have higher targets for modern biofuels for the period after 2020. I think that, for all the criticism that is being levelled, we should not forget that biofuels – whether first or second generation – and this directive as a whole help us to become more independent of oil. I think this Parliament should agree on this objective.

name: Sergio Gaetano Cofferati (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, with the reforms of the directives on fuel quality and renewable energies, the Eu ropean Union is taking a step in the right direction, which is to build a greener and more sustainable future for this part of the world.  It is important that, in these months of negotiations, the European Parliament has stood out for its strong vision for innovative rules on biofuels and for supporting the Role of the European Union in combating climate change and promoting the green economy.  The text produced by the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy had set standards that were rightly very ambitious. The conclusions of the agreement with the Council significantly reduce these standards. Nevertheless, I would like to thank Mrs Torvalds for the way in which she has carried out her work and for the results that have been achieved. With these new rules, even though they have already been mentioned, Europe is finally saying no more competition between food and fuel, and this is an important result of principle; just as it puts a daring end to the distorting effects that have driven up the prices of many food products in the poorest countries under the pressure of easier gains thanks to fuels.  It is therefore a sign of encouragement which is heading in the right direction and which will stimulate many Member States, including myself, to invest in the subsequent return of Parliament's work on these issues in order to achieve what has not been possible today.

name: Evžen Tošenovský (ECR).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the promotion of conventional biofuels and the fixing of a 10% share was a mistake with negative effects on agriculture. I am glad that the European Commission has recognised this and now we have a chance to make amends at European level.  However, the 7% limit is still too high and I am sceptical about the willingness to reduce at national level. Unfortunately, I see a reality in my own country where biofuels have become an interesting business linked to public subsidies. What is alarming is that there is even a conflict of interest in our country. At the same time, the owner of the dominant fuel producer is a member of the government that decides on the subsidy system. I therefore support the 5% to 6% share of the first generation bio-components, because of all the negative experiences with the current directive that brought about this.

name: Jan Huitema (ALDE).
text: – It has already become clear that biofuels are a contentious issue and the lengthy negotiations indicate that there were many obstacles to overcome. I would also like to thank the rapporteur for this. In the long term, we will always have to strive to use our raw materials more efficiently. This is sustainable and economic. Our farmers and gardeners are crucial to this. They produce more and more food with ever lower environmental pressures. Innovations have contributed to an increasingly effective but also more efficient use of raw materials. Biofuels are an opportunity for farmers to make the most of a natural cycle. They can contribute to a more circular economy. To do this, we need the right and clear objectives and there must be room for innovation and experimentation. European agriculture is capable of great performance through new insights. The agricultural sector makes an important contribution to our common challenge.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, the revision of these two key issues of energy legislation has taken five long years to get to this vote and unfortunately a lot has been lost by Parliament in the face of a relentless Council. There is no doubt about it that this deal is far weaker than anything we would have envisaged, and I am disappointed by the Council’s attitude. Indirect land-use changes should have been accounted for, instead of just reported on, and advanced biofuel should have had a stronger target.  Whilst I would also have preferred to see a much lower cap on first generation biofuels, the 7% limit which has been agreed upon will see their growth curbed which is good news for the environment, for biodiversity and for hunger in the developing world. After five years of long and difficult negotiations, I am sure many are ready to put this issue to bed, but if we are truly going to commit to a feature of sustainable transport in the European Union, it can only be just the beginning.

name: Martin Häusling (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I think we agree that we need to change the direction of agrofuels. In my opinion, however, what is to be decided now is not enough at all. I know that ten years ago we all had high expectations of these fuels as an alternative to fossil fuels. But those expectations have not been met. We see that today climate balances of agrofuels are sometimes worse than those of fossil fuels. We must take note of that. Especially in the case of palm oil or soybean oil, there is competition for tank or plate. I find it simply scandalous that the iLUC factors are not taken into account at all now. Of course, you can discuss all the factors, they are not perfect. But not taking these land-use conflicts into account at all now is not a good approach. We must, in any case, discuss again whether we can simply remove these factors. We are now writing at 7%. We guarantee, so to speak, protection for investments. But we are going the wrong way! Ladies and gentlemen, I do not believe in the second generation either. I am quite honest about that. After all, if we understand what residual material potential is now being calculated – which is supposedly usable for this – then that is not appropriate, because these residues do not exist in the quantity. We will not make any progress with this, and we will put a lot of investment in the sand. We need to shift in transport policy to energy saving and to new transport concepts. That is the only alternative.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (EFDD).
text: – Incentives to move towards biofuel production are essential today. The new rules must facilitate the development of the next generation of the least polluting biofuels across the European Union. However, it is also essential to take into account legitimate business expectations, investment and their protection, and the different situations of the Countries of the European Union, when setting ambitious targets. Firstly, the threshold for first-generation biofuels must be acceptable and implemented for all countries. I think it's important. Market stability needs to be ensured and the investments already made in the cost-effectiveness of first generation biofuel production capacity.  Secondly, the development of new technologies would simplify the process of production of biofuels and the cost of production, and allow the use of new types of raw materials. However, technologies for the production of advanced biofuels are still in development, many at demonstration level and economically unjustified. Therefore, dear colleagues, I believe that it is very important to promote research and development in new advanced biofuels sectors. Only in this way will we be able to achieve the desired objectives.  (The speaker agrees to answer the blue card question of the person who raised the Blue Card (Rule 162(8)).

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: Question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – I would like to ask our colleague Mazuronis how he believes that the Commission of the European Union should stimulate the consumption of biofuels and advanced biofuels.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (EFDD)
text: answer to the blue card question. – I believe that now ( and the document we are talking about) is the promotion and search for a solution to the question that you are asking. On the one hand. On the other hand, we must also take into account the interests of the members of the European Union, the situations in the different Countries of the European Union, and, in the end, the investments made in business and so on. In this place, we must seek reasonable consensus and a reasonable compromise for maximum results. Otherwise, we will have ambitious targets, we will have great ambitions and, unfortunately, a poor result.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI).
text: – The Biofuels Directive is discussed in ordinary legislation, i.e. in a codecision procedure with the Council, but only in principle. Only in principle, because the Council refuses to take into account Parliament's amendments, and even the empty seats show that it does not even listen to us. That is why the rapporteur can agree with the view that parliament's amendments at first reading will be repeated again. The most important thing is to severely limit the share of conventional biofuel, i.e. biofuel produced from food crops. If we do not do this and energy prices increase and we know that they will increase, crop production will be grown for energy purposes in ever larger areas, not for food use. And the serious consequences of this have been seen on other continents.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, after difficult negotiations, we have reached an agreement on the ILUC, known as an indirect change in land use, with the aim of setting a ceiling on greenhouse gas emissions caused by the increasing use of agricultural land for the cultivation of products intended for the production of biofuels.  The objective we have set ourselves with this dossier is to make a transition to biofuels that offer substantial savings in greenhouse gases even when estimated and provisional emissions due to indirect changes in land use are reported, while protecting existing investments by economic operators who have focused on first-generation biofuels under current European standards.  I would, of course, like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Torvalds, for the work he has done for Parliament, as well as my colleagues from the other political groups who have cooperated and worked on this dossier. But I should also like to thank the Latvian Presidency, as chairman of the ENVI Committee, which negotiated with the Presidency for cooperation during the negotiations, which enabled us to reach agreement on a joint text with the support of the Commission. I am not going to go into detail as the rapporteurs and shadow rapporteurs have done, but I believe that, overall, this is the only possible compromise; it does not satisfy everyone, it is not satisfactory to everyone, but it is the only compromise that could be brought between the Council and Parliament at the end of the vote today.

name: Jo Leinen (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The debate on the revision of the two directives has shown that, in future, we need to focus more on second-generation biofuels. Mr Häusling, these are not only straws and residues from agriculture, but also novel substances such as algae and others. I would like to ask the Commission: what are we doing to research and market these novel biofuels? Do we have a programme in the European Union? We will need biomass for aviation fuel, and most probably also for lorries, where there are no alternatives yet. However, this must be limited in car traffic, which is not necessary, because I believe that electromobility and hydrogen technology are alternatives. It is therefore right to really restrict first-generation biofuels. We would have liked 5.5%, now 7% have come out. This will mean much more land use. It is therefore not good that the iLUC factor does not have to be included now. After all, as early as 2009, Parliament adopted the directive only on condition that the iLUC factor is assessed, and now we are losing many years before that happens again. This is a bad sign for the EU's climate policy, because the bottom line is that we are bringing out more emissions rather than reducing them.

name: Dawid Bohdan Jackiewicz (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. The aim of this directive is to initiate a process of shifting to a biofuel policy that will ensure a significant reduction in greenhouse gas emissions. The European Commission has m.in to reduce the contribution of conventional biofuels, improve greenhouse gas emissions from biofuel production and promote greater market share for advanced biofuels. The provisions of this directive have been working in the right direction up to a certain point, but its final form is not satisfactory. The Commission's proposal to improve reporting on greenhouse gas emissions by obliging Member States and fuel suppliers to report estimated emissions is simply a fiction. Most importantly, this directive would have serious consequences for agricultural production in many EU m.in in Poland. This means losses for processors and farmers, and we do not even know yet how these losses would be compensated. We need to listen more closely to those who will be most affected by these regulations. That is why we, as the Polish delegation in the ECR Group, will abstain from voting on this directive.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, the need to develop and support renewable energy sources in the transport sector is now more imperative than ever. However, many important points are absent from the report we are called upon to vote on to amend the relevant directive. Further increasing the contribution of renewable energy sources requires parallel policies, i.e. the promotion of appropriate infrastructure, the rationalisation of support schemes, and the exploitation of opportunities for international cooperation. It is also very important to add measures to ensure the boost of renewable sources at the lowest possible cost to consumers as well as measures to support small producers of renewable energy sources. Finally, the new projects and investments financed by the European Union in the transport sector must take account of environmental protection, support the low-carbon economy and promote renewable energy sources and, of course, energy efficiency measures.

name: Roger Helmer (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, my party holds no particular brief for biofuels, but we are particularly concerned about the damaging regulatory uncertainty which this Parliament has created. First, we mandated 10% biofuels and we allow industry to make major investments on that basis. One major European company has invested EUR 0.5 billion in a palm oil refinery. Now, we propose to cut the biofuel percentage to 5 or 6 or 7%. We are doing huge damage to investors. We are cutting them off at the knees. This is no way to run an economy.  More generally, we see a world awash with cheap oil and gas and that is a situation which is likely to continue for some time. CO2 emissions will increase for decades, regardless of what we in this House do. I have a word of advice for colleagues: it is time they got used to the idea.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE).
text: – Thank you President, I truly believe that you have inadvertently done so. Commissioner, indeed, biofuels seemed to be the right solution to many problems a few years ago. There is currently agreement between the Commission and Parliament, a 7% limit for first-generation biofuels produced from food crops. Such drastic policy changes once again show that legislation must be very measured. In Lithuania, the growth of the biofuel market was very marked – as many as four biofuel plants were built. It is essential that the proposed protection of existing investments is proposed by 2020. It is also in order to promote greater development of advanced biofuels with a lower indirect land use change rate than conventional biofuels. It is necessary for viable companies to invest in progress.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE).
text: Mr President, it is true that this issue has been very controversial for a number of years. The European Union had worked hard for the development of biofuels, but as a result of the somewhat disappointing results of these efforts, they were called into question.  Some feel that the agreement reached is not ambitious enough, others that it goes too far. I would say that it is balanced and, in short, preserves the investments made in these first-generation biofuels, but at the same time ensures that these biofuels do not compete with food production and that they do not produce greenhouse gas emissions that are excessive compared to other agricultural land.  Investors could not be the victims of a radical change in policy: they need time. When you invest, you have to have a long-term vision. Nor could they suffer the consequences of this method of calculating land use, which seems to me to be very uncertain and highly scientifically challenged. I am pleased that this agreement allows only a simple report until better methods of calculation are made. The 0.5% sub-target of advanced biofuels is an encouraging, pragmatic target, but I regret that it is not binding, because the resources to create such biofuels are still too low.  Europe must not be left behind technologically in the field of sustainable fuels, and that is why it must resolutely support research and development in this area.

name: Gilles Pargneaux (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, this is finally the end of a false good solution, that of first-generation agrofuels. The idea originally seemed attractive: driving without using oil. Yet hell is paved with good intentions. This was an aberration and we must, of course, be satisfied that the European Union and you, Commissioner, have decided to turn their backs on these fuels which have only the name of organic. At a time when we have the ambition to reach a binding compromise on a global scale at the Paris summit - COP21 - we have a first positive signal from Europe: we are ready to put ourselves seriously at the service of a low-carbon economy. Of course, not everything is perfect, far from it. I personally would have liked to go further, by calling for the inclusion of ILUC factors in the sustainability criteria for agrofuels or by imposing binding targets for virtuous biofuels. However, we must be clear that this is a compromise that is only one step, but an important step. We now have the course: the future is for advanced biofuels; first-generation biofuels are outdated. The bottom line is that Europe finally recognises that agrofuels are not a response to climate change. The ball is now in the Member States' court. In France, for example, the goal is to create 150,000 jobs in advanced biofuels by 2020. We are facing a challenge, which we will address at COP21 in December in Paris. This decision we are making today is a good move.

name: Julie Girling (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur very much for all his hard work on this file. For those of us who have followed it all the way through the last Parliament and this, it has been a long road. I am glad we have actually reached – or at least I think we are reaching – the end of it. It is amazing how there does not seem to be anybody here who wants to take responsibility for the 2008 agreement and for the 10% cap, which seems to be such a terrible idea all of a sudden. However, I for one am glad that we have settled on 7% because the first thing that that comes to mind with this file is how we have created a huge amount of uncertainty amongst investors. It really should be a cautionary tale to this Parliament that, if we are going to try to do things that are far-reaching, we must get it right and we must stick to it. It is entirely unfair to pull the plug a few years before the end, so I am delighted that we have, at least, settled on 7%. The second issue with this file for me was the indirect land—use change (ILUC) factors. This morning many have deplored the fact that we are not going to be accounting, but are only going to be reporting. I am delighted about that too, because it is absolutely clear that the science on ILUC factors is not good enough. The maths do not add up and the model does not work. I am happy to accept accounting when we get it right, but it is not right now.  The last thing I would like to touch on is Parliament’s negotiating. I take my hat off to Mr Torvalds: it is absolutely the case that the single most important thing that could have come out of this file was a mandatory target on advanced biofuels, but we did not get that. It was the one thing on which every political group across the spectrum agreed, but we did not get it. I think those who were involved in the negotiations should be ashamed of that fact.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD).
text: – I have tabled an amendment to reduce the share of traditional biofuels to 6%. If the Rules of Procedure allowed this, I would propose a complete repeal of the Biofuels Directive. Our predecessors created a monstrous system that leads to food price increases and people starvation in the world's poorest countries. We've created a system where a few oligarchs get rich. In the Czech Republic, for example, one such oligarch, Mr Babiš, first bought politicians to secure his disposal for his rapeseed oil. Then he bought a TV and radio station, bought the country's largest diaries, and eventually bought voters and became deputy prime minister proposing additional tax breaks for biofuels. Therefore, please support an amendment that would at least reduce the share of traditional biofuels to 6%.

name: Werner Langen (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I would like to thank Mr Torvalds first. The result is better than he himself has portrayed. It is the right balance between the protection of investor confidence and the demands made by this Parliament, particularly under the leadership of the Green rapporteur, Turmes, in 2008. I was a spokesman for my group at the time. And the value could not be high enough. Even then, the CO2 balance of biofuels was already known. This was nothing new. So, into the potatoes, get out of the potatoes! I think the compromise is a good one. The result is good. The objectives set by the Committee on Industry and industrial policy and adopted at first reading have largely been achieved. The inclusion of indirect land-use changes as malus for European biofuels was rejected because of a lack of scientific basis. With reporting, we have taken the first step towards evaluation for the future. The 7% ceiling is good and justifiable, even if it is higher than Parliament's proposals. Conventional biofuels thus have investment security. However, i believe that the operational target of 0.5% for the second generation is not ambitious enough. However, the quadruple credit is off the table. It is regrettable that there is no separate sub-target for bioethanol. The call for a continuation beyond 2020 is positive. Overall, the compromise is positive between market stabilisation and CO2 reduction. Now it is the turn of the Commissioner, because we have decided that we want a regulation beyond 2020. You now have the floor, Commissioner, with a new proposal.

name: Karin Kadenbach (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has A compromise can be accepted with the fullest conviction, or it can also be perceived as just acceptable. This second wording is true for me. It's better than what we had before. I am often asked: Why are you against biofuel, that sounds so good? Yes, many in our ranks were convinced to decide something good. But the truth has shown that in reality there has been a shift, from a production for the plate – for human and animal food – to feeding the tank. We have found that, in the end, the climate balance of this so-called biofuel – agrosprit – did not correspond to what we expected, but that in reality it led to a change in land use not only within Europe, but also in third countries, and that we were exposed to the risk that what we decided in good faith – I say now – ten years ago, in the meantime has turned the other way. The 7% is an acceptable compromise, because we have often heard today that we must, of course, also provide planning security and investment security. I just think that this planning certainty is already very high for the 7%. I would have preferred the 6%, which was already a compromise. In general, however, we must pay attention – and this has already been said several times today – to the fact that we continue to have new, progressive production and, above all, to invest in research and development on how we can guarantee mobility with the lowest possible burden. That is what Europe needs for the future.

name: Pilar Ayuso (PPE).
text: – Mr President; Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the first thing I want to do is congratulate the rapporteur, the Latvian Presidency and the Commission on this outcome and this agreement which has not been easy at all. Boosting advanced biofuels without closing the door on first-generation biofuels, after the investments that have been made, also in R&D, is a challenge that I think has been reasonably well addressed. I was rapporteur for the first Biofuels Directive and I recall the enthusiasm of the Greens demanding more ambitious and also binding objectives. We need to promote new technologies for emission reduction and provide adequate protection to existing ones. In the biofuels sector, high-quality investments have been made that have allowed us to reduce emissions and replace a portion of fossil biofuels for transport. ILUC factors, on the other hand, need more studies and more evaluations, because we already have enough unfortunate examples in the European Union of wanting to move from theory to practice without applying these prerequisites. I hope that Member States will take the necessary measures to ensure that biofuels involve a growing share of biofuels for transport by 2020 and also by 2030.

name: Pavel Poc (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, today we are voting on a proposal that does not meet the European Parliament's ideas on biofuels policy, nor does it even meet the original idea of the European Commission. It fulfils only the ideas of some Member States or of the specific manufacturing sector in those Member States. No wonder the Representative of the European Council did not even come here today. It would have to admit that the European Council tends to pass on a certain level of democratic deficit to the European level.  Two-thirds of the $17 billion biofuels market is represented by first-generation producers. No wonder their lobbying activity was known. The European Parliament has not succumbed to it, but unfortunately the Member States have succumbed to it. Not all Member States have the same ambitions when it comes to second- and third-generation biofuels, but we could have achieved much more. All we had to do was listen to the voices of parliaments, the non-profit sector and the innovative industry. Instead of at least stopping the growth in the share of first generation biofuels at current levels, we are committing to continue to increase them with all the negative concomitant effects. Instead of supporting innovation, we will have only non-binding objectives. Despite all the reservations, the result achieved is better than the current situation and to vote against the proposal would be to preserve the conditions that are present in the biofuels market today. We have at least limits on biofuels produced on agricultural land, a ceiling – some ceiling – for first generation biofuels, and some support for innovation in this sector. However, we are sending a very bad signal to the Council and the Member States if we 'get over' this nasty compromise again.

name: Andrzej Grzyb (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by This 2009 regulation, which relates to both directives, as in the mirror, shows how sometimes the legislative activities of the European Union can affect the consequences of economic activity. We are withdrawing from what we said at the time to be sustainable. After all, this objective of the 10% share of biofuels in transport was obvious at the time. People made decisions, took loans, built installations. Of course, I am talking about those countries where raw materials from agricultural crops in Europe were raw materials. I am not talking about those installations that have been prepared to import palm oil and in the countries of origin to change land use. And from this, for example, in my country, there are two million tonnes of protein feed, that is, feed, which we will not import in the form of genetically modified soybean, which also contributes to the ILUC phenomenon, but in South America.  I think that we should plan in a sensible way all legal solutions that relate to economic activity as well as to energy issues. After all, let us point out that here we are destroying or wasting about a third of the food – some in the harvest and some also in the form of waste. In Europe, we throw away around 90 million tonnes of food, including processed food. After all, this food has also been produced somewhere, so we cannot say that only because of biofuels we restrict access to food. Also because we're wasting it. Which energy is best? The one that is not used, unused. That is why we must have a policy that reduces the amount of energy consumed, but we should not demolish the whole economic system that we have built on our regulations. Prudent decisions must be taken.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, although this directive predate the Energy Union Communication, we now have the opportunity to review it in the light of a new perspective, a European Union that prioritises renewable energy, security of supply, energy efficiency and leadership in innovation and research.  The proposals in this report are quite balanced and call on the Commission to come forward with an ambitious proposal to promote the use of renewable energy in transport from 2020 on. In this plan, in addition to the necessary incentive for the most advanced technologies, in particular new generation biofuels that minimise competition with other levels, which minimise greenhouse gas emissions, it is important, Commissioner, to consider the ambitious objective for the development of electric mobility. Electric mobility, using electricity produced from renewable sources, can, in conjunction with biofuels, provide very high levels of penetration of endogenous energy into transport and this is very important to contribute to the energy security of the European Union, to reduce dependence and to lead, in European terms, the new era of the transport industry.  What we do by 2020 will indelibly mark our ability to lead the energy transition. Europe's energy transition is a necessity for the planet and we also aim for that to happen. With the document under consideration today, the European Parliament has made a positive contribution to this.

name: Ivo Belet (PPE).
text: I think we can say that we are pleased that, after years of negotiations, there is finally an agreement on biofuels. This agreement, we know, is not perfect, but with this adjustment, we are finally going down the path of so-called 'advanced' biofuels which do not tax agriculture, do not drive up food prices in the long term and reduce deforestation. Profit for the environment, so profit for the climate. And we're going to put an end to those bad side effects. Producers now know where they stand and can plan investments that will eventually benefit the production of advanced biofuel, renewable fuel. This agreement, of course, also gives clarity to the producers of the so-called conventional fuels, those of the first generation. They will have time to prepare and gradually switch to those environmentally advanced biofuels. Finally, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to say that we are pleased that this reform also makes a first and important impetus to encourage electric driving, of course on the basis of renewable sources. I think we can conclude that what we are adopting today is indeed a first important step in the right direction and also one of the pillars of that energy union that is so dear to all of us and you, Commissioner, and which we must realise in the months and years to come.

name: Damiano Zoffoli (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, after years of heated discussions on the future of biofuels in Europe, the European Parliament is finally preparing to vote on a dossier that is nevertheless an important signal in the fight against climate change and in promoting the green economy.  Real intelligent, sustainable and inclusive growth cannot, as at the time, pass from the production of so-called traditional biofuels from food crops that use land that can be used instead to produce food, while new land is taken from forests by increasing CO2. At the moment, given the strong resistance of the Council, this is the best possible agreement, a step towards objectives that will have to be more ambitious in the future.  Europe's challenge, also in view of the Paris meeting, is to strengthen its leading role in the battle against climate change, promoting the green economy with fair and sustainable policies. Without social equity and environmental sustainability, there is no exit from the crisis and there will be no new and good employment.

name: Norbert Lins (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I would like to express my sincere thanks to the Members who have taken up this issue and who, after many years of and controversial discussions, have now reached a compromise. I am glad that we have reached an agreement with the Council. I also believe that the compromise as a whole is a satisfactory result. Biofuels make a major contribution to increasing the use of renewable energies and reducing CO2 emissions. They also support our efforts to make the EU more independent of energy imports. I believe that we have reached a responsible compromise on first-generation biofuels. It is crucial that our political decisions are credible and sustainable. Farmers and businesses need planning certainty for long-term and expensive investments in their plants. I also think that the iLUC factors should only be included in the reports, but not counted, a good choice. This means that we have even more time to resort to comprehensive, scientifically proven studies. With this report, we have set the course for the future. Biofuels are important. However, they must not be produced at the expense of nature, especially areas worthy of protection.

name: Miapetra Kumpula-Natri (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I am pleased to chair the Working Party on Bioeconomy in this House, and I am therefore pleased that we have reached a compromise on which we are voting today. However, the goal must be the 2020 extension years, because there is very little time to get to that year.  I hope that the focus will then be on the objective of reducing CO2 emissions in transport. This can be done without competition with food production, because for example we can develop good raw materials from northern forests and waste and food residues. The European Parliament itself recorded in the residencies that the EU should seek to make use of biofuels made from waste, which can achieve high emission reductions.  Unfortunately, the form under discussion does not give industry a very convincing picture of what needs to be done now. I regret that there was no binding objective for the future. I would therefore like to ask how national implementations can play such a big role? In Finland, ten per cent of that 20 per cent target has already been achieved and in Sweden 17 per cent. Does the Commission intend to intervene in order to achieve a real internal market in biofuels as well?

name: Elisabeth Köstinger (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I too would like to join my fellow Members in welcoming this agreement and the achievement of this proposal. I also fear that this debate has inevitably been conducted almost only ideologically, and above all on the backs of producers in Europe. The local entrepreneurs no longer had planning and investment security. I also believe that this is relatively difficult. The result on which we are now going to vote is passable in itself, but certainly not enough. The first steps have been taken in the right direction. I believe it is important to continue to promote bioethanol and biodiesel. I am sometimes surprised by the one-dimensional discussion. In Austria, for example, a by-product of bioethanol production is of great importance, namely a 100% GM-free protein, which is produced and, of course, is also made available again for animal feed. Fortunately, I say now, we have been able to prevent iLUC factors because they are highly questionable scientifically. We are happy to discuss this if we have them, which will ultimately work. I would like to join the previous speaker, who is already talking about thinking about the post-2020 period, because we simply need the right measures to further boost CO2 reduction, energy supply and other things. The promotion of advanced biofuels is important, and I would like to emphasise this once again. Fuel from algae or waste products is the future of biofuels. We must also put every effort and energy into this to make this possible in the future.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, tá áthas orm cúpla focal a rá ar an ábhar tábhachtach seo. I must say that since our good Commissioner Arias Cañete came into office he has been at pains to point out the need to create an Energy Union by first of all decreasing our dependency on imported fossil fuels and increasing our resources within the European Union – and of course one area is that of biofuels.  Particularly in transport we have to say that emission reductions are not quick or good enough and with a growing economy we are going to see far more lorries and trucks and cars on the roads; therefore this has to be addressed. I think, as my colleagues in the EPP Group have pointed out, this is a good compromise because we do not throw the baby out with the bathwater by discriminating against first-generation biofuels, but we certainly send a signal that advanced biofuels are the way to go, and I would agree totally with that. Also we will reduce ILUC (indirect land use change) and particularly give legal certainty and confidence to investors that this is what they need to do if they want to be at the races in the years to come.  Particularly, I would like to say, I have met many people recently, investors and so forth, who see that we have had a wasted opportunity in not utilising waste in the past, but this now will change into the future. That will be good for the environment, CO2 emissions and for the Energy Union.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE).
text: – I also support this compromise proposal, which responds to a problem that has ariseted from an overly ambitious objective, where we have seen that there have been negative consequences in the exploitation of agricultural land and, indirectly, food price increases. And it's right that we take the time to think. It is also right that, when adopting the energy concept or the Energy Union, we really place emphasis on the objective that we have set ourselves that energy saving is the first source of energy. And I think that in the transport where we need these biofuels, the most opportunities are also possible and that we also have the biggest problems here with the objectives set. It is also important from the point of view of technological development... I think that, as necessary and will encourage this proposal, technological reflection in the field of biofuels, that technological reflection is also needed in electric car technologies. Because I am convinced that if we make great progress there, we will generate this energy saving precisely by using less fossil fuels and using more electricity in transport.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: – Mr President, first of all I want to congratulate the rapporteur, even though I felt that he was not fully satisfied with what he had achieved, but I believe that, always, before we vote on a report, we have to think about what it means if we do not vote for it, where we remain. Such a complex and complicated issue, as the issue discussed today, of course it cannot bring a compromise that pleases everyone, but I very much believe that we need to talk less politically here. We need to talk rationally and how it is good for the citizens who sent us. I think it is a step forward and I think we need to take into account the need for retrofitting, the need for investment. That is why, Commissioner, I think you have a very important role in the Commission: to persuade Mr Junker and the Junker committee to allocate for research, because we cannot make progress without research in this area either. We must bear in mind that the energy mix is extremely important and we need to see what we can do in terms of the effects on citizens, the cost of energy, but also the right to a clean environment. It's extremely complicated. I think compromise is a step forward. Of course, we cannot say that this compromise has been resolved, but we can say that we have made progress and, of course, I join those who vote for this report.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Mr. President, I will say right at the beginning that I will support this report, primarily because I know that its author, Mr. Torvalds, has done everything to reach a compromise and to make the expression of this Parliament as strong and as strong as possible.  Personally, I was able to speak and do things that are important for this report when I was in the executive branch and I must say that I was not inclined to the first generation of fuel and that I did not do much to put it into practice in Croatia, especially in Istria where I acted. However, I am convinced that it is this debate about the advanced generation, which talks about the use of waste, that we need to focus on.  I call really to invest significant money all together in research to turn waste and everything we can from waste into advanced bio fuel. I think that's the way we have to go.

name: Εμμανουήλ Γλέζος (
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, biofuels, apart from the pollution of the environment which they entail, mainly due to carbon dioxide, contribute to an increase in the heat of the earth. This increase in heat creates two phenomena: - The ice melts and the crust rises at this point, as we have measured in Greenland and as it did in the Himalayas and that is why the great Himalayan earthquake took place. - The second phenomenon is the challenge, with the melting of the ice, of a huge increase in evaporation and evaporation, resulting in rainfall, flooding and sprawl of soils in the low points.  Apart from these points, however, there is a huge burden of which we cannot understand the consequences. I sound the alarm if we don't take the necessary measures. I'm sounding the alarm!

name: Claude Turmes (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the As ex-rapporteur for the renewable energy directive, I am, of course, interested in what has now come out of this. So overall, this is not a wonderful deal, it's pretty weak. This has less to do with us as a Parliament than with the position of the Council – whose representatives are not even here. We must limit the first generation of biofuels. We have too much competition with food production. 7% is high, probably too high, good, but... Secondly, we need a methodology to account for the overall carbon footprint of biofuels. Without this, it is never possible to approach this subject scientifically in any way. Thirdly, the Commission, and perhaps you too, Commissioner Arias Caete, are called upon to do so. We need planning and investment security. That is why, following this relatively weak deal, the Commission should now also examine this 0.5% for the second and third generation – which are not even mandatory. The Commission should now take a firm initiative and see what money it has in the common agricultural policy, what funds in research policy, and that should link it to the Juncker investment plan. We need investment in Romania, Bulgaria, Poland – and perhaps even Ukraine – in this second and third generation of biofuels.

name: Miguel Arias Cañete
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you very much for your contributions throughout this debate. The plurality of arguments that have developed during it highlights the difficulties that have taken place throughout the processing of this directive and how difficult it was to reach such a delicate compromise which, as you have said, does not fully satisfy any of the participants in it, but of which, however, it was , it must be recognized that it mitigates the indirect change in land use and prepares a transition to advanced fuels. Now it's time to look forward and let me remind you of the general context. The energy union strategy reflects President Juncker's ambition for the European Union to become the world leader in renewable energy, and this strategy undoubtedly outlines a transition for the European energy system, leaving behind the fossil fuel-driven economic model, where energy has a centralized supply-side approach and is based on outdated technologies and business models. For me, renewable fuels that are not based on food crops and have a low carbon footprint, including ILUC, are part of this strategy. The energy union roadmap states that the Commission will present a renewable energy package setting out a comprehensive policy that includes biofuels for the post-2020 period. And as you have stressed, in the development of this renewable energy package with a comprehensive policy we will take into account all the experience we have accumulated in this area.

name: Nils Torvalds
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, listening to the debate in Parliament sometimes feels like looking at a film by Sergio Leone. For some of us, it is ‘The Good, The Bad and The Ugly’ and for others it is ‘For a Few Dollars More’. In some respects, I think all those who spoke here were on the right track – not always, but in some respects – but we did not fix everything. We did not fix everything that should be fixed on the earth, and I think Commissioner Arias Cañete will be back with this issue in, let us say, three years’ time, not just because of the Energy Union, but because of the fact that the technological progress we see out there in reality is for the moment very fast and we do not know where it is going to end and what possibilities we will have after two or three years.  When I say that I think we fixed one thing, by that I meant – and my friend, Mr Fjellner, used the Swedish expression ‘stabila spelregle’ or ‘stable rules of the game’ – I think what we gave was a signal that the European Union should have stable rules for the industry, because if we do not have that, the faster the technological development is, the greater the risk that industry goes elsewhere. I think we fixed that, but saying that we have fixed it at the same time as we have very fast progress it is a very tricky issue. So, Commissioner Arias Cañete, I think you have every reason to be slightly worried. You are going to have a lot of work and you are going to be back with us trying to fix some of the next problems we have before us – and for sure we are going to have them. Thank you all for a very interesting debate. The struggle goes on.

name: El Presidente. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place today at 12.30 a.m. Written statements (Article 162 of the Regulation)

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. The European Union is taking another step towards a greener and more sustainable future.  In all these months of negotiations, the European Parliament has distinguished itself by a strong vision in favour of innovative rules on biofuels and a stronger ROLE for the EU in combating climate change and promoting the green economy. The vote in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy set more ambitious standards than was achieved in the agreement with the Council, but I would like once again to thank Mr Torvalds for the way in which he has conducted his work and for the results achieved. With these new rules, Europe is finally saying no more competition between food and fuel and putting a stop to the distorting effects that have driven up the prices of many food products in the poorest countries, driven by easier profits from fuels.  At the same time, there is a strong signal of encouragement for those who invest in clean and sustainable energy technologies. Many European countries, including Italy, have already embarked in recent months on a virtuous path of innovation in the biofuels sector, the hope being that the new common regulatory framework can now be followed by other important measures within the framework of the Energy Union strategy.

name: Adam Gierek (S&D)
