text: I would like to write to the Commission. – EU legislation is full of inconsistencies – hasty, not very well thought out, trying to impose the same patterns of solutions on all Member States, despite other, sometimes extremely different economic conditions in them. A typical example of this is the climate and energy package, which is extremely unfavourable to some (e.g. Polish), very beneficial to others (e.g. France or Sweden) and indifferent to the third group of Community countries. The source of these inconsistencies is the solutions promoted by lobby groups in our House aimed at saving the climate. Thanks to these climate 'defenders', a legislative package of 'monsters' has been created, namely the RED Directive, which obliges countries to use 10% of biofuels in transport by 2020. As life has shown (and this was predictable), it will lead to deforestation and also to the use of soils, so that global food prices will rise sharply and, as a result, instead of reducing global CO2 emissions, we will see an increase in it. I ask for an urgent examination of the entire climate and energy package – which has so far caused numerous economic damage in some countries, such as Poland – in order to reduce these damage at least as quickly as possible. As the law should not change overnight, putting at risk some countries, such as Poland, which, thanks to the EC and the EP, has focused on the production of biofuels, I will vote against the supposedly compromiseD ILUC directive.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. – Reducing greenhouse gas emissions from marketed fuels is an important element of the European Union's efforts to combat climate change. This is an extremely complex subject: with many stakeholders, with different interests. I believe that we have succeeded in finding a compromise that is currently aiable. I repeat, this is a compromise, so many of us are not entirely satisfied. I would like to refer for a moment to the vote last December on the implementation of the Fuel Quality Directive. With the adoption of the average overall greenhouse gas emissions figure, I believe that a good compromise has been reached. At the time, the most important aspect was to reduce the administrative and bureaucratic burden on industry players. It is less about the administrative burden than the current debate, but about predictability: stability and predictability of the investor environment are the most important aspects for business operators. For the European People's Party, thinking on these aspects is a priority: economic development, job creation and competitiveness are key in the recovery from the economic crisis.

name: Филиз Хюсменова (ALDE)
text: in writing. – The amendment of the Fuel Quality Directive and the Renewable Sourcing Directive is an important element in the series of measures proposed by the Commission in relation to the fight against global climate change. I welcome the steps taken by the European Commission with regard to the European Union's biofuels policy and believe that the so-called "second generation" biofuels will contribute to reducing greenhouse gas emissions, protecting the environment and the health of European Union citizens. I believe that the amendment of these directives is a good example of the transfer of political priorities to concrete measures.

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D)
text: in writing. – The agreement this week sends a clear message from the European Parliament; we need to limit the use of first-generation biofuels and move towards more sustainable alternatives which put less pressure on the environment, food prices, and food security. Using existing agricultural land for first-generation biofuels, and clearing natural carbon sinks such as ancient forests, actually contribute to the environmental problems which biofuels were supposed to help solve. The use of sustainability criteria should drive the development of more advanced biofuels, ones which are fully compatible with environmental objectives and not in direct competition with food crops.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. The pressure on agricultural land generated by the agrofuel industry will have the direct consequences of a risk of food shortages and an increase in the price of food. It is therefore necessary to limit its production and rethink the concept itself. However, we would have liked more. Among our regrets: - we were asking for a ceiling of 5%. Less would not be acceptable given the investments made by the sector in this area and since the current share at European level is 4.5%. This is far from a detail when we know that every per cent of agrofuel represents just over one million hectares that is subtracted from food production, i.e. almost the entire arable area of a country like Belgium; - we also wanted binding targets for advanced agrofuels (second and third generation), whereas the agreement provides only an incentive. I am in favour of these advanced agrofuels. They use only inedible parts of plants and agricultural waste. The absence of binding targets in this area is a mistake.

name: Владимир Уручев (PPE)
text: in writing. – I welcome the final agreement reached on the amendment of the Fuel Quality and Renewable Energy Directives, as it offers a realistic approach that will allow investment in renewable fuels in transport to continue. The 7% ceiling for first generation biofuels will allow for the preservation of investments already made in these biofuels and, at the same time by introducing a reference value, albeit non-binding, for advanced biofuels of 0.5%, we will encourage investment in second generation biofuels.  I would like to recall that some of our colleagues are not entirely consistent. Seven years ago, they insisted on using biofuels from food products in Europe and defended the production of ethanol or biodiesel. At the time, they criticized us for not supporting these biofuels enough, and today the opposite – they criticize us for not banning them quickly enough. I was strongly opposed to drastic measures to decommission first generation fuels, because this would punish those European entrepreneurs who took the biofuels initiative and fulfilled all European requirements, opened up businesses and invested in their production. What is most lacking in our investors is the guarantee that there will be perseverance in European legislation. The adoption of this Agreement will largely guarantee them.

name: Henna Virkkunen (PPE)
text: Written. "One of our most important objectives is to get more investment in Europe. For companies to have the courage to invest, they need legal certainty long into the future. The development and production of biofuels is often hundreds of millions of euros for an individual company. It is therefore regrettable that this ILUC, which is now under discussion, does not provide companies with the long-term prospect that is needed. The directive has been set for the 2020 targets, even though we already have the recent 2030 climate and energy targets, to which renewable fuels for transport should certainly have been linked more strongly by now.  Similarly, a list of raw materials included in IIC, on the basis of which some raw materials receive double counting, is problematic. Such double-terms calculators distort the raw materials market and do not encourage research and product development. Technology is developing rapidly; Today's waste could be a valuable commodity tomorrow. Legislation must form a framework, but it is up to researchers and companies to assess how this objective is achieved.  Transport accounts for 30% of CO2 emissions in Europe and the fastest way to cut emissions is to replace fossil fuels with renewable energies. That is why work on energy efficiency and low emissions in transport must also continue at global level.

name: El Presidente. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Recommendation for second reading, of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, on the Council position at first reading with a view to the adoption of the Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 94/62/EC, packaging and packaging waste, to reduce the consumption of plastic bags (05094/1/2015 - C8-0064/2015 - 2013/0371(COD)) (Speaker: Margrete Auken) (A8-0130/2015).

name: Margrete Auken
text: Rapporteur. Mr President! It is a great day today because we have to adopt this proposal. We are challenged by a truly massive environmental problem: 100 billion of these lightweight plastic carrier bags are spent every year in the EU, and 8 billion of them end up directly in the wild as litter, if not more. We have the figures from the Commission, and this is something that is really harmful to nature and to the seas: to humans, to animals, to fish and to birds. There is only one thing to do about it, and that is to reduce the number. We have now succeeded in achieving something that is actually No 1 in the EU waste hierarchy, namely prevention. This is the first time we have passed a law containing prevention!  According to the Commission's 70% survey, citizens support us taking action. It was therefore really a pity when the Commission's proposal finally came. It was the previous Commission, but on this point it was not much better than the one we have now. It was a lousy proposal we were given that simply contained pious wishes. Fortunately, Parliament took action. I would like to take this opportunity to thank my colleagues for their excellent cooperation, first of all Gerben-Jan Gerbrandy, who was with us all the way, and in the second round La Via. In fact, we adopted a very good proposal. Then it was the Council's turn, and here I would like to thank the Italian Presidency. They managed, through excellent efforts, to keep the Council together, so that we now have a joint proposal.  It is short on reducing consumption, either by what I would recommend that countries decide to put a price on these bags. If you do that in 2018, the reduction will be achieved quickly. Ireland is a shining example of a price being put on plastic bags and within five months they achieved a 90% reduction. I have just heard that Portugal is doing something similar. If you do not choose that solution, you can go for the reduction targets. This means going down to 90 bags per capita in 2019 and as much as 40 per head by 2025 - which is a good result.  In this process, the Commission has been a nuisance! (Sorry to a good friend of mine from the Commission who is sitting here). It's worked us out all along. It has come up with all sorts of irrelevant objections so as not to do anything! In fact, it believes that it is up to the countries themselves to do something - but they do not. That is why we have received such good support for it. Despite the effectiveness of these proposals, despite the great economic gain - EUR 740 million a year, we are saving - again according to the Commission's own calculations. In addition to what nature saves, what the oceans save, we also save a lot of money! Nevertheless, right up to the finish line, we had problems with the Commission. I will belatedly forget the face timmermans was wearing when he had to go out and announce that the Commission had decided not to withdraw the proposal.  Finally, let me say that just during the time I have been talking here and talking, just in the four minutes, 750 000 plastic bags have been used in Europe. If you can see nothing more than that, then you can at least see that something has to be done. We are now addressing that. Thank you again to all the good forces in this House and in the Member States that have helped, and I hope that the Commission will also think it will be good to get something done about it. It's a "win, win, win situation."

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, we are here today to finalise the last stage of the legislative process of adopting a directive that aims to tackle a very serious and highly visible environmental problem: the overconsumption and littering of lightweight plastic carrier bags. These bags, as was already mentioned, easily escape waste management streams and accumulate in our environment, often in the form of marine litter. Once discarded, they can last for hundreds of years, often as harmful microscopic particles that threaten the environment worldwide, especially the marine environment in terms of marine litter. The very high and ever-increasing consumption rates of plastic bags – currently some 100 billion bags per year in the EU alone, and up to 200 bags per person per year – also imply a squandering of resources and have become a symbol of a throw-away society and a symbol of unsustainable lifestyles. Lightweight plastic carrier bags that are used once only and then discarded are the example of a ‘linear’ model of dealing with resources. Action is needed. We need to tackle the problem of marine pollution, which is to a great extent caused by plastic waste, and we need to save resources and move to a circular economy. Clearly, this is a global problem, requiring action beyond the EU, but it is important that we do our part. An early second reading agreement on amending the Packaging and Packaging Waste Directive to reduce the use of lightweight plastic carrier bags can be formalised today. Looking at the different positions of the co-legislators at the start of the legislative process, it is clear that this has not been an easy task, but thanks to the efforts undertaken by all parties, we now have a compromise on the table. Let me particularly express my gratitude to the rapporteur, Margarete Auken, for her dedicated and thorough work on the Commission’s proposal, as well as to the shadow rapporteurs in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. The Commission welcomes the agreement reached by the co-legislators, even though it includes some elements that would, in the Commission’s view, have been better addressed in a different, and in a much broader context. Nevertheless, this agreement has been possible because we all share the same objective: limiting the consumption and littering of plastic carrier bags. The text presented to you here today will make a real difference in reaching this objective.

name: György Hölvényi
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. Let me also start by thanking Mrs Auken and Commission President La Via first. I think we have taken a very serious step to get rid of a very bad habit in Europe. From the consumer habit that Commissioner Vella mentioned. We need to get rid of it, because we throw away 90% of these plastic bags and practically 8 billion plastic bags a year – and we have not yet drawn attention to this – become rubbish in nature, we do not know where it goes. It's just a scandal, it's our scandal. This proposal is trying to rid us of that. It is obviously a compromise, but we can show that it is really possible to deal with something that everyone in Europe is interested in in a citizen-friendly way.  And, as the reporting woman has said, there have obviously been solutions in several countries, and in fact I would like to highlight one thing: there is a choice. A choice can be made between the fact that, indeed, as in my country, a product fee will be introduced in Hungary in 2011, thereby reducing plastic bags radically or otherwise starting to fill and reduce the quota. It is very important that no one is left out of this, and it is still a compromise, because we know that we have not yet found a solution under a certain number, under 15 microns, we need to continue working and we have seen what interests are still there against it, but I certainly think that is very important. This alone is not enough, we need a cleaner, liveable European environment, and in fact we, too, have given the decision not only to governments, but also to European consumers. (The speaker agrees to answer a 'Blue Card' question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – Mr Hölvényi, you are in fact talking about a matter of choice. You talked about compromise. I do not think that we should have to compromise with our lives, because all these items are very polluting. In the end, I truly hope that we are going to call on the Commission and the Council to ban completely all these plastic carrier bags and not merely to reduce or limit them. Do you not think so?

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you very much for this opportunity. I agree with you of course, but I think that in this case everybody has to take care of his own country first rather than Europe doing everything. We have gone so far in Europe and every country has the opportunity to go faster and further with the European Union following behind.

name: Simona Bonafè
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, allow me first of all to thank the rapporteur, Mrs Auken, for the determined work she has done in recent months.  What we are bringing home today, after a negotiation that has been going on for some time and which has been unblocked under the Italian Presidency, as has been mentioned, is a very important measure that goes beyond its specific merit, which is, as we mentioned, to force the Member States to reduce the use of light plastic bags, which are considered to be one of the factors of pollution in general and the first factor in the pollution of the sea.  But it takes on an aspect, let me say, symbolic in my opinion. Because? If European waste legislation has been set at '4 R', which is the basis for proper and effective sustainable management, the first 'R', the reduction of waste production, has not always worked. On the contrary, we have data in Europe which, after the crisis, show us that the quantities of waste have increased in recent years, not least because of the inability to implement serious prevention policies. This measure starts from there, that is, for the first time we are going to act on the first level of the waste hierarchy, we are going to tell the States that they must reduce waste production with a mandatory target with the introduction of a price.  I now move on to the other key point of the measure. With this directive, the European Union is equips itself with an important instrument to advance the circular economy, the new frontier of the sustainable economy. The new rules, through the reduction of waste, in this case light potato bags, go at the same time to promote a more effective and efficient use of resources with a positive impact on the entire economy. In fact, we move from products of simple use, disposable, typical of a linear economy, to the need instead of finding alternative solutions, less impactful for resources and the environment and that also stimulate new green technologies, for example the green chemistry supply chain, to the production and research on organic bags, one of the virtuous challenges of the green economy.  I will end by saying that this is an important process that must go ahead, as we undertake to do as soon as possible with the new, more ambitious proposal that the Commission will present on the waste cycle.

name: Julie Girling
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur. I welcomed the Commission proposal when it was first launched, as I believe absolutely that we need to tackle the issue of plastic waste, particularly plastic bags, in the environment. The Commission proposal, when it came, was relatively flexible and it set out a variety of options for Member States to pursue, but as a result of amendments here, the final agreement lacks flexibility and contains a number of overly prescriptive and, in my view, potentially unworkable requirements. I cannot support the requirement for the adoption of a label for biodegradable and home-compostable bags without an impact assessment, given the possible additional administrative burden for the Member States and economic operators. There are certain provisions which I believe would have been better addressed in the context of the follow-up to the Commission Green Paper on plastic waste, such as the report on the use of oxo-biodegradable bags. I have concerns that the possibility to vary the measures taken towards plastic bags, based on their environmental impact or other properties, could be problematic as regards the principle of non-discrimination and proportionality, as well as the possible impact on the smooth functioning of the single market. Should Member States opt to achieve the reduction target in the ‘either/or’ scenario, they would need to meet the levels predetermined by the directive. I cannot support this approach, as these levels were set in the absence of statistical consumption data for all Member States. Lastly, Mrs Auken has said that we need to do something because countries are not doing it themselves. This is patently not the case because, whilst all of this was going on, my own Member State was objecting to the lack of flexibility but, at the same time, putting forward its own measures for reducing plastic bags, which are in fact now statute. So it simply is not the case that if Europe does not do it, Member States will not: they do, and they do it at their own pace, and that is the best way to do legislation.

name: Gerben-Jan Gerbrandy
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, even in the most remote places of this planet, hardly any seabird is being found without plastic in its stomach. This is plastic that is not being digested, plastic that is often toxic. We all know that plastic bags are one of the major causes of this huge plastic pollution, and many of these birds, fish, turtles and other marine animals have fragments of the 100 billion European plastic bags that we use annually in their stomachs.  But despite these devastating figures there is good news. Actually, there are two parts this. First of all, this huge environmental problem is relatively easy to solve and, secondly, there is huge public support for the measures to solve this problem. Therefore, the result that we are discussing today is, I think, an example of very good European policy-making. We have seen a strongly united European Parliament, thanks to a very good rapporteur, Ms Auken – whom I thank – but also because we had a Presidency, Italy, that was not just focusing on avoiding problems between Member States but that actually wanted to solve a problem, which is, unfortunately, something rather unique from the Council side. Contrary to what some people within the Commission might think – and I do not mean you, Commissioner Vella – this legislation will be seen in the future as one of the European Union’s best achievements of the last couple of years.

name: Eleonora Forenza
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to say that despite unacceptable pressure from the lobbies representing producers and distributors and despite the Indifference of the Commission that the rapporteur previously condemned, we have managed to reach an agreement that will make it possible, in the coming years, to reduce the consumption and use of light plastic bags, acting in three directions that I would like to highlight here: mandatory reduction targets for Member States, price actions and a marketing ban. For this result, we would like to thank the rapporteur, Margrete Auken, very much for this result.   Reducing the overconsumpation of plastic bags is a contribution to changing the way we buy and consume in Europe, in short, we are countering disposable Europe. In recent years, we have actually pushed gue for even stricter legislation than an agreement that has been reached here, aimed at eliminating 50% of the consumption of plastic bags within three years in order to reach 100% within five years.  Furthermore, there is no ban on oxo-biodegradable additives in the text, the danger of which we continue to denounce. In short, as is often the case with urgent environmental issues, we are still responding too long. At the same time, the compromise reached contains one fundamental element for us: the obligation for Member States to monitor the state of implementation of the legislation on the basis of a common methodology and controls entrusted to the European Commission.  Let me say one thing in conclusion: I believe that it is essential to involve environmental movements in this monitoring. In recent years we have learned how conflicts for environmental justice are fundamental to a fairer Europe.

name: Michèle Rivasi
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would first like to warmly congratulate my fellow Danish Ecologist, Margrete Auken, rapporteur of this text for Parliament, for the quality of the negotiations and for the results achieved. Today we will vote on the new European strategy to reduce plastic bags for the next adoption by our Assembly. It is true that these bags can take up to four centuries before they begin to degrade, and the oceans are asphyxiated by their particles. Composed, in particular, of petroleum-based polyethylenes, plastic bags are a wound to the environment, as has been said, a real poison, and major measures had to be taken to curb this massive pollution. It is now done. There will, indeed, be a reduction: today, 200 plastic bags are consumed per capita; this figure will rise to 90 by 2019 and 40 in ten years. Then we will end the free plastic bags for food by 2018. The task has not been easy, as too often when it comes to protecting our health and our ecosystem, water being at the heart of the problem we are addressing today. But we could have gone further, because, as they say in French, the devil hides in the details. I am talking about the so-called oxobiodegradable bags, as my colleague mentioned. In reality, they are not biodegradable: they fragment into millions of microparticles and they increase the risk at the level of ecosystems. This means, Commissioner, that tomorrow, when you eat oysters, you will find microparticles in these oysters and in the water they contain. The Commission could have gone much further by banning, precisely, these so-called oxobiodegradable bags. You did not do that and you preferred to focus on the interests of a particular niche rather than preventing this pollution that will affect biodiversity.

name: Eleonora Evi
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we have reached the final stage of this decision-making process, which has been much more difficult and impervious than I imagined.  I was very impressed at the time by the alarming data that emerged from reading the impact assessment of the measure, especially with regard to the damage caused by plastic bags and their fragments to marine habitats and fauna, as has already been mentioned several times. However, I was equally impressed, given the seriousness and urgency of the phenomenon, to note the absolute incongruity of the Commission's proposal, without any clear constraint on the reduction of shoppers.  Mrs Auken's difficult task has been to introduce concrete elements to the proposal and, thanks to her work, a text has resulted which, although imperfect and improveable, is probably the best that could be achieved, not least in the light of the Commission's difficult and uncooperative attitude on this dossier. For these reasons, I confirm today that the Italian delegation of the EFDD Group will support the motion to close the agreement concluded with the Council.

name: Olaf Stuger (NI).
text: In its wisdom, the Commission has decided to appoint a special Commissioner for better regulation. It is still a Vice-President, Mr Timmermans. Better regulation is needed, because the Dutch taxpayer was perplexed when he heard that the EU is concerned with the amount of cinnamon in cinnamon buns, the length of ladders and – yes – the curvature of bananas. We were therefore very pleased to hear from Mr Timmermans that he wanted to scrap the regulations on plastic bags. Rightly so, because that is another typical pointless and hopeless measure. It is now clear that Mr Timmermans has already called back the best action in his first action. In doing so, he degrades himself as Mr Juncker's 'interpreter-translator', but the highest paid interpreter-translator there is. Mr President, this shows all the more that this Commission is on the wrong track. Many promises, but little to live up to in practice. Normally I would call to ... (The Speaker is interrupted by the President.)

name: Peter Liese (PPE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has I would like to thank all those who have contributed to this compromise on plastic bags, the rapporteur, Margrete Auken, and– in the Group of the European People's Party – György Hölvényi, who, as a new member but with a great deal of experience in national politics and other areas, has conducted the negotiations for the EPP. We have a real problem, a big problem. There is a plastic carpet in the Pacific Ocean that is three times the size of the Iberian Peninsula. We have also spoken about it personally. What we are going to decide today – hopefully by a large majority – is a first step towards tackling this problem. I also see in very specific discussions with the citizens that people perceive this and that they see it positively, that we are dealing with this problem. We are setting clear guidelines for the reduction of plastic bags, but I also think it is right that we should leave the resources to the Member States and that we should not impose a European ban. I am also relying on incentives where the Member States still have to take decisions. Ireland and the Scandinavian countries have managed to dramatically reduce the number of plastic bags by means of economic means, without bans, but with incentives. In any case, that would be my recommendation that the Member States, which are now considering how to implement these requirements, should not rely on bans, but on market-based means. We must take further steps, and I hope that the European Commission, you, Commissioner Vella, but also the Vice-President concerned will also have the problem of plastic waste in mind when you present us with an improved proposal on the circular economy in the autumn. After all, it is not only the light plastic bags that contribute to the problems in the world's oceans, but also elsewhere. We are eagerly awaiting what the Commission will present to us. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. – In fact, several speakers in this debate, but Also Mr Liese, have generally said what is expected of the Member States, and he has also said that they have also spoken to consumers. However, here in this Parliament, we cannot get stuck at the level of generalities, and I would respectfully ask The Member what steps he finds necessary, in particular with regard to reducing consumption, and therefore on the consumer side, because it is generally difficult to deal with, even at the level of the debate.

name: Peter Liese (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Thank you for the question! You are often approached when you are in the shop and say, "I don't want a plastic bag." We politicians should also be role models. Many sellers then say, "Yes, this should actually be banned." But that suggests that we are also addressing the problem we are raising on behalf of the people. Nevertheless, I believe that systems such as those in Ireland, where a fee has been levied for light plastic bags, or deposit schemes, are more appropriate than the ban. We still have the choice. But the results are being achieved. Ireland, for example, has impressive figures.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D).
text: – Madam President; Commissioner, the directive we will adopt in Parliament today is much more than an effective instrument for erasing from our environmental memory the terrible photograph of the sea watered by plastic. It is true that the image is striking at sea, but also on earth, where every bag that is poured takes no more and no less than 150 years to disappear. If plastic revolutionized our production and consumption model years ago, now the model change we have pending is that of the circular economy. And so we have a new challenge, a new revolution to make. That is why we said that this directive is more than an instrument, it is an emblematic example of how to achieve the transition to more sustainable production, in which, from design to waste, more environmentally friendly materials are chosen, alternatives are shether alternatives are sned, if contaminated and reuse and responsible collection are encouraged. We think it is a success to sort the bags according to their weight and their use. The temporary permanence of such bags will help to achieve the desired transition, but the Commission must ensure that alternative materials can be developed on a large scale. Going from 200 to 40 bags per person on the 2025 horizon is our goal. If it were achieved, it means that we have also managed to turn the system around and bet on a new production model. It will be an effort for countries and consumers, but the benefit will be extended to the entire planet.

name: Marcus Pretzell (ECR).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for The figures on the use of plastic bags in the European Union are indeed alarming. The reasons why this should no longer be the case in the future are also obvious. We have an excessive waste of raw materials at this point, an unnecessary waste of energy, far too little lifespan and, in addition, poor recyclability, and then experience the result, particularly in the world's oceans. All this cries out for sensible regulation, for reasonable targets and for measures. That is why the approach at this point is absolutely right, to reduce the use of plastic bags with wall thicknesses of less than 50 microns in the European Union. However, it is also inadequate and opens a back door, which may be counterproductive as a result, because we will see manufacturers turning to plastic bags of more than 50 microns, so that more resources are wasted, more energy is wasted and, ultimately, even more plastic waste will be disposed of in the environment.

name: Catherine Bearder (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, every year more than eight billion plastic bags end up as litter in Europe. Not only do these plastic bags blight our countryside, but they blight our rivers and seas. They are deadly for seabirds, fish, seals, dolphins and other marine animals.  The only way we can tackle this shared issue is by taking action across Europe. Now we can dramatically curb disposable plastic bags right across the EU. The average use of around 200 plastic bags per person will reduce to about 40 by 2025. This is a huge step forward, leading to cleaner oceans and less suffering for marine wildlife. Yet, time and again, Conservative MEPs have refused to back these targets. In the UK, Liberal Democrats fought hard in government, against the Conservatives, to ensure a 5p tax on plastic bags, coming in this year, and here in the European Parliament Conservative MEPs have shown their true colours by not supporting these much-needed EU limits. This shows how weak the Conservative commitment to environmental protection is. Cutting wasteful bag use must start now. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Julie Girling (ECR)
text: blue-card question. – Could I ask Mrs Bearder if she believes that the proposal before us now is better, and will be more effective in the UK, than the proposal put before, and voted for in, the UK Parliament – and supported by the Liberal Democrats – for the reduction of plastic bags in the UK?

name: Catherine Bearder (ALDE)
text: blue-card answer. – Yes, the proposal here is a pan—European proposal which leaves it to the countries to deliver what they feel is best to reduce plastic bag use. In the UK it was the Liberal Democrats, in their manifesto, who delivered in Government a 5p tax. It will be different in different countries. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Michèle Rivasi (Verts/ALE)
text: "blue card" question. Madam President, Mrs Bearder, you who are sensitive to the environment, what is your position on the fact that we have not banned the use of oxobiodegradable plastic bags? We prohibit what is seen, but what is not visible is not prohibited because there are economic issues.

name: Catherine Bearder (ALDE)
text: blue-card answer. – The use of biodegradable plastic bags is a problem. I do not know that we have sorted it here, but what happens is that, if the biodegradable ones get into the recycled waste stream, they corrupt that waste cycle. So I think we may need to come back and look again at biodegradable plastic bags. I do not think they should be used as shopping bags, quite frankly.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, I agree with the concept of introducing taxes to reduce the consumption of plastic bags. It has been introduced in my Member State, the Republic of Ireland, to great effect.  However, the other side of the argument must also be looked at. What has it driven us to use? It has driven us to use more paper bags rather than go down the road of using reusable bags, and it is important to point out that paper production causes 70 % more air pollution. It consumes more energy, it consumes more water, and it is more inefficient in recycling.  I found it very interesting earlier to hear one MEP say that we need to come up with or invent an alternative. Well I have news for you. My grandmother already knew of this alternative, it was called a hemp twine bag. I think she used about three of them in the 70 years of her life. We already have invented it. Do not reinvent the wheel.  On the point that, if Member States are not forced to implement something they will not do it, the way I feel about it is this: if you force Member States to do something they will not do it right. You do something because you want to do it. Leave it up to the Member States. We are proof of that.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (EFDD).
text: – The use of plastic bags is constantly increasing. In just one minute, about a million people in the world consume them. This poses a serious threat to the environment and to people, and we cannot delay. Firstly, the new rules and measures to reduce the use of plastic bags must not only be ambitious, but also have a real positive environmental impact. Environmental sustainability needs to be made economically beneficial to people. Secondly, realistic and measurable results will only be achieved if the reduction targets set are based on real consumption data. Therefore, a methodology for the accounting of lightweight plastic bags should be developed in the European Union before binding targets are set for reducing the use of plastic bags, otherwise we will not achieve the result. Thirdly, a charge for plastic bags can be a good solution to the problem. However, in no case may disguised charges be applied for their use, which would be included in the price of the product. The transition to the new taxation cannot be drastic. At the same time, we need to promote the use of alternative instruments.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The devastating effects of our plastic consumption on the environment– especially for the world's oceans – have long been known. I therefore welcome today's move to reduce one of the main causes of this pollution. Nevertheless, it must be stressed that it can only be a step, albeit in the right direction. Taxation and quotas are not, after all, a real barrier that can prevent plastic bags with a rotting period of up to 500 years from entering our environment. In the long term, therefore, we must abandon these non-reusable plastic bags, regardless of the planned intermediate steps such as a deposit solution or taxes on them – as we say in Austria – "Sackerl". Our aim must be the complete switch to biodegradable plastic bags, and we must also consider whether we want to tackle this plastic packaging inflation in PET bottles and plastic products in any other way. In other words, research must be stepped up and consumers and industrial suppliers must be held accountable. But this is especially true in the Member States.

name: Pilar Ayuso (PPE).
text: – Madam President; Commissioner, plastic bags, as has already been said here, are the source of many environmental problems, especially at sea. In recent years, Member States and the undertakings concerned have made considerable efforts to reduce stock market consumption and many of them have taken steps to reduce their consumption. This Directive aims to give the countries of the European Union certain tools to prevent the generation of this type of waste, including by prohibiting the free delivery of shopping bags. In my country they are already charged in most supermarkets and I assure you that it is an effective measure. I also welcome the allow for exceptions for thinner bags. These bags are indispensable for the bulk sale of perishable food products, making it a good decision for hygiene and food safety reasons, and these also prevent the dispersion of food waste. Its replacement, if decided, must be done by carefully calibrating the advantages and disadvantages, in addition to the replacement materials. I would like to congratulate the rapporteur very warmly on the work she has done, and all the rapporteurs for the great fruit they have gained from the negotiations with the Council, and for getting us to vote here today with broad consensus.

name: Karin Kadenbach (S&D).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has Very often, as Members of Parliament, we have the great problem of communicating our decisions, of making it clear to the people why we want something. This time, I believe, it is simply because we are finally fulfilling a great desire of Europeans. More than 78% of Europeans were and are in favour of reducing this flood of nylon bags – plastic carrier bags, as we call them. In Austria, too, 73% of the population voted in favour of banning them in general. Here we now have a first step in this direction, namely to reduce once and, above all, to create awareness, both in the retail sector and among consumers. Because very often it is a very thoughtless takeaway from a offered sackerl. "Do S' a Sackerl need?" "Yes, please! Plug in." I can only encourage each of us not to throw away all these plastic bags for a while, but to collect and see how quickly a huge mountain of plastic has accumulated at home. If we then continue to think that this mountain usually takes 400 years to disintegrate – it is not gone yet, it is still present, only decay – then that is a very high price for these 15 or 30 minutes of comfort to transport something home. I am convinced that we need very flexible regulations here. We have a very different landscape in Europe, in the EU. Consumption of 200 to 400 plastic bags on average per European and per European – this is far apart. I assume that the pressure from the population will continue to be strong in the future and that we will also have a general ban on these plastic bags, these plastic bags, in the foreseeable future.

name: James Nicholson (ECR).
text: – Madam President, at the launch of the Commission’s 2015 Work Programme, Jean-Claude Juncker said he wanted to see an EU that is bigger and more ambitious on big things and smaller and more modest on small things. I fear the Directive we are debating today is an example of the EU being far too big and overly ambitious on the small things. As an item used nearly every day in households across Europe, plastic bags could not be any smaller. The underlying principle of reducing environmental damage from discarded plastic bags is, of course, one we can all support. Yet the measures to be introduced in the second reading agreement, while an improvement on the first, risk being overly prescriptive and potentially unworkable. Mandatory reduction targets, without adequate data, do not take into account the huge disparities in the rates of consumption between Member States. In my own constituency, we reduced the amount of plastic bags dispensed by retailers by 72% after the introduction of a 5p carrier bag levy: leave it to the Member States.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE).
text: Madam President, sometimes a few figures are better than a long speech: a plastic bag is 5 seconds of production, 5 minutes of use and up to 500 years of decomposition. That is to say the importance of the compromise we are talking about here, which has been found between Parliament and the Council to discourage their use. Practically 20, therefore, Member States will have a choice: reduce the number of lightweight plastic bags used per person each year - no more than 40 bags by 2025 - or stop giving them away free of charge in stores by 2018. That's reasonable. Unfortunately, given the disparities that exist in Europe - 4 plastic bags per consumer per year in Finland, for example, compared to 400 in Poland or Portugal - this is probably reasonable but unsustainable, and I regret that. It will take ten years in total to do, in the end, worse than the best students in the class. Frankly, Europe can do better and it needs to do better. When I say 'Europe', I am well understood, I am talking about the Member States lagging behind, which could usefully draw inspiration from good practices from the North. Not just from the North, for that matter, because, as we have heard, the good students are in Ireland and the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg, among others.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, I have put forward a proposal to reject this directive on the prohibition of plastic bags in shops. This gives you a unique opportunity to let people decide voluntarily what they will take away their purchase by voting. Please don't underestimate people's ability to make decisions. People recycle when it's rational. I take a paper bag from the store when I need a paper waste container. If I need a plastic waste container, I'll take a plastic bag.  What do you think happens when you ban plastic bags? People will take more microtene bags, people will have to buy more rolls of plastic waste packaging if they don't get them as bags in stores. I very much hope that you who want to ban plastic bags never take a plastic bag in the store. Because if you're marrying her and you want to ban others, you're just hypocrites.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, a superficial look at this text aimed at reducing the consumption of plastic bags should lead us to adopt it unanimously. Yet on closer inspection, it is less akin to a compromise than to an optical illusion of which the European Union is customary.  We focus our efforts on one detail so as not to question the system, we enact a cosmetic directive on certain plastic bags, at the same time encouraging more transport and more international interdependence. First, these are provisions that apply to a small sample of packaging, with no overall vision. Thus, the ban on certain bags will generate the proliferation of questionable alternative packaging, as is already seen in many shops.  On the other hand, nations are under the control of the Commission on a new, to the very smallest, chapter. It is therefore an emblematic text of an ultra-legislative European Union, without regard for the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the fact is that this has become a global problem and that the use of plastic bags is a symbol of consumer society. It is good that the European Union has now reached an agreement between the Council, the Commission and Parliament, although Parliament clearly dealt with this more and obviously Parliament had more sensitivity than the Commission. What I'm trying to say is that it's not the old Indian one: "We borrowed this land from our heirs," so since we borrowed it from the heirs, we have to treat it that way.  This is very important and therefore plastic bags are really becoming a huge problem and I think it is a good directive that allows Member States to make the situation in their area in the best possible way. I like this initiative more about incentives than about bans because we have proof in countries like Ireland, scandinavian countries that incentives have come to a result. When it comes to plastic bags in Croatia, then I am concerned about the state of our rivers, especially the state of our Adriatic Sea.  Here I want to point out, I have said this several times, and today I want to repeat, the problem of plastic bags that come with sea currents through the Adriatic Sea from Albania to Croatian beaches and the Croatian sea. So in addition to endangering the environment, we are also endangering the economy, because we are coming into a vicious circle, which is our tourism. And so I think we need to find a way to solve this problem with countries that are not members of the European Union.  (The Speaker accepts to answer the question posed by raising the blue card (Article 162(8) of the E.S. Rules of Procedure))

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – I would like to ask you about this topic that you eventually talked about, about cross-border pollution coming to the coast of Croatia from Albania and through the Neretva River from Bosnia and Herzegovina. Do you think, as I think, that the European Commission, in negotiations with the Republic of Albania, which is a candidate country but also with Bosnia and Herzegovina, should certainly make it one of the further conditions of progress, the address of this issue of cross-border pollution coming through the Adriatic, in negotiations with Albania and Bosnia and Herzegovina?

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – Thank you, Mr. Jakovcic, for this question. Since the Adriatic is a semi-sealed sea, I think it is very important that all countries that gravitate to the Adriatic have the same regulations. The fact is that not all countries are members of the European Union, here I especially emphasize Bosnia and Herzegovina and Albania, but also Montenegro. However, she solves this problem of her own.  That is why we will insist, I have repeatedly said this in the Environmental Protection Committee, that these details must be entered into the negotiating chapters and it is very important that we have the same rules because unless we care equally we will not protect the sea equally.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D).
text: – Madam Chairman, most people don't think about plastic bags when they put things in them in the store or when they're piling them up in the kitchen. I believe most of you in the house have one drawer that's overcrowded with bags like that. These are the ones that are not in the environment, but the vast majority of them end up in nature. They pollute forests, rivers, float on the seas, and the next time you're disgusted at a bag floating next to you, remember that you had a chance to do something about it.  The figure of 8 billion discarded bags a year at European Union level is truly frightening and commits to action. This directive asks member states to reduce the consumption of thin pay bags. The document prescribes measures, objectives, deadlines but takes into account the results of the Member States so far. My country, for example, has lower consumption of plastic bags than a lot of other Member States, and therefore such an approach is welcome. In my view, an acceptable compromise has been reached in the negotiations to ensure that the consumption of thin plastic bags is reduced. Member States have the possibility to choose how to achieve this objective, allowing them to adapt the measures to their specificities. This is the first time in 14 years that binding measures have been put in place at European Union level to reduce waste generation and we must certainly welcome this.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has This morning, on the way to the European Parliament along the canal, I saw three of them – plastic bags on the shore, in the water. Recycling rate equals zero. This makes disposal into the environment all the more frequent. There, the problem has long been global and can no longer be hidden under the surface of the water. I would like to make this more precise: hundreds of thousands of tonnes of plastic waste are polluting the world's oceans. Well over 140 million tonnes of plastic waste are stored there. Up to 13 million tonnes are added each year. Many already speak of the seventh continent, 3.4 million km2 in size, in the middle of the Pacific Ocean between California and Hawaii, larger than India, and it consists exclusively of plastic waste. I keep telling my children that they are not allowed to pull these plastic bags over their heads, but that's exactly how many marine animals end up. It is good that we in Europe are now tackling this plague of marsupials. Let us make methods for the recovery and recovery of plastic waste our task. Let us conquer the seventh continent and let us relieve the environment. I think we need to talk about this much more regularly.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI).
text: – The excessive use of lightweight plastic carry-on bags causes serious pollution of the environment in all EU countries. The number is a deterrent. 8 billion of these carrybases end up in the trash every year, so regulation is needed. The legislation should also be supported because it is a directive, it will be transposed into their own legal order by the Member States themselves and, moreover, it leaves a number of possibilities as to how that Member State will carry out this task. I consider it particularly important to combat false labelling. The name oxidative, biodegradable plastic case is completely misleading because, in fact, after decomposition into microparticles, it can cause even more serious environmental pollution. It is clear that the best solution would be to use a plastic bag that is truly biodegradable and compostable.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE).
text: – Madam President; Commissioner, when we talk about reducing the consumption of plastic bags we are talking about improving our environment, legislating to leave a better planet for our children. It may not seem like an interesting debate at first glance, but it is, as it affects millions of Europeans every day and will have a direct impact on our day-to-day lives. After years of battle, we came to the door of an agreement for the reduction of plastic bags, an important and necessary agreement to advance the improvement of our environment, since – as the Commission's own information campaign says and has also been said here today – it takes five minutes to produce a plastic bag that will be used for five minutes , but it will take 500 years to disappear. Given the disparity in situations in the different Member States, I believe that the possibility given to them to decide between reducing this consumption to 40 bags per person per year by 2025, or paying for the consumption of these bags, which must come into force by the end of 2018 is important. However, you have to be vigilant to get real changes in customs that bring us to the target. And I agree with Mr Flanagan: our grandmothers could give us great lessons without so much talk. In Catalonia we have been working to achieve this goal since 2007, with really hopeful results, because in 2012 we already achieved a reduction of 54% and we have set out to reach the reduction of 33 bags per person per year by 2020. I would not like to end without first congratulating the rapporteur, Mrs Auken, as well as the shadow rapporteurs, on the extraordinary work done. (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: the blue card. – In fact, I have the impression that the only way to reduce the use of plastic bags is to not give them free of charge. Do you think it would not be the most effective tool for us to consider from when to do this? From 2015, or from 2016, or from 2018, or from 2020? How do you think?

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: "blue card" response. – MrRopo, cashing in bags is an alternative, but the good alternative is one that helps European citizens change their mindset when consuming plastic bags.

name: Jo Leinen (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Commissioner Vella, you are also responsible for maritime policy. I can only repeat that many of the plastic bags end up in the waters, first in the rivers, then in the seas. We have these gigantic waste carpets in the Pacific Ocean – my colleague has even talked about a seventh continent. We know that this plastic material is very durable and that it also has a diabolical characteristic: the fish believe it is food, they swallow all the stuff, die or get sick. There is therefore a great need for action to reduce this plastic flood. I would also say that plastic bags can no longer be delivered free of charge in the European Union. It must be a must to pay for it if you want to have a plastic bag and perhaps need it. There may also be ways of banning parts of it because we have alternatives. In other areas of legislation, we are also doing the same by banning the worse methods and making the better ones possible. I thank Mrs Margarete Auken. It has remained true to Parliament's objectives. That was not easy in the trialogue. The Commission even wanted to withdraw the dossier. It is good that we have this result, a good law. Commissioner Vella, it is now up to you to implement the whole thing.

name: David Campbell Bannerman (ECR).
text: – Madam President, much of the debate around this report has been characterised by an unjust, misinformed attack on oxo—biodegradable plastics technology, which has a considerable contribution to make in the battle against excessive plastic bag littering, which is something we would all like to stop. This innovative technology has been driven by a company in my East of England constituency with 30 dedicated employees. As one of the local MEPs, I applaud the work they have done and recognise the potential for thousands of jobs in the future. Yet, while this technology has vast potential, the report’s rapporteur has given in to rival Italian vested interests resting on hydro-biodegradable technology, which has simply sought to eliminate a competitor from the market. We should proceed on the basis of independently produced, solid, scientific evidence, not misinformed smears. Thanks to the tireless work by my ECR colleagues, the Commission and Council saw sense. The finalised directive rightly refuses to ban oxo—biodegradable technology and calls on the Commission to conduct a proper scientific study. We must await its outcome and not rush to judgement. (The speaker agreed to take two blue-card questions under Rule 162(8))

name: John Stuart Agnew (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Madam President, this is a little unusual: this is a friendly question, because I also represent the same constituency as Mr Campbell Bannerman and I do not think that I am going to be able to speak under ‘catch the eye’, so I am going to give him the opportunity to say a little bit more, if he wants to, for the firm Symphony (I think it is) in Hertfordshire, so on you go. Isn’t that unusual for people to cooperate?

name: President. –
text: That is unusual, but I would say that the blue cards are there to put questions. You did not ask any questions, so I will give the floor straight away to Ms Auken and then Mr Agnew will have 30 seconds to answer.

name: Margrete Auken (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card question. – Here we have had an illustration of what the problem was with oxo—degradable plastics. Symphony is a UK firm and we wanted to keep the Council together. That was why we did not go down the direct route, despite having proof that oxo—degradable is worse than nothing. Now, at least, we have the Commission investigating this. I would ask my colleague whether he is in favour of a clear investigation and, if it shows that oxo—degradable is worse and the plastics industry is against it, whether he will then – as I hope – support us to get rid of it?

name: David Campbell Bannerman (ECR)
text: blue-card answer. – As I say, what I am arguing for is that we have a proper scientific study and let us see how it works. I am convinced – and knowing it from the constituency – that this is a very good technology that will help us address this pollution problem. I am afraid there is a lot of unscientific abuse being used against this company and the technology. Let us look at the facts rather than relying on these prejudices.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI). Madam President, today we are discussing plastic carrier bags and how to limit their use, which has brought a great environmental burden. First of all, we consider this report to be a step in the right direction, but unfortunately it is not enough. Especially on the issue of so-called 'self-breaking plastic bags', I think the measures we want to take are inadequate. Some were treasured for promoting the material as supposedly environmentally friendly, at the same time as causing terrible ecological damage. I therefore believe that we should propose a total ban on their use. My view is that we need to move towards banning thin and very thin plastic bags, keeping only those that are thick enough to be reusable. In fact, I believe that the consumer should pay a price for their acquisition, a practice that is already in place in some countries of the Union. As far as their replacement is concerned, we must return to the use of paper bags, and exclusively recyclable. This is probably neither so convenient nor economically advantageous, but we must also be willing to make sacrifices to protect the environment, because the future consequences will be disastrous for the whole planet if we continue to apply today's practice.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna Łukacijewska (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I think that this directive is one of the few that, despite the slight differences of opinion here in this House, has the support of all political groups. We all notice the problem. I agree with everyone, or most of my colleagues, who have said how many plastic bags we put into circulation every year. These are billions! How long does it take to decompose these bags? A minute takes the purchase, without thinking we throw away the bag, and its distribution runs for several hundred years. Environmental pollution, the effects on fauna and flora are absolutely catastrophic and it is good that we are struggling to solve or try to solve this problem.  I am pleased that, in fact, this payment, which they are introducing, whether introduced by the Member States, has resulted in less distribution or a reduction in the distribution of plastic bags. I am also pleased that this directive will give further tool to the Member States, and I hope that they will be ambitious in achieving the objectives. On the other hand, I will not agree with those who believe that this price is the most important argument of the restriction. I think it is very important that we – parents – educate our young children, educate them, make them aware of the environmental impact, change civic attitudes. If you have a choice of a plastic bag and a bag made of flax or paper, we reach for these other packaging.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D). Madam President, according to calculations, 99 billion plastic bags were used in the European Union in 2010. This figure translates to 200 bags per person. The majority of them are so-called thin plastic bags, which we see mainly in supermarkets and in shops. Since most of the time these bags are not reused, the environmental burden is significant, especially for aquatic ecosystems. With this Directive, the necessary amendments are made to waste legislation in order to limit the consequences for the environment. Parliament called on the authority to set specific targets for reducing the use of thin plastic bags.  With the agreement reached, Member States have two options and can either take appropriate measures to reduce annual consumption to 90 per person by the end of 2019 and 40 by 2025, or prohibit their supply at points of sale of goods and products by the end of 2018 at the latest.  I welcome and support this agreement and believe that today we are lay the foundations for tackling a very important source of contamination.

name: Renata Briano (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, today we are talking about the circular economy and we are taking an important step forward in reducing disposable platic bags.  The Member States now have precise rules to implement. Last year Italy introduced a ban on the free marketing and sale of plastic bags, producing significant results, but it is now necessary to pursue more ambitious results, which can really be monitored in the context of policies of prevention of waste and incentive to recycle, with adequate governance tools and support for industrial research and widespread actions of education.  The dispersion of plastic waste has devastating effects in terrestrial environments and especially in marine environments, just think of the huge accumulation of floating garbage, called "Pacific trash vortex", which has formed in the Pacific Ocean since the 1950s. Estimates of its extent vary from two to thirty times the size of Italy. Acting now is not a discretionary choice, but it is an obligation because, it is always good to remind us, children look at us.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: I don't take any more blue cards from people who have had one before, because I have to see that I get through with time to the polls. I ask for your understanding. I have already made ten requests for the catch-the-eye procedure that follows. However, I shall only take one per group. Catch-the-eye procedure

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that this is a great success for Parliament, Commissioner, because, as you know, during the trialogue that I had the pleasure of chairing as chairman of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy, we managed to reach an agreement with the rapporteur and the Council.  A deal that looks far away. The Commission has not always acted as a facilitator, and you are well aware that there was a debate in committee on whether to withdraw this proposal in the end or to keep it on the table, just as there are comments at the end of the text put forward by the Commission on the applicability of the rule. However, it was certainly an important agreement reached by the co-legislators, as provided for in the current Treaty of Lisbon.  We have acted in the interests of the environment by seeking the solution that some European countries have already adopted and which seems to be going well. Today we have targets on plastic bags, we have targets, we have new technologies and we ban and remove those that do not seem the best for maintaining the environment.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, reducing the consumption of light plastic bags is an objective that the European Union must pursue as a matter of priority.  The context in which this measure matures is worrying. In 2010, it was estimated that every European citizen used 198 plastic bags, mostly light and not easily reusable. I believe that the agreement reached by Parliament – and I therefore congratulate the rapporteur, Mrs Auken, on her excellent work – represents an essential improvement on the Commission's proposal and should therefore be supported. The inclusion of mandatory reduction targets and the obligation to charge for plastic bags are measures that significantly strengthen EU rules aimed at reducing the use of plastic bags.  The text also has the merit of introducing an obligation for Member States to submit an annual report on the consumption of plastic bags of light material 36 months after the entry into force of the legislation. This strengthens existing reporting obligations and consequently the concrete instruments available to Member States to monitor and assess the effectiveness of the measures taken.

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR).
text: – Look at the enormous damage that is being done in our maritime environment and then we all understand that the use of lightweight plastic bags must be limited. At present, there are major differences between Member States. Flanders, the region I represent, can produce good results. Since 2003, the use of plastic bags has decreased by more than 80 percent. We are therefore part of the leading group, but there is still room for improvement and a European objective also offers benefits for leaders, such as a clearly predictable legal framework, the creation of a level playing field and the protection and improvement of the environment for all EU citizens. The text also gives the necessary flexibility to the Member States. This measure as patronising labels smells of populism. The huge plastic mountain presents us with environmental challenges that require a broad approach. The upcoming review of the waste package offers an opportunity to take further structural measures to make the transition to a circular economy that deals more efficiently with raw materials.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, Croatia is a relatively small consumer of lightweight plastic bags by population when it comes to the average in Europe. However, I want to emphasize that Croatia is a big manufacturer of lightweight plastic bags and this of course creates certain problems for us, because we will lose our proper jobs and all that it carries. In fact, I'll even say that in the 1980s I worked in an industry like that. I was very close and today I am very close to this industry and I must say that I will certainly not advocate this industry here, but will advocate this very discussion, because lightweight plastic bags have proven to be a serious environmental problem. And that is why I want to emphasize once again the serious problem we have on the Adriatic Sea.  I hope that it will not turn into a carpet like it is in the Pacific, but we have a problem of cross-border pollution from Albania and Bosnia and Herzegovina and I ask you as a Commission to help in negotiations with Albania and Bosnia and Herzegovina.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE).
text: – First, of course, congratulations to Mrs Auken on the persistence and pervasiveness of this report and, of course, for the excellent report itself. Plastic bags are, of course, a great habitat for consumers and, on the other hand, an exceptional advertising space for traders. Therefore, of course, these measures, which are provided for in the directives, may probably be a little more difficult to achieve in the directives and targets than we think. Above all, there's something to know. If people and consumers knew what the consequences of dumped plastic were, they would certainly have acted differently. Therefore, of course, people need to be told the truth about plastic, and not therefore the plastic truth. I think the numbers are horrific. If 90 per cent of bags are used only once, it means that the waste is only accumulating and is actually bathed in plastic. And each country can do the most by raising awareness by persuading plastics to be harmful to the environment. I think that plastics can also mean material, including an option for a cyclical economy, and, of course, I recommend that the Commission reintroduce the cyclical economy project as a priority.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, I would like to thank you all for this debate and for the very constructive comments that you have all made.  A number of examples already mentioned, outlining the measures some Member States have taken to curb the use of lightweight plastic carrier bags, do prove that action is effective. As an example, Ms Auken mentioned Ireland. Another example is Scotland where early figures from retailers show that single-use carrier bag usage has fallen by more than 80% since a charge was introduced last October. These are just a few, and not the only Member States that have actually taken action.  Once this amendment to the Packaging and Packaging Waste Directive is adopted and has entered into force, Member States will have the tools available for effective action. They are responsible for the crucial task of implementation. The first step they have to take is to choose from among the instruments available to them to reduce the use of plastic carrier bags.  I would also like to add that this directive addresses a major problem at source from a preventive perspective, and I have to say that the more preventive action we take today the less remedial action we will need tomorrow – especially in terms of marine litter, as was mentioned several times by a number of the Members of this Parliament. As many also mentioned, marine litter is a huge environmental problem threatening mainly, but not only, our marine biodiversity. I would say that this is a global problem needing a global solution. Today we are only talking about the EU consumption of plastic bags but the problem is much bigger than that. I can assure everyone here that we will continue to take this problem very seriously and monitor it accordingly. The new directive also entrusts the Commission with a number of tasks, such as the development of a methodology for calculating the annual per capita consumption of lightweight plastic carrier bags, the development of labels or marks to ensure Union-wide recognition of biodegradable and compostable plastic carrier bags, and assessing the impact of the use of oxo-degradable plastic carrier bags on the environment. We will tackle these tasks without delay with a view to meeting the – frankly more than challenging – deadlines agreed in the compromise. The compromise reached is an important step forward in addressing the issue of plastic waste, endorsed by overwhelming public support. I think that, through this new directive, we can demonstrate that the EU is able to effectively respond to matters of concern to citizens as well.

name: Margrete Auken
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I very much hope that this will be our first victory over those in the Commission who are against the environment. I hope it will not be the last, although we might fear that, but this here should be our first.  It is a historic day as we managed to get so much support from this Parliament and the Member States in order to bring about a clear reduction. Flexibility is still built into it, although it is not as flexible as originally proposed by the Commission, which was the kind of flexibility where they did nothing but just hoped. I am strongly in favour of hope – I am a Christian – but I think sometimes that we need to do something. We are here not to hope but to do. That is what we will do now.  I am so happy that you promise to live up to the expectations in our proposal in order to achieve good figures. For instance, I think the figures from Denmark are far too optimistic. Just two days ago I had to decline five of these lightweight plastic bags which were just handed out to me. So I think the actual figures are much more than four annually per inhabitant, but they are still good figures and there is flexibility.  Again let me repeat here that we are not talking about a ban, because plastic bags can be reusable. We are talking about a reduction and if you put a price – not a tax, but a price – on each bag we know that the consumers will ask themselves whether they really need to pay 50 cents or whatever it might be and they might remember that they have pockets or bring their own bag with them. They might have a reusable plastic bag or a cotton bag. They are not that idiotic. It is good if they get into new habits. We have seen it.  I would like to thank everybody. This is historic. Let it not be the last victory for the environment in this Commission, but the first one.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: Thank you, rapporteur. Congratulations also from my side to all those who have contributed to this success. The debate is closed. The vote will take place today, 28 April, from 12.30 p.m. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. –  I support this report. Action to reduce the usage of plastic bags in Scotland by the SNP Government has already proven to be enormously successful, with figures at the end of 2014 showing a massive 90% reduction in plastic bag usage. Under these new rules, which I trust will be approved by MEPs, Member States would be able to choose between two policy options: to either take measures to ensure that average yearly consumption of these bags does not exceed 90 lightweight bags per citizen by 2019 and 40 by 2025, or alternatively, to ensure that, by 2018, they are not handed to shoppers free of charge. Plastic bags are not biodegradable and are especially harmful to marine animals. That is why targeted action is essential to making a difference, as Scotland’s experience proves. These measures will make many consumers get into the habit of reusing bags, which should reduce the amount of litter that blights our communities and natural environment, and costs a fortune to clean up. Scotland has raised over GBP1 million for charities as a result of the single-use carrier bag charge; I would be delighted to see this model replicated amongst EU retailers.

name: Claudiu Ciprian Tănăsescu (S&D)
text: in writing. – Plastic bags have a negative impact on the environment and human health. It is absolutely necessary that the Member States take action. Parliament considerably improved the Commission proposal, also leaving enough space for the Member States to act in order to curb the consumption of lightweight plastic carrier bags in the European Union. On the other hand, the consumers have to be aware how their specific behaviour impacts on the environment and public health before they decide to use or not plastic bags.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
