text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the recommendation for the second reading of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety on the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of the regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on the monitoring of carbon dioxide emissions from maritime transport, reporting on these and the examination of these emissions and amending Directive 2009/16/EC (17086/1/2014 - C8-0072/2015 - 2013/0224 (COD)) (Rapporteur: José Inscio Faria) (A8-0122/2015).

name: José Inácio Faria
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, Commissioner Arias Cañete, ladies and gentlemen, it is a pity that the Council is not present here in this important document.  The transport sector accounts for around a quarter of greenhouse gas emissions in the European Union, just after the energy sector. In 2012, greenhouse gas emissions in the transport sector were allocated between road transport with a majority of 72 % of the total against 12.8 % for civil aviation, less than 1 % for rail transport and 13.9 % for the total of the navigation sector.  Between 1990 and 2007, CO2 emissions in sectors other than transport decreased, while in this sector their increase was around 36 %. Although the economic crisis has contributed to the slowdown in greenhouse gas emissions, we have already seen the first signs that these emissions are increasing again.  Contrary to what has happened in other forms of transport, the maritime transport sector has remained the only one not subject to any measure to reduce CO2 emissions. In view of this, the 2020 energy and climate framework provides for a review clause for the inclusion of maritime transport in the Union's reduction targets in the event that an international agreement is not reached in the meantime.  In this plenary session we will pass legislation which represents a first step towards reducing such emissions, which represent around 4 % of CO2 emissions at European Union level. Contrary to those that are the objectives of decarbonising the European economy in the medium and long term, if nothing is done, greenhouse gas emissions by ships will increase by more than 50 % by 2050.  The adoption at second reading of this regulation will, in my view, meet three important policy objectives: firstly, this European legislative initiative applies to all vessels climbing European ports and will provide an opportunity to influence negotiations at the level of the International Maritime Organisation regulating this sector. Regardless of the progress made in this forum, in setting emission reduction targets is somewhat disappointing, the truth is that cooperation with our international partners is essential in terms of climate policy and the European Union once again takes the leading position in this area. We will continue our efforts and this is one of those steps towards achieving an ambitious agreement of an international nature. Secondly, this legislation will combine the monitoring of CO2 emissions with energy efficiency data from ships and the transparency of these data. On an annual basis, the European Commission will now provide the market with reliable information on the energy consumption and efficiency of ships.  In this way, we can remove barriers for the sector to adopt technical and operational measures that will reduce CO2 emissions into lower net costs, i.e. around EUR 1.2 billion/year, as well as greater competitiveness of European maritime transport, which will benefit international trade. Finally, this legislation will have the potential to create around 10,000 jobs in green technology areas linked to the maritime sector, as well as public health benefits related to lower emissions of other pollutants such as nitrogen oxides, sulphur oxides and suspended fine particles. I therefore believe, ladies and gentlemen, that a robust system of monitoring, information and verification of emissions is a precondition and a cornerstone for any other emission reduction measure that will be determined for this sector in the near future. Finally, I would like to thank the shadow rapporteurs who have worked with me on this dossier, Colleagues Cristopher Fjellner, Jytte Guteland, Julie Girling, Bas Eickout, Josu Juaristi Abaunz and Marco Affronte, as well as President Giovanni La Via and Vice-President Benedek Jávor, for their excellent cooperation. A word of appreciation also to the representatives of the European Commission, especially Mary Veronica Pleterski and her council team, Roberta di Lecce, and Wilhelm Bargum, alde's political adviser, who were involved in the negotiations, for their always constructive attitude.

name: Miguel Arias Cañete
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would first like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Faria, for his constructive approach to the Commission's proposal and all his work in the negotiations with the Council with a view to reaching a quick agreement at second reading. I am also grateful for the work of the previous rapporteur, Mr Skylakakis, and that of the other rapporteurs in the shadow of this dossier. The Regulation on the monitoring, reporting and verification of CO2 emissions from maritime transport is consistent with the policy framework adopted for 2030 on energy and climate. Maritime transport should not be the only unregulated economic sector in this area and should contribute to the fight against climate change. The introduction of transparency, based on reliable and robust data, will help mobilize the industry's exceptional remaining potential to reduce its emissions at very low cost or even without costs. And this means that the additional costs arising from monitoring, reporting and verification will undoubtedly be covered by subsequent savings in terms of fuel expenditure. I must stress that the European Union's primary interest is to find global solutions to maritime emissions and that the European Union will therefore continue to drive progress in discussions within the International Maritime Organization. In this regard, the Monitoring, Notification and Verification Regulation signals an important political signal for the next session of the IMO Committee, which will discuss global data collection and be held in London next May, and also with a view to the United Nations Climate Change Conference to be held in Paris in December 2015. The Commission welcomes the text presented by the Council, which reflects the agreement reached in the three-way dialogues; this text strikes a delicate balance between collecting the most relevant data for the sector and imposing the least administrative burden possible. On the one hand, rationality in the approach is maintained by covering only CO2 emissions, but, on the other hand, in line with what is discussed at international level, the monitoring covers energy efficiency parameters in which significant improvements agreed by the Council and the European Parliament have been incorporated. Increasing transparency on energy efficiency in the sector should enable the adoption of emission mitigation measures by the sector and, moreover, this Regulation ensures that, where agreement is reached on a legal framework for a future measure applicable at the global level, we can adapt our monitoring system. Finally, the proposed agreement, as I pointed out above, is a very important signal of the European Union with a view to the preparation of the Paris Conference, indicating that we are committed to actions to combat climate change and that, at the same time, we promote greater international progress in the case of maritime emissions, mainly within the International Maritime Organization.

name: Christofer Fjellner
text: On the other: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Shipping is the bloodstream of world trade. More than ninety per cent of world trade is transported by sea.  Not only is shipping cost-effective, it is above all also environmentally efficient, because although it accounts for such a large proportion of transport, it accounts for just under 3% of global CO2 emissions. Nevertheless, shipping must be involved in taking climate responsibility, and that is why I am glad that we are now taking the first step in bringing shipping into european climate policy.  I hope that this will enable us to speed up the process that is going on in the International Maritime Organisation in order to get the rest of the world to follow our example. Shipping needs global rules to work because it is a global industry. For me who has negotiated this on behalf of my group, it has been particularly important to ensure that the new rules on shipping are cost-effective and do not impair the competitiveness of shipping. After all, any new burden that we are imposing on shipping risks using less eras, moving things to, for example, trucks, and it will be particularly serious if we believe that the rest of the world should follow our example. Therefore, I am a little extra proud of two victories that I understand that I have pushed for and received a hearing in this work.  The first is that we should focus on CO2 – and the proposal that we are adopting today focuses on CO2 – which is the most important and most serious climate gas in this context. The second is that we are focusing on the larger ships, and that we exclude smaller ships that account for forty per cent of our fleet but only emit 10%. It is crucial to make this cost-effective, and we have heard of that.  It is now a matter of Sweden and other countries pushing in the IMO so that we also get the rest of the world with us, because all the world's ships must of course take the same responsibility for the climate as the European ships do after this decision.

name: Matthias Groote
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I believe that MRV is a first step. It is not that it is an instrument for bringing about reductions, but first of all to generate data, to compare, to get an overview of what the situation in this area really is. It has been mentioned that it is a small area. 3% of greenhouse gas emissions globally are caused by shipping. Nevertheless, we are seeing an increase in trade flows. This will become a problem in the next few years. That is why MRV is certainly a good basis, a small step forward, in order to reach an international agreement at the end of the day, because that is where the journey must go. That must be the course we are taking for the international negotiations. We are seeing this at ICAO. I have such a déja vu experience, I have to say. At ICAO, the fronts are hardened, and there is currently a debate about whether there is only an offsetting in international air traffic. Of course, this is not the way to go, it has to be said. Everyone has to make their contribution. Best of all, we solve it internationally. Nevertheless, we should also reserve the right to take steps if no international agreements are reached, as we do with other areas. That is why I would also like to know from the Commissioner: what are the negotiations at IMO level at the moment? What can we expect? Does the Commission have a plan B if the international negotiations at the IMO fail, so that we do not agree to any diaper-soft compromise there and, just as in air traffic, stop the clock, then start again and then stop again.

name: Julie Girling
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, I would like to thank the rapporteur. I think his approach to this file, given that he was not working on it from the beginning is, in line with that of his colleague, Mr Torvalds, an exemplar of openness and transparency, so I would like to thank them both.  The ECR is very pleased to vote in favour of this regulation, which will establish an EU system for monitoring, reporting and verification of CO2 emissions from maritime transport. Our aim throughout has been to ensure that the EU regulation is practicable, that it is proportionate in terms of the burden it imposes on industry, and that it is compatible with the work of the IMO on global measures. Once this work in the IMO is completed – and I share Mr Groote’s desire to know how that is going – we will be amending EU legislation to make sure that it is aligned. So I am pleased with our success on this file in ensuring that we do not repeat the mistake on aviation by going for a unilateral approach. It constitutes a welcome first step to reducing CO2 from the maritime sector.

name: Nils Torvalds
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, shipping, like any other industry, should be regulated on environmental standards. However, it is important to bear in mind that shipping is a very international industry, and therefore the question of a level playing field is of the utmost importance. Therefore, I would like to take the opportunity to call on the Commission and the Member States to step up their activity in the IMO, and not just concerning emissions MRV. I am satisfied with the report since I think it struck the right balance and we are able to make some adjustment, but that does not mean disproportionate red tape. I am also satisfied that navigation in ice is mentioned because it entails a lot of costs, and if we do not take into account the different circumstances which shipping has to work in then we, willingly or not, create an uneven playing field. The estimated cost of the MRV per ship will be about EUR 7 000. However, any implementation or any rule is only as good as the implementation.  We who are mainly concerned with shipping in the Baltic Sea would like to know how good the control will be because we have – for ‘some peculiar reason’ – some second thoughts about Russian ships. How will Russian ships in the Baltic be controlled? If there are no effective fines, then we again have a playing field which is not as even as the sea level. I think we have a lot of work to do. We have to be effective in the IMO and we have to be effective in implementing this file. If we are not, then we are going to have more problems.

name: Josu Juaristi Abaunz
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, the GUE/NGL Group tabled a number of amendments seeking a broader development of this monitoring system; we understand that this position has been taken into consideration in the proposal and I wanted to congratulate the rapporteur on his work. In this sense, establishing a European surveillance system for CO2 emissions from ships is therefore a first step in reducing these and other emissions with much more decision and ambition. It will therefore be necessary for the collection and exchange of information to be truly effective, because it must be stressed – it has already been said – that it is estimated that greenhouse gas emissions generated by maritime transport will grow at such a rate that they will neutralize the effects of other measures – which I still believe – aimed at curbing or reducing global warming. Clearly, the ultimate goal of this system is to help reduce maritime emissions and fossil fuel consumption. It must therefore be, as the rapporteur points out, a first step. We must be more ambitious in regulation and objectives, and I too would like to ask the Commission how it plans to accelerate or impact these negotiations in the International Maritime Organization. Finally, we must be aware that any measure will be insufficient if it is not accompanied by a deep reflection on the overall system of production, distribution and consumption.

name: Bas Eickhout
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, firstly I would like to extend my gratitude to the rapporteur, Mr Faria, for his excellent work on this file. Mr Faria, you had to take over the work of Mr Skylakakis and I think you did so very well, so thank you for that. My group can also support the deal which is on the table now. Of course, at the moment we are only discussing the monitoring of international shipping, and we all know that international shipping is one of the few sectors which is not regulated for CO2 at all. In that sense, a first step of monitoring and reporting on the CO2 impact is of course a good start, but it is only a start. I am also very happy that, in the deal we have, there is an obligation for the Commission to have biannual reporting on the full climate impact: shipping is more than just CO2, and it is good that the Commission will also report on that biannually. The most important question is what will the next step be, and that is a question for the Commissioner, Mr Arias Cañete.  We all know that the IMO is supposedly working on something, but we all know that this work is going very, very slowly, so my question to the Commissioner would be: what are you going to do to make sure that the IMO delivers on international shipping, ensures that they really do start reducing their emissions; and if they do not, then what is the Commission planning to do about reducing the CO2 emissions of shipping? We need to act, and just waiting for the IMO to decide to do something might be too little, so I am curious and anxious for your answer. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – It is such a pleasure to put a question to my friend, Mr Eickhout, concerning this very important issue. As you mentioned, we are talking about monitoring, reporting and verification, and so on. But that is only talking. Do you not think it is time for the European Union to add this important issue to the negotiations taking place before the climate change summit, and for this important issue to be then addressed at the summit in Paris next year? As you said, it is time to move to the next phase. We have talked too much about this issue. It is time for implementation.

name: Bas Eickhout (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you for your question. I think I could not agree more that we should be doing something. Maybe this also refers to Mrs Girling, who talked about the failure of international aviation. I see that completely differently because, by action at the European level, this also made the international world move on aviation. So sometimes you see a positive impact when Europe moves, and in that sense indeed I fully agree with you that on shipping it is also time to act.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The next speaker is Mrs Daniela Aiuto from the EFDD Group. A warm welcome also for your baby!

name: Daniela Aiuto
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we welcome and support this proposal for a regulation, which finally goes in the direction of greater control of CO2 emissions, including for the maritime sector, which contributes as much as 4%, with a greater impact on port operations.  As a spokesperson I receive many reports from port realities close to residential units such as Taranto, Ancona or Voltri, Prà in western Liguria, where environmental pollution is added to noise pollution. I would remind you that a ship stopped at the port pollutes as much as a thousand cars that keep the engine at a minimum. We must work to promote controls, but also concrete and eco-sustainable solutions such as electric docks or so-called 'cold ironing' which involves the use of only electric thrusters within port areas.  In Italy there are already legislative provisions that require the construction of electrical connections for ships on the quayside. We must adapt all European environmental standards to the highest levels, without creating second-class ports and second-class ports.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union is once again engaged in a debate with good intentions, but without providing a viable solution. Monitoring, monitoring and sanctioning non-compliance with targets for reducing carbon dioxide emissions in the shipping sector is a very timid triptych to try to limit air pollution. You are not trying to solve the problem at its source, which is a globalized economic system that encourages unlimited and ever more intense free trade.  The proposal we are discussing is also a collection of complexity and regulatory costs. It would be necessary to involve the relevant economic actors more in order to carry out a solid study on the consequences of this proposal.  Finally, I draw your attention to the method that has been chosen because there is no satisfactory mechanism here for an international agreement binding the Member States. Should the Commission act and impose a supranational framework? No! This reasoning runs counter to respect for sovereignty. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Dear colleague, I understand that you have given a critical note to the Commission, that it does not get involved and has no solutions. Of course we, as parliamentarians, can criticise the actions of the Commission and the Council. My question is: do you have a concrete proposal to add to this topic that is important to everyone?

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: "blue card" answer. Madam President, the proposal does be based on the finding of a lack of agreement, but it is not for the Commission to fill this void. Member States are the first to be concerned and must negotiate this in a multilateral and international framework, not supranational.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Faria, and my colleagues from the other political groups for their work on this dossier.  Maritime transport is a vital sector for the world economy, given that more than 80% of goods are transported by ships. Sea transport is also the most environmentally efficient and environmentally sustainable mode of transport of goods, given that the CO2 emissions required to transport one tonne of goods per kiloser at sea are lower than transport by both road and air. However, over the last ten years, we have seen a 48% increase caused by maritime transport of greenhouse gas emissions, which has contributed significantly to the pollution of our planet.  Today's vote, following an agreement reached in December, following important negotiations with the Italian Presidency, shows once again how the European Parliament is showing great attention to sustainability issues by setting an EU system for monitoring, communicating and verifying CO2 emissions from maritime transport, as a basis for facilitating the setting of reduction targets at a later stage and for the application of a market-based measure , which could take the form of a contributory or objective-based compensation fund, or an emissions trading scheme that will be able to ensure a reduction in CO2 emissions in maritime transport. It is a step forward and it is not the solution, but it is a step forward.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D).
text: Madam President! Maritime transport, as has been said here today, is not part of the EU's commitment to reducing CO2 emissions, despite the fact that shipping and its emissions have actually increased a great deal. It is incredibly important, I think, to ensure that shipping as an industry also contributes to our climate policy. It is important that we make an effort to get shipping companies to want to invest in energy-efficient ships also for the sake of climate policy. That is why what we are going to vote on today is a good thing, because with the new EU system for monitoring and reporting and verifying CO2 emissions from ships calling at European ports, we will have a system that will be able to provide us with good data. With this data, we will be able to get a better overview of how much the sector is emitting in the long term, and so hopefully we can also hopefully tighten the rules on how much we allow them to emit. It is important for me also to say that it is gratifying that in this work we have not only looked at the size of the ships, but that we have also taken into account how much goods they transport. Of course, it also has an impact on CO2 emissions. However, this is only one step. This is a step in the right direction, but it is still only one step. We need to work to ensure that we create standards globally for the entire shipping sector and for us to set real emission requirements globally so that we can reduce CO2 emissions.

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR).
text: – I welcome the agreement reached as a good, balanced and feasible first step to reduce CO2 emissions from maritime transport. International maritime transport is pretty much the last of the Mohicans, because it is the only mode of transport that has not yet been included in the EU's commitment and objectives to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. This sector accounts for 4% of the EU's total greenhouse gas emissions. This share is increasing and will increase further in the coming years, not only in the EU but also globally. There is therefore an objective reason to make the necessary efforts in this mode of transport. Reliable and comparable data must always form the basis of a well-thought-out policy. The proposed system of monitoring, reporting and verification is therefore a good and necessary starting point and also has the potential to create a win-win situation in various areas. So there are plenty of reasons to support this agreement with conviction.

name: Gesine Meissner (ALDE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Thank you first of all to my colleague Mr Faria. It has been said that he has negotiated this excellently. Mr Bas Eickhout said he took it on at short notice. Agrees! But he is Columbus' successor, he is Portuguese and has EMSA on his doorstep. If anyone can do that, then of course he can. So i.e. a lot of praise to my colleagues. There is a great deal of agreement in the Chamber that this was an important matter for climate protection, so that we are now setting up a monitoring system for shipping. However, I think it is not only important for global climate protection, it is also important for the sea. I am a great advocate of integrated maritime policy – many people know this – and it is the case that the sea will be used much more economically in the future. It is particularly important to protect not only biodiversity, but also the climate. Ship traffic will increase. That is what everyone is saying – globally – and it is the big ships that are causing emissions. We want to record them now, and then we will report on them. What is important, as my colleague Mr Torvalds also said, is that, because it concerns all the flags in Europe, everyone is also involved in ensuring that this is controlled by the Commission, so that is also a task for you, Mr Arias Caete, and it is good that all the flags are included. I certainly see it that way. Ship owners will have to report. It is good that the ALDE has succeeded in simplifying this reporting procedure in comparison with the Commission proposal, that there is transparency in it and that it is also possible to take out very sensitive economic data. In general, I have to say that I very much welcome the fact that we, as Europe, are now once again going ahead and trying to influence the IMO. We absolutely need that! We have already achieved various things in the SECA zones with sulphur emissions, and if we can do that here, it would be excellent for global shipping and for all of us on the subject of climate.

name: Merja Kyllönen (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, calls for a reduction in the environmental impact of shipping have recently become significantly tightened, including as a result of the entry into force of the Sulphur Directive, placing the so-called SECA area of the Baltic Sea under a special magnifying glass here in Europe and challenging the shipping industry to renew its fleet and technologies at a rapid pace.  I could talk at length about the specific characteristics of the Baltic Sea, but it is particularly important here in Parliament's legislative work to remember the fact that the Baltic Sea is dominated by an ice cap that lasts for months in winter. Safe shipping is always conditional on the ice resistance of ships in winter conditions, which in practice means more steel, while at the same time reducing the energy efficiency of ships. It is also important to take into account the specific characteristics of different regions in the further work on CO2 emissions, so that safety and environmental requirements do not have to be pitted against each other.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE).
text: – Madam President, our goal is to reach an international agreement and the same rules for all. This is a good start. Next week is being held at the International Maritime Organisation in London a committee meeting to participate as a member of the environmental committee, dominated by the very topic we are talking about here today. The fact is that only this area is not covered by any agreements so far and therefore we must include the introduction of specific measures.  However, we must not harm the competitiveness of maritime transport and we must worry about protecting the rights of small fishermen. I welcome the section that excludes smaller ships and includes ships larger than 5,000 tons of payload. In any case, it is good that there is a monitoring, reporting system and that it will be implemented in such a way that the shipowner, i.e. the company, has to calculate the amount of carbon dioxide released for each trip and must report it annually to the European Commission and the flag state on the amount of carbon dioxide released.  We also know that the Commission must report to Parliament every two years. We hope that this is a good and ambitious goal, but it is also necessary to include countries that are not members of the European Union. They should be encouraged by an international agreement and regional linking. I warn about the sharp increase in cruising tourism and here I especially emphasize my hometown of Dubrovnik. I hope that this new sulphur directive and the one we are talking about today will contribute to reducing the amount of gases dropped.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D).
text: – Grazzi, Chair, u grazzi, Kummissarju. Fil-fatt il-White Paper tal-2011 tal-Kummisjoni Ewropea dwar it-Trasport tindika li l-emissjonijiet CO2 mis-settur marittimu għandhom jonqsu b'minn tal-anqas 40% tas-sena 2050 meta mqabel mal-livelli-2005. Fir-realtà, iżda, minkejja d-dħul ta' standard minimi tal-effi大jenza enerġetika għal ikeerti kategoriji ta' vapuri u minkejja t-teknoloġija ġdida, l-emissjonijiet mis-settur marittimu mistennija jkomplu jiżdiedu, u dan minħabba żieda fid-domanda għat-trasport marittimu kkawżata minn żieda fil-kummer大 dinji. Iż-żieda fl-emissjonijiet mis-settur marittimu, iżda, imorru għal kollox kontra l-miri klimatici tal-Unjoni Ewropea. Għalhekk li s-sistema tal-MRV fuq l-emissjonijiet CO2 hija biss l-ewwel pass lejn it-twaqqif ta' sistema globali għall-moniteraġġ, rapurtaġġ u verifikazzjonijiet tal-emissjonijiet mis-settur marittimu internazzjonali. Dan is-settur jista' jikkontribwixxi għat-tnaqqis tal-emissjonijiet jekk ikun hemm miżuri regolatorji b'saħħithom, flimkien ma' teknoloġija ġida u oħrajn eżistenti, li flimkien jistgħu jgħinu biex jonqsu l-emissjiet. Mill-perspettiva tat-tibdil fil-klima din 大ertament li hija kunsiderazzjoni pożittiva li għandna nżommu f'moħħna. Huwa fatt li s-setturi kollha jridu jikkontribwixxu u meta wieħed iqis in-natura internazzjonali tat-trasport marittimu, allura huwa 4-a-aktar metodu effettiv biex innaqqsu l-emissjonijiet serra f'dan is-settur huwa ftehim globali fi ħdan l-Organizazzjoni Marittima Internazzjonali, u allura interessanti nkunu nafu x'se tagħmel l-IMO.

name: Dawid Bohdan Jackiewicz (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab International shipping remains today the only mode of transport not included in the European Union's commitment to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. According to Parliament and the Council, the most effective way to reduce CO2 emissions from shipping at Union level will continue to be the establishment of a CO2 monitoring, reporting and verification system. I would like to say that environmental protection is a very important issue, but I do not know why only the European Union is to be responsible for this? Imposing further restrictions and obligations on EU maritime transport can significantly reduce its competitiveness vis-à-vis Asian or American shipping. Moreover, we run the risk of EU ships changing their flags in order to avoid the consequences of unequal rules and restrictions on European shipping. I call for common sense and moderation in imposing new restrictions on further industries. Let climate policy not be a stone at the neck of the European economy, including maritime ones.

name: Kaja Kallas (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, it is of course important that the EU leads the way in the fight against climate change, but we should also look at not harming our companies. Initiatives to reduce CO2 emissions in maritime transport need to aim at setting the standards globally, in particular to give a level playing field to our shipping companies as they do not compete locally, or even at European level, but at the international level. The sulphur provisions, for instance, in the Baltic Sea are increasing the costs of maritime transport. They represent real challenges to shipping companies. We have to protect our environment, but we also have to keep in mind that our companies compete on the global market and transport corridors can be changed for cheaper ones. I therefore hope that the Commission will ensure that all European shipping companies, wherever they operate, can be competitive.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, cosúil leis na Feisirí eile fáiltím roimh na moltaí seo.  Gan dabht ar bith, tá sé in am dúinn rud éigin a dhéanamh faoin truailliú agus faoi na hastaíochtaí CO2 atá ag teacht ón tionscal iompair mhuirí – 4% mar a dúradh cheana féin. Mura ndéanaimid aon rud faoi, fásfaidh sé sin go dtí 50% i gceann cúpla bliain; ach má dhéanaimid rud éigin faoi is féidir é a laghdú faoin méid sin ar a laghad.  Dá bhrí sin, caithfimid an t-eolas a bhailiú ar dtús go háirithe faoi na longa a thagann isteach i gcalafoirt na hEorpa. Mar a dúradh, is í an chéad choiscéim í seo agus, mar a dúirt an Coimisinéir Arias Cañete chomh maith, is féidir é a dhéanamh gan mórán costas a chur ar an tionscal, nó b’fhéidir gan aon chostas a chur orthu. Má dhéanaimid é sin beimid ag tabhairt comhartha an-mhaith don chruinniú ollmhór i bPáras amach anseo.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D).
text: – Carbon dioxide emissions from fossil fuels are largely responsible for so-called "greenhouse gases" and thus for the intensification of global climate change, but also for ocean acidification. All issuing sources must be reduced, with the utmost urgency. In the case of maritime transport, in particular, it is essential to reduce the use of heavy fuels and to use alternatives such as liquefied natural gas or other environmentally appropriate sources. This transformation will have to be accompanied by the use of intermediate filling stations and the Azores, located in the middle of the Atlantic, in the transit between the Panama Canal and Europe, are ready to respond positively to this need through its infrastructure of the oceanic port of Praia da Vitoria.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, Dear Mr. Commissioner, I would like to emphasize, as you know, but I would like to emphasize that Croatia is a maritime country. Maritime affairs is an extremely important economic branch for Croatia.  Port jobs as number two are a very important industry, but also the production of engines for the ship, marine engines, is something of utmost importance for our industry. So, when we talk about this regulation, I think it is of course absolutely necessary to regulate this part of transport, because this part of transport also pollutes the environment, pollutes our planet and we need to measure not only the issue of CO2, but we also need to measure other gases. And I want to thank all those who have made great efforts to come to this document, that is, to this compromise, but I emphasize once again, it is very important that we take into account all those elements and maritime and port industry and the production of marine engines.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, maritime transport is in a position to assume even greater predominance in global freight transport in the future. It is therefore important to take into account this sector's dependence on fossil fuels and the implementation of measures to reduce its associated greenhouse gas emissions. Some concerns, some ideas to be taken into account in the future, the exploitation of the potential of liquefied natural gas, the transition to low-carbon technologies as a medium-term objective, the rejection of market solutions adopted in other sectors, such as the carbon market, giving prevalence to normative solutions and the need to recognise the situation and the specific needs of the outermost regions and , in particular, the need to ensure public transport services, regular inter-island connections between them and the mainland, whether of persons or cargo, on a regular basis.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, international maritime transport remains the only mode of transport that is not part of the European Union's commitment to reducing greenhouse gas emissions, despite the fact that emissions from the maritime transport sector make an important contribution to both air pollution and climate change. For this reason, the development of a European monitoring, communication and verification system (MRV) of CO2 emissions from maritime transport is to be considered fundamental. It may be the basis on which Europe may or rather must develop emission reduction policies for the maritime sector consistent with global policies on climate, air pollution and the protection of human health.  The development of ambitious policies to reduce emissions in this sector is all the more important in view of the challenges facing the maritime sector in the coming years. In the future, world trade is expected to grow significantly due to the expected increase in population and it is therefore urgently necessary to develop technologies and practices to be applied for fuel quality, emission reduction technologies and operational measures for ships.

name: Miguel Arias Cañete
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, once again I would like to thank this Parliament and, in particular, the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs for their great work. This Regulation is an important and coherent signal to the European Council conclusions on the climate and energy framework until 2030 and confirms that all economic sectors, as well as maritime transport, must contribute to the fight against climate change. Let me stress that it is important for the European Union to achieve global solutions for maritime emissions. That is why this Regulation is important, as it casts an unequivocal signal of what we want in the framework of the next session of the International Maritime Organization, to be held next May in London, and also for the Paris Climate Change Conference at the end of the year. The implementation of a regional data monitoring, reporting and verification system in the European Union, in addition to direct positive effects, is also a useful experience and provides a technical vision for international negotiations. When discussing these issues on a global scale, our experience will identify solutions that have already been implemented. Moreover, as we remain committed to making as rapid progress globally as possible to address greenhouse gas emissions on ships, this Regulation ensures that, at the time of agreement on a legal framework for a future global measure, we can adapt our monitoring, reporting and verification system. Some Members asked what the status of the negotiations in the International Maritime Organization was. Negotiations at the International Maritime Organization to implement a global monitoring, reporting and verification system are progressing slowly; slowly, but I understand that in the right direction. The Community legislation we have put on the table has been a fundamental input in the negotiating process. At present, the Panamanian Presidency has an optimistic view of this process, but at the moment, given the state of the negotiations, it seems difficult, if not impossible, for us to successfully conclude this negotiation before Paris, because there are countries, such as China or India, that hold positions that are not easy in the search for such a comprehensive agreement. The Commission will therefore make every effort to conclude a satisfactory agreement as soon as possible. (The President interrupts the speaker to call Members to order)

name: José Inácio Faria
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, at this end I would like to thank my colleagues and Commissioner Arias Cañete for their comments on this important matter. Ladies and gentlemen, I hope you will listen to me, ladies and gentlemen, despite the fact that this regulation imposes new obligations on shipowners, such as monitoring and reporting OF CO2 emissions and other data on distance traveland cargo transported, the truth is that this regulation will safeguard ways of fulfilling those obligations without this being an additional administrative burden. , and this does not mean to contradict my colleague Nistelrooij, since pre-existing documentation can be made on board. With the same objective, this regulation will apply only to vessels with a gross tome exceeding 5,000 tonnes, which account for only 55% of all vessels but which constitute about 90% of CO2 emissions. Moreover, this document will not ignore the work that is being done at the level of the International Maritime Organisation. It is still desirable for a comprehensive agreement to be reached quickly and if this happens, as I hope, the Commission should conduct a re-examination of the adaptation of the legislation if this is justified. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that this regulation will contribute to a more modern and environmentally friendly maritime transport sector. This is a small step, no doubt, but at the same time an essential step so that in the future we can impose concrete objectives of decarbonisation and reduction of air pollution by this sector, and i hope that such an agreement can be reached globally. It is true that in the negotiations on this document I have not been able to include some of the issues I wanted, such as a more ambitious approach to greenhouse gases in general, but the truth is that in order to achieve the final goal, the production of a consensual document that appealed to all political groups with different environmental sensitivities, we had to accept compromise agreements. I hope, Commissioner, that you can make this appeal at the international maritime organisation's office, as in all other forums. In fact, it was not easy, with moments of great negotiating tension between Parliament and the Council, but in the end common sense and the common interest prevailed in obtaining a balanced final document, which would please everyone, and which is precisely, ladies and gentlemen, the document that we are going to vote on today. Thank you, Commissioner, thank you, ladies and gentlemen, thank you for your interest in this subject and I hope to be able to count on your vote in favour.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place at the end of this debate.

name: n/a
text: (For results and other details of votes: see Minutes)

name: Nirj Deva (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I declare a commercial interest in this matter and I am not voting.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to ask you to postpone the final vote on the legislative resolution for the purpose of conducting the negotiations with the co-legislators.

name: Georg Mayer (NI).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the In my opinion, this vote was a little chaotic. And I think you have also forgotten to vote on something above. I would just like to record this for the Record.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. On 7 July 1995, the International Convention on Training, Qualification and Guarding Standards for Fisheries Vessel Personnel was adopted on 7 July 1995 at an international conference in London involving more than 74 governments, including 22 of the current Member States of the European Union. The objective of the Convention is to ensure that staff present on fishing vessels are appropriately qualified and in good health. The International Convention contradicts certain points of Directive 2005/36/EC, which mutually recognise the professional qualifications of the Member States by limiting this recognition to the signatory States of the Convention. The ratification of this Convention therefore requires prior authorisation from the EU and a written commitment by the Member States where, in the event of a conflict, Community legislation shall prevail. This report allows the ratification of this Convention to Member States which have not signed it and clarifies the situation of those who have already ratified it. That's why I voted for it.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This was a consent report which will provide Member States with the requisite authority to sign the International Convention, which sets minimum standards on training, competence and fitness for the personnel of large fishing vessels, aimed at improving safety. It is for these reasons that I voted in favour of this report.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. This proposed Council decision authorizes Member States to become parties to the International Convention on Standards for Training Fisheries Vessel Personnel, PatentIng and Monitoring of the International Maritime Organization. Fishing jurisdiction normally rests with the Eu under the Treaties, however only Member States can ratify this convention. It provides that a minimum of qualifications will be required for aircrew as well as vocational training standards. Thus, it contributes to the harmonization of equal treatment of workers. In addition, there will be no increase in training costs for Member States, as the EU already funds training in the fisheries sector through the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund. So I voted in favour of the text.

name: Guillaume Balas (S&D)
text: In writing. I supported the recommendation allowing Member States to become a party, in the interests of the European Union, to the Convention on Standards for Training Of Fishing Ship Personnel, PatentIng and Watch of the International Maritime Organization. The purpose of this agreement is to ensure qualified marine personnel by promoting vocational training and to help reduce the risks associated with the safety and health of seafarers and all fishing vessel personnel. Its scope covers vessels of 24 metres or more with a power of 750 kW or more. The Convention encourages Member States to apply these safety and professional qualification standards to vessels of the same size but which would have less power.  I voted for this recommendation because it is important to ensure a minimum level of training in the fishing sector and to ensure working and safety conditions on board to prevent workplace accidents. By adopting this recommendation, the Union thus authorises member states to ratify this Convention.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to empower Member States to ratify the International Convention on Standards of Personnel for Fishing Vessels. The International Convention on Standards of Training, Certification and Watchkeeping of Fishing Vessel Personnel was adopted by the International Maritime Organisation in 1995. It aims to ensure that the personnel on board fishing vessels are qualified (with appropriate official certificates) and are able to carry out their duties, as demonstrated by medical examination, in order to minimise the risk to life and property or the marine environment through operations carried out by fishing vessels at sea. Fishing is the profession in which the accident rate is highest: the number of deaths at work is 24 000 per year. I agree with the suggestions that, in addition to training to prevent accidents at work, it is important to ensure minimum standards of work and safety on board, and therefore it is necessary that all Member States apply the same provisions in line with international safety recommendations and that those standards also apply to vessels operating in EU waters.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which, in line with the Council's recommendations, aims to authorise all member states to ratify the international convention on the training of fishing vessel personnel of IMO (International Maritime Organization) adopted by the ILO (International Labour Organization) in July 1995. If this report reminds us that EU directives take precedence in the event of an intra-Community dispute, the ratification of this convention by all member states will guarantee a minimum level of qualification for sailing personnel, as well as vocational training standards that will contribute to risk reduction.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. Sailor-fisherman is one of the most dangerous occupations. It is estimated that 24,000 fishermen die each year in the line of duty. In order to ensure the safety of personnel working on fishing vessels, it is essential that they are qualified and fit for work. The purpose of the International Convention on Standards for Fishing Vessel Personnel is to improve the training of fishermen by ensuring minimum skills and qualifications. It is therefore in the interest of ensuring the protection of workers and enhancing safety in the workplace that I voted in favour of this text.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Resolution authorising Member States to accede to the International Convention on Standards of Training, Qualification and Guarding for The Personnel of Fishing Vessels of the International Maritime Organization, after seeing the positive recommendation of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. This accession will enable the groups concerned to have better and more harmonised training at European level.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. This report relates to the Council's plan to allow EU Member States to become parties to the International Convention on Standards for Training Fishing Ship Personnel, Patenting and Watch of the International Maritime Organization. Currently, only four EU Member States have ratified the Convention. In particular, it aims to reduce the risks to the safety of fishing vessel personnel by requiring the holding of a certificate attesting to their qualification and medically recognized fitness.   Indeed, the Union does not have the right to sign this convention, because only the Member States are entitled to do so. However, the case law of the Court of Justice requires EU authorisation to allow Member States to ratify the Convention, since fishing is one of the EU's exclusive competences. In fisheries, Member States are thus placed under the tutelage of the Union, but the aim of this report, namely the accession of the Member States of the Union to this Convention, can be welcomed. That is why I voted for it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this measure, the main objective of which is to authorise the other EU Member States to ratify the International Convention on Rules on the Manning of Fishing Vessels, while the Union's exclusive competence in this area has been established.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I supported this Recommendation at first reading and abbreviated procedure by which Parliament approves the Council Decision to authorise Member States to ratify the International Convention on Standards of Training, Qualification and Guarding for Fisheries Vessel Personnel (STCW-F Convention) under the EU's exclusive competences in the recognition of regulated professions performed by EU nationals on board fishing vessels. The purpose of the Convention is to ensure that personnel on board fishing vessels are qualified and fit for use, so that threats to the safety of human life, goods at sea or the marine environment are minimized during on-board operations. Provisions are mandatory for vessels over 24 metres in force and a driving power of 750 Kw or more and concern captains, officers, machine officers and radio operators. Spain had already ratified it. From Parliament we use it to recommend the establishment of a minimum level of training at EU level and we believe that it is appropriate to extend the scope of the Convention or at least adopt regulatory provisions applicable to vessels of less than 24 metres, so we call on the Commission to legislate on this.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it endorses the Council decision authorising Member States, in the interest of the European Union, to become parties to the International Maritime Organisation Convention on Standards of Training, Certification and Watchkeeping for Fishing Vessel Personnel. It is true that four EU Member States, including Lithuania, have already ratified this Convention. The Convention aims to ensure that personnel on board fishing vessels are qualified (with appropriate official certificates) and are able to carry out their duties, as demonstrated by medical examination, in order to minimise the risk to life and/or property or the marine environment through operations carried out by fishing vessels at sea. The Convention requires staff to have knowledge of certain matters at least to the extent necessary and have held certain duties on board for at least the minimum period required. The Convention also promotes vocational training to achieve and maintain an adequate level of productivity in the fisheries sector and to help reduce risks.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. I support this recommendation with the purpose of 100 qualified personnel who have received adequate training and medical examination on boats. Fishing is the occupation with the highest rate of accidents.  An estimated 24,000 people a year lose their lives while fishing. Therefore, I consider it necessary that all adequate measures be implemented in order for professional people who have received adequate training to work on boats, and this recommendation does not require any increased costs for EU member states.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This was a consent report which will provide Member States with the requisite authority to sign the International Convention, which sets minimum standards on training, competence and fitness for the personnel of large fishing vessels, aimed at improving safety. It is for these reasons that I voted in favour of this report.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this recommendation because I believe that the safety of seafarers is a priority and, therefore, Member States should be encouraged to take part in this Convention that aims at improving the standards of safety on fishing vessels.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Today the European Parliament has taken a step forward in the protection of seafarers, because this convention to which the EU is preparing to accede aims to ensure that personnel working on board fishing vessels are qualified and fit for work in order to reduce risks to safety and the environment.  Fishing is, in fact, a professional activity that exposes itself to an exponential index of accidents and even serious accidents. The EU's accession to the International Convention on the Training and Employment of Seafarers is also a key warning to Member States to improve the application of labour law and employment guarantees to seafarers. Because certain guarantees are essential and it is not acceptable that legal certainties in contractual and wage terms, for example, should be recognised in such a diverging way from country to country and from sector to sector.  That is why we welcome the outcome of this vote, in the hope that working conditions in the fisheries sector will become uniform in the Member States and more attractive to those who wish to engage in this activity.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. The European Parliament proposes to adopt a motion for a resolution approving the Council's draft that allows Member States to ratify the international convention on the harmonization of standards for training fishing vessel personnel, issuing patents and monitoring of the International Maritime Organisation.  First of all, we should be pleased that the Member States (not the European Union) have the competence to sign an international convention. In addition, it increases the minimum level of qualification required for aircrew in order to improve the safety of marine navigation. The sea must no longer remain a lawless zone in which unfair competition and non-compliance with basic safety rules flourish. That is why I voted for this draft resolution.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Recommendation on the draft Council decision authorising Member States to become parties, in the interest of the European Union, to the International Convention of the International Maritime Organisation on Standards for the Training of Seafarers, Certification/Attestation and Watchkeeping for Fishing Vessel Sreferred Personnel. The objective of the Convention is to ensure that the staff of fishing vessels have the necessary qualifications to mitigate potential risks to the safety of persons and/or goods at sea or risks to the marine environment during operations on board seagoing vessels. I believe that maritime training ensures greater safety and security in this area. Maritime know-how is of strategic importance in maintaining the EU's position as a world leader in maritime.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour.  The Convention provides for the issue of certificates enabling seaman to practise on fishing vessels, in line with the minimum requirements introduced at IMO level.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the recommendation concerning the draft Council decision authorising Member States to sign and/or ratify, in the interests of the European Union, the International Maritime Organisation's 1995 International Convention on Standards for the Training of Fishing Crews, the Issue of Patents and the Watchman.  The aim of the Convention is to ensure that personnel operating on board fishing vessels are qualified and fit for work, in order to minimise potential risks to human safety or the marine environment. The Convention provides that staff shall have minimal knowledge of specific matters and shall have exercised their duties on board a vessel for a minimum period by introducing a balanced operational level in the fisheries sector, promoting vocational training and contributing to the reduction of the rate of accidents. Given that the proposed recommendation is intended to encourage Member States to ratify the convention in question, I have decided to vote in favour of it.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This was a consent report which will provide Member States with the requisite authority to sign the International Convention, which sets minimum standards on training, competence and fitness for the personnel of large fishing vessels, aimed at improving safety. It is for these reasons that I voted in favour of this report.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The object of the International Convention on Standards of Training, Certification and Watchkeeping for Fishing Vessel Personnel (STCW-F Convention) is to ensure that personnel sailing on fishing vessels are qualified and fit for the job in order to minimise, where possible, the potential threats to safety of life and/or property at sea or to the marine environment. The decision under consideration is intended to enable Member States to ratify the STCW-F Convention without encroaching on the EU’s exclusive competence regarding the recognition of regulated professions pursed by EU nationals on board fishing vessels. Following Parliamentʼs discussion on this topic I voted in favour to give my consent to the text of the draft Council decision.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The International Convention on Standards for the Training of Fishing Crews, Patent Issuance and Watchman was adopted by the IMO in 1995 in London in the presence of 74 governments, including those of 22 current EU Member States.  So far, only four Member States (Denmark, Spain, Latvia and Lithuania) have ratified the STCW-F Convention. The aim of the Convention is to ensure that personnel operating on board fishing vessels are qualified and fit for work, so that the potential risks to the safety of persons and property at sea or to the marine environment are minimised during operations on board fishing vessels.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. I supported this Council proposal as it will facilitate member states' ratification of the International Convention on Standards for Fishing Vessel Personnel.  It seems to me that it is a common sense measure to guarantee a minimum level of qualification for these staff. It is also a question of equal treatment of workers as it will allow the harmonisation of vocational training standards as a whole. This Council proposal underlines that the EU does not have the power to ratify international conventions; it is therefore a reminder of the sovereignty of the Member States and the non-federal character of the European Union. I note, however, that the Council, in its proposal, has insisted on the principle of the primacy of European standards in the event of differing opinions in the context of intra-Community relations.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 With this decision, the Council authorises EU Member States to ratify the International Convention on Standards for Fishing Crews, adopted by the International Maritime Organisation (IMO) on 7 July 1995 in London, in the presence of 74 countries including 22 EU Member States.  So far, only four Member States (Spain, Denmark, Latvia and Lithuania) have ratified the Convention. The aim is to ensure that personnel operating on board fishing vessels are qualified (and have an official certificate attesting to it) and fit for work (following a medical examination), so that the potential risks to the safety of persons and property at sea or to the marine environment are minimised during operations on board fishing vessels. The Convention also provides that staff shall have minimal knowledge of specific matters and shall have carried out duties on board a vessel for a minimum period. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution because I agree with the objective of ensuring that personnel working on board fishing vessels are qualified and fit for work, so that the potential risks to the safety of people and property at sea or to the marine environment are minimised during operations on board.  I therefore believe, in view of the thousands of fatal accidents that occur every year, that in order to reduce the high rate of accidents, staff must have minimal knowledge of specific subjects and must have performed functions with less responsibility on board a ship for a minimum period.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Fishing is one of the professional sectors with the highest rates of accidents, with very serious consequences on the lives of fishing professionals as well as their households. It is estimated that 24,000 lives are claimed per year in the exercise of the activity. The International Convention of the International Maritime Organisation on Standards of Training, Certification and Room Service for Seafarers of Fishing Vessels aims precisely at reducing as much as possible the occurrence of these threats to the safety of the lives of workers by ensuring that personnel embarked on a set of minimum appetites and qualifications for the sector. I support Mrs Ribeiro's report and I believe it is essential that all Member States ratify this Convention.  That this decision should now encourage the Member States to ratify the Convention as soon as possible.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Adequate training of crews on board fishing vessels is essential to ensure the safety of maritime personnel on board. From this point of view, the International Convention on Standards for the Training of Fishing Crews, the Granting of Patents and the Guard clearly interprets this need. In the light of these considerations, I have decided to vote in favour of the proposal, in order to encourage Member States to ratify this convention, in accordance with the exclusive competences of the European Union.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The International Convention on Standards of Training, Certification and Watchkeeping for Fishing Vessel Personnel (STCW-F Convention) ensures that personnel sailing on fishing vessels are qualified and fit for the job, so that potential threats to safety of life and/or property at sea or to the marine environment can, wherever possible, be minimised when operations are being carried out on seagoing vessels. I voted in favour of this report to enable Member States to ratify the STCW-F Convention without encroaching on the EU’s exclusive competence regarding the recognition of regulated professions pursed by EU nationals on board fishing vessels. This decision should therefore encourage Member States to take all necessary steps without delay to ratify the STCW-F Convention in the best interests of the personnel.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. On 7 July 1995, the International Convention on Training, Qualification and Guarding Standards for Fisheries Vessel Personnel was adopted on 7 July 1995 at an international conference in London involving more than 74 governments, including 22 of the current Member States of the European Union.  The objective of the Convention is to ensure that staff present on fishing vessels are appropriately qualified and in good health. The International Convention contradicts certain points of Directive 2005/36/EC, which mutually recognise the professional qualifications of the Member States by limiting this recognition to the signatory States of the Convention. The ratification of this Convention therefore requires prior authorisation from the EU and a written commitment by the Member States where, in the event of a conflict, Community legislation shall prevail. This report allows the ratification of this Convention to Member States which have not signed it and clarifies the situation of those who have already ratified it. That's why I voted for it.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this text because I believe it is essential to ensure that personnel working on board fishing vessels are qualified, including through an official certificate attesting to it, and fit for work, so that the potential risks to the safety of people and property or the marine environment are minimised.  At last, it is arranged for staff to have minimal knowledge of specific matters and to have been having worked on board a ship for a minimum period. The aim is thus to introduce and maintain a balanced level of operation in the fisheries sector, promoting vocational training and contributing to the reduction of the accident rate. Fishing is a professional activity with a very high rate of accidents and an estimated 24 000 fatal accidents are reported in each year of activity. That is why professionalisation and fitness must be encouraged.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which is intended to enable Member States to ratify the IMO’s International Convention on Standards of Training, Certification and Watchkeeping for Fishing Vessel Personnel without affecting the EU’s exclusive competence. The object of the Convention is to ensure that personnel sailing on fishing vessels are qualified and fit for the job, so that potential threats to safety of life and/or property at sea or to the marine environment can be minimised.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. The aim of this report is to authorise Member States to ratify the STCW-F Convention in accordance with the EU's exclusive competence in recognising regulated professions carried out by EU nationals on fishing vessels. Considering that the convention is intended to ensure that the personnel working on European fishing vessels are qualified, fit for work and operate in the necessary safety conditions, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. As the report points out, fishing has one of the highest accident rates. However, this sector plays an important role in the European economy.  Through this text, the EU authorises Member States to ratify the International Convention on Standards for Fishing Vessel Personnel. It thus demonstrates its consideration of the issues of training workers on fishing vessels, which fall under its exclusive jurisdiction.  That is why I voted in favour of this text.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The aim of the International Convention on Standards for the Training of Crews of Fishing Vessels is to ensure that personnel working on board vessels are qualified and fit for work. In this way, the potential risks to the safety of people and property at sea will be minimised during on-board operations.  The Member States cannot ratify the STCW-F Convention without the authorisation of the European Union, since this is a matter for the Eu ropean Union. I voted in favour of this convention in order to encourage The Member States to take all necessary steps for ratification without delay.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. This proposed Council decision authorizes Member States to become parties to the International Convention on Standards for Training Fisheries Vessel Personnel, PatentIng and Monitoring of the International Maritime Organization. Fishing jurisdiction normally rests with the Eu under the Treaties, however only Member States can ratify this convention. It provides that a minimum of qualifications will be required for aircrew as well as vocational training standards. Thus, it contributes to the harmonization of equal treatment of workers. In addition, there will be no increase in training costs for Member States, as the EU already funds training in the fisheries sector through the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund. So I voted in favour of the text.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the recommendation because the Convention must also include the smaller vessels which make up the bulk of the southern European fishing fleet.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The International Convention on the Training, Qualifications and Watch of Fishing Vessel Crew is intended to ensure that personnel on board fishing vessels are properly qualified (certified by official documents) and fit to work (as confirmed by medical examination). This is necessary in order to minimise the potential threats to life and/or property and the marine environment during operations at sea on board fishing vessels. In my opinion, the crews of fishing vessels should also be adequately knowledge of sustainable fishing methods in order to maintain marine fish stocks. It also follows from the foregoing that the Common Fisheries Policy should pay much more attention to sustainable fish farming, i.e. aquaculture, and in particular to freshwater fish farming. A significant number of fish ponds in Hungary are located in Natura 2000 sites. These farms do not pose any threat to the natural assets of these areas. Moreover, in many cases it is precisely because of our closed-system fish ponds that they have created or preserved individual wetland associations.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. The proposal aims to ensure that embedded personnel have the necessary qualifications in order to reduce threats to the safety of persons or property at sea or to the marine environment during operations on board fishing vessels. The Convention requires staff to have a minimum level of knowledge in specific matters and to have performed duties on board a ship for a minimum period. Fishing is the professional activity that knows the highest rate of accidents, with an estimated loss of 24 000 lives per year in the exercise of the activity. I would like to like to like to take out the excellent work done by colleague Sofia Ribeiro.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The International Convention of the International Maritime Organisation on Standards of Training, Certification and Room Service for Seafarers of Fishing Vessels was adopted on 7 July 1995 at an International Conference attended by 74 governments, 22 of which are currently members of the European Union. The purpose of the Convention is to ensure that personnel on board fishing vessels have professional qualifications proven by official certificate and that their fitness for work is proven by medical services. These measures aim to increase safety conditions in this work, as well as minimize threats to the marine environment. For countries that sign the Convention, these provisions are mandatory only for vessels with a minimum of 24 metres in length and a power of 750kw. This Recommendation agrees that the Council may authorise the Member States to sign the Convention, if they so mean, which seems to us to be positive. We voted for it.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The International Maritime Organisation Convention on Standards of Training, Certification and Watchkeepership for the Crew of Fishing Vessels aims to ensure that workers on board fishing vessels (mandatory only for vessels of 24 metres in length and over and with a power of 750 kW or more) are qualified to demonstrate this qualification by an official certificate and a fitness for work on the basis of a medical examination. This would minimise possible threats to life and property as well as threats to the marine environment during operations on board vessels. Since the Convention cannot be ratified by the European Union, it must be acceded to separately by the Member States in accordance with the precedent in the SDEU on external competence, but member states cannot ratify the Convention without the authorisation of the European Union. The objective of this Decision is to authorise Member States to ratify this Convention.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the measure on the STCW-F/95 Convention which was drawn up by the IMO in 1995.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 My vote is negative for the International Convention on Standards for Fishing Vessel Personnel because I believe that the Convention should also include the smaller vessels that make up the bulk of the southern European fishing fleet.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of the proposal as it authorises Member States to become signatories to the International Convention on Fishing Vessel Personnel of the International Maritime Organization.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the International Convention on Standards of Training, Qualification and Guarding for Fishery Vessel Personnel with the aim of ensuring that personnel on board fishing vessels are qualified and fit for use, so that potential threats to the safety of human life or property at sea or to the marine environment are minimized during on-board operations. The purpose of this Decision is to authorise Member States to ratify the Convention under the exclusive competences of the European Union in this area.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 As also confirmed by the AETS judgment of the Court of Justice, Member States cannot ratify the International Convention of the International Maritime Organisation of 1995 on standards relating to the training of fishing vessel crews, the granting of patents and the guard, without specific authorisation to do so by the EU.  The Convention, concluded in 1995, contains rules aimed at improving the safety conditions of all persons working on fishing vessels. I therefore voted in favour of this recommendation so that it is possible for the Member States to ratify this important instrument as soon as possible.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. I warmly welcome the recommendation on the draft Council decision authorising Member States to sign and ratify, in the interests of the European Union, the 1995 International Convention of the International Maritime Organisation on standards relating to the training of fishing crews, the issue of patents and watch.  I agree with the encouragement of the Member States, currently standing at just four for implementation, to start ratifying the STCW Convention as soon as possible, not only because they are fully in line with the Exclusive Competences of the Union with regard to the recognition of professions exercised by EU citizens on board fishing vessels, but above all because it arises from the need to ensure maximum safety on board and to reduce as far as possible the accident rate during fishing activities. , through the adoption of international safety recommendations and adequate and shared minimum vocational training.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 As shadow rapporteur for the Group of the Party of European Democrats, I voted in favour of the proposal for a Council decision authorising Member States to sign and ratify, in the interests of the European Union, the 1995 IMO International Convention on Standards for the Training of Fishing Crews, The Granting of Patents and watch, because I am convinced of the need to put an end as soon as possible to the current situation that has led to distortions in the EU.
