The decision was necessary because the parts of the Convention which concern the mutual recognition of professional qualifications possessed by certain categories of personnel making up the crews of fishing vessels fall within the exclusive competence of the Union and affect the provisions of the Treaty and secondary union law, in particular Directive 2005/36/EC of the EP and of the Council. Hence the Council's authorization to accede to the Convention. The aim is to encourage Member States (not necessarily coastal) which have vessels flying their flag, whose ports are sea fishing vessels and which fall within the scope of the Convention or where training establishments are located for crews of vessels which have not acceded to the Convention, to take the necessary measures to deposit the instrument of accession to the Convention as soon as possible.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report today because, as an MEP from Mecklenburg-Western Pomerania and a social policy expert, I am very concerned about rules applicable to staff at sea and the proposal takes sufficient account of the concerns of small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I gave my support to the Ribeiro report on the International Convention on Standards of Training, Certification and Watchkeeping for Fishing Vessel Personnel because I believe it is vital to ensure that personnel sailing on fishing vessels are qualified and fit for the job so that potential threats to safety of life and property at sea or to the marine environment can be minimised when operations are being carried out on seagoing vessels.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour of the Recommendation on the draft Council Decision authorising Member States to accede to the International Convention on Standards of Training, Qualification and Guarding for Fisheries Vessel Personnel of the International Maritime Organization. The EU cannot join, and Member States need prior EU authorisation because the provisions on the recognition of regulated professions practiced by EU nationals on board fishing vessels affect the exercise of the EU's exclusive competence in this area. The objective of that convention, moreover, is to ensure that personnel on board fishing vessels over 24 m in size are qualified and fit for use, so that potential threats to the safety of human life or property at sea or to the marine environment are minimized during on-board operations.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, authorising Member States to become party to the International Convention on Standards of Training, Certification and Watchkeeping for Fishing Vessel Personnel of the International Maritime Organization. Fishing is the occupation with the highest accident rate. Twenty-four thousand lives are lost each year during fishing operations and any safety improvement must therefore be welcome.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour because I believe it is important to ensure that personnel sailing on fishing vessels are qualified and fit for the job. Minimising potential threats to safety and property at sea, and also to the marine environment is necessary; therefore we need to establish and maintain fair performance standards in the fisheries sector.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour of the Recommendation on the draft Council Decision authorising Member States to accede to the International Convention on Standards of Training, Qualification and Guarding for Fisheries Vessel Personnel of the International Maritime Organization. The EU cannot join, and Member States need prior EU authorisation because the provisions on the recognition of regulated professions practiced by EU nationals on board fishing vessels affect the exercise of the EU's exclusive competence in this area. The objective of that convention, moreover, is to ensure that personnel on board fishing vessels over 24 m in size are qualified and fit for use, so that potential threats to the safety of human life or property at sea or to the marine environment are minimized during on-board operations.

name: Carlos Iturgaiz (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 Vote for. Due to the high number of accidents in the fisheries field, I consider it necessary to ensure minimum working and safety conditions on board, in the context of the prevention of occupational accidents, which justifies the adoption of uniform standards for all Member States, which must be governed by international safety recommendations, standards which should also be required of vessels operating in Union waters.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted to recommend the Council's draft decision authorising Member States to become parties, in the interest of the Union, the International Convention of the International Maritime Organisation on training standards, issuing certificates and keeping a guard on staff on fishing boats, as the EU cannot ratify that convention, but member states can do so with EU authorisation.  This Convention creates the conditions for ensuring standards so that staff on board fishing vessels are qualified and ready to do their job, and minimises the risks of this occupation, which unfortunately has a high number of deaths annually and has one of the highest accidents at work.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. This proposed Council decision authorizes Member States to become parties to the International Convention on Standards for Training Fisheries Vessel Personnel, PatentIng and Monitoring of the International Maritime Organization. Fishing jurisdiction normally rests with the Eu under the Treaties, however only Member States can ratify this convention. It provides that a minimum of qualifications will be required for aircrew as well as vocational training standards. Thus, it contributes to the harmonization of equal treatment of workers. In addition, there will be no increase in training costs for Member States, as the EU already funds training in the fisheries sector through the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund. So I voted in favour of the text.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of approving the Council's draft decision on the International Convention on Standards for Fishing Vessel Personnel. This convention aims in particular to ensure that personnel working on fishing vessels are qualified, but also to reduce the risks to the safety of seafarers and to promote vocational training. With the draft decision aimed at allowing Member States to ratify this convention in accordance with the competences of the European Union, I welcome the approval given by the European Parliament.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report authorising Member States to become a party to the International Convention on The Standards for Training Fishing Ship Personnel, Patenting and Watch of the International Maritime Organization.  The main objective of this agreement is to ensure that personnel working on fishing vessels are qualified, in particular to limit the risks to the safety of persons and property at sea.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI)
text: Writing. The EU has exclusive competence in the field of fisheries. The aim of the decision submitted is to enable Member States to ratify the STCW-F Convention in accordance with this competence in the field of the recognition of regulated professions exercised by nationals of an EU Member State on board fishing vessels. As this is an important labour law step for safety standards on fishing boats, I am voting in favour of this motion.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I enthusiastically support this Convention. That 24 000 lives are lost each year during fishing activities is an alarming statistic and one that highlights how hazardous a profession it is. It is important that personnel sailing on fishing vessels are qualified and fit for the job to ensure their own safety and to ensure that threats to the marine environment are minimised. The International Convention on Standards of Training, Certification and Watchkeeping for Fishing Vessel Personnel seeks to ensure these objectives and I hope that this decision will encourage Member States to ratify it.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report as it authorises Member States to become signatories to the International Convention on Fishing Vessel Personnel of the International Maritime Organization.

name: Gabrielius Landsbergis (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 International Convention on Standards of Training, Certification and Watchkeeping for Fishing Vessel Personnel (STCW-F Convention) adopted by the International Maritime Organisation (IMO) in London on 7 July 1995. One of the four states that has ratified the Convention is Lithuania. The Convention aims to ensure that staff on board fishing vessels are qualified, vocational training is encouraged to help reduce risks and maintain an adequate level of productivity in the sector. I therefore voted in favour of the decision and I call on the other Member States to contribute to the general safety and training of qualified personnel on fishing vessels.

name: Jérôme Lavrilleux (PPE)
text: In writing. After having already made this known in the Employment and Social Affairs Committee, I voted in favour of the RIBEIRO recommendation on the Council's decision authorising Member States to sign and/or ratify, in the interests of the European Union, the 1995 International Convention on Training Standards for Fishing Vessel Personnel Concretely, the Convention ensures that personnel working on fishing vessels are qualified and fit for work. It will also reduce risks to the safety of people and/or property at sea and establish and maintain fair working conditions in the fishing sector.

name: Gilles Lebreton (NI)
text: In writing. I voted for this text because it encourages Member States to ratify this convention which guarantees a minimum level of qualification for fishing vessel personnel, as well as vocational training standards that contribute to risk reduction.

name: Philippe Loiseau (NI)
text: In writing. Vote for. Parliament must adopt the Council's proposal for a decision allowing member states to sign the international convention on the training of fishing vessel personnel of the IMO (International Maritime Organization) adopted by the ILO in July 1995. The purpose of this agreement is to ensure a minimum level of qualification for sailing personnel, as well as the application of mandatory vocational training standards that contribute to risk reduction. As EU legislation prevails over that of member states, they must apply the guidelines that establish rules on the professional qualification of fishing vessel personnel, patenting or equal treatment in the event of workers' mobility.  This proposal will facilitate the ratification of this Convention by the Member States. Although we may regret that European legislation is necessary for member states, this project aims to harmonize and eliminate inequalities in the treatment of sea professionals. So I'm voting for it.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. This is the vote on the Recommendation at first reading and abbreviated procedure by which Parliament consents (approves) the Council Decision which aims to authorise Member States to ratify the STCW-F Convention under the European Union's exclusive competences in the recognition of regulated professions exercising EU nationals on board fishing vessels. The objective of the STCW-F Convention is to ensure that personnel on board fishing vessels are qualified (which will attest to an official certificate) and are suitable for use (after medical examination), so that potential threats to the safety of human life or property at sea or to the marine environment are minimized during on-board operations. Provisions are mandatory only for vessels over 24 metres in force and a driving power of 750 kW or more and concern captains, officers, machine officers and radio operators.  The European Parliament takes advantage of its area of co-legislation to recommend the establishment of a minimum level of training at EU level.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. On 7 July 1995, the International Convention on Training, Qualification and Guarding Standards for Fisheries Vessel Personnel was adopted on 7 July 1995 at an international conference in London involving more than 74 governments, including 22 of the current Member States of the European Union.  The objective of the Convention is to ensure that staff present on fishing vessels are appropriately qualified and in good health. The International Convention contradicts certain points of Directive 2005/36/EC, which mutually recognise the professional qualifications of the Member States by limiting this recognition to the signatory States of the Convention. The ratification of this Convention therefore requires prior authorisation from the EU and a written commitment by the Member States where, in the event of a conflict, Community legislation shall prevail. This report allows the ratification of this Convention to Member States which have not signed it and clarifies the situation of those who have already ratified it. That's why I voted for it.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. In view of the draft Council Decision authorising EU Member States to accede to the International Convention on Standards of Training, Qualification and Guarding for Fisheries Vessel Personnel (STCW-F Convention), I grant my approval to that draft Decision. That decision is based on the great importance of this Convention in the field of maritime organisation. It imposes a necessary general security, since fishing is an activity in which every year there are numerous deaths. Measures such as monitoring the qualifications of fishermen or a minimum period of compulsory prior training for vessels exceeding 24 metres in size are some examples of what this Convention imposes to improve the conditions of fishing staff. The aim of the Decision is for Member States to ratify this Convention in order to have a minimum level of training and fisheries safety at European level, bearing in mind that such training costs would not increase expenditure for States, since the EU finances such training costs.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support Rapporteur Riberio's recommendation to encourage Member States to take all necessary steps to ratify the International Maritime Organisation's International Convention on Training Standards, Certifications and Keeping a Guard of Personnel on Fishing Vessels. The objective of this Convention is to ensure that personnel on fishing vessels are qualified and able to operate under such conditions.  All Member States should have the same minimum standards for working conditions and safety on board for the purpose of reducing accidents.  Fishing is the occupation with the highest rate of accidents in the workplace. According to statistics, 24 000 fishermen lose their lives annually, so the implementation of this Convention and its prescribed rules would ensure that potential threats to the safety of human lives and property at sea are reduced.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 It is necessary to create the conditions for the Member States of the Union to ratify the International Maritime Organisation Convention on Standards of Training, Qualification and Watchkeeper of The Crew of Fishing Vessels. Uniform rules for this type of economic activity will increase the qualifications of employees while increasing the safety of the work carried out. This will lead to a reduction in accident rate and, at the same time, to an increase in the protection of the life and health of employees in this sector.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council Decision authorising Member States to become Contracting Parties, in the interests of the European Union, to the International Convention of the International Maritime Organisation on training standards, certification and shifts of fishing vessel personnel, because the European Parliament rightly considers it appropriate to extend the scope of the STCW-F Convention; , at the very least, to adopt Regulations at Union level applicable to ships of less than 24 metres in length and less than 24 metres in length, and because it also rightly calls on the Commission to draw up relevant legislative proposals.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this proposal. Fishing is the occupation with the highest accident rate; an estimated 24 000 lives a year are lost during fishing operations and anything that contributes to improved safety must be welcome.

name: Dominique Martin (NI)
text: In writing. Dominique Martin voted for this report, as he had already done in the EMPL committee. This report will enable EU member states to ratify the International Maritime Organization(IMO) International Convention on Standards for Fishing Vessel Personnel. This ratification will set the same standards in all signatory states and allow for a uniformity of the treatment of workers from one country to another. This ratification will therefore ultimately enable the fight against social dumping.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The recommendation concerning the International Maritime Organisation Convention on standards for the training of fishing crews, the issue of patents and the guard gives me a favourable opinion. One of the objectives is to ensure that the personnel on board are fit to carry out the tasks with all due precautions and relative minimal experience to minimize the possibility of safety risk. It should be stressed that fishing is a professional activity with a still very high rate of accidents and that every year it has about 24 000 fatal accidents. This requires an increase in efforts to ensure that those who work on board these vessels are guaranteed.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 On 7 July 1995, the International Maritime Organisation (IMO) adopted, in the presence of the governments of 22 EU Member States, the International Convention on Standards for the Training of Fishing Crews, the Issue of Patents and the Watchman. The aim of this agreement is to ensure the presence, on board fishing vessels, of highly qualified personnel who can adequately manage the potential risks to the safety of people and property at sea.  Since the European Union is not in a legal position to be able to ratify the STCW-F Convention, it is necessary to extend its scope by adopting applicable regulations. I voted in favour of the Ribeiro report because I believe that it adequately urge the Commission to legislate on this matter.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. With this Decision which we have supported in the European Parliament, we authorise Member States to ratify the International Convention on Standards of Training, Qualification and Guarding for Fisheries Vessel Personnel to ensure that personnel on board fishing vessels are qualified and fit for use, so that potential threats to the safety of human life or property are minimized during operations carried out on board at sea or for the marine environment. We would like to encourage all Member States that have not yet done so to implement the measures necessary for the ratification of this Convention.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. The International Convention on Standards for training, certification and guarding of personnel on board fishing vessels (STCW-F Convention for short) was established to ensure that personnel on board fishing vessels are qualified and fit for the activity themselves. Since fishing is the activity with the highest accident rate and the potential dangers to people, property at sea, etc. should be minimised, I believe that the report should be supported.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The proposed text aims to encourage states to ratify the international convention on the training of fishermen. In effect only member states can ratify this convention but after EU agreement. The training of sailors is based on a foundation of high-level skills. Visiting the Euromaritime fair last February, I had the pleasure of meeting the students of the National Maritime Higher School. I was able to measure how much passion drives seafarers. The recommendation here is not about the commercial navy but about fishing, the most accident-prone sector, however, I note that the Commission wants to force the Member States that have ratified this international convention to refrain from using international law so that disputes are dealt with under the mallet of the European Court of Justice. I vote for it with my reservation on this point.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Fishing is the professional activity that knows the highest rate of accidents, estimating the loss of 24 000 lives per year in the exercise of the activity. The STCW-F Convention contains only mandatory provisions for fishing vessels of 24 metres in length or more and with a power of 750 kW or more, but merely encourages the signatory countries to apply training standards to seafarers of vessels of the same length but of a lower power, not specifying mandatory minimum knowledge for fishing vessels of less than 24 m in length. I believe that it is appropriate to extend the scope of the STCW-F Convention or at least to adopt regulatory provisions applicable to vessels less than 24 metres at Union level. Hence my sense of vote.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. Fishing is a dangerous trade with a higher rate of occupational mortality than other occupations. The number of deaths in the fishing sector is 24,000 per year.  It was therefore urgent that Parliament send a strong message by encouraging the Member States of the Union to become parties, in the interests of the Union, to the International Convention on The Standards for Training Fishing Ship Personnel, Patenting and Watch of the International Maritime Organisation.  Currently, 22 of the 28 Member States of the European Union have already adopted this convention, which ensures that fishing vessel personnel are qualified and fit to work, and four have already ratified it.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this report, which authorises Member States to become signatories to the International Convention on Fishing Vessel Personnel of the International Maritime Organisation.

name: Bernard Monot (NI)
text: In writing. The proposal will facilitate ratification of the IMO International Convention on the Training of Fishing Vessel Personnel, adopted by the ILO in July 1995 by member states.  It also recalls that European standards take precedence when there are differing opinions in the context of intra-COMMUNITY relations. To the extent that this contributes to the harmonization of equal treatment of workers, the vote may be favourable.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. MEPs are to adopt, in plenary session, the report on the Council's plan to allow EU Member States to become a party to the International Convention on Standards for Training Fishing Ship Personnel, PatentIng and Watch of the International Maritime Organisation.  Only four EU Member States have ratified the convention. Indeed, the Union cannot ratify this convention, only the Member States are entitled to do so. However, the case law of the Court of Justice of the Union requires an authorisation from the Union to allow Member States to ratify the Convention, since fishing is under the exclusive competence of the Union.  This agreement aims to reduce the risks to the safety of fishing vessel personnel by requiring a certificate attesting to their qualification, as well as their medically recognized fitness.   Although the Member States are under the EU's fisheries tutelage, the aim, namely the accession of eu Member States to this convention, can be welcomed. That is why I voted for it.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which allows Member States to sign and ratify the 1995 International Convention on The Standards for Training Fishing Ship Personnel, PatentIng and Watch of the International Maritime Organization (IMO). While fishing is one of the most dangerous occupational activities in the world (24,000 deaths per year), this convention contains provisions to harmonize protections for people working on fishing vessels (qualification, risk limitation, promotion of vocational training).

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We call on all Member States to sign and ratify this Convention, which aims to ensure that personnel working on board fishing vessels are qualified and fit for work, so as to reduce the potential risks to the safety of people and property at sea and to the marine environment.  We believe it is important to promote a high-profile operational level in the fisheries sector by supporting the need for adequate vocational training of crews, so that we can also contribute to reducing the rate of accidents. In addition to training, which is one of the pillars of maritime safety, minimum working conditions and safety on board must also be guaranteed in relation to the prevention of accidents at work.  For this reason, we need harmonisation of standards for all Member States, with reference to international safety recommendations. In the light of these observations, we believe it is appropriate to extend the scope of the STCW-F Convention or, at the very least, to adopt new regulatory provisions applicable to vessels less than 24 metres in length at EU level; We therefore call on the Commission to legislate in this area.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The International Convention on Standards for Crews of Fishing Vessels (shortly to be referred to as the "STCW-F Convention") was drawn up by the International Maritime Organisation (IMO) in 1995, signed by 22 European countries – including Italy – and subsequently ratified by four European countries (Denmark, Latvia, Lithuania and Spain).  The Convention, which entered into force on 29 September 2012, lays down rules for the issue of certificates enabling the profession of seaman to be practised on fishing vessels, in line with the minimum requirements introduced at IMO level. As the main objective of the procedure is to authorise the other EU Member States to ratify, since the exclusive competence of the Eu ropean Union on this matter has been established in the meantime, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. – On 7 July 1995, the International Maritime Organisation (ICO) adopted in London the International Convention on Standards for the Training of Seafarers, Certification and Watchkeeping for Fishing VesselS (hereinafter referred to as the 'STCW-F Convention'). Four Member States have ratified this Convention: Spain, Denmark, Latvia and Lithuania. The European Union does not have the power to ratify the STCW-F Convention, only Member States can do so. By contrast, Member States cannot ratify the Convention without EU agreement. I voted for this resolution because, through its text, it authorises the Member States to ratify the 'STCW-F Convention'.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: and scríbhinn. \u2012 Tuarascáil toilithe é seo a thabharfaidh údarás do na Ballstáit an Coinbhinsiún Idirnáisiúnta a shíniú a leagann amach íoschaighdeáin ar thraenáil, inniúlacht agus corpacmhainn dóibh siúd a bhíonn ag obair ar árthaí iascaireachta móra chun an tsábháilteacht a fheabhsú. Mar sin chaith mé volóta i bhfabhar na tuarascála seo.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I strongly agree with the need of unified standards for the security of large fishing vessels personnel. Adequate verifications should indeed be mandatory on the qualifications and health conditions of these people. It is a dangerous profession and this can both save lives and improve the quality of this field and I welcome the final text adopted by our House.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. The STCW-F Convention is designed to ensure that personnel on board fishing vessels are qualified and suitable for the activities. Safety for on-board personnel plays a very important role here. Staff must have basic knowledge of certain areas and have performed tasks on board a ship for a specified minimum period. As a result, all staff have the same level of knowledge and could intervene in the event of an incident. In the wake of recent incidents, I voted in favour of the International Convention on Standards for Personnel on Board Fishing Vessels.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This report concerns the International Convention on Standards for Training Of Fishing, Patent and Watch Vessel Personnel (STCW-F), adopted by the International Maritime Organization on 7 July 1995. EU member states are invited to ratify this convention, which aims to ensure that personnel working on fishing vessels are qualified and fit to work and thus minimise risks to the safety of people and property at sea. Knowing that fishing is one of the highest accident rates, I supported this report by voting, which will improve the quality of work and the safety of fishermen.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The purpose of the vote is to authorise Member States to accede to the Convention. I supported the draft because the Convention contributes to the safety of crew members at sea by requiring certificates that they are qualified and fit for work.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The International Convention on Standards for the Training of Fishing Crews, Patent Issuance and Watchman was adopted by the International Maritime Organisation (IMO) on 7 July 1995 in London in the presence of 74 governments, including those of 22 current EU Member States. So far, the STCW-F Convention has been ratified by four Member States (Spain, Denmark, Latvia and Lithuania).  Given the need to establish a minimum level of training in the Union, it is appropriate to extend the scope of the STCW-F Convention or at least to adopt applicable regulatory provisions and vessels with less than 24 metres in length at Union level, urging the Commission to legislate in this area. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Florian Philippot (NI)
text: In writing. The agreement guarantees a minimum level of qualification for sailing personnel, as well as professional training standards that contribute to risk reduction. EU legislation prevails for member states in fisheries: they must comply with several directives setting out rules on the professional qualifications of seafarers, or patenting, or equal treatment in the event of workers' mobility. However, the European Union cannot, as an organisation, ratify this convention: only member states can, individually.  Several Member States have already signed this convention: this legislative proposal must simply specify the terms of compatibility between the ratification of this Convention and European legislation.  I therefore vote in favour of this report.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. \u2012 Fishing activity is the activity with the highest percentage of accidents at work, as many as 24 000 people per year die while carrying out fishing activities. This is alarming data that indicate the need to significantly better protect fishermen when carrying out their activity. The International Convention on Standards of Training, Certification and Keeping a Guard of Personnel on Fishing Vessels (STCW -F Convention) was adopted by the International Maritime Organisation (IMO) in London on 7 July 1995 by 74 States, 22 of which are now members of the European Union. However, the STCW - F Convention was ratified by only four member states (Spain, Denmark, Latvia and Lithuania).  This is also because, according to EU regulations, the EU must give its consent to member states for ratification. I therefore support giving consent to the Council authorisation of Member States to become parties, in the interests of the Union, the International Maritime Organisation International Convention on training standards, issuing certificates and keeping a guard on staff on fishing vessels.  I believe that this decision is the right step forward towards better protection of our fishermen, and I hope that soon similar standards of protection will be applicable to all fishermen, regardless of the length and strength of the boats on which they sail.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support the proposal to authorify members to become parties to the IMO International Convention on Training Standards on Fishing Vessels. The aim of these measures is that staff are qualified and adequate for work according to medical standards in order to minimise the risks and threats to the safety of life and property at sea, as well as the marine environment as a whole.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 As the statistics confirm, fishing is a professional activity with a high accident rate. For this reason, the authorisation that the European Union gives the Member States for the ratification of the STCW-F Convention is a very important step for the entire fisheries sector. The implementation of the Convention will lead to a balanced level of operation in the fisheries sector, to improve vocational training and to contribute to the reduction of accidents at work. It should also be stressed that this will not increase the training costs of the Member States, because it will be financially supported through the European Maritime affairs and Fisheries Fund.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. Today, fishing is the occupation with the highest accident rate, with an estimated 24,000 deaths per year. In the face of this worrying finding, the Union has decided to react and encourage Member States to take the necessary measures.  I am pleased to have voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to ensure that the personnel working on fishing vessels have the necessary qualifications, thereby limiting the risk of endangerment and death.  In addition, this text is of particular importance in authorising Member States to ratify the 1995 International Convention while ensuring compliance with the EU's exclusive competences in recognising regulated professions in this sector.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The International Convention of the International Maritime Organisation on Standards of Training, Certification and Service of Rooms for Seafarers of Fishing Vessels ('STCW-F Convention') was adopted by the International Maritime Organisation on 7 July 1995 in London. The Purpose of the Convention is to ensure that personnel on fishing vessels have the qualifications (proven by official certificate) and the necessary suitability for work (according to medical certificate) in order to reduce as much as possible potential threats to the safety of human lives, goods at sea, or to the marine environment during operations on board fishing vessels. The Union cannot ratify the STCW-F Convention and it is only possible for Member States to do so. However, in accordance with the AETR case-law of the Court of Justice of the EU, Member States may not ratify the STCW-F Convention without union authorisation, since the provisions on the recognition of regulated professions by Union citizens on board fishing vessels affect the exercise of the Union's exclusive competence in this area. The purpose of this Decision is to authorise Member States to ratify the STCW-F Convention in accordance with the exclusive competences of the Union. I voted in favour.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This is a document under which Member States are authorised to ratify the International Convention on Standards for Seafarers of Fishing Vessels. The aim is to create a level of fair performance in the fisheries sector, encouraging vocational training, which will certainly contribute greatly to reducing casualties, which is the highest rate of accidents, with an estimated loss of 24,000 lives per year. For these reasons I voted in favour of this report.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. With 24,000 seafarer deaths each year, fishing is the professional activity that officially records the most work-related accidents. The European Parliament's vote means to push Member States to authorise the ratification of the 1995 International Convention (STCW-F). 20 years later, only four Member States have ratified the text. These countries are therefore the only countries where fishermen benefit from secure working conditions under the Convention, safety training and patents guaranteeing the quality of personnel on boats over 24 metres.  In reality, the EU can only give its approval to a ratification of the agreement which must take place at national level, even if it is European legislation that takes precedence in the event of a conflict. The International Maritime Organization (IMO) aims to enforce these safety standards and ensure a significant reduction in accidents in the maritime sector. It also encourages Member States to adopt their own safety laws for seafarers working on boats under 24 metres this time. Unfortunately, they are not yet considered in the international convention. #MRK

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I consider that recommendations on vocational training and safety at work under the STCW-F Convention (International Convention of the International Maritime Organisation on Standards of Training, Certification and Room Service for Seafarers of Fishing Vessels) are advantageous to all Member States. These are standards that must also be required of all vessels operated in Eu waters. I therefore vote in favour of training as a foundation for promoting equal work and safety for fisheries professionals.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I supported this Recommendation at first reading and by the abbreviated procedure by which Parliament approves the Council's decision to authorise Member States to ratify the STCW-F Convention under the EU's exclusive competences in the recognition of regulated professions practiced by EU nationals on board fishing vessels. The purpose of the Convention is to ensure that personnel on board fishing vessels are qualified and fit for use, so that threats to the safety of human life, goods at sea or marine environment are minimized during on-board operations. Provisions are mandatory for vessels over 24 metres in force and a driving power of 750 Kw or more and concern captains, officers, machine officers and radio operators. Spain had already ratified it. From Parliament, we take the opportunity to recommend the establishment of a minimum level of training at EU level and believe that it is appropriate to extend the scope of the Convention or at least adopt regulatory provisions applicable to vessels of less than 24 metres, so we call on the Commission to legislate on this.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. The purpose of the vote on this STCW-F agreement is to ensure that personnel working on fishing vessels are qualified (and have an official certificate certifying it) and are fit to work (after a medical examination) and, therefore, to minimize risks to the safety of persons and/or property at sea, or to the marine environment, during operations on board ships. The purpose of this decision is to authorise Member States to ratify the STCW-F Convention in accordance with the EU's exclusive competences in recognising regulated professions carried out by EU nationals on fishing vessels.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this recommendation because it is in line with the objective of the STCW-F Convention, which is to ensure that personnel operating on board fishing vessels are qualified (and have an official certificate attesting to it) and fit for work (following a medical examination), so that the potential risks to the safety of persons and property at sea or to the marine environment are minimised during operations on board fishing vessels.  Following the Court of Justice's AETS ruling on external competence, Member States cannot ratify the STCW-F Convention without EU authorisation as the provisions on the recognition of regulated professions exercised by EU citizens operating on board fishing vessels restrict the exercise of the Eu ropean Union's exclusive competence in this area.  That is why I supported the decision to authorise Member States to ratify the STCW-F Convention in accordance with the exclusive competences of the European Union with regard to the recognition of regulated professions exercised by EU citizens on board fishing vessels.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. I have chosen to vote in favour of the International Convention on Standards for Crews of Fishing Vessels, as this Convention, which entered into force on 29 September 2012, lays down rules for the issue of certificates enabling seaman to practise as a seaman on fishing vessels in line with the minimum requirements introduced at IMO level. The main objective of the procedure is to authorise the other EU Member States to ratify, since the exclusive competence of the Eu ropean Union on this matter has since been established.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour of the Recommendation on the draft Council Decision authorising Member States to accede to the International Convention on Standards of Training, Qualification and Guarding for Fisheries Vessel Personnel of the International Maritime Organization. The EU cannot join, and Member States need prior EU authorisation because the provisions on the recognition of regulated professions practiced by EU nationals on board fishing vessels affect the exercise of the EU's exclusive competence in this area. The objective of that convention, moreover, is to ensure that personnel on board fishing vessels over 24 m in size are qualified and fit for use, so that potential threats to the safety of human life or property at sea or to the marine environment are minimized during on-board operations.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. On 7 July 1995, the International Convention on Training, Qualification and Guarding Standards for Fisheries Vessel Personnel was adopted on 7 July 1995 at an international conference in London involving more than 74 governments, including 22 of the current Member States of the European Union.  The objective of the Convention is to ensure that staff present on fishing vessels are appropriately qualified and in good health. The International Convention contradicts certain points of Directive 2005/36/EC, which mutually recognise the professional qualifications of the Member States by limiting this recognition to the signatory States of the Convention. The ratification of this Convention therefore requires prior authorisation from the EU and a written commitment by the Member States where, in the event of a conflict, Community legislation shall prevail. This report allows the ratification of this Convention to Member States which have not signed it and clarifies the situation of those who have already ratified it. That's why I voted for it.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 With today's vote, Parliament has given its approval to the proposal for a Council decision which aims to authorise Member States to ratify the International Convention on Standards for the Training of Fishing Crews, the Granting of Patents and the Watchman.  I have chosen to vote in favour of this recommendation because I believe that we must try to minimise the potential risks to the safety of people and property on board fishing vessels or to the marine environment, ensuring that staff are adequately qualified and fit for work. We need only recall that fishing is a professional activity with a very high rate of accidents and that, according to some estimates, fatal accidents amount to around 24 000 per year.  I therefore hope that the national authorities will now proceed without delay towards the ratification of the Convention in such a way as to contribute to reducing the number of accidents and making fishing activities better and, above all, safer.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted positively on the proposed report because it gives Member States the possibility to become parties to the International Convention of the International Maritime Organisation on Standards of Training, Certification and Room Service for Seafarers of Fishing Vessels.  Every effort to increase the responsibilities and training opportunities of sea professionals is positive and this effort must extend to the most remote points of European territory. Coming from the Azores, I consider it essential to structure training centers in the Azores islands, especially when they become the appropriate place to allow the widespread, intensive and sustainable use of the sea.  In the Azores, the sea represents about one million square kilometers and the land about 2300. It is clear that the future of these islands implies a specialised and applied knowledge of the maritime domain.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in support of the decision authorising Member States to become party, in the interest of the European Union, to the International Convention on Standards of Training, Certification and Watchkeeping for Fishing Vessel Personnel of the International Maritime Organization. The decision will enable Member States to ratify the STCW-F Convention without encroaching on the EU’s exclusive competence regarding the recognition of regulated professions pursed by EU nationals on board fishing vessels.

name: Jutta Steinruck (S&D)
text: Writing. I welcome the vote on the International Convention on Standards for the Training of Personnel on Board Fishing Vessels. It is important that minimum standards for training and further training in Europe are set for all workers. In addition, working hours are to be observed. This will ensure that the staff on board are sufficiently qualified and well-fit to carry out this heavy and demanding activity. This ultimately leads to minimisation of potential hazards and can significantly increase the safety of seafarers on board. Continuing vocational training is also intended to create a level playing field in the fisheries sector.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for this resolution aimed at empowering Member States to become parties, in the interest of the Union, the International Maritime Organisation Convention on training standards, issuing certificates and keeping a guard of staff on fishing vessels. It is necessary to ensure that staff on fishing vessels are adequately qualified and perform appropriate tasks, so that potential threats to the safety of life and/or property at sea, of the marine environment, wherever possible, are minimised.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the International Convention on Standards of Training, Certification and Watchkeeping for Fishing Vessel Personnel. By ratifying the Convention, Member States are required to ensure that personnel sailing on fishing vessels are qualified and physically fit for the job. This will be important in promoting the safety of personnel, property and the marine environment.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the recommendation on the International Convention on Standards of Training, Certification and Watch keeping for Fishing Vessel Personnel, signed in 1995, as it will allow Member States to ratify the Convention without infringing on the EU's executive competence in regards to the ‘recognition of regulated professions pursed by EU nationals on board fishing vessels'. The importance of this Convention is evident as the highest accident rates occur when fishing- approximately of 24 000 lives are lost, per year, in fishing incidents. The recommendation supports a Convention that aims at helping ensure safety measures for all life and property on sea. The countries that signed the STCW-F Convention in 1995 are to ensure mandatory training for personnel using vessels that are 24 meters or more in length, while countries who did not sign the Convention are encouraged to do so as its training requirements will ensure that the personnel using fishing vessels are qualified to do so- the qualification entails an official certificate accompanied by a medical certificate. Furthermore, the signatory countries are not obliged, but encouraged to adapt laws that will require training and certification standards for smaller vessels, or vessels of less strength, as it will help minimise the high number of accidents that occur at sea.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal because, although I am not entirely convinced of the correctness of the Convention in view of the possible increase in regulatory burdens and/or other costs, I agree that Member States should be able to accede to this Convention if they consider it appropriate.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We consider it very important both to develop a sound training content and to certify it properly, especially for people with increased responsibilities (masters, officers, ship engineers, radio operators) and in particular in the categories of fishing vessels over 24 metres long and at least 750kw in power, where specific high capacities are required.  We welcome the step taken and that is why we voted in favour.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The Staff Safety Treaty of large fishing vessels does not include smaller vessels, but they make up the majority of the southern European fishing fleet.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. Finally, I want to say! Of course, I voted in favour of the text. I would like to remind you that fishing has the highest rate of accidents, with an estimated 24,000 deaths per year. This legislation is timely.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D)
text: In writing. Fishing is the professional worker with the highest rate of accidents and deaths at work, so we must act on the causes of this sad toll. Vocational training reduces accidents and prevents them by preparing sailors for risk situations at sea. For example, the 1995 IMO STCW-F Convention aims to ensure that personnel working on fishing vessels are qualified, with an official certificate certifying them fit for work.  As rapporteur for opinion, I have recommended that the provisions of the Convention be incorporated into Community law, in order to extend it to vessels less than 24 metres and to avoid it being a levelling down, since some Member States have higher requirements. Workers' rights to living and working conditions on board must also change. For example, there is an urgent need for ILO Convention 188 on fisheries work to be ratified and incorporated into EU law. Beyond these issues, the quality of the work tool is also a safety factor. Fishing vessels with an average age of more than 30 years must be urgently renewed.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour of the Recommendation on the draft Council Decision authorising Member States to accede to the International Convention on Standards of Training, Qualification and Guarding for Fisheries Vessel Personnel of the International Maritime Organization. The EU cannot join, and Member States need prior EU authorisation because the provisions on the recognition of regulated professions practiced by EU nationals on board fishing vessels affect the exercise of the EU's exclusive competence in this area. The objective of that convention, moreover, is to ensure that personnel on board fishing vessels over 24 m in size are qualified and fit for use, so that potential threats to the safety of human life or property at sea or to the marine environment are minimized during on-board operations.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (NI)
text: In writing. Everything that falls within the eu's domain of fisheries, however, cannot, as an organisation, ratify this convention. Only Member States can do so, individually.  This agreement guarantees a minimum level of qualification for sailing personnel, as well as professional training standards that contribute to risk reduction. But EU legislation prevails for member states on fisheries; they must comply with several directives setting out rules on the professional qualifications of seafarers, or patenting, or equal treatment in the event of workers' mobility.  I vote FOR this convention because it encourages equal treatment of workers and therefore would allow French staff to be better able to defend themselves than they can today.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Of course I supported the recommendation. I think it is very important that the crew work on the fishing vessels in the safest possible conditions. Fishing is a sector where many people are injured and killed at work, with more than 20 000 people a year.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour of the Recommendation on the draft Council Decision authorising Member States to accede to the International Convention on Standards of Training, Qualification and Guarding for Fisheries Vessel Personnel of the International Maritime Organization. The EU cannot join, and Member States need prior EU authorisation because the provisions on the recognition of regulated professions practiced by EU nationals on board fishing vessels affect the exercise of the EU's exclusive competence in this area. The objective of that convention, moreover, is to ensure that personnel on board fishing vessels over 24 m in size are qualified and fit for use, so that potential threats to the safety of human life or property at sea or to the marine environment are minimized during on-board operations.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report as the Convention aims to ensure that fishing vessel staff receive the training and qualifications necessary to carry out their work, therefore improving their safety conditions.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. This Convention had already been ratified by Spain because it is an improvement in maritime safety and helps to maintain and develop the knowledge and skills of fishing vessel personnel. That is why we welcome this draft report which gives its consent to the proposal for a Council Decision.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. On 7 July 1995, the International Convention on Training, Qualification and Guarding Standards for Fisheries Vessel Personnel was adopted on 7 July 1995 at an international conference in London involving more than 74 governments, including 22 of the current Member States of the European Union.  The objective of the Convention is to ensure that staff present on fishing vessels are appropriately qualified and in good health. The International Convention contradicts certain points of Directive 2005/36/EC, which mutually recognise the professional qualifications of the Member States by limiting this recognition to the signatory States of the Convention. The ratification of this Convention therefore requires prior authorisation from the EU and a written commitment by the Member States where, in the event of a conflict, Community legislation shall prevail. This report allows the ratification of this Convention to Member States which have not signed it and clarifies the situation of those who have already ratified it. That's why I voted for it.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'In the context of the Convention on Standards for The Crew of Fishing Vessels, I voted in favour.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The International Convention on Standards of Training, Certification and Watch-keeping for Fishing Vessel Personnel of the International Maritime Organisation (hereinafter called the STCW-F Convention), was adopted on 7 July 1995 at the International Conference held in London from 26 June to 7 July 1995, with the participation of 74 governments and amongst them 22 current European Union Member States. Professional activities related to the STCW-F Convention are regulated in most of the Member States. In accordance with the AETR case law of the Court of Justice on external competence, the Member States are not allowed to ratify the STCW-F Convention without European Union authorisation as the provisions concerning the recognition of regulated professions pursed by EU nationals on board fishing vessels affect the exercise of the European Union's exclusive competence in this area. As regards those Member States that have already ratified the Convention before the entry into force of the proposed Decision, they are required to deposit with the IMO Secretary-General a statement whereby they acknowledge that EU law shall prevail in case of conflict in relations between Member States.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. The International Convention on Standards for Training, Certification and Guard ingestion of personnel on board fishing vessels (STCW-F Convention for short) was established to ensure that staff on board fishing vessels are qualified and fit for the activity themselves. Since fishing is the activity with the highest accident rate and the potential dangers to people, property at sea, etc. should be minimised, I believe that the report should be supported.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the Council Decision authorising Member States to become Contracting Parties to the International Convention of the International Maritime Organisation on training standards, certification and shifts of fishing vessel personnel, as the objective of the STCW-F Convention is to ensure that personnel on board fishing vessels have the skills and competences required for this work in order to minimise all potential risks to its safety of their lives.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The International Convention of the International Maritime Organisation on Standards of Training, Certification and Room Service for Seafarers of Fishing Vessels was adopted on 7 July 1995 at an International Conference attended by 74 governments, 22 of the current EU. The purpose of the Convention is to ensure that personnel on board fishing vessels have professional qualifications proven by official certificate and that their fitness for work is proven by medical services. These measures aim to increase safety conditions in this work, as well as minimize threats to the marine environment. For countries that sign the Convention, these provisions are mandatory only for vessels with a minimum of 24 metres in length and a power of 750kw. This Recommendation agrees with the possibility for the Council to authorise the Member States to sign that Convention, if they so seem, which seems to us to be positive. We voted for it.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 For the recommendation on a draft Council Decision authorising I voted in favour of the International Convention (STCW-F) of the International Maritime Organisation on standards for training, certification and watch-watchment for personnel on board fishing vessels, as the aim of the Convention is to ensure that personnel on board fishing vessels are competent and fit for work, thus minimising the potential threat to life at sea and reducing the threat to the marine environment during activities on fishing vessels. The Convention provides that staff must have minimal knowledge in specific fields and minimum experience of working on board a ship. The Convention may be ratified exclusively by the Member States and they need the European Union's power of ratification. Eu decisions on the recognition of regulated professions carried out by EU citizens on fishing vessels affect the exercise of the European Union's exclusive competence in this area. The proposed decision thus seeks to encourage Member States to take all necessary measures to ratify the Convention without delay. While the provisions of the Convention apply only to personnel working on ships of at least 24 metres in length, although most accidents at sea occur on shorter ships. The European Parliament therefore proposes to extend the scope of the Convention, or at least at European Union level, to adopt rules for ships of less than 24 metres in length.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The late implementation of several EU programmes (some as important as fisheries, cohesion, social or asylum funds) has resulted in many of the budget transfers allocated for 2014 not being used. Draft amending budget No 2/2015 continues the routine procedure by which unused appropriations the previous year are transferred to this year's budget, in compliance with the general guidelines of the Multiannual Financial Framework. While I regret the consequences of this delay, and despite the limitations of the European budget, I voted in favour of this project, making it easier for these amounts to be available in 2015.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 As the negotiations on the Multiannual Financial Framework took a long time to complete, many of the appropriations planned for 2014 remained unused. The amount that had been left unused and could not be transferred amounted to EUR 21 billion and concerned all Member States. In order not to lose this money, the European Commission has presented a proposal to amend the Multiannual Financial Framework and transfer this money to 2015. Following the revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework, we are now amending the 2015 budget so that this money can be used.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. I welcome this report, as the funds not used due to the late adoption of the programmes under shared management must be carried over from 2014 to the following years in order to avoid unfair treatment of certain Member States and regions. However, given the large amount of unpaid invoices, the Commission should take the most out of this situation to ensure that this postponement does not create further bottlenecks and propose appropriate solutions. It is also essential that all programmes are launched as quickly as possible in order to avoid further delays.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted for this deliberation because at a time when Europe recognizes investment deficits, it was to percolate 21 billion European funds. However, I regret the rigidity of our budgetary procedures which led to the delay in the release of these funds.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to transfer unused EU support in 2014 to the following year. The proposal aims to clarify the 'ceiling' of the EU budget for 2014-2017, which would allow the unused EUR 21 billion in 2014. 2015-2017 and ensure the financing of delayed programmes. It is proposed to transfer EUR 21.1 billion. In three instalments of the outstanding commitments of certain funds from 2014 to the following year: EUR 16.5 billion. Eur 4.5 billion would be allocated to cover the commitments of the EU budget for 2015, EUR 4.5 billion. In 2016, €0.1 billion was allocated to the European Commission. In 2017, the Under the consent procedure, Parliament can only either approve or reject the proposal without amendments, which have already been formally unanimously approved by the Council of the EU.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. After abstaining on the vote on the Obrycht/Thomas report on the postponement of unused appropriations in 2014, I have again chosen to abstain on this draft amending budget, because the benefits it presents - I am thinking of the sums paid to the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development - do not allow the destination of part of these credits to be approved for the Asylum, Migration, Integration Fund, which, as the name suggests, is aimed at facilitating legal immigration.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The purpose is to transfer unused credits from 2014 to fiscal 2015 up to the maximum possible. This should, in particular, encourage efforts to increase and create jobs. That is why I support this report. As the report points out, however, the long-term impact of this deferral on the overall payment situation must remain extremely vigilant. The commission will therefore have to monitor its implementation closely in order to avoid the "snowball" effect.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the amending budget because it meets all established legal requirements and is an improvement in budget management with adjustments. It is, in turn, a clear improvement for job creation and growth. It also aims to eliminate unequal treatment between some Member States, regions and programmes by improving cohesion policy. Please note that in 2014 commitment appropriations amounting to EUR 21 043 639 478 were cancelled, which corresponds to programmes that were unable to commit in 2014 or be extended to 2015, and which are expected to transfer most of these allocations to the 2015 budget, increasing it by EUR 16 476.40 million and EUR 2.5 million for the Pre-Accession Aid Instrument , integrating other smaller transfers into the budgets for the 2016 and 2017 financial years. This management will also require a flexible attitude on the part of the Commission towards the difficulties that different actors may encounter and, above all, management that avoids the accumulation of outstanding invoices.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. This vote concerns the draft amending budget following the adoption of the amendment to the regulation (EU, Euratom) No. 1311/2013 to allow the postponement to subsequent years of unused commitment appropriations in 2014 (21 billion euros, or 15% of the budget for 2014), in accordance with Article 19 of the Multi-Year Financial Framework. As the legal acts setting out the rules for the implementation of the funds were adopted later than planned, this effectively created a delay in the conclusion of the agreement on the Multi-Year Financial Framework for the period 2014-2020. These credit deferrals from year to year feed the stock of unpaid bills (which amounted to about 24 billion euros at the end of 2014, despite the 4.8 billion euros obtained in the trilogue at the end of 2014). We are being sold the situation as simple technical adjustments, whereas in the end, local authorities are paying the price for these delays and unpaid bills. Nevertheless, in accordance with the Obrycht/Thomas report, I have decided to abstain on this draft amending budget.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this measure because the late adoption of cohesion policy regulations for the period 2014-2020 meant that it was impossible to adopt all operational programmes in good time. In practice, the entire MFF has not been realistically programmed, to the point that, in order to cope with their own inefficiency, the European institutions must shift the funds to subsequent years in order to cope with their own inefficiency.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. I've abstained. The unused appropriations for 2014 are mainly carried over to the financial year 2015. I believe that it would have been better to have unused funds repaid to the Member States, where they could be used for job-creating green investments in the public sector. That's why I choose to abstain.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. The revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework Regulation is a common procedure at the beginning of each MFF period, and the corresponding draft amending budget should be in line with this review. A significant number of programmes could not be adopted in 2014, which is why commitment appropriations for shared management programmes amounting to EUR 21 billion expired. The Commission has proposed, and Parliament endorsed, that these appropriations be transferred to the maximum extent possible to the 2015 financial year, which will avoid unequal treatment between certain Member States, regions and operational programmes, speed up the implementation and implementation of cohesion policy and help to avoid the concentration of payments at the end of the multiannual financial framework period. That's why I voted for it.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it supports the amendment of the EU Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) and recalls that the revision of the MFF is a standard procedure at the beginning of each MFF period. In this case, the multiannual financial framework shall be adjusted to allow the carry-over of unused appropriations in 2014 to subsequent years in excess of the corresponding expenditure ceilings. Parliament welcomed the transfer of the maximum possible amount of unused appropriations for 2014 to the financial year 2015, which will help to avoid unfair terms for certain Member States, regions and operational programmes, as well as speed up the implementation of cohesion policy and the achievement of its results and avoid the concentration of payments at the end of the MFF period.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Article 19 of the MED Regulation provides for the revision of the MED in the event of the late adoption of new rules or programmes implemented under shared management in order to allow the transfer of funds not used in 2014 to the following years in excess of the corresponding ceilings. The amount of discontinued commitment appropriations for programmes implemented in 2014 under shared management under Article 19 of the MTMS Regulation amounts to EUR 21 043 639 478 at current prices, which corresponds to the parts of the programmes due in 2014 which could not be tied up in 2014 or transferred to 2015. I support the fact that appropriations have been carried over as far as possible to the financial year 2015, as this avoids unfair treatment of Member States, regions and operational programmes, speeds up the implementation and implementation of cohesion policy and helps to avoid the concentration of payments at the end of the MTMD. As a member of the Fidesz-KDNP delegation, I supported the adoption of the report in line with the position of the People's Party.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. \u2012 Article 19. The multiannual budget contract provides for the possibility of financing projects that are too late to close the budget year. As projects are community service and based on European values, I support the proposal.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted ʽyesʼ to this report on the revision of the multiannual financial framework since it is of paramount importance that the unused appropriations for the year 2014 be transferred to subsequent years in order to contribute to the creation of jobs and growth.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. The proposed regulation relates to the adoption of an amending budget to revise the multi-year financial framework for the period 2014-2020. This revision follows the postponement of the FEDER and FEADER appropriations not committed in 2015 due to serious delays in the signing of partnership agreements and in the adoption of operational programmes. While the European Union is facing record arrears of invoices of 24 billion euros, the deferral of these commitment appropriations will have a heavy impact on the overall payment situation. In addition, the draft amending budget proposes an increase of EUR 2,500,000 for the pre-accession aid instrument, which is totally out of place given the need to control spending, particularly those for the accession of new Member States.  For all these reasons, I abstained on the vote of this draft amending budget.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Amending Draft Budget on the amendment of the Multiannual Financial Framework for the period 2014-2020. The budget shall be presented together with the Commission's parallel proposal to revise the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) for the period 2014-2020 in accordance with Article 19 of the MFF Regulation and shall practically reschedule the related commitments for the coming years.  This project covers all 28 Member States and aims to avoid delays in the adoption of programmes and ensures the smooth implementation of programmes supporting growth and employment. It is equally important that payment appropriations in this context do not change in any way.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the adoption of the measure. The entire MFF has not been realistically programmed, to the point that, with measures such as this, the European institutions have to shift the funds to subsequent years.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the Council's position on draft amending budget No 2/2015 of the European Union for the financial year 2015, Section III – Commission. Indeed, the report has the merit of emphasising that it is essential for European citizens and for the economies of all Member States that unused appropriations for the financial year 2014 can be transferred to subsequent years, in order to contribute to job creation and growth, to avoid the unfair treatment of certain Member States, regions and operational programmes, and to speed up the implementation and achievement of cohesion policy objectives.  I consider the report to be very timely as it emphasises that the decision to transfer most unused appropriations in 2014 to 2015 may require a flexible approach on the part of the Commission to address any issues arising from an uneven financial profile, which could produce unused commitment appropriations in the period 2014-2020.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. It needs to be stated for clarification that the increase does not provide new money – instead it is money being moved from 2014 to 2015 as various programmes were not adopted by the end of 2014. It was necessary to vote in favour of this report in order to enable this technical change.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the Council position on Draft amending budget No 2/2015 of the European Union for the financial year 2015, Section III – Commission. It proposes an increase of EUR 16 476.4 million in commitment appropriations in 2015 for the various funds under shared management under subheading 1b, heading 2 and heading 3. It also proposes an increase of EUR 2.5 million for the Instrument for Pre-accession Assistance (IPA II) under heading 4, to preserve similar treatment between contributions from heading 4 and heading 1b to the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) European territorial cooperation (ETC) programmes.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the amending budget, which serves to regularise the fact that unused appropriations during an annual financial year are transferred to subsequent years. This makes it possible to adjust the budget accordingly and aims to avoid an accumulation at the end of the multiannual financial framework of payments not made.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This measure amends the 2015 budget following the approval by the European Parliament at the previous plenary session of the allocation to the 2015 budget of funds not committed in 2014. As noted in the opinion of the Committee on Regional Development, the late adoption of the cohesion policy regulations for the period 2014-2020 meant that it was impossible to adopt all operational programmes in good time. The project aims to transfer to 2015 almost all programmes for economic and social cohesion, with the exception of ERDF contributions to cross-border programmes under the Pre-Accession Instrument (IPA) and the European Neighbourhood Instrument (ENI) which are instead transferred to 2017. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of approving draft amending budget No 2/2015, as I agree with the transfer of most unused allocations to the 2015 budget and with the transfer of smaller allocations to draft budgets for the 2016-2017 financial years.  For 2015 alone, the draft amending budget proposes an increase of EUR 16476.4 million in commitment appropriations for the various funds under shared management. Both for European citizens and for the economies of all Member States, it is vital that unused appropriations can be transferred each year to subsequent years to help create jobs and grow.  Nevertheless, I hope that the Commission will carry out its monitoring activities in order to prevent the postponement of these appropriations from year to year from having a negative effect on the payment of invoices. If we manage to overcome this dangerous obstacle, we will be able to create a virtuous circle which will breathe new life into the economies of the Member States.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In view of the delay in adopting certain regulations and operational programmes concerning European Funds, I considered it appropriate to vote in favour of changing the financial framework for 2014/2020 by transferring unused resources in 2014 to the current budget.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ It is in the best interests of EU citizens for unused appropriations for the year 2014 to be transferred to subsequent years in order to contribute to the creation of jobs and growth. I thus voted in favour of the report.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I agree that unused funds in 2014 due to the delay in adopting some programmes are reallocated to subsequent years in the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014-2020. I therefore think it is important that there should be a real possibility of reallocation of these funds.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The late implementation of several EU programmes (some as important as fisheries, cohesion, social or asylum funds) has resulted in many of the budget transfers allocated for 2014 not being usable. Draft amending budget No 2/2015 continues the routine procedure by which unused appropriations the previous year are transferred to this year's budget, in compliance with the general guidelines of the Multiannual Financial Framework. While I regret the consequences of this delay, and despite the limitations of the European budget, I voted in favour of this project, making it easier for these amounts to be available in 2015.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
