text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which focuses on the fact that a significant amount of programmes could not be adopted in 2014, and thus commitment appropriations for programmes under shared management lapsed in 2014 for an amount of EUR 21 billion. This is a clearly defined procedural financial mechanism.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the revision at the beginning of the multiannual financial framework. In the event of delayed adoption of rules or programmes under shared management, unused allocations must be transferred to subsequent years and the annual management exercises must be aligned.  Draft amending budget No 2/2015 provides for the transfer of most unused allocations to the 2015 budget and a smaller part will be allocated to the 2016 and 2017 financial years. The weighting of the principles of predictability and budgetary flexibility is a prerequisite for the realisation of the interests of European citizens. It is strategic to know the availability of the framework in advance and then to intervene with flexibility as a safeguard clause.  In order not to create a flaw in the 'Europe system' in programme management, it is useful to avoid a negative long-term impact by closely monitoring their implementation. What is at stake is the effectiveness and efficiency of cohesion policy funding, which aims to create jobs and, more generally, support the economic growth of the European Union.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this draft amending budget, because the delay in the adoption of programmes should not penalise the recipients of European funds. The multi-year financial framework must therefore be flexible to ensure that unused commitment credits in 2014 are used in 2015, or in subsequent years.  However, I call for vigilance on this type of practice in the future, because we must not get into the habit of reprogramming the appropriations already committed to a later exercise.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report aims to revise the 2014-2020 multi-year financial framework to allow the appropriation of commitments to the tune of $21 billion for fiscal years 2015, 2016 and 2017. This amount corresponds to funds not spent during the last 2007-2013 multi-year financial framework that could not be committed in 2014. Although this decision should relieve the construction of the 2015, 2016 and 2017 budgets in terms of payment appropriations, it does not solve the problem of unpaid payments of member states, which still amount to 24.4 billion. It is necessary for the European Commission to take the initiative quickly to find a solution to this problem. For all these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Article 19 of the MED Regulation provides for the revision of the MED in the event of the late adoption of new rules or programmes implemented under shared management in order to allow the transfer of funds not used in 2014 to the following years in excess of the corresponding ceilings. The amount of discontinued commitment appropriations for programmes implemented in 2014 under shared management under Article 19 of the MTMS Regulation amounts to EUR 21 043 639 478 at current prices, which corresponds to the parts of the programmes due in 2014 which could not be tied up in 2014 or transferred to 2015. The report welcomes the fact that appropriations have been carried over as far as possible to the financial year 2015, as this avoids unfair treatment of Member States, regions and operational programmes, accelerates the implementation and implementation of cohesion policy and helps to avoid the concentration of payments at the end of the MTMD. The Fidesz-KDNP delegation supports the adoption of the report in line with the position of the People's Party.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 After voting on 15 April 2015 on the proposal for a Council regulation amending Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 1311/2013 laying down the multiannual financial framework for the years 2014-2020, adjusting the MFF ceilings with the current draft amending budget No 2/2015: revision of the MFF 2014-2020, the European Parliament agrees that the corresponding appropriations for 2014 should be amended to allow unused resources in 2014. I supported this proposal because by transferring the appropriations from 2014 to 2015, we would prevent delays in payments under many operational programmes, which would have negative consequences for regions and cities and therefore for European citizens. In addition to my support, I would like to once again call on the Commission to pay particular attention to the least developed regions in the European Union, as provided for in Article 174 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. In poor regions, every Eurocent european investment is valued and the benefits of membership of the European Union are most visible.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report because the possibility of using appropriations not used in previous years is a step in the right direction, provided, of course, that this is not an accounting ploy.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the amendment of the MED. This is necessary in order to transfer commitment appropriations not yet used from the 2014-2020 framework budget, amounting to EUR 21.1 billion, to the budget for the coming years. This situation has been caused by delays in the adoption of operational programmes for cohesion, rural development and fisheries and their legislation, which is largely due to the European Commission's delay.  I therefore call on the Commission to do its best to swiftly approve the member states' operational programmes for cohesion, rural development and fisheries, which are still to be adopted.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Article 19 of the MFF Regulation provides for a revision of the multiannual financial framework in the event of delays in the adoption of rules or programmes under shared management in order to transfer unused appropriations in 2014 to subsequent years, in addition to the corresponding expenditure ceilings, with more than EUR 21 billion last year. I believe that the practice should be that unused appropriations in one financial year should be transferred to the following financial year in order to contribute to job creation and growth, which would ensure that the commitments made in the MFF are respected.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote against this change to the MFF in view of the late adoption of the cohesion policy regulations for the period 2014-20, which meant that it was impossible to adopt all operational programmes in good time.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The possibility of using appropriations not used in previous years is moving in the right direction provided that this action is not an accounting ploy. My vote is in favour of the report on the Council's position on draft amending budget No 1/ 2004. 2/2015 of the European Union for the financial year 2015, Section III - Commission

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this proposal to transfer the bulk of the allocations that were not used in 2014 to 2015, as adopted with unanimity in the Committee on Budgets.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Article 19 of the MED Regulation provides for the revision of the MED in the event of the late adoption of new rules or programmes implemented under shared management in order to allow the transfer of funds not used in 2014 to the following years in excess of the corresponding ceilings. The amount of discontinued commitment appropriations for programmes implemented in 2014 under shared management under Article 19 of the MTMS Regulation amounts to EUR 21 043 639 478 at current prices, which corresponds to the parts of the programmes due in 2014 which could not be tied up in 2014 or transferred to 2015. The report welcomes the fact that appropriations have been carried over as far as possible to the financial year 2015, as this avoids unfair treatment of Member States, regions and operational programmes, accelerates the implementation and implementation of cohesion policy and helps to avoid the concentration of payments at the end of the MTMD. The Fidesz-KDNP delegation supports the adoption of the report in line with the position of the People's Party.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour considering that draft amending budget No 2/2015 proposes an increase of EUR 16 476.4 million in commitment appropriations in 2015 for the different funds under shared management, as well as an increase of EUR 2.5 million for the Pre-Accession Aid Instrument. It is essential for European citizens and the economy of all Member States that unused appropriations in the 2014 financial year can be transferred to the following financial years in order to contribute to job creation and growth.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Mr Gardiazabal Rubial's report on draft amending budget No 2/2015 of the European Union for the financial year 2015.  I think it is important to remember, as the report does, that it is essential for european citizens and for the economies of all The Member States that unused appropriations for the financial year 2014 can be transferred to subsequent years, in order to contribute to job creation and growth, and above all to speed up the implementation and achievement of the objectives of cohesion policy.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of Mrs Gardiaz-bal Rubial's report on the amendment of the multiannual financial framework for 2014-2020, because it is a technical, overall well-balanced process of the amending budget, which I support in this form.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I support Mrs Gardiazabal Rubial's report on draft EU amending budget No 2/2015. I believe it is essential – for the citizens and economies of all Member States – that the eur 21 billion unused in 2014 can be carried over to the following years. It is also an important financial boost to further development and to the overarching objective of job creation and economic stimulation.  Having watched the European Commission and the Member States in the Committee on Budgets over the years, I do not see a clear tendency to comply rigorously with financial management. The overall error rate has been steadily increasing since 2009 and was estimated at as much as 4.7% in 2013. I support the report's idea of forcing greater transparency on the part of the Member States in cooperation with the Commission and, if there is a failure to comply with the provisions, to penalize them.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of Draft amending budget No 2/2015. I believe it is crucial that the unused appropriations for 2014 can be transferred to the upcoming years in order to contribute to the creation of jobs and growth.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which supports the amendment of the Multiannual Financial Framework of the European Union, in order to clarify the financial framework and to reallocate unused funds into the following budget year.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Article 19 of the MED Regulation provides for the revision of the MED in the event of the late adoption of new rules or programmes implemented under shared management in order to allow the transfer of funds not used in 2014 to the following years in excess of the corresponding ceilings. The amount of discontinued commitment appropriations for programmes implemented in 2014 under shared management under Article 19 of the MTMS Regulation amounts to EUR 21 043 639 478 at current prices, which corresponds to the parts of the programmes due in 2014 which could not be tied up in 2014 or transferred to 2015. The Fidesz-KDNP delegation supports the adoption of the report in line with the position of the People's Party.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Article 19 of the MED Regulation provides for the revision of the MED in the event of the late adoption of new rules or programmes implemented under shared management in order to allow the transfer of funds not used in 2014 to the following years in excess of the corresponding ceilings. The amount of discontinued commitment appropriations for programmes implemented in 2014 under shared management under Article 19 of the MTMS Regulation amounts to EUR 21 043 639 478 at current prices, which corresponds to the parts of the programmes due in 2014 which could not be tied up in 2014 or transferred to 2015. The report welcomes the fact that appropriations have been carried over as far as possible to the financial year 2015, as this avoids unfair treatment of Member States, regions and operational programmes, accelerates the implementation and implementation of cohesion policy and helps to avoid the concentration of payments at the end of the MTMD. As a member of the Fidesz-KDNP delegation, I support the adoption of this report in line with the position of the People's Party.

name: Carlos Iturgaiz (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 Vote for. As a full member of the Committee on Budgets, I consider it necessary to make the suggestions of the Committee on Regional Development with regard to the multiannual financial framework necessary, which would facilitate the adoption of programmes necessary for cohesion policy; the Committee on Regional Development also requests the transfer of commitment appropriations that were not used in 2014 due to the late adoption of shared management programmes, also within the framework of the European Structural and Investment Funds.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for draft budget amendment No. 2/2015: Revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020, as such a revision of the multiannual financial framework is a standard procedure at the beginning of each MFF period and that the corresponding draft budget change should be harmonised.  This ensures that unused appropriations for 2014 are transferred to next year, thus helping to create jobs and boost growth. This ensures that cohesion policy funds are used as not all Member States' operational programmes have been adopted.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Eider Gardiazabal's report on the European Union's 2015 amending budget proposed by the Committee and the Council. This report commends the decision of the Board and the Committee to reallocate unused funds in 2014 to the 2015 budget. And recalls that it is essential for citizens and member states that the funds not used in 2014 be allocated to the 2015 budget.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the European Union's amending budget for the 2015 financial year, which includes, among other things, a revision of the multi-year financial framework in the event of late adoption of rules or programmes in shared management, so that allocations not used in 2014 are transferred to subsequent years.  I welcome the adoption of this report.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which provides for the transfer of unused commitment appropriations of EUR 21.1 billion from 2014 to subsequent years, including EUR 16.5 billion to the 2015 budget. This revision of the multiannual financial framework (MFF) and the adoption of Draft Amending Budget No 2 are necessary in order to implement the 300 EU programmes for which the 2014 allocation has not been used, due to the late agreement on the 2014-2020 MFF. This revision concerns all EU Member States. At the end of last year, only 39% of programmes had been adopted, and so I welcome this transfer of appropriations, which allows the 300 programmes that were postponed to be adopted.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposal as it does provide a practical solution for implementation of delayed operational programmes and the overall size of the multiannual financial framework (MFF) 2014-2020 remains unchanged.

name: Jude Kirton-Darling (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today Parliament voted to ensure that EU citizens and our regions do not miss out on key investment which has been delayed as a result of our governmentʼs incompetence. In 2010, the Tory-Liberal Democrat coalition unilaterally abolished the English Regional Development Agencies and created Local Enterprise Partnerships, seemingly with total disregard for the impact of this decision on EU funding.  Leaving regions like mine – the North-East of England – unable to access the EU funds allocated: funds to address unemployment, grow businesses and provide training. Today, we have made sure that the North-East will not lose a penny of the GBP 724 million allocated to us up to 2020, but now we need to get that investment unblocked and out to where it is needed.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Article 19 of the MED Regulation provides for the revision of the MED in the event of the late adoption of new rules or programmes implemented under shared management in order to allow the transfer of funds not used in 2014 to the following years in excess of the corresponding ceilings. The amount of discontinued commitment appropriations for programmes implemented in 2014 under shared management under Article 19 of the MTMS Regulation amounts to EUR 21 043 639 478 at current prices, which corresponds to the parts of the programmes due in 2014 which could not be tied up in 2014 or transferred to 2015. The report welcomes the fact that appropriations have been carried over as far as possible to the financial year 2015, as this avoids unfair treatment of Member States, regions and operational programmes, accelerates the implementation and implementation of cohesion policy and helps to avoid the concentration of payments at the end of the MTMD. The Fidesz-KDNP delegation supports the adoption of the report in line with the position of the People's Party.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 From eu accession to the present day, my country has suffered terrible losses, as our production capacities have been eliminated, our factories have been dismantled, our foreign markets have been destroyed, our agriculture has been destroyed. In return, we get some handouts under various items, from which we can cover the public squares with imported paving stones and provide WIFI at the bus stop, where there are 3 flights a day and the like. Due to the protracted approvals, certain programmes are often not paid for in the current year and therefore unused resources remain, which then have to be transferred to the following years. These arrears have accumulated in recent years, so I had to vote for the proposal so that at least after the work done, our contractors could be paid.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. Since a significant number of programmes could not be adopted in 2014, commitment appropriations, amounting to EUR 21 billion, for shared management programmes expired in 2014. The Commission proposes to transfer these allocations, which were not used in 2014, to 2015. The review adjusts the MFF deadlines and, consequently, the corresponding appropriations have been budgeted for 2015 through PPR No 2/2015. The European Parliament gave its opinion in accordance with the adjustment of the maximum limits of the Multiannual Financial Framework at the April meeting. It is now time to vote on the corresponding appropriations budgeted for 2015 through this draft amending budget No 2.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The late implementation of several EU programmes (some as important as fisheries, cohesion, social or asylum funds) has resulted in many of the budget transfers allocated for 2014 not being usable. Draft amending budget No 2/2015 continues the routine procedure by which unused appropriations the previous year are transferred to this year's budget, in compliance with the general guidelines of the Multiannual Financial Framework. While I regret the consequences of this delay, and despite the limitations of the European budget, I voted in favour of this project, making it easier for these amounts to be available in 2015.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ At its last plenary session in Brussels, the European Parliament adopted an amendment to the Multiannual Financial Framework for 2014-2020, the european parliament approved the transfer of €21 billion in unused funds for 2014 to 2015, 2016 and 2017. As the adoption of part of the operational programmes is delayed by this amendment of the MFF, it will allow unused funds to be transferred with a view to addressing unpaid commitments to Member States.  The amendment to budget number 2 for 2015 foresees an increase of €16 billion in commitment appropriations for structural funds under economic, social and territorial cohesion (subtitle 1.b), and sustainable development programmes (Heading 2), security and citizenship (Heading 3). Amending budget number 2 also envisions an increase of €2.5 million for the Global Europe Pre-Investment Assistance Facility (Heading 4).  I believe that the transfer of these funds will help accelerate the implementation of regional policy programmes, thus contributing to the creation of economic growth and development and in job creation, which is why I support this report.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the Council's position on draft amending budget No 1/2012. 2/2015 of the European Union for the financial year 2015, Section III – Commission, because I believe that this is a vital issue - for both European citizens and the economy in all Member States - to be able to transfer appropriations that were not used in 2014 to subsequent years in order to contribute to job creation and growth.

name: Dominique Martin (NI)
text: In writing. This vote on the draft amending budget is the logical continuation of the April 15 vote on the multi-year financial framework. Dominique Martin again abstained on this vote because the reasoning remains the same: 21 billion credits were not used in 2014 due to the late adoption of regulations and programmes concerning certain European funds. Although the problem of late payments is likely to worsen, funds benefiting France, such as FEADER or fisheries, are also included in the budget lines at issue: it is therefore fairer to abstain again.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on the Council's position on draft amending budget No 2/2015 of the European Union for the financial year 2015 gives me a favourable view. It is right to recall the crucial importance of the European Structural and Investment Funds and their programmes, which are a driver of growth and employment in the Member States. We need rapid approval so that the funds made available can be used efficiently. It is very important for European citizens and Member States to ensure that unused appropriations for the financial year 2014 can be transferred to subsequent years, in order to contribute to job creation and growth.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Draft amending budget No 2/2015 provides for the transfer of most of the resources not used for the 2015 budget for the benefit of draft budgets for the financial years 2016 and 2017.  This operation will help to speed up the implementation of the objectives of cohesion policy, while avoiding the concentration of payments at the end of the period of the current multiannual financial framework. Mrs Rubial's report sums up this need adequately, and that is why I have decided to support it with a vote in favour.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 I support the report approving the Council position on the draft amending budget No 2/2015 of the EU for the 2015 financial year.  MEPs welcome the fact that unused appropriations in 2014 were transferred to the maximum extent possible to the 2015 financial year, which will avoid unequal treatment between certain Member States, regions and operational programmes, speed up the implementation and implementation of cohesion policy and help avoid the concentration of payments at the end of the multiannual financial framework period. However, we call on the Commission for strict monitoring of implementation in order to ensure that this process is carried out effectively in order to avoid problems arising from the delay in the adoption of the programmes.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. I refused to approve the amending budget for amending the Multiannual Financial Framework for 2014-2020, as I did at the last vote in Brussels on 15 April 2015. Unused funds from 2014 are to be used for 2015. However, these funds have not been called up for no reason and should therefore not be spent by coercion in 2015, but should be returned to the individual Member States.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This report amends the 2015 EU budget to reflect the revision of the 2014-2020 multi-year financial framework that Parliament voted on at the previous session.  In intangible principle, this framework can be revised in the event that some programmes could not be launched as early as 2014. Rather than losing all the appropriations set aside for 2014 for these programs, this amendment allows them to be partially deferred in 2015. This only corrects the notorious shortcomings of this multi-year financial framework, which is marked by austerity. And this once again reflects the unprescing of European budgetary management. Plagued by the fussy conditionalities imposed by the European Commission, 21 billion euros of EU programmes could not be committed in 2014. We are only talking about deferring $19 billion. The lack of serious budget planning also serves as a pretext for a new round of austerity screws minus two billions. I vote against these manipulations which do not improve an already calamitous initial budget.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The revision of the MFF and the adoption of this POR No 2 are a necessary condition for the adoption in 2015 of operational programmes that were not and whose 2014 allocation was not used. The corresponding commitments should therefore be rescheduled for later years. All 28 Member States are covered by this reprogramming exercise. Rapid adoption of the revision of the MFF and this POR(2) would avoid further delays in the adoption of operational programmes and ensure the good implementation of programmes supporting growth and jobs. With the proposal to amend the Council MFF Regulation, unused 2014 appropriations will be transferred to subsequent years by revising the ceiling on commitments of the various headings. On the basis of this adjustment of the ceiling, this POR submits the necessary applications for authorisation appropriations for the 2015 budget. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Revisions of the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) Regulation are a standard procedure at the beginning of each MFF period. The adoption of this draft amending budget means that unused funds for 2014 can be transferred to subsequent years. I therefore voted in favour of this motion as it means that the majority of these unused funds will be used in 2015, thus accelerating the implementation and delivery of the cohesion policy across the Member States.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I welcome the adoption of the draft amending budget, which will contribute to the revision of the multi-year financial framework for the period 2014-2020.  It is essential for European citizens and for the economy as a whole that the funds that have not been used since 2014 be transferred to the following years. This will help create jobs and growth. This postponement will also avoid inequalities in treatment between Member States, regions or programmes.  This budget adjustment reminds us of the significant impact that unpaid debts can have on the implementation of promising projects.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The implementation and implementation of cohesion policy for the well-being of European citizens and the economy of all Member States depends on the effective treatment of the appropriations allocated in the multiannual financial framework. In order for unused appropriations from 2014 not to be forthcoming but to be able to be transferred to the following years, a revision of the MFF Regulation is needed.  I therefore welcome the relevant revision, which will allow appropriations not used in 2014 to be transferred as far as possible to the financial year 2015.  At the same time, however, I must express my deep concern at the fact that a significant number of programmes have still not been adopted. Delays in the adoption of programmes cause overall delays in the implementation of cohesion policy and its objectives and undermine citizens' confidence in its functioning. I therefore consider it extremely important that all programmes be adopted by mid-2015.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the fact that the unused appropriations for the year 2014 were transferred, to the maximum extent possible, to the financial year 2015 as this will avoid unfair treatment of certain Member States, regions and operational programmes, accelerate the implementation and delivery of Cohesion policy and help avoid the concentration of payments at the end of the MFF period.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported draft amending budget No 2/2015 dealing with the transfer of commitments under shared management, economic, social and territorial cohesion, sustainable growth, security and citizenship and global Europe.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Council's draft regulation allows the transfer and subsequent use of some EUR 21 billion not used up to 2014 from the various FUNDS of the Union for later years. The draft cannot be adopted without the approval of the European Parliament.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission has presented draft amending budget No 2/2015 which aims to transfer unspent funds from the Structural Funds and the Common Agricultural Policy from 2014 to 2015. This transfer of funds is due to the delay in the adoption of the Partnership Agreements that are concluded between the European Commission and the 28 Member States.  I support this report and believe that appropriations not used in the financial year 2014 should be fully transferred to subsequent years in order to contribute to job creation and economic growth. I would also like to point out that the decision to transfer unused appropriations from 2014 to 2015 will have to involve a flexible approach by the Commission in order to address any difficulties resulting from an irregular financial profile, which is due to the lack of payment commitments.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. This vote concerns the draft amending budget following the adoption of the amendment to the regulation (EU, Euratom) No. 1311/2013 to allow the transfer of unused commitment appropriations in 2014 (21 billion euros or 15% of the budget for 2014) to the subsequent years, in line with Article 19 of the Multi-Year Financial Framework.  This is related to the delay in the conclusion of the Agreement on the Multi-Year Financial Framework (MFF) for 2014-2020, as the legal acts setting out the rules for the implementation of the funds were adopted later than expected. As a result, these commitment appropriations for shared management programs were cancelled in 2014 and could not be committed in 2014 or postponed to 2015.  If this is a seemingly technical correction, these year-to-year deferrals feed the stock of unpaid bills (which amounts to about 24 billion euros at the end of 2014 despite the 4.8 billion euros obtained in the trilogue at the end of 2014).  Nevertheless, we are still waiting for a clean-up plan. Meanwhile, it is the local authorities that are paying the price. In accordance with the vote on the Obrycht/Thomas report, I have decided to abstain.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I believe this proposal provides a practical solution for the implementation of delayed operational programmes; 2014 allocations for unapproved UK programmes total EUR 1.25 billion.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which organises the effective transfer of unused commitment appropriations in 2014 to the 2015 budget. The principle of this transfer, which ensures that these Structural and Investment Funds are not lost and implemented quickly, has already been voted on at the previous plenary session.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 With this report we take note of draft amending budget No 2/2015 presented by the Commission and we want to stress how crucial it is for all European citizens and for the economies of all Member States that unused appropriations for the 2014 financial year can be transferred to subsequent years in order to contribute to job creation and growth.  We cannot fail to express our concern at the long-term impact this one-year postponement will have on the overall payment situation. Let us therefore take this opportunity, once again, to call on the Commission to monitor implementation more closely and to do everything possible to avoid non-payment of commitments made by making appropriate proposals to adjust the annual levels of payment appropriations if necessary, in accordance with the relevant provisions of the MFF Regulation. Agreement must be reached on this draft amending budget in good time in order to allow for the rapid adoption of all the programmes in question.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The late adoption of cohesion policy regulations for the period 2014-2020 meant that it was impossible to adopt all operational programmes in good time. In the last plenary session, therefore, in order not to lose the 2014 appropriations, it was decided to revise the annex to Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 1311/2013 by transferring the commitment appropriations not used in 2014 to the 2015 budget. Given the enormous importance of European funds at this time of economic and financial crisis for Italy, and for Europe as a whole, I have given my approval to draft amending budget No 2/2015 amending the multiannual financial framework for the years 2014-2020.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted on this report on the Council's position on draft amending budget No. 2/2015 of the European Union for the financial year 2015, Section III – Commission because, through its text, it invokes the need to be able to transfer unused appropriations from the 2014 budget to the budgets of the following years, this measure being vital for European citizens and for the economy of all Member States, as this can contribute to job creation and economic growth, two of the EU's major objectives.

name: Péter Niedermüller (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Additional resources will be available for catch-up and social funds in the proposal. This, in my view, contributes to reducing disparities within the UNION and creating jobs. I also support the need for a flexible approach in the area of financial planning in order to avoid losing resources or spending at an irregular pace.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. I refused to approve the amending budget for amending the Multiannual Financial Framework for 2014-2020, as I did at the last vote in Brussels on 15 April 2015. Unused funds from 2014 are to be used for 2015. However, these funds have not been called up for no reason and should therefore not be spent by coercion in 2015, but should be returned to the individual Member States.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the bill because the revision of the MULTIANNUAL FINANCIAL FRAMEWORK will result in the transfer to 2015 of programmes that have not yet been adopted but for which the funds allocated in 2014 are to be used. This will enable these programmes to move forward and will support growth and job creation.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission considers it essential to adopt PBR No 2/2015 as quickly as possible, which is a necessary condition for the approval of programmes, including cohesion policy programmes, for which appropriations could not be used in 2014. Recalls in this regard the importance of the European Structural and Investment Funds and their programmes as a crucial source of investment, growth and employment in the Member States; welcomes the overall logic of the proposal to bring back to 2015 the unused allocations in 2014 for subheading 1b – Economic, social and territorial cohesion, in order to ensure equal treatment between programmes adopted under the carry-over procedure and those that should be adopted in 2015 on the basis of the MFF review and amending budget proposal No 2/2015. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 Draft Budget Amendment No. 2/2015 amending the multiannual financial framework for 2014-2020 should be adopted to facilitate the use of unused funds from 2014, notably in 2015 and then in 2016 and 2017.  The revision of the multiannual financial framework will enable the swift adoption of all operational programmes that were not adopted in 2014, including the Croatian Rural Development Programme, and therefore I support this report on the Council's position on draft amendments to budget No 2015. 2/2015 of the European Union for the financial year 2015

name: Florian Philippot (NI)
text: In writing. This amendment to the budget follows the Obrycht-Thomas report adopted at the first session in April. This is a simple operational decision. To the extent that I abstained on the report, it is logically and not concerned with coherence that I also abstain on this amendment.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. \u2012 Article 19. The MFF Regulation provides for a revision of the multiannual financial framework in the event of late adoption of rules or programmes under shared management to transfer unused funds from 2014 to the coming years, which are higher than the corresponding expenditure ceilings.  Given that the maximum amount of appropriations has been transferred in the financial year 2015, as this will avoid unfair treatment of Member States, regions and operational programmes, accelerate the implementation and delivery of cohesion policy and avoid accumulating payments at the end of the MFF period, I support the proposed draft amendment to budget No 2016/2016. 2/2015: amendment of the Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020  At the same time, I share my concerns about the long-term impact of this one-year delay on the general payment situation and join calls on the Commission to closely monitor the implementation of the budget and to do all it can to submit, if necessary and in accordance with the relevant provisions of the MFF Regulation, appropriate proposals on adjusting the annual levels of payment appropriations in order to avoid an avalanche of outstanding bills.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Bearing in mind the fact that it is essential for European citizens and economies in all Member States that unused appropriations for 2014 and 2015 are not approved. the maximum amount of appropriations has been transferred to the following years and thus contribute to job creation and growth promotion, as well as the fact that the maximum amount of appropriations was transferred in the financial year 2015 in order to avoid unfair treatment of Member States, regions and operational programmes, accelerate the implementation and delivery of cohesion policy and avoid accumulating payments at the end of the MFF period, I supported the draft amendment to budget No 2/2015.  However, I share my concerns about the long-term impact of this one-year delay on the general situation of payments, and I also urge the Commission to closely monitor the implementation of the budget and to do all it can to submit, if necessary and in accordance with the relevant provisions of the MFF Regulation, appropriate proposals to adjust the annual levels of payment appropriations in order to avoid an avalanche of outstanding bills.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. The revision of the multiannual financial framework is a standard procedure at the beginning of each MFF period and, consequently, the draft amending budget must be aligned with the review. It is to the benefit of European citizens and the economies of all Member States that unused appropriations for the financial year 2014 can be transferred to subsequent years, in order to contribute to the economic objectives of the Member States and to possible job creation and growth.  I hope, however, that this one-year postponement will not affect the overall payment situation. That is why the Commission must monitor and submit appropriate proposals to adjust, if necessary, the annual levels of payment appropriations, as provided for in the provisions of the MFF Regulation.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. After the approval of the Council of the Union, Parliament voted to revise the 2014-2020 multi-year financial framework. This change relates to the effective transfer of commitment appropriations not used in 2014 in the 2015 budget. I have expressed my support for this correction, which will allow us to use these funds for new projects.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Draft amending budget No 2/2015 concerns the proposal for a Council Regulation amending the Regulation of the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) in order to authorise the transfer of unused appropriations in 2014, which as a result of delays in the adoption of rules or programmes under shared management, could not be authorised in 2014. Such commitment appropriations for shared-management programmes have been cancelled amounting to EUR 21 043 639 478 at current prices. This resolution approves draft amending budget No 2/2015 which provides for the transfer of most of these appropriations to the 2015 budget, while lower amounts will be integrated into the draft budgetfor the financial years 2016 and 2017. Thus, because I believe that the transfer of these appropriations will contribute to job creation and growth, as well as accelerate the implementation and implementation of cohesion policy, I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of revising the QFB regulation as it is an ordinary procedure at the beginning of each period. In this case, it expects unused transfers in 2014 to be transferred to 2015 in order to contribute to job creation and growth. However, I express my concern about the average payment period to suppliers.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. The revision of the Regulation establishing the Multiannual Financial Framework is a common procedure at the beginning of each MFF period, and the corresponding draft amending budget should be in line with this review. In 2014, a significant number of programmes could not be adopted, which is why commitment appropriations for shared management programmes amounting to EUR 21 billion expired. The Commission has proposed, and Parliament endorsed, that these appropriations be transferred to the maximum extent possible to the 2015 financial year, which will avoid unequal treatment between certain Member States, regions and operational programmes, speed up the implementation and implementation of cohesion policy and help to avoid the concentration of payments at the end of the multiannual financial framework period. That's why I voted for it.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. The report discussed here highlights the unreliability of some of the controls carried out by Member States in the context of shared management and the data they have provided. I voted in favour of this report because, because of the reservations expressed by DG AGRI, DG REGIO and DG EMPL in their respective annual activity reports, Parliament cannot guarantee that the monitoring procedures put in place by the Commission and the Member States have offered all necessary guarantees as to the legality and regularity of all operations carried out. This is the credibility of the European institutions. Moreover, over the years, the Commission and the Member States have been reluctant to respect rigorous financial management. The overall error rate, estimated at 4.7% in 2013, has continued to increase since 2009 (especially in spending on the Common Agricultural Policy, where the error rate is 6.7%). The report I supported therefore calls for more transparency on the part of the Member States cooperating with the Commission and states that the disclosure of erroneous information on the part of the Member States must be punished.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft amending budget because I believe that it is essential for European citizens and for the economies of all Member States that unused appropriations for the financial year 2014 be transferred to subsequent years, in order to contribute to job creation and growth.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. I have chosen to vote against on a point of principle: in practice, the entire multiannual financial framework has not been realistically programmed, to the point that, with measures such as this, the European institutions have to shift the funds to subsequent years.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The late implementation of several EU programmes (some as important as fisheries, cohesion, social or asylum funds) has resulted in many of the budget transfers allocated for 2014 not being usable. Draft amending budget No 2/2015 continues the routine procedure by which unused appropriations the previous year are transferred to this year's budget, in compliance with the general guidelines of the Multiannual Financial Framework. While I regret the consequences of this delay, and despite the limitations of the European budget, I voted in favour of this project, making it easier for these amounts to be available in 2015.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft amendment of the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) for the period 2014-2020. I consider this correction to be urgent and necessary in order to adopt in 2015 the programmes and appropriations not used in 2014 for the Structural Funds, the Cohesion Fund, the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development, the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund, the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund and the Internal Security Fund.  I am convinced that, in the current economic situation, this budgetary manoeuvre meets the need to maintain the pace of investment in growth and employment.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted with the majority of MEPs in favour of Draft amending budget No 2/2015. It is vital for European citizens and for the economies in all Member States that the unused appropriations for the year 2014 can be transferred to subsequent years in order to contribute to the creation of jobs and growth. The 2014 allocations for unapproved UK programmes total EUR 1.25 billion.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the draft amendment to budget No. 2/2015, as the revision of the multiannual financial framework and the adoption of the draft amendment to budget No 2015 2 preconditions for adopting programmes in 2015 for which the 2014 allocations have not been used.  All 28 Member States are covered by the reprogramming and the corresponding commitments will be reprogrammed in 2016 and 2017. The reprogramming will not cover contributions to the instrument of pre-contribution assistance and the neighbourhood instrument due to the complexity of the procedure itself and the impact on a wide range of stakeholders. By swiftly revising the multiannual financial framework and adopting a draft amendment to budget No 10000/2013, 2 should avoid further delays in the adoption of programmes and ensure the smooth implementation of programmes supporting growth and employment across the Union. Reprogrammed funds should be directed towards long-term sustainable investments. We need to recognise the public policies that will deliver the real and stable growth of the European economy. Encouraging SMEs towards green innovation, eco-design and resource efficiency building should be high on the Commission's list of priorities. Green jobs and the circular economy are the solution to most of the economic difficulties faced by Member States. I call on the Commission to be guided by the arguments mentioned above in the reprogramming of funds.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. – I supported the draft amending budget because it is extremely important for EU citizens and for the economy of all Member States that appropriations not used in 2014 can be carried over to the coming years and contribute to job creation and growth. Although the revision of the MFF Regulation is practically standard procedure at the beginning of each MFF period, we must be concerned about the long-term impact of the one-year postponement on the overall payment situation. The transfer of funds may put considerable pressure on some Member States, leading to difficulties in drawing on the funds. That is why the Commission must provide the Member States with all the necessary assistance to overcome the existing problems with the implementation of the Structural Funds. At the same time, when approving the amending budget, we must point out that a significant number of programmes have still not been adopted, which may cause a further delay in the implementation of the absorption policy by individual Member States in the coming years.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \ As a result of the late Agreement on the Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020, a number of legal acts containing provisions for the implementation of the Funds were only adopted in December 2013. Subsequently, a number of implementing and delegated acts were adopted for each fund in 2014. As a view, many shared management programmes could not be adopted in 2014. Appropriations that were neither used nor allowed to be transposed in 2014 will have to be reallocating to the coming years by revising the MFF ceilings. In addition to the revision of the MFF ceilings, it was also necessary to adopt an amending budget for commitment appropriations for 2015. Both the revision and the amending budget are prerequisites for the adoption of programmes triggering a budgetary commitment and the payment of initial pre-financing.  In 2014, commitment appropriations for shared management programmes of EUR 21 billion were due. Draft amending budget No 2/2015 provides for the transfer of much of these appropriations directly to 2015 in order to maintain the level of investment in growth and jobs and to ensure that the debts of 2007-2013 are paid as soon as possible, which is why I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the possibility of transferring appropriations not used in 2014 to the financial year 2015. Such a measure can help job creation as well as economic growth. Nevertheless, I consider it essential that the Commission closely monitors the area of payments and ensure that funds are used effectively.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the draft amendment to the budget as Article 19 of the The MFF Regulation provides for a revision of the multiannual financial framework in the event of late adoption of rules or programmes under shared management to transfer unused funds from 2014 to the coming years, which are higher than the corresponding expenditure ceilings.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on the multiannual financial framework. The draft amending budget will allow funding delayed from 2014 to be allocated to the 2015 budget year, which will give support to programmes across the EU.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the revision Draft amending budget NO. 2/2015 as it will allow the redistribution of the multiannual financial framework for the years 2014-2020. Due to the postponement of the final agreement on the Multiannual Financial Framework for the period from 2014-2020, the legal provisions needed for the implementation of funding of various programmes were delayed and as a consequence, all of the funds allocated to the programmes were not used. Funds will be transferred to various programmes including the European Social Fund, Youth Employment Initiative, the Cohesion Fund, European Regional Development Fund, the Rural Development Fund and others. The unused and non-transferable funds intended for the year 2014 amount to over 21 billion euro, equivalent to almost 15% of the budget for 2014. The planned revision of the budget will thus allow full implementation of funds that were intended for the various programmes in 2014 to be used in 2015 and beyond.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the proposal because I do not agree with the transfer of unused funds from 2014 to the following years. The European Union has long spent taxpayers' money desperately inefficiently, without any self-reflection. This, too, is one way to save at least some of taxpayers' money from further waste.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Most of the text neither refers to the conclusions drawn from the Commission's assessment of its general budget for 2013, nor focuses on the arguments for the Commission's discharge or not, but focuses on current issues and political positions, thus altering the meaning of the report itself.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the draft amending budget 2/2015: revision of the multi-year financial framework for the period 2014-2020. However, I am concerned that a significant number of programs are still awaiting adoption. It is essential that all programmes are adopted and launched as soon as possible.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I support the draft amendment to the 2015 EU budget and the revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework for the period 2014-2020, as the revision of the Framework must also be appropriately amended. We understand that the ultimate goal in managing budget funds is to reduce social and economic disparities as well as promote sustainable development.  I believe that the transfer of funds and the rebalancing of the budget are necessary measures to continue disbursement of funds under advance payments for late programmes in order to ultimately stimulate growth, create new jobs and contribute to strengthening institutional capacity. The difficulties that may arise during the transfer of unused funds, which may create additional pressure in their further absorption, require that Member States, in particular the poorer ones, be provided with regulatory assistance.  There is a real need for continued financial assistance as well as for the realization of projects in many Member States that are in an unenviable position, because in a large number of cases the funds from these funds represent the only external investments in certain areas, so I voted for this report.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Council Regulation lays down the transfer of nearly EUR 21 billion not used until 2014 to later years. The European Parliament needs its approval, so it is important to change the legislation, which I supported.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this partial correction of the annual budget, which is necessary due to delays in the implementation of the new generation of Structural Funds, since this year's increase corresponds to a reduction in appropriations in last year's budget and is a dysfunction that needed to be corrected.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. In April, the European Parliament consented to the revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework. This review provides for the transfer of unused commitment appropriations. We are talking about a review to transfer those funds committed and unused due to the late adoption of structural programmes for the European Structural and Investment Funds, the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund and the Internal Security Fund, so their approval is welcome.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The late implementation of several EU programmes (some as important as fisheries, cohesion, social or asylum funds) has resulted in many of the budget transfers allocated for 2014 not being usable. Draft amending budget No 2/2015 continues the routine procedure by which unused appropriations the previous year are transferred to this year's budget, in compliance with the general guidelines of the Multiannual Financial Framework. While I regret the consequences of this delay, and despite the limitations of the European budget, I voted in favour of this project, making it easier for these amounts to be available in 2015.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I have approved this report on the Council's position on the draft amending budget.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The appropriations that could not be used in 2014 and which did not carry over to 2015 are very significant, totalling more than EUR 21 million, equivalent to 15% of the 2014 Budget. This draft amending budget provides for the majority of the money to be allocated to the 2015 budget, with an increase of EUR 16 million in commitment appropriations for all funds under shared action. This budget, however, also proposes an increase of EUR 2.5 million for the Instrument for Pre-Release Assistance. As an instrument aimed at implementing economic and social policies for candidate countries to align themselves with EU rules, policies and practices, the same policies and measures are among the policies and measures financed by this instrument that have contributed and continue to contribute today to the destruction of the productive sectors of countries such as Portugal, such as progressive alignment with internal market rules , the stability pact and the Europe 2020 strategy, the objectives of which are to continue to privatise even more companies, extending this process also to public services, and to liberalise sectors of the economy that are fundamental to the lives of workers and peoples.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. I refused to approve the amending budget for the amendment of the Multiannual Financial Framework for 2014-2020, as I did at the last vote in Brussels on 15 April 2015. Unused funds from 2014 are to be used for 2015. However, these funds have not been called up for no reason and should therefore not be spent by coercion in 2015, but should be returned to the individual Member States.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted on the Report on the Council's position on draft amending budget No 1/2002. 2/2015 of the European Union for the financial year 2015. I agree with the position expressed by the report on the need for more careful monitoring by the Commission of budget implementation so as to avoid the accumulation of an increasing volume of unpaid invoices. In the context of the decision to transfer most of the unused appropriations from 2014 to 2015, I agree with the proposal to the Commission to take a flexible approach to deal with possible difficulties arising from an unequal financial profile, which could lead to unused commitments in the period 2014-2020.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 For the report on the Council position on draft amending budget No 2/2015 for the financial year 2015, Section III — I voted in favour of the Commission because the draft amending budget No 2/2015 concerns the proposal for a Council regulation amending the MFF Regulation (COM(2015)0015) and because Article 19 of the MFF Regulation allows for the revision of this framework in the event of late adoption of rules or programmes under shared management to transfer funds not used in 2014 to subsequent years. It is important for European citizens and economies in the Member States that unused appropriations for 2014 can be carried over to the following years in order to contribute to job creation and growth. As unused appropriations for 2014 have been largely carried over to the financial year 2015, we will speed up the implementation of cohesion policy and reduce the accumulation of payments at the end of the MFF.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I, at the eCall point, just want to say on the microphone that I could not vote because of a broken card, i.e. I will add my vote, otherwise I would have voted against the amendment of the Group of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe, although I support the idea of eCall as such. But again, I was not allowed to vote because of the malfunctioning of my card.

name: Angelika Mlinar (ALDE).
text: I have included the amendment on the on/off button in the eCall system and have therefore voted in favour of it. Like everyone, of course, I am in favour of greater road safety, but we really must be careful not to sacrifice more and more of our freedoms in every additional regulation. Whether it is data retention or, more generally, what is being sold to us as a counter-terrorism, unfortunately also with the eCall: it always goes in the direction of glass people. And as a Liberal Member, I strongly oppose this. The eCall system, which has been adopted with it, is intended to make it possible to provide rapid assistance to motorists throughout the EU in the event of an accident. But, like many others, I fear that the system installed in the vehicle will continuously monitor our location, monitor our driving behaviour and thus compromise our privacy. When I hear as an argument that it is a sleeping system in which everything is deleted anyway, the alarm bells ring for me. Also a sleeping tiger is a tiger. And we see how our data is handled almost every day. I do not understand why we do not want to give mature citizens the choice of judging this system themselves with an on/off button.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D).
text: – Mr. President, almost 30,000 people die on European roads every year. The number of injured is many times higher. This is shocking data and calls for urgent action.  An electronic call is an appropriate response that can detract from these tragic figures as it will allow an automatic call to the emergency services at the time of the accident instead of those who are unable to do so themselves. And every minute we lose until the ambulance arrives strengthens the chances of survival and recovery of the afflicted.  I am pleased that this proposal also covers the principles of data protection of citizens. The technical provisions of the proposal are perfect, and the time for the mandatory introduction of an electronic call system has enough.  That is why I fully support it and congratulate the rapporteur who has been working on it for two terms. It is time to introduce a single system of assistance to the afflicted in the European single market with a single number of emergency services 112. Such a system can save as many as 2,500 lives a year and is worth applying.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would like to congratulate my colleagues and the Council on the compromise reached on this regulation. The European Commission needs to promote this service even more actively before it becomes a mandatory service for only some motor vehicles in 2018.  The Union must support such safety measures for its citizens. I therefore believe that the European Commission should propose in the coming months the relevant legislative measures that will facilitate the installation of the eCall system. I call for financial instruments to be provided at European level as well in order to make this service free and easily accessible to all European citizens as soon as possible.  Every year, more than 25,000 European citizens die on the roads. Should we allow an estimated 380,000 more people to die in 2033 to make this service ubiquitous? And a lost human life on the road is one more than we can afford.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, no one can deny the enormous usefulness of a system such as eCall, which will indeed be able to save lives after road accidents. However, eCall does not guarantee the safeguarding and protection of personal data and privacy because, firstly, eCall is compulsory in all cars, secondly, eCall continues to operate even against the will of the driver, thirdly, because the principle of flexibility creates significant gaps in privacy, fourthly, because personal data will be retained for some time and , fifthly, because personal data will be available to private operators. Therefore, the eCall system could be used to strengthen big brother who attempts to control every aspect of our privacy.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would also like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur and, at the same time, saying that I could not vote on the amendment that was tabled because my card did not work either. Of course, I couldn't have known that when I came to the oral explanation. I would like to say in my explanation that I support this system, but I have some concerns about it and I think it is appropriate to communicate it here. Many sides of data retention have already been said here. As regards the fact that it is indeed a dormant system, I must point out that any system that stores data, even for a certain period of time, can be misused. Modern technologies always go ahead in a way that we often don't even see a threat. Therefore, I would therefore warn to some extent against ing a system that does not know the possibility of automatic shutdown. Yes, I accept that communication traffic should be subject to certain rules, but data retention is something that I think should also be subject to a personal decision.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, I supported the ALDE amendment on the eCall in-vehicle system. I think this is an example of where we try to balance individual rights with societal benefits, where we protect individual data but recognise how data-sharing can, in the case of the eCall system, save lives, reduce the seriousness of injury, facilitate the work of rescuers and fire-fighters, and indeed save money. But in this context I support the amendment which requested that manufacturers ensure that eCall users can easily deactivate the eCall system manually in cars. This, I believe, will help to ensure a balance between the right to privacy and the possibility to save lives or reduce injury. I do recognise that certain safeguards have been put in place. For example, there can be no tracking of any call-equipped vehicle before an accident occurs; in the internal  memory of the system, data are automatically and continuously removed; and data-gathering by emergency centres must not be transferred to third parties without explicit consent. I am pleased that the ALDE Group played an important role in ensuring these protections.

name: Peter Jahr (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the It is a good day for the security of citizens in the European Union. With the eCall system, we are also completing our strategy. We used to have a single emergency number, now also an eCall system. In the end, it is also true that it is installed in every car and that it is automatically put into effect in an emergency. I would also ask those who are critical of this to profess this and to discuss the question: what do you actually do when there are several people in the car, who takes responsibility if you can choose to turn this eCall system on or on? I do not want to take on this responsibility. That is why I prefer the proposed solution here and I am pleased that Parliament has voted accordingly.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, vótáil mé le mo ghrúpa faoi na moltaí seo agus cuirim fáilte mhór rompu.  Dar ndóigh, lower uafásach an scrios atá with tarlú ar na bóithre trasna na hEorpa gach uile bhliain – 28 000 duine with fáil bháis; milliún real leith duine gortaithe; agus é seo ag cosnú EUR 130 billiún in aghaidh na bliana. Dar ndóigh is uafásach than figiúirí iad sin. I mo thír féin, d'ardaigh an méid daoine a fuair bás on na bóithre anuraidh; an dara bliain i ndiaidh and chéile go bhfuil fás tar éis teacht tar éis laghdú roimhe sin.  Dá bhrí sin, aon rue and chabhraíonn chun na figiúirí seo a ísliú caithfimid fáiltiú roimhe. By dabht on bith, an Glao e-teicneolaíochta seo, déanfaidh sé é sin. Deirtear, nó meastar ar a laghad, go mbeidh siad in ann teacht ar thionóisc 40% nó 50% níos tapúla ná mar atá with tarlú faoi láthair agus cabhróidh sé sin go mór leis an bhfadhb a réiteach.

name: Dieter-Lebrecht Koch (PPE).
text: Mrs Sehnalova, we have gone a long way together in fair cooperation for much of the twelve-year journey. The 112-based eCall is our baby. Thank you for not letting the concerns get you wrong. Our eCall, based on the Europe-wide uniform emergency number 112, will now become a matter of course in passenger cars and light commercial vehicles in a few years, just as seat belts have been for decades. My ambition goes further to the fact that motorcycles, heavy goods vehicles and buses must also have such a life-saving system. Until then, it is likely to be only a small step. Anyone who complains of road accidents with deaths and serious injuries has today had to support eCall.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament has voted positively on the measure it intends to introduce on all cars that will be registered after 31 March 2018 the emergency e-Call device.  This tool will allow you to make an automatic direct call to the nearest rescue in the event of an accident. More than 25 000 people died on Europe's roads during 2014 and at least 10% of them could be saved thanks to the e-Call service. The text is also attentive to the privacy of the people involved. The automatic call will indicate to the rescuers the information related to the vehicle only, which can be sent to third parties in case the data subject consents. For the above reasons, I voted positively for the IMCO Committee measure.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The implementation of this system may clash with some individual rights and freedoms. For this reason, we welcome the proposed amendment which suggests that manufacturers should ensure that users of the eCall system can easily and manually deactivate the system on board their vehicles if they wish. Conditions need to be created to reduce accidents on roads, build safe roads, improve existing traffic and safety conditions and jointly promote actions with relevant victim relief entities. These are indispensable measures for accident prevention and relief, and eCall is a good mechanism to contribute to this. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 The development of a public pan-European emergency call system in all cars, linked to the number 112, represents a very important and essential step in improving the safety of citizens. It is estimated that this system will be able to help save over 2500 victims of road accidents each year.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. Our Parliament today approves the introduction of the eCall automatic emergency call system. The system, which is installed in cars, is intended to automatically trigger a 112 emergency call throughout Europe in the event of an accident, which can be used to save lives. According to the Commission, around 25 700 people lost their lives in road accidents in 2014. This number should be reduced by up to ten percent through the eCall. From 31 March 2018, all car manufacturers will have to provide such a device in their new cars. I welcome this step. Rapid assistance is often vital, especially in the case of accidents involving serious injuries. With the obligation to install the eCall in all vehicles from 2018, we can contribute to significantly reducing the number of road deaths.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. This proposed regulation aims to introduce the requirement for car manufacturers to install an on-board eCall system in certain types of motor vehicles. The device would provide adequate handling of emergency calls by the response services and the sending of a GPS signal to enable rescuers to easily locate the crashed vehicle. The expected benefits are the reduction in the number of fatalities and the severity of injuries, as well as lower congestion costs. However, this system seems questionable regarding the protection of users' privacy. We cannot guarantee that these provisions have no purpose other than the safety of users. In particular, it risks driving up the price of automobiles. Although an amendment provides that users can unplug this geolocation system fairly easily, it would be more appropriate for users to be able to initiate this system voluntarily only if they wish.  These uncertainties regarding the protection of privacy and the purchasing power of users, as well as the impact assessment, will lead me to vote against this proposed regulation. However, I voted in favour of the amendment, which is to make it easier and manual for users to unplug the eCall system.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation because it provides greater security and access to care following a road accident. Every second counts in terms of medical assistance.

name: Janice Atkinson (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This amendment permits that the eCall system may be turned off and is therefore preferable from the position of the rights of member states than to have it mandatory for it to be turned on.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to introduce an automatic eCall system in new passenger car models from 31 March 2018, which will allow emergency services to respond more quickly to accidents. In 2014 alone, 25 700 deaths on EU roads have claimed 25,700 lives, and the new system is expected to reduce this by a tenth. The eCall system service will be provided free of charge and regardless of the type or price of the car. In the event of a serious accident, the system will automatically dial the European emergency number 112 and provide emergency services with information about the incident. This will allow officers and rescuers to reach the crash site more quickly, reduce injuries and save more lives, and reduce traffic jams. It is important to strengthen data protection provisions and to ensure that cars are not continuously tracked. The system will only turn on at the time of the accident or when the driver presses the corresponding button. Only a set of minimum data will be sent to the emergency services: the vehicle class, the type of fuel used, the number of passengers, as well as the exact time and situation of the event. I support the calls on the Commission to assess within three years of that deadline whether it would be appropriate to install such a system in buses and tractors. The rules adopted in June last year required EU countries to prepare infrastructure by October 2017 to receive and process eCall calls.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. This text is intended to force car manufacturers to generalize the installation of the eCall system. An initiative of the European Commission, this automatic emergency call system is supposed to allow a crashed vehicle to instantly call the emergency services while sending its precise position, whether its occupants are aware or not, and regardless of the EU country in which the vehicle is located. Based on the "E112" (Enhanced 112), that is, the single European emergency number 112, the eCall would allow a faster emergency services response, adapted to the severity of the accident and the type of vehicle involved The vote was only about an amendment providing that users could easily disconnect the eCall system and I therefore voted in favour.  However, I remain perplexed as to the relevance of the implementation of this system: the impact analysis seemed to me to be very unsatisfactory and therefore cannot be used to promote this dubious "technological evolution". In addition to the impact on the cost of production and therefore on the selling price of the vehicle, how can we be assured that this data will not be used for any purpose other than that of the rescue vehicle?

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The deployment of an on-board eCall system across all vehicles is one of the European Union's main road safety objectives. This system would make it mandatory to install an emergency call service in all new vehicles sold in the European Union. It would ensure that an emergency call to number 112 is triggered in the event of a serious accident. The installation of this system would reduce the number of road deaths by 1-10% depending on the Member State. I consider road safety to be a top priority, we must reduce the number of deaths on European roads. That is why I voted in favour of this text, which will undoubtedly save lives.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: in writing. This Regulation calls for the introduction of an emergency call system (eCall) in commercial cars and light vehicles as of 31 March 2018. It will be directly connected to emergency service 112 in the event of a serious accident transmitting the exact location of the vehicle, so the number of road accidents and deaths is expected to be significantly reduced. We have decided to vote in favour of this initiative as long as the data protection provisions are respected and users are not subject to permanent tracking.

name: Ivo Belet (PPE)
text: Written. 'With our vote today, the light for the roll-out of eCall is finally on the green. Parliament has long insisted on this: every new car will be equipped with an eCall system by 2018. Because the emergency services are automatically alerted in the face of an accident, they can be on the scene up to 50% faster. This will save 2,500 traffic victims a year. eCall will therefore be crucial to achieving our commitment to halve the number of road deaths by 2020. eCall is already on the market, but is currently an optional gadget that is only reserved for those who have extra touch in their portfolio. From 2018 there will fortunately be no additional costs, but it will be mandatory built into every new car.
