With this new legislation, we ensure that privacy is protected and that access to other additional services (such as repair works) is guaranteed in an open and transparent manner. Of course, member states must also fulfil their obligations and prepare to process the eCall data and ensure that eCall works everywhere.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I welcome the outcome and agreement of the development of the eCall system that we voted on today after months of work and negotiations. It is as important to protect driver data, which is guaranteed by this agreement, as the system itself, that it will allow you to arrive on time in many cases of accident. Safety is the first thing on the road.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. The purpose of this recommendation is to introduce a requirement for car manufacturers to install the on-board eCall system in certain types of motor vehicles. The proposed basic regulation requires that new types of passenger cars and light commercial vehicles be constructed to ensure that an emergency call to number 112 is automatically triggered and that a GPS signal is sent to help rescuers easily locate the crashed vehicle, effective October 1, 2015. It also provides for data and privacy rules, given the nature of the information provided by this service.  I oppose this recommendation because, under the guise of protecting citizens and improving prevention and road safety, two problems arise: what assurance is provided to ensure that the data will not be exploited for any purpose other than relief and is there no risk of intrusion into the privacy of citizens? Second, how much will the cost of manufacturing vehicles increase and what additional costs to purchase will the consumer have to bear?  Given these elements, I have decided your against this text.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. I have voted in favour of the report.  The installation of eC all systems based on the 112 service in vehicles is good from a road safety/lifesaving point of view, which I believe must be a first priority. eCall is a public service, free for all citizens, regardless of vehicle type or purchase price. However, there is a data security problem linked to the issue, but the wording scans now underline that data collected by psaps through eCall is not transmitted to third parties without the person concerned having explicitly given their prior consent. It is also established that the system shall be designed in such a way as to allow for the full and permanent deletion of the data collected. I would have preferred there to have also been an on/off function, but unfortunately that amendment did not go through.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on type-approval requirements for the deployment of the eCall system integrated into vehicles and amending Directive 2007/46/EC.  Under this proposal, at the end of March 2018 all commercial cars and light vehicles will have to be equipped with eCall devices that will automatically connect with the 112 emergency services in the event of an accident. This will improve road safety and significantly reduce the arrival time of emergency services in the event of a serious accident. It is estimated that this system could save 2,500 lives each year and reduce the severity of wounds.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it supports the mandatory installation of the 112-based eCall in-vehicle system for all new types of vehicles starting with vehicles of categories M1 and N1. The introduction of the eCall call service in all vehicles and in all Member States has been one of the Union's main objectives in the field of road safety since 2003. However, it was found that the voluntary installation of the call system initially introduced did not lead to significant progress in the EU, and the EU is now introducing a mandatory safety system for all new production cars, which will be mandatory in all EU countries from 31 March 2018.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Those who consider the high number of people killed in accidents on European roads to be unacceptable are absolutely right. Thousands of families are affected by tragedy, and we lose strong adults and talented children every day. In order to halt this process and prevent major accidents, much has happened in the Member States of the European Union in recent years: controlling and sanctioning overspeeding, reducing drink-driving. In the technical field, the mandatory use of seat belts and airbags was an important step, but it still does not seem sufficient.  The planned eCall system, proper application and full compliance with data protection rules can be an effective tool for reducing road deaths and caring for accident victims as quickly and efficiently as possible.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in support of the introduction from 2018 of emergency call devices (eCall) on new car models. In view of the number of accidents and the large number of human lives lost, 25 700 in Europe in 2014 alone, it is important to introduce innovations that simplify and speed up the arrival of relief in the event of serious accidents throughout the EU. It will be a free public service that, thanks to new technologies, will automatically make a call to 112 communicating the place and size of the accident. The measure rightly provides for a step that guarantees data protection, so that the device can only be traced from the moment of the accident and in any case provides only the information necessary for a better performance of the rescue. Without consent, the data cannot under any circumstances be transferred to third parties and must be able to be deleted.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. As a doctor, I can confirm the importance of medical as quickly as possible for those injured in traffic accidents. We call it the gold watch. The introduction of the e-Call will speed up the arrival of ambulances by 40 and 50% respectively in urban and rural areas. A single alert system is particularly important for cross-border journeys where language barriers often cause assistance to be delayed.  Within seconds of the accident, the new system will send a notification via satellite to paramedics, police and firefighters about the location, type of vehicle and number of passengers, and the direction in which the vehicle was moving, which is especially important in case of accidents in tunnels and highways. I am also glad that Croatia will welcome the system prepared. Road safety is invaluable and I believe we will all feel safer when this document comes to life in practice.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (NI)
text: In writing. On 19 March, the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection approved the Council's position without making any amendments. The commission's recommendation calls for new commercial and private vehicles to be equipped with a system that allows a call to the European emergency number, 112, in the event of a serious accident. The objectives are laudable, but one can question the proportionality of the means proposed with the stated objectives. This type of equipment raises questions about the protection of personal data. Moreover this system is not new, manufacturers proposing it on some models.  This mandatory system will have a cost that will ultimately be borne by the consumer. I regret the shortcomings of the impact analysis. So I voted against it.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this recommendation since the deployment of the eCall in-vehicle system will substantially improve safety on European roads. I strongly believe that making our roads safer should be one of the main goals of the European Union.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 28 000 people die as a result of road accidents in Europe every year. The eCall project is an important step to reduce deaths by making relief more efficient. That is why I am voting in favour, in the hope that the project will also be extended to heavy goods vehicles. The introduction of eCall should be accompanied by the complete introduction of 112 as a single emergency number, which is still lacking in Italy despite European sanctions. In this respect, given the importance of this issue for the safety of individuals, the Commission should take a stronger political initiative towards Italy, together with initiatives to spread knowledge of the single number among European citizens, which is still very scarce.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. The European Parliament's proposed regulation aims to introduce an obligation for car manufacturers, an on-board eCall system that allows the response services to handle emergency calls properly. Vehicles will need to be built to ensure that an emergency call is automatically triggered to the 112 number and that a GPS signal is sent to allow for a quick location. These provisions raise questions about privacy and the use of geolocation data for purposes other than first aid. Moreover, the impact study does not suggest that the benefits gained will outweigh the financial costs of such a device and the risks it poses to the user's right to privacy. We may even wonder whether the stated intention is indeed the real goal to be achieved. That is why I voted against this proposed regulation.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the installation of the eCall system on board vehicles. Currently, road transport exceeds 100 million vehicles annually in different Member States and is increasing due to the strengthening of the European Union. That is why road safety is a matter of major interest throughout the European Union and for all its citizens.  The aim of the EU-interoperable eCall initiative is to introduce the minimum functionality needed to ensure the proper handling of emergency calls by emergency response services in all EU vehicles.  I believe that action at EU level is needed to ensure interoperability and continuity of service across Europe, which is commendable and auspicious in the current European context.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour. The purpose is to activate an eCall system with an automatic emergency call to 112 in the event of a serious accident. The text also seems to take due account of the protection of motorists' privacy, access to the provision of the service by independent operators and compatibility with galileo and Egnos satellite navigation systems.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the implementation of the eCall regulation. This mechanism provides that in the event of an accident the eCall system automatically triggers to call the emergency number (112). By October 2015 all new passenger vehicles or light commercial vehicles will be required to be equipped with the eCall system. Drivers and their passengers will now be assured that, in the case of an accident, emergency services arrive as soon as possible. This is a significant step forward in terms of road safety.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today against the amendment proposed by the GROUP of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe to the recommendation for second reading concerning the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on type-approval requirements for the development of the on-board eCall system based on service 112 and amending Directive 2007/46/EC. The amendment provided for the deactivation of the system by a simplified manual procedure, making its optional use too easy at the expense of safety. As far as the on-board eCall system is concerned, I believe that, together with the other driving systems that integrate wireless and ICT technologies, it is a priority in road transport safety as it is able to provide rapid assistance for motorists involved in a collision anywhere in the European Union.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ It has been established that action is needed at EU level in order to guarantee interoperability and continuity of the service throughout Europe. Following these discussions, I can support the text of this report. This proposal requires that new types of passenger cars and light commercial vehicles include the possibility that in the event of a severe accident an emergency call (eCall) to the 112 number is triggered automatically. It must also be possible to trigger manually emergency calls (eCalls) to the 112 number. The proposed draft legislation also covers elements related to privacy and data protection. It also forms part of a set of EU legal acts for ensuring the deployment of the 112-based eCall service by 1 October 2015.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The approved text introduces type-approval requirements for the development of the on-board eCall system and amends Directive 2007/46/EC to this end. This system should make it possible, from each vehicle, to make automatic emergency calls in the event of accidents, and therefore aims to reduce, through rapid intervention, the victims and serious injuries, but also the costs of resorting to emergency services. In general, the system thus designed should reduce all the inconvenience caused by road accidents. Parliament is trying to introduce profiles in this area to protect citizens' privacy.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this regulation because it could help to save lives. I also voted for the amendment to have an On-Off button, which I regret did not go through in the final text. Citizens should have the right to decide if they want to have this additional assurance while driving, at the expense of their privacy.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. I objected to this text, which, under the laudable pretext of strengthening road safety, poses risks in terms of protecting the privacy of our citizens.  Indeed, the text provides for the geolocation of vehicles damaged by the eCall system. However, there is no guarantee that these data will not be used for any other purpose. Moreover, this system will have a direct impact on the cost of producing cars since it carries the obligation of the installation of the eCall system in new types of passenger cars and light commercial vehicles. This will therefore result in a further decline in the purchasing power of citizens of EU Member States. The European Union, so committed to freedom of movement, is therefore proposing a measure here that restricts the freedom of citizens through the security theme.

name: Nessa Childers (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ From March 2018, this new regulation will make sure that car manufacturers will equip vehicles with a public and free ʽ112-based eCallʼ system. This is the first time that vehicles will have full EU-wide coverage in all Member States. It is estimated that about 2 500 lives could be saved every year in Europe as a result of implementing this new regulation. Furthermore, the severity of injuries will be considerably reduced in tens of thousands of cases. Of course, the issue of data protection was treated very seriously and we have ensured that vehicles equipped with 112 public eCall are not traceable and are not subject to any constant tracking and that the minimum set of data sent by the in-vehicle eCall system includes the minimum information required for the appropriate handling of emergency calls.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This measure concerns the introduction into the EC type-approval system of motor vehicles the obligation to install an on-board eCall system, i.e. a mechanism allowing the automatic call of 112 in the event of an accident. The system brings important benefits such as reducing fatal accidents and the severity of injuries sustained, facilitating emergency services and improving the safety of rescue teams. For these reasons, I have decided to vote against.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal for a regulation for two reasons in fundamentally. The first, but less important, is the approval of the work done for years now by the rapporteur, with the group of shadow rapporteurs, on behalf of Parliament and the Council, with successive presidencies. The second, the most substantial is that I find it sacrosanct to use the technology that is now available at low cost to save lives. I have heard of several cases of people who have had road accidents and who could have been saved (or would have had less serious consequences) if the rescue had arrived earlier. Well, technology makes it possible to locate, automatically start calls to rescuers and send invaluable information. Of course, there is a privacy problem, but I believe that the right to health and the saving of human lives is much more important.  However, I will remain vigilant when the regulation enters into force so that there are no distortions in its application.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ At a time when many claim that more Europe is unnecessary, the legislation on eCall is a good example of Europe doing more, being so much more effective in an area as important as reducing mortality rates and better assisting victims of road accidents – ʽbetter integration, better regulationʼ, explained Carlos Coelho. All vehicles produced from 2018 will be required to install a device which is activated automatically in the event of a violent crash through sensors incorporated into the vehicle that connect to the appropriate emergency call centre by sending specific details about the accident.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The adoption of the Regulation on type-approval requirements for the deployment of the eCall system of edges in vehicles is the result of a long work of the European Parliament in reducing road accidents. It is never too much to remember that the Ecall system saves lives! In a Europe where thousands of families suffer from the tragedy of road accidents, the implementation of the eCall system with direct connection to European Emergency Number 112 is a milestone in road prevention. By automatically establishing, in the event of a car accident, a direct link to the European Emergency Service 112, transmitting a minimum set of accident, vehicle and passenger data, eCall will allow for faster, more effective and lower costly rescue. I would remind you that eCall is free, secure, works in all Member States and complies with strict data protection rules. I therefore welcome the adoption of this important regulation to which I have made my contribution as shadow rapporteur for the EPP.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. I support the introduction of the on-board eCall system in vehicles. Time and again, emergency services arrive late at the scene of the accident due to a lack of or incorrect location information. As a result, the rescue workers lose valuable time, which can decide on life and death. I therefore welcome the fact that, from 31 March 2018, car manufacturers will have to introduce the eCall emergency call system into their new cars.  The eCall system automatically notifies the emergency services via the emergency number 112 after a serious accident and thus helps to save lives. This ensures that data protection is guaranteed.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation at second reading drawn up by Olga Sehnalová on the development of the on-board eCall system. The benefits of putting this system into operation will be manifold and have been proven by in-depth studies, including: the reduction of the percentage of victims and serious injuries, the reduction of traffic jams, the timely intervention of all necessary rescues, the elimination of sos columns along motorways.  The proposal to install an eCall tool on all EU motor vehicles will enable emergency services to respond promptly, wherever they arise within the Union's borders. The system will help reduce the fragmentation of services and the market and facilitate the free and safe movement of European citizens. I would remind you, however, that this system cannot replace road education in any way, especially among young people, who must know the Highway Code and be aware of what behaviour must be taken in urban and extra-urban contexts.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ In the event of a car accident, the eCall system establishes communication with the European emergency services (112) providing a minimum set of information about the accident, vehicle and passenger(s), allowing a faster, more effective response with less costs. The eCall system is free, safe, can work in all Member States and respects the rules on data protection. I thus voted in favour of the report in order to guarantee interoperability and continuity of the service throughout Europe.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The implementation of this system may clash with some individual rights and freedoms. For this reason, we welcome the proposed amendment which suggests that manufacturers should ensure that users of the eCall system can easily and manually deactivate the system on board their vehicles if they wish. Conditions need to be created to reduce accidents on roads, build safe roads, improve existing traffic and safety conditions and jointly promote actions with relevant victim relief entities. These are indispensable measures for accident prevention and relief, and eCall is a good mechanism to contribute to this. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. – Adequate availability of emergency assistance is an integral part of the single market and its freedoms in order to increase road safety. In the 21st century, Europe cannot allow emergency services not to have a single IT backend or to stop data search and positioning, since operating in its previous form has not only not promoted it, but it makes it particularly difficult to organise a single approach to assistance. Particular attention should be paid to the existence of technical conditions. It is important to create a free system that works effectively at EU level and respects data protection. This conditionality is met in the second reading report and I therefore voted in favour of it.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this initiative, because I believe that this is a development which can save lives. The deployment of a public EU-wide emergency call system embedded in the vehicle and based on 112 represents a very important and concrete achievement for the safety of citizens. Through such a development, about 2 500 lives could be saved every year in Europe.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. The purpose of this report is to deploy an automatic and manual emergency call system in the event of a serious accident involving personal vehicles from 1 October 2015. This text will eventually enable all EU vehicles to be equipped and the emergency and response services of member states to be adapted to the minimum functionality necessary to ensure adequate call handling. Considering that this system should strengthen the capacity of Member States to respond to road accidents, improve road safety while respecting the principle of subsidiarity, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. With more than 100 million road journeys a year across the EU, road safety is a major issue for citizens. The deployment of the on-board eCall system is a real step forward from this point of view.  In the face of numerous road accidents, this system will allow faster management of the injured. This will be a factor in reducing road deaths.  Moreover, in a free-movement area, ensuring the continuity of emergency call service in all Member States seems essential to me. That is why I voted in favour of this text, which has European added value.

name: Philippe De Backer (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the proposal by the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection (IMCO) to install a life-saving emergency call system in cars. I am in favour of this system because I believe that the emergency services can give a swifter response to car crashes with the eCall system. An estimated 2 500 lives can be saved throughout Europe as the call system enables the emergency services to reach crash scenes faster. Another reason why I voted in favour of eCall is because the system works only as a safety device and not as a method of tracking vehicles to misuse location data. As rapporteur for the related Committee on Transport and Tourism (TRAN) eCall report, I am looking forward to the inauguration of the eCall system on the 31 March 2018.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The on-board eCall system represents a strong innovation for the transport sector. These new emergency call devices must be installed on all new models of cars and light vans by March 31, 2018 and will be able to automatically alert the emergency services in the event of a road accident. The information transmitted will allow you to immediately know the type and size of the necessary rescue operation, allowing rescuers to reach the place faster. In addition, according to some estimates, the eCall system will reduce the number of road accident deaths by about 10% per year.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. The text aims to introduce in the EU an obligation to install the eCall system for all vehicles from 2018. The principle: in the event of an accident, the vehicle will automatically call 112 and automatically send the basic data (vehicle type, fuel type, accident time and vehicle location) to the emergency services.  I supported this text because the measures it provides should save lives. Everyone knows that in the event of an accident, the first few minutes are of paramount importance and that they greatly determine the chances of survival of the victims. The eCall system should save valuable minutes by automatically (or manually triggering) relevant information to emergency services.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. Road accidents still kill 70 people every day in the European Union. In 2014, 28,000 people died and more than one million were seriously injured.  The deployment of the free "eCall" system, an emergency call on board the vehicles, will automatically alert the 112 emergency services in the event of an accident and thus locate the vehicle and speed up the response of the emergency services.  From 31 March 2018, new models of passenger cars and light commercial vehicles will need to be equipped. It is obviously necessary that this facility be financially and regulatoryly "neutral" for manufacturers and users so as not to jeopardize the economic recovery.  Finally, the "eCall" system must comply with the highest data protection requirements. After lengthy negotiations with the Council, the European Parliament has secured a continuous and unseating of them, ruling out the risk of possible tracing.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Adequate availability of emergency assistance is an integral part of the single market and the freedoms it provides. In the 21st century, Europe cannot allow emergency services not to have a single IT backend or to stop data search and positioning, since operation in its previous form has not only not promoted it, but it makes it particularly difficult to organise a single approach to assistance. According to the Hungarian delegation of the European People's Party, special attention should also be paid to the existence of technical conditions. We are proud to say that the Hungarian Government is committed to the operation of the eCall system. It is important to create a free system that works effectively at EU level and respects data protection. This conditionality is met in the second reading report and I therefore voted positively in favour.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. This proposed regulation aims to introduce the requirement for car manufacturers to install an on-board eCall system in certain types of motor vehicles. The device would provide adequate handling of emergency calls by the response services and the sending of a GPS signal to enable rescuers to easily locate the crashed vehicle. The expected benefits are the reduction in the number of fatalities and the severity of injuries, as well as lower congestion costs. However, this system seems questionable regarding the protection of users' privacy. We cannot guarantee that these provisions have no purpose other than the safety of users. In particular, it risks driving up the price of automobiles. Although an amendment provides that users can unplug this geolocation system fairly easily, it would be more appropriate for users to be able to initiate this system voluntarily only if they wish.  These uncertainties regarding the protection of privacy and the purchasing power of users, as well as the impact assessment, will lead me to vote against this proposed regulation. However, I voted in favour of the amendment, which is to make it easier and manual for users to unplug the eCall system.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support this report, as it is very important that citizens be able to have a public system free of charge, not only for emergencies, but also to have a much more efficient rapid connection mechanism that can save many lives. In Bulgaria, we were one of the first to support this initiative and adopted the entire eCall pilot system in our national legislation as early as 14/02/2014. This report will contribute not only to the further improvement of the system, but especially to improving the balance within the EU itself, so that this service is available to all very soon.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the recommendation because there are no guarantees that electronic monitoring systems will not be used for illegal acts and because the protection of personal data is not fully guaranteed.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Adequate availability of emergency assistance is an integral part of the single market and the freedoms it provides. In the 21st century, Europe cannot allow emergency services not to have a single IT backend or to stop data search and positioning, since operating in the previous form has not only not promoted it, but makes it particularly difficult to organise a single approach to assistance. According to the Hungarian delegation of the European People's Party, special attention should also be paid to the existence of technical conditions. We are proud to say that the Hungarian Government is committed to the operation of the eCall system. It is important to create a free system that works effectively at EU level and respects data protection. This conditionality is met in the second reading report and I therefore voted positively in favour.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 ECall is an emergency road safety system which, in the event of a car accident, automatically makes a direct connection to the European Emergency Service 112 (via sensors installed in the vehicle to public safety service points), while sending a set of data on the vehicle's location. Reducing mortality on European roads is the great objective of this measure which i agree with. The introduction of points in the privacy and data protection proposal, including the continuous and automatic removal of data or the permission to retain the last three locations of the vehicle, improved the initial proposal. I highlight the precious and excellent work done in this matter by my colleague Carlos Coelho.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The implementation of the eCall system involves the installation in all VEHICLES of the European Union of a minimum of features necessary for the location of the car accident, as well as the interoperability of the system in the various Member States. The implementation of this system may conflict with some individual rights and freedoms. We therefore consider that the installation of equipment of this nature should be at the discretion of users. This is positive, the proposed amendment suggests that manufacturers should ensure that users of the eCall system can easily manually disable the on-board system in their vehicles if they so wish. It is for the Member States to create conditions aimed at reducing road accidents, in particular, among other measures, building safe roads, improving the conditions of movement and safety of existing ones, promoting, together with the competent authorities, actions to control and prevent motor traffic, and provide means and equipment to the authorities responsible for rapid aid to victims. These are indispensable measures for the prevention and rescue of car accidents. The existence of a system like eCall cannot lessen its importance.

name: Raffaele Fitto (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted with conviction in favour of the report. The eCall emergency system will be able to automatically alert emergency services in the event of a road accident, improving both road safety and the speed of rescue.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The introduction of a pan-European interoperable eCall service has been on the agenda of the European institutions since 2005, and although this innovative system could save thousands of lives, the implementation deadline is constantly being postponed. Road safety must be one of the European Union's main priorities. It is very important to adopt legislation that will improve the safety of Citizens of the Member States on the roads in the European Union, because statistics on road fatalities are very saddening. In addition to increasing active safety, we must not forget passive safety and constantly work to improve and improve the efficiency of rescue and medical services. The gradual deployment of the eCall on-board system will produce positive results in the future, because if there is a serious traffic accident, every minute or second decides whether or not the person in question survives. We must support any innovative system that can reduce the response time of arrival of emergency services, and at the same time we can reduce in this way the total number of traffic jams caused by road accidents.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the system whose purpose is to activate the eCall system with an automatic emergency call to the number 112 in the event of a serious accident.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the development of the eCall system in vehicles because there are no guarantees that electronic monitoring systems will not be used for illegal transactions and because the safeguarding of personal data is not fully guaranteed.

name: Ashley Fox (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this measure as I do not believe that eCall should be compulsory. This measure will make cars more expensive for the consumer. It also ignores the views of motoring organisations which say that drivers should be left to deal with the circumstances on the road.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ On 13 June 2013, the Commission adopted two proposals to ensure that by October 2015 cars will automatically call emergency services in the event of a serious crash. The eCall system automatically dials 112 – Europeʼs single emergency number – in the event of a serious accident. This legislative package contained the Regulation on the in-vehicle system which establishes the technical requirements for the EC type-approval of vehicles regarding the eCall in-vehicle system on the basis of which the Sehnalová report has been drafted.  The deployment of a public EU-wide emergency call system embedded in the vehicle and based on the 112 number represents a very important and concrete achievement for the safety of citizens. About 2 500 lives could be saved every year in Europe. I therefore voted for adoption of the report.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Adequate availability of emergency assistance is an integral part of the single market and the freedoms it provides. In the 21st century, Europe cannot allow emergency services not to have a single IT backend or to stop data search and positioning, since operating in the previous form has not only not promoted it, but makes it particularly difficult to organise a single approach to assistance. According to the Hungarian delegation of the European People's Party, special attention should also be paid to the existence of technical conditions. We are proud to say that the Hungarian Government is committed to the operation of the eCall system. It is important to create a free system that works effectively at EU level and respects data protection. This conditionality is met in the second reading report and I therefore voted positively in favour.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Adequate availability of emergency assistance is an integral part of the single market and the freedoms it provides. In the 21st century, Europe cannot allow emergency services not to have a single IT backend or to stop data search and positioning, since operating in the former form has not only not promoted it, but it makes it particularly difficult to organise assistance with a uniform approach. According to the Hungarian delegation of the European People's Party, special attention should also be paid to the existence of technical conditions. We are proud to say that the Hungarian Government is committed to the operation of the eCall system. It is important to create a free system that works effectively at EU level and respects data protection. This conditionality is met in the second reading report and I therefore voted positively in favour.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this draft Legislative Resolution of the European Parliament bearing in mind the safety and physical integrity of passengers travelling in vehicles. Further progress is needed in all those mechanisms to provide greater safety and speed in the reaction to a possible traffic accident.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The eCall system, already approved by the European Parliament at first reading, represents a major breakthrough in terms of safety protection for hundreds of thousands of European citizens moving by car.  I voted in favour of the recommendation for second reading so that an effective regulation on type-approval requirements for the development of the system can be adopted as soon as possible.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. In 2014, some 25 700 people died in road accidents in Europe. The situation fell slightly (1%) in 2013, but there is still much to be done for full road safety. The 2011/2020 Guidelines programme for road safety is one of the instruments that the Union intends to use to promote effective prevention measures. with a transition phase by 2018, the new types of cars with the eCall safety system that, in the event of an accident, will send an alarm with the exact location of its position to 112, for sudden intervention and immediate assistance.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. I have advocated the introduction of the eCall system in vehicles. With the new technology, an automatic 112 emergency call is triggered in the event of an accident in order to shorten the time until the helpers arrive. In Parliament, we have decided that from 2018 every new vehicle must have eCall technology. Far too many people are still dying on Europe's roads. Thanks to the innovative technology, rescue workers can get to the scene of the accident more quickly. It was therefore important to me that this system in new cars should not be voluntary, but compulsory.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Sehnalová report because the deployment of a public EU-wide emergency call system embedded in the cars of EU citizens represents a very important and concrete achievement for the safety of citizens, having the potential to save more than 2 500 lives yearly across Europe. I am proud that my group were the leading force in ensuring this service based on the 112 emergency number, available free of charge to everyone. Crucial in gaining my support was the fact that vehicles equipped with 112 public eCall are not traceable and not subject to constant tracking.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. At last, an agreement has been reached between the European Parliament and the Council for vehicles to carry as standard a device which, in the event of an accident, automatically calls emergency services. This will reduce the response time to rescue and care for the injured, with a 10% reduction in car accident deaths. It is therefore a big step in the fight against accidents on the road. Allowing users to disable the system with ease would make ineffective the obligation we are imposing on manufacturers. That is why I voted against the amendment to that effect. I understand the reluctance raised by some colleagues regarding data privacy, but the approved text prevents vehicle tracking prior to the accident, prohibits emergency services from transferring received information to a third party and requires data to be automatically erased from the device's internal memory.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against it. We understand that the granting of systems that promote quality and technology at the service of prevention must be welcome, although in this case it is not clear what will be done with the information collected by these new telecommunications systems. We understand that reports and amendments are needed to ensure the privacy of information produced in the field of telecommunications before promoting system deployments without such prior guarantee.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report to support the deployment of the eCall in-vehicle system. The deployment of a public EU-wide emergency call system embedded in the vehicle is an important achievement for the safety of citizens and can save lives across Europe. From 31 March 2018, all new cars and light commercial vehicles will be equipped with an eCall emergency device that will automatically dial the 112 emergency number in the event of an accident, sending details of the accident to emergency services. This will also be free of charge for all citizens.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which requires that new types of passenger cars and light commercial vehicles be built in such a way as to ensure the automatic triggering of an emergency call (eCall) to number 112 in the event of a serious accident. Road safety is such a matter of great concern to all our citizens. I therefore welcome this action at European level which will ensure interoperability and continuity of service.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this directive because in the event of a car accident it will call the emergency phone number and transmit data with the details of the vehicle, the type of fuel used, the time of the accident and the exact location. I believe it will help to save lives and facilitate the work of the emergency services.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Adequate availability of emergency assistance is an integral part of the single market and the freedoms it provides. In the 21st century, Europe cannot allow emergency services not to have a single IT backend or to stop data search and positioning, since operating in its previous form has not only not promoted it, but it makes it particularly difficult to organise a single approach to assistance. According to the Hungarian delegation of the European People's Party, special attention should also be paid to the existence of technical conditions. We are proud to say that the Hungarian Government is committed to the operation of the eCall system. It is important to create a free system that works effectively at EU level and respects data protection. This conditionality is met in the second reading report and I therefore voted positively in favour.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this proposal as it introduces in all vehicles in the EU the minimum functionalities needed to ensure appropriate handling of emergency calls by the emergency response services. Action is needed at EU level in order to guarantee interoperability and continuity of the service throughout Europe.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. The Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection has introduced a draft law into Parliament requiring car manufacturers to introduce an on-board emergency call system in all 28 European countries. I think that such a system can be useful, and I would also be able to afford to install such a system. I just wonder why the European Commission should deal with this. I believe that this should be left to the manufacturers and, above all, to the motorists in the countries themselves. A single emergency number ('112') is certainly a matter that should be dealt with throughout Europe and therefore also in Brussels. This is an example of 'more Europe', which I can endorse. But requiring the installation of such costly systems in all countries at the same time goes too far. This should be left to the manufacturers, to the countries and, above all, to the motorists themselves. That is why I voted against today.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Adequate availability of emergency assistance is an integral part of the single market and the freedoms it provides. In the 21st century, Europe cannot allow emergency services not to have a single IT backend or to stop data search and positioning, since operation in its previous form has not only not promoted it, but it makes it particularly difficult to organise a single approach to assistance. According to the Hungarian delegation of the European People's Party, special attention should also be paid to the existence of technical conditions. We are proud to say that the Hungarian Government is committed to the operation of the eCall system. It is important to create a free system that works effectively at EU level and respects data protection. This conditionality is met in the second reading report and I therefore voted in favour.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. This is a concrete achievement of the European Union, the effects of which will be able to be measured by 2018. The introduction of an automatic on-board call system in vehicles that triggers in an emergency and contacts the emergency services will save valuable time for response teams and will surely save lives. I do not know if the ambition to reduce the annual number of road deaths by 10%, but it is certain that this device will demonstrate its effectiveness as soon as it is operational. The European Union is regularly accused of being disconnected from the population. This type of initiative confirms that this is in no way the case.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against it. We understand that the granting of systems that promote quality and technology at the service of prevention must be welcome, although in this case it is not clear what will be done with the information collected by these new telecommunications systems. We understand that reports and amendments are needed to ensure the privacy of information produced in the field of telecommunications before promoting system deployments without such prior guarantee.

name: Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz (EFDD)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The e-Call system can undoubtedly be an interesting solution to help save accident victims. However, its main problem, which was the imco committee's dispute over the mandatory installation and data security, has still not been resolved. As the producers point out, the mandatory requirement will lead to an increase in the price by around EUR 150 and will increase the costs for producers for research. Another issue is the issue of the protection of personal data, which is still not subject to adequate safeguards, so that the security of personal data collected and acquired by the e-Call system cannot be guaranteed. For this reason, I voted against.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the Council's position at first reading in order to adopt a regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on approval requirements for the introduction of a vehicle-based e-Call system based on service 112 and an amendment to Directive 2007/46/EC, as it requires new types of passenger vehicles and light commercial vehicles to be constructed in such a way as to ensure that an automatic or manual emergency call to 112 is launched in the event of an accident.  Some of the advantages are reducing road accidents, reducing the number of injuries and deaths, ensuring faster access to services that help the afflicted, greater safety of such services when working, reducing road congestion, reducing the need for other road safety infrastructure.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. This proposed regulation aims to introduce the requirement for car manufacturers to install an on-board eCall system in certain types of motor vehicles. The device would provide adequate handling of emergency calls by the response services and the sending of a GPS signal to enable rescuers to easily locate the crashed vehicle. The expected benefits are the reduction in the number of fatalities and the severity of injuries, as well as lower congestion costs. However, this system seems questionable regarding the protection of users' privacy. We cannot guarantee that these in particular will drive up the price of automobiles. Although an amendment provides that users can unplug this geolocation system fairly easily, it would be more appropriate for users to be able to initiate this system voluntarily only if they wish.  These uncertainties regarding the protection of privacy and the purchasing power of users, as well as the impact assessment, will lead me to vote against this proposed regulation. However, I voted in favour of the amendment, which is to make it easier and manual for users to unplug the eCall system.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the eCall system, which automatically calls 112 in the event of a car accident, and establishes a link to more rapid and efficient help in the event of an emergency. The technological improvement introduced in all new vehicles is an important one. Nevertheless I believe consumers should have the right to choose whether or not to activate the system in their own car.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Olga Sehnalova's report on the deployment of the eCall system as part of the EU's road safety policy. This system, once deployed in the new car models, will allow the European Rescue Service 112 to be automatically called in serious accidents, allowing emergency services to arrive quickly at the scene of the accident, including in the event of loss of consciousness of the accident person. The report will ensure interoperability and continuity of the system across Europe and preserve the privacy and data protection of citizens. I welcome the adoption of this report which will reduce the loss of life on the road in Europe.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this recommendation for the deployment of the eCall emergency call system. This recommendation requires that new types of passenger cars and light commercial vehicles be constructed to ensure that an emergency call to number 112 is automatically triggered in the event of a serious accident, while ensuring the protection of personal data. This is a major step forward in rescuing victims of road accidents.  I welcome this vote.

name: Kaja Kallas (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the positive outcome of the vote on eCall. The deployment of the eCall system for new cars will be vital in order to reduce the number of traffic fatalities, as it will allow emergency services to arrive as soon as possible. We must also ensure that citizens’ privacy is to be respected and see to it that the system will not give rise to improper use.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the regulation on the creation of an eCall system in cars because I believe that this will save many lives in the event of accidents. This law requires car manufacturers to insert a device in the production process that automatically calls the responsible services in the event of an accident. This system allows an ambulance to arrive in advance to the specific place where the accident occurred. In situations where every minute is important for saving human life, it is very important that ambulances arrive as soon as possible.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this recommendation, which would require all new car models to be equipped with eCall technology from 31 March 2018. It is expected that this technology could save 2 500 lives a year in Europe and reduce the gravity of injuries through the earlier arrival of assistance. Road accidents across the EU caused 28 000 deaths and left 1.5 million injured in 2012, and cause an economic burden of EUR 130 billion every year. In 2014 alone, 196 people lost their lives on Irish roads, the second consecutive year in which there was a rise in Irish road fatalities. This new technology could speed up emergency response times by 40% in urban areas and 50% in the countryside, benefiting all Irish and EU citizens.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I very much welcome the report as it represents a very important and concrete achievement for the safety of citizens. The quicker response by the emergency services to accidents on roads across Europe could save about 2 500 lives in the EU every year. Moreover, the vehicles equipped with the 112 public eCall system will not be traceable and not subject to constant tracking. In fact, the device will upgrade the data constantly and keep the minimum information required to handle the emergency calls.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although I believe that Mrs Sehnalová's proposal is of high quality and has my support, I believe that this system deserves less adjustment. We live in a world in which the differences between private and public life are erased, and it is becoming increasingly difficult to maintain our privacy. I have therefore decided to agree to an amendment which states that: "Manufacturers will ensure that eCall users can easily deactivate the eCall on-board system." I believe that it is not necessary for eCall to monitor the movement of our means of transport 24 hours a day and to expose us to further monitoring. Citizens should have the right to shut down the system if it is in accordance with their wishes. We should limit dictation and rather present options. Forcing someone to watch without offering an alternative is not very worthy of the 21st century, and we should think about what kind of relationship we want to have with our citizens. I am therefore sorry that this amendment has not been adopted and we are in danger of being monitored a little more in the future.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Adequate availability of emergency assistance is an integral part of the single market and the freedoms it provides. In the 21st century, Europe cannot allow emergency services not to have a single IT backend or to stop data search and positioning, since operation in its previous form has not only not promoted it, but it makes it particularly difficult to organise a single approach to assistance. According to the Hungarian delegation of the European People's Party, special attention should also be paid to the existence of technical conditions. We are proud to say that the Hungarian Government is committed to the operation of the eCall system. It is important to create a free system that works effectively at EU level and respects data protection. This conditionality is met in the second reading report and I therefore voted positively in favour.

name: Alexander Graf Lambsdorff (ALDE)
text: Writing. ECall systems are designed to automatically transmit position data and direction of travel to the emergency call centre in the event of an accident. The use of modern technology for road safety is fundamentally to be welcomed. However, a red line is crossed if this data can theoretically also be used to create motion profiles of all motorists. It was therefore important for the FDP that motorists must have the freedom to switch off the eCall system manually if they do not want to use it. This freedom of choice would have been possible with the on/off button in the car proposed by the Liberals. Unfortunately, the majority of Parliament has today opted for the glass motorist. Despite the promise that the data will only be transmitted in the event of an accident, used properly and deleted immediately after evaluation, there is a risk that personal data will be collected, stored and used for other purposes. That is why the FDP rejects eCall in this form.

name: Jérôme Lavrilleux (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the SEHNALOV report, following the European Commission's legislative proposal to roll out an automatic emergency call system in new cars. The e-call system, which will be effective from 31 March 2018, will allow rescuers to have the position of a crashed vehicle in an instant and thus reduce, according to the commission's estimates, the number of road deaths by 10% per year. With more than 25,000 deaths on European roads each year, the mobilization of digital intelligence is proving to be an innovative and adapted solution. It should be remembered that this e-call system is part of proposals supported during the campaign for the European elections.

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 It is estimated that the introduction of the e-Call system will reduce the number of fatalities by around 2500 each year. The system will automatically connect to the nearest emergency call centre via mobile network, even when passengers are unable to speak. The issue of the protection of personal data is the most controversial, but it should be remembered that it is not a permanent connection to the network, and the system is active only when an accident occurs. The introduction of e-Call is an important step towards increasing road safety in the European Union.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. At the end of March 2018, all commercial cars and light vehicles will need to be equipped with eCall devices that will automatically connect to the 112 in the event of an accident. The rapporteur for the report in the IMCO Commission was Olga Sehnalova of the S&D Group, who stressed that the new system will improve road safety and significantly reduce the arrival time of emergency services when a serious accident occurs. The eCall system will be a free public service for all citizens, regardless of the vehicle model or the price of the vehicle. It is estimated that the rapid response of emergency services could save the lives of 2,500 people each year and the number and severity of injuries would be significantly reduced.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The implementation of this system may clash with some individual rights and freedoms. For this reason, we welcome the proposed amendment which suggests that manufacturers should ensure that users of the eCall system can easily and manually deactivate the system on board their vehicles if they wish. Conditions need to be created to reduce accidents on roads, build safe roads, improve existing traffic and safety conditions and jointly promote actions with relevant victim relief entities. These are indispensable measures for accident prevention and relief, and eCall is a good mechanism to contribute to this. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I have nothing against improving vehicle safety or introducing new elements that can contribute to improving passenger safety. However, I do not agree with mandatory and centralised ordering. It is the customer's right to choose which car to choose and whether to buy the one in which the eCall system will be built in.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The fact that more than 100 million people lose their lives annually on the roads of the Member States of the European Union is worrying for everyone. One way this black statistic could be reduced is by introducing an e-Call system.  The plan is for the system to be installed in all vehicles registered in the Member States to ensure adequate response and emergency treatment in the event of an accident. I support Rapporteur Sehnalova's recommendation and believe that with the entry into force of this regulation, scheduled for 31 March 2018, the number of accidents on European roads will be significantly reduced.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because long ago it was worth it. This system will save around 2 000 lives a year. It will cost just tens of euros.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the recommendation for second reading on the Council's position at first reading on the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on type-approval requirements for the development of the eCall system based on service 112 on vehicles and amending Directive 2007/46/EC, because I believe that eCall does not guarantee the safeguarding and protection of personal data and privacy, because, firstly, eCall is compulsory in all cars, secondly, because it continues to operate even against the will of the driver, thirdly, because the principle of flexibility creates significant gaps in privacy, fourthly, because personal data will be retained for some time; , fifthly, because personal data will be available to private operators.

name: Marian-Jean Marinescu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the Approval Requirements Regulation for the installation of an eCall system based on the 112 in-vehicle service so that citizens can benefit from it from 2018. 26,000 people die in road accidents every year in the EU. The improvement of security on European roads is urgent and requires a system that can shorten the time it takes response teams to reach the accident site. ECall is a valuable, free and secure tool in terms of respecting private data protection.  Accident location data must be used for the same purpose: halving road deaths over the next 10 years.  The negotiations of this regulation clarified the rules according to which the coordinates of the vehicle are transmitted only in the event of the start of the 112 service. This data is transmitted only to 112, not to other operators.  The mandatory nature of eCall for new types of cars is paramount. Parliament voted today to introduce this life-saving tool which can be compared to the introduction of the seat belt and airbag. ECall is a good example of what can be done at European level for the citizen: from March 2018, eCall will be operational on all roads in Europe.

name: Dominique Martin (NI)
text: In writing. Although there is no final vote at second reading Dominique Martin is against this project. This eCall system is supposed to automatically trigger a call to the emergency number in the event of an accident and allow geolocation. This means that all vehicles will be able to be located at any time without users knowing who is using this information. This is an invasion of users' privacy.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the adoption of this regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council concerning type-approval requirements for the deployment of the eCall in-vehicle system based on the 112 service.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The recommendation for second reading concerning the Council's position on the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on type-approval requirements for the development of the on-board eCall system based on service 112 and amending Directive 2007/46/EC does not support me.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of developing the on-board eCall system, as I believe it is a good tool for increasing the possibility of saving the lives of road accident victims.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. Saving lives on the roads remains, to this day, a matter of paramount importance. For some years now we have discussed in the EU how to do this and one of the measures we think it can serve is what we now approve: the installation in cars of a rescue and emergency call device in the event of an accident. My support for the agreement reached with the Council, as this new technology will undoubtedly serve to help victims and reduce the severity of injuries.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. The eCall system is an emergency call system built into the car to ensure automatic notification of emergency services in an accident situation. The safety aspect is laudable, but it must be borne in mind that all vehicle manufacturers, regardless of the 'own' emergency call systems already installed, are forced to install the 'public' system as standard in all new cars, and in many respects the costs and implementation are not clarified. There is also a risk of misuse of this system, as the data sets can be passed on to third parties with the permission of the data subject. Thus, insurance undertakings can also obtain this data and misuse it because of the weaker position of the policyholder. For these reasons, I voted against the decision to introduce the on-board eCall system in vehicles.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as the eCall devices fitted in new car models and light vans can automatically alert emergency service in the event of an accident. These devices are capable of cutting traffic deaths by 10%.

name: Gesine Meissner (ALDE)
text: Writing. ECall systems are designed to automatically transmit position data and direction of travel to the emergency call centre in the event of an accident. The use of modern technology for road safety is fundamentally to be welcomed. However, a red line is crossed if this data can theoretically also be used to create motion profiles of all motorists. It was therefore important for the FDP that motorists must have the freedom to switch off the eCall system manually if they do not want to use it. This freedom of choice would have been possible with the on/off button in the car proposed by the Liberals. Unfortunately, the majority of Parliament has today opted for the glass motorist. Despite the promise that the data will only be transmitted in the event of an accident, used properly and deleted immediately after evaluation, there is a risk that personal data will be collected, stored and used for other purposes. That is why the FDP rejects eCall in this form.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The E-call system is an on-board emergency call system. It is being developed at European level because Europeans are increasingly crossing the borders of their country of origin to other EU countries. The Council took into account Parliament's criticisms at first reading. In particular, it made it mandatory for the eCall system to be compatible with the Galileo and EGNOS navigation systems. It also specifies the applicable rules for the protection of personal data. Certainly I continue to regret that this system does not include a permanent translation service within the eCall service. But to the extent that it will help save lives I vote FOR.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 New models of light and commercial vehicles sold in the EU will have to be equipped with the eCall system from 31 March 2018. The deployment of this system on board vehicles on the basis of number 112 aims to reduce mortality on European roads and ensure better assistance to road accident victims. eCall is an emergency system in the field of road safety which, in the event of a car accident, automatically makes a direct connection to the vehicle by means of sensors installed in the vehicle to the European Emergency Service 112 (through public safety service points), while sending a set of data on the location of the vehicle. This is a very important mechanism which will in future reduce accidents on European roads. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The eCall in-vehicle system will save lives on our roads and I wholeheartedly support its implementation.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I welcome the European Parliament's desire to generalise the technology system known as eCall in Europe. This system automatically calls the European emergency number, 112, in case of road accidents and immediately gives the location and details of the vehicle.  All new vehicles will have to be equipped with this new device from 2018. This is an important step that will save lives as some studies suggest that emergency response times will be halved, particularly in rural areas.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In rescue operations in connection with traffic accidents, minutes are decided by life and death. Emergency services must therefore have at their disposal the exact navigation to the crash site in order to be able to provide first aid to the victims of accidents as soon as possible. Unfortunately, inaccurate information about the location of the accident provided by injured or shocked accident participants or other witnesses has little information value and thus creates delays in rescue action. The eCall on-board system, which automatically activates and calls the emergency number 112 itself after a serious accident has been recorded, will speed up the call of emergency services to the exact crash site to help save the lives of thousands of citizens and improve overall road safety. For these reasons, I am voting in favour of adopting the recommendation for second reading on the Council's position at first reading with a view to adopting a regulation on type-approval requirements for the deployment of the eCall in-vehicle system using the 112 emergency services. As a doctor, I believe that eCall will soon be launched in all Member States.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report on the deployment of a public EU-wide emergency call system embedded in the vehicle and based on 112, which represents a very important and concrete achievement for the safety of citizens. About 2 500 lives could be saved every year in Europe.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Council recently approved the requirement for cars to have an automatic system for connecting to health care services in the event that vehicles are in accidents. I support this report which will improve passenger safety conditions and speed up medical service provided during an accident. It should be noted that all cars should have this system up and running as soon as possible, helping to reduce the number of fatalities that still exist on European roads.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. The eCall system aims to speed up the emergency call procedure for road accidents. A European Union regulation therefore envisages generalising it and introducing an obligation for car manufacturers to install the on-board eCall system. However, several criticisms can be made. First of all, this system is expensive, which may increase the final price of vehicles, and this for a gain in terms of reducing the severity of accidents that has yet to be demonstrated. Second, it is an invasion of privacy. How can we ensure that this data is not used for purposes other than that of relief? Indeed, the geolocation of accident vehicles means that all vehicles can be tracked. This is yet another blow from the Commission against Individual Freedoms and Privacy. In these circumstances, I can only oppose this text and vote against it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The deployment of a public EU-wide emergency call system embedded in the vehicle (and based on the 112 emergency number) represents a very important and concrete achievement for the safety of citizens, having the potential to save more than 2 500 lives yearly across Europe.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text on the deployment of the European eCall system. From 2018, all new vehicles will have to be equipped with this system which will automatically call for help in the event of a serious accident. The eCall system is likely to save many lives, while in Europe 25,700 people lost their lives in a road accident in 2014. It comes with strong privacy safeguards, such as the location of the vehicle only in the event of the airbag being triggered and the limited extent of data automatically transmitted to the emergency services by the aircraft.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We express our full and strong support for this proposal, which aims to introduce an on-board eCall system into the EC type-approval system for motor vehicles.  This plant, installed in new types of passenger cars and light vehicles, will in fact be able to guarantee, in the event of a serious accident, an automatic emergency call to the number 112. This call will provide a minimum set of data such as the type of vehicle, the location of the vehicle and the direction of travel which allow and facilitate the rapid intervention of the rescue vehicles.  We believe it is essential to improve road safety, in order to reduce the increasing number of fatal accidents throughout Europe and to facilitate the work of teams and emergency services. The development of a single system at European level is a concrete step towards the security of all European citizens: the protection of privacy and the protection of their personal data will be ensured through non-traceability of the vehicle and the absence of constant control under the normal operating conditions of eCall.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal aims to introduce into the EC type-approval system for motor vehicles the obligation to install an on-board eCall system. In the event of a serious accident, this plant will automatically forward an emergency call to number 112 which will provide operators with a minimum set of data, such as the type of vehicle, the location of the vehicle and the direction of travel, which will allow and facilitate rapid intervention by the rescue vehicles.  According to official statistics on eCall, it is estimated that the full integration of the system into the cars of the EU Member States will save up to 2 500 lives each year, but also reduce the severity of injuries caused by road accidents by 10-15%. For these reasons, I thought it appropriate to vote in favour of the report.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted on this report on the Council's first-reading position with a view to adopting the European Parliament and Council Regulation on type-approval requirements for the installation of an eCall system based on the 112 in-vehicle service and amending Directive 2007/46/EC, because I believe that the installation of the 112-based eCall system in the vehicle is extremely necessary and very useful to all citizens.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the introduction of the eCall in-flight system, because I consider the mandatory enactment of eCall to be a step forward. At the same time, it should be added that many carmakers, such as BMW, Ford, Peugeot/Citroen and Volvo, are not waiting for a European prescription and are already equipping their cars with eCall or similar technologies. This is proof that road safety is being given great attention in the EU.

name: Péter Niedermüller (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 In my view, the proposal can increase road safety, save lives in the event of a major road accident and contribute to the most efficient use of the resources available for rescue. Although there are costs for consumers, they are negligible compared to the individual and Community benefits available.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. In principle, an automatic emergency call system with rapid help is an important and also very good decision. However, I see a few problems here: on the one hand, the problem here is with regard to the telematics platform – data protection. I doubt that the flood of data, which is certainly desirable for car manufacturers, will be kept secret. It will attract another industry, namely insurance companies. I see another problem in security. Especially in rural areas, there is a lack of reception coverage. Furthermore, not all rescue workers can be everywhere at the same time. Because of these numerous problems, I have expressed my opposition to this recommendation.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. – I supported the proposal because it should enable the emergency services to arrive more quickly at the crash site, thus saving lives and preventing more serious injuries as a result of complications.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE)
text: in writing. This Regulation calls for the introduction of an emergency call system (eCall) in commercial cars and light vehicles as of 31 March 2018. It will be directly connected to emergency service 112 in the event of a serious accident transmitting the exact location of the vehicle, so the number of road accidents and deaths is expected to be significantly reduced. We have decided to vote in favour of this initiative as long as the data protection provisions are respected and users are not subject to permanent tracking.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI)
text: Writing. – The regulation is falsified and not innocent at all. It creates a system of mandatory, permanent and continuous satellite monitoring of all vehicles and their passengers, even against their will. The fact that the European Parliament has rejected the amendment allowing the user of the system to turn it off manually shows that the aim of the regulation is not to ensure the safety of passengers but to monitor them.
