The EU is using every pretext to set up a giant monitoring and database network of everything, consisting of the EU's "smart borders" and the EUROSUR system for the continuous monitoring of every third-country national entering the EU, interconnected with the VIS and Eurodack, from the SIS I and SIS II databases in Schengen, by land observation satellites of the GOMES system , by unmanned aircraft (spy) UAVs, by monitoring systems for the "movement and rescue of ships" (VMS systems, SafeSeaNet). They even use the pretext of supposedly fighting the archaeocapel circuits and the looting of works of art by the "jihadists" to activate the EU Satellite Centre in Torrejón. Now they're adding eCall. There is not a single EU policy, even among those who seem 'innocent', which is not aimed at shielding their monopolies and power.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Taking into account the Council's position at first reading (05130/3/2015 – C8-0063/2015) and the opinion of the European Economic and Social Committee of 19 September 2013, I voted not in favour.

name: Florian Philippot (NI)
text: In writing. The proposal of the Basic Regulation requires that new types of passenger cars and light commercial vehicles be constructed to ensure that an emergency call to number 112 is automatically triggered and that a GPS signal is sent to enable rescuers to easily locate the vehicle in the event of an accident, effective October 1, 2015. How can we be assured that this data is not being used for purposes other than that of relief? The geolocation of accident vehicles means above all that all vehicles will be able to be. A wonderful gift for the European Commission and a new intrusion into the privacy of people already badly damaged.  In addition, I want to point out that such a system will have a mechanical impact on the cost of production of the vehicle and therefore on the selling price to the consumer which will be negatively impacted. I therefore vote against this proposal.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted clearly in favour of the resolution introducing an eCall system for our cars, compulsorily and free of charge, so that it is synonymous with help and safety for European citizens.  This mechanism will not only lead to a reduction in the time required for intervention in road accidents, but will therefore lead to more immediate treatment of emergencies and thus to a reduction in road fatalities. From March 2018 each new car will be equipped with such a device that, connected to the digital navigation service automatically in case of need, will send a distress signal with the details of the road accident to the emergency number 112, active throughout Europe. The mechanism will help to reduce road fatalities, which have always been priorities for this Parliament. Speed in response to rescue calls can save about 2,500 lives each year. A service for citizens that will not limit their right to privacy or data protection, vehicles equipped with the eCall device will not, in fact, be tracked or subjected to continuous monitoring, but only the basic information necessary to carry out the roadside assistance service in the event of an accident will be used.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support the Council's position at first reading in order to adopt a regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on type-approval requirements for the introduction of a service-based e-Call system 112 and the amendment to Directive 2007/46/EC.  The introduction of the e-Call service available in all vehicles and in all Member States has been one of the Union's high priorities in the field of road safety since 2003.  The eVocation system should reduce the number of deaths in the Union as well as the severity of road accident injuries, thanks to the current call to the 112 service. The activation of the emergency protocol of service 112 would be based on the received exact location of the accident with the help of a satellite positioning system built into the means of transport, and synchronized with the e-Call. The number of deaths in car accidents in the Union, in 2014 compared to 2010, decreased by 5 700 cases, i.e. 5 700 cases. 18 %. As the Commission aims to reduce by 50% by 2020, the e-Call system would certainly speed up this demanding process. Statistics recording an average of 4 cases of permanent disability, 8 serious and 50 minor injuries with each fatality would also be improved. Therefore, I give strong support to the introduction of e-Calls in vehicles that will ensure greater safety for Union citizens on European roads.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I clearly consider the introduction of a mandatory installation of the eCall on-board system in all (newly produced) passenger vehicles to be a positive step and I am glad that the European Parliament has given it the green light. From the end of March 2018, passenger cars and light commercial vehicles will be equipped with a so-called eCall device, which automatically dials the emergency number 112 in the event of an accident and sends all necessary data to the emergency services headquarters. As a result, this will mean many more lives saved and less material damage. From a formal point of view, the proposal also fully reflects the requirements in relation to personal data protection (we strengthened the data protection clause in the proposal) as well as road safety regulations, European brand standards and certification, as well as regulations on telecommunications networks, electronic and mobile communications. I am glad that the European Parliament has voted over the proposal by the European Liberals to switch off the device manually. This would, of course, make no sense for any investment in eCall.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the vote by a large majority on the proposal introducing an obligation in the EC type-approval system for motor vehicles to install an on-board eCall system. This improves road safety by significantly reducing the number of victims and injuries caused by road accidents.  At the same time, emergency services are facilitated and any user will be able to send an emergency call from their vehicle. In addition, the regulation introduced the possibility for the user to be able to use other emergency systems in addition to those provided by the eCall system, ensuring an even higher level of security.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. At a time when road fatalities are high, the EU must react and encourage Member States to take real measures to improve road safety. This is directly about the lives of every European citizen.  Parliament responded to the call by adopting the regulation to ensure the deployment of the eCall service based on number 112 within the Union. I have spoken in favour of this text in order to provide solutions to improve road safety in the Union.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This resolution shall aim at providing, in the long term, all Union vehicles with the minimum functionalities necessary to ensure adequate handling of emergency calls by intervention services. Action at Union level appears to be necessary to ensure interoperability and continuity of service throughout Europe. The proposed Regulation is part of a set of Union legal acts to ensure the deployment of the eCall service, on the basis of paragraph 112, by 1 October 2015. The proposal requires that new types of private vehicles and light utility vehicles be built to ensure the automatic triggering of an emergency call (eCall) to 112. In addition, rules are laid down for respect for privacy and data protection. I voted in favour.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. 25,700 Europeans lost their lives on our roads last year and it is estimated that one tenth of them are the response time. Not the slowness of the emergency services, but the delay in getting them notified. This afternoon's vote gives the green light to eCall, a device embedded in cars from 2018 to automatically call for help in the event of an accident, even if passengers are unconscious. It is easy to imagine the time saved, let alone in our large states where victims of accidents can remain unreported for long hours, sometimes with dramatic consequences. I have been very sensitive to enhanced data protection for the drivers we are. There is no way that our geolocations will be transmitted to third parties or kept indefinitely. At the risk of what excesses?  It was in the same spirit that I tabled an amendment calling for the possibility of disconnecting the system. It was not supported. I admit that this freedom could have been misused, especially by young people, the first victims of the road: cutting the system systematically, and by bravado, could, in this case, have a dramatic effect.

name: Dominique Riquet (ALDE)
text: In writing. Road safety is one of the european Parliament's main concerns. That is why I welcome the adoption of this report which paves the way for the generalisation of the eCall system on new cars within 2 to 3 years. By providing early warning to emergency services in the event of an accident, this system will contribute greatly to the reduction of deaths on our roads and the severity of injuries. It will also be a cost and time gain for society as a whole if congestion and social security costs are taken into account, as well as the insurance that these accidents can cause. However, we cannot make the digital revolution in transport without safeguards. The text voted in plenary therefore prohibits all follow-up of users via eCall which is also a "dormant" system and is triggered only in case of shock (only the last three positions are recorded to facilitate the arrival of emergency services and are then automatically deleted). In another text, we also ensured that states could establish screening of these calls so as not to clog up emergency services with calls that were more technical assistance.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. On the eCall file, I voted, like the overwhelming majority of my colleagues, against the amendment which provided that users could manually unplug it at will. First, it seems foolish to me to force car manufacturers to install a system on their vehicles in the name of a road safety imperative and then hasten to foresee a possible manual deactivation, as if the instrument were ultimately merely an option. Why allow the deactivation of a function that will be made mandatory for the future construction of automobiles? Secondly, it seems to me that the arguments in favour of manual deactivation, in the name of a need to avoid tracing, are contradicted by the content of the negotiated text: on the question of personal data, the European Parliament has ensured that it is deleted continuously, completely and permanently, thus excluding any inappropriate storage. I welcome the completion of our long work on this regulation: from 2018, in the event of a car accident, an automatic call to emergency 112 will be triggered and will send essential data to the emergency services. By accelerating the arrival of relief efforts on the ground, and providing them with the information they need to do their mission, the system will save lives.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on type-approval requirements for the deployment of the integrated eCall system in vehicles, amending Directive 2007/46/EC. Under this proposal, at the end of March 2018 all commercial cars and light vehicles will have to be equipped with eCall devices that will automatically connect with the 112 emergency services in the event of an accident. This will improve road safety and significantly reduce the arrival time of emergency services in the event of a serious accident. It is estimated that this system could save 2,500 lives each year and reduce the severity of wounds.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. By March 31, 2018, all new models of cars and light commercial vehicles will need to be equipped with emergency call devices (eCalls), which will automatically alert emergency services in the event of an accident. I recall that in 2014, road accidents claimed the lives of 25,700 people in the Union. This figure could be reduced by about 10% per year.  The eCall system will use 112 emergency call technology to automatically alert emergency services in the event of serious traffic accidents. These services will be able to immediately decide the type and extent of the rescue operation required, allowing them to arrive at the scene of the accident more quickly, save lives and mitigate the severity of the injuries.  The voted text also calls for the European Commission to assess, within three years after spring 2018, whether the eCall should be extended to other vehicles such as buses, buses or lorries.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal for the installation of an emergency call system in cars. At the same time, I would like to point out that, although, on the one hand, this system can contribute to saving lives, on the other hand, the Commission has provided very little evidence that the system can actually contribute to this, especially on a densely populated continent such as Europe. At the same time, I would like to call on the producers and the relevant control authorities to ensure that the new system does not become an additional burden on customers, that its price is minimal or at least reduced as quickly as possible. In addition, it is essential to keep track of the fact that the new positioning system does not become an instrument for mass surveillance of citizens, and a number of concerned interest groups have already raised suspicions about this.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which will require all new car models to be equipped with an automatic emergency call system from 31 March 2018. The eCall on-board emergency system will automatically alert emergency services in the event of an accident, allowing rescuers to arrive at the scene of the accident more quickly and save lives.  The on-board eCall system could reduce the number of road accident victims by around 10%, while road accidents still cost 25,700 people in the European Union in 2014.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposed regulation to establish type-approval requirements for the development of the eCall system based on service 112 amending Directive 2007/46/EC, as this legislation represents a significant increase for safety and consumer protection as well as for the progress of the internal market.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. I am in favour of the text, which is the result of the agreement between the EP, the Commission and the Council, which provides for the introduction of an on-board eCall system linked to the 112 service.  This regulation sets out the approval requirements of the eCall system, which will become mandatory for new models of passenger cars and light commercial vehicles from 31 March 2018. The purpose is to activate the eCall system with an automatic emergency call to 112 in the event of a serious accident. Some categories of vehicles have been exempted and the text seems to take due account of the protection of motorists' privacy, access to the provision of the service by independent operators and compatibility with the Galileo and EGNOS satellite navigation systems.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against it. We understand that the granting of systems that promote quality and technology at the service of prevention must be welcome, although in this case it is not clear what will be done with the information collected by these new telecommunications systems. We understand that reports and amendments are needed to ensure the privacy of information produced in the field of telecommunications before promoting system deployments without such prior guarantee.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The implementation of this system may clash with some individual rights and freedoms. For this reason, we welcome the proposed amendment which suggests that manufacturers should ensure that users of the eCall system can easily and manually deactivate the system on board their vehicles if they wish. Conditions need to be created to reduce accidents on roads, build safe roads, improve existing traffic and safety conditions and jointly promote actions with relevant victim relief entities. These are indispensable measures for accident prevention and relief, and eCall is a good mechanism to contribute to this. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have voted in favour of the adoption of the Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the type-approval requirements for the implementation of the on-board eCall system in vehicles. I believe that the mandatory implementation of the eCall system could reduce the response time of rescue teams and thus reduce road mortality. However, I will be aware of the issue of protecting citizens' personal data.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the obligation to install the on-board eCall system in newly approved vehicles because this proposal makes it possible to protect the safety of citizens on the roads more effectively through immediate first aid.  There is talk of reducing fatal accidents by between 1% and 10% and reducing the severity of accident injuries by between 2% and 15%. I am sure that this facility, by automatically forwarding an emergency call to Number 112 in the event of a serious accident, will make a significant contribution to saving many lives.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I fully support the implementation of the eCall system in European vehicles, as a system that increases safety on our roads is undoubtedly very important and timely. Often the aid does not arrive at the accident site as quickly as necessary due to delays in the transmission of information. The eCall system considerably reduces this delay by establishing contact with emergency services immediately after the accident. This electronic system will be available to all European citizens, thus ensuring that we are all equally protected. At the same time, the eCall system respects the protection of Europeans' privacy by not using their data to put that privacy at risk.  I am sure that this European technology will have a positive impact on the safety of our roads and I would like to see the system implemented within the framework envisaged. I therefore support the eCall system in European vehicles.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Socialists and Democrats Group voted in support of the deployment of the eCall in-vehicle system.  The deployment of a public EU-wide emergency call system embedded in the vehicle (and based on the 112 emergency number) represents a very important and concrete achievement for the safety of citizens, having the potential to save more than 2 500 lives yearly across Europe.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider E-Call to be a good concept. Modern technology brings us innovations that can protect our lives in need. At the same time, I would point out that this instrument should not be misused to monitor the movement of persons in the hands of governments or interest groups. I therefore voted in favour of the amendment, which would allow e-Call users to decide when to use the system and when to switch it off.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. \u2012 I strongly support the introduction of eCall in vehicles within the European Union that will enable adequate implementation of emergency calls through a specialised service.  Worrying data from the Road Safety Institute points to devastating results on european transport safety.  In fact, around 3 900 collisions occur within the Union each day, of which 70 per cent are deaths. The introduction of this system would speed up emergency intervention by as much as 40% in urban and up to 50% in rural areas, thus saving around 2 500 lives a year. I agree that the e-Call system needs to be made financially affordable, as security and quick access to rescue services must be made available to all union citizens and citizens.  I would also be pleased to emphasize croatia's outstanding achievement in this matter, as Croatia is the winner of a special award for successful implementation and testing of the e-Call of the System in 2013 by the Association of european emergency numbers, together with eight other Member States.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. – Road traffic accidents represent an incalculable cost for each EU country. The figures from 2012 - but also last year - are alarming. Around 28 000 people are killed and more than 1.5 million injured on EU roads every year. The European Parliament has long sought to introduce a system that mitigates the consequences of road accidents, in particular saving people's lives, and would be accessible to every driver. The introduction of eCall using line 112 in all new vehicles will certainly contribute to the construction of the necessary infrastructure for immediate operational assistance. I appeal not only for passenger cars to remain, but for this obligation to also apply to motorcycles, buses and other means of transport in order to protect the life and health of road users. No less serious is the protection of personal data, which must be treated, both legislatively and technically, in order to ensure the required level of privacy protection and the measures taken to prevent surveillance and misuse.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. Road safety is very important and the number of road accidents on an annual basis still takes too many lives. This figure is as high as 26,000 deaths per year in the EU. More needs to be done on prevention and the fact is that the number of road deaths could be reduced by reducing the average speed limit by 10 km/h. Prevention should also cover further awareness-raising and actions in the so-called sober driver. It is true that the system we are going to vote on will not in itself reduce the number of road accidents, but it will, of course, reduce the consequences and, above all, help to deal with those involved in road accidents. However, there is probably room for a number of compromises on the protection of personal data when this system is introduced. I see as problematic the constant monitoring and movement of the driver by the device. Taking into account the general concern at the moment about the mass surveillance of EU citizens, this is one way of being monitored and ubiquitous. For the reasons set out above, I voted against the recommendation for second reading on the e-Call system.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the draft regulation aimed at equipping all new vehicles with the eCall emergency device, which will make travel on Europe's roads safer, saving 2 500 lives every year, according to estimates. As of March 31, 2018, the eCall emergency device will be installed in all new cars and light commercial vehicles, a technology that allows you to automatically alert the emergency services in the event of a road accident by making an emergency call to the number 112.  The device sends the emergency services information about the accident (type of vehicle, fuel used, time of accident, exact location, number of passengers) allowing a considerable reduction in the response time of the rescue, which can reach the crash site faster and proceed with the rescue operations.  With this vote in favour, the initial legislative proposal on the protection of drivers' data is also strengthened: Parliament has in fact inserted a clause according to which the eCall on-board system will not be traceable before the accident has occurred, but will confine itself to transmitting the minimum information on the accident at the time of this occurring.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The eCall system will allow accurate identification of the accident site and provide sufficient data to enable more efficient and faster intervention by police and paramedics. In addition to reducing road deaths, its introduction is another step towards unifying rescue systems in the European Union.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for this proposal, which ultimately aims to introduce, in all vehicles in the EU, the minimum functionalities necessary to ensure adequate emergency treatment. Action is needed at EU level to ensure interoperability and continuity of services across Europe.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly supported this report which calls for the mandatory equipping of new passenger cars and light vehicles with the eCall in-vehicle system. In the event of a serious accident, the system will automatically call the emergency services regardless of where the vehicle is in the EU. This is a very important and concrete achievement for the safety of citizens, and has the potential to save more than 2 500 lives yearly across Europe.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the report and in favour of the deployment of the eCall in-vehicle system as it aims to implement a system that will help ensure the safety of passengers and better road safety in across the EU.  In Croatia alone, in 2014, 11 547 individuals were injured in a road accident, while 2 675 had severe injuries. The new system, which is expected to be activated by October 2015, will assure passengers of more security in emergency cases as it will improve communication between passengers and the emergency services across the EU. The system entails the introduction of ʽminimum functionalitiesʼ that will make it easier for the emergency response service to handle emergency calls.  The new passenger and lighter commercial vehicles will entail a system that triggers an eCall to the 112 emergency services automatically and/or manually in the event of a severe accident and will provide the exact location of the vehicle. More importantly, data sent to the emergency services (the location of the vehicle, etc.) will only be available upon request or for an accident – the data cannot be used for tracking, thus ensuring passengers of their privacy while increasing their safety on the road.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the recommendation on the Council position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on type-approval requirements for the introduction of the eCall system fitted to the vehicle as a service number 112. Almost 26,000 people die in road accidents in the Member States every year. The eCall system will not reduce the number of road accidents, but will make a significant contribution to saving lives. The system will enable a faster and more efficient response from the emergency services. It is safe, free and will operate in all Member States. I also support the introduction of eCall for all new passenger cars and vans because it will take appropriate care to ensure the protection of personal data, as the data will not be stored for longer than is strictly necessary.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the introduction of the eCall system, which can help to mitigate the consequences of road accidents, especially by informing rescuers in a timely way about the exact location of the crashed vehicle. If eCall starts due to an accident, only basic minimum data such as vehicle type, fuel type, time of accident, exact position of the vehicle and number of passengers will be automatically sent to the emergency services. I believe that this system, which will be provided to all citizens free of charge, regardless of the type or purchase price of the car, deserves to be put into practice. The introduction of eCall in cars represents an important contribution to strengthening road safety in particular in all 28 Member States.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I consider that there are no guarantees that electronic monitoring systems will not be used for illegal transactions and I also consider that the safeguarding of personal data is not fully guaranteed.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Adequate availability of emergency assistance is an integral part of the single market and the freedoms it provides.  In europe in the 21st century, it is essential that emergency services operate with a single IT backend, so that data search and positioning function properly, since the previous form of the system not only did not promote it, but made it particularly difficult to organise a single approach to assistance.  According to the Hungarian delegation of the European People's Party, special attention should also be paid to the existence of technical conditions.  It is important to establish a free system that works effectively at EU level, while respecting EU data protection principles to a great deal. This conditionality is met in the second reading report and I therefore voted in favour.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 In my view, a regulation making it compulsory to install an automatic accident notification system in new car models – the so-called eCall system – must be controversial and ambivalent.  On the one hand, it is about protecting the health and life of road users, but on the other hand it is about not interfering with the privacy of citizens of the European Union. eCall system allows you to collect data important for the privacy of citizens, m.in. regarding the make of the vehicle, the type of fuel used, the direction of travel and the exact location or number of seat belts. Experience has taught us that there are no safeguards that would completely prevent access to such data, even if its acquisition remains illegal. I therefore believe that eCall could perhaps be implemented, but only on a voluntary basis, i.e. the installation of that system should be dependent on the decision of the owner or user of the vehicle concerned. However, the regulation does not provide for this possibility, which is why I abstained.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. We voted this lunchtime in favour of the implementation of the eCall following an agreement reached with all parties. In the event of an accident, your car's eCall system will automatically dial 112. All new vehicles sold in the European Union from 31 March 2018 must be provided. The aim is to save 2500 lives a year across Europe by halving the response time and saving 26 billion euros. A possible extension of the system to other types of vehicles, such as trucks or motorcycles, will be considered in 2021. The last obstacle to the validation of this text was the issue of data protection, which I was also in charge of. We have decided: - that the data will be processed only in connection with the accident and deleted at the end of the emergency; - that any system providing for an exchange between the eCall and a third-party system will be prohibited. Respect for privacy and security can be combined.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the agreement on eCall. All new cars should therefore be equipped with this system as from March 2018. The eCall system is a technology that will help to save lives in the event of an accident by automatically calling the emergency services. While the question of data protection could be a concern for some of the users, the system developed will be a dormant one, which means that it will not actively transmit the position of the vehicle in question.

name: Michael Theurer (ALDE)
text: Writing. ECall systems are designed to automatically transmit position data and direction of travel to the emergency call centre in the event of an accident. The use of modern technology for road safety is fundamentally to be welcomed. However, a red line is crossed for me if this data can theoretically also be used to create motion profiles of all motorists. It was therefore important for the FDP that motorists must have the freedom to switch off the eCall system manually if they do not want to use it. This freedom of choice would have been easily possible with the on/off button in the car proposed by the Liberals – but the majority of Parliament has now opted for the glass motorist.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the report on type-approval requirements for the introduction of a e-Call system built into vehicles based on 112, as I consider this on-board system to be useful for improving the efficiency of emergency services, as appropriate emergency responses can reduce the number of deaths in road accidents.  I find it particularly useful to have multiple e-Call options, either automatically through on-board sensors if there is a traffic accident or manually, and an additional positive option is to transmit data showing key information about the accident, such as time, current location, vehicle type and (possibly) the number of occupants of the vehicle.  At the same time, the report highlighted the need to preserve user privacy by removing the internal memory of the system automatically and continuously, and information about the last three locations should be available to the system to determine the current location of the vehicle. I also believe that vehicle owners are properly given the opportunity to use another emergency call system if it complies with the standards, but this public emergency call service is still available to these vehicle owners.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against it. We understand that the granting of systems that promote quality and technology at the service of prevention must be welcome, although in this case it is not clear what will be done with the information collected by these new telecommunications systems. We understand that reports and amendments are needed to ensure the privacy of information produced in the field of telecommunications before promoting system deployments without such prior guarantee.

name: Giovanni Toti (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament has repeatedly stressed that reducing deaths and the severity of road injuries is its priority. With today's vote, we are proposing the introduction of new emergency call devices, capable of automatically alerting the emergency services in the event of a road accident. These devices must be installed on all new models of cars and light vans by March 31, 2018.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this system. The eCall system is a great tool to save more lives on our roads and reduce the seriousness of injuries.   In my opinion, we've reached a good balance between a high level of data protection and increased safety to the benefit of European citizens.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (NI)
text: In writing. The aim is to introduce a requirement for car manufacturers to install an on-board eCall system. Road safety would thus be a priority concern: supporting figures are more than 100 million road journeys per year in the Member States. This would involve equipping all vehicles of the interoperable on-board eCall throughout the EU, automatically triggering an emergency call to the number 112 and sending a GPS signal to enable rescuers to easily locate the crashed vehicle. It also provides for data and privacy rules, given the nature of the information provided by this service. The latter privacy provisions are the ones that get us caught. The geolocation of accident vehicles means above all that all vehicles will be able to be. A new intrusion into people's privacy. In addition, we must stress that such a system will have a mechanical impact on the cost of production of the vehicle and therefore on the selling price to the consumer. Instead, IMCO should focus on protecting the economic interests of consumers rather than ensuring its safety by tracking it.  I vote AGAINST this text.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I fully agree with Parliament’s position concerning the eCall emergency device.  From 31 March 2018, all new cars and light commercial vehicles will be equipped with an eCall emergency device that will automatically dial the 112 emergency number in the event of an accident, sending details of the accident to emergency services. The quicker response from the emergency services to accidents on roads across Europe could save about 2 500 lives in the EU every year. And this is free of charge for all of our citizens.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against it. We understand that the granting of systems that promote quality and technology at the service of prevention must be welcome, although in this case it is not clear what will be done with the information collected by these new telecommunications systems. We understand that reports and amendments are needed to ensure the privacy of information produced in the field of telecommunications before promoting system deployments without such prior guarantee.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted against this proposal as its objective is to introduce the mandatory requirement to install an eCall system on board vehicles into EU type-approval. Road safety specialists confirm that this system will not result in a significant improvement in the protection of injured persons. On the other hand, questions arise regarding data protection, as the device would constantly monitor the location of the vehicle in order to transmit, in case of activation, the direction of the vehicle's movement and its location.

name: Inese Vaidere (PPE)
text: Writing. – Although overall the number of victims of car accidents on European Union roads is slowly decreasing, around 26 000 people die every year and thousands more are suffering serious injuries. The statistics in Latvia are even darker. If, in the European Union as a whole, an average of 50 people per million people lose their lives in road accidents in a year, unfortunately, it is 106 people in Latvia. I therefore believe that increased attention should be paid to the provision of assistance to those affected by accidents. The proposal for a directive provides for the gradual introduction of an eCall system, which will automatically send data on the location of the machine to the nearest rescue service in the event of an accident, in all new car models. As the eCall system will operate on the basis of an existing 122 service, the provision of assistance across the European Union will be standardised and will remove language barriers. I trust that the eCall system, which will be a public service, is available to all free of charge, regardless of the class or brand of the machine, that ambulances will be able to respond more in a timely manner, thereby reducing the number of crash victims.  Given that the bill contains provisions on data protection to exclude the possibility of tracking eCall cars or transfering personal data to a third party, the amendment tabled for the vote has been rejected.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this regulation concerning ʽeCallʼ, an EU-wide emergency call system, because it will substantially contribute to the Commissionʼs road safety programme (2011-2020) and will help decrease road deaths as well as facilitate the work of rescue teams and firefighters. The ʽeCallʼ system will assist in the immediate rescue of passengers in road accidents. The system will be activated in the event of a car accident by automatically calling the 112 European emergency phone number, and all the necessary details, such as the exact location of the vehicle, will be transferred to the emergency call centre, for the immediate rescue of the passengers.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The implementation of this system may clash with some individual rights and freedoms. For this reason, we welcome the proposed amendment which suggests that manufacturers should ensure that users of the eCall system can easily and manually deactivate the system on board their vehicles if they wish. Conditions need to be created to reduce accidents on roads, build safe roads, improve existing traffic and safety conditions and jointly promote actions with relevant victim relief entities. These are indispensable measures for accident prevention and relief, and eCall is a good mechanism to contribute to this. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The implementation of the eCall system involves the installation, in all vehicles in the European Union, of a minimum of features necessary for the location of the car accident, as well as the interoperability of the system in the various Member States (EU-wide eCall). It is understood, first of all, that the implementation of the installation of this system, even if the laudable purpose, clearly calls into question the freedom of choice of citizens. The intention of installing georeferencing equipment must be at the sole discretion and choice of users. From the foregoing, we voted against it.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. The eCall system is an emergency call system built into the car to ensure automatic notification of emergency services in an accident situation. The safety aspect is laudable, but it must be borne in mind that all vehicle manufacturers, regardless of the 'own' emergency call systems already installed, are forced to install the 'public' system as standard in all new cars, and in many respects the costs and implementation are not clarified. There is also a risk of misuse of this system, as the data sets can be passed on to third parties with the permission of the data subject. Thus, insurance undertakings can also obtain this data and misuse it because of the weaker position of the policyholder. For these reasons, I voted against the decision to introduce the on-board eCall system in vehicles.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I cannot agree with the plan to impose an automatic emergency call system for all newly registered vehicles from 2018 by means of a regulation. The aim of this automatic emergency call system is to reduce the number of victims of accidents in the EU. I agree with the idea that the so-called eCall system can reduce the number of accident victims, as in the event of a serious accident, the emergency call centre 112 is alerted more quickly. However, this costs the price of the threat of comprehensive monitoring of all vehicles and their movements. The emergency call system, which works over the mobile network, will produce movement data. I do not know how it can be ruled out that public authorities can access this data. Despite the improvements in data protection law, I am sceptical. In any case, even if the concerns about surveillance could be addressed, forcing the system to be installed is completely disproportionate. Every car buyer should be able to decide for himself whether he wants to operate such a system. After all, he is also deeply affected if help is not available in time for assistance in the event of an accident.

name: Glenis Willmott (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This vote is for the implementation of the eCall in-vehicle system. From now on, car manufacturers will be required to install an on-board ‘E-Call’ system in new cars, which will automatically dial the emergency services in the event of a serious accident. The system is designed to work with the Europe-wide 112 emergency services number, ensuring that UK drivers are protected both at home and abroad. The proposal also takes privacy concerns seriously, by ensuring that the eCall system is dormant until activated in the event of an accident. Vehicles equipped with eCall are not traceable and are not subject to any constant tracking. The set of data sent by the in-vehicle eCall system includes the minimum information required for the appropriate handling of emergency calls. I voted for this proposal because it will save lives by reducing the response time of emergency services, while also maintaining the privacy of drivers by not collecting any unnecessary data.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the legislative resolution on type-approval requirements for the development of the eCall system based on the 112 service on vehicles. The emergency call system that will immediately and automatically notify rescue services in the event of a car accident is estimated to reduce the number of road deaths by 10%. It is particularly positive that as a European Parliament we have strengthened the privacy clause so that the eCall-equipped car cannot be monitored unless an accident has occurred and we have ensured that the data collected by emergency centres through the eCall system cannot be provided to third parties without the express consent of the person concerned.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Today in Strasbourg we approved by a very large majority a draft regulation on emergency devices eCall, which can automatically alert the emergency services in the event of a road accident.  The eCall system on board vehicles uses technology that automatically makes an emergency call to number 112 in the event of a serious road accident. This will allow you to immediately know the type and size of the necessary rescue operation, the exact location of the accident, thus allowing the rescue to reach the place faster and save lives, reduce the severity of the injuries and the cost of traffic jams. Road accidents in the EU cost 25 700 lives in 2014 alone, a figure that, thanks to the installation of the new eCall devices, could be reduced by around 10% per year, helping to improve road safety in all 28 Member States.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI)
text: Writing. – The regulation is falsified and not innocent at all. It creates a system of mandatory, permanent and continuous satellite monitoring of all vehicles and their passengers, even against their will. The fact that the European Parliament has rejected the amendment allowing the user of the system to turn it off manually shows that the aim of the regulation is not to ensure the safety of passengers but to monitor them. The EU is using every pretext to set up a giant monitoring and database network of everything, consisting of the EU's "smart borders" and the EUROSUR system for the continuous monitoring of every third-country national entering the EU, interconnected with the VIS and Eurodack, from the SIS I and SIS II databases in Schengen, by land observation satellites of the GOMES system , by unmanned aircraft (spy) UAVs, by monitoring systems for the "movement and rescue of ships" (VMS systems, SafeSeaNet). They even use the pretext of supposedly fighting the archaeocapel circuits and the looting of works of art by the "jihadists" to activate the EU Satellite Centre in Torrejón. Now they're adding eCall. There is not a single EU policy, even among those who seem 'innocent', which is not aimed at shielding their monopolies and power.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am clearly in favour of the introduction of the eCall on-board system. The introduction of eCall into road vehicles effectively avoids a large number of road deaths and therefore makes a huge sense for the future. It is also important to me that eCall will be mediated free of charge, reliably, will work in all Member States and, above all, will respect the rules on data protection.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I have unequivocally supported the eCall Regulation, which will help reduce the number of deaths and the severity of road injuries. The Union has been trying to introduce this service since 2003, and today we have approved March 2018 as the deadline for the installation of eCall in passenger cars. Owners of vehicles produced before this year will be able to activate the system on a voluntary basis. I trust that the Commission will resolve all the technical perils associated with the introduction of the service and that people with disabilities, namely deaf people, will also be able to use the system.

name: Kosma Złotowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The fight against high road fatalities is one of the most important priorities of EU transport policy, which is why I voted in favour of this report. When looking for the right tools to achieve this goal, we must use modern communication technologies. The rapid response of emergency services is often crucial to avoiding the deaths of victims. eCall appears to be a solution to reduce as much as possible the time between an event and information sent from a vehicle to emergency services using the emergency number 112. I believe that the european Union's action should lead to the introduction of this solution by manufacturers in the design of vehicles.  Of course, all aspects of the functioning of this system, in particular those related to the protection of sensitive data, in particular vehicle location information, should be subject to special protection. The implementation of this system should not in any way violate the right to privacy. We should closely monitor the implementation of this system at every step so that, by protecting human life, we do not open the door to abuse.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The implementation of the eCall system involves the installation, in all vehicles in the European Union, of a minimum of features necessary for the location of the car accident, as well as the interoperability of the system in the various Member States. The implementation of the installation of this system, although with a commendable purpose, clearly calls into question the freedom of choice of citizens, which is even more serious when it comes to the principle of data privacy that is in the possession of multinational concessionaires. The intention to install equipment of this nature should be at the discretion of users. We have therefore voted in favour of the amendment which suggests that manufacturers should ensure that users of the eCall system can easily manually disable the on-board system in their vehicles. It is up to the Member States to create conditions aimed, among other measures, at building new roads, improving the conditions of movement and safety of existing ones, promoting, together with the competent authorities, actions to control and prevent motor traffic, and to provide means and equipment to the authorities responsible for the rapid relief of victims. These are essential measures for the prevention and relief of car accidents, rather than a huge public investment for the implementation of a "service" that will be granted to private individuals.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing. The agreement between Parliament and the Council on the directive governing the eCall system is undoubtedly good news. It will then be possible to proceed quickly with the implementation of this system, which will have to be installed in all vehicles, and will automatically contact the nearest emergency center in the event of an accident, providing data such as location and type of vehicle and allowing more targeted and faster rescue. However, despite assurances from the Commission, many doubts have been raised about the effective protection of privacy and sensitive user data. I therefore voted in favour of the proposed amendment, which aimed to ensure that users were able to regulate the activation of the service and thus the sending of personal data.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted against the proposal for Article 6 (after § 3) to the recommendation for second reading on the Council position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on type-approval requirements for the introduction of the e-Call system. Article 6 proposed that the e-Call system should be set up in such a way that it can be switched off manually by car users. By rejecting this article, MEPs approved the Council's position at first reading and confirmed the requirement that all new passenger cars and vans produced after 31 March 2018 should be fitted with an automatic notification device for road traffic accident paramedics. Last year alone, 25,700 people died in road accidents in the EU. ECall will use emergency call technology 112 (European emergency services) and automatically alert paramedics in the face of serious road accidents, thus increasing their efficiency, improving injury care and protecting lives. In the event of a serious traffic accident, the sensors in the vehicle will be triggered, which will connect to the appropriate call centre and send: vehicle location, exact time, direction where the vehicle is pointing, number of passengers, etc. The system will be free, secure and work in all Member States and, as is very important, will respect data protection rules.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I supported the new form of the Fuel Quality Directive and the Renewable Energy Directive, because I believe, and the debate that has taken place here, shows that there is a need for greater support for advanced biofuels in the future and to move away from supporting those traditional biofuels whose production is so environmentally demanding that their environmental benefits are then relativised at all. I am glad that the European Union is changing the trend of its policy in this way, this is a very good and important signal for me. I want to say that we are having a similar debate in the Czech Republic, in the Czech Parliament, on how renewables are to be promoted. I am a little sorry that in the Czech Republic the theme of modern and new biofuels is not so perceived. So I hope that today's vote by the European Parliament will be an impetus for the Czech Government, which will be more supportive of advanced biofuels in the future, not the old ones, from which some politicians in the Czech Republic have economic advantages.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Commission has again wanted to adopt directives from technocrats, motivated solely by ideology. Because of the cultivation of biofuels in South-East Asia, which leads to deforestation and pollution, our good environmental friends wanted to put an end to all biofuel cultivation in Europe. But what Neither NGOs nor environmentalists have understood is that Europe does not need to destroy its forests in order to cultivate land. Fortunately, the Member States have once again proved that they are the only ones able to defend the interests of their fellow citizens. In the Council of the Union, they have managed to force the rapporteur of this project and the Commission to scale back their ambitions. Thanks to the compromise reached, we will be able to safeguard the funds already invested in the first generation biofuels industry and thus safeguard tens of thousands of jobs. By preserving first-generation biofuel crops, we will be able to maintain know-how that will facilitate the transition to advanced biofuels.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, with regard to this vote, which concerned the amendment to the original Directive 2009/28/EC, I would like to say that this vote was a little difficult for me. Firstly, I am not in a supporter of the creation of conventional biofuels, it is those first generation biofuels that have quite fundamental implications for land use, and we may not have yet found out all the effects that these biofuels will have on land. Finally, I decided to support this proposal because it is giving way to the original objective, and I think that this is very important precisely for our land use and for what we will leave to future generations.  I would also like to warn against, for the future, ambitious targets being accompanied, say, by an uncritical view of how the impact of our decisions can affect our soil, on our future generations.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, I supported the final agreement on the Fuel Quality Directive and Renewable Energy Directive but it is far from ideal. Still, it represents progress. In this agreement I believe we are addressing the negative side effects of the EU’s support policies for biofuels and we are also trying to ensure that publicly subsidised biofuels achieve real greenhouse gas savings. I believe that we are also promoting the development of advanced biofuels. While the European Parliament did not achieve many of its key objectives, nonetheless the compromise will ensure a cap on first generation biofuels of 7%, with Member States having the possibility to set lower limits. Indirect land use change (ILUC) factors will be reported by fuel suppliers and by the Commission and in its review the Commission will consider including ILUC emission factors in the maximum emission levels for biofuels in the future. Furthermore, energy crops will in principle be included in the 7% cap. As I said, this proposal is not as ambitious as we would have liked but it is an improvement.

name: Peter Jahr (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Biofuels have come under criticism in recent years, especially because of imports that have not been produced sustainably. This criticism is taken up by the decision as part of a compromise. It does not abruptly end the promotion of biofuels, it also guarantees a 7% cap on conventional biofuels, it does not abandon its emission targets, and it says that at least 0.5% of biofuels should come from the second or third generation. Finally, I have two wishes. The first wish is that, within the framework of the entry into force of the necessary regulation, we should also look at how the method of indirect land use is actually capable of adequately reflecting the things we want to reflect. I am sceptical about that. Secondly, we must also look at the post-2020 period in the interests of industry. The economy needs investment security and society, by the way, also.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: – Mr. President, I have already said once in this hall that I want Europe to remain at the forefront of positive global policies aimed at climate change mitigation and to be proud to live in a society that takes this danger to civilization seriously, in a society that, through its commitment and responsibility, leads global efforts and in a society that delivers on its promises.  Europe also sets the bar for this year's meeting in Paris. This document is precisely one of the documents that responsibly supports these efforts, and this responsibility of ours as a co-icon must also be recognized in those from whom we seek effort and renunciation to achieve our common goal. How and by whom this responsibility of ours manifests itself, we must ask ourselves. To our industry and to our workers. With clear objectives and rules with clear and realistic deadlines for their application, such clarity provides the necessary potential for greater and safer financial investments and for job creation.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Several of the amendments to this report significantly improve the Council's position by stressing the importance of reducing energy consumption in order to meet global energy sustainability objectives or to monitor and monitor the impact on ecosystems and food of biofuel development. We also value protecting the land to prevent the cultivation of biofuels from provocating the displacement of local and indigenous communities. This report has no final vote, as it is a second reading within the three-way dialogue process.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the text which was the outcome of the recent negotiations between the Council, the Commission and Parliament.  The EU biofuels policy needs serious reform and whilst I welcome the increased certainty this long-awaited agreement will bring, the overall package was extremely weak and I was very disappointed with several aspects of the final text.  Environmentalists and biofuel producers alike have both expressed their discontent with the advanced biofuels target – not only is it too low to stimulate real growth in this sector but the Council pushed for, and won, the right to not even make the target mandatory. Furthermore, one of the most contentious aspects of this report, indirect land use change (ILUC) factors, will be reported on but, unfortunately, not accounted for. This agreement must now be seen as a stepping stone and not the end of moving towards sustainable transport in Europe.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 The revision of the Fuel Quality and Renewable Energy Directives enters a limit on the use of first generation biofuels with the often negative consequences for the environment and unfair competition with agricultural and food production. This proposal, which I voted in favour of, provides incentives for the development of environmentally friendly biofuels based on waste.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. The present amendment to Directives 98/70/EC and 2009/28/EC aims to switch to low-greenhouse gas biofuels. Conventional biofuels lead to indirect land-use change, which means that plants for biofuels are grown sustainably, but displace food crops and lead to increased propellant emissions. This will undo the environmental benefits sought. For this reason, I welcome the switch from conventional biofuels to those that take account of indirect land-use change, and I hope that a long-term perspective for sustainable biofuels will also be created in this context.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this revision of the fuel quality and renewable energy directives because it does not obstruct the maintenance of the existing agrofuel industry, by encouraging technological innovations.  The proposed changes to the legal framework for biofuels address the Commission's concern to increase the share of next-generation (advanced) biofuels. The aim is to limit the exploitation of agricultural land for the production of biofuels and to reduce the very use of agricultural products by promoting the use of 'waste' The Commission's objective was to reduce the share of first-generation biofuels to 5% of all fuel used in Europe. The agreement finally sets this proportion at 7%, which allows us to cover the considerable investments made in Europe over the past several years. The compromise text also covers industries that are now in operation on the model prior to the revision of the Fuel Quality Directive. On the other hand, the now-preferred model is to avoid the use of agricultural land in favour of more innovative technologies.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that the recommendation by Nils Torvalds gives reasonable, comprehensive and forward-looking proposals and views on Directive 98/70/EC and Directive 2009/28/EC relating to the quality of petrol and diesel fuels and promotion of biofuels. It has been a long debating process and I believe that the compromise on the directive is extremely important for the European Union in order to achieve its targets on reducing greenhouse emissions and remain a front runner in innovation and sustainable biofuels. This legislation is an important step in the improvement of the current situation. We have to move forward with the regulation and create long-term perspectives for advanced biofuels, which will bring benefits not only for the environment but will also secure investment and the creation of new jobs.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to reduce carbon dioxide emissions in the transport sector. The EU has long promoted the production of biofuels from food crops in order to reduce carbon dioxide emissions in the transport sector, but the popular cultivation of cereals for fuel can lead to the translation of forests into cultivated land, thereby further increasing carbon dioxide emissions, leading to a shift to biofuels produced from non-food crops, but from non-food biomass, such as garbage or algae. The existing rules oblige EU countries to ensure that renewable energy accounts for at least 10% of transport energy consumption by 2020. The new rules specify this obligation by noting that by 2020 the share of first generation biofuels must not exceed 7% of the energy consumed in the transport sector. In addition, fuel suppliers must report to EU Member States and the Commission the level of greenhouse gas emissions caused by indirect land use change (indirect land use change – current biofuels are mainly produced from crops grown on agricultural land). I agree that the Commission must publish data on contaminants related to indirect land use change. It is important that EU Member States set national targets for the share of advanced biofuels in the overall energy consumption of transport no later than 18 months after the entry into force of the Directive.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. There was no final vote on this text presented at second reading. I therefore only voted in favour of the amendments to protect the investments already made by the agrofuels sector. We would be wrong to give up first-generation biofuels abruptly. Numerous studies, including the Ecofys report published on 12 November, challenge the method of calculating indirect changes in soil conditions, a method on which the Commission relied to abruptly change its 1998 and 2008 directives. If further research on advanced biofuels is needed, the heavy investments already made must be taken into account. I am thinking in particular of our farmers who have used these energies of the future to emerge from the serious crisis in their sector. Their efforts cannot be ruined with the stroke of a pen even though the second generation of biofuels does not yet seem able to take over from the first. The ceiling of 7% - proposed by the Council and finally approved by Parliament - therefore seems to me more reasonable because it is more respectful of investments that have been made in the long term, for the long term.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. Transport-related CO2 emissions play an important role in global warming. The Renewable Energy Directive sets binding targets to be achieved before 2020, with a view to achieving a 10% share of energy from renewable sources in transport. Directive 98/70/EC, for its part, plans to reduce the greenhouse gas intensity of fuels used in road transport by 6% by 2020.  To achieve these goals, it is essential to increase the share of advanced biofuel and limit the contribution of traditional biofuels to the composition of diesel and petrol in the European Union. Advanced biofuels can significantly reduce greenhouse gas emissions even when emissions from indirect changes in land use are taken into account.  It is therefore in order to achieve these objectives and preserve the environment that I voted in favour of this text.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I welcome the adoption of the report for the importance of the quality of fuels and renewable energy, especially in its impact on the common agricultural policy. There are four important points to be negotiated with the Council, which are the limitations of conventional biofuels, the factors for changing land use, the objective of advanced biofuels and the achievement of a policy after 2020. Our stance on all of it will be fundamental.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. This recommendation for a compromise between Parliament and the Council aims to change the positive law on biofuels in the context of reducing greenhouse gas emissions. For years, in order to reduce greenhouse gas emissions from transport, the EU has encouraged the production of biofuel from food crops. Unfortunately, this policy has not reduced CO2 emissions.  The Union is therefore trying to change its mind by promoting the production of biofuels from non-food sources. It's about time! For example, the Commission was considering a 5% cap on the share of fuel from food grains. The Council retained 7%. The compromise reached focuses on reducing the use of agricultural land in biofuel production in favour of investment in the search for more advanced renewable fuels. This compromise is moving in the right direction and I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this measure: the biofuels bubble was created by the EU imposing mandatory 'organic' production quotas for ecological and climatic purposes. To deflate it, it would have been enough to repeal these quotas. On the other hand, the pressure from the industries in this sector has got the better of it. Therefore, we have gone into astruse formulae for calculating the ILUC factor and a very complicated mechanism for transition to future so-called advanced or second generation biofuels. The proposals contained in the text have therefore missed an opportunity to solve the root cause of the problem of the environmental and economic unsustainability of biofuels from agricultural crops.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the ratification of the agreement reached with the Council at second reading on the amendment of the Directive on the quality of petrol and diesel and the Directive on the promotion of the use of energy from renewable sources. The revision of these two Directives was necessary to adapt them to the new climate change targets, in particular the mandatory target of achieving a 10% share of renewable energy in the transport sector by 2020 and reducing the greenhouse gas intensity of road transport fuels by 6%. The agreement places a limit on the production of conventional (food) biofuels of 7%, including energy crops. A binding target for advanced or second generation biofuels could not be achieved, but a recommended target of 0.5% has been achieved. In addition, the text recognizes the impact on climate change of land use change for biofuels (ILUC factors). Although more far could have been reached in terms of the obligation of ILUC factors, it does include the concept of the EP concerning 'low biofuels in ILUC factors'.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it confirms the European Parliament's position on the proposal for a directive that will lead to a transition to a biofuel policy that would significantly reduce greenhouse gas emissions, taking into account indirect land-use change emissions. The directive promoting the use of energy from renewable sources, adopted as early as 2009, sets a binding target of 10% of energy from renewable sources from energy used in the transport sector by 2020.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Biofuels Agreement creates a balanced compromise between EU environmental objectives and the legitimate interests of agribusiness operators and biofuel producers.  The phenomenon of global land use resulting from the production of so-called conventional biofuels produced from agricultural raw materials does not apply uniformly in the European Union. The new legislation takes better account of the specific situation in the Central European region than in previous drafts, where large quantities of biofuel can be produced without compromising food production and rainforests, with a mere increase in yields, giving a secure livelihood to those living in agriculture.  In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I believe that the directive voted on today provides an opportunity to increase the export revenues of Hungary and to sell our agricultural crops in a secure, long-term way. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposed compromise proposal for a directive because, in my opinion, it responds to a problem that arose from the overly ambitious target on the use of biofuels set years ago. The negative consequences of such a policy have been demonstrated in the excessive use of agricultural land for the production of biofuels, which has indirectly increased food prices.  It's right that we take the time to think. It is also right that, when adopting the EU's energy concept or the Energy Union, we really place emphasis on the objective that we have set ourselves: energy saving is the most important source of energy. Most of the reserves and the possibilities for tracking this objective are, in my opinion, precisely in transport, where biofuels are used to the fullest extent. In addition, in the field of transport, we also have the most problems with achieving environmental objectives. The directive adopted will, in my opinion, also lead to technological reflections on the relevance of the long-term use of biofuels in transport. The focus must be shifted to the development of technologies that will make the production of electric vehicles cheaper, thus making them available to the widest possible population. If more concrete steps are taken in this area, this will have a decisive impact on transport's dependence on fossil fuels, energy savings will be huge and the environment cleaner.

name: n/a
text: in writing. I voted against the Torvalds report, despite the great work and efforts made by the rapporteur in recent months, because I believe that the compromise reached does not go in the direction of making biofuel legislation truly sustainable. Nor does it defend our industries which really rely on the circular economy, such as the panel and furniture industries, which traditionally make use of woodworking waste and wood waste, but which, as a result of this directive too, will find it increasingly difficult to find the raw material.  In my view, it is a mistake not to guarantee adequate recognition of the principle of cascade use of biomass (use, reuse, recycling and only finally energy use of wood), so as to encourage the energy use of wood alone, which can no longer be used for other industrial sectors.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I believe that in terms of biofuels it is necessary to take a step forward towards a solution that will have a positive climate impact and will not increase competition with the food industry. After two rounds of trilogues with the Council, no progress has been made in finding compromise on fuel quality and renewable energy directives.  In this regard, Parliament has sent the Council a list of things it considers to be the biggest obstacles to the agreement in the hope that the Council will consolidate the ranks and find a common line. Progress was eventually made at COREPER level, resulting in this compromise I support.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (NI)
text: In writing. The European Union encourages biofuels, especially "next generation" biofuels. It presents this initiative as the main solution to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.  However, many have criticised the current policy, including the European Parliament. The Commission introduced a legislative initiative in October 2012. The second reading in the European Parliament has issued a compromise, which is the subject of this text. I voted against this one. Indeed, if I am sensitive to environmental issues, they must be tackled effectively, setting aside the ideological assumptions of the dangerous "Green Ayatollahs".

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this recommendation since I believe that the development of advanced biofuels is of key importance for both the creation of jobs and growth and the reaching of the goal of a greener Europe in terms of energy.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. The European Parliament's draft resolution deals with the adoption of the guidelines on fuel quality and renewable energy. The initial objective of the text was to limit the exploitation of agricultural land for biofuel production and to support new types of fuels derived from the use of waste such as biomass. The target of reducing the total share of biofuel fuels to a 5% share has been reduced to 7%, which helps to preserve the considerable investments made in Europe by companies in the sector. Anxious not to destabilise the biofuels sector, I voted for this text, which is the result of a compromise between the European Parliament and the Council.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The 6% reduction in the intensity of greenhouse gas emissions from fuels used in road transport and non-road mobile machinery by 2020 is an ambitious objective of the European Commission.  One of the objectives set out in the Sixth Community Environment Action Programme, established by Decision No 17/2002/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 30 June 2002 on the common organisation of the environment, is to ensure that the Community Environment Action Programme is implemented in accordance with the procedure laid down in Article 13 It is the responsibility of the Health And the Environment In the field of air quality which does not have a significant negative impact on human health and the environment;  I voted in favour of this directive because, in this way, it would further reduce the permitted national emission levels of the Member States' main pollutants, as well as the emissions associated with the refuelling of petrol from petrol stations, and address the problem of the sulphur content of fuels.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the adoption of the measure. The opportunity to solve at its root the problem of the environmental and economic unsustainability of biofuels from so-called conventional or first-generation agricultural crops has been missed, of which the indirect change in land deforestation – in other words, deforestation, the removal of agricultural land for non-food production and land grabbing – is the most obvious negative impact.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the guidelines on fuel quality and renewable energy. Through this text, we adapt these two directives to the new environmental characteristics related to biofuel production. We did not want to jeopardize the investments already made in the first generations of biofuels. Nevertheless, the legislation encourages producers and investors to move towards a more environmentally friendly generation of biofuels. I am also sensitive to the effects of indirect changes in land use. However, as the method of calculating these effects is disputed, I believe it is premature to include it in the legislation at this stage.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the proposal to speed up the transition from first-generation biofuels, derived from agricultural crops, to the more advanced second generation biofuels, produced from certain types of waste, waste and new sources such as algae.
