To justify its need, the many critical issues related to first-generation biofuels, derived from agricultural crops, accused of causing indirect emissions, linked to the change of land use ("Indirect Land Use Change", ILUC), given that the expansion of the cultivated area at the expense of forests leads to the increase in greenhouse gases. First-generation biofuels are also accused of weighing on food security and people's land access rights, because the demand for land for their production is leading to the race to hoard land, especially in African countries. The demand for food for the production of biofuels is also held responsible for the increase in their prices. For all these reasons, I wonder whether the rule adopted is ambitious enough. We had much higher targets, both in terms of reducing greenhouse gas emissions from first-generation biofuels and in terms of technological progress through greater promotion of second-generation biofuels.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the text which was the outcome of the recent negotiations between the Council, the Commission and Parliament.  The EU biofuels policy needs serious reform and whilst I welcome the increased certainty this long-awaited agreement will bring, the overall package was extremely weak and I was very disappointed with several aspects of the final text.  Environmentalists and biofuel producers alike have both expressed their discontent with the advanced biofuels target – not only is it too low to stimulate real growth in this sector but the Council pushed for, and won, the right to not even make the target mandatory. Furthermore, one of the most contentious aspects of this report, indirect land use change (ILUC) factors, will be reported on but, unfortunately, not accounted for. This agreement must now be seen as a stepping stone and not the end of moving towards sustainable transport in Europe.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of a draft legal proposal to cap crop-derived biofuel production and accelerate the shift to alternative sources (non-food derived). The aim behind this proposal is to cut greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions and safeguard food security caused by the growing use of farmland for biofuel crops. Using farmland to produce biofuel crops reduces the area available for food crops. This adds to pressure to free up more land, e.g. through deforestation, to grow more food – a process known as indirect land use change (ILUC). EU Member States will have to set a national target, no later than 18 months after the EU directive enters into force, for the share of advanced biofuels, e.g. those sourced from certain types of waste and residues and new sources such as seaweed, in total transport consumption.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Parliament's position at second reading which, with regard to the Directive on fuel quality and renewable energies, introduces elements of improvements in relation to increased investment in renewable sources and energy efficiency.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. I have taken the decision to vote in favour of this text as it is the result of a compromise between Parliament and the Council on the revision of European biofuels policy. I can only welcome this text, which promotes biofuels with a aim of reducing greenhouse gases, in favour of sustainable development when it is carried out in accordance with the principle of freedom. The directive also favours reducing the use of agricultural land for biofuels and favouring more innovative technologies that are respectful of farms.

name: Nessa Childers (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The need to further reduce carbon emissions, and curb the harmful effects of land use change arising from the cultivation of crops for fuel, prompted us to change the current EU policy. Our biofuels policy was badly outdated and broken. The human and environmental side effects of this route are increasingly apparent and we had to do something to address this. Land and food price speculation are exacerbated in the process. EU governments at Council level have shown an abysmal lack of willingness to think in our long-term interest and decided to concede as little room for reform as possible. We now have a 7% cap on the use of ‘old-school’, land-intensive biofuels, even if, like many colleagues involved in this issue, I wanted a much stricter cap on the share of conventional biofuels in the overall mix, preferably at 5%. We also pushed for sounder definitions and hierarchies of what qualifies as waste as source materials for more advanced biofuels exploiting by-products of other agricultural activities. There is also progress on the recognition of the land rights of indigenous people, a critical overseas development and human rights aspect our policies in this area must not ignore.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The use of renewable energy sources (RES) has significant positive advantages for both the environment and the economy and humans. Reducing the use of polluting fossil fuels and replacing them with RES should be a key EU objective. The EU's heavy dependence on gas and oil, both for electricity generation and for many other uses in industry, the domestic economy and more broadly in areas vital to society and the economy, poses many problems in the EU at both socio-economic and political level. The use of RES, especially at a time when their costs are completely competitive compared to those with less clean forms of energy, is imperative and we must create an important package of incentives and facilities for further development and promotion of RES. I believe that support for RES from the European Investment Programmes can also combat the Energy Poverty that affects many EU citizens. The benefits of the extensive use of RES are very important and can be extended to all sectors of the economy and society.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The measure proposed by the Commission aims to initiate the transition to a biofuels strategy that will produce substantial reductions in greenhouse gas emissions when emissions associated with indirect land use change are also taken into account.  Having examined Directives 2009/28/EC and 98/70/EC, which provide, respectively, for the 10% share of renewable energy in the transport sector to be achieved, and for a binding 6% reduction in fuel gas emissions from road and non-road vehicles, and given that the measure also contains indications for achieving these results, I have decided to vote on some significant amendments to the measure positively while others are negative.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal for a directive, which I had had the opportunity to examine in the ENVI Committee, of which I am a member. It is very important to make progress in reducing the environmental impact of cars, these tools that are now indispensable in the organization of our lives. It is not conceivable to think of lowering CO2 levels by reducing the routes that each of us does, but it is possible to expect that in the tanks of our cars there are more environmentally friendly fuels, more sustainable even in the long term and above all less polluting. It is in this direction that the directive is heading, and it is in this spirit that I have supported it.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the Fuel Quality Directive and the Renewable Energy Directive. I am pleased that we have been able to advance this complex, technical and technological dossier. It is particularly important that the position reached jointly with the Council is in line with the priorities of the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats: we have campaigned for newer-generation biofuels (for example, algae) while maintaining the agricultural production of 'classic' biofuels such as ethanol and biodiesel within a reasonable and appropriate framework, thereby securing investment. On the positive side, the compromise reached between Parliament and the Council means that the scientifically very questionable and highly controversial factors for indirect land-use change (iLUC factors) are initially used only for reporting purposes. This allows the iLUC factors to be tested for their practicality. Without this solution, the future of biofuels would be uncertain.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have chosen to vote in favour of amending the Fuel Quality Directive and the Renewable Energy Directive.   The Commission's proposal to initiate the transition to a biofuels strategy that will produce substantial reductions in greenhouse gas emissions, also taking into account emissions associated with indirect land use change, is fully acceptable.   This reduction would ensure that Europe not only achieves the objectives set out in the Europe 2020 strategy, but also the possibility of determining a long-term investment perspective, through support for innovation in sustainable biofuels and other instruments for decarbonising the transport sector.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ A strong cap on land-based biofuels is needed in order to reach the 2020 targets of Directives 2009/28/EC and 98/70/EC and to ensure a transition towards advanced biofuels.  Failure to address the indirect land use change (ILUC) effect would compromise the EU’s climate targets for the transport sector. The amendments send a strong signal that ILUC factors have to be seriously considered.  It is important to create and reserve a certain space for advanced biofuels in the future fuel mix. A dedicated and binding target for advanced biofuels as set by the amendments proposed is an effective way of doing this.  I thus voted in favour of this report to support the development of new advanced biofuels in Europe without hampering the use of climate-effective ethanol and biodiesel.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against because I believe that it is unsatisfactory, but that more efforts are needed to achieve acceptable results.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Several of the amendments to this report significantly improve the Council's position by stressing the importance of reducing energy consumption in order to meet global energy sustainability objectives or to monitor and monitor the impact on ecosystems and food of biofuel development. We also value protecting the land to prevent the cultivation of biofuels from provocating the displacement of local and indigenous communities. This report has no final vote, as it is a second reading within the three-way dialogue process.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The agreement on biofuels voted on today creates a balanced compromise between EU environmental objectives and the legitimate interests of agricultural operators and biofuel producers.  The phenomenon of globally increased land use as a result of the production of so-called conventional biofuels produced from agricultural raw materials does not apply uniformly. The new legislation takes better account of the specific situation of the Central European region than in previous drafts, where, without compromising food production and rainforests, a large amount of biofuel can be produced by a mere increase in yield, giving a secure livelihood to those living in agriculture. By 2017, the European Commission should develop a calculation methodology for ethanol with low land use change. Within the framework of parliamentary work, we will work to make sure that the criteria to be developed are favourable to farmers.  The Directive provides an opportunity to increase export revenues in central European Member States and to ensure the long-term sale of their agricultural produce. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I would have wanted to see more ambition; however, what the agreement achieved was the best in the circumstances. I believe in moving towards advanced biofuels that ultimately deliver real benefits for the climate while avoiding competition with food production.

name: Seb Dance (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the package negotiated with the Council and the Commission because it is better to enact meaningful change in the Union's policy than make political statements that derail an outcome, which has been welcomed by both NGOs and industry. While I hope to see more certainty about ILUC factors and how we will deal with them as soon as possible, I shall be seeking them by maintaining political pressure on the Commission and Council through the framework established in this agreement. Consequently I voted against the amendments tabled by the EFDD group, not because I do not believe in their content, but because I feel it would be morally irresponsible to sink a deal which so many people are waiting for. A clear outcome from these negotiations is needed so that people in developing countries in particular can gain certainty over the use of their land and that industry receives a clear signal to be able to move forward to newer generations of biofuel technology. I believe this deal, with a higher cap on first generation biofuels than I would want, is better than no deal as it represents a genuine move away from harmful biofuels.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I appreciate and consider it important that the report includes the latest available information to assess the modelling of greenhouse gas emissions related to indirect land use change and associated with the production of biofuels and bioliquids, including the measurement of trends in agricultural yield and productivity, the allocation of co-products and observed global rates of land use change and deforestation, and the possible impact of Union policies , such as climate, environmental and agricultural policies, involving stakeholders in this analysis process.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This text aims to define the European Union's biofuels strategy, and in particular to encourage operators to use so-called 'advanced' biofuels, which I support. The European Commission's initial proposal was too much to integrate the indirect land use changes in biofuels into account. This factor is not yet scientifically proven and its estimation is still too risky to incorporate into this Directive. That is why I voted in favour of the text agreed upon by the legislators, whose moderate approach to CASI/ILUC factors seems to me to be justified at the moment.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, because if we are to achieve the environmental targets set for 2020, we must not deprive ourselves of ambition with regard to the transport sector. Like the rapporteur, I hope that we can promote as much as possible the penetration of advanced biofuels into the fuel market. The European Union must have an incentive effect on this sector in order to attract investment in return.  In my view, innovation in renewable energy and clean fuels will be both the guarantee of a greener European Union than its global competitors and a source of jobs in a sector of the future.

name: Philippe De Backer (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the final compromise package on the Fuel Quality Directive and Renewable Energy Directive as I believe that the EU has shown a clear vision on its approach to biofuels and the related indirect land use change. Although I voted in favour, I nevertheless believe that this compromise package fails to address some opportunities for a further use of industrial waste streams as renewable fuels. I firmly believe that firms that can reuse carbon, through the addition of bacteria to its industrial waste streams (CO2 bio-fermentation of industrial waste streams), should be considered (at least) twice their energy content in Annex IX. This should not be conditional upon being renewable according to Article 2a, but should rather be based on respecting the sustainability criteria (60% GHG reduction vis-à-vis fossil fuels).

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which presents a fundamental issue for all those involved in biofuels. Throughout the negotiation - together with my colleagues in the EPP Group - we have defended a balanced position. Our role as an MEP is not to change direction along the way - as some wanted to do - but rather to accompany and encourage a change of course in order to meet environmental needs but also not to divert the citizens of the European Union.  I regret, however, that we have not been able to go through with the logic of encouraging the new generations of biofuels by not putting in place a binding target at European level.  On the other hand, I welcome the agreement reached on the ILUC factor. The calculation of this factor on the consideration of the effects of indirect changes in land use is scientifically disputed and it would have been absurd to include it as it is in the directive. The analysis of this factor must be continued, as indicated in the voted text.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As a result of today's vote, hopefully we will end a three-year series of negotiations and move closer to a solution that is acceptable to the majority of participants. In my opinion, we should not use a single system for first generation biofuels, we must take into account the natural conditions and potential of some Member States. For example, in most of the new Member States, it remains possible not to use the land used for the production of food for the production of biofuels, but on the one hand to produce falllagen and, on the other hand, to increase yields. According to a study published in January 2015 by the University of Utrecht, huge amounts of biofuel can be produced without increasing the risk of indirect land use change (ILUC). In the 3 Member States examined (Hungary, Romania, Poland), 1.3% of the total energy use of the EU transport sector in 2020 could be extracted with low ILUC biofuels, while the area under consideration accounts for only 6% of the total EU production area. According to the same study, some 1.2-5.2 billion litres of bioetanol could be produced from maize in Hungary, which would have no negative impact on the use of farmland.  In these countries, large quantities of biofuel can be produced without compromising food production, increasing yields and mapping areas. This in turn provides jobs and income for farmers, but does not make it impossible for investors. We must not be satisfied with today's result. Science and industry must continue to be encouraged and supported as much as possible to create environmentally friendly and sustainable alternatives.

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR)
text: Written. The reform of biofuels policy is necessary. Biofuels were welcomed 10 years ago as the solution for renewable energy in transport, but they are not blissful and sometimes even really problematic. For example, more land is being used to produce biofuels based on agricultural crops, resulting in deforestation, increased CO2 emissions and rising food prices, especially in developing countries. The N-VA therefore supports the new rules for the production of biofuels, which adjust policy in the right direction and limit conventional biofuels based on agricultural crops. However, this is done in a workable, consistent and realistic way, so that investment security is not compromised. The N-VA also supports the development of advanced biofuels but considers it too early for a binding target. We are therefore satisfied with the indicative target of 0.5% by 2020. The technology for these advanced biofuels is still in its infancy. We do not want to risk making the same mistakes as in the past. The focus on sustainability factors, respect for the waste hierarchy and biomass cascade in the choice of raw materials for this new generation of biofuels are crucial in this regard.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Biofuels Agreement creates a balanced compromise between EU environmental objectives and the legitimate interests of agribusiness operators and biofuel producers. The phenomenon of globally increased land use as a result of the production of so-called conventional biofuels produced from agricultural raw materials does not apply uniformly. The new legislation takes better account of the specific situation of the Central European region than in previous drafts, where, without compromising food production and rainforests, a large amount of biofuel can be produced by a mere increase in yield, giving a secure livelihood to those living in agriculture. It is also thanks to the hungarian delegation's prot support that the European Commission should develop a calculation methodology for ethanol with low land use change by 2017. In the future, we will fight to make sure that the criteria to be developed are favourable to Hungarian farmers. In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I believe that the directive voted on today provides an opportunity to increase the export revenues of Hungary and to sell our agricultural crops in a secure, long-term way. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this revision of the fuel quality and renewable energy directives because it does not obstruct the maintenance of the existing agrofuel industry, by encouraging technological innovations.  The proposed changes to the legal framework for biofuels address the Commission's concern to increase the share of next-generation (advanced) biofuels. The aim is to limit the exploitation of agricultural land for the production of biofuels and to reduce the very use of agricultural products by promoting the use of 'waste' The Commission's objective was to reduce the share of first-generation biofuels to 5% of all fuel used in Europe. The agreement finally sets this proportion at 7%, which allows us to cover the considerable investments made in Europe over the past several years. The compromise text also covers industries that are now in operation on the model prior to the revision of the Fuel Quality Directive. On the other hand, the now-preferred model is to avoid the use of agricultural land in favour of more innovative technologies.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the amendment of the Fuel Quality Directive and the Renewable Sourcing Directive, as I believe that, in view of the high energy dependency of some Member States from third countries, the European Union needs to review the existing legal framework in this area. I support my colleague Turvalds's view that one of the biggest challenges in updating Directive 2009/28/EC and Directive 98/70/EC is the lack of a long-term perspective. If no action is taken, Europe will face the serious challenge of becoming a continent that is seriously technologically lagging when it comes to sustainable fuels.  We have to make an effort not to get to a situation like this.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the text as a whole because the ways in which it tries to promote biofuels will in fact place an even more burden on the environment. It also bases energy consumption in Europe on third countries, in particular unstable countries in the so-called third world, thus prolonging energy insecurity and prolonging the colonial relationship with these countries.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Biofuels Agreement creates a balanced compromise between EU environmental objectives and the legitimate interests of agribusiness operators and biofuel producers.  The phenomenon of globally increased land use as a result of the production of so-called conventional biofuels produced from agricultural raw materials does not apply uniformly. The new legislation takes better account of the specific situation in the Central European region than in previous drafts, where large quantities of biofuel can be produced without compromising food production and rainforests, with a mere increase in yields, giving a secure livelihood to those living in agriculture. It is also thanks to the hungarian delegation's prot support that the European Commission should develop a calculation methodology for ethanol with low land use change by 2017. In the future, we will fight to make sure that the criteria to be developed are favourable to Hungarian farmers. In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I believe that the directive voted on today provides an opportunity to increase the export revenues of Hungary and to allow Hungarian farmers to sell their crops in a secure, long-term way. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – I opposed these rule on biofuels because they will not curb the negative impact of indirect land use change (ILUC) on climate change. The rules allow a 7% share of land-based biofuels, such as rapeseed biodiesel or wheat ethanol, in the overall fuel mix. Using food crops to fuel cars will contribute to rising food prices and the further destruction of the rainforest. This cap is much too high. I have had a lot of contact from my constituents in Wales on this important issue and I will continue to work for a better policy.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. – The extensive use of fuels of plant origin, also promoted by Directive 2009/28/EC on the promotion of the use of energy from renewable sources, has led to the development of industrial supply chains with serious repercussions on the fragile ecosystems of primary forests and has led to the abandon of food production for the most profitable energy production. In order to prevent these perverse effects from continuing to be produced, the M5S worked to reduce the percentages of mandatory mixing of biofuels, as well as to promote the introduction of environmental and social sustainability concepts for their production. As I did not find the consensus hoped for in our proposals, I decided to vote against the measure in its final form.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. The Directive encourages the transition from classic biofuels to second generation biofuels with the aim of reducing greenhouse gas emissions resulting from the increasing use of agricultural land for the production of biofuels. The new rules on biofuels stipulate that the share of energy from "classic" or first generation biofuels should not exceed 7 % of final energy consumption in Member States' transport by 2020. For "advanced" or second generation biofuels, a non-binding target is set with a reference value of 0.5 percentage points in energy content of the share of energy from renewable sources in all forms of transport in 2020.

name: Edouard Ferrand (NI)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, because it is for me a balancing act between the need to introduce a significant amount of biofuels into energy consumption, while rejecting an absolutist view on this point, which aims to preserve agricultural land from a biofuels.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission presented a legislative proposal in 2012 with the aim of minimising greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions, mainly in road transport.  In 2009, as part of the 2020 climate and energy strategy, a dual target was set by 2020: 10 % share of renewable energy (mainly biofuels) in the transport sector, introduced by the Renewable Energy Directive, and a 6 % reduction in the ghg intensity of fuels used in road and non-road transport, introduced by a revision of the Fuel Quality Directive. This report recovers a large part of parliament's concerns and demands already put forward. The effects of a shift in the use of agricultural land to more carbon-rich production are a strong concern in the proposed changes. This change could also raise questions about biodiversity and food sovereignty. The rapporteur proposes setting targets for advanced biofuels to encourage the change to this type of fuel, not so dependent on agricultural production and with a much greater GHG reduction capacity. It also proposes that other renewable energy sources be taken into account.  The fact is that, in these texts, little is said in other cases other than biofuels.

name: Raffaele Fitto (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the directive because the EU's objective must be to find a strategy in the biofuels sector that will produce substantial reductions in greenhouse gas emissions, also taking into account emissions associated with the indirect change in land use. Competitive Europe, as far as sustainable fuels are concerned, means both investment and employment and sustainability and respect for the environment.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Commission's proposal, presented in October 2012, aimed to launch a transition to biofuels that would ensure greenhouse gas savings, even taking into account the indirect land use change. The European Parliament adopted its position as early as September 2013. The ceiling for the use of conveveve biofuels has been set at 6%, an increase from the 5% ceiling in the European Commission's proposal. According to the European Parliament, this ceiling should also apply to financial support granted for biofuels. It is essential that this ceiling is strictly set to achieve the 2020 targets, that it does not increase further and that the directives are updated with a sufficient long-term perspective.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the whole text because the ways in which it tries to promote biofuels will in fact place an even more burden on the environment. Once again, Europe's energy consumption is based on third countries, in particular unstable countries in the so-called third world, with the result that energy insecurity is prolonged and the colonial relationship with these countries is being prolonged. However, I am voting in favour of some amendments which are moving in the right direction.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Fuel Quality Directive and Renewable Energy Directive (RED) aim at limiting the contribution of conventional biofuels towards the attainment of targets in the RED, improving greenhouse gas (GHG) performance of biofuel production processes, encouraging greater market penetration by advanced biofuels and reporting the estimated indirect land use change (ILUC) emissions. I supported the adoption of the report in the plenary because I believe it is fundamental to move towards advanced biofuels that deliver real benefits for the climate while avoiding competition with food production.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Biofuels Agreement creates a balanced compromise between EU environmental objectives and the legitimate interests of agribusiness operators and biofuel producers. The phenomenon of globally increased land use as a result of the production of so-called conventional biofuels produced from agricultural raw materials does not apply uniformly. The new legislation takes better account of the specific situation in the Central European region than in previous drafts, where large quantities of biofuel can be produced without compromising food production and rainforests, with a mere increase in yields, giving a secure livelihood to those living in agriculture. It is also thanks to the hungarian delegation's prot support that the European Commission should develop a calculation methodology for ethanol with low land use change by 2017. In the future, we will fight to make sure that the criteria to be developed are favourable to Hungarian farmers. In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I believe that the directive voted on today provides an opportunity to increase the export revenues of Hungary and to sell our agricultural crops in a secure, long-term way. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Biofuels Agreement creates a balanced compromise between EU environmental objectives and the legitimate interests of agribusiness operators and biofuel producers. The phenomenon of globally increased land use as a result of the production of so-called conventional biofuels produced from agricultural raw materials does not apply uniformly. The new legislation takes better account of the specific situation in the Central European region than in previous drafts, where large quantities of biofuel can be produced without compromising food production and rainforests, with only an increase in yield, giving a secure livelihood to those living in agriculture. It is also thanks to the hungarian delegation's prot support that the European Commission should develop a calculation methodology for ethanol with low land use change by 2017. In the future, we will fight to make sure that the criteria to be developed are favourable to Hungarian farmers. In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I believe that the directive voted on today provides an opportunity to increase the export revenues of Hungary and to sell our agricultural crops in a secure, long-term way. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. The aim of the proposal is to initiate the transition to a biofuel policy that allows significant savings in greenhouse gas emissions, also taking into account emissions related to indirect land use change. The contribution of biofuels to the achievement of the 2020 targets is expected to be significant.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Mr Torvalds' report, which closes a long negotiation phase on a strategic issue.  With these new rules, Europe is finally saying no more competition between food and fuel and putting a stop to the distorting effects that have driven up the prices of many food products in the poorest countries, driven by easier profits from fuels. At the same time, there is a strong signal of encouragement for those who invest in clean and sustainable energy technologies.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the recommendation for second reading on the Fuel Quality Directive and the Renewable Energy Directive. European environmental legislation is a key instrument for achieving the binding target of reducing the intensity of greenhouse fuel emissions by 6% by 2020. In particular, biofuels have a significant effect in terms of greenhouse gas emissions and indirect land-use change. I therefore support the call for a 6% limit on the share of conventional biofuels contributing to the objectives of Directives 2009/28/EC and 98/70/EC and actions to improve the environmental performance of biofuel production processes, in particular for new plants. These forecasts are directed towards better protection of the environment without sacrificing existing plants and investments already made. I also agree with the objective of targeting the market for advanced biofuels, and the call to include the factors attributable to the indirect change in land use in the monitoring and reporting obligations set out in the two directives. We need to develop a long-term strategy to reduce transport pollution that will enable Europe to be at the forefront of the fight against pollution while maintaining technological primacy in sustainable fuels.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I gave my support to the Torvalds report because it offers a step towards the development of an advanced policy on biofuels that benefits EU citizens. I specifically welcome the fact that my group was able to push through wording on respecting the waste hierarchy, and protections for indigenous peoples’ land rights. I also applaud that this legislation will help reduce CO2 emissions from transport and curb the undesired effects induced by indirect land use change caused by biofuels.  Unfortunately, due to the reluctance of the Council and the Commission, there has been a missed opportunity to make headway on developing an advanced policy on biofuels that delivers real benefits for the climate while offering a strong regulation for safeguarding the stability of investment and jobs.  However, thanks to the introduction of a review clause championed by my group, the door has been left open for further legislation. I urge the Council and the Commission to seriously reflect on the crucial importance of a directive on fuel quality and renewable energy that truly responds to the EU’s ambitious goals in the fields of climate, energy, jobs, development assistance and, last but not least, the achievement of sound policy coherence between all these fields.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. Since the past decade, the EU has promoted the use of biofuels to reduce CO2 emissions in transport. The result has been the development of a sector, both in agriculture and business, capable of producing them to comply with European guidelines. Over time, however, it has been discovered that first-generation biofuels present a number of environmental problems that do not make them so attractive. That is why I support the agreement reached by the European Parliament and the Council to state that the biofuels that deserve European support are second generation biofuels, which do not present the drawbacks attributed to first generation biofuels.

name: Julie Girling (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The Conservatives recognise the role that biofuels can play in reducing emissions and therefore help the EU and Member States achieve important environmental objectives. Biofuels play an important role in the UK energy mix as the EU looks towards achieving its climate goals whilst achieving greater energy security. An unscientific approach towards accessing the environmental impact of biofuels could have damaged business confidence in the sector. Having seen the role that this industry plays in contributing towards the green economy and providing jobs in the UK, I am pleased to see some steps towards evidence-based policymaking, along with proposals that will offer the industry greater clarity and certainty. We believe provisions such as allowing Member States to set lower caps on conventional biofuels will enable some Member States to meet their goals. We regret that the target for advanced fuels remains non-binding.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (NI)
text: In writing. I voted for this project to reduce first-generation biofuels (produced from crops on farmland). The main reason given is that this activity would lead to significant deforestation and pollution. This is true in South-East Asia but not in Europe where existing agricultural land is used. In the end, a compromise was adopted: first-generation biofuels should not exceed 7% of final energy consumption in transport by 2020. They will then be gradually replaced by other biofuels that are more environmentally virtuous.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted AGAINST the proposal to amend directives because the proposals put forward by Parliament, such as setting a 6.5% limit on first generation biofuels or a binding target for the limitation of advanced biofuels, have been rejected by the Council. Coincidentally, Member States maintain the same position as lobbies in industrial sectors, which reject any initiative aimed at reducing energy consumption aimed at increasing efficiency.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the package negotiated with the Council and the Commission because it is better to enact meaningful change in the European Union’s policy than make political statements that derail an outcome, which has been welcomed by both NGOs and industry. While I hope to see more certainty about indirect land use change (ILUC) factors and how we will deal with them as soon as possible, I shall be seeking them by maintaining political pressure on the Commission and the Council through the framework established in this agreement.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this directive as I believe Parliament has legislated for a balanced and reasonable cap on the amount of crop-based biofuels that count towards the EU’s 10% renewable energy targets.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Biofuels Agreement creates a balanced compromise between EU environmental objectives and the legitimate interests of agribusiness operators and biofuel producers. The phenomenon of globally increased land use as a result of the production of so-called conventional biofuels produced from agricultural raw materials does not apply uniformly. The new legislation takes better account of the specific situation in the Central European region than in previous drafts, where large quantities of biofuel can be produced without compromising food production and rainforests, with only an increase in yield, giving a secure livelihood to those living in agriculture. It is also thanks to the hungarian delegation's prot support that the European Commission should develop a calculation methodology for ethanol with low land use change by 2017. In the future, we will fight to make sure that the criteria to be developed are favourable to Hungarian farmers. In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I believe that the directive voted on today provides an opportunity to increase the export revenues of Hungary and to sell our agricultural crops in a secure, long-term way. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted AGAINST the proposal to amend directives because the proposals put forward by Parliament, such as setting a 6.5% limit on first generation biofuels or a binding target for the limitation of advanced biofuels, have been rejected by the Council. Coincidentally, Member States maintain the same position as lobbies in industrial sectors, which reject any initiative aimed at reducing energy consumption aimed at increasing efficiency.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the Council's position at first reading in order to adopt a directive from the European Parliament and the Council amending Directive 98/70/EC on the quality of petrol and diesel fuels and amending Directive 2009/28/EC on promoting the use of renewable energy, given that environmental improvements are at issue, taking into account the directives' targets of using 10 % renewable energy in the transport sector by 2020, and achieving a 6 % reduction in greenhouse gases in road-based fuels by 2020.  I support the process of limiting the contribution of conventional biofuels to such targets, and improving biofuel production in terms of less greenhouse gas harm, and greater market access to advanced biofuels. Furthermore, I support the transition of biofuels policy to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, which takes into account emission criteria due to land use change.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this revision of the fuel quality and renewable energy directives because it does not obstruct the maintenance of the existing agrofuel industry, by encouraging technological innovations.  The proposed changes to the legal framework for biofuels address the Commission's concern to increase the share of next-generation (advanced) biofuels. The aim is to limit the exploitation of agricultural land for the production of biofuels and to reduce the very use of agricultural products by promoting the use of 'waste' The Commission's objective was to reduce the share of first-generation biofuels to 5% of all fuel used in Europe. The agreement finally sets this proportion at 7%, which allows us to cover the considerable investments made in Europe over the past several years. The compromise text also covers industries that are now in operation on the model prior to the revision of the Fuel Quality Directive. On the other hand, the now-preferred model is to avoid the use of agricultural land in favour of more innovative technologies.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the reduction in the use of certain risky biofuels and an increase in biofuels that deliver greenhouse gas savings. The directive provides a clear legislative framework for the production of future biofuels as well as guidelines for future investment without disrupting existing ones.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Nils Torvalds' report on fuel quality and renewable energy, which aims to validate the agreement reached with the Council and the European Commission. The agreement caps conventional biofuels at 7% in the calculation to achieve the renewable energy target by 2020 in the field of transport, reflecting the investments made by the sector. The development of advanced biofuels, which are less greenhouse gas emitters, will also be encouraged. I welcome the adoption by a large majority of this report.

name: Josu Juaristi Abaunz (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The ILUC directive has come under fire over the last five years from business-oriented industry lobbies who claim that its methodology of accounting and calculation is not adequate to meet the objective. The truth is that industry sectors do not want to endorse any political responsibilities in safeguarding soil and food crops or support a reliable improvement in reducing energy consumption. The new rapporteur assigned to the report supported Parliament in demanding more ambitious targets regarding second and third generation sustainable low-GHG emission fuels. The Council’s approach of a non-binding target of 0.5 % was not satisfactory, nor were other positions expressed by the Council that systematically refused to negotiate or look for viable solutions within the Coreper mandate.  Even though the provisions on low-ILUC fuels have been improved to prevent loopholes and the Commission can review the legislation, Member States who wish to apply a cap on land-based fuels in order to comply with the FQD target will be able to do so. Energy crops have been made part of the ILUC legislation, correcting an omission in the original Commission proposal. Appropriate references to the Waste Framework Directive have been incorporated.  The result is so deceiving, that the proposed deal is not acceptable and therefore EH Bildu has voted against.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the compromise reached in trilogue on the proposal on the quality of petrol and diesel fuels and on energy produced from renewable sources. It is a balanced compromise that protects investments already made while encouraging the development of new, greener fuels.

name: Jarosław Kalinowski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Proposals for amendments to Directives 98/70/EC on fuel quality and 2009/28/EC relating to the promotion of energy from renewable sources were put forward by the European Commission in October 2012. From the outset, they have sparked heated debate, finding both staunch supporters of the proposed changes and unmoved opponents of the project among the Member States. According to (not entirely reliable) scientific data, the indirect land-use change (ILUC) effect is expected to result in a reduction in greenhouse gas emissions achieved through the use of biofuels. The EC has therefore proposed to reduce as much as possible the target (set in Directive 2009/28/EC, expected to be reached in 2020) of a 10% use in the transport of conventional biofuels. However, in many Member States the investments made by producers have not yet started to generate revenue, after all, only a few years have passed since the directive entered into force. This change would also hit farmers who have prepared production for the near future with great force. After two and a half years of negotiations, an agreement was reached to limit the use of first generation biofuels to 7% in transport and to introduce an additional ceiling of 0.5% for advanced biofuels. This is a compromise, but changing the rules during the game is a disastrous move on the part of the Commission and will certainly have a negative impact on both agriculture and the EU economy.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the directive regulating the sources from which biofuels should be produced, because the industry must be clear about the future. You cannot make demands and change the rules of the game that destroy an entire industry. This is about first- and second-generation biofuels. The production of first generation fuel requires large areas of agricultural land to produce raw materials. This raises concerns that the reduction in CO2 emissions might not be as significant as food could be grown or forested instead of this agricultural land. Second-generation biofuels, on the other hand, are produced from other sources, such as waste. Second-generation biofuels are even more friendly to nature. However, it should be remembered that the industry has made huge investments in first-generation biofuels, which are already making a major contribution to reducing polluting activity in the transport sector. It is not possible for this industry to start producing biofuels from other sources immediately because of the need for other technology and, consequently, huge investments. The transition is gradual. Therefore, the initial requirement for the rapid transition of first-generation biofuels to second-generation biofuels is unworkable. I believe that the text we voted on is balanced. This gives time for first-generation biofuel producers to switch to second-generation biofuel production in order to keep the balance between return on investment and environmental protection.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This is a good compromise and I am pleased to see that an agreement was reached with the Council on a reform of biofuels policy. This is a positive step towards promoting advanced biofuels which will play a key role in decreasing the CO2 emissions in our transport sector. This agreement will bring much needed improved regulatory certainty to the biofuels industry and in doing so make it more attractive to investment, creating more jobs and growth, especially in the EUʼs rural areas.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the legislation as it will help reduce CO2 emissions from transport and also curb the undesired effects induced by indirect land use change caused by biofuels, such as land use for speculation and higher food prices. This legislation will improve the current status, but is in no way satisfactory. We managed to introduce a review clause, and we intend to come back with our proposals for a more efficient and ethical use of biofuels. We have to move towards advanced biofuels with the proper regulation both for the environment and for the stability of investments and jobs.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Biofuels Agreement creates a balanced compromise between EU environmental objectives and the legitimate interests of agribusiness operators and biofuel producers.  The phenomenon of globally increased land use as a result of the production of so-called conventional biofuels produced from agricultural raw materials does not apply uniformly. The new legislation takes better account of the specific situation in the Central European region than in previous drafts, where large quantities of biofuel can be produced without compromising food production and rainforests, with a mere increase in yields, giving a secure livelihood to those living in agriculture. It is also thanks to the hungarian delegation's prot support that the European Commission should develop a calculation methodology for ethanol with low land use change by 2017. In the future, we will fight to make sure that the criteria to be developed are favourable to Hungarian farmers.  In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I believe that the directive voted on today provides an opportunity to increase the export revenues of Hungary and to sell our agricultural crops in a secure, long-term way. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Elisabeth Köstinger (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the compromise agreement on the iLUC dossier. The share of renewable energy in Europe needs to be further increased. The decision in this dossier is already overdue, the future of biofuel production is at stake if entrepreneurs do not have planning certainty! This bill on the addition of biofuel to conventional fuels is a compromise that goes in the right direction. I would have liked to see a mandatory bioethanol target so that the protein by-products, which are so valuable for agriculture, continue to be secured, but unfortunately this was not enforceable. In any case, it is to be welcomed that the unrealistic iLUC factors do not need to be applied. It is also important that there is now a commitment to advanced biofuels: without support for the development of this new generation of fuels from algae and waste, there would have been no future for biofuels!

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, all my fellow Members who have worked on this dossier, the Presidency of the Council and the European Commission for the agreement reached on ILUC.  The aim of the directive is to break off competition between bioenergy and food production which, through the change in the use of agricultural land, threatens food security. But there was also a need to protect the investments already made by those economic operators who focused on first-generation biofuels. With the text approved today, we are calling for a ceiling on first-generation biofuels and binding energy consumption targets to be achieved with advanced biofuels by 2020, for a strategy that will create a long-term perspective for environmental protection, food sustainability and to support innovation in sustainable biofuels.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. The three institutions agree to put a limit on the production of conventional (food) biofuels. It has finally remained at the 7% proposed by the Council, but the EP has succeeded in claiming to include energy crops in this cap (with a revision clause in 2017). The first reading commitment agreed at the EP said that, by 2016, at least 1.25% of total fuel had to be obtained from advanced or second generation biofuels (biomass, etc.) and that by 2020 the target should be 2.5%. The commitment does not set a binding target for advanced ones, although it does set a recommended target of 0.5%. Since land use change for biofuels has an indirect impact on climate change, the Commission proposed accounting for them within co2 emission calculations. The commitment does not require ILUC factors, but it does provide that, in the abovementioned review clause, they are take into account when determining sustainability criteria and, moreover, the concept of the EP relating to 'low biofuels in ILUC factors' is included.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Several of the amendments to this report significantly improve the Council's position by stressing the importance of reducing energy consumption in order to meet global energy sustainability objectives or to monitor and monitor the impact on ecosystems and food of biofuel development. We also value protecting the land to prevent the cultivation of biofuels from provocating the displacement of local and indigenous communities. This report has no final vote, as it is a second reading within the three-way dialogue process.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 At the time of the first reading of this directive, I was not yet a Member and I could not propose the abolition of the mandatory incorporation of bio-components into fuels. I voted in favour of amendments to reduce the share of first generation biofuels to 6% compared to the current level.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ One of the main objectives of the European Union by 2020 is to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 20% compared to the situation in 1990. It also aims to increase energy efficiency by 20%, provided that 20% of all energy is drawn from renewable energy sources.  In 2014, Croatia adopted the Third National Energy Efficiency Action Plan for the period 2014-2016 and the new Energy Efficiency Act. Data for Croatia have been available since 2005, and the state's efforts by 2012 have led to a reduction in greenhouse gas emissions by just over 13%. The percentage of energy in final consumption drawn from renewable energy sources in 2012 was 16.8% and in 2013 it was 18%. The National Renewable Energy Action Plan defines targets for three sectors: electricity, transport and heat and cooling.  I support The Torvalds MP's recommendation, as we need stronger measures to encourage the use of biofuels and renewables to meet our 2020 targets. It is important to correct directives that lack a long-term perspective at the moment, as a greener Europe needs to be a priority for everyone.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support a system which, however, restricts the use of food raw materials in the production of biofuels. Because this can lead to the lunch being burned in developing countries in the car engines of developed countries.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 The draft recommendation re-establishes Parliament's position at first reading, which consists in its opposition to a further increase in the ceiling established by the Council on the share of conventional biofuels which can contribute to the achievement of the objectives of Directives 2009/28/EC and 98/70/EC. At the same time, it is necessary to revise the methodology for assessing emission factors, given both land use change and adaptation to technical and scientific progress.

name: Dominique Martin (NI)
text: In writing. This was a second reading which did not require a final vote, however, Dominique Martin would have voted for this directive which will limit the exploitation of agricultural land for the production of biofuels.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The recommendation for second reading on the Council's position on the quality of petrol and diesel fuel, and Directive 2009/28/EC, on the promotion of the use of energy from renewable sources, is favourable to me. It is very important to achieve a 10% share of renewable energy in the transport sector by 2020 and to reduce the intensity of greenhouse gas emissions from fuels for road transport and non-road mobile machinery by 6% by 2020. An improvement in performance linked to greater efficiency and lower pollution would lead to a positive trend not to be underestimated. Helping biofuel development is beginning to be an important point in achieving these 2020 values.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In October 2012, the European Union adopted Directive 2009/28/EC on the promotion of the use of energy from renewable sources, setting a binding target of achieving a 10% share of renewable energy in the transport sector by 2020, through a 6% reduction by 2020 in the intensity of greenhouse gas emissions from fuels for road transport and non-road mobile machinery. However, Directives 2009/28/EC and 98/70/EC lack a long-term perspective, so instruments and measures need to be examined for a global and technologically neutral approach to promoting emission reduction and energy efficiency in transport for a post-2020 strategy.  I voted in favour of the Torvalds report, which has decided to table amendments to underline the need for a longer-term strategy that can bring investment into Europe.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 I support the resolution we have adopted in the European Parliament on the Directives on the quality of petrol and diesel and the promotion of the use of energy from renewable sources. We must move in Europe towards a biofuel policy that allows significant savings in greenhouse gas emissions, also taking into account emissions related to indirect land use change. As the rapporteur has pointed out, if we do not move forward in this area, Europe may be threatened with its future in environmental, employment and investment matters.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. We welcome the reduction in the share of biodiesel in fuels from ten to six and seven percent respectively, as this does not intensify indirect land-use change. This would eliminate greenhouse gas emission savings through the use of biofuels.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this technical report as moving towards advanced biofuels is an important step in reducing greenhouse gas emissions arising from biofuel crops.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The 2009/28/EC Directive on the promotion of the use of energy produced from renewable sources requires that a 10% share of energy from renewable sources in transport be achieved by 2020. The aim of the Commission's proposal here is to begin the transition to a biofuels policy that significantly reduces greenhouse gas emissions. We know the drawbacks of this choice, which replaces food production. The report therefore aims to cap the use of conventional biofuels, i.e. agrofuels that compete with agricultural production for food use, at 6% of total energy consumption in transport. The report also introduces a target of 1.25% for so-called "advanced" biofuels, such as those produced from algae. Finally, the text proposes to take into account the impact of the change in land use in the overall CO2 production balance that this new allocation generates.  Also despite its shortcomings I support the progress contained in this text and I vote for

name: Joëlle Mélin (NI)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this revision of the fuel quality and renewable energy directives because it does not obstruct the maintenance of the existing agrofuel industry, by encouraging technological innovations.  The proposed changes to the legal framework for biofuels address the Commission's concern to increase the share of next-generation (advanced) biofuels. The aim is to limit the exploitation of agricultural land for the production of biofuels and to reduce the very use of agricultural products by promoting the use of 'waste' The Commission's objective was to reduce the share of first-generation biofuels on all fuel used in Europe to 5%. This is below the 7% requested by our group, but it still covers the considerable investments made in Europe over the past several years. The compromise text also covers industries that are now in operation on the model prior to the revision of the Fuel Quality Directive.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The objective of the Commission proposal, which was presented in October 2012, is to initiate the transition to a biofuels policy that can substantially minimise greenhouse gas emissions, also taking into account emissions associated with indirect land use changes (IUUS). By 2020 the EU will have to work hard to achieve the levels approved in this document. I hope that the adoption of this report will give us an important boost in increasing the use of renewable energy. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this recommendation for a second reading in order to keep the European Union moving towards achieving its goals of promoting and increasing the use of renewable energy sources in the transport sector by 2020. I also chose to support the rapporteur’s view that Parliament should highlight the need for a longer-term policy that will lead to greater investment in sustainable fuels in the European Union.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I welcome the adoption of the Directive amending the Guidelines on Fuel Quality and Renewable Energy, which limits the contribution of conventional biofuels, improves the performance of biofuel production processes in terms of greenhouse gases by raising minimum levels of reduction of greenhouse gas emissions for new facilities and encourages greater penetration into the market for so-called "advanced" biofuels. It is essential to promote sustainable biofuels, i.e. made from waste or plant residues, so that their production does not harm the food needs of the population and livestock.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I support this report, which calls for a move towards advanced biofuels that deliver real benefits for the climate while avoiding competition with food production.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 According to this report, by 2020 each Member State should ensure that the share of energy from renewable energy sources in all modes of transport accounts for at least 10 % of the final energy consumption in the transport of its Member States. I support this report as we believe that we must increasingly invest in sustainable and environmentally friendly energy sources, and renewable energy sources are a good example of the desired sustainability. However, I would like to warn of the importance of taking other measures to reduce energy consumption (rationalisation of modes of transport) and to increasingly focus on research and the development of new energy sources.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. The European Parliament must vote on a recommendation on the adoption of a compromise between Parliament and the Council to change the positive law on biofuels in the context of reducing greenhouse gas emissions. Indeed, the EU has for years pushed the production of biofuels from food crops, with the aim of reducing greenhouse gas emissions from transport.  However, this policy has had perverse effects and has not reduced CO2 emissions. The UNION is therefore trying to change its mind by promoting the production of biofuels from non-food sources. For example, the Commission was considering a 5% cap on the share of fuels derived from food cereals.  Finally, the Council has retained a proportion of 7%, which allows to cover the massive investments made in the European Union. The compromise reached focuses on reducing the use of agricultural land in biofuel production in favour of investment in the search for more advanced renewable fuels.  Considering that this is a compromise that goes in the right direction, I have decided to vote for it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as this is a stepping stone in the right direction, keeping the door open for further legislation in the future, and ensuring that it was not watered down or lost should we be forced to go to conciliation. The final offer includes a cap on conventional biofuels of 7% that can be counted towards the 10% target for renewable energy in transport and set a non-binding target of 0.5% for advanced biofuels. It also obliges fuel suppliers to report on the indirect land use change (ILUC) emissions of their fuels, but these will not be taken into account when calculating fuels’ carbon footprint under the fuel quality directive.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this agreement on the proposed Directive on Indirect Land Use Change (CASI). The agreement aims to encourage the production of next-generation biofuels, which require less agricultural land for their production. The EPP group to which I belong fought and got this agreement not to call into question the investments made or the jobs created by the production of first-generation biofuels.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The aim of the Commission's proposal, which we welcome, is to initiate the transition to a biofuels strategy that will produce substantial reductions in greenhouse gas emissions by 2020.  To this end, we believe it is necessary to introduce a stricter limit, that of 6%, on the share of conventional biofuels that can contribute to the objectives of these two directives. On the other hand, however, we believe that failure to address the effects of indirect land-use change would undermine the EU's climate targets in the transport sector. In this case, a complete review should be carried out of the methodology for estimates of factors attributable to indirect land use change, also in the light of adaptation to technical and scientific progress.  In addition, in order to create a long-term perspective for investment and support innovation in sustainable biofuels and other instruments for decarbonising the transport sector, it is necessary to examine instruments and measures in order to have an increasingly global and technologically neutral approach.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the final text proposed by the EU Council on the Fuel Quality Directive and the Renewable Energy Directive. The main aim of the directive is to initiate the transition from conventional biofuels to biofuels that offer substantial greenhouse gas savings: so-called 'second generation or advanced biofuels'. The directive also establishes a clear legislative framework for the production of biofuels, protecting existing investments in the sector.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 One of the objectives of Directive 2009/28/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council is that each Member State must ensure that the percentage of energy obtained from renewable sources used in all means of transport will be at least 10 % of the final energy consumption in the transport sector in that Member State in 2020. I voted for this report because, through the amendments introduced, the aim is to achieve this objective, but also to other important and much-needed objectives, including encouraging research and development in the new advanced biofuelproduction sectors.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the text which was the outcome of the recent negotiations between the Council, the Commission and Parliament. The EU biofuels policy needs serious reform and whilst I welcome the increased certainty this long-awaited agreement will bring, the overall package was extremely weak and I was very disappointed with several aspects of the final text.  Environmentalists and biofuel producers alike have both expressed their discontent with the advanced biofuels target – not only is it too low to stimulate real growth in this sector but the Council pushed for, and won, the right to not even make the target mandatory. Furthermore, one of the most contentious aspects of this report, indirect land use change (ILUC) factors, will be reported on but unfortunately, not accounted for. This agreement must now be seen as a stepping stone and not the end of moving towards sustainable transport in Europe.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report and welcome the work done by the rapporteur, as I believe no effort should be spared in our attempts to improve fuel quality with a view to increasing the use of renewable, green and sustainable energy sources. We could indeed promote even more the development and production of biofuels, and I believe that the short-term costs of implementing directives like this one, of adapting the car manufacturing industry to the new fuels, will be easier to bear than the long-term immense environmental costs associated with pollution and loss of sources for current conventional fuels.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Fuel Quality and Renewable Energy Directives because, in the context of many studies carried out, I believe that the promotion of traditional biofuels, however substantial even in terms of limiting energy imports into the EU, has significant negative effects. That is why I am in favour of redirecting the EU's attention from traditional biofuels to advanced biofuels or electromobility, which do not burden the environment with negative effects. I consider it a mistake that the Czech Government is underestimating the change in the trend in the promotion of biofuels and will therefore be a question of how it will cope with the agreed objectives.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this directive, as a switch to advanced biofuels is certainly promising for the future. Algae or certain types of waste should lead to reductions in greenhouse gas emissions. Stocks of cereals are enormously high despite their use for ethanol production. In theory, there is also no reason to expand additional areas for biofuel production. Even if the demand for cereals and vegetable oil were to increase dramatically, there would still be enough unused arable land in Europe, Africa and South America. Furthermore, there is enormous potential compared to food. One billion foods or food raw materials do not reach the plate at all. Due to inefficient harvesting methods, raw materials are infested with mould or pests or are lost during transport. In Germany, about 11 million tons of food end up in the garbage, which is about 4 to 5 million hectares of arable land. On the basis of this fact, I voted in favour of the sensible use of raw materials and, therefore, of this directive.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. I supported the bill because it aims to start the transition to biofuel, the use of which would help reduce greenhouse gases.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In view of the position of Parliament and the Council at first reading and in view of the recommendation for second reading by the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, I voted in favour.

name: Florian Philippot (NI)
text: In writing. The proposed changes to the legal framework promoting biofuels in greenhouse gas emission reduction targets address the Commission's concern to increase the share of next-generation (advanced) biofuels. The aim is to limit the exploitation of agricultural land for the production of biofuels and to reduce the very use of agricultural products by promoting the use of "waste". The Commission's aim was to reduce the share of first-generation biofuels to 5% of all fuel used in Europe. The agreement finally sets this proportion at 7%, which allows us to cover the considerable investments made in Europe over the past several years. The compromise text also covers industries that are now in operation on the model prior to the revision of the Fuel Quality Directive. On the other hand, the now-preferred model is to avoid the use of agricultural land in favour of more innovative technologies. This compromise seems to me to be balanced and I therefore vote for the text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒the Commission's original proposal was to amend the Fuel Quality Directive 98/70/EC (FQD) and renewable energy sources (Directive 2009/28/EC) with a view to encouraging the transition of biofuels and delivering significant greenhouse gas savings including ILUC while protecting existing investments.  The primary objective was to limit the contribution of conventional biofuels towards achieving the objectives set out in Directive 2009/28/EC, improve the GHG performance of production process biofuels, encourage greater market penetration for advanced biofuels and report estimated ILUC emissions. Since the trilogues did not agree with the Council on most competition-related issues, I am pleased that most provisions were subsequently compromised at COREPER, where the Council accepted some of Parliament's proposals. I hope that the adoption of the second reading position will lead to a final compromise on the entire legislative package, which will in a balanced way allow the implementation of the provisions on the first generation of biofuels.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 Emission of harmful exhaust gases may cancel out the appropriate supplies of natural gases. Back in October 2012, guidelines were given on controlling fuel quality, promoting the use of renewable energy and moving to the use of biofuels, ensuring their sufficient production, as well as entering the market as much as possible, with a view to protecting against harmful emissions.  Mandatory use in the calculation of exhaust emissions when determining biop gases stocks has been proposed and a target 6% yield of first generation biofuels has been set for renewable energy sources as well as the introduction of advanced biofuels. Positively, the proposal for a target of 6% has been adopted and the introduction of a binding 1.25% for advanced biofuels by 2020, as well as support for a long-term investment policy in sustainable biofuels after 2020.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 We must stress that the objectives of the two directives are: the achievement by 2020 of a 10% share of renewable energy in the transport sector and the reduction by 6% of greenhouse gas emissions from fuels for road transport and non-road mobile machinery by 2020.   In order to have a long-term perspective for investment and to support innovation in sustainable biofuels and other instruments for decarbonising the transport sector, we need to have a global and technologically neutral approach to promoting emission reduction and energy efficiency in transport for a post-2020 strategy. That is why it is important that there should be a long-term strategy that can bring significant investment into Europe.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. Energy and climate issues are now at the heart of the Eu's priorities. The use of biofuels had emerged as a solution for Europe's energy supply. However, some agrofuels have been shown to have a harmful effect on the environment.  The European Parliament voted on Tuesday in favour of the directive bringing together and amending two existing directives on fuel quality and renewable energy. I have spoken in favour of this conciliatory text. The share of biofuels for transport will not exceed 7%. The aim of this directive is not to jeopardising the investments already made in biofuel research and production, while encouraging the development of a more environmentally friendly biofuel generation.

name: Christine Revault D'Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D)
text: In writing. The European Parliament today voted on the agreement reached with the Council on the revision of the Fuel Quality Directive, which is supposed to cap the share of "first generation biofuels" in final energy consumption in the transport sector.  These biofuels, derived from food products, have harmful effects both on an environmental level (intensive agricultural production, water pollution by pesticides and fertilizers, massive deforestation, reduction of biodiversity...) as well as socio-economic (competition to food crops, increased food prices, impact on local populations...).  For all these reasons, it is essential that the European Union caps these biofuels. However, the agreement with the Council does not go far enough to limit the negative consequences of these biofuels. I have therefore decided to abstain on this agreement, because it proposes a ceiling of 7% of first generation biofuels (the European Socialists proposed 5%).
