Moreover, the text also does not repeat Parliament's objective of setting at 2.5% the share of second-generation biofuels, made from waste and inedible plants, which are nevertheless a viable solution for biofuels.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. Driving or feeding, you will still have to choose, for a few years at least. Indeed, the European agreement adopted today by the plenary of the European Parliament on biofuels is not a major reform. This is a compromise in the classic sense of the word that, although it provides a clear legislative framework for biofuel production, from the first to the third generation, while protecting the investments already made in agricultural crops, does not take a clear position.  The new legislation states that first-generation biofuels (mainly rapeseed or palm oil) should not account for more than 7% of final energy consumption in transport by 2020. These agrofuels were promising ten years ago, but they have the major disadvantage of putting food prices under pressure. Member States' reluctance has done the rest by preventing investment in future biofuels from waste or innovative technologies from microorganisms. As the rapporteur, my liberal colleague Nils Torvalds, said: "As far as the market for more advanced biofuels is to be opened up, we have not been fully successful. That's an understatement...

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted for this text, the real culmination of the negotiations on this complex issue. Although there were many compromises in relation to Parliament's first reading position, it was urgent to have a text dealing with the issue of the Indirect Soil Allocation Change (CASI), which causes famine and deforestation in developing countries, and runs counter to the European Union's greenhouse gas emission reduction targets. We are validating the cap on the production of first-generation biofuels, and we welcome the inclusion of provisions encouraging the development of advanced biofuels.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. I agree with the harmonisation of EU directives and legislation in order to initiate a biofuels policy that can minimise greenhouse gas emissions. There is an urgent need for environmental investment in the European Union in the short and long term in achieving a greener Europe and in achieving the 2020 targets.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the ratification of the agreement reached with the Council at second reading on the amendment of the Directive on the quality of petrol and diesel and the Directive on the promotion of the use of energy from renewable sources. The revision of these two directives was necessary to adapt them to the new climate change targets, in particular the mandatory target of achieving a 10% share of renewable energy in the transport sector by 2020 and reducing the greenhouse gas intensity of road transport fuels by 6%. The agreement places a 7% limit on the production of conventional (food) biofuels, including energy crops. A binding target for advanced or second generation biofuels could not be achieved, but a recommended target of 0.5% has been achieved. In addition, the text recognizes the impact on climate change of land use change for biofuels (ILUC factors). Although more far could have been reached in terms of the obligation of ILUC factors, it does include the concept of the EP concerning 'low biofuels in ILUC factors'.

name: Jens Rohde (ALDE)
text: Written. The European Parliament has today passed a law which means that 1st generation biofuels may account for a maximum of 7% of fuel consumption for transport by 2020. In future, 0.5% of transport fuel will come from 2nd generation biofuels, but the latter is unfortunately not a binding target. This is a disappointing result for Denmark and not least for Maabjerg, and it is conciliatory that there is no greater willingness among the Member States to set ambitious targets. But little is better than nothing, and voting against would be an empty demonstration. The ambitions have been reduced in the negotiations with the Council. Parliament's original proposal included a 6% cap on 1st generation biofuel and a binding target for second generation biofuel of 2.5% by 2020. I am voting in favour because the alternative is worse, but unfortunately it is a long way from parliament's proposal. Unfortunately, Parliament cut itself off from influence in the last period, as the Conservative Group would not give a mandate to the rapporteur for the report because she was left-wing. In doing so, the best was done, the worst enemy of the good.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. Yesterday, the European Parliament formally endorsed the agreement reached in trilogue on the draft legislation to encourage more sustainable biofuels that preserve the interests of developing countries and the climate. The draft directive aims to cap, by 2020, the use of agrofuels in transport, to accelerate the production of advanced biofuels, such as algae and waste, which do not compete with food production, and to take into account the ILUC factor (for "indirect changes in soil conditions") in order to account for greenhouse gas emissions linked to the production of these 1st generation agrofuels. For the most part, the text voted caps the use of first-generation agrofuels in the final energy consumption of transport at 7% by 2020. Fuel suppliers will report to Member States and the Commission on the estimated level of greenhouse gas emissions linked to indirect land use change. It will then be up to the Commission to publish the data on these emissions related to the ILUC factor. By the end of 2017, the Commission will have to assess the possibility of including ILUC factors in the biofuel sustainability criteria.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour. Biofuels seemed to be the right solution to many problems a few years ago. We are bound by the requirement to produce 20% of the EU's total energy consumption and 10% of the energy consumed in the transport sector by 2020. We believed that the rise of biofuels would help address the challenges of decarbonisation, climate change, employment and the development of renewable energy. Today, however, we are already discussing how not to increase and limit the production of biofuels using food and feed crops. Scientists warn that the benefits of reducing greenhouse gas emissions associated with the use of biofuels compared to fossil fuels may be lower or despised, as indirect land-use change emissions can be high and sudden global food price hikes raise ethical questions about the production of biofuels from food crops. The agreement reached between the Commission and Parliament seems logical, with a 7% limit on the total volume of transport fuels in the country for first-generation biofuels produced from food crops. Such drastic policy changes once again show that legislation must be very measured. It is essential that the proposed protection of existing investments is being made by 2020. It is good that we will promote greater development of advanced biofuels, the production of which is reduced than conventional biofuels. This is necessary in order for viable companies to invest in progress.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this report, which reflects the position of our group. Throughout this issue, we have defended a balanced position by not questioning the investments already made in the sector but at the time encouraging the development of a new generation of biofuel that is safer for the environment.  We have also refused to include in this directive a method of calculation on the consideration of the effects of indirect changes in land use (CASI effect) which is disputed at the scientific level, however we are in favour of further studies in this area.  Among the important points of the agreement, it should also be noted that first-generation biofuels are not expected to account for more than 7% of final energy consumption in transport by 2020; this makes it possible not to question the investments already made.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation at second reading, as it is in line with the objective of the Commission's proposal, presented in October 2012, namely to initiate the transition to a biofuels strategy that will produce substantial reductions in greenhouse gas emissions when emissions associated with indirect land use change are also taken into account.  Indeed, the proposals to limit the contribution made by conventional biofuels to the achievement of the objectives set out in Directive 2009/28/EC are welcome. to improve the greenhouse gas performance of biofuel production processes by increasing the greenhouse gas reduction threshold for new plants, protecting plants already operational as of 1 July 2014, and to encourage greater market penetration of advanced biofuels, enabling them to contribute more to the targets set by Directive 2009/28/EC than conventional biofuels.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted AGAINST the proposal to amend directives because the proposals put forward by Parliament, such as setting a 6.5% limit on first generation biofuels or a binding target for the limitation of advanced biofuels, have been rejected by the Council. Coincidentally, Member States maintain the same position as lobbies in industrial sectors, which reject any initiative aimed at reducing energy consumption aimed at increasing efficiency.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Several of the amendments to this report significantly improve the Council's position by stressing the importance of reducing energy consumption in order to meet global energy sustainability objectives or to monitor and monitor the impact on ecosystems and food of biofuel development. We also value protecting the land to prevent the cultivation of biofuels from provocating the displacement of local and indigenous communities. This report has no final vote, as it is a second reading within the three-way dialogue process.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of the package on the Fuel Quality Directive and Renewable Energy Directive. If we do not step up to the plate, the overarching challenge Europe faces is the continent being technologically overtaken regarding sustainable fuels. This is something we cannot afford – regardless of where we find ourselves on the political map. Not being on par with the challenges would mean the end of a greener Europe, as well as a more jobs-friendly Europe and a more investment-friendly Europe.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider the use of agricultural land in Slovakia and the EU for the production of biofuels to be a bad solution. If we are to produce biofuels at all, we prefer waste unsuitable for use in the food or feed industry. Agricultural land is here as a gift to be used to ensure the livelihood of the human population. I therefore voted in favour of approving the resolution on the Council's position on the Fuel Quality Directive and the Renewable Energy Directive.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the fuel quality directive as well as the renewable energy directive, as I think it is time to start the transition to biofuels that allow for significant greenhouse gas savings and estimated emissions related to indirect land use change. The shift to renewables is the cornerstone of any modern society.  I agree with the limitation of the share of first generation biofuels, as they bring the risk of emissions related to indirect land use change. Stronger improvements and reductions in the efficiency of biofuel production processes in relation to greenhouse gases are needed. In addition, it should be welcomed to encourage greater market penetration of advanced biofuels and to improve greenhouse gas emissions reporting by introducing a reporting obligation on estimated biofuel emissions related to indirect land use change for Member States and fuel suppliers as the main objectives of these directives.  Croatia has great potential in using renewable energy sources and reducing energy consumption by applying energy efficiency. Both contribute to reducing greenhouse gas emissions and preserving the environment, and reduces dependence on imported energy.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. – The Directive on the promotion of the use of energy from renewable sources sets a mandatory target of 10% renewables in the transport sector by 2020. Another directive introduced a mandatory target of achieving a 6% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions from fuels used in road transport and non-road mobile machinery by 2020. In the final form of both directives, it will be important what positions the Commission takes and its alignment with the European Parliament's amendments. The main problem is the setting of a ceiling for conventional biofuels. While the EP has adopted at first reading a position introducing a 6% cap on the use of conventional biofuels, the Commission is proposing a ceiling of 5%. Another problem for the final form of the directive will be the target for modern biofuels. While the EP proposed at first reading a level of 0.5% in 2016 and 2.5% in 2020, the Council only proposes a non-binding milestone at the 0.5% reference level. Aligning a green Europe and a Europe open to creating new jobs and boosting investment will be a task for representatives of the EP, the Commission and the Council in the coming months.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of revising biofuel legislation, which will help reduce CO2 emissions in transport and accelerate the shift to less polluting biofuels. In fact, first-generation biofuels, produced mainly from cereals, have proved counterproductive in the fight against climate change: by taking fertile land away from agriculture, they pose a threat to food security, while, by contributing to the deforestation of forests, greenhouse gas emissions increase. Today's vote, the result of a tough compromise with the Council, provides for a ceiling on the production of biofuels derived from agricultural crops: under the target of 10% renewable energy in the transport sector by 2020, first-generation biofuels should account for no more than 7% of total energy consumption in transport, compared to 5% proposed by the Commission and supported by the S&D Group. Innovation is also being promoted for the production of second-generation biofuels (e.g. from certain types of waste and new sources such as algae), for which Member States will have to set a national target for the share of innovative biofuels in total consumption in the transport sector.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the fuel quality directive and the renewable energy directive. Each Member State shall ensure that the share of renewable energy in all forms of transport in 2020 represents at least 10 % of the final energy consumption in transport in that Member State. Biofuel mixing is one of the methods available to Member States to achieve this objective and is expected to contribute the most to this objective.  Other methods for achieving this goal are to reduce energy consumption, which is necessary because the mandatory target percentage for renewable energy is likely to be increasingly difficult to achieve permanently if overall demand for transport energy continues to grow, and the use of electricity from renewable energy sources.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report relating to the quality of petrol and diesel fuels. This will have a positive impact on the environment, for example by improving the greenhouse gas performance of biofuel production processes and encouraging biofuels to increase their market penetration.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. – After 2 intensive trilogues, an agreement was finally reached with the Council and we can say that the views of the EPP have been adopted. For the 1st and 2nd generations of biofuels, we achieved what we wanted. We have reduced crops for the production of 1st generation biofuels and encouraged innovation for the 2nd generation of biofuels.  The Greens insisted on biofuels a few years ago and then saw that crops are not the best way to produce biofuels, and to move to the 2nd generation, which is generated from waste, new plants need to be made because the same plants cannot be used to process crops and waste.  We need to have strong legislation so that investors can be confident in their investments, not that the rules are often changed especially as these investments become profitable only over the long term. The agreement should preserve the first generation industry, as some investments have already been made and at the same time should encourage the development of the 2nd generation of biofuels.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the recommendation on the Council position at first reading with a view to adopting a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the quality of petrol and diesel and amending the Directive on the promotion of the use of energy from renewable sources. The proposal foresees a restriction on the production of biofuels from food-producing crops and speeds up the transition to alternative sources such as waste and seaweed. The agreement reached between the Commission, the European Parliament and the Council on the share of biofuels means a drastic reduction in the use of 1st generation biofuels. The debate has shown that we need to focus on second-generation biofuels in the future. We must encourage and support research and development in this area. I support the directive because it wants to launch a new policy on biofuels, it wants to reverse a new leaf in the fight against CO2 emissions. We also need to develop renewable energy sources in the transport sector as well. This is necessary today, more than ever.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The need to develop and support renewable energies is now more imperative than ever. However, there are unfortunately many important points in the report amending this directive. Further increasing the contribution of renewable energy sources requires parallel policies such as promoting appropriate infrastructure, streamlining renewable energy support schemes and exploiting opportunities for international cooperation. Measures should be promoted to ensure the promotion of renewable sources at the lowest possible cost to consumers, as well as measures to support small producers of renewable energy sources. New projects and investments financed by the EU in the transport sector should also take into account environmental protection, support the low-carbon economy and promote renewable energy sources, as well as energy efficiency measures. All these elements are absent from the report and that is why we voted against it.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 This directive is another move to support the import of energy into Europe from unstable countries in the so-called third world. In this way, however, we ensure the perpetuation of both the existing energy insecurity and the colonial-style relationship with these countries. Moreover, the ways in which the directive tries to promote biofuels will not, in fact, solve the problem but will place an even more burden on the environment.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the second reading of the draft resolution, which aims both to reduce emissions of harmful substances and to allow for further technological developments. I believe that the issue of biofuels needs to be looked at from many sides because of its complexity. In addition to reducing greenhouse gas emissions, we are talking about an existing sector that also provides jobs, which encourages further investment and job creation in rural areas. It is also important to note that this will reduce the External Energy Dependency of the European Union and that certain by-products of biofuel production are valuable feed or fuel. I therefore consider it important that the draft legislation has been informally agreed between Parliament and EU ministers, so that a compromise solution has been found. Under the Directive, Member States must transpose its content into their own legal systems by 2017 and ensure that first-generation biofuels (i.e. energy sources from crops grown on land) can make up to 7% of transport energy by 2020. Personally, when drafting the Indirect Land Use Directive, I supported the higher blending rate of 4-7.5% of biofuels from arable crops (so-called first generation) and I feel that this has achieved a healthy balance.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 It is in the interest not only of European agriculture, but above all of consumers, that farmland should be used primarily for the production of agricultural crops for the consumer market or for the production of feed for farmed animals. Human energy should try to produce, in addition to mining sources, also from genuinely renewable energy sources such as sun, wind or water, and thus avoid the use of plants, especially those grown for the human food market. Therefore, instead of increasing the standards for the share of such plants in the overall energy balance, more resources should be allocated to research and development of new energy generation technologies, making it possible to increase its availability and at the same time reduce its price. I therefore voted in favour of the amendments to the directives on the quality of fuels and renewable energy, but I believe that, in parallel, a policy should be pursued to promote innovation and the development of new technologies for the clean use of fossil energy sources and natural renewable sources.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the vast majority of cases, biofuels are not exactly environmentally friendly or sustainable. Three problems: – put pressure on residual natural ecosystems, from which new arable land is derived: but marshes, forests or grasslands store carbon underground and in plant biomass; their transformation into fields and plantations involves the release of indirect land use change impact (ILUC); - biofuels from food crops (such as ma corn) put the car's tank in competition with the stomachs of the poor; – the production of biofuels requires fossil fuels, used both for agricultural machinery and to produce chemical fertilizers and pesticides: considering this, CO2 emissions linked to the use of biofuels can be completely similar to those of diesel and petrol and EROEI (the energy return on energy investment) is minimal or negative. I said yes to the amendments in favour of advanced biofuels that are not linked to food crops; yes also to those that aim to reduce the pressure of biofuels on food crops. I said no to the amendments opposing the principles set out above and those that open the door to safeguarding investment in the 'business as usual' of biofuels. The climate and the land are priceless.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Finding viable policies for decarbonisation of the transport system has proved more difficult in practice than originally estimated, and achieving the objectives we have set ourselves in this regard will not be possible without the contribution of biofuels. Today We voted after two years of negotiations full of syncope and compromises. The final document is not what the European Parliament wanted at first reading, but it clarifies some uncertainties and sets out a roadmap for quantifying the real impact of ILUC on reductions in greenhouse gas emissions from first generation biofuels. Our role is to regulate in such a way as to facilitate a stable and investment-friendly framework that fosters job creation and sustained growth of the economy. Imposing a 7% limit on first-generation biofuels will allow us to redirect investments to so-called sustainable advanced biofuels, without jeopardising investments already made in the first generation sector. We do not yet have a scientific method of determining the factor - that is why I believe that the agreement reached on monitoring and reporting it will provide us with the data needed to introduce this factor into the sustainability criterion.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. However, we would have liked more. Among our regrets: - we were asking for a ceiling of 5%. Less would not be acceptable given the investments made by the sector in this area, since the current share at European level is 4.5%.  This is far from a detail when we know that every per cent of agrofuel represents just over one million hectares that is subtracted from food production, i.e. almost the entire arable area of a country like Belgium; - we also wanted binding targets for advanced agrofuels (second and third generation), whereas the agreement provides only an incentive.  I am in favour of these advanced agrofuels. They use only inedible parts of plants and agricultural waste. The absence of binding targets in this area is a mistake.  First-generation agrofuels have too negative an impact on food production and deforestation. The agreement certainly goes less far than one might have hoped, but remains a step in the right direction. Agrofuels produced from waste or plant residues must be promoted, which do not compete with human or animal feed. The future of food, environment and social the planet is at this price.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ After five years of interinstitutional negotiations, I voted in favour of the reform of the EUʼs biofuels policy. If not perfect, the text arrives at a good compromise. In particular, the text sets a cap of 7% on the use of first-generation agri-fuels in the final energy consumption of transport by 2020. Fuel suppliers will also have to report to the Member States of the EU and the Commission on the estimated level of greenhouse gas emissions linked to indirect land-use change (ILUC). The Commission will then publish data on these emissions linked to the ILUC factor. By the end of 2017 at the latest, the Commission will report back to Parliament and the Council on the possibility of including ILUC factors in the sustainability criteria for biofuels, on the basis of the best scientific data available.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I voted to adopt a directive by the European Parliament and the Council amending Directive 98/70/EC on the quality of petrol and diesel fuels and amending Directive 2009/28/EC on promoting the use of renewable energy to ensure that the share of energy in all forms of transport in 2020 represents at least 10 % of final energy consumption.   In my view, it is necessary to take steps to make it easier and easier for Member States to make recommendations for additional measures to achieve energy efficiency and to ensure energy savings in the transport sector. The issue of the quality of petrol and diesel fuels as well as the promotion of the use of biofuels and the use of energy from renewable sources are some of the key issues for europe's future both in environmental and economic terms. This topic needs consensus from experts, farmers and legislators. Member States are given some room for manoeuvre in terms of adapting their national programmes, i.e. flexibility in setting targeted parameters within national frameworks, and that is why I supported this requirement.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted AGAINST the proposal to amend directives because the proposals put forward by Parliament, such as setting a 6.5% limit on first generation biofuels or a binding target for the limitation of advanced biofuels, have been rejected by the Council. Coincidentally, Member States maintain the same position as lobbies in industrial sectors, which reject any initiative aimed at reducing energy consumption aimed at increasing efficiency.

name: Evžen Tošenovský (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 It is very positive that the share of first generation biofuels will be reduced. At the same time, However, I am disappointed that the reduction to 7% is not ambitious and the 6% share I supported has not received wider support in the European Parliament.

name: Giovanni Toti (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In order to create a long-term perspective for investment and support innovation in sustainable biofuels and other instruments for the decarbonisation of the transport sector, it is necessary to examine tools and measures for a global and technologically neutral approach to promoting emission reduction and energy efficiency in transport. Today's vote underlines the need for a longer-term strategy that can bring investment to Europe.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted AGAINST the proposal to amend directives because the proposals put forward by Parliament, such as setting a 6.5% limit on first generation biofuels or a binding target for the limitation of advanced biofuels, have been rejected by the Council. Coincidentally, Member States maintain the same position as lobbies in industrial sectors, which reject any initiative aimed at reducing energy consumption aimed at increasing efficiency.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted against this report as the agreement with the Council is not sufficient to deal with the significant negative climate impact due to the shift in food production caused by the demand for biofuels in the EU, as an increase in the caps allowed so far is allowed.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the EU final compromise on the biofuels directive. I supported this draft directive since it will accelerate the necessary transition from conventional biofuels to ʽsecond generationʼ biofuels: this will entail a substantial reduction in greenhouse gas emissions. Another positive aspect of the directive is that it will provide a clearer legislative framework for the production of all biofuels and ensure that existing investments in the sector are protected. Parliament should also make sure that in the near future ʽadvancedʼ biofuels are produced on a larger scale in the EU, in order to achieve further decreases in CO2 emissions.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Several of the amendments to this report significantly improve the Council's position by stressing the importance of reducing energy consumption in order to meet global energy sustainability objectives or to monitor and monitor the impact on ecosystems and food of biofuel development. We also value protecting the land to prevent the cultivation of biofuels from provocating the displacement of local and indigenous communities. This report has no final vote, as it is a second reading within the three-way dialogue process.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Based on the finding of the poor "climatic" balance sheet of agrofuels, this revision aims to reduce greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions by integrating the effects induced by the increasing use of agricultural land for the production of agrofuels called "indirect change in land use" (CASI ). The revision also proposed to reduce the share (supported by the EP) of agrofuels in fossil fuels from 10% to 6%, compared with 5% in the Commission's original proposal. But in reality the "CASI criterion" is not taken into account in calculating the "climate quality" of agrofuels and will only be the subject of a Commission report on the basis of the information provided by producers. That's all there is to it. Voted by a large majority of the European Parliament, this revised legislation is not up to the climate challenges, with member states, including France, bearing a large responsibility for this bad compromise! I therefore voted against this text, so as not to join this bad signal from the EU just a few months before the Paris climate change conference.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The effects of a shift in the use of agricultural land to the richest carbon production for biofuel production, including its own contribution to GHG production, which can happen when existing agricultural production is shifted to other previously uncultivated land, and a concern very demarcated in the proposed changes. The rapporteur proposes setting targets for advanced biofuels in order to encourage the change to this type of fuels, which are not so dependent on agricultural production and with a much greater GHG reduction capacity. It also proposes that other renewable energy sources be taken into account and electric vehicles to be promoted.  Although the titles of both the Communication, directives and this report refer to the promotion of the use of energy from renewable sources, it is the fact that in these texts there is little talk in other cases other than biofuels, leaving it to be seen that, under the guise of noble objectives, such as the reduction of factors that cause climate change, such as GHGs, another potentially very profitable business is promoted. , which could mean the loss of agricultural production to feed the peoples, so that we have agricultural production for the production of biofuel raw materials.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. We welcome the reduction in the share of biodiesel in fuels from ten to six and seven percent respectively, as this does not intensify indirect land-use change. This would eliminate greenhouse gas emission savings through the use of biofuels.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I did not agree to the amendment of the Directive on the quality of fuels and the directive on energy from renewable sources. I welcome the objective of reducing the share of biofuels. The argument is correct that the forced admixture or use of biofuels creates a competitive relationship between how arable land is to be used. The amendment of the directive reduces the proportion. However, I cannot agree with this further, because it is not the task of the legislator as a whole to determine the quality and composition of fuels. This may well be reserved for the automotive industry and its customers. It is therefore the wrong approach to say that biofuels should now be produced from alternative sources such as algae or waste instead. The central istic hubris of being able to determine the proportion to which biofuels are to be used is the problem – not the production of the product itself.

name: Glenis Willmott (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This amending directive applies to indirect land-use change (ILUC) and amends the Fuel Quality Directive and Renewable Energy Directive. The original Directives aimed to enable a transition from fossil fuels to biofuels to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. However, these ʽfirst generationʼ biofuels use crops that would otherwise have been used for food or animal feed, and the indirect land-use change can produce enough emissions to negate the benefits of biofuels over fossil fuels. This proposal caps the contribution of first generation biofuels to greenhouse emissions targets and encourages the use of advanced biofuels that will be more beneficial to our environment. Labour MEPs wanted a stronger cap, but we voted for this report as it is a step in the right direction and the door is open for further legislation in the future.

name: Jan Zahradil (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 Promoting first generation biofuels and setting a 10% share was a huge mistake now recognised by the European Commission. In the Czech Republic, biofuels have become an attractive business linked to public subsidies, and there is even a conflict of interest, with the dominant producer of biofuels being a company owned by the current member of the government, which decides on the subsidy system. We now have a chance to remedy this at European level, but the ceiling is still unnecessarily high and I would like an even lower limit than the approved 7%.

name: Flavio Zanonato (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the directives on fuel quality and renewable energies. The two directives now provide a positive framework for ensuring the sustainable use of biofuels in transport. I believe that limiting the share of biofuels for reaching 10% of renewable energy in transport to 7% is a relevant and necessary measure and I welcome the provisions promoting the use of advanced biofuels. I will conclude by recalling the need to take into account the indirect impact of land use on biofuel production, which could frustrate efforts to control greenhouse gas emissions as well as increase the cost of agricultural food.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposals contained in the Torvalds Recommendation because I considered them balanced in the right extent that they set an adjusted limit for the introduction of conventional biofuels. They introduce a target for new generation biofuels, which should be encouraged, in particular in the framework of horizon 2020 research and innovation policy and the Principles of the Energy Union. They reinforce the need to consider in the assessment of the impact of the use of biofuels, the evaluation of the alterations induced in land uses. They stress the importance of restricting competition between the biofuel production row and food ranks. They call on the Commission to put forward an ambitious proposal for the promotion and use of renewable energy in transport for the post-2020 period. In addition to the incentive needed for the most advanced technologies, in particular new generation biofuels that minimise competition with other ranks and greenhouse gas emissions, I believe that the conditions for pursuing the ambitious goal of the development of electric mobility are finally in place.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission presented a legislative proposal in October 2012 with the aim of starting a transition to a biofuels policy that can significantly minimise greenhouse gas emissions, especially in road transport.  In 2009, as part of the 2020 climate and energy strategy, a dual target was set by 2020: 10 % share of renewable energy (mainly biofuels) in the transport sector, introduced by the Renewable Energy Directive, and a 6 % reduction in the intensity of greenhouse gases of fuels used in road and non-road transport, introduced by a revision of the Fuel Quality Directive. Although the titles of both the communication, directives and this report refer to the promotion of the use of energy from renewable sources, it is a fact that, in these texts, little is said in other cases other than biofuels, leaving it to be seen that under the guise of noble objectives such as the reduction of the factors that cause climate change, such as GHGs, another potentially very profitable business is promoted. , which could mean the loss of agricultural production to feed the peoples, so that we have agricultural production for the production of biofuel raw materials.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I was very hesitant about voting on this point, because it is a question of how much restrictions on plastic bags should be addressed by the European Union or, on the basis of the principle of subsidiarity, this should remain the responsibility of individual national states.  I do not deny that this is an extremely beneficial environmental objective. Finally, I supported this compromise solution, which is much more accommodating to individual sovereign states and allows states to choose their own measures to reduce the consumption of lightweight plastic shopping bags. This is certainly a better solution than the original proposal that imposed on states that they must charge for shopping bags, which seems to me to be really something that, as the European Union, we should not impose on states in this directive. Rather, we should give them general objectives and general visions of which direction we want to go. This is for me this proposal, which, as I have already said, allows its own solution for nation states. That is why I supported the proposal.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE).
text: – I support such a report, because the plastic bags that we have millions in Europe are indeed a major polluter for the environment. I like that it's... the measure goes in this direction so that countries can decide for themselves, on the principle of subsidiarity, how they reduce the bags in circulation. But they do have a European... europe clearly set targets, borders, for 2019 and also for 2025. I support for sure, if he does... these border targets will not be achieved, the European Parliament, the European Commission will be able to take some sharper action. At the moment, however, I think that such a measure, for the states themselves, choose the way to reduce the number of plastic bags, correct.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D).
text: – Dear Mr President, I supported this directive because I am of the opinion that a clean environment is a prerequisite for good public health. I think that plastic bag contamination is worrying and that this problem needs to be tackled.  At the same time, I am of the opinion that the text as such, with a proposal to impose additional levies and charges in a state of de facto economic stagnation, poses economic and social risks. Such measures may seem like a solution to finding quick statistical results, but the economic and social effect is not negligible. I fear that this directive will be used as a pretext to impose not disproportionately high charges on consumers, which, in my view, is a prerequisite for a dangerous effect – a drastic reduction in demand for this type of production, which in turn poses a danger to workers in the sector.  I call on the Commission and the Governments of the Member States to put forward quality proposals in this regard, as well as more ambitious measures to present the benefits of using bags of other materials.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, today I was delighted that we in this Parliament are responding to the concerns of EU citizens. Just recently in a Eurobarometer survey, 92% of citizens expressed concerns and asked to reduce single-use plastic bags. I come from a Member State that was a trailblazer in this, in that we managed a 90% reduction of plastic bag usage by the introduction of a charge for a plastic bag. Supermarkets and shops can no longer give out free plastic bags. There is a charge of 22 cents per bag. This is a substantial amount and what it does is to make people think and to ensure that most of the time, in fact 90% of the time, consumers will either reuse bags or buy recyclable bags that can be used many times.  I believe that the proposal today is flexible enough in that it gives Member States a choice: either to have a binding reduction target, or a mandate to improve composting standards for plastic bags, along with other measures.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: Mr. President, this is the final step of adopting a directive that aims to solve a major environmental problem. Lightweight plastic bags often end up in the sea or in nature instead of in the regular waste management cycle. The very high consumption of plastic bags in the European Union threatens us and implies that we will spend our resources in an unsustainable way. Lightweight plastic bags used once and then throw away are an example of high environmental pollution.  The compromise reached on this directive took into account the habits of our consumers, the survival of small businesses producing plastic bags and the nature that cannot suffer additional burdens. Therefore, a good solution is to ensure that the definition of very thin bags from 10 to 15 microns is amended, as it will allow small bag manufacturers whose production was compromised by the original proposal.  Member States will have to take measures to reduce the consumption of plastic bags, but have been given the choice of how they will do so.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, arís vótáil mé le mo ghrúpa ar na moltaí seo agus chuir sé áthas orm gur vótáil 590 Feisire as 691 i bhfabhar. Taispeánann sé seo go dtuigimid go bhfuil sé seo an-tábhachtach mar ábhar agus gur féidir linn rud éigin a dhéanamh faoi.  Is maith an rud is go bhfuil spriocanna ann, agus tá na spriocanna réadach agus is dóigh liom gur féidir iad a bhaint amach. Rud eile: nuair a bhíonn air dhaoine íoc as rud bíonn leisce orthu mí-úsáid a bhaint as. Mar shampla, sa Danmhairg agus i dtíortha eile i dtuaisceart na hEorpa deirtear nach bhfuil daoine ag úsáid ach 4 mhála plaisteach in aghaidh na bliana. Mar a bhí Marian Harkin ag rá cúpla nóiméad ó shin, i mo thír féin tugadh isteach íoc ar mhálaí plaisteacha in 2002 – 15 cent an mála, deir siad gur 22 cent anois é – ach tharla laghdú air na málaí ó 328 mála an duine go dtí 21 mhála an duine. Cabhraíonn sé seo chun an comhshaol a chaomhnú.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE).
text: – Mr. President, I supported the amendment of the directive on the reduction of lightweight plastic bags, because the position of small producers, including from the Republic of Croatia, is included, by which very thin bags are still those of 15 microns, not 10 as previously proposed.  The fact is that plastic bags are not dangerous to the environment, but pollute it. And that is why a much better solution would be to establish a collection and recycling system, but since this did not pass such an agreement was not reached. The solution in the directive is a compromise of sorts that I also agreed to.  These Member States have two options, limited annual consumption of plastic bags per person or other option, the start of the collection of plastic bags from 2018, with very thin bags with a thickness of 15 microns and less than that being excluded from this measure. The implementation of this directive will reduce the negative impact on the environment and therefore I am happy to support it.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to explain why I did not vote in support of the proposal to reject this directive. The directive concerns only a certain detail, and these are plastic bags that have an impact on environmental protection. Plastic bags that have a wall thickness of 15 to 50 microns. These are therefore lightweight plastic bags. This Directive does not infer anything to The Member States, but gives them the opportunity to choose which tool to reduce consumption they choose, whether it will be charging or limiting the number of plastic bags. The labelling of compostable materials and the pressure on research towards recycling these plastic bags are also an important measure.  I expect the European Union to address those problems that the Member States cannot solve, and environmental protection is one of these issues. That is why I supported this directive.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. The Spanish Socialists very positively value the adoption of this new Directive aimed at reducing the consumption of plastic bags, not only to combat the high incidence and persistence of this waste on the environment, but also because the text adopted with the Council is also a first and innovative step in understanding our production model. For the first time, the three European institutions have been able to promote a legal text entirely based on preventive criteria. In the case of plastic bags, our much-claimed strict application of the waste hierarchy is now a reality. Preventing waste is the first link in the circular economy model we believe in and which has to be our new industrial revolution. Given the wide disparity between Member States with regard to the consumption of plastic bags, measures such as the distinction of ultralight bags, the promotion of new alternative materials, labelling to identify certain types of bags and the recommendation on a price per unit at the point of sale will be, in addition to the binding objectives, essential steps to achieve the minimisation of the waste that the challenge of the circular economy imposes on us.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The objective of this report is to help reduce the consumption of plastic bags with a thickness of less than 50 microns. Our position in the Group was in favour of the proposals introduced by Parliament, which allow greater control and definition of the measures necessary to reduce the environmental impact of plastic bag consumption. This report has no final vote, as it is a second reading within the three-way dialogue process.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. Plastic bags are not biodegradable and can take between 400 and 1 000 years to break down in the environment. It is estimated that 1 million plastic bags are used every minute globally which makes it no surprise that plastic waste is causing some serious impacts on the worldʼs oceans. Plastic never completely deteriorates – it breaks down into ever smaller pieces. With up to 12 000 000 tons of plastic entering the world’s oceans every year it is worrying but inevitable that the fish we eat will have ingested some of it. In Ireland, both north and south, the plastic bag charges have a proven record. Indeed, Ireland was the first country in the world to introduce such a levy and currently charges EUR 0.22 per bag. The number of bags used per inhabitant fell from 328 per year to just 21, already well below the target of 90 in this report.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. Directive 94/62/EC on packaging and packaging waste fails to regulate the use of lightweight plastic bags (wall thickness below 50 microns). However, these lightweight plastic bags make a significant contribution to the Union-wide waste load, as they are not particularly suitable for re-use due to their light material and therefore usually end up in waste immediately. There are different legal frameworks in the Member States on this issue, some of which are exemplary. In order to guarantee a uniform and high standard across the EU and to reduce waste pollution across the Union, I welcome the amendments that are being made.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. This text is only a "cosmetic" legislative tool. I welcome the desire to limit the use of plastic bags. But it is clear that the consequence of such a text is the increase in the use of vacuum overpacking, and, therefore, the displacement of the problem without reducing the consumption of plastic in the Member States. The whole model of mass consumption should have been rethought and not just legislated on a consequence of it. Finally, this directive is symbolic of a Commission producing excessive texts, whose will is to govern all areas of public life, without respecting the principle of subsidiarity which is enshrined in the Treaties. So I voted against it.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation because it encourages users of plastic bags to be more environmentally responsible

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to oblige Member States to reduce the use of plastic bags because they pollute the environment and water bodies and harm the ecosystem. In 2010, one European consumed an average of 198 plastic bags, of which 90% were lightweight. In the same year, more than EUR 8 billion was invested in the development of the european economy. plastic bags have become rubbish. These indicators increase year on year. This proposal requires member states to opt for one of the two obligations: either to adopt measures to ensure that up to 90 light plastic carrier bags per person are consumed on average by the end of 2019, and no more than 40 lightweight plastic carrier bags per person by the end of 2025, or to ensure that plastic bags are not distributed free of charge locally by the end of 2018 for the sale of goods or products until uniformly effective measures are applied (i.e. taxing them). I agree that Member States must report annually on the annual consumption of plastic carrier bags. I support the obligation to label biodegradable and compostable plastic carrier bags and the proposal to assess the aerobic effects of biodegradable plastic carrier bags in normal plastics( a supplement added to ordinary plastic, which in the long run breaks down plastics into microparticles).

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. Yes, we need to reduce the consumption of plastic bags, but it is not up to the European Union to decide what steps to take to achieve this laudable target. The vote was not on the recommendation but on an amendment rejecting the Council's position at first reading.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The high consumption of plastic bags less than 50 microns thick has a major impact on the environment in the European Union. Too many plastic bags are found in the wild and have a negative impact on the ecosystem. It is also estimated that it takes several hundred years for a plastic bag to decompose. Plastic bags are therefore responsible for a considerable amount of wild waste. In order to reduce pollution and preserve the environment, it is therefore necessary for Member States to adopt economic measures and marketing restrictions aimed at drastically reducing the use of plastic bags. This justifies my vote.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I am pleased with Parliament's position to reject the position presented and the second-reading agreement. Reducing the use of plastic bags is a very important point, and from Parliament we will continue to be very firm in our line, which is linked to that of the ALDE Group and the campaign under way.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. This recommendation concerns the reduction of the use of lightweight plastic bags in the EU. The text requires Member States to either ban the free availability of plastic bags in stores before the end of 2018, or to introduce a ceiling on the average consumption of disputed bags per capita (90 bags per person per year by 2019, and 40 by 2025). In addition, states will also have an obligation to establish proper labelling that reflects the biodegradable nature of bags, and will have a multitude of sanctions, such as taxes, to enforce this demand. If, at first glance, the intention to reduce the ecological problem posed by the dumping of bags is commendable, the measures envisaged may lead to negative consequences by encouraging the production of expensive paper bags in water or vacuum packaging. This will not reduce the production of plastic in any way... This text is indicative of the attitude that denies the sovereignty of the Member States. I therefore abstained on this recommendation.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. The Spanish Socialists very positively value the adoption of this new Directive aimed at reducing the consumption of plastic bags, not only to combat the high incidence and persistence of this waste on the environment, but also because the text adopted with the Council is also a first and innovative step in understanding our production model. For the first time, the three European institutions have been able to promote a legal text entirely based on preventive criteria. In the case of plastic bags, our much-claimed strict application of the waste hierarchy is now a reality. Preventing waste is the first link in the circular economy model we believe in and which has to be our new industrial revolution. Given the wide disparity between Member States with regard to the consumption of plastic bags, measures such as the distinction of ultralight bags, the promotion of new alternative materials, labelling to identify certain types of bags and the recommendation on a price per unit at the point of sale will be, in addition to the binding objectives, essential steps to achieve the minimisation of the waste that the challenge of the circular economy imposes on us.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it supported the legislation imposing an obligation on Member States to reduce the consumption of lightweight plastic carrier bags. This will be the first mandatory eu-level waste reduction measure. This environmental objective will be achieved by requiring Member States to choose between two obligations: either to adopt measures to ensure that up to 90 light plastic carrier bags per person are consumed on average by the end of 2019 and up to 40 light plastic carrier bags per person by 2025. Alternatively, ensure that plastic bags are not distributed free of charge at the point of sale of goods or products until the end of 2018 until they are applied.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Today, 90% of plastic bags used for purchase in the European Union are used only once before they become highly environmentally polluting, not at all, or difficult to degrade waste. This places an extremely heavy burden on the environment, with 8 billion plastic bags becoming waste in nature every year. The new European legislation approved is therefore intended to reduce excessive and sometimes unnecessary waste production. Hungary, thanks to the environmental product fee law introduced earlier, is already meeting the targets set for 2025 by the newly approved Directive, with exemplary results in Europe.  As a member of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I supported the adoption of the new EU legislation, which, in addition to effectively reducing nylon waste, will also encourage the development of environmentally conscious customer habits. This will contribute to a cleaner, more livable European environment.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (NI)
text: In writing. The aim of the text is to encourage the reduction of the use of plastic bags. Indeed, while these are used by the end consumer only a few minutes, the damage to the environment is disastrous.  In fact, 99 billion plastic bags every year in the European Union.  The text was adopted by the Council on 2 March 2015 and an agreement was reached to ask member states to reduce the number of bags used and/or to ensure that they are no longer provided free of charge to consumers after December 2018. I voted against this text because the policy of the European Union is not in line with laudable objectives. It does not offer a comprehensive view of the problem and treats with lightness, from an economic point of view, the fate of nearly 20,000 workers in the sector's enterprises.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. Plastic bags are not biodegradable and can take between 400 and 1 000 years to break down in the environment. It is estimated that 1 million plastic bags are used every minute globally, which makes it no surprise that plastic waste is causing some serious impacts on the world’s oceans. Plastic never completely deteriorates – it breaks down into ever smaller pieces. With up to 12 000 000 tons of plastic entering the world’s oceans every year it is worrying but inevitable that the fish we eat will have ingested some of it. In Ireland, both north and south, the plastic bag charges have a proven record. Indeed, Ireland  was the first country in the world to introduce such a levy and currently charges 22 cents per bag. The number of bags used per inhabitant fell from 328 per year to just 21, already well below the target of 90 in this report.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted yes to this recommendation because reducing the consumption of plastic carrier bags would be a big step forward towards a society more respectful of the environment.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. The directive aims to reduce the use of plastic bags with a target of 90 plastic bags per person per year by 2020. If the over-consumption of plastic bags is a real problem, it cannot be solved by means of yet another directive without a comprehensive strategy in this area. It should also be remembered that the implementation of the environmental policy under Article 11 of the TFUE must respect the principle of subsidiarity. However, the limit on the use of plastic bags can be decided sovereignly by the Member States without the European Union legislationing.. The Commission must stop its inflationary legislative policy and respect the latitude of member states in implementing environmental protection policies. That is why I voted against this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Reducing the consumption of plastic bags necessary for transport, together with packaging and packaging waste, must be an immediate concern of all the factors responsible for protecting the environment. With the decomposition of a plastic package can take several hundred years, it is more than worrying that more than 8 billion bags become waste in Europe every year. I voted for the proposal for a regulation obliging Member States to adopt measures to reduce the consumption of plastic carrier bags less than 50 microns thick. However, I believe that things need to go further and focus on encouraging consumers to reuse plastic carrier bags. Furthermore, the introduction of standards establishing biodegradable properties for transport bags used on the European market, as well as setting limits on their quantities, would help to decrease the number of plastic bags.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 My position is favourable. The Commission's proposal put at risk the biodegradable bag sector, where Italian industry is at the forefront. The text agreed at second reading avoids this danger while combining the requirements of environmental and public health protection.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. The Spanish Socialists very positively value the adoption of this new Directive aimed at reducing the consumption of plastic bags, not only to combat the high incidence and persistence of this waste on the environment, but also because the text adopted with the Council is also a first and innovative step in understanding our production model. For the first time, the three European institutions have been able to promote a legal text entirely based on preventive criteria. In the case of plastic bags, our much-claimed strict application of the waste hierarchy is now a reality. Preventing waste is the first link in the circular economy model we believe in and which has to be our new industrial revolution. Given the wide disparity between Member States with regard to the consumption of plastic bags, measures such as the distinction of ultralight bags, the promotion of new alternative materials, labelling to identify certain types of bags and the recommendation on a price per unit at the point of sale will be, in addition to the binding objectives, essential steps to achieve the minimisation of the waste that the challenge of the circular economy imposes on us.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of a directive to reduce the consumption of lightweight plastic bags with handles. These bags, used daily by a multitude of consumers, are too often responsible for environmental pollution. In many Member States, the use of these bags is rationed. For example, in some countries, these bags are no longer free, which causes consumers to reuse them and thus reduce their consumption. The directive proposes that Member States adopt various measures to significantly reduce the consumption of plastic bags in their territory. Mandatory labelling will also be required for recyclable bags. We must make efforts to preserve our environment. These kinds of measures help to adapt our mindsets to today's environmental challenges.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the recommendation for second reading on the Council's position at first reading with a view to adopting a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 94/62/EC as regards the reduction of the use of light plastic bags. The text voted on has the merit of including mandatory reduction targets and the obligation to charge for plastic bags, measures that significantly strengthen EU rules aimed at reducing the use of plastic bags.  The text also introduces an obligation for Member States to submit an annual report on the annual consumption of light plastic bags 36 months after the entry into force of the legislation. This strengthens existing reporting obligations and, consequently, the concrete instruments available to Member States to monitor the effectiveness of the measures taken. I believe that the agreement reached by Parliament represents a substantial improvement on the Commission's initial proposal, and that is why I supported it.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. This report sought to look for solutions as to how to reduce the consumption of lightweight plastic carrier bags. The excessive consumption of plastic bags in the EU is a matter of serious concern and as plastic bags tend to be used on a once-off basis, this results in unnecessary and preventable waste. Every year nearly 100 billion plastic bags are used and it is projected that this figure will grow to 111 billion plastic bags by 2020 if no action is taken. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The proposal, based on the Commission’s own impact assessment, amends Directive 94/62/EC by requiring Member States to take measures to significantly reduce the consumption of lightweight plastic carrier bags across the EU. It stipulates that these measures may include the use of economic instruments as well as marketing restrictions in derogation of Article 18 of the Directive. This derogation allows for a broader range of instruments available for Member States to address the unsustainable consumption of plastic bags. I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following negotiations between the European Parliament and the Council, the European Commission's proposal has been improved by making it compulsory for Member States to ensure a reduction in the consumption of plastic bags. For the first time in forty years of European waste legislation, binding measures will finally be envisaged at EU level to reduce waste production. We voted in favour.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this report which not only supports a directive that is binding on member states but also carries the risk of having the opposite effect to the stated objective. Indeed, the Commission's directive aims to reduce the use of plastic bags. A laudable goal from a sustainable development perspective. However, the provisions proposed by the Commission to achieve this objective seem to me to be inefficient and inconsistent. Indeed, removing plastic bags from supermarkets will lead to the development of vacuum overpacking, which only displaces the problem. Moreover, the demands on Member States posed by this directive are disproportionate: the reduction in the level of consumption by 2019 to 90 plastic bags per person per year; the obligation on Member States to make the reduction effective from 36 months after the legislation comes into force, all requests that do not take into account the cyclical specificities linked to each state, whether in economic, political or administrative organisation.

name: Nessa Childers (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Since 2002, Ireland has had a levy on plastic bags. This has brought about a significant effect on the use of plastic bags, decreasing from 328 bags per capita to 21 bags overnight. However, not all EU Member States have put those types of measures into place. The majority of MEPs rightly saw the need for binding measures at EU level so as to tackle serious damage caused by plastics to the environment and biodiversity. Ninety-two per cent of the EU population agrees with reducing the use of plastic bags; furthermore, we believe that restricting the use at EU level will be a quick and sustainable way of reducing the problem.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 After lengthy negotiations with the Council, agreement was finally reached and final vote on amending the directive to reduce the consumption of the use of plastic bags.   The introduction of obligations for states to reduce the use of plastic bags will help protect the environment, especially the marine environment. If you consider that the amount of plastic particles in our oceans is greater than the amount of plankton, you get an idea of the gravity of the phenomenon and the need to intervene for more rational consumption and to find environmentally friendly alternatives. This will certainly encourage the development of products that are less impacting on the surrounding environment and the search for new, less polluting materials. The final text could have been more ambitious, but I consider it a good compromise or at least the best possible one at this stage. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 If we study data on the use of plastic bags as well as on their impact on the environment and, by extension, on human health, then we realise the need to take effective measures to limit their use. We have in particular, firstly, 1.2 trillion plastic bags every year, secondly, every European uses an average of about 200 bags, most of which end up in the garbage, thirdly, 100 billion tonnes of plastic that pollute the seas and make up 90% of marine pollution and, fourthly, plastic remains in the environment from 500 to 1000 years. Thus the plastic particles from which the bags are made enter the food chain.Although it has not been studied whether harmful chemicals are actually transmitted from fish to humans, it is nevertheless known that plastics bind pollutants. As stated in the Green Paper adopted by the European Commission in March 2013 "obsessive organic pollutants can cling to pieces of plastic and enter the food chain through the marine fauna that consumes plastics."

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Directive on reducing the consumption of light plastic bags requires Member States, to (1) take measures to ensure that the annual consumption level does not exceed, on average, 90 light plastic bags per person by the end of 2019 and no later than 40 light plastic bags per person by 2025 or (2) to ensure that , by the end of 2018, plastic bags are no longer supplied free of charge at points of sale of goods or products, unless other instruments of equal effectiveness are implemented.  In order to assess the effectiveness of the reduction measures, there is a monitoring system which requires Member States, 36 months after entry into force, to submit an annual report on the annual consumption of light plastic bags on the basis of a common methodology to be adopted by the Commission within 12 months. In addition, the Commission is obliged to lay down specifications for the labelling of biodegradable and compostable plastic bags. A final point to note is that the measures provided for in the directive are binding. For these reasons, I voted against.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal for a directive because I agree that we want to prevent and reduce the impact of packaging and packaging waste on the environment.  The context in which this measure matures is worrying: in 2010 it was estimated that every European citizen used as many as 198 plastic bags per year, mostly light and not easily reusable. The use of plastic bags with a thickness of less than 50 microns, much less reused than thicker plastic bags, involves a considerable amount of waste, which is reduced by the application of this directive. The text also has the merit of introducing an obligation for Member States to submit an annual report on the consumption of light plastic bags 36 months after the entry into force of the legislation. This monitors the results to monitor and evaluate the effectiveness of the measures taken and to question their validity if they do not meet expectations.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Plastic bags used by consumers to carry food products (between 15 and 50 microns in thickness), targeted by the directive, pose a greater environmental risk than thicker ones. Due to irresponsible consumer habits, 90% of these bags are thrown away after first usage, amounting to 8 billion bags turning into waste every year. Decomposition of plastic bags can take hundreds of years, making accumulation a major problem. Plastics constitute a large part of marine debris, especially the single-use items: packaging, bags, bottles. Even those plastics which are degradable do not entirely disappear into nature. After a certain time, they turn into microscopic particles, microplastics, which are harmful to the environment and especially to marine ecosystems.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. Almost 100 billion plastic bags are consumed annually in the EU each year, a figure expected to increase to 111 billion by 2020 if no reduction measures are taken by then. Because of their low recycling value, plastic bags today represent a serious environmental problem, with the most plastic waste accumulating in European seas and can last hundreds of years, mainly in the form of fragments. I support the Auken report because I believe that this scourge is urgently necessary and that the EU should set an example in this area.  I am pleased that, unlike the first reading text adopted by this House in April last year which did not advocate any action at European level simply suggesting that each Member State unilaterally resolve the issue of plastic bags (without imposing any targets on them), the text adopted today establishes an alternative obligation to limit the annual consumption of bags per person by 2019 or the end of their gratuity by 2019 or the end of their gratuity , as has been implemented recently in my country for example.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on reducing the use of plastic bags because the compromise reached is a major step in the right direction. The legislation, which has now been formally confirmed, is intended to address the problem of increasing plastic waste, especially in the world's oceans. The compromise stipulates that only a maximum of 90 plastic bags may be consumed by 31 December 2019 and 40 by the end of 2025 per capita per year. The Member States have a wide margin of discretion when it is allocated to the choice of funds. They can ban traditional plastic bags or use economic tools such as deposits or fees. I believe, even if the Member States have a free hand here, that bans are not the best means. Experience from Ireland shows that people change their behaviour as soon as market economy measures are introduced. This illustrates the enormous reduction in the consumption of disposable plastic bags after the introduction of a levy and thus an end to the free handing out of disposable plastic bags.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of amending Directive 94/62/EC on reducing the use of light plastic bags, believing that the provisions introduced are functional to achieving the objectives set. In this case, the text asks states to make a choice between the following two obligations: to take measures to ensure that the per capita consumption level of light plastic bags does not exceed an average of 90 by the end of 2019 and is no later than 40 by 2025 or, alternatively, to ensure that plastic bags are more costly for consumers by the end of 2018 and, therefore, their use is discouraged. I am particularly pleased that, for the first time in forty years of European legislation on waste, it has finally been possible to introduce binding measures against the Member States, a sign of the Union's stronger and stronger commitment to regulating certain aspects of this sector.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Littering of plastic bags is a widespread problem and can be harmful especially to the marine environment. Decreasing plastic bag usage will lead to a cleaner environment in Europe. The Directive in question targets plastic bags between 15 and 50 microns in thickness which pose a greater environmental risk than thicker ones, as the former are rarely re-used. As a result of the decision, Member States will either have to impose a price on plastic bags by the end of 2018 or limit the annual consumption of plastic bags to 90 bags per person by the end of 2019, and further reduce this number to 40 by the end of 2025. I have thus voted in favour.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I firmly believe that we must move towards a sharp reduction in the use of the most polluting plastic bags.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The objective of this report is to help reduce the consumption of plastic bags with a thickness of less than 50 microns. Our position in the Group was in favour of the proposals introduced by Parliament, which allow greater control and definition of the measures necessary to reduce the environmental impact of plastic bag consumption. This report has no final vote, as it is a second reading within the three-way dialogue process.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The directive we are voting on will limit the consumption of non-biodegradable disposable plastic bags, so as to reduce the huge amount that ends up every day in the waste cycle or dispersed in the environment and waterways and aquatic ecosystems, where it remains for many years.  The adoption of this directive is important because it provides for the possibility for Member States to impose at national level bans or targets for reducing the consumption of bags, either alongside or as an alternative to imposing a price to discourage their use. Member States will be able to choose whether to take measures to reduce average annual consumption to 90 non-biodegradable plastic bags per citizen by 2019 and 40 by 2025, or whether to ensure that, by 2018, bags are no longer supplied to consumers in supermarkets and shops free of charge– another important step for protecting our environment.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Currently, 90% of plastic bags used for purchase in the European Union are used only once before they become waste. This places an extremely heavy burden on the environment, with 8 billion plastic bags becoming waste in nature every year. The new European legislation approved is therefore intended to reduce excessive and sometimes unnecessary waste production.  It is a milestone that we have succeeded in adopting binding measures at EU level to reduce waste. I hope that the Member States will take appropriate measures as soon as possible to meet the targets of the newly approved directive for 2025.
