I was pleased to support the adoption of the new EU legislation, which, in addition to effectively reducing nylon waste, will also encourage the development of environmentally conscious customer habits. This will contribute to a cleaner, more livable European environment.  I also consider it important to call on EU citizens and businesses to protect the environment in this way.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am against rejecting the Council position in this dossier. Plastic bags are seriously harmful to the environment. They are also damaging to our marine environment. Some Member States, including Malta, have already started addressing this issue. I believe that charging for the use of plastic bags is a quick way of reducing the problem.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the obligation imposed on the Commission to provide for specific measures on the labelling of biodegradable and compostable plastic carrier bags is an important means of avoiding misleading practices of false labelling of plastic bags, especially in the case of so-called 'oxo-biodegradable' plastic bags.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of amending the European directive on reducing the consumption of light plastic bags. The European Parliament has greatly improved the European Commission's original proposal and the agreement concluded takes this into account. The text adopted today will allow, among other things, those Member States that want to set more ambitious targets than ordinary European ones to be able to proceed by means of national restrictions as well.  This aspect is particularly important for our country, favoring the closure of a long-running dispute that had seen Italy the recipient of an infringement procedure, with the "fault" of having been at the forefront of the production of virtuous plastic bags from an environmental point of view. More generally, however, the proposal approved today by Parliament at second reading has the merit of establishing a new legal framework for a more ambitious common European policy on the treatment of plastic bags in favour of the preservation of the environment and biodiversity.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. The aim of this report is to avoid the consumption of plastic bags up to 50 microns thick and therefore reduce their impact on the environment. It is a balanced report that gives Member States the choice, in order to achieve their objectives, to either impose binding reduction measures of up to 90 bags per person by the end of 2019 and 40 bags per person by the end of 2025, or to impose measures prohibiting the free supply of this type of plastic bags by 31 December 2018. Considering also that this report will reduce the significant impact of the consumption of plastic bags on the environment while respecting the principle of proportionality by excluding very light bags as well as bags intended to pack fresh food, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I welcome this text, which recalls the essential reduction in the consumption of plastic bags in Europe and introduces binding measures for The Member States for the first time. This is a real step forward in European legislation, which will help to tackle pollution and limit waste production.  In the run-up to the Paris climate conference, the adoption of this directive is a reminder that the European Union is committed to protecting the environment.

name: Philippe De Backer (ALDE)
text: in writing. – Europeans use about 99 million plastic bags every year. A rough 8 million plastic bags end up in our environment, both on land and at sea. Although the consumption of plastic bags varies across the Member States, Parliament strongly believes that we can do better. That is why I follow the Commission in its proposal to reduce the use of plastic bags to 90 bags per person per year in 2019 and to reduce this amount to 40 bags in 2025. I voted in favour of reducing lightweight carrier bags as the Member States receive the freedom to choose how they will reach these targets. In the meantime I am convinced that it is also important that Europeans make a mentality switch. We must become more conscious of our impact on the environment in general.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Billion plastic bags end up in the wild every year as untreated waste. I strongly supported this proposal, which obliges Member States to reduce the consumption of light plastic bags.  European states will be able to choose whether to take measures to reduce the average consumption of plastic bags to 90 bags per citizen by the end of 2019 and to 40 by the end of 2025, or to ensure that plastic bags are no longer delivered free of charge by the end of 2018.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. Of the 100 billion plastic bags consumed each year in the EU, nearly 8 billion end up in the wild. It is a deadly danger to birds and marine animals and a scourge on the environment. This situation is no longer acceptable.  The European Parliament's vote at second reading of the directive to reduce the consumption of lightweight plastic bags now provides for a strict limit on the use of single-use plastic bags in Europe, which is a step in the right direction.  The implementation of pilot projects at European level has had a rapid and effective effect, showing that a voluntary environmental management policy at community level can provide a serious and concrete response. That is why we must continue in this direction.  At the same time, the principle of subsidiarity must apply to implementation, at national, even regional and local level, probably being better able to take the appropriate measures for each territory to achieve these objectives. This division of missions between the Union setting the main guidelines and the authorities of the implementing member countries is a guarantee of greater efficiency.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Nowadays, pollution is so large that we have to fight it at every level and in every possible area. The amendment of the Directive obliges Member States to continuously limit the number of lightweight plastic bags in order to reduced littering.  These carry-on pouches are dangerous to the environment in many ways, so it is important to pay attention to them. Due to their thinness and poor texture, the possibility of reusing them is limited, people throw them away more often than thicker bags, and thus do not get into the waste disposal system. The amendment to the Directive offers several options for sustainable restrictions on the number of lightweight plastic bags, such as reducing the number to 40 per person per year by the end of 2025. Alternatively, by the end of 2018, Member States will ensure that they do not provide free lightweight plastic bags in their stores when shopping, or that they can use other methods to ensure that the number of plastic bags is reduced equally effectively.  I consider it very important to adopt this amendment, because with its entry into force, Member States must reduce the number of lightweight plastic bags and report on this to the Commission in annual reports, so that they can effectively monitor compliance. If this amendment to the restriction is not made, the number of plastic carry-on bags would be shown to increase in the future and this would have unforeseen consequences for nature.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. Plastic bags are a major source of pollution worldwide and a serious threat to wildlife (in the North Sea, 94% of birds have already ingested plastic). It appears that, on average, a European citizen uses 190 plastic bags per year and 89% of these bags are used only once. Of the 100 billion plastic bags used annually by Europeans, 8 billion would end up in lakes, rivers, countryside and roadsides. Knowing that it takes 500 years for a plastic bag to decompose, it is essential to adopt new rules to drastically limit the use of lightweight plastic bags. EU countries will have to choose between two approaches: either reduce the number of lightweight plastic bags used per person (90 bags/person/year by the end of 2019 and 40 bags/person/year for 2025), or stop giving away bags free of charge at food outlets by the end of 2018, as is already the case in some EU countries. That is my preferred option.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Today, 90% of plastic bags used for purchase in the EU are used only once before they become waste. This places an extremely heavy burden on the environment, with 8 billion plastic bags becoming waste in nature every year. The new European legislation approved is therefore intended to reduce excessive and sometimes unnecessary waste production. Hungary, thanks to the Environmental Product Fee Act introduced in 2011, is already meeting the 2025 targets of the newly approved Directive, with exemplary results in Europe.  As a member of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I was pleased to support the adoption of the new EU legislation, which, in addition to effectively reducing nylon waste, will also encourage the development of environmentally conscious customer habits. This will contribute to a cleaner, more livable European environment.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. I decided to vote against this text because it is only a cosmetic legislative tool. Of course, we can welcome the desire to limit the use of plastic bags. But it is clear that the consequence of such a text is the increase in the use of vacuum overpacking, and therefore only displace the problem without reducing plastic consumption in the Union. The model of mass consumption as a whole should have been rethought and not just legislated on a consequence of it. Finally, this directive is symbolic of an "ultra-legislative" European Commission whose will is to govern all areas of public life, without respecting the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstained on the report on reducing the consumption of lightweight plastic carrier bags because I believe, as the European Commission mentioned, that the proposal contains specific texts that are also outside the competence of a legislative body.  I and my political group fully support the long-term objectives contained in the EC proposal.  However, they must be clear, consistent and feasible in reducing the use of a plastic bag, not overly restrictive - and potentially unworkable - requirements such as those set out in this Agreement.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report even though it is a step in the right direction and aims, in any case, to improve the current situation, because I would like to point out that this is not enough and that our ultimate objective must be a complete ban on the use of such plastic carrier bags.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Today, 90% of plastic bags used for purchase in the EU are used only once before they become waste. This places an extremely heavy burden on the environment, with 8 billion plastic bags becoming waste in nature every year. The new European legislation approved is therefore intended to reduce excessive and sometimes unnecessary waste production. Hungary, thanks to the Environmental Product Fee Act introduced in 2011, is already meeting the 2025 targets of the newly approved Directive, with exemplary results in Europe.  As a member of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I was pleased to support the adoption of the new EU legislation, which, in addition to effectively reducing nylon waste, will also encourage the development of environmentally conscious customer habits. This will contribute to a cleaner, more livable European environment.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – I voted to approve new rules on plastic waste. European governments will have to adopt measures to reduce the use of single-use carrier bags, either by introducing a charge, as we have done in Wales, or by another method, to achieve set targets. This is a welcome step. Every year nearly 100 million plastic bags are used in Europe and the number is growing. Eighty-nine per cent of them are used only once and then thrown away. Half end up in landfill sites where they can be blown into the environment. The legislation adopted in Wales was a major success. I am certain that this new EU legislation will have a similar impact.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. With the last passage in plenary, we have reached the final stage of negotiations on the directive to limit the use of plastic shoppers. A much more difficult negotiation than might have been imagined, even considering that the Commission had drawn up an accompanying document with alarming data, especially as regards the damage caused by plastic bags and their fragments to marine habitats and fauna. I was impressed, given the seriousness and urgency of the phenomenon, to note the absolute incongruity of the Commission's original proposal, without any clear constraint on the reduction of shoppers. Mrs Auken's difficult task has been to introduce concrete elements to the proposal and, thanks to her work, it has resulted in a text which, although imperfect and improveable, is probably the best that could be achieved, also in the light of the Commission's difficult and uncooperative attitude on this dossier, and that is why I decided to vote against the motion opposing the closure of the agreement.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal for a Directive received my positive vote as it was a diploma aimed at limiting the negative impacts on the environment resulting from waste production by encouraging a reduction in waste production, more efficient use of resources and the use of thinner plastic bags (with a thickness of less than 0.05 mm).

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Almost 100 billion plastic bags are consumed in the EU each year, a number expected to increase to 111 billion by 2020 if no reduction measures are taken by then. On average, each European uses 198 plastic bags over the course of a year. In the next five minutes, another million plastic bags will have been consumed in the EU. 89% are used only once before they become waste. The Directive requires Member States to have at least one of the following two options: to take measures to ensure that the level of annual consumption does not exceed an average of 90 light plastic bags per person by the end of 2019 and 40 by 2025, or to ensure that by the end of 2018 such plastic bags are not supplied free of charge. In the EU, plastic bags are considered packaging in accordance with the Packaging and Packaging Waste Directive 1994. The new legislation amends this directive to reduce the consumption of lightweight plastic bags, i.e. those with a thickness of less than 50 micrometres, or 0.05 millimetres.

name: Jonás Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. The Spanish Socialists very positively value the adoption of this new Directive aimed at reducing the consumption of plastic bags, not only to combat the high incidence and persistence of this waste on the environment, but also because the text adopted with the Council is also a first and innovative step in understanding our production model. For the first time, the three European institutions have been able to promote a legal text entirely based on preventive criteria. In the case of plastic bags, our much-claimed strict application of the waste hierarchy is now a reality. Preventing waste is the first link in the circular economy model we believe in and which has to be our new industrial revolution. Given the wide disparity between Member States with regard to the consumption of plastic bags, measures such as the distinction of ultralight bags, the promotion of new alternative materials, labelling to identify certain types of bags and the recommendation on a price per unit at the point of sale will be, in addition to the binding objectives, essential steps to achieve the minimisation of the waste that the challenge of the circular economy imposes on us.

name: Edouard Ferrand (NI)
text: In writing. The objective of reducing or even disposing of plastic bags is certainly laudable, given the nuisance caused to the environment.  However, the method envisaged by the European Commission is most questionable. Indeed, states alone can implement effective substitution policies for durable bags or paper bags.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report recommends accepting the Council's position after negotiations with Parliament. The need to reduce the use of plastic bags - excessive and resulting from wrong economic options - is evidence. To this end, awareness-raising and environmental awareness campaigns can contribute, encouraging the change of packaging or means of transport of goods marketed by the various sectors and the call on Member States to promote the use of alternatives. Moreover, nothing prevents the distribution of plastic bags, whether paid or not, by replacing it with the provision of non-disposable bags or carrycots. This report advocates the application of the polluter pays principle, here understood as the reserve of the "right to pollute" to those who can afford it - a view that we do not follow. Pollution is no less harmful if someone pays more or less.  Further research and development of solutions to prevent the damage associated with plastic bags should be continued, replacing them in their various uses.  In the meantime, states should be held accountable for waste policy and management, for imposing operating standards on companies aimed at improving the standard of living and environmental quality, rather than the usual reduction to the profit target.

name: Raffaele Fitto (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Auken report significantly improves the European Commission's proposal by making it compulsory for Member States to ensure a reduction in the consumption of light plastic bags. The directive will provide for binding measures at EU level to reduce waste production, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 A permanent reduction in the consumption of lightweight plastic bags and the imposition of this obligation on Member States marks a significant step forward for the first time in 40 years in the history of European waste legislation. The advantage for Member States is to choose between two commitments and either to take measures to ensure the consumption rate of 90 lightweight plastic bags per person by 2019 and 40 by 2025, or the second option is that by the end of 2018, lightweight plastic bags will no longer be provided at the point of sale free of charge. It is also progressing that the European Commission has laid down specific labelling conditions for biodegradable and composted plastic bags, thereby avoiding false labelling in particular in the case of oxidative and biodegradable plastic bags.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the text agreed at second reading that avoids dangers for companies in the sector, while combining the requirements of environmental protection and public health.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against reducing the consumption of thin plastic carrier bags, although the report is a step in the right direction and in any case improves the current situation, because I would like to point out that this is not enough and that our ultimate aim must be a complete ban on the use of such plastic carrier bags.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Parliament concluded its first reading on 16 April 2014, which was adopted by a wide majority of 543/54/68. It supported binding targets to achieve a 50% reduction in consumption of plastic bags within three years and an 80% reduction within five years as compared to the average EU consumption in 2010. Considering the fact that discarded plastic bags cause serious damage to the environment, not to mention the harm being done by marine litter to biodiversity, I strongly support Parliamentʼs recommendation. The problem can be easily and efficiently addressed as already proved in some Member States; putting a charge on the use of plastic bags is a quick and sustainable way of reducing the problem overnight.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Today, 90% of plastic bags used for purchase in the EU are used only once before they become waste. This places an extremely heavy burden on the environment, with 8 billion plastic bags becoming waste in nature every year. The new European legislation approved is therefore intended to reduce excessive and sometimes unnecessary waste production.  Hungary, thanks to the Environmental Product Fee Act introduced in 2011, is already meeting the 2025 targets of the newly approved Directive, with exemplary results in Europe.  As a member of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I was pleased to support the adoption of the new EU legislation, which, in addition to effectively reducing nylon waste, will also encourage the development of environmentally conscious customer habits. This will contribute to a cleaner, more livable European environment.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Today, 90% of plastic bags used for purchase in the EU are used only once before they become waste. This places an extremely heavy burden on the environment, with 8 billion plastic bags becoming waste in nature every year. The new European legislation approved is therefore intended to reduce excessive and sometimes unnecessary waste production. Hungary, thanks to the Environmental Product Fee Act introduced in 2011, is already meeting the 2025 targets of the newly approved Directive, with exemplary results in Europe. As a member of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I was pleased to support the adoption of the new EU legislation, which, in addition to effectively reducing nylon waste, will also encourage the development of environmentally conscious customer habits, thereby contributing to a cleaner, more livable European environment.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. After years of battle we came to the door of an agreement for the reduction of plastic bags. An important agreement, and necessary to advance the improvement of our environment. Given the disparity in situations in the different Member States, it is important that they have been able to decide between reducing consumption to 40 exchanges per person per year by 2025 or paying for consumption of these bags by the end of 2018. However, it should also be noted that there are no situations of change of customs in users or establishments.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. The Spanish Socialists very positively value the adoption of this new Directive aimed at reducing the consumption of plastic bags, not only to combat the high incidence and persistence of this waste on the environment, but also because the text adopted with the Council is also a first and innovative step in understanding our production model. For the first time, the three European institutions have been able to promote a legal text entirely based on preventive criteria. In the case of plastic bags, our much-claimed strict application of the waste hierarchy is now a reality. Preventing waste is the first link in the circular economy model we believe in and which has to be our new industrial revolution. Given the wide disparity between Member States with regard to the consumption of plastic bags, measures such as the distinction of ultralight bags, the promotion of new alternative materials, labelling to identify certain types of bags and the recommendation on a price per unit at the point of sale will be, in addition to the binding objectives, essential steps to achieve the minimisation of the waste that the challenge of the circular economy imposes on us.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. I would like to thank Mrs Auken and my S&D colleagues in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy for the result that has been achieved. The Commission's proposal has been significantly improved by mandatory Member States to ensure a sustained reduction in the consumption of light plastic bags: for the first time in forty years of European waste legislation, binding measures will be envisaged at EU level to reduce waste production. This is a very important example of Good European Practice.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft legislative resolution on the Council's position with a view to adopting the directive on reducing the use of light plastic bags. Reducing the use and consumption of plastic bags is an issue that affects all European citizens, and that can really contribute to achieving Europe's objectives in the fight against pollution and environmental protection. I am very pleased with the introduction of the obligation for Member States to ensure a sustained reduction in the consumption of light plastic bags, because binding European waste standards are being introduced for the first time. The decision to give Member States a fair amount of flexibility with regard to the modalities of this obligation is also good, either by limiting the personal annual consumption of plastic bags to 90 bags per person by 2019 and 40 bags by 2025, or by permanently eliminating the free supply of plastic bags of material to the points of sale of goods and products. I also welcome the obligation to lay down technical specifications for the labelling of biodegradable and compostable plastic bags in order to avoid abuse and deceptive practices, as well as the particular attention paid to 'oxo-degradable' and ultralight bags.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I abstained today in the vote on the EFDD amendment on the recommendation for second reading on the Council's position at first reading with regard to the adoption of the European Parliament and Council Directive amending Directive 94/62/EC on reducing the consumption of light plastic carrier bags, because I consider the compromise proposal to be so good.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. In the EU, we consume 100 billion plastic bags every year. This is too much, because it takes centuries for them to be degraded by nature. I have therefore supported the directive on reducing the use of lightweight plastic carrier bags. It was important to me that the directive should allow the Member States to implement the requirements according to their individual situation. In accordance with the principle of subsidiarity, they now have two options: either impose a price on plastic bags by the end of 2018, or they cap the annual consumption of plastic bags at 90 bags per person by the end of 2019 and 40 by the end of 2025. In some countries, this figure is currently over 400. Although Germany is already on the right track with around 70 bags per person per year, Germany can also learn from best practices from Finland, Denmark or Luxembourg. There, bags are often reused or spent much less from the outset.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Over 8 billion plastic carrier bags are littered in the EU every year, causing significant harm to the environment, especially under the form of marine litter. Initiatives adopted by some member states, however, prove this problem has an easy and efficient solution: changing societies' mind-set on the use of plastic bags by putting a charge on their use. That's why I gave my support to the Bonafi report, which combines ample flexibility for member states with a call to make those who want to use plastic bags bear the price and the responsibility. Because we simply can't accept for plastic particles in our oceans to outnumber plankton.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. The average number of plastic bags that the European citizen throws away a year, often having used them only once, is around 180 bags. These bags end up in nature and at sea, leading to an environmental problem to which the legislation for which I vote in favour today is intended to put an end. It's not about avoiding its use, it's about rationalizing it. To do this, one measure that has been shown to be effective is to charge for their use, so that consumers have a greater incentive to reuse them. In any event, if States prefer not to apply this measure, they may apply others that they consider to be more appropriate, provided that they achieve the objective of reducing their use set out in the Directive.

name: Julie Girling (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The Conservatives favour proposals to reduce the consumption of plastic bags and their effect on the environment, particularly the blight of marine litter. However this proposal is not consistent with the principle of better regulation and many elements fall outside of the scope of the original Commission proposal. The Conservatives have set out to simplify EU regulation so that it becomes more practicable and straightforward for businesses to comply with. We wish to make reaching our dual goals of a green and business-friendly economy more achievable. We reject the mandatory nature of the final agreement and remain convinced that voluntary measures would be more effective.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (NI)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the amendment to reject the recommendation on reducing the consumption of light plastic bags. In practical terms, how can the proposed quotas be applied? Especially since quotas are only an improvement for a small number of countries. An EU-wide measure is therefore inadequate. Why not have taken back, through incentives, initiatives that are flourishing in Member States such as unwry shops or the sale of reusable bags? In France, this last measure has reduced the number of bags distributed by 93% in less than 10 years.  The cultivation of the plastic bag is that of disposable and biodegradable bags are also not a lasting solution, suggesting that one could now throw one's bags into the wild without consequence, which is not true.  While the problem of plastic bags is real and leads to dramatic pollution, the Commission's proposal is clearly not up to the challenge. A massive rejection would have forced her to review her copy and I regret that MEPs are satisfied with half measures.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted AGAINST the proposal since the Commission's position does not imply the necessary commitment to solve this serious environmental problem. Measures such as reducing the average annual consumption of non-biodegradable lightweight plastic bags to 90 per capita by the end of 2019 and 40 at the end of 2025, as well as not ensuring immediately but from 2018 that bags are not delivered free of charge to buyers, we understand that it responds to a lack of real commitment to the problem.

name: Γιώργος Γραμματικάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. Today's vote is an important first step in the fight against plastic pollution. In Greece billions of plastic bags are used every year at a cost of over EUR 300,000.  Thus, the plastic bag has become the symbol of a consumer society that destroys the environment and causes unnecessary death to a large number of birds and fish. It is the symbol of a society without environmental sensitivities that does not protect its natural wealth, that is, in the case of Greece, our heavy industry. It is a symbol that must soon become a thing of the past. The biggest victim of the plastic bag is the seas. Especially we Greeks who have been given the rare gift of a vast coastline and thousands of enchanting islands must adopt bold and pioneering policies. The policy I am proposing is to tax the use of plastic bags and to use the proceeds exclusively to protect the environment, in particular our coasts and seas.  Today's compromise at European level must be a first step. There are viable alternatives if we change attitudes. We must already envision a responsible society, a Greece and a Europe free of plastic bags.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on reducing the consumption of lightweight plastic bags. I believe that discarded plastic bags cause serious damage to the environment and harm biodiversity as marine litter. The problem can be easily and efficiently addressed as already proved in some Member States. Putting a charge on the use of plastic bags is a quick and sustainable way of reducing the problem.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. On Tuesday 2 April, I voted in favour of a report to limit the negative impact of plastic bags in Europe.  With an annual consumption of 200 bags per European citizen, there was an urgent need for action. We now have appropriate tools to limit the use of these bags and disseminate good environmental practices. Member States will now have the choice of setting progressive targets for reducing light bags (90 maximum per person per year by 31 December 2019 and 40 by the end of 2025) or making them pay by 31 December 2018. In 2017, the European Commission will have to propose labelling and marking measures for EU-wide recognition of biodegradable and compostable plastic bags.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Plastic bags are a big cross-border environmental problem. I voted in favour because I support the measures to tackle this problem. It will help to reduce the number of plastic bags used.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. The Spanish Socialists very positively value the adoption of this new Directive aimed at reducing the consumption of plastic bags, not only to combat the high incidence and persistence of this waste on the environment, but also because the text adopted with the Council is also a first and innovative step in understanding our production model. For the first time, the three European institutions have been able to promote a legal text entirely based on preventive criteria. In the case of plastic bags, our much-claimed strict application of the waste hierarchy is now a reality. Preventing waste is the first link in the circular economy model we believe in and which has to be our new industrial revolution. Given the wide disparity between Member States with regard to the consumption of plastic bags, measures such as the distinction of ultralight bags, the promotion of new alternative materials, labelling to identify certain types of bags and the recommendation on a price per unit at the point of sale will be, in addition to the binding objectives, essential steps to achieve the minimisation of the waste that the challenge of the circular economy imposes on us.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Today, 90% of plastic bags used for purchase in the EU are used only once before they become waste. This places an extremely heavy burden on the environment, with 8 billion plastic bags becoming waste in nature every year. The new European legislation approved is therefore intended to reduce excessive and sometimes unnecessary waste production. Hungary, thanks to the Environmental Product Fee Act introduced in 2011, is already meeting the 2025 targets of the newly approved Directive, with exemplary results in Europe.  As a member of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I was pleased to support the adoption of the new EU legislation, which, in addition to effectively reducing nylon waste, will also encourage the development of environmentally conscious customer habits; contributing to a cleaner, more livable European environment.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report as it encourages the reduction of the number of plastic bags in circulation throughout Europe. Plastic bags are harmful to the environment and to animals and marine life.

name: Anja Hazekamp (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. 'The abolition of the free bag reduces the amount of plastic waste that enters the environment. It is good that the European Parliament has today supported measures to reduce the use of so-called 'light plastic bags'. These are the free bags that are often provided at the checkout for single use. The Party for Animals has long called for the abolition of one-off carrier bags. Every year, some 100 billion plastic bags are used in Europe, of which some 8 billion end up in the environment and our seas. The plastic carrier bag has an average useful life of only 15 minutes. Carrier bag waste is a typical example of waste that can be prevented. By means of a price incentive, people are encouraged to use reusable bags. The proposal aims to reduce the use of plastic bags by 50 to 80% in the coming years. The remaining bags must also be made from more environmentally friendly and biodegradable materials.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Today, 90% of plastic bags used for purchase in the EU are used only once before they become waste. This places an extremely heavy burden on the environment, with 8 billion plastic bags becoming waste in nature every year. The new European legislation approved is therefore intended to reduce excessive and sometimes unnecessary waste production. Hungary, thanks to the Environmental Product Fee Act introduced in 2011, is already meeting the 2025 targets of the newly approved Directive, with exemplary results in Europe. As a member of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I was pleased to support the adoption of the new EU legislation, which, in addition to effectively reducing nylon waste, will also encourage the development of environmentally conscious customer habits, thereby contributing to a cleaner, more livable European environment.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted AGAINST the proposal since the Commission's position does not imply the necessary commitment to solve this serious environmental problem. Measures such as reducing the average annual consumption of non-biodegradable lightweight plastic bags to 90 per capita by the end of 2019 and 40 at the end of 2025, as well as not ensuring immediately but from 2018 that bags are not delivered free of charge to buyers, we understand that it responds to a lack of real commitment to the problem.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the Council's position at first reading in order to adopt a directive from the European Parliament and the Council amending Directive 94/62/EC to reduce the consumption of lightweight plastic bags, given the great contribution to reducing negative environmental impacts, especially in terms of discarding such waste into the environment.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. I decided to vote against this text because it is only a "cosmetic" legislative tool. Of course, we can welcome the desire to limit the use of plastic bags. But it is clear that the consequence of such a text is the increase in the use of vacuum overpacking, and therefore only displace the problem without reducing plastic consumption in the Union. The model of mass consumption as a whole should have been rethought and not just legislated on a consequence of it. Finally, this directive is symbolic of an "ultra-legislative" European Commission whose will is to govern all areas of public life, without respecting the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Margrete Auken's report on the consumption of plastic bags. The vote was on the validation of the agreement with the Council and the Commission on the amendment of a 1994 directive on plastic bags. The new legislation will require Member States to pay for light plastic bags by the end of 2018 and/or reduce consumption to 90 bags per capita by the end of 2019. By 2025, annual consumption will have to be a maximum of 40 bags per capita, up from 178 in 2010. The rapid implementation of this directive will help to combat the scourge of plastic bags that pollute our environment. I can therefore only welcome the very broad adoption of this report.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to reduce the consumption of lightweight plastic bags with handles. The text requires Member States to either reduce the number of lightweight plastic bags to 40 per person by 2025 or to make them pay from 2018.  I welcome the adoption of this report.

name: Jarosław Kalinowski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Due to the progressive degradation of the environment and the disruption of ecosystems, any action in the area of reducing these destructive processes is highly desirable. Therefore, the initiative to reduce the use of plastic bags is worthy of strong support.  Reducing waste production is what we can do ourselves as citizens who care about their future. Each of us, if we look around and analyze our daily habits, can in small steps contribute to better environmental protection, saving electricity or just reducing the consumption of disposable plastic bags. The introduction of supermarket charges for them is one of the most effective tools for reducing their production and consumption. Action must be carried out constantly so that civilization does not destroy our most precious treasure, nature. Monitoring of the strategy is needed, as well as environmental education from an early age. To destroy is very easy, but what is destroyed is not always easy to reproduce.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the directive to reduce the consumption of plastic bags at the European Parliament plenary session in Strasbourg. Statistics and facts are indisputable: plans for the consumption of plastic bags tend to increase and are reused by a very minimal proportion of the European Union's population. This inefficient farming results in a rapid increase in waste. This poses considerable environmental problems, as the decomposition of this material in nature takes many decades and irreversibly pollutes the environment. The Directive obliges Member States to take measures to reduce the consumption of plastic bags by half. It is up to the Member States to achieve this. I believe that this directive on reducing the consumption of light plastic bags is a necessary step in the area of protecting our environment, which will ensure a more sustainable and healthier ecosystem for the citizens of the European Union and reduce the waste of resources.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the recommendation for the second reading on reducing the consumption of lightweight plastic carrier bags. In 2010 on average every EU citizen used 198 plastic bags of which 90% were lightweight carrier bags. Each year roughly 100 billion plastic bags are being used by EU inhabitants.  The primary task in drastically reducing the usage of plastic bags, especially light weight carrier bags is to protect the environment. But it would also result in saving of oil which is used for the production of plastic. Completing the second reading will lead EU into the practical stage of implementation.  Personally I am in favour of the maximum goal to reduce the usage of plastic bags to maximum 40 per person per year by 2025.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The current EU-wide consumption of lightweight plastic bags is having a significant detrimental impact on our environment. This proposal seeks to reduce this unsustainable consumption from an EU average of 198 bags per capita to 90 in each Member State by 2020. This proposed change to the Packaging and Packaging Waste Directive will enable Member States to avail of a broader range of instruments, such as levies or marketing restrictions, to achieve this. Ireland’s plastic bag levy, introduced in 2002, has proven that these measures can have instant positive effect – plastic bag consumption in Ireland reduced immediately from 328 per capita to 21. The proven success of these measures means the targets set out in this proposal are very achievable and it therefore has my full support.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report. Discarded plastic bags cause serious damage to the environment, not to mention the harm being done by marine litter to biodiversity. Putting a charge on the use of plastic bags is a quick and sustainable way of reducing the problem.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 On 28 April 2015, the European Parliament voted on a directive amending Directive 94/62/EC as regards the reduction of the consumption of lightweight plastic shopping bags. I voted against the rejection of the November 2014 text, which was the result of long interinstitutional negotiations between the Council, the European Parliament and the Commission, because I consider it to be of good quality and to help protect the environment. If we reject the new arrangements, the overall situation would deteriorate further. Every year, billions of plastic bags end up as waste and are carried by oceans and seas, where they gradually break down into smaller and smaller particles and disrupt food chains. Today we are talking about the amount of plastic in the seas that would create an entire new continent. The text of the Directive wants to halve the consumption of these bags over three years and to a fifth within 10 years. One of the biggest advantages of the new treatment is that it does not necessarily require artificial interference with the price increase of these plastic bags. Member States will be able to choose between two options: either take measures to ensure that each citizen's average annual consumption of lightweight plastic bags is not more than 90 by 2019 and 40 by 2025, or ensure that these bags are not provided free of charge by traders by 2018.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Today, 90% of plastic bags used for purchase in the EU are used only once before they become waste. This places an extremely heavy burden on the environment, with 8 billion plastic bags becoming waste in nature every year. The new European legislation approved is therefore intended to reduce excessive and sometimes unnecessary waste production. Hungary, thanks to the Environmental Product Fee Act introduced in 2011, is already meeting the 2025 targets of the newly approved Directive, with exemplary results in Europe.  As a member of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I was pleased to support the adoption of the new EU legislation, which, in addition to effectively reducing nylon waste, will also encourage the development of environmentally conscious customer habits. This will contribute to a cleaner, more livable European environment.

name: Elisabeth Köstinger (PPE)
text: Writing. Eu Member States in November last year, against opposition from Commission Vice-President Frans Timmermans, clearly supported new rules to reduce plastic bags. I welcome this clear commitment to reducing plastic waste, and there is still a lot of catching up to do in some regions of Europe. Member States are free to choose how they want to achieve these targets – either from the end of 2018 they will no longer be allowed to hand over the bags free of charge, or they will have to reduce consumption by around 80 percent to 40 bags by 2025. This flexibility would also be desirable for other EU rules! Last but not least, the reduction of plastic bags is part of a much-needed package of measures to combat microplastic particles that end up in nature, food and the food chain when bags decompose in the wild. These particles can also enter our bodies, causing disturbances in the hormonal system. So we must finally get to grips with plastic waste! This compromise is the right step in this direction: I am therefore voting in favour of it.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Auken report to reduce the consumption of plastic bags in the European Union.  This report serves as the basis for the implementation of a directive that will set progressive targets for member states to reduce lightweight plastic bags (90 maximum per person per year by 31 December 2019 and 40 by the end of 2025) and encourage them to pay by 31 December 2018. By adopting this report and supporting the implementation of this directive, the European Parliament is once again encouraging the dissemination of good environmental practices within the European Union.

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Used plastic bags cause serious environmental damage. The Commission's proposal aims to significantly reduce the consumption of lightweight plastic carrier bags in the European Union. This problem can be easily and effectively solved, as has already been proven in many EU countries. The introduction of charges for plastic carrier bags is a quick and sustainable way to reduce their consumption. It is also important to set clear targets such as reducing the number of bags to 40 per person per year by 2025 and introducing mandatory bag charges from 31 December 2018. Until now, only targets have been set for the recycling of plastic bags, and the goal of preventing excessive use is a significant step forward.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. The Plenary will vote to ratify the agreement reached at second reading with the Council on the amendment of Directive 94/62/EC as regards the reduction of plastic bag consumption.  These new review measures will reduce the current consumption of plastic bags (176 per person per year according to 2010 data) to 90 units per person per year in 2019 and to 40 units per person per year in 2025. The agreement also draws a distinction between the different types of exchanges, for each of which provides for specific measures and different reduction targets.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The objective of this report is to help reduce the consumption of plastic bags with a thickness of less than 50 microns. Our position in the Group was in favour of the proposals introduced by Parliament, which allow greater control and definition of the measures necessary to reduce the environmental impact of plastic bag consumption. This report has no final vote, as it is a second reading within the three-way dialogue process.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I do not agree with the European Union ordering customers to wear their purchases. I have therefore proposed the rejection of this directive, which would put an end to its legislative process.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support this decision for both hands. The era of plastic bags has led to 89% of bags being used only once. It pollutes the environment and damages it for decades. The European Parliament made a good decision.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission's declaration on the adoption of an agreement amending Directive 94/62/EC as regards the reduction of the consumption of lightweight plastic bags is a qualitative shift in the introduction of rules on the consumption of these goods, which has negative environmental impacts. It is in the interests of all of us that the Member States of the European Union adopt clear and firm rules as soon as possible, which will lead to a reduction in plastic bags with a thickness of less than 0.05 mm, so that the measures taken take account of the economic and social situation in the country, while at the same time strengthening environmental protection.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 The recommendation for second reading on the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 94/62/EC with a view to reducing the consumption of thin plastic bags is a positive development since, in the view of the European Parliament, the final agreed text is based on the preferred option identified in the Commission's own impact assessment and after the appropriate provisions have been adopted for the Member States in order to achieve an effective reduction in the consumption of plastic bags throughout the Union.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this proposal. As result of the negotiations between Parliament and the Council, the Commission proposal has been significantly improved by laying down an obligation on Members States to achieve a sustained reduction in the consumption of lightweight plastic carrier bags. Importantly, for the first time in 40 years of European waste legislation, we will have binding measures at EU level to reduce waste generation.

name: Dominique Martin (NI)
text: In writing. This was a second reading, with no final vote. However Dominique Martin is against this draft report which is too limited. Even if it is indeed necessary to rethink our use of plastic bags this project, without a global vision, will apply to only a few types of packaging and will simply move the problem: to compensate for the absence of plastic bags in supermarkets we will develop vacuum overpacking which will not reduce our consumption of plastic.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am not in favour of the recommendation for second reading on the Council's position on the use of light plastic bags.  As stated by the European Parliament, in accordance with Article 30 of the Interinstitutional Agreement, it is up to the co-legislators to decide whether an impact assessment should be carried out before any substantive changes are adopted.  Although there is appreciation for the Commission's efforts, the criticism is that these issues have already been adequately addressed during the legislative procedure.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. The reduction in the use of plastic bags is a long-set target in the EU and which we must all meet. That is why I welcome this new legislation, where we will be able to move forward to avoid pollution caused by this cause. This proposal, to which I support it, also allows the States themselves to choose the option that best suits them to achieve the intended objective, because here the important thing is to end a practice that endangers our environment.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. As the Freedom Party of Austria, we are committed to comprehensive environmental protection. The Council's objective of reducing the high consumption of lightweight plastic carrier bags is in itself worthy of support.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report to reduce the use of lightweight plastic bags. In the EU billions of these bags end up directly in water bodies and aquatic ecosystems every year as untreated waste. Ireland leads the EU in this area of plastic bag reduction.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. In 2010, 95.5 billion plastic bags (1.42 Mt) were on the EU market, most of which (92%) single-use. Plastic bags accounted for 73% of the objects recovered by trawlers on the Tuscan coast during the summer of 2011.  The proposal aims to reduce the consumption of these bags. Following Parliament's recommendations at first reading, significant improvements were made to this report. Thus the text removes the existing ambiguity in the denominations "biodegradable" and "oxobiodegradable" by defining the labeling of bags. But this report does not address unnecessary packaging, which is the primary source of plastic waste. It also ignores the innovative processes for the production of algae-based plastic. And it is as always a question of charging consumers (not distributors) for the use of these plastic bags. Green capitalism is present as a deception. It is time to reorient the sector towards eco-design and recycling. I abstain.

name: Joëlle Mélin (NI)
text: In writing. This text is only a "cosmetic" legislative tool. Of course, we can welcome the desire to limit the use of plastic bags. But it is clear that the consequence of such a text is the increase in the use of vacuum overpacking, and therefore only displace the problem without reducing plastic consumption in the Union. The model of mass consumption as a whole should have been rethought and not just legislated on a consequence of it. Finally, this directive is symbolic of an "ultra-legislative" European Commission whose will is to govern all areas of public life, without respecting the principle of subsidiarity.  So I voted AGAINST.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I agree with the adoption of these measures. Plastic bags are the most polluting elements and their indiscriminate use only contributes to deteriorating the environment. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the measures to reduce the consumption of lightweight plastic carrier bags. The negotiations between Parliament and the Council have led to an obligation amongst Member States to reduce the consumption of the aforementioned bags. These binding measures would be the first pieces of legislation introduced at the EU level that will reduce waste generation.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. In Europe, the problem of plastic bags is serious. On average, a European uses up to 200 plastic bags per year, most of which are discarded after a single use. The European Parliament has launched a new fight to reduce this consumption and thus better protect the environment.  To do this, we have set two separate objectives. States will either have to reduce the average annual consumption of plastic bags to 90 light bags per capita by the end of 2019, or ensure that no more light plastic bags are delivered to customers free of charge by 2018.  By adopting this report, the European Union is reinforcing its promise to better protect the environment for the benefit of all.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The reckless treatment of consumers and businesses with plastic bags has serious negative environmental impacts due to the large quantities of waste and pollutants that penetrate the environment, including water.  Studies have shown that ordinary Europeans use around 200 plastic bags a year, almost 90% of which end up in waste after a single use. Such a course of action is unacceptable and it was therefore necessary to guide the action of economic operators not to waste and to give priority to greener substitutes. I consider it an important positive step by the EU that, for the first time in forty years of the history of European waste legislation, it has adopted binding measures at EU level to reduce waste generation. In particular, it is about imposing an obligation on Member States to achieve a permanent reduction in the consumption of lightweight plastic bags.  For these reasons, I voted in favour of adopting the European Parliament legislative resolution on plastic bags.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Discarded plastic bags cause serious damage to the environment, not to mention the harm being done by marine litter to biodiversity. The problem can be easily and efficiently addressed as already proved in some Member States. Putting a charge on the use of plastic bags is a quick and sustainable way of reducing the problem overnight. That is why I am in favour of this report.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union wants Member States to take measures to ensure that the level of annual consumption of plastic bags does not exceed, on average, 90 units per person by the end of 2019 and units per person by 2025. Alternatively, and by 2018, they may prohibit the free distribution of plastic bags or adopt measures that have the same objective. I am in favour of this report, which is understood as a measure of environmental preservation and of great importance for the rational consumption of plastic bags throughout the European Union. I would like to stress that I absolutely agree with President Juncker when he said that the European Union should focus on the major strategic activities in which it will make a difference and leave the small legislative provisions to the Member States.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. This vote concerns the reduction of the use of light plastic bags in the EU. The text requires Member States to either ban the free availability of plastic bags in stores before the end of 2018, or to introduce a ceiling on the average consumption of disputed bags per capita (90 bags per person per year by 2019, and 40 by 2025). States will also be required to establish adequate labelling that demonstrates the biodegradable nature of bags. In order to enforce these injunctions, states may, for example, use an arsenal of sanctions such as taxes.  If the intentions are laudable at first glance, the measures envisaged to reduce the ecological problem posed by the dumping of bags may lead to negative consequences by encouraging the production of expensive paper bags of water, or vacuum overpacking. It would then be a zero-sum game that would only move the problem without reducing the production of plastic.  This text is emblematic of the legislative inflation that the European Union is suffering from. Finally, it is indicative of an attitude denying the sovereignty of the Member States. So I abstained.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Discarded plastic bags cause serious damage to the environment and harm biodiversity as marine litter. The problem can be easily and efficiently addressed, as already proven in some Member States. Putting a charge on the use of plastic bags is a quick and sustainable way of reducing the problem overnight.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to reduce the consumption of plastic bags in the European Union. Each European citizen consumes an average of 200 plastic bags per year. 8 billion bags end up in the Environment of the European Union where they can last for many years. With this text, Member States can either set progressive targets for reducing plastic bags (90 maximum per person per year before 31 December 2019 and 40 by the end of 2025), or make them pay by 31 December 2018.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We cannot fail to welcome this change, following the negotiations between Parliament and the Council, which significantly improved the Commission's original proposal by making it compulsory for Member States to ensure a sustained reduction in the consumption of light plastic bags.  For the first time in forty years of European waste legislation, binding measures will be envisaged at EU level to reduce waste production. In order to assess the effectiveness of the reduction measures, we have also called for the introduction of new monitoring measures which require Member States to submit an annual report on the annual consumption of light plastic bags.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal amends Directive 94/62/EC, requiring Member States to take measures to reduce the consumption of light plastic bags.  In particular, the text provides for Member States to choose between two obligations: to take measures to ensure that the annual level of consumption does not exceed, on average, 90 light plastic bags per person by the end of 2019 and no more than 40 light plastic bags per person by 2025 or, alternatively, ensure that plastic bags are no longer supplied free of charge at points of sale of goods or products by the end of 2018, unless other instruments of equal effectiveness are implemented.   In the light of the above, I supported the report because I believe that it is the right way to prevent the production of waste and thus mitigate its overall environmental impact, promoting a more efficient use of resources.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider this report to be crucial. At last, we may be able to stop the crazy pollution caused by the spread of plastic bags. From 2019, these free-to-hand plastic pests will finally disappear, poisoning not only our land, but also our minds. Ironically, these bags were "invented" for single use, yet after people throw them away after a few minutes of use, they stay on us for hundreds of years. I trust that with the disappearance of the bags, our irresponsible wasteful human attitude, which has been brought about, will disappear, which only means the comfort of today. This is a negative example of influencing consumer habits. I believe that with positive examples and ideas, we can control half the attention of environmental awareness.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission's objective of this directive is to 'limit the negative effects on the environment, in particular with regard to waste production, to encourage waste prevention and more efficient use of resources, while limiting negative socio-economic effects. More specifically, the proposal aims to reduce the consumption of plastic carrier bags of less than 50 microns (0.05 millimetres) in the European Union.' I voted for this report because it respects the objectives of the European Commission's proposal, which is badly needed to improve environmental conditions and the quality of life of citizens.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: i scríbhinn. ‒ Chaith mé vóta i bhfabhar na tuarascála seo. Níl málaí plaisteacha in-bhithmhillte agus glacann sé 400 go 1 000 bliain chun iad a scriosadh sa timpeallacht. Tá sé measta go mbaintear úsáid as 1 mhilliún mála plaisteach gach nóiméad ar fud an domhain. Ní haon ionadh é mar sin go bhfuil tionchar damáisteach ag dramhaíl phlaisteach ar aigéin an domhain. Ní thagann meathlú iomlán ar phlaisteach, briseann sé síos i bpíosaí beaga. Téann 120 000 tona de phlaisteach isteach sna haigéin gach bliain agus tá sé thar a bheith scanrúil le smaoineamh go bhfuil seans mór ann mar sin go bhfuil plaisteach ionghafa ag na héisc a ithimid.  In Éirinn, sa tuaisceart agus sa deisceart, tá sé soiléir go raibh tionchar maith ag na táillí ar na málaí plaisteacha. Ba í Éire an chéad tír a chuir an tobhach seo i bhfeidhm agus faoi láthair tá costas de 22 cent ar gach mála. Thit líon na ndaoine a úsáideann málaí plaisteacha ó 328 gach bliain go 21 agus tá sé sin i bhfad níos lú ná an sprioc de 90 atá sa tuarascáil seo.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ This report is in truth long overdue. I voted in favour because I believe all our voters are tired of seeing trash dumps and landfills full of plastic bags. These items have become ubiquitous in our lives and it is unfortunate. We should actively promote people to reuse bags, to use recyclable and biodegradable materials and to make an effort, over a small immediate personal comfort, for the protection of our environment. I believe any costs associated with this text would be far outweighed by the costs of cleaning and processing the massive amounts of plastic bags in usage today.

name: Péter Niedermüller (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The primary objective of the proposal is to mitigate the environmental damage caused by plastic bags and to encourage the spread of responsible waste management. In my view, the proposed proposal is necessary to achieve these objectives and can therefore be supported.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. In principle, I welcome the 'reduction in the use of lightweight plastic carrier bags'. Nevertheless, I must stress that taxation and quotas are not a real barrier and do not prevent consumers from using plastic carrier bags. In the long term, we must move away from non-reusable plastic bags. A switch to biodegradable plastic carrier bags must be targeted. We must invest in research, and consumers and industrial suppliers must be held accountable. That is why I abstained.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the draft, which requires EU Member States to reduce the use of the most widespread plastic bags that are most widely polluting the environment. Reducing the use of plastic bags is one of the easiest ways to change their habits slightly, making it possible for everyone to contribute to cleaner nature. Often, a plastic bag is used only once, after which it is thrown away as debris. In the wild, this plastic bag will be preserved for hundreds of years, as a burden on the environment. Changing habits often requires a reason, and there can be a price.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 Plastic bags are one of the most important sources of pollution of modern society and the marine ecosystem. Estimates show that the consumption of plastic bags tends to increase further. In 2010 alone, more than eight billion plastic bags were turned into rubbish in the EU. After forty years of European waste legislation, existing legislation marks the beginning, at European Union level, of binding measures to reduce waste production. Specific measures referred to in the resolution ensure a significant reduction in annual levels of plastic bag consumption and strict monitoring of Member States on the implementation of legislation. On the basis of the new European regulation, I believe that an integrated strategy to deal with the consequences of uncontrolled use of plastic bags is being developed immediately and effectively, both in the environment and in the marine habitat. For the above reasons, I voted in favour of the European Parliament's report on restricting the use of plastic bags.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI)
text: Writing. – Reducing consumption of small plastic bags concerns a minimum percentage of environmental pollution from plastic waste, but the EU directive neither wants nor can touch and cope with, since prevention in their management does not serve the interests of monopolies at the moment. Once again in the name of environmental protection, the EU is seeking to impose new engravings on the popular family, since the measure to reduce consumption it provides is the payment for small bags to be collected directly from the monopolies managed by supermarkets. At the same time, it opens the way to new areas of profitability for monopolistic groups that manufacture so-called "biodegradable and compostable" bags, which it excludes from reduction targets. EU policy exacerbates all popular problems because it addresses them on the sole criterion of the profitability of monopolistic groups.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that "oxo-degradable" plastic material is used specifically for the production of plastic bags, it is absolutely appropriate to ensure legally binding monitoring measures in the context of an amendment to the Packaging Directive with regard to plastic bags, rather than postponing the issue to the uncertain follow-up of the Commission's Green Paper on plastic waste. For these reasons, I voted against.

name: Florian Philippot (NI)
text: In writing. This text introduces various restrictions on the use of plastic bags. First, the reduction in the level of consumption for 31/12/2019 to 90 plastic bags per person per year; secondly, the obligation for Member States to make the reduction effective from 36 months after the legislation comes into force; the obligation for the Commission to assess the impact of the various possibilities of reducing plastic bags to a very light lightness (less than 15 microns thick), and to present a proposal for a directive if necessary; and the Commission's obligation to establish the details of the biodegradable or renewable nature of plastic bags.  The consumption of plastic bags is a habit of mass consumption to rethink. However, the Commission's policy is not satisfactory. These are provisions that apply to a small sample of packaging, without a global vision, but with the binding paraphernalia that European nations do not have to accept. Moreover, removing plastic bags from supermarkets will logically develop vacuum overpacking, and thus move the problem, without reducing our consumption of plastic. Political effectiveness and ecological relevance are questionable. It is also an emblematic text of an "ultra-legislative" European Commission, without respect for the principle of subsidiarity. I therefore vote against this text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒Over 8 million plastic bags are discarded in the European Union every year, most of which end up in the sea, causing the accumulation of plastic bags in the environment to have a very negative impact on some branches of the economy such as tourism. In addition, while recyclable, current recycling rates are very low. As a result, the new Plastic Bag Regulation is a welcome step towards reducing the negative impact on the environment.  The charging of plastic bags is one of the solutions, as the available data on the use of plastic bags in the Union have clearly shown that consumption is low or reduced in those Member States where economic operators do not hand out plastic bags without charge but sell them for a small amount. In particular, I welcome the flexibility provision for implementing the proposed measures, which clearly set the objectives, but the path to their achievement depends on the Member States. In Croatia, the plastic bag production sector employs almost two thousand citizens and I am glad that with the new compromise their jobs will be able to be preserved.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I strongly support the proposal to combat the unnecessary use of plastic bags by 50% by 2019 with a view to further reduction of hard-to-degrade bags. Just as all bio retail chains have been offering only paper or cloth bags for years, in the same way it is possible to reduce the sale of plastic bags, the same way to put an end to the negative habits of buying them.  Paper bags are degradable within a year, and canvases, in addition to being degradable, can also be used for years, which contributes to the reduction of waste and environmental protection, i.e. supports sustainable development and contributes to the change of collective consciousness.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposal now includes an obligation on Member States to achieve a permanent reduction in the consumption of lightweight plastic shopping bags. I am glad that the European Parliament has gone further in this regard than the commission's original proposal. I am convinced that the proposal will not have the impact of excessive demands on EU citizens, but will adequately insipulate them to protect natural resources. EU member states must now ensure that by 2019 the annual consumption of lightweight plastic shopping bags does not exceed 90 ks/person (and 40 bags/person by the end of 2025). I also consider it essential to call on the Commission to put forward proposals for the labelling of biodegradable and compostable plastic bags as quickly as possible. The absence of uniform labelling so far means that products with different levels of degradability are issued as biodegradable or compostable (some products may even cause more harm than good to nature in the decomposition process, especially so-called oxo-biological bags), thus the concept of biodegradable loses content and does not guarantee the consumer that he is indeed doing good for nature conservation. The regulation adopted by Parliament does not concern so-called very light plastic bags (e.g. plastic bags used in the purchase of fruit), which are necessary for hygiene reasons as well as for protection against waste. In the future, however, we will have to look for meaningful and realistic solutions to deal with this problem as well.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am delighted that the resolution on reducing the use of lightweight plastic bags was adopted by a very large majority. This introduces an obligation for Member States to ensure a reduction in the consumption of light plastic bags and will also include binding measures in the EU to reduce waste production.  I hope that all this will lead to greater public awareness of sustainable consumption by reducing waste and with positive environmental results.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I see the obligation on Member States to achieve a permanent reduction in the consumption of lightweight plastic bags as an obligation for each of us to work towards reducing the burden on the environment and trying to prevent further unnecessary pollution. For the first time in 40 years of European waste legislation, we will have binding measures at EU level to reduce waste generation. It's high time.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. The increasing accumulation of waste is a growing problem with the storage and destruction of waste. Within the framework of the EU's climate targets, and a healthier environment and sustainable growth, the EU is trying to limit the production of certain waste. In 2010, the European average was 170 bags per capita.  The European Parliament voted on Tuesday on a proposal to amend Directive 94/62/EC on packaging and packaging waste to reduce the consumption of lightweight plastic bags with handles. I have spoken in favour of this text, which will really limit the production of this type of waste. By 2025, annual consumption should not exceed 40 bags per capita. This text will require states to take appropriate measures to achieve this goal.

name: Laurențiu Rebega (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 All studies carried out by European and world institutes over the last 30 years, unanimously recognized in the global work to reduce the widespread use of plastic, show that the environment is irretrievably poisoned by the indiscriminate use of this material. In this context, I welcome today's vote in the plenary of the European Parliament in favour of new legislative proposals aimed at limiting plastic bags, considered to be the most used packaging, but also the most polluting ones, within the European Union. Legislative changes on the use of plastic bags are in line with all sustainable development programmes adopted at both European level and by the governments of the Member States of the European Union.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. Every year, eight billion plastic bags end up as waste in the European Union environment, including in the seas, where plastic is often absorbed by animals (94% of birds in the North Sea have it in their stomachs). Faced with this invasion of plastic bags that pollute our environment, the European Union had to react. This afternoon's vote endorses the compromise reached between the European Parliament and the Council for a reduction of lightweight plastic bags. In practice, Member States will have to choose between two approaches: reducing the number of lightweight plastic bags used per person (no more than 40 bags by 2025); - or stop giving away bags for free at food outlets by the end of 2018. On the surface, this solution is reasonable given the gap in Europe: 4 bags used per year per consumer in Finland and Denmark, compared to 400 in Poland and Portugal. But this solution is not sustainable and the Member States which are lading behind, and which have forced this compromise downwards compared to the Commission's original proposal, must achieve better results.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
