text: In writing. I voted against the amendment rejecting the recommendation on reducing the consumption of single-use light plastic bags in the Member States. As a result of negotiations in trilogue, I consider this agreement to be balanced: while being firm on the European targets for reducing the use of light plastic bags distributed in supermarkets, it leaves it to the Member States to choose the binding means to be put in place to achieve them.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. The reduction in the consumption of lightweight plastic bags is relevant in that it limits negative impacts on the environment. The proposal presented aims to reduce the consumption of plastic bags with a thickness of less than 0.05mm in the European Union. However, it is a proposal that should be considered when implementing it in order to have a gradual transition to implementation in civil society.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. The Spanish Socialists very positively value the adoption of this new Directive aimed at reducing the consumption of plastic bags, not only to combat the high incidence and persistence of this waste on the environment, but also because the text adopted with the Council is also a first and innovative step in understanding our production model. For the first time, the three European institutions have been able to promote a legal text entirely based on preventive criteria. In the case of plastic bags, our much-claimed strict application of the waste hierarchy is now a reality. Preventing waste is the first link in the circular economy model we believe in and which has to be our new industrial revolution. Given the wide disparity between Member States with regard to the consumption of plastic bags, measures such as the distinction of ultralight bags, the promotion of new alternative materials, labelling to identify certain types of bags and the recommendation on a price per unit at the point of sale will be, in addition to the binding objectives, essential steps to achieve the minimisation of the waste that the challenge of the circular economy imposes on us.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. In 2010, each EU citizen used the equivalent of 198 plastic bags per year. This consumption should only increase... Since 2010, more than 8 billion plastic bags in the EU have become waste. Light plastic bags, thinner than 50 microns - the vast majority of bags used in the EU - are less reusable than thicker models and become waste faster. They are also more likely to seriously pollute the environment and aquatic ecosystems. I therefore welcome the vote of this report, which aims to drastically reduce the use of the most frequently used and most polluting plastic bags. EU Member States will be able to choose either to take steps to reduce the average annual consumption of non-biodegradable plastic bags to 90 light bags per capita by the end of 2019 and 40 by the end of 2025, or to ensure that by the end of 2018 no more lightweight plastic bags are given to customers free of charge. In addition, the European Commission will have to assess the environmental impact of oxobiodegradable plastics and propose appropriate measures to deal with this phenomenon.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported this proposal. It is essential that the Directive contains a provision that measures to reduce plastic bags should be such as not to increase the total quantity of packaging. It is not entirely clear whether this norm will be implemented. What will happen if, for example, dairy producers start using thicker packaging because bags have disappeared in supermarkets? Another obvious lack of regulation is the 50 micron thickness limit. After all, manufacturers will very easily be able to produce a 51 micron thick bag that can be used without restrictions. It is also very important that the shortage of plastic bags in the market does not become an incentive for people to shop only in supermarkets. If we take any market where the total number of packages is significantly lower than in supermarkets, but lightweight plastic bags are the main form of packaging of goods on the market and their availability facilitates the needs of the buyer and seller. Thus, the need for such a packaging tool will not disappear, so it is worth legitimising the alternative now so that the EU's use of plastic bags will be replaced by fully biodegradable bags made, for example, from maize starch.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report which obliges the European Union to reduce the use of the most common and polluting plastic bags. While today's annual consumption is 200 plastic bags per European citizen, Member States will have to set progressive targets so that the consumption of plastic bags does not exceed an average of 90 bags per person per year by 2019, and then 40 in 2025.  In parallel to these measures, it will be forbidden to distribute free plastic bags to customers by 2018.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Finally we should have succeeded in drastically reducing the number of light plastic "bags" that are often not reused and represent a huge environmental cost, because they are difficult to destroy and because they cause serious damage to the environment. Small daily gestures would be enough to have great benefits.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. I have chosen to vote against the proposal for a reject because I support the text agreed at second reading between the Council and Parliament in order to avoid the danger of endangering the biodegradable bag sector, where the Italian chemical industry is at the forefront, combining the requirements of environmental protection and public health.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted AGAINST the proposal since the Commission's position does not imply the necessary commitment to solve this serious environmental problem. Measures such as reducing the average annual consumption of non-biodegradable lightweight plastic bags to 90 per capita by the end of 2019 and 40 at the end of 2025, as well as not ensuring immediately but from 2018 that bags are not delivered free of charge to buyers, we understand that it responds to a lack of real commitment to the problem.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the resulting compromise between the European Parliament and the Council, which sets out binding measures to reduce waste in the case of plastic bags at EU level. In doing so, Member States may decide for themselves how to limit the consumption of lightweight plastic bags and to implement measures to do so. Waste prevention is more important than addressing environmental impacts. I therefore welcome the agreement and thank the rapporteur for the work done.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The objective of this report is to help reduce the consumption of plastic bags with a thickness of less than 50 microns. Our position in the Group was in favour of the proposals introduced by Parliament, which allow greater control and definition of the measures necessary to reduce the environmental impact of plastic bag consumption. This report has no final vote, as it is a second reading within the three-way dialogue process.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am proud that my country was the first in Europe to adopt legislation to reduce the per capita consumption of light plastic bags. I would like to point out, in fact, that in Italy, since 2011, the law prohibiting the sale of non-biodegradable plastic bags has been in force.  It seems to me that the agreement reached between Parliament and the Council allows for fair room for manoeuvre for Member States that will be able to take different measures depending on the environmental impact, compostability and expected use of plastic bags. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote in favour of the measure.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. The consumption and disposal of lightweight plastic bags is a serious environmental problem, and a problem which, according to EU surveys, is at the top of the list of europeanenvironmental concerns. I believe that this challenge is a good example of the benefits of coordination and legislation at European level. I fully support the objectives of this legislation, namely to limit the impacts of waste production on the environment, as well as to prevent and reduce waste production. At the same time, I think it is important that the potential socio-economic negative effects of this legislation be minimised. I believe that the text agreed between the European Parliament and the Council is in line with these objectives, while promoting the most efficient way of achieving them. Finally, we have binding measures in the EU to slow down waste production. I am operanding the amendment put to the vote because I believe that the common text that best responds to the need to reduce the consumption of light plastic bags in Europe has been achieved.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today we voted in support of the proposal on reducing the consumption of lightweight plastic carrier bags. The S&D Group believes that discarded plastic bags cause serious damage to the environment and harm biodiversity as marine litter. The problem can be easily and efficiently addressed as already proved in some Member States. Putting a charge on the use of plastic bags is a quick and sustainable way of reducing the problem.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the amendment on the Council's position with a view to adopting a directive on reducing the consumption of lightweight plastic bags, because I am strongly in favour of reducing the consumption of plastic bags. Today, we can say that the amount of such waste would create one new continent in its area. As citizens, we need to rethink our shopping habits in order to preserve the cleanliness of the ecosystem.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I strongly support the adopted directive, which aims to reduce the consumption of lightweight plastic bags. They have long-term environmental and biodiversity damage, given the fact that in the European Union over 8 billion plastic bags end up as waste every year in the European Union. Given their small mass, resistance and properties that make them commercially attractive plastic bags are put off everywhere in nature.  On average, every EU citizen uses 198 plastic bags a year and only 10 per cent are repeatedly used. Following the directive, Member States will have the option to choose: either to take action and ensure that the average consumption of light bags does not exceed 90 per capita until 2019 and 40 by the end of 2025 or to ensure by the end of 2018 that manufacturers do not hand out bags like this free of charge. The negative consequences of this directive are often mentioned in Croatia, because it is precisely with the production of bags that about 1 800 jobs are related and 87 companies are engaged in their production. I see hemp as a solution to this problem because if its cultivation were legalized, it would employ a lot more people than the production of plastic bags, but it would also create new jobs in agriculture.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. – Plastic waste is a major environmental problem in every single Member State. Waste sorting and separation is insufficient and, if it is, plastic waste is not recycled but incinerated, which again has a negative impact on the environment. Plastic bags such as packaging are very easy to replace with another packaging material that will be used for a long time and will not be a burden on nature. I am aware that many workers are employed in the production of the 100 billion plastics a year that we consume in the EU and lose their jobs. Therefore, the resolution also envisages a gradual reduction in the production and consumption of plastic bags. Member States have two choices: they can take measures to ensure that the annual consumption rate does not exceed an average of 90 lightweight plastic bags per person by the end of 2019 and no more than 40 lightweight plastic bags per person by 2025, or to ensure that by the end of 2018 plastic bags are no longer provided at the point of sale of goods free of charge.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. The new rules oblige Member States to take measures to help drastically reduce the consumption of single-use plastic bags. Plastic bags are a great thing for consumers, with the average European citizen consuming 175 single-use bags a year. The numbers are horrific! If 90 per cent of bags are actually used only once, it means that the waste is only accumulating and is actually bathed in plastic. Each country can do the most by raising awareness and persuading them of the harmful effects of plastics on the environment. A good example is, for example, Ireland, which has reduced the use of bags by 94% by paying for bags, and Italy, which has already banned the use of single-use bags. The bag pay measure is already in place in many countries and needs to be introduced everywhere, from big supermarkets to small shops. The new rules will drastically reduce the use of plastic bags, as they foresee a reduction in consumption to 40 bags per capita by 2025, and represent a historic breakthrough in tackling plastic waste in our environment and reducing waste in general, which is why I supported the proposal for a directive.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of introducing new rules to reduce the consumption of light plastic bags in the EU. Under the new legislation, Member States will be able to decide between two options: deciding whether to limit average per capita consumption to 90 bags by the end of 2019 and, subsequently, to 40 bags by 2025; or, establish a bag price system. These rules are favorable for Italy, which had banned light bags in 2011, paving the way for the use of biodegradable bags, thus becoming a leader in the sector. This is an important measure, answerable to 92% of EU citizens who consider it necessary to reduce the consumption of plastic bags (source: Eurobarometer). These have a devastating impact on the environment: it is estimated that 8 million bags are thrown into the EU every year, ending up in rivers, lakes and seas, where they cause long-term pollution due to the polluting particles they release into the water, seriously altering ecosystems. Since this pollution also endangers the safety of the food chain, it is a threat to human health.

name: Bart Staes (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. The plastic soup in the oceans must be reduced. This is the central objective of the agreement to drastically reduce the use of disposable plastic bags. This is an environmental victory over the blind deregulation drive of the European Commission. The numbers don't lie. In 2010, 88 billion single-use plastic bags were seized, which is 200 bags per EU citizen per year. A large part of this ends up in the water. More than 70% of litter in our European seas is plastic. This plastic soup is then made up of 70% plastic bags. This is a disaster for millions of sea creatures that die as a result of the plastic in their stomachs. This agreement will reduce the presence of plastic in the oceans. It also shows how green politicians, such as rapporteur Margrete Auken, really weigh up the burden on our environment through European legislation. Ms Auken ensured that binding targets were proposed. Member States can now choose between two methods. Either they reduce the use of disposable bags by half by 2019 and by 80% by 2025, or they will end the free distribution of plastic bags by 2018.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The most effective way to protect the environment is economic instruments. 90% of plastic bags are used once, which has an adverse impact on the environment. Slovakia also needs to reduce the consumption of these disposable bags, as consumption in slovakia is 466 units per person per year compared to, for example, Denmark, where it is only 4 pieces. Environmental protection can thus also be guaranteed by reducing the consumption of disposable goods, which require a long recycling period.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for this directive, which encourages the reduction of negative environmental impacts, especially in terms of waste rejection into the environment, encourages waste prevention and more efficient use of resources, while limiting negative social and economic impacts.  The directive aims to reduce the consumption of plastic bags that are thinner than 50 microns (0.05 millimetres) in the European Union, 90% of which are thrown away after first use due to irresponsible consumer habits, and 8 billion bags are converted into waste each year.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Discarded plastic bags cause serious damage to the environment, therefore I voted against the EFDD proposal to reject the Council’s position on reducing the consumption of lightweight plastic carrier bags. Steps have already been taken in the UK to introduce charging for plastic bags and it is important that similar action be taken across the Member States.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. - An interinstitutional agreement on this topic has been reached, approved by both the Council and the European Commission. Apart from the ECR, everyone supported the deal and it's about raising awareness about environmental protection. It will require a reduction in the use of commonly used plastic bags, which are also the largest polluters.  Throwing plastic bags into the environment causes pollution and exacerbates the problem of waste in seas, oceans and rivers by endangering aquatic ecological systems around the world. This regulation will require states to choose between two options. The first is to take action and ensure that the average consumption of lightweight bags does not exceed 90 pieces per capita until 2019 and 40 pieces by 2025 or to ensure by 2018 that sellers do not hand out bags like this for free.  Plastic bags thinner than 50 microns, which make up the vast majority of the total number of plastic bags used in the Union, are less suitable for reuse than thicker plastic bags, making them waste faster and more often discarded into the environment.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ I supported the recommendation on the Council position at first reading with a view to adopting a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending the Directive to reduce the consumption of lightweight plastic carrier bags. Every year, citizens of the European Union use 100 billion plastic carrier bags. Of these, 8 billion remain in nature or waste. Plastic bags are the source of many environmental problems. They have a particularly negative impact on the oceans. I also support the directive because it wants to offer Member States a tool to reduce the amount of such waste. We are talking about a significant reduction in plastic bags. If we can achieve this, then we will take a big step forward.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I consider the European Parliament's legislative resolution to be an example of an acceptable compromise reached between the institutions. I believe that the environment is one of those areas which, by logic, is to be of EU interest. All Member States can then influence, for example, the amount of plastic waste in the seas, which is certainly of interest not only to the citizens of the seaside Member States, but to the citizens of all Member States insidiously.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The new legislation on the use of plastic bags, which includes strict measures to limit it, is an important measure to reduce waste, especially plastics, which will help to reduce environmental pollution. However, we must take seriously the consequences of the implementation of the new legislation at social and economic level. Under no circumstances should we and will we consent to the cost being moved to the consumer as a measure to limit the use of bags. Next, it is important to point out that the measure of limiting the use of plastic bags alone is not enough to achieve the quality of life we want. For us it is clear that this measure must be part of an integrated strategy for waste management and environmental protection.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. Although the report is a step in the right direction, we note that this alone is not enough. Our aim is to completely ban the use of such plastic carrier bags.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the second reading of the draft recommendation, as I consider it of the utmost importance to minimise the use of so-called plastic bags in the European Union. As we all know, it takes five seconds to produce these sachets, while their total decomposition takes 500 years. The recycling level of these pouches is almost zero, and most of this is buried mainly in waste bins in rural areas. In 2010, it was estimated that more than eight billion plastic bags ended up in the rubbish, so I believe that this legislation is good for everyone, as it is a huge environmental problem. The agreed recommendation is that Member States should limit the annual use of lightweight plastic bags to 90 pieces per person by the end of 2019 and 40 by the end of 2025, or guarantee that customers will not be able to receive such plastic bags for free after 2018. It is precisely for these reasons that I supported the second reading of the recommendation, as it requires Member States to radically reduce the use of plastic bags, while providing a transitional period.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 In order for environmental action to produce the expected results, its implementation must be practically possible. The idea of drastic allying the consumption of lightweight plastic carrier bags is the right one. However, I believe that it would be even more important to support research into new technologies for the production of environmentally neutral packaging. Otherwise, consumer societies, while agreeing to bear higher costs, will not significantly reduce the amount of plastic consumed. Therefore, although I voted in favour of the proposed packaging and packaging waste directive, I am calling for research into new packaging technologies to be supported, on the one hand, and more innovative and, in particular, more efficient ways of recycling plastic packaging. At the same time, the use of paper cannot be promoted, which is often done. This increases, for example, the need for tree felling. In my opinion, measures to reduce plastic consumption and promote other packaging should be carried out in parallel, otherwise we will not have the globally desired effect on the environment.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the agreement concluded with the Council on the adoption of the Directive amending the Directive of 94/62/EC as regards reducing the use of light plastic bags.  The proposal introduces important, though improveable, binding elements for Member States to reduce the consumption of plastic bags, such as the imposition of certain levels of annual consumption or the payment of plastic bags at points of sale.  Among the various measures included in the proposal that I welcome positively, but which certainly solves only part of the problem, is the labelling of 'oxo-biodegradable' plastic bags. Oxo-biodegradable bags, contrary to the name suggests, are not a solution to the problem of environmental pollution by microplastics, but rather aggravate it because they contain an additive that causes plastic to fragment into microparticles. The labelling of bags would give clear indications of the components of biodegradable bags and thus give all citizens the opportunity to consciously choose those truly biodegradable and compostable plastic bags.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. When we know that every European uses 176 sachets a year, with little or no reuse, this gives an idea of the magnitude of the environmental consequences. Member States will be forced to reduce the consumption of these fine bags by at least 50% by 2019 and by 80% by 2025. In other words, the citizen who now uses 176 bags a year will consume 90 bags in 2019 and only 40 in 2025. States can use an arsenal of tools to achieve these goals and will need to conduct awareness campaigns. It should be noted, for example, that states that have made single-use plastic bags mandatory have performed very well. Fine plastic bags are a real environmental calamity. They are among the most collected waste by volunteers who clean coastlines around the world and defile our planet almost irreversibly. This legislation is a great step towards greater respect for our planet and for generations to come.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the agreement reached on the plastic bags legislation which aims to reduce by half, by 2019, and at least 80% by 2025, the use of disposable lightweight plastic bags, which is a major source of pollution. This legislation, if properly implemented could solve a major environmental problem. Under the text agreed, Member States will be able to choose between charging for these bags by 2018 or reducing average annual consumption to 90 per citizen by the end of 2019. The Member States will report back on the annual consumption of these plastic bags three years after the directive enters into force.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D)
text: In writing. I campaigned and voted in favour of the report on the drastic reduction of the use of plastic bags. While blue growth is our future, we must protect biodiversity and natural environments to ensure their sustainability. Today the environment is threatened by the incalculable amount of waste that will impact it for centuries to come. This problem is an example of the multitude of telluric pollutions that harm biodiversity and of which we are too little aware. It is therefore a great step forward to regulate the use of plastic bags The European Commission is called upon to assess the impact of plastic waste on the environment. It will need to maintain a sustained pace of reducing the consumption of plastic bags by 2025. Member countries will have to intervene to prevent plastic bags from being made in 2018. While the most polluting bags will be subject to taxes, labelling, or marketing bans, all oxobiodegradable plastic materials will be gradually replaced by biodegradable packaging. I note that the FN voted against certain aspects of the text, again demonstrating its retrograde vision

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ The adverse consequences of climate change, which are partly the result of poor waste management, cannot be escaped today. Therefore, I believe that continuous efforts are needed to achieve consistency in law enforcement and to address effective waste management. Thus, in terms of the manufacture and use of plastic bags, the best medium-sized solution should be found, which will actually put legislative regulation into practice.  The agreement reached in November 2014 outlines the long-term reduction targets for annual bag consumption by 2019 and 2025 respectively, ultimately indicating the correct treatment of plastic bags. However, I consider that the provisions and unrealistic deadlines provided for their adoption and the absence of relevant country-specific statistics calls into question the principle of subsidiarity, but also the possibility of implementing these measures in individual Member States.  Attention should primarily be focused on the methods of proper management and sorting of waste, not the creation of an additional administrative burden for states, and as a result I voted abstaining.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted AGAINST the proposal since the Commission's position does not imply the necessary commitment to solve this serious environmental problem. Measures such as reducing the average annual consumption of non-biodegradable lightweight plastic bags to 90 per capita by the end of 2019 and 40 at the end of 2025, as well as not ensuring immediately but from 2018 that bags are not delivered free of charge to buyers, we understand that it responds to a lack of real commitment to the problem.

name: Evžen Tošenovský (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 On the one hand, it is good that Member States will have a choice of which route to limit plastic bags they choose. On the other hand, this directive provides an administratively quite complex system and I have some doubts about the meaningfulness of this regulation. For this reason, I abstained.

name: Giovanni Toti (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Legislation adopted today will force Member States to take new measures to reduce the average annual consumption of plastic bags to 90 light bags per citizen by 2019 and to 40 by 2025. This decision not only preserves the environment in which we live, but also saves EUR 740 million a year.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the approval of this report, as it settles clear targets for Europe in order to achieve more sustainable practices regarding the use of plastic carrier bags. I hope that in the coming years the ideas today supported will be correctly applied in all Member States in order to protect our environment.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (NI)
text: In writing. The consumption of plastic bags is a habit of mass consumption to rethink. However, the Commission's policy is not satisfactory. These are first of all provisions that apply to a small sample of packaging, without a global vision, but with the binding paraphernalia that European nations do not have to accept. Moreover, removing plastic bags from supermarkets will logically develop vacuum overpacking, and thus move the problem, without reducing our consumption of plastic. Political effectiveness and ecological relevance are questionable. It is also an emblematic text of an "ultra-legislative" European Commission, regardless of the principle of subsidiarity. I vote FOR the rejection of the Council's position.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I completely agree to have legislation to reduce the consumption of lightweight plastic carrier bags, as the statistics show over 8 billion plastic carrier bags are littered in the EU every year. More than 90% of the European citizens support to have measures to reduce the usage. The new legislation will oblige member states to adopt measures ensuring that the annual consumption level does not exceed and ensuring that they are not given these plastic bags for free at stores and sales points by the end of 2017.

name: Владимир Уручев (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the final agreement reached at second reading to amend the Directive restricting the use of plastic bags with a wall thickness of less than 0.05mm, because I hope it will put an end to their excessive waste and unregulated discharge within the European Union. The fact is that plastic carrier bags are among the most environmentally polluting substances and pose a significant problem, especially for our aquatic ecosystem. Estimates show that more than 8 billion bags turn into waste every year.  The new legal measure, which has been significantly improved in all aspects compared to the commission's original proposal, obliges Member States to ensure one of two conditions: that by 2019. the average annual consumption will not exceed 90 thin plastic bags per capita or, alternatively, to suspend their free supply on the shop network by 2018. I believe that such measures have the potential to limit the negative environmental impact of plastic bags and will lead to their more efficient and sustainable use. However, in order to be successfully implemented, it is necessary to ensure their public acceptance, which is related to raising citizens' awareness of the motives and nature of the changes approved today, as well as promoting the use of biodegradable and compostable envelopes.

name: Inese Vaidere (PPE)
text: Writing. – European Union citizens use 200 000 plastic bags every minute, which is the most common and environmentally damaging type of plastic. For the most part, we use one bag only for a couple of minutes, but in the environment they are stored for hundreds of years and pose a serious threat to fish and birds. The most environmentally harmful are single-use plastic products, as 8 billion of such bags are wasted annually, with negative impact on the ecosystem. In Latvia, an increase in the tax rate on thin plastic bags was already set in 2008, reducing their consumption by 40 % over half a year. However, one Resident of Latvia still uses an average of 466 plastic bags per year, and their consumption is decreasing relatively slowly.  The proposal for a directive obliges countries to gradually reduce the consumption of plastic bags, so that it does not exceed 90 bags in 2019 and 40 bags per in-population in 2025. In order to achieve the set targets, all EU countries will have to ensure by 2018 that this type of plastic bags are no longer available free of charge to customers. I believe that stricter rules are needed to reduce the consumption of lightweight plastic bags, which is why I support the directive and voted against the amendment tabled.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Europeans throw away a huge amount of almost unused plastic bags; according to statistics, an average European citizen wastes 200 plastic bags annually. I voted in favour of this report because it sets new binding targets to decrease the use of plastic bags in the EU by 80% by 2025. According to the new rules, Member States will now have two options: to either reduce per-capita plastic bag use to 90 bags by 2019 and 40 bags by 2025, or to impose charges for all plastic bags by the end of 2018. These decisions are of significant global importance, since most of the hardly-used plastic bags end up polluting ocean waters worldwide. Respecting the environment by introducing such measures is urgent if we want to ensure that future generations of Europeans will enjoy a life without dramatic climatological phenomena taking place.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D)
text: in writing. The Spanish Socialists very positively value the adoption of this new Directive aimed at reducing the consumption of plastic bags, not only to combat the high incidence and persistence of this waste on the environment, but also because the text adopted with the Council is also a first and innovative step in understanding our production model. For the first time, the three European institutions have been able to promote a legal text entirely based on preventive criteria. In the case of plastic bags, our much-claimed strict application of the waste hierarchy is now a reality. Preventing waste is the first link in the circular economy model we believe in and which has to be our new industrial revolution. Given the wide disparity between Member States with regard to the consumption of plastic bags, measures such as the distinction of ultralight bags, the promotion of new alternative materials, labelling to identify certain types of bags and the recommendation on a price per unit at the point of sale will be, in addition to the binding objectives, essential steps to achieve the minimisation of the waste that the challenge of the circular economy imposes on us.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: in writing. I decided not to support the proposed amendment because it was necessary to close a very difficult decision-making process. The elements included by Parliament and the Council in the Commission's proposal have led to a text which, although it can be improved, is probably the best that could be achieved, not least in the light of the Commission's uncooperative attitude on this dossier. I believe that it is extremely important to ensure a sustained reduction in the consumption of plastic shoppers, including by introducing specific provisions on monitoring, which make it compulsory for Member States to submit an annual report on their consumption.  Finally, for the first time in forty years of European waste legislation, binding measures will be put in place at EU level to reduce its production, a measure that I can only support.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The objective of this report is to help reduce the consumption of plastic bags with a thickness of less than 50 microns. Our position in the Group was in favour of the proposals introduced by Parliament, which allow greater control and definition of the measures necessary to reduce the environmental impact of plastic bag consumption. This report has no final vote, as it is a second reading within the three-way dialogue process.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'Some 8 billion plastic bags end up in the EU environment every year. The European Parliament and I have voted in favour of a compromise that would allow member states to choose between two options: either reduce the number of plastic bags to a maximum of 40 per person per year by 2025, or by 2018, it will be prohibited to give free bags in food-selling shops. Belgium has already made a lot of efforts in this area in recent years and is therefore one of the better learners. But it could be even better to see that Finland and Denmark consume only 4 bags per person per year.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted AGAINST the proposal since the Commission's position does not imply the necessary commitment to solve this serious environmental problem. Measures such as reducing the average annual consumption of non-biodegradable lightweight plastic bags to 90 per capita by the end of 2019 and 40 at the end of 2025, as well as not ensuring immediately but from 2018 that bags are not delivered free of charge to buyers, we understand that it responds to a lack of real commitment to the problem.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, which is the formal adoption of that agreement, i.e. accepting the Council's common position without modification, in order to significantly reduce the use of plastic bags.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The directive at issue is not more than the direct application of the polluter pays principle - a view which we do not follow - and the Council's position worsens, whereas as an alternative to the obligation to adopt measures to ensure that the level of annual consumption of plastic bags does not exceed on average 90 bags/person by 2019 and 40 bags/person by 2025, it intends to impose it as mandatory for Member States by the end of 2018, imposing that free light plastic bags are not made available at points of sale.  Furthermore, the Council's position proposes a mandatory annual declaration of the consumption of plastic bags by Member States in order to assess the effectiveness of the measures taken, the mandatory identification of biodegradable bags and for composting. As for the designation of "oxo-degradable" proposed mainly by plastic bag producers, the Council proposes to carry out further environmental impact studies on these products.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. As the Freedom Party of Austria, we are committed to comprehensive environmental protection. The Council's objective of reducing the high consumption of lightweight plastic carrier bags is in itself worthy of support.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour because I believe that it is Europe's responsibility, including as an institution, to send out a signal for respect for and protection of the environment. The exploitation of plastic, a very polluting chemical process, can no longer be carried out indiscriminately and without limits. Limiting the spread of plastic bags (often used only once as waste containers, moreover, greatly increasing the cost of disposal processes) is a clear message, first cultural, and then political, to try to make the continent more sustainable.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. The European Parliament voted this Tuesday to reduce plastic waste in the EU. By 2019, the average annual consumption of thin plastic bags per person is to be reduced from the current level of around 200 to 90, and by 2025 to 40 bags per year per citizen. I voted against. It is true that the Union generously leaves the way for the Member States to achieve this objective. However, if the goal is not correct, each path is the wrong one. Of course, I can see the aim of reducing pollution from plastic. Only the incorrect disposal of plastic bags causes environmental problems. Some people throw plastic bags into rivers and other waters, polluting the environment, but others do not. However, charges apply equally to all people, not just polluters. So all citizens are punished, even though few are wrong. I do not think that is a fair approach. A more proportionate solution would be to consistently penalise infringements of environmental legislation.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – I welcome the fact that, after lengthy negotiations between the European Parliament and the Council, the Commission has improved its proposal on reducing the consumption of thin plastic bags by including an obligation for the Member States. As such, I voted on the Recommendation on the Council's position at first reading with a view to adopting a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 94/62/EC as regards the reduction of the consumption of thin plastic carrier bags.  In practice, in terms of waste legislation, we will have for the first time binding measures across the EU on waste generation and management. I believe that Romania is directly interested in introducing binding measures at EU level that have positive effects in our waste management system.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 It is estimated that around 98.6 billion plastic bags were placed on the EU market in 2010. Most of them are lightweight plastic bags, the use of which is usually disposable. Although I support reducing the use of lightweight plastic bags and introducing, for example, charges for their use, I abstained from voting because the proposed rules are too restrictive.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP legislative resolution amending Directive 94/62/EC with a view to reducing the consumption of thin plastic carrier bags. Thin plastic bags make up the vast majority of plastic bags used in the EU. This is a huge environmental problem, as billions of plastic bags end up as untreated waste, destroying our natural environment. Under the new European directive, EU Member States will have two options: either take steps to ensure that average annual consumption is gradually reduced, or, alternatively, to ensure that, from the end of 2018, these bags are not given to shoppers free of charge.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Today we approved the request to EU Member States to reduce the use of plastic bags.   Under the new rules, Member States will have to drastically reduce the use of 'disposable' plastic, which is less than 0.05 millimetres thick, which is the vast majority of plastic bags used in the EU. From now on we will have to halve consumption compared to 2010, already by the end of 2019, and we will not be able to use more than 90 "light" bags each, and then fall to 40 by the end of 2025.  Alternatively, EU countries will have to ensure by 2018 that consumers pay in order to use ultra-light plastic bags. This is a huge environmental problem, as billions of plastic bags disperse into the environment and seriously pollute waterways and aquatic ecosystems. I am therefore pleased that the recommendation has been adopted.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI)
text: Writing. – Reducing consumption of small plastic bags concerns a minimum percentage of environmental pollution from plastic waste, but the EU directive neither wants nor can touch and cope with, since prevention in their management does not serve the interests of monopolies at the moment. Once again in the name of environmental protection, the EU is seeking to impose new engravings on the popular family, since the measure to reduce consumption it provides is the payment for small bags to be collected directly from the monopolies managed by supermarkets. At the same time, it opens the way to new areas of profitability for monopolistic groups that manufacture so-called "biodegradable and compostable" bags, which it excludes from reduction targets. EU policy exacerbates all popular problems because it addresses them on the sole criterion of the profitability of monopolistic groups.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am clearly in favour of the initiative to reduce the consumption of lightweight plastic shopping bags. Current consumption, in my view, has exceeded the limits of tolerability and has a very negative socio-economic impact. I therefore fully support the application of price increases in combination with restrictions on the sale of plastic shopping bags. It is important for me to achieve positive environmental results in order to raise awareness of sustainable consumption by the public.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 Although I do not overregulation, I supported the proposal setting specific targets aimed at reducing the consumption of plastic bags. Hundreds of billions of plastic bags are consumed annually in Europe and their overuse has a disastrous impact on the environment. Slovakia is one of the EU Member States with the highest consumption, and unlike other EU countries, there is currently no legislation in place to solve this problem. In order to be successful in practice, Slovakia must ensure the simplest possible implementation of new measures and communicate intensively not only with traders, but also with plastic bag manufacturers. However, the most important thing will be to gradually change people's minds so that they stop using plastic bags one time and think more about recycling and the environment.

name: Kosma Złotowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Care for the environment is important, but there are limits to the interference of public institutions in the area of economic freedom. Imposing restrictions on the consumption of plastic carrier bags per person is an extreme solution, although of course justified. Definitely a more important and effective way to change customers' habits is to educate and run information campaigns to discourage the unlimited use of plastic shopping bags. Such a solution would be more rational. As history teaches us, racking up a system of orders and prohibitions does not always have the desired effect, and often, instead of encouraging society to act environmentally, it provokes the opposite reaction. Imposing an obligation on Member States to reduce the consumption of lightweight plastic carrier bags will also hit their manufacturers. While it is difficult to assess all the negative effects of these regulations on the labour market and the economies of the Member States, they cannot be underestimated. Therefore, in view of all the above arguments, I have decided to abstain.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is in this report recommended that the Council's position be accepted after negotiations with Parliament. This directive is not more than the direct application of the polluter pays principle, a view which we do not follow - and the Council's position worsens, since as an alternative to the obligation to adopt measures to ensure that the level of annual consumption of plastic bags does not exceed on average 90 bags/person by 2019 and 40 bags/person by 2025, it intends to impose it as mandatory for Member States by the end of 2018, imposing that free light plastic bags are not made available at points of sale. Research and development of solutions to prevent the damage associated with plastic bags should be encouraged, replacing them in their various uses, contributing to and promoting awareness-raising and environmental awareness campaigns, encouraging the change of packaging or means of transport of goods marketed by the various sectors.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, this is a good proposal and one where the EU is leading the field. Our goal is an international agreement to ensure a level playing field for all. Four per cent of all greenhouse gases come from the maritime sector, and as world trade grows, that percentage will rise. The maritime sector is the only area not covered by agreements or regulations in regard to CO2 reductions. Therefore it is time to act. We need a supranational framework: that is our aim. But we must make a start, and this is the start, where all vessels entering European ports will have to monitor the verified amounts of CO2 emitted by their large ships on voyages to, from and between the EU ports. They will also have to report the amounts. Other information will also be required, for example data to determine the ship’s energy efficiency. It is also important that this proposal can be implemented without major costs being involved.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, tá áthas orm gur glacadh leis an moladh seo agus go ndéanfaimid rud éigin faoi astaíochtaí CO2 atá ag teacht ón tionscal iompair mhuirí. Is fiú é sin a dhéanamh anois mar, mar a dúradh ar maidin agus bhí seans agam labhairt sa díospóireacht, tá 4% de na hastaíochtaí CO2 ag teacht ó longa agus mar sin de agus is fiú rud éigin a dhéanamh faoi.  Go háirithe amach anseo, beimid in ann monatóireacht a dhéanamh ar na longa a thagann isteach i gcalafoirt na hEorpa agus ina dhiaidh sin is dócha gur féidir linn comhbheartas éigin idirnáisiúnta a dhéanamh agus chabhródh sé sin leis an bhfadhb seo a réiteach ní hamháin san Eoraip ach trasna an domhain uile. Dá bhrí sin, arís, is coiscéim chun cinn é seo agus taispeánann sé gur féidir leis an bParlaimint agus an Eoraip obair ar son na saoránach.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 Carbon dioxide emissions from maritime transport contribute to air pollution and climate change and their reduction is part of the EU's overall strategy in this sector. While our group's position to extend reduction plans to smaller tonnage ships and other greenhouse gases was not taken into account in its entirety, we consider that the three-way dialogue process has brought improvements in the monitoring and penalization of carbon dioxide emissions. As a result, parliamentary approval of the report contributes to the urgent fight against climate change.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. Marine shipping is the only form of transport in which the EU has not yet adopted greenhouse gas reduction regulations. This proposal for a directive provides for the creation of a system for monitoring emissions and for reporting and auditing. Negotiations are currently underway within the IMO (International Maritime Organisation) to implement a global MRV system (measurement, reporting and verification). Such a system is now being introduced throughout Europe within the framework of this Directive; as soon as an international agreement is concluded, the Directive will be re-examined and, where appropriate, adapted. I welcome the new directive, especially as maritime shipping contributes at least 6% to the Union-wide propellant pollution.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. This text proposes measures that appear to be irrelevant and ineffective in relation to environmental concerns within a complex system.  Moreover, it is a strengthening of European regulations and the control requirements imposed on Member States by the European Union. An agreement between Member States would be more relevant and successful while allowing respect for national sovereignty. The Commission cannot afford to circumvent the absence of an agreement between states by supranational regulation.  Finally, this text does not address the intensification of free trade in international trade, which is a major cause of carbon dioxide pollution.  So I voted against it.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to establish a framework for monitoring, reporting and verifying carbon dioxide emissions from maritime transport. The projected increase in CO2 emissions from EU ships is not in line with EU targets and will have a negative impact on climate change. At EU level, international maritime transport remains the only mode of transport not covered by the EU's commitment to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. The exact CO2 emissions from EU-related maritime transport are not yet known due to insufficient monitoring and reporting requirements for these emissions. I therefore agree with the need for a reliable system for monitoring, reporting and verifying greenhouse gas emissions from maritime transport.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. In the end, this text was not put to a vote. If it had been, I would have voted against it because it is again a question of imposing a supranational standard with questionable effectiveness.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The EU has pledged to reduce CO2 emissions by 20% by 2020 from 1990 levels. The Commission estimates that shipping was responsible for the emission of 180 Mt of CO2 in 2010 and these are expected to increase. This is out of step with the reduction targets that the Union has set for itself. It is therefore essential to be able to reduce CO2 emissions from shipping. However, at this time, the precise emission of greenhouse gases produced by shipping is not known. Therefore, before considering a gradual reduction in greenhouse gas emissions through shipping, it is necessary to put in place a system of monitoring, reporting and verification (MRV) of greenhouse gas emissions by ships. This MRV system represents the first phase of a program to reduce CO2 emissions from shipping. It is therefore in the interest of combating global warming and protecting the environment that I voted in favour. I believe that this monitoring system is necessary to improve information and encourage the reduction of emissions and fuel consumption.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. This report proposes to adopt the Council's position on monitoring, reporting and verification of carbon dioxide emissions from the shipping sector amending the 2009/16/EC Directive. The Commission's aim is to fill the legal void in international law regarding the lack of regulation on greenhouse gas emissions in maritime transport under IMO. Unfortunately, the Union is in complete contradiction with this report, since, on the one hand, it encourages savage globalisation and open borders, in order, on the other hand, to complain about the pollution which is the consequence of this policy. I therefore voted against this text, which is neither effective nor fair, since it denies national sovereignty.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report to ratify the agreement reached with the Council at second reading on the new Regulation laying down the basis for monitoring, reporting and verifying carbon dioxide emissions from maritime transport. This Regulation is of great importance, as it is the first step in enging greenhouse gas emissions from maritime traffic in the future and setting targets for reducing them.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it supported the Commission's proposal to establish a framework for monitoring, reporting and verifying carbon dioxide emissions from maritime transport. December 2010 The parties to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) have recognised that global warming must not exceed the temperature of more than 2°C before the industrial revolution. As early as 2010, the EU institutions agreed that all sectors of the economy, including maritime transport, which are expected to increase their emissions, should contribute to emission reductions. The main reason for the increase in emissions is considered to be the increase in demand for maritime transport as global trade increases.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this measure, which aims to reduce greenhouse gas emissions in the maritime transport sector as well. What is expected is a monitoring, reporting and verification system, with the aim of increasing information on the efficiency and emissions of ships, thereby encouraging the reduction of consumption and therefore of emissions. In transport, the maritime sector is the only one in Europe today that is not affected by Community measures to reduce CO2 emissions. The text we approve today is a first step that takes into account the fact that the sector accounts for 4% of total EU emissions, given that it is estimated to increase by around 50% by 2030. This legislation applies to vessels over 5 000 tonnes passing through European ports, irrespective of their country of registration, and which will also have to be taken into account in future negotiations by the International Maritime Organisation. This is a positive sign that reinforces the message that the transition to a more sustainable European system must necessarily affect each sector concerned.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Maritime transport is the only form of transport not involved in the European Union's efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.  At union level, the maritime sector today emits about 3% of all greenhouse gases and this figure is expected to grow as the economy grows further. A unified system of monitoring, reporting and verification of greenhouse gases by naval vessels should be established in order to have accurate and usable data on their environmental and energy efficiency. This is one of the preconditions for reducing greenhouse gas emissions in seafaring and reducing fuel consumption.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (NI)
text: In writing. International shipping is the only means of transport that is not apprehended by the European policy on reducing greenhouse gases. It is questionable whether the European Commission's action on this issue, which proposes only monitoring and verification of CO2 emissions, is effective for large vessels using European ports. I voted against this text because the approach adopted is reprehensible. Indeed, I cannot accept the questioning of national sovereignty by this intrusion of the European Union and the regulatory complexity it encourages for a literary impact that proves to be limited.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. The European Parliament's proposed regulation concerns the monitoring, reporting and verification of carbon dioxide emissions from the shipping sector. In the absence of an international agreement setting targets for reducing carbon emissions, the Commission is seeking to circumvent the need for a regulatory bypass to impose monitoring and control of carbon emissions on Member States. This supranational drift will have a reduced environmental impact on air pollution. It is a global challenge to the savage globalization that must be undertaken if we are to reduce carbon dioxide emissions in the shipping sector. That is why I voted against this text.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the measure. I have always expressed a strongly critical view of climate policy, of which this measure is a part. In this case, I fear that this will result in unnecessary red tape.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on carbon dioxide emissions from the shipping sector. These regulations will monitor the carbon dioxide emissions of ships. Fishing vessels and vessels under 5,000 tonnes are exempt from this regulation. For the latter, the administrative burden would have been too great and would have had negative consequences. We need to reduce our greenhouse gas emissions. The European Union must be a world leader in this area. However, we need a balanced regulation that allows us to achieve this objective while taking into account the specificities of certain industries such as fishing.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This report was concerned with emissions from the maritime transport sector which contribute to both air pollution and climate change. It has not been possible to calculate the precise amount of CO2 and other GHG emissions of EU-related maritime transport due to the lack of monitoring and reporting of such emissions. The Commission proposed an integrated measurement, reporting and verification (MRV) system covering emissions of air pollutants and GHG with the aim of providing improved information on the co-benefits and trade-offs on related policies in Europe. In this regard, my Group, GUE/NGL, tabled several amendments in order to develop more details on the MRV data and to include not only CO2 emissions in the MRV system but to also extend the monitoring system to other emissions that are of concern in the main EU harbour cities. This key provision was included in the report. It was for these reasons that I voted in favour of this report.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The main objective of the proposed regulation is to establish an EU-wide system for monitoring, reporting and verification (MRV) of greenhouse gas emissions from shipping, in order to improve the information about ship efficiency and emissions and to encourage reducing emissions and fuel consumption, as a first step towards a global MRV system. The MRV requirements will apply to CO2 emissions arising from voyages between EU ports. All ships over 5 000 gross tons will be covered, with some exceptions, like fishing vessels. International maritime shipping remains the only means of transportation not included in the Union’s action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. I voted in favour of this proposed legislation.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal sets new EU rules to collect data on engine emissions and efficiency from boats for incremental improvements, requiring shipowners using EU ports to monitor and report CO2 emissions each year from January 2018. This is a first step towards reducing greenhouse gas emissions for large ships.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this report, which is another attempt by the Commission to override the sovereignty of Member States. Indeed, the Eurocrats in Brussels are seeking to replace an international standard for setting emission reduction targets from the international maritime sector. Defining such a standard would indeed be the role of the International Maritime Organization, i.e. the member states of that organisation who would decide sovereignly what measures to put in place. In addition to this attack on the sovereignty of States, the measures defined by the directive will run up against the reality of savage globalization, which itself guarantees pollution that no simple control or surveillance measure will allow to contain.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal introduces a system for monitoring, reporting and verifying greenhouse gas emissions from maritime transport.  In order to reduce carbon dioxide emissions from maritime transport, it has been proposed to create a system for monitoring, reporting and verifying (MRV) CO2 emissions based on the fuel consumption of ships, as a first step in a step-by-step approach to including maritime transport emissions in EU policies for the reduction of greenhouse gases. The introduction of an MRV system allows a reduction of emissions of up to 2% compared to the status quo and a reduction in total net costs of up to 1.2 billion euros by 2030. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote in favour of this regulation.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal for a regulation because I believe it is appropriate to establish a system for monitoring and controlling CO2 emissions in the maritime transport sector, as a first step towards a global monitoring system. International maritime transport remained, in fact, the only mode of transport that was not part of the European Union's commitment to reducing greenhouse gas emissions, despite the fact that emissions from the maritime transport sector make an important contribution to both air pollution and climate change. I believe that this resolution is the basis on which Europe may or rather must develop emission reduction policies for the maritime sector consistent with global policies on climate, air pollution and the protection of human health.  Finally, I believe that the development of ambitious policies with regard to reducing emissions in this sector is even more important in the light of the challenges facing the maritime sector in the coming years. In the future, world trade is expected to grow significantly due to the expected increase in population and it is therefore urgently necessary to develop technologies and practices to be applied for fuel quality, emission reduction technologies and operational measures for ships.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. The maritime transport sector plays a crucial role in the European economy and is responsible for much of the international freight transport between the EU and the rest of the world, and intra-Community freight transport. The regulation of emissions from maritime transport has been identified as a necessity in the context of air quality and climate policy-making at both European and intercontinental level. I support The Report by Mr José Inácio Faria because it establishes, at European Union level, a system for monitoring, reporting and verifying (VMs) of greenhouse gas emissions from the maritime sector, which will make it possible to develop policies to reduce emissions associated with the sector in harmony with general policies on climate, air pollution and the protection of human health.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the regulation to create a system for monitoring, recording and assessing carbon dioxide emissions from maritime transport.  The introduction of the new mechanism is of primary importance, especially in view of the fact that maritime transport remains the only transport activity not yet included in the European plan to reduce pollutant emissions.  Improving the quantity and quality of information available on pollution caused by shipping will not only provide a clearer picture of the condition of the seas, but is expected to stimulate the reduction of emissions and the consumption of hydrocarbons. I also welcome the provisions contained in this regulation, which have the effect of minimising administrative and bureaucratic practices against companies, making the information collected accessible and reusable for other purposes, as well as the introduction of the obligation for all categories of vessels to report the indication of energy efficiency.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ At EU level maritime shipping is the only means of transportation not included in the European Union’s action to reduce greenhouse emissions. This sector accounts for 4% of greenhouse gas emissions and these are expected to increase in the future. The objective of the proposed regulation is to introduce a system for monitoring, reporting and verification (MRV) of carbon dioxide emissions from maritime transport as a first step towards a global MRV system.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I agree with the proposal committing shipowners using EU ports to monitor and report CO2 emissions every year from January 2018, although the rules will only apply to vessels over 5 000 tonnes gross tonnage. I believe that this is a first step towards reducing greenhouse gas emissions for these large ships.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 Carbon dioxide emissions from maritime transport contribute to air pollution and climate change and their reduction is part of the EU's overall strategy in this sector. While our group's position to extend reduction plans to smaller tonnage ships and other greenhouse gases was not taken into account in its entirety, we consider that the three-way dialogue process has brought improvements in the monitoring and penalization of carbon dioxide emissions. As a result, parliamentary approval of the report contributes to the urgent fight against climate change.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in agreement with the EU MRV system for CO2 emissions from the maritime transport industry. This is a system which can hopefully encourage emission and fuel consumption reduction. Having said that, I believe that this is just one step towards having a global agreement through the International Maritime Organisation, since maritime transport is an international industry. It is only through a global agreement that we can start addressing reduction in maritime transport emissions.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. The purpose of this report is to establish a system for managing, reporting and verifying the reduction of carbon emissions emitted in the context of shipping. The European Union, through this text, wishes to set an example with a view to eventually imposing a comprehensive system within the International Maritime Organisation (IMO). This is a balanced report as it limits the scope of the legislation to carbon dioxide only and excludes small vessels, which, although they represent 40% of the European maritime sector, contribute only 10% to carbon emissions. Finally, the report refuses to set up a travel report for ships making several stops per day. Considering that this legislation is in line with the international rules of the IMO and goes even further while respecting the principle of proportionality and avoiding imposing an excessive administrative burden on the sector, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. The adoption of this text will enable effective monitoring and control of carbon dioxide emissions from the shipping sector.  We must deliver on our commitments to the energy-climate 2020 package, and this text represents a concrete step in that direction. Moreover, it will have a wide impact, as it will be applied to all ships arriving or departing from a European port.  That is why I supported this report.

name: Philippe De Backer (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the opinion by the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (ENVI) as shipping is an important means of transport and, although an environmentally friendly way, it is also a large and growing source of greenhouse gas emissions. The Commission has proposed that owners of large ships using EU ports should report their verified emission from 2018 onwards. I believe this is a good first step towards cutting emissions and reaching our Europe 2020 Strategy and the Kyoto commitment period (2013-2020). With this ENVI proposal I am convinced that the European Union leads by example to major emerging economies. The European Union shows that economic growth and emission cuts can go hand in hand.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported this proposal for a recommendation requiring all shipowners using EU ports to monitor and report CO2 emissions produced each year. This rule, which will enter into force from 2018, will apply to all vessels over 5 000 tonnes, regardless of the country in which they are registered. International maritime transport remains the only type of sector not yet included in Community measures to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. The adoption of this measure is a first step in this direction.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on carbon dioxide emissions from the shipping sector.  First of all, this text proposes measures that appear to be irrelevant and ineffective in relation to environmental concerns, within a complex system.   It is also a step up to European regulations and the control requirements imposed on Member States by the European Union. An agreement between Member States would be more relevant and successful while allowing respect for national sovereignty. The Commission cannot afford to circumvent the absence of an agreement between states by supranational regulation.  Finally, this text does not address the intensification of free trade in international trade, which is a major cause of carbon dioxide pollution.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour because I am in favour of any attempt to limit carbon dioxide emissions. Of course, there are still many steps that need to be taken until the desired results are achieved.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. Parliament approved the Council's position at first reading because it was in accordance with the agreement reached in the trialogue. I support the second reading of this proposal, which introduces a system for monitoring, reporting and verifying greenhouse gas emissions from maritime transport. The system is designed to collect data on engine emissions and efficiency and encourage further efforts to reduce emissions and fuel consumption.  This is therefore a first step towards reducing greenhouse gas emissions for ships by more than 5 000 tonnes gross tonnage, while excluding warships and fishing boats from monitoring.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. International shipping is the only means of transport that is still not included in the EU's greenhouse gas reduction commitment. Emissions from this sector currently account for 4% of emissions at EU level. This Regulation introduces a System at European level for monitoring, reporting and verification (MRV system) of CO2 emissions from maritime transport. The aim is to increase transparency on ship emissions and create an incentive for their reduction. From 1 January 2018, shipowners will have to monitor and report CO2 emissions from vessels with gross tome swells of more than 5000 GT, representing around 55% of vessels climbing EU ports and around 90 % of associated emissions. The new rules apply to CO2 emissions from travel to, to and between European ports. In order to minimise the administrative burden borne by shipowners and operators, the communication and publication of the information should be made annually.

name: Edouard Ferrand (NI)
text: In writing. From the moment that only the Member State, of course, can take sanctions, it seems normal for the legislation to return exclusively to their hands. That is why I refuse to vote on a text which provides for giving more powers to the Commission without proposing effective solutions to the problem.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Parliament adopted, at first reading, the proposal for the introduction of a system for monitoring, declaration and verification of CO2 emissions from maritime transport. After all the interinstitutional discussion procedures between Parliament and the Council, this report focuses on the Council's position at first reading.  The Council's position is in line with the discussed and negotiated with Parliament on the EU's objectives of reducing greenhouse gas emissions, and the Transport White Paper which requires policies to do so, given the sector's dependence on the use of fossil fuels and its emissions also contribute to air pollution and climate change.  We see as a positive monitoring, communication and verification system that serves as a purpose to provide better information not only on the amount of greenhouse gases (GHG) emitted by this sector, but also on obtaining concrete data to enable concrete policies to be developed to deal with the problem of GHG emissions, which is why we voted favourably. In the plenary debate, we have moved on with some concerns and ideas to be taken into account in the future.

name: Raffaele Fitto (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that the Council's position at first reading is in line with the agreement reached in the trialogue, confirming the text voted in the ENVI Committee by a very large majority, I am voting in favour.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Following the difficult course of the trilogue, the European Parliament, together with the Council and the Commission, has finalised a proposal that optimises the reduction of carbon dioxide emissions in maritime transport. Maritime transport is one of the most important sectors of the economy and employment in the European Union, and it is essential that the European Parliament, even in this important industrial sector, takes note of compliance with environmental rules.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal would like to introduce a system for monitoring, reporting and verifying greenhouse gas emissions from maritime transport. We believe that, given the measures of the past, this too will result, despite reassurances, in unnecessary bureaucratic burdens.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the recommendation for second reading, the reporting and verification of carbon dioxide emissions from maritime transport and the amendment of Directive 2009/16/EU, because I am in favour of any attempt to limit carbon dioxide emissions. Of course, there are even more steps that need to be taken until the desired results are achieved.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Maritime shipping remains the only means of transportation which is not included in the European Union’s action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. At EU level, the international maritime sector today accounts for around 3% of global greenhouse gas emissions and these are expected to increase significantly in the future. The main objective of this regulation is to establish a European monitoring, reporting and verification (MRV) system for CO2 emissions from ships as the first step in a staged approach to reducing these emissions. In order to reduce the related administrative costs while ensuring robust results, simple and lean MRV requirements are proposed. An EU-wide system for the MRV of greenhouse gas emissions from shipping is necessary in order to improve the information about ship efficiency and emissions from the sector, and encourage reducing emissions and fuel consumption.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this proposal which establishes a system for monitoring, reporting and verifying carbon dioxide emissions from maritime transport, one more step in the necessary fight against climate change.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing.
