I congratulate my colleagues in the ENVI Committee, and in particular José Inácio Faria, rapporteur for the draft resolution on the Council's position at first reading with a view to adopting a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the monitoring, communication and verification of carbon dioxide emissions from maritime transport and amending Directive 2009/16/EC, for its rapid and prompt approval and adoption.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the recommendation for second reading on the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of the regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the monitoring of carbon dioxide emissions from maritime transport, the reporting on and the examination of these emissions and the amendment of Directive 2009/16/EC, because I consider this draft to be good and balanced.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Faria report, because the establishment of a European Monitoring, Reporting and Verification (MRV) system of greenhouse gas emissions from shipping is a crucial - and long overdue - measure to improve the information about ship efficiency and emissions from the sector, and encourage reducing emissions and fuel consumption.

name: Julie Girling (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ Climate change and pollution are not restricted to international borders so the Conservatives recognise that an EU-wide approach is needed to successfully tackle carbon dioxide emissions, in this case from maritime transport. I am pleased to have secured an acceptable exemption clause for short-sea shipping whilst ensuring that the overall proposals do not extensively burden the maritime industry by creating provisions to extend monitoring, reporting and verification. We also removed provisions that would have integrated maritime emissions into EU ETS before any global agreement at the International Maritime Organization.  I am therefore happy to support this ambitious proposal that does not disadvantage short-sea shipping whilst reducing the regulatory burden on the maritime industry as a whole.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted IN FAVOUR as the new rules require boat owners using EU ports to report their CO2 emissions from January 2018. It applies to vessels with more than 5 000 tonnes of gross registration regardless of where they are registered.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on monitoring, reporting and verification of carbon dioxide emissions from maritime transport. At EU level, the international maritime sector accounts for around 3% of global greenhouse gas emissions and these are expected to increase significantly in the future. An EU-wide system for the MRV of greenhouse gas emissions from shipping is necessary to improve the information about ship efficiency and emissions from the sector, and encourage reducing emissions and fuel consumption.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report. The proposed directive of 28 June 2013 aimed to establish a system for monitoring, reporting and verifying carbon dioxide emissions from the shipping sector in order to reduce greenhouse gases from this sector. My priorities have been taken into account, including the exclusion of small vessels, which account for 40% of the sector but less than 10% of emissions, and alignment with IMO's international standards. The report also avoids reporting that would lead to excessive administrative burdens.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted IN FAVOUR as the new rules require boat owners using EU ports to report their CO2 emissions from January 2018. It applies to vessels with more than 5 000 tonnes of gross registration regardless of where they are registered.

name: Carlos Iturgaiz (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting in favour of this proposal which establishes a system for monitoring, reporting and verifying carbon dioxide emissions from maritime transport.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the Council's position at first reading to adopt a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council on monitoring, verifying and reporting on carbon dioxide emissions from maritime transport and amending Directive 2009/16/EC; as this is a proposal introducing a system for monitoring and reporting carbon dioxide emissions in maritime transport, thereby contributing to the care of the environment.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on carbon dioxide emissions from the shipping sector.  First of all, this text proposes measures that appear to be irrelevant and ineffective in relation to environmental concerns, within a complex system.   It is also a step up to European regulations and the control requirements imposed on Member States by the European Union. An agreement between Member States would be more relevant and successful while allowing respect for national sovereignty. The Commission cannot afford to circumvent the absence of an agreement between states by supranational regulation.  Finally, this text does not address the intensification of free trade in international trade, which is a major cause of carbon dioxide pollution.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague José Inacio Faria's report on CO2 emissions from ships. This is the validation of an agreement with the Council and the Commission that will bring European standards in line with existing international standards, while excluding small vessels, which account for 40% of the sector but less than 10% of emissions. I welcome the broad adoption of this report.

name: Josu Juaristi Abaunz (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 Greenhouse gas emissions generated by maritime transport are expected to grow at such a rate as to neutralize the effects of other measures aimed at curbing or reducing global warming. According to the agreed text, the Regulation shall establish a Community system for monitoring, reporting and verifying CO2 emissions from maritime transport, with a view to improving information on ship efficiency and emissions in the sector, and promoting emission reduction and fuel consumption. This is only a first step in reducing these and other greenhouse gas emissions from maritime transport. We must be much more ambitious in regulation and objectives, and the Commission must negotiate with the International Maritime Organization with that approach.  This is the mandate given to the Commission by the European Parliament and that is why our vote has been in favour of the adoption of the Regulation.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this recommendation on carbon dioxide emissions for the shipping industry. This recommendation establishes a system for monitoring, reporting and verifying the sector's carbon dioxide emissions in order to monitor and work towards their limitations.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI)
text: Writing. The reduction of CO2 emissions from shipping is very welcome. I am therefore voting in favour of this motion.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ As the international maritime shipping regulation is the only regulation which is not included in the EU’s CO2-reduction emission scheme, I support this recommendation which aims to provide a basis for monitoring, reporting and verification (MRV) of large ships (over 5 000 gross tonnes) using EU ports and their CO2 emissions. As this proposal would allow for the creation of an EU-wide data collection system, a necessary tool for a proper CO2 emission scheme to be in place, thus I fully support it.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as an EU-wide system for the monitoring, reporting and verification system for CO2 emissions from ships is necessary in order to improve the information about ship efficiency and emissions from the sector, and encourage reducing emissions and fuel consumption.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Mrs Faria's proposal, for which I thank her for her excellent work. Maritime transport is a vital sector for the world economy, given that more than 80% of goods are transported by ships.  Today's vote confirms the result achieved in December, following important negotiations with the Italian Presidency, and shows once again how the European Parliament is paying close attention to sustainability issues by establishing an EU monitoring, communication and verification system (MRV) of CO2 emissions generated by maritime transport, as a basis for facilitating the setting of reduction targets at a later stage and for the application of a market-based measure , which could take the form of a contribution or objective-based compensation fund or an emissions trading scheme, which will be able to ensure a reduction in CO2 emissions in maritime transport.

name: Philippe Loiseau (NI)
text: In writing. Vote against. I am opposed to the desire to impose this agreement on the maritime sector in order to reduce carbon dioxide emissions because it does not respect national sovereignty. Because the consequence of this decision will be to submit the member states. As always, we find the European Union's desire to establish itself as an international authority through supranational standards. Moreover, the objective of reducing carbon dioxide with its control measures is at odds with the trading system defended by the European Union. This trade, which is based on free trade without any restrictions, is incompatible with a desire to reduce emissions since by definition this kind of trade is "polluter". The Commission is not addressing the real problem. No positive results are to be expected.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. U2012 Vote on the agreement reached with the Council at second reading on the new Regulation laying the groundwork for the monitoring, reporting and verification of carbon dioxide emissions from maritime transport. This Regulation is important, as it is seen as the first step in engsing greenhouse gas emissions from maritime traffic in the future to enter the emissions trading system (STD).

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 Carbon dioxide emissions from maritime transport contribute to air pollution and climate change and their reduction is part of the EU's overall strategy in this sector. While our group's position to extend reduction plans to smaller tonnage ships and other greenhouse gases was not taken into account in its entirety, we consider that the three-way dialogue process has brought improvements in the monitoring and penalization of carbon dioxide emissions. As a result, parliamentary approval of the report contributes to the urgent fight against climate change.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒One of the objectives of the European Union's 2020 strategies is to reduce carbon dioxide emissions from shipping by 40 percent. At Union level, maritime greenhouse gas emissions are four per cent and rising, but exactly how much and at what rate as there are no measurement and reporting obligations.  I support the recommendation of Faria MEPs and believe that the introduction of a monitoring, reporting and emissions verification system will result in better future union climate change decisions and will be an incentive for a global debate on this issue. The system should serve as an example for creating and implementing a global monitoring and compliance system with global standards.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the recommendation for second reading on the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the monitoring, reporting and verification of carbon dioxide emissions from maritime transport and the amendment of Directive 2009/16/EU, because this proposal establishes a positive and effective system for monitoring, reporting and verifying carbon dioxide emissions from maritime transport.

name: Dominique Martin (NI)
text: In writing. Dominique Martin voted against this text. This report imposes a supranational standard and ignores national sovereignty and differences between member states. Moreover, it is feared that this proposal will ultimately be ineffective in reducing air pollution.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this overdue proposal to introduce a system for monitoring, reporting and verification of carbon dioxide emissions from maritime transport.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The recommendation on the monitoring, reporting and verification of carbon dioxide emissions from maritime transport amending Directive 2009/16/EC is favourable to me. It is important to be able to control the consumption and pollution of vessels fishing in the seas and oceans at European level. Given the importance of adequately protecting marine flora and fauna, and given the necessary trend to be respected for 2020, it is necessary to exercise an effective form of control that allows an analysis of what happens and where. Protecting our areas at environmental level remains a widespread priority that must be respected and effective monitoring remains crucial.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 I support the new regulations, which will force boat owners using EU ports to notify their C02 emissions, as we must adopt measures to advance the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions and, in this regard, maritime transport must also contribute to the achievement of this objective. It is also important, as set out in the regulations, to establish an EU-wide system for monitoring, reporting and verifying polluting vessel emissions.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. I welcome the Council's position on the monitoring of CO2 emissions from maritime transport.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This text establishes a necessary system for monitoring greenhouse gas emissions in the area of maritime transport. Unfortunately, the proposed system is primarily declarative. But above all by dealing separately with the different transport sectors it does not allow the implementation of a comprehensive strategy that would include the relocation of the economy and ecological transport planning by promoting piggybacking and maritime transport. I abstain in denouncing the lack of ambition of this text.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This Regulation obliges shipowners entering and leaving EU ports to monitor and report carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions from January 2018. The new rules apply to vessels with a gross tome of more than 5000 GT, regardless of the flag State, and represent a first step towards reducing CO2 emissions from maritime transport. The new Regulation introduces a European system for monitoring, reporting and verifying CO2 emissions from maritime transport at European level. The aim is to increase transparency on ship emissions and create an incentive for their reduction. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The proposed regulation seeks to develop a system of monitoring, recording and verification (MRV) of CO2 emitted by marine transport. The EU institutions reached an agreement to create such a system and Parliament chose to support this agreement and take negotiations to the next stage.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I did not support the report on carbon dioxide emissions from maritime transport.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am in favour of this agreement already reached by the European institutions. However, I note that it did not take due account of the Outermost Regions of the Union, including the island of Madeira, which have maritime transport as the Gateway.  I do not disagree with the real need to reduce carbon dioxide emissions from maritime transport. However, I believe that this same approach should be achieved within the Framework of the International Maritime Organisation. The regional application of this Regulation will thus be limited.  As we know more than 70 % of world trade is carried out by sea. This MCV system is complex for both the sector and the authorities and many of the data to be communicated are irrelevant to the objective in question.  Pollution must, however, be combated by increasing the use of alternative fuels such as LNG. We must therefore stimulate the market for research, development, production, implementation and maintenance of new technologies, and adapt the sector gradually and proportionately.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. This report proposes to adopt the Council's position on monitoring, reporting and verification of carbon dioxide emissions from the shipping sector amending the 2009/16/EC Directive.  The Commission's aim is to fill the legal void in international law regarding the regulation of greenhouse gas emissions in maritime transport, within the framework of the International Maritime Organisation.  Once again, the Union is proving itself in its role as an arsonist firefighter. It feeds international flows, pushing for globalization at all costs (where we produce on the other side of the world and then import into Europe), and then complains about the pollution that is the consequence.  In addition to being ineffective, this text denies national sovereignty. Disputing any excessive international regulation that binds member states, I voted against it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This is a crucial step towards making sure we have effective CO2 monitoring in the EU, and well overdue. An EU-wide system for the MRV of greenhouse gas emissions from shipping is necessary in order to improve the information about ship efficiency and emissions from the sector, and encourage reducing emissions and fuel consumption.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this agreement on the carbon dioxide monitoring, reporting and verification system in the shipping sector. This agreement between the European Parliament, the Council and the European Commission (trilogue) aligns existing standards with those of the International Maritime Organisation (IMO). In addition, it spares small maritime enterprises too much administrative burden, as it excludes small vessels that account for 40% of the fleet but less than 10% of CO2 emissions from the scheme.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal that we have discussed and approved today is of fundamental importance as it introduces a system for monitoring, reporting and verifying greenhouse gas emissions from maritime transport.  The final text, the result of the long and complex interinstitutional negotiations that ended on 18 November 2014, was accepted by a very large majority in our Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy. We therefore give our full support without the need for further changes.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The text establishes a Europe-wide system for monitoring, reporting and verification (MRV) of greenhouse gas emissions from maritime transport, in order to improve information on ship efficiency and emissions in the sector, and to encourage the reduction of emissions and fuel consumption.  The new rules, already agreed informally with the Council of Ministers, will apply from 2018 for vessels over 5 000 tonnes, regardless of the country in which they are registered. According to the impact assessment accompanying this proposal for a regulation, CO2 emissions from EU international maritime transport increased by 48% between 1990 and 2007. To date, the exact extent of CO2 and greenhouse gas emissions from maritime transport is unknown due to the lack of monitoring and reporting of these emissions.  For these reasons, I am voting in favour of this report. I believe that a Europe-wide system for monitoring, reporting and verification is absolutely essential.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this resolution on the Council's position at first reading, with a view to adopting a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the monitoring, reporting and verification of carbon dioxide emissions from maritime transport and amending Directive 2009/16/EC because, with its proposal, it introduces a much-needed system for monitoring, reporting and verifying carbon dioxide emissions from maritime transport.

name: James Nicholson (ECR)
text: in writing. – International maritime shipping is the only form of transportation that is not included in the EU’s commitment to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. EU-related carbon dioxide emissions from international shipping increased by 48% from 1990-2007. The EU Climate and Energy Framework for 2030 sets a binding EU target of at least 40% reduction in GHG emissions by 2030 compared to 1990. In setting this target the EU identified the need for GHG emissions reduction in the transport sector. It is important that the regulation is proportionate and workable in practical terms. I therefore welcome efforts made to minimise the administrative burden on ship owners and operators through the use of records already available. The approach proposed for reporting emissions on an annual basis will benefit operators in British waters, and is to be welcomed. This agreement is an important first step in reducing CO2 emissions in the sector without introducing unworkable administrative burdens on the shipping industry.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the draft because it aims in the long term to reduce CO2 and other greenhouse gases from maritime transport. To this end, a monitoring, information and confirmation system shall be established in maritime transport.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Having regard to the Council's position at first reading and having regard to the opinion of the European Economic and Social Committee of 16 October 2013; Since the Council's position at first reading is in line with the agreement reached in the trialogue and the rapporteur recommends that the committee approve it without further amendment, I voted in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒International maritime transport emissions today account for 3% of global greenhouse gas emissions and 4% of EU greenhouse gas emissions. Forecasts predict a global share of 5% by 2050 and significant increases at EU level, with figures varying between 51% and 86%, whichever year is taken as a reference.  The EU Climate and Energy Package sets an ambitious target to reduce greenhouse gas emissions in all sectors, but there is no legal obligation obliging the shipping sector to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and no binding targets have been agreed for shipping. As other transport sectors are covered by mandatory reductions in greenhouse gas emissions, it was necessary to apply the same rules to maritime transport.  The establishment of a system for monitoring, reporting and checking CO2 emissions will apply to ships with a mass of more than 5000 t. I am particularly pleased that fishing boats are exempted from this obligation, as they are not about transport, but about carrying out the original economic activity.

name: Florian Philippot (NI)
text: In writing. The Faria report recommends voting on the Council's position at first reading for the adoption of the European Parliament and Council regulation on the monitoring, reporting and verification of carbon dioxide emissions from the shipping sector and amending the 2009/16/EC directive. The starting point for this text is the Commission's desire to make up for the lack of an international agreement setting targets for reducing emissions from the international maritime sector within the framework of the International Maritime Organisation and which would bind member states.  This bypass is therefore a method of integrating European regulatory systems and normative construction on an international scale. Moreover, the objective of reducing carbon dioxide emissions from the maritime sector only calls for monitoring and monitoring of emissions, with the possibility of sanctions taken by the Member State, while the very logic of unlimited and intense international trade is a significant cause of pollution.  This text does not respect national sovereignty and promises to be ineffective in reducing air pollution. So I'm voting against it.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support my colleague Faria's first reading report on the Council's position in order to adopt the Regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on monitoring, verifying and reporting on carbon dioxide emissions from maritime transport and amending Directive 2009/16/EC.  Given that maritime transport is the only type of transport not included in the Guidelines and objectives of the European Union on reducing carbon dioxide emissions, while this type of transport is responsible for the release of 3% of total carbon dioxide emissions, I also support the rapporteur's proposal to accept the Council's position without amendments. This proposal is planned to monitor and measure carbon dioxide emissions from ships as a first step towards adopting a strategy to reduce them starting in 2018. A system of monitoring and measuring CO2 emissions from ships at European level is necessary to gather information on the efficiency of ships and encourage the reduction of CO2 emissions and fuel consumption, which is why I once again express my support to it.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ International shipping is the only traffic for which co2 broadcasting is not yet prescribed. The introduction of control of the amount of fuel use can further affect climate change caused by excessive carbon dioxide emissions.  The proposal is to provide mandatory documentation on ships on fuel status, routes on which they carry ships and the cargo they carry by July 2015, with the aim of reducing annual CO2 emissions by 2% and fuel savings of €1.2 billion by 2030. I support this proposal as well as its further consideration.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal that has been voted on introduces a sound system for monitoring, reporting and verifying greenhouse gas emissions from maritime transport. As you can easily see is a highly positive proposal, the envi committee had already approved it by a very large majority in the votes of December 2014 and there was great agreement from all the stakeholders.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Maritime transport currently spews more than one billion tonnes of CO2 into the air every year, according to some estimates. If we are fighting to reduce emissions in the field of automotive and air transport, it goes without saying, from my point of view, to do so in this area as well.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. In the face of growing concerns about global warming and the weakening of the ozone layer, the EU is trying to legislate more to encourage Member States to limit and reduce their production of environmentally harmful gases.  On Tuesday, the European Parliament adopted the regulation on the monitoring, reporting and verification of carbon dioxide emissions from the maritime transport sector, and amending the current directive 2009/16/EC. This proposal, for which I have spoken positively, tends to control more emissions of this gas while taking into account the realities and constraints of this economic sector. Small vessels, representing 40% of the sector but less than 10% of emissions, are excluded from this agreement. In addition, actions involving additional administrative burdens, such as mandatory reporting, were not included.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. I supported the report by my Portuguese colleague, José In-cio Faria, on the monitoring, reporting and verification of carbon dioxide emissions from the maritime transport sector. In practice, MEPs approved the agreement with the Council in favour of a new regulation that takes a first step towards the resolution of maritime transport emissions.  Surprising as it may seem, commercial shipping is the only major mode of transport that is not yet covered by the EU's commitments to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. Without action, marine GHG emissions are expected to more than double by 2050. Hence the importance of the legislation adopted this lunchtime, which should help to reverse this negative trend but also to ensure an increased level of transparency in the maritime transport sector. In fact, from 2018, owners of large vessels (above a threshold of 5,000 gross tonnes), regardless of their flags, will be required to monitor CO2 emissions and other climate-related information when travelling within the EU and on inbound and outbound european territorial waters.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. I approved this text on maritime transport emissions, which aims to impose the regular postponement, from 2018, of CO2 emissions from this sector, which were previously excluded from any reduction target. Without specific measures, they could increase sharply in the coming years: we thereby encourage the European Union to anticipate and encourage the implementation of a global agreement by the International Maritime Organisation. The final compromise is consistent, as it provides for the postponement of CO2 emissions from the largest shipping companies, which account for 98% of emissions, without being unnecessarily binding on the companies concerned.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. The creation of a system for monitoring, reporting and verifying carbon dioxide emissions from maritime transport is important as we are moving towards green and sustainable targets. These days, ecological and environmentally friendly behaviours must be fostered and stimulated, as such, this system proves to be advantageous in the field of sustainable ecology. It will undoubtedly be an advantage to have greater control over carbon dioxide emissions from maritime transport.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report to ratify the agreement reached with the Council at second reading on the new Regulation laying down the basis for monitoring, reporting and verifying carbon dioxide emissions from maritime transport. This Regulation is of great importance, as it is the first step in enging greenhouse gas emissions from maritime traffic in the future and setting targets for reducing them.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament today - and I welcome this - new provisions requiring owners of vessels using EU ports to report their CO2 emissions every year. The new rules, already informally agreed with the Council, will apply from 2018 to vessels of more than 5,000 tonnes, regardless of the country in which they are registered.  This is a first step towards reducing greenhouse gas emissions from a sector - that of shipping - which is still excluded from EU measures to reduce carbon emissions. The new rules establish a European-wide system for monitoring, reporting and verifying carbon dioxide emissions from the shipping sector, to improve information on ship efficiency and emissions, and to encourage emission reductions and fuel consumption.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation at second reading as this proposal introduces a system for monitoring, reporting and verifying greenhouse gas emissions from maritime transport in line with the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategic plan for reducing greenhouse gases.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. I have chosen to vote against it because I have always expressed a strongly critical position towards climate policy, to which this measure is a part. In this case, I fear that, despite the reassurances, this will result in unnecessary bureaucratic burdens.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted IN FAVOUR as the new rules require boat owners using EU ports to report their CO2 emissions from January 2018. It applies to vessels with more than 5 000 tonnes of gross registration regardless of where they are registered.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The problem of CO2 emissions needs to be addressed internationally. I therefore believe that the IMO is the right place to discuss a global monitoring system in order to involve the entire maritime transport sector.  The fight against climate change cannot continue to be an exclusive battle of the EU, but must affect all major greenhouse gas emitters. I have chosen to vote in favour of this new European regulation in the hope that it will lead the way in action shared by the international community to reduce emissions from maritime transport. Only in this way will we be able to secure some tangible results and improve the situation of the marine environment, without putting European industry at a disadvantage compared to its foreign competitors.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. Carbon dioxide emissions from fossil fuels are largely responsible for so-called "greenhouse gases" and thus the intensification of global climate change, as well as ocean acidification. All issuing sources must, with the greatest urgency, be reduced.  In the case of maritime transport, in particular, it is essential to reduce the use of heavy fuels and to use alternatives such as liquefied natural gas or other environmentally appropriate sources. This transformation will have to be accompanied by the use of intermediate filling stations and the Azores, located in the middle of the Atlantic in a transit location between the Panama Canal and Europe, are ready to respond positively to this need through its infrastructure of the Atlantic Port of Praia da Vitória. For these reasons I voted positively for this proposal. I look forward to this initiative going further to the necessary change in European energy options in the maritime transport sector.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs voted in favour of the report on Monitoring, reporting and verification of carbon dioxide emissions from maritime transport. At EU level, the international maritime sector today accounts for around 3% of global greenhouse gas emissions and these are expected to increase significantly in the future. An EU-wide system for the MRV of greenhouse gas emissions from shipping is necessary in order to improve the information about ship efficiency and emissions from the sector, and encourage reducing emissions and fuel consumption.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the report on carbon dioxide emissions from the maritime sector on the grounds that maritime transport is the only sector not included in commitments to reduce greenhouse gases at EU level.  The aim of this regulation is to provide a framework for a system for monitoring, reporting and verifying greenhouse gas emissions emitted by ships with a mass of more than 5 000 gross tonnes. The current lack of monitoring and reporting makes it impossible to review the state of maritime transport emissions clearly and accurately in order to reduce them. Greenhouse gas emissions from maritime transport at EU level amount to 4% of total emissions. It is worrying that emissions are seeing a constant increase and it is necessary to offer solutions that will reach high efficiency standards. With the adopted regulation, the Commission opens up new opportunities in the shipbuilding sector. Innovation and eco-renewal of existing ships provide a great opportunity for Croatian shipyards as well. Croatian shipbuilders must recognise the potential of new European demand in order to create long-term lucrative jobs with innovative solutions, thereby ensuring safe and quality jobs. A large number of Croatian passenger and trade fleets of ships will be affected by the newly established measurement framework. Ferries such as Marco Polo will prove ineffective in terms of fuel consumption and greenhouse gas emissions. The success of Croatian shipbuilding would be the application of successful green innovations in the mentioned types of ships.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. – Water transport has always been, and I assume, always will be a key part of our daily lives, as evidenced by the fact that up to 90% of the goods traded worldwide are transported by waterways. Although maritime transport has a significant impact on the development, integration and growth of the internal market, with tangible benefits for the European economy, I would like to point out that overseas and ocean navigation produces 1.2 billion tonnes of CO2 per year, representing 4.5% of global greenhouse gas production. I also consider it unacceptable that ships produce, in addition to CO2, a lot of nitrogen oxides and sulphur, which have a significant impact on global climate change and damage to the health of the population. I supported the resolution because we consider reducing global greenhouse gas emissions to be an option to contribute as effectively as possible to meeting the EU's climate targets. I also supported the report because I am concerned by the statement by the Intergovernmental Group of Experts on Climate Change (IPCC) that shipping emissions should increase by a further 30% by 2020. I expect that, with the adoption of this report, emissions will finally be suspended and even those governments that have so far ignored the emissions produced by shipping will also think.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft legislation establishing a European system for monitoring, reporting and verifying (MRV) greenhouse gas emissions related to maritime transport, in order to improve information on the energy efficiency of ships and to encourage the reduction of emissions and fuel consumption. International maritime transport, which accounts for around 4% of all greenhouse gas emissions in the EU, remains the only type of transport not yet included in EU CO2 emission reduction measures. In anticipation of a substantial increase in emissions in the future, action was needed at European level with a first measure, requiring shipowners using EU ports to monitor and report CO2 emissions from ships over 5 000 tonnes each year. The exclusion from the MRV system for fishing, war, wood and state vessels used for non-commercial purposes ensures that control is applied only to the most polluting means.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for this resolution, which foresees monitoring and verifying CO2 emissions from transport that is not in line with EU objectives, leading to negative impacts on climate change.  The precise amount of CO2 and other EU-related greenhouse gases in shipping is unknown due to a lack of monitoring and reporting of such emissions. A reliable monitoring, reporting and verification (MRV) system for greenhouse gas emissions from maritime transport is a prerequisite for any measures.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ It is vital that we have effective CO2 monitoring in the EU, which is why I voted in favour of this report on carbon dioxide emissions from maritime transport. By putting an EU system into place, it will be possible to monitor the shipping sector and encourage a reduction in emissions and fuel consumption.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. - I voted for a proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council on monitoring and verifying carbon dioxide emissions from maritime transport and amending Directive 2009/16/EC. The main objective of the directive is to establish a system for monitoring, reporting and verification (MVR system) of CO2 emissions from maritime transport, all with the aim of achieving a global MVR system. On a global level, emissions from ships are very high, and it is also a growing source of greenhouse gases that cause climate change and affect the reduction of the diversity of the underwater world. More than 19,000 ships larger than GT 5,000 have sailed in the EU, and this category of ships represents 60% of the world's fleet.  Ships larger than 5,000 GT emit 90% of all carbon dioxide emissions. Croatia has only 45 ships over 5 000 GT, and in our registers 1 497 boats with a total of 1 462 458 GT are registered. Monitoring CO2 emissions, i.e. gathering information, would enable businesses to increase energy efficiency and reduce CO2, which is a goal we all need to strive for.  We must also think about the ambitious EU target we have set, which envisages reducing greenhouse gas emissions from international shipping by up to 40% by 2050, or 70% of total CO2 emissions in Member States by 2020. That's why I welcome a resolution like this.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the recommendation on the Council position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the monitoring, reporting and verification of carbon dioxide emissions from maritime transport. Maritime transport is a crucial transport for the global economy. More than 80% of goods are carried by ship, and this is also energy efficient transport, as we can transport goods with less CO2 emissions here compared to air and road traffic. I also welcome this measure because it wants to ensure that the new measures are cost-effective and that our businesses do not become less competitive. This risks transferring trade and transport to less environmentally friendly means (such as trucks). However, I would like to point out that we will have to be strict in monitoring and monitoring, as this is a prerequisite for these measures to succeed.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Climate change and its impact on the environment are of deep concern to us. We consider it necessary to take measures to reduce CO2 emissions, in particular in international maritime transport, which remain the only mode of transport not included in the commitments to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.  Nevertheless, we consider the EU's basic policy on tackling climate change to be wrong and the perception that the solution can be found through market mechanisms, especially when we consider that it was the unregulated operation of these mechanisms solely based on enrichment that made these problems great. For the above reasons we decided to hold an abstention stop.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Any attempt to limit carbon dioxide emissions is likable. However, there are still many steps to be taken until the desired results are achieved.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation on the monitoring, reporting and verification of carbon dioxide emissions from maritime transport.  The proposal represents a small but equally significant step forward in the fight against climate change. The maritime transport sector is one of the largest sources of climate-altering gas emissions (4% of total emissions in the EU). Without regulation and standardised control, emissions from this sector could more than double by 2050. The proposal introduces, from 2018, monitoring, reporting, testing carbon emissions for large ships docking in European ports and including emissions from maritime transport in greenhouse gas reduction targets. This will allow to collect data and information on the performance of individual ships that will later be useful to encourage subsequent efforts to reduce emissions as well as the energy performance of the ships themselves.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I of course voted in favour of the text. One wonders why it took so long to get legislation in this sector, which is the only one that did not yet have it, when it represents 4% of the emanations from transport.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D)
text: In writing. I have approved new rules to monitor CO2 emissions from ships from 2018. The legislation targets vessels with more than 5,000 gross tons, regardless of the country in which they are registered. Shipping is the only transport that the European Union's commitment to reducing greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions did not apply. This legislative advance establishes a system for monitoring, reporting and verifying CO2 emissions in the marine transport sector. We need to work with our international partners to define an ambitious global agreement. I want to congratulate this initiative, but these rules have to apply to the plan... fair competition from an environmental point of view. I also regret that some of my Liberal colleagues abstained in this important vote for the future of the regulation of our emissions. Parliament to these rules, the European Union must finance research and innovation for alternative modes of propulsion.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted IN FAVOUR as the new rules require boat owners using EU ports to report their CO2 emissions from January 2018. It applies to vessels with more than 5 000 tonnes of gross registration regardless of where they are registered.

name: Giovanni Toti (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal voted on today introduces a system for monitoring, reporting and verifying greenhouse gas emissions from maritime transport. A new step towards protection and protection that is increasingly environmentally friendly.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (NI)
text: In writing. I oppose the desire to impose this agreement on the maritime sector with the aim of reducing carbon dioxide emissions because it does not respect national sovereignty. The consequence of this decision will be to submit a little more to the member states. As always, we find the European Union's desire to establish itself as an international authority through supranational standards. Moreover, the objective of reducing carbon dioxide with its control measures is at odds with the trading system defended by the European Union. This trade, which is based on free trade without any restrictions, is incompatible with a desire to reduce emissions since by definition this kind of trade is "polluter". The Commission is not addressing the real problem. No positive results are to be expected. I'm voting AGAINST.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 CO2 emissions from maritime transport are 4% of emissions from all transport sectors. I completely agree with the report, because this issue was not regulated in this transport sector.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted IN FAVOUR as the new rules require boat owners using EU ports to report their CO2 emissions from January 2018. It applies to vessels with more than 5 000 tonnes of gross registration regardless of where they are registered.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Maritime transport is currently the only transport mode that is excluded from the EU’s commitments to cut down greenhouse gas emissions. With the approval of this new regulation, which I voted in favour of, as of 2018 shipowners will have to monitor the CO2 print of ships travelling in EU waters and report the information to the Commission. The ships covered by the regulation are those above the threshold of 5 000 tons, which are responsible for 98% of emissions. The benefits for the shipping sector related to the introduction of these measures are threefold: 1) a higher level of transparency; 2) an incentive to adopt ʽcleanerʼ and more efficient technologies; 3) an incentive to reduce costs associated with fuel consumption.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. Because of the agreement reached through interinstitutional negotiations between Parliament, the Commission and the Council, it is coherent to approve the Council's position at first reading on a proposal establishing a system for monitoring, reporting and verifying CO2 emissions from maritime transport which may provide data for future analysis.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 Carbon dioxide emissions from maritime transport contribute to air pollution and climate change, and their reduction is part of the EU's overall strategy in this sector. While our group's position to extend reduction plans to smaller tonnage ships and other greenhouse gases was not taken into account in its entirety, we consider that the three-way dialogue process has brought improvements in the monitoring and penalization of carbon dioxide emissions. As a result, parliamentary approval of the report contributes to the urgent fight against climate change.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The Council's position is in line with the discussed and negotiated with Parliament on the EU's objectives of reducing greenhouse gas emissions and the Transport White Paper which requires the implementation of policies to this end. This sector is dependent on the use of fossil fuels and its emissions also contribute to air pollution and climate change.  We see as a positive monitoring, communication and verification system that serves as a purpose to provide better information not only on the amount of GHG emitted by this sector, but also on the acquisition of concrete data to enable the development of concrete policies to deal with the problem of GHG emissions.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. I welcome the Council's position on the monitoring of CO2 emissions from maritime transport.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the Regulation on carbon dioxide emissions in maritime transport because, although not yet completely satisfactory, it has the merit of pointing to a more efficient and ethical use of biofuels, allowing for a European regulatory framework, in the absence of international regulation, on the subject of surveillance, declaration and verification of greenhouse gases and the emission of atmospheric pollutants from the maritime sector , in the wider scope of the fight against climate change.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Parliament adopted, at first reading, the proposal for the introduction of a system for monitoring, declaration and verification of CO2 emissions from maritime transport. After all the interinstitutional discussion procedures between Parliament and the Council, this report focuses on the Council's position at first reading.  The Council's position is in line with parliament on the EU's targets for reducing greenhouse gas emissions, and the Transport White Paper which requires policies to do so, given the use of fossil fuel and its emissions also contribute to air pollution and climate change.  We see as a positive monitoring, communication and verification system that serves as a purpose to provide better information not only on the amount of greenhouse gases (GHG) emitted by this sector, but also the obtaining of concrete data to enable concrete policies to be developed to deal with the problem of GHG emissions, which is why we voted favourably.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report concludes the tripartite dialogue process on improving the quality of European statistics. The changes introduced will improve the quality of the statistics provided by the NSO and other State statistical authorities participating in Eurostat, ensure their compatibility with those developed by the Bank of Spain and allow the Commission to monitor and inspect violations or manipulations committed by political interference in the definition and measurement of socio-economic variables.  We value the final agreement on an issue of particular relevance in the Spanish State, for the violations committed in measuring the public deficit or unemployment and the dubious adjustments in indicators such as poverty or inequality, with the aim of hiding the serious consequences of the neoliberal economic model.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. As new surveys show, citizens' levels of confidence in economic statistics are very low. Since statistics are essential for our work in particular, for example as decision-making aids or indicators, it is important that this confidence is restored. For these reasons, I welcome the proposal to revise the existing rules. Particular emphasis is on ensuring the professional independence of national statistical authorities, as well as clear and transparent execution, a control system and a system of sanctions in the event of non-compliance with the specified quality.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to update the existing basic framework of European statistics legislation and to adapt it to the political needs that european statistics must meet as a result of recent events in the world economy. The reliability of statistics is closely linked to the way it is held by the public, in particular financial markets. In order to ensure that users have confidence in statistics, it is necessary that they strictly comply with the technical criteria for quality assessment. It is also important that the statistical authorities are trusted. In this context, particular attention needs to be paid to the professional independence of the statistical authorities and for its legal consolidation.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. In the end, this text was not put to a vote. If it had been, I would have abstained because of the vagueness of the concrete content of the indicators.  Is GDP still relevant as a measure of prosperity? Should it remain the main objective of economic policies? What are the alternative indicators? What about the calculation of unemployment? Etc.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I was rapporteur on this issue and therefore I was leading the negotiations for the European Parliament. This legislation aims to achieve a comprehensive reform of the European statistical system in order to restore confidence in European and national statistics.  In negotiations, we have succeeded: to improve parliamentary control. Thus the head of Eurostat will appear before the ECON committee immediately after being appointed and before taking office; strengthen the independence of the directors of the National Statistical Institutes in order to avoid political interference in the production of statistics; to ensure equal opportunities, particularly on gender, in national bodies ensuring the independence of statistical producers; the Commission has the authority to conduct on-site inspections to determine whether a false statement of statistics is serious and intentional or is the result of negligence.  This agreement represents a good result and should lead to the strengthening of the quality of European statistics. This collection will be more transparent. And the European body responsible for collecting these figures will provide analyses that will allow us to have a better view of the situation in each country. This will enable europeans to put in place the policies that Europeans need.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. The aim of this text is to adopt reliable statistics with harmonised definitions at European level. It aims, in a comparative effort, to deal with statistical gaps and the heterogeneity of definitions according to the Member States, as well as to ensure the independence of national statistical institutes to avoid known statistical manipulations. It also increases data accessibility in the interests of transparency. Nevertheless, if it can go in the right direction, some measures seem to me to be abnormal, such as the possibility of inspections in Member States by European officials and the possibility of fines for incorrect statistics. This desire for transparency must not be at the expense of the sovereignty of the nations. Finally, this text on statistics does not propose new statistical models of harmonisation as for GDP or the calculation of "well-being". Bhutan did invent the "gross national happiness" (BNB), why not also look (apart from the above anecdote) at a modernized indicator? Following his remarks, I have therefore decided to abstain on this point.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Parliament's Recommendation for the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 223/2009 on European statistics. The commitments reached will ensure that statistics are more credible and harmonised in Europe, transparency will be increased and Member States will be prevented from interfering with the preparation of statistics. Likewise, the control role of the European Commission and the European Parliament in the appointment and functioning of the President of Eurostat is increased and the methodology in the collection of information is improved. In addition, field missions will be authorized to avoid manipulation situations such as past ones.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it supported the Regulation on Statistics in Europe proposed by the Commission. Reliable statistics are becoming increasingly important to enable politicians, businesses and citizens to make appropriate and evidence-based decisions. The main concern of all statistical authorities is therefore to ensure that the data produced are of high quality. Recent economic events have reaffirmed the need for further action to strengthen the reliability of statistics. Economic policies and results have been particularly strongly influenced by the sentiment of global financial markets and the strategies taken by their participants. The reliability of statistics is closely linked to the way it is held by the public, in particular financial markets. In order to ensure that users have confidence in statistics, it is necessary that they strictly comply with the technical criteria for quality assessment. However, it is equally important that the statistical authorities are trusted. In this context, particular attention needs to be paid to the professional independence of the statistical authorities and for its legal consolidation.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Reliable and accurate European statistics, as public good, have two fundamental goals: as building blocks, they form the basis of policy-makers' decisions and provide an overview of the state of the economy and society, providing reassassment to other governments and the financial market. However, the events of recent years have shaken the confidence of the public and the markets. Since then, we have witnessed how misleading and false statistics can exacerbate political and economic turmoil. The sovereign debt crisis has certainly been exacerbated by public and market skepticism about the accuracy of statistics showing public debt and general government deficits. This should be seen as a warning, as public confidence in the credibility of statistics is key if we are to create a culture of evidence-based policy-making and accountability. In this respect, the timing of the report is excellent. We need to rebuild public confidence in statistical data. I believe that previous initiatives need to be strengthened. The statistical code of practice adopted by the Commission and the Member States must be implemented and strictly enforced, so I voted positively in favour of this report.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. \u2012 I support the text because it requires changes in European statistical measurement to keep up with global developments.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. Statistics are an indispensable basis for monitoring public policy. Because of the suspicions about their reliability, this report aims to strengthen the independence of the Eurostat institution and the various national institutes, as well as the harmonization of the various statistical measurement tools. However, while the framework of institutions will make it more difficult to manipulate figures or produce erroneous data, questions about the content of indicators will still remain. For example, is the "GDP" indicator still relevant to measuring a country's degree of prosperity? What about, for example, the ecological footprint associated with GDP growth? In the absence of substantive reflection on the content of the statistical tools, I abstained on this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Report on the amendment of Regulation (EC) No 1493/1999. 223/2009 on European statistics in order to strengthen the professional independence of national statistical authorities. Recent economic developments have once again demonstrated the need to further strengthen the credibility of statistical authorities. The reliability of statistical data with regard to technical assessment criteria is a condition for ensuring user confidence, but equally important is the credibility of statistical institutions. In this context, the professional independence of statistical authorities must receive special attention and be guaranteed by law.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstained. The text in itself would be positive and devoid of particular problems, but we must be careful with a vote of abstention. It is well known that the European institutions also use Eurostat data for political purposes and in order to justify and promote their initiatives against the political forces that criticise their action and, in particular, monetary policy.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This regulation was a re-consultation on the outcome after trilogue negotiations in their second reading. The proposal approves the Council position after the consideration of the reasoned opinions of the opposed Member States in the Council and the opinion of the European Central Bank. The file was concerned with providing independent, objective and impartial statistics. This is extremely important as the manipulation of statistics provides a very distorted view of economic performance and thus recovery. It was for these reasons that I voted in favour of this report.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The proposal calls for a revision of the current basic legal framework for European statistics. Its main goal is to further strengthen governance in the European Statistical System. The text focuses on the professional independence of national statistical authorities, without sacrificing a high degree of accountability. The proposal also includes the establishment of a declaration of ‘Commitments on Confidence in Statistics’, which would contain country-specific improvement actions. Furthermore, the proposal aims to establish a legal framework for more extensive use of administrative data sources in European statistics. It also ensures the independent position of Eurostat at European Union level, and for the programming period of the European statistical programme to coincide with the European Union’s multiannual financial framework. I voted in favour of this proposed legislation.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Unfortunately, the new regulation does not significantly improve the previous text, so I abstained.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. I preferred to abstain on this text. Indeed, I am in favour of a more closely framed framework for statistics in order to avoid their political manipulation, a practice unfortunately common in France. Thus, I support certain provisions of this report: it is legitimate to demand the professional independence of the statistical authorities, just as it is hoped that control should be exercised over the Commission which is in charge of European statistics via Eurostat. However, I reject the possibility of inspection visits to Member States which is, once again, an attempt on the part of the European authorities to monitor sovereign nations, or even to lecture them as if they were bad pupils. The statistical institutes should remain under the control of national courts.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal concerns the revision of the current legal framework for European statistics. The aim, as underlined by the Commission in its communication on 'Strengthening the quality management of European statistics', is to strengthen the governance of the European Statistical System (ESS) by unconditionally applying the principle of professional independence of national statistical institutes (INS), clarifying their coordinating role in national statistical systems and enhancing the use of administrative data for statistical purposes.  In addition, it has been proposed to introduce "commitments to ensure confidence in statistics" to make national governments pay attention to their role and co-responsibility as guarantors of the credibility of official statistics, while respecting the independence of national statistical institutes. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of changing the current legal framework governing European statistics, in order to make it possible to strengthen the governance of the European statistical system.  The pursuit of this objective involves strengthening the independence of national statistical authorities, so that they are able to express unconditional data while being aware of their important responsibilities. In addition, this amendment will make it possible to establish a new legal framework to allow for a wider use of administrative data for the implementation of European statistics.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcomed the proposal to revise the current legal framework on European statistics, aimed at strengthening the professional independence of statistical authorities.  I believe that this condition is a guarantee of reliability and that, in this respect, Eurostat's position of independence must be preserved. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have chosen to abstain because this regulation, which aims at a reform of the European statistical system, although it improves the previous text, I do not think it is entirely satisfactory.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report concludes the tripartite dialogue process on improving the quality of European statistics. In this respect, the timing of the report is excellent. We need to rebuild public confidence in statistical data. I believe that previous initiatives need to be strengthened. The statistical code of practice adopted by the Commission and the Member States must be implemented and strictly enforced, which is why I supported this report.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. The aim of this report is to revise the current legal framework governing the European statistical system, particularly in terms of governance and independence of the appointment of the Director-General of the European Statistics Service Eurostat. Considering that the independence and impeccable work of the statistical services must be guaranteed in all national democracies and within the European Union, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. European citizens and those who govern them must be able to rely on statistics. I voted for this text, which is in line with the guarantee of independent statistics at the level of the European Union and all member states.  I call on them to immediately adopt texts allowing inspections in the national statistical institutes.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Hugues Bayet's report on European statistics addressed some fundamental problems, which had been unresolved for years due to a lack of agreement between the Council, the Commission and Parliament in the last parliamentary term. Statistics are very important for understanding and interpreting reality, particularly when we consider the role they have played in economic and monetary policy decisions in recent years. The calculation of the unemployment, poverty and inflation rates are just some of the most significant examples of their important contribution to European and national economic policies.  There were three guidelines around which this relationship was built. The first is to increase the quality of unemployment and the transparency of European statistics. The second concerns the appointment of the head of Eurostat, which is highly controversial and which has managed to be resolved by involving Parliament during the decision-making process. Together with this important issue, it has also been ensured that the selection process for heads of national statistical institutes is standardised at European level, thus ensuring an increase in quality and transparency. For these reasons, I strongly vote for this text so that the European statistics system is innovated in a more transparent and independent path.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I firmly endorse this report, which is a matter of great importance especially for my country. Statistics must be a real factual, but in fact, so far they are more often under the influence of manipulation for political purposes. This undermines not only national legislation and the economic system, but also the political supremacy and legitimacy of our governments, which also means the EU as a whole. We need more accurate and independent statistical authorities in order to be able to rely on the data provided to us, in particular on sensitive and problematic issues such as illegal trade and trafficking in human beings, etc.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour because amendments to the way statistics are collected are necessary.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Reliable and accurate European statistics, as public good, have two fundamental goals: as building blocks, they form the basis of policy-makers' decisions and provide an overview of the state of the economy and society, providing reassassment to other governments and the financial market. In this respect, the timing of the report is excellent. We need to rebuild public confidence in statistical data. I believe that previous initiatives need to be strengthened. The statistical code of practice adopted by the Commission and the Member States must be implemented and strictly enforced, so I voted positively in favour of this report.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the validation of this Regulation, which requires the revision and adaptation of the current basic legal framework for European statistics, taking into account the needs and challenges created for European statistics in the face of recent developments in the global economy. The main objective is to strengthen governance in the European Statistical System, safeguard its high credibility and adequately respond to the data needs resulting from enhanced economic policy coordination in the European Union.

name: Jonás Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Regulation to improve the transparency and quality of statistics provided to Eurostat by national and subnational agencies. The availability of quality statistical information, a public good in itself, is essential for economic research, financial stability and informed decision-making in the field of European public policies. This is particularly important in the light of cases such as the manipulation of statistics by some Member State, but also by region, as was allegedly the case in Spain with the Valencian Community, governed by the PP since 1995, which led to the opening of an investigation by the Commission in 2014, an investigation not yet concluded. For this reason, it is essential to strengthen the independence of State statistical agencies and to introduce the possibility of on-the-spot inspections by the Commission in the Member States. Eurostat's parliamentary control and coordination with the European System of Central Banks is also improved. I therefore believe that this Regulation deserves full support, and I congratulate rapporteur Hugues Bayet on the excellent work done.

name: Edouard Ferrand (NI)
text: In writing. I abstained on this report because too much uncertainty remains about the future of statistics at european Union level and, above all, the contours of national statistics, in this context, remain poorly defined.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European statistical system carries out a number of key activities for the development of Union policies. In the economic field, we call for the collection and formulation of data to be carried out with criteria of transparency and independence at the highest level.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the recommendation for second reading on the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1782/2003. I believe that there is a need to make changes to the way statistics are collected.
