name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of amending the Regulation in accordance with Protocol No 2 on the application of the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. Mr Hugues Bayet has produced a report which I support and which I voted for with conviction. The amendment of the Regulation on European statistics makes it possible to define and strengthen the criteria for the reliability of data. This is an essential measure to ensure autonomy and independence in data processing, which is a prerequisite for the quality of legislation.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the recommendation for second reading on the Council's position on the adoption of a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 223/2009 on European statistics, because I welcome the approach in it.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Our position is in favour of this proposal, which has been approved without a vote. This is the final phase of a legislative process that seeks to ensure the independence and reliability of statistical agencies in different countries.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on the European statistics proposals. The proposal for a regulation called for a revision of the current basic legal framework for European statistics, adapting it to meet the policy needs and challenges created for European statistics by recent developments in the global economy. The main goal is to strengthen governance in the European Statistical System in order to safeguard its high credibility and to respond adequately to data needs resulting from enhanced economic policy coordination in the EU.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour because I think it is very important to strengthen the independence of national statistical authorities from political interference by governments in order to avoid manipulation of statistics.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as this amendment to the existing EU Regulation on Statistics strengthens the role and independence of national statistical institutes in Member States as well as that of Eurostat. We need to bring in increased scrutiny of official statistics following the economic crisis and also ensure the quality and objectivity of official statistics.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. In today's vote on 'European statistics', I voted in favour with most, if not all, of my colleagues in the ECR Group. If Brussels is useful, it is safe to process data that will allow MEPs and national parliaments to make comparisons on the basis of objective data.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Our position is in favour of this proposal, which has been approved without a vote. This is the final phase of a legislative process that seeks to ensure the independence and reliability of statistical agencies in different countries.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the Council's position at first reading with a view to adopting a regulation of the European Parliament and the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 2012/2013; 223/2009 on European statistics, given the importance of statistics for policy-making, the need to adopt measures improving the credibility of statistics, the independence of statistical institutions, the management of statistics, the coordination of European statistics and their co-responsibility.

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Regulation as it improves the transparency and quality of statistics provided to Eurostat by national and subnational agencies. The availability of quality statistical information, a public good in itself, is essential for economic research, financial stability and informed decision-making in the field of European public policies. This is particularly important in view of cases such as the manipulation of statistics by some Member State, but also by region, as appeared to have happened in Spain with the Valencian autonomous community, in the hands of the right, which led to the opening of investigation by the European Commission in 2014. For this reason, the independence of state statistical agencies is strengthened and the possibility of on-the-spot inspections by the European Commission in the Member States is introduced. It also improves Eurostat's parliamentary control, as well as eurostat's coordination with the European System of Central Banks. That is why I believe that this Regulation deserves all the support, and at the same time I congratulate rapporteur Hugues Bayet on the magnificent work done.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report as it creates a framework for strengthening the independence of national statistical authorities, the selection of statistical methods and the way data is collected. This process is important for the impartiality, trustworthiness and high quality of data collected across the Member States.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this report on European statistics. The proposed amendment to the current regulation is an essential element aimed at strengthening the reliability of European statistics. I welcome the adoption of this report.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI)
text: Writing. The proposal is an important step for the correctness of statistical data, the production of statistics and the verification of data. This makes it easier to avoid irregularities or intentional manipulation of data and to detect it more quickly. A welcome point is the independence of the statistical institutes from political influence. As this brings great benefits for Europe, the European economy and the making of recommendations that resort to statistics, I am voting in favour of this motion.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I am very much in favour of this proposal which seeks to revise the legal framework for the collection, production and dissemination of European statistics. These changes aim to strengthen the professional independence of national statistical authorities, and that of Eurostat, and their ability to meet the expected quality standards. Ireland already has a very strong legislative foundation for statistics; however this proposal will further strengthen the ability of the Central Statistics Office, which currently produces 90% of all European statistics for the Irish state, to meet quality standards. Such efforts will ensure increased confidence in statistics and it therefore has my full support.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this legislation as it seeks to carry out a wholesale reform of the European Statistical System in order to bring back confidence in European and national statistics.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Huge global forces are working to transform Europe in the model of the US. In the model state of democracy, the creation of the United States went relatively simply in areas stolen from extermed indigenous people. In Europe, the process is faltering, nation states and people with national sentiments are resisting. The European Commission, on the other hand, is trying to eradicate everything that is national. This proposal contradicts even the principles set out in Protocol 2 to the Treaty of Lisbon, which are intended to guarantee the limited autonomy and proportionality of countries, so I could not accept it.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. The commitments reached will ensure that statistics are more credible and harmonised in Europe and transparency is increased so that national policy in the Member States does not interfere with the preparation of statistics. The role of the Commission and the European Parliament in the appointment and functioning of the President of Eurostat is also increased and the methodology in the collection of information is improved. In addition, field missions will be authorized to avoid manipulation situations such as those with Greece in the past.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report concludes the tripartite dialogue process on improving the quality of European statistics. The changes introduced will improve the quality of the statistics provided by the NSO and other State statistical authorities participating in Eurostat, ensure their compatibility with those developed by the Bank of Spain and allow the Commission to monitor and inspect violations or manipulations committed by political interference in the definition and measurement of socio-economic variables.  We value the final agreement on an issue of particular relevance in the Spanish State, for the violations committed in measuring the public deficit or unemployment and the dubious adjustments in indicators such as poverty or inequality, with the aim of hiding the serious consequences of the neoliberal economic model.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 Statistics must be accurate, true, comprehensive and comparable. They monitor developments in the Member States, compare each other and define recommendations for the necessary reforms, with a view to achieving common growth and development. In practice, there were examples of attempts to hide or inaccurately present statistics, sometimes because of ignorance of methodology and sometimes intentionally with the aim of concealing shortcomings in the work of the state and the economy. Penalties are provided for such actions and statistical systems must not be subject to political decision-making.   I supported the report amending the legal framework for European statistics, as it insists on strengthening the independence of national statistical authorities while pointing to the high level of accountability they have. Specific country-specific measures are required to improve the national statistical system and comply with the Code of Practice of European Statistics. A legal framework is also being established for a more extensive use of administrative data to produce European statistics.    The main objective of this amendment is to further strengthen the European Statistical System, its independence and the production of quality data, which are a key basis for decision-making and good governance. That is why I supported this report on European statistics.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I abstained because I consider that this recommendation for second reading on the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1782/2003 should be amended accordingly. In the case of European statistics, it is necessary to amend Regulation (EC) No 223/2009 on European statistics. 2 on the application of the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am pleased that we were able to get a first reading agreement on European statistics.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This is the draft recommendation for second reading on the Council's position at first reading on the regulation amending the System of European Statistics.  The final proposal, for which I voted in favour, provides for a revision of the basic legal framework for European statistics with the aim of further strengthening governance in the European statistical system and focuses on the professional independence of national statistical authorities, with coordination of national statistical institutes in national statistical systems, while maintaining a high degree of responsibility with country-specific improvement actions. It also aims to create a legal framework for wider use of administrative data sources for the production of European statistics.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. The proposal to amend the regulation on European statistics is not only an important step in maintaining correct statistical data, but also in the production and verification of data and statistics, which would make it easier to get to the bottom of any irregularities or to avoid them, as in the case of Greece. In addition, the independence of the statistical institutes from the government would be welcome, in order to avoid falsification or euphemism of certain data. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This report amends a European regulation that strengthens the independence of European (mainly Eurostat) and national statistical services to remedy recent statistical fraud and manipulation. The report recommends that European statistical production should be extended to the whole of the economic and social field and not to confine it to the data needed for budgetary surveillance linked to the Stability Pact. But the text also gives the Commission stronger powers to investigate possible statistical manipulation of member states are much more questionable, as are the planned EU fines.  Applied in the context of the Troika's austerity plans, these new powers of investigation and sanction could seriously undermine the sovereignty of states. The trilogue did take into account some of Parliament's demands to clarify the roles of European and national institutions, but without going back on the powers given to the Commission. I'm voting AGAINST.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. Reliable and accurate European statistics play two vital roles as a public good: they are the basis for decision-makers' decision-makers and serve as a barometer for analysing the state of the economy and society, providing guarantees to governments and financial markets. However, some events in recent years have shaken public and market confidence.  It is important and necessary to have confidence in statistics. Eurostat must have the means to produce valid and reliable information. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposal as it seeks to ensure the independent position of Eurostat at European Union level. The recommendation also includes a declaration of ʽConfidence in Statisticsʼ which will enshrine the principle of professional independence. This is crucial for national and EU level statistics institutions to retain credibility.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this report that seeks to carry out a wholesale reform of the European Statistical System in order to bring confidence back into European and national statistics.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposal is the second reading of the motion amending Regulation No 223/2009 on European statistics. I supported the Council's position on the text adopted at first reading in line with the rapporteur's proposal.

name: Bernard Monot (NI)
text: In writing. Statistics are an essential tool for steering public policy.  Their presentation is often made difficult at European level because of the lack of harmonisation.  We must welcome the desire of the regulation to have unified, comparable and accessible statistics.  Penalties should probably have been provided for handling, but the definition of such an offence remains rather subjective.  Nor will Europe save a substantive debate on the content of indicators, such as GDP or the unemployment rate, and see if they remain relevant.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. The aim of the text put to a vote is to adopt reliable statistics and harmonised definitions at European level. It aims to remedy the statistical gaps and the heterogeneity of their definitions in the Member States, with a comparative concern, as well as to guarantee the independence of national statistical institutes in order to avoid known statistical manipulations, for example, in Greece. It is also about increasing data accessibility, in the interests of transparency.  However, while this may be a step in the right direction, a few measures are akin to unjustified interference, such as the possibility given to European officials to carry out inspections in the Member States, with the possibility of fines for incorrect statistics. While the objective of reducing the manipulation of statistics is laudable, it must not be at the expense of the sovereignty of the Member States.  Nor does this text raise the question of the relevance of statistical indicators, such as GDP, which is widely decried in academic literature. Nor is there anything about thinking about a more relevant indicator of "well-being".  It is indeed a global reflection that must be carried out, not a reform with constant definitions. So I decided to abstain.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as it will improve parliamentary scrutiny, strengthen the independence of the heads of national statistical institutes (NSI) in order to avoid political interference in the production of statistics. In addition, it will ensure equal opportunities, in particular on gender, in national bodies assuring the independence of the producers of statistics. The text also clarifies the relationships between the two main pillars of the production of European statistics: the European System of Central Banks (ESCB) and the European Central Bank and the Commission (Eurostat) which are called upon to coordinate the statistical activities of the institutions and bodies of the European Union, in particular with a view to ensuring consistency and quality of the data and minimising the reporting burden.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament has approved this text on the revision of the legal framework governing European statistics to enable them to better account for developments in the global economy, particularly in the context of improved economic policy coordination within the EU.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The aim of this regulation is to promote a general reform of the European statistical system, in order to restore confidence in European and national statistics.  We believe it is essential, in order to improve parliamentary control, the introduction of new forecasts relating to the obligation for the Director of Eurostat to appear before the ECON Committee immediately after he has been appointed and before taking up his duties; strengthening the independence of the directors of national statistical institutes in order to avoid political interference in the production of statistics; the obligation to ensure gender equality in national bodies.  We welcome this text, which also clarifies the relationship between the two main pillars of European statistics production: the European System of Central Banks (ESCB) and the European Central Bank. It will also be necessary to coordinate the statistical activities of the Union institutions and bodies, in particular in order to ensure the consistency and quality of data and to minimise reporting requirements.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In order to make decisions based on objective data, governments, businesses and citizens must increasingly have reliable statistics. That is why I voted in favour of Mrs Bayet's report. The proposal involves a review of the existing legal framework for European statistics in order to respond to the needs and challenges posed by recent developments in the world economy. The main objective is to strengthen the governance of the European statistical system in order to safeguard its high credibility and respond adequately to data needs in the European Union. In particular, the professional independence of national statistical authorities in the performance of their duties is of fundamental importance in this context.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the Council's position at first reading with a view to adopting a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1493/1999. 223/2009 on European statistics, taking into account the importance and necessity of these European statistics. I stress that the adoption of the act in accordance with the Council's position is a success.

name: Péter Niedermüller (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 A fact-based approach to policy issues requires the reliable and expedient functioning of the European statistical system and the adaptation of the system to economic change. I consider it particularly important to guarantee the professional independence of the heads of statistical authorities in the Member States.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. I consider the proposal to amend the regulation on European statistics to be an important step towards maintaining correct statistical data, but also for the production and verification of data and statistics, which will make it easier to get to the bottom up of any irregularities. In addition, the independence of the statistical institutes from the government would be welcome, in order to avoid falsification or euphemism of certain data. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal to amend the regulation, which aims to strengthen the independence of national statistical offices. The Statistical Office and its output must be reliable and this requires that the people who work there are professional, free in their positions and impartial. The purpose of the amendment of the Regulation is to ensure this.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Taking into account the reasoned opinions sent by the Spanish Congress of Deputies, the Spanish Senate and the Austrian Federal Council, within the framework of Protocol No 2 on the application of the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality, which declares that the draft legislative act does not comply with the principle of subsidiarity, I voted in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ By adopting the Regulation of the European Parliament and the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 2012/2013, 223/2009 on European statistics (05161/2/2015 - C8-0073/2015 - 2012/0084 (COD)) will strengthen the professional independence of national statistical authorities and strengthen the credibility of statistics. The reliability of statistical data is a prerequisite for ensuring the trust of users, and equally important is the credibility of the institutions in charge of producing statistics.  This Regulation calls for a revision of the existing fundamental legal framework for European statistics, adapting it to meet the needs and policy challenges created for European statistics by recent developments in the world economy. In particular, the regulation concerns the leaders of national statistical offices as persons whose independence in the performance of their duties is a precondition for establishing the independence of the relevant institutions and also includes the establishment of an 'obligation of trust in statistics'.  In view of all of the above and given the high likelihood of positive effects of this Regulation, I support the proposal for a regulation and the Council's position.

name: Florian Philippot (NI)
text: In writing. The aim is to achieve harmonised statistics across Europe, with the hope that they will be more reliable. Nevertheless, the choice of criteria is already a political choice and it is well known that the figures will always be interpretable and manipulated. I am not convinced by the implementation of these devices to ensure better data reliability and I therefore prefer to abstain on this text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support colleague Bayet's positive report on the Council's position at first reading with a view to adopting the Regulation of the European Parliament and the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 2012/2013; 223/2009 on European statistics, following the recommendations and opinions of the European Central Bank as of 6 November 2012 and the Spanish Congress of Members and the Spanish Senate and the Austrian Federal Council, submitted under Protocol No 100/2013. 2 on the application of the principle of subsidiarity and proportionality declaring that the draft legislative act does not comply with the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ It is of utmost importance to continue working to strengthen the professional independence of national statistical authorities in order to ensure the full credibility of statistics at Member State and EU level. For this reason, the amended regulation is necessary to define measures that achieve the legally guaranteed independence of statistical authorities, impede political pressure and guarantee the highest standards of statistical processing.  It is therefore good that member states' statistical authorities will not be allowed to seek or receive instructions from national political authorities through their leaders. It is equally important to ensure the independence of the statistical system at European level as well. The Statistical Office of the European Communities (Eurostat) is essential so that european institutions can make quality and informed decisions at all stages and levels of their work. The reliability of statistics is also properly attempted by a stronger European Statistical System – coordination between Eurostat, national statistical institutions and other national statistics authorities.  For all this, I welcome the Commission's proposal to adopt a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 2020/2013. 223/2009 on European statistics, I support the Council's position at first reading, as well as rapporteur Bayet's recommendation.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In this case we are in the ordinary legislative procedure at second reading, and the act that is adopted is in full compliance with the Council's position. That is why I am voting in favour.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Parliament's Recommendation for the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 223/2009 on European statistics. The commitments reached will ensure that statistics are more credible and harmonised in Europe, transparency will be increased and Member States will be prevented from interfering with the preparation of statistics. Likewise, the control role of the European Commission and the European Parliament in the appointment and functioning of the President of Eurostat is increased and the methodology in the collection of information is improved. In addition, field missions will be authorized to avoid manipulation situations such as past ones.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of revising the basic legal framework for European statistics. This aims to meet the new needs resulting from the changing global economy and to strengthen the governance of the European statistical system. This proposal refers in particular to the independence of the heads of the national statistical institutes in carrying out their tasks as a precondition for the independence of their respective institutes. The revision also clarifies the coordinating role of INS in national statistical systems. Moreover, it incorporates the need to ensure Eurostat's independence at EU level.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation as I support the need for a review of the regulatory framework for European statistics in order to strengthen their governance, independence and reliability. It is essential to implement the use of available sources of administrative data to develop more statistical analyses at European level.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. I have chosen to abstain because it is known that the European institutions are also using Eurostat data for political purposes and in order to justify and promote their initiatives towards the political forces that criticise their action and, in particular, monetary policy.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Our position is in favour of this proposal, which has been approved without a vote. This is the final phase of a legislative process that seeks to ensure the independence and reliability of statistical agencies in different countries.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report concludes the tripartite dialogue process on improving the quality of European statistics. The changes introduced will improve the quality of the statistics provided by the NSO and other State statistical authorities participating in Eurostat, ensure their compatibility with those developed by the Bank of Spain and allow the Commission to monitor and inspect violations or manipulations committed by political interference in the definition and measurement of socio-economic variables.  We value the final agreement on an issue of particular relevance in the Spanish State, for the violations committed in measuring the public deficit or unemployment and the dubious adjustments in indicators such as poverty or inequality, with the aim of hiding the serious consequences of the neoliberal economic model.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal to revise the legal framework for European statistics. I believe it is important to improve the governance of the European statistical system by maintaining the independence of national statistical authorities in deciding on the methods of data collection, standards and procedures, content and timing of all publications.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in support of the European Statistics proposal. The proposal for regulation called for a revision of the current basic legal framework for European statistics, adapting it to meet the policy needs and challenges created for European statistics by recent developments in the global economy. The main goal is to further strengthen governance in the European Statistical System in order to safeguard its high credibility and to respond adequately to data needs resulting from the enhanced economic-policy coordination in the European Union.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 European statistics should be carried out in a transparent manner, on the basis of professional criteria and without political pressure. All procedures and information should be made public. Member States may establish a national authority which contributes to ensuring the professional independence of European statistics promoters in a Member State. It is also important to guarantee eurostat's independence through effective parliamentary scrutiny.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I voted for this resolution because I think it is necessary to strengthen the governance of the European Statistical System (ESS) by ensuring the unconditional application of the principles of professional independence of the National Statistical Institute (NSIS), by clarification of its role as coordinator in national statistical systems and by increasing the use of administrative data for statistical purposes.  The proposal calls for a revision of the existing basic legal framework for European statistics, adapting for policy purposes and challenges created for European statistics to recent developments in the global economy. The main objective is to further strengthen governance in the European Statistical System in order to protect high credibility and adequately respond to the needs of data arising from enhanced economic policy coordination in the European Union.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. It is important that we are able to have confidence in our European and national statistics and so I support this legislation for a wholesale reform of the European Statistical System.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. - I supported this proposal as it will ensure greater quality and credibility of statistics in the Member States of the European Union on the basis of which, ultimately, we in the European Parliament and the European Commission take our decisions. It is particularly important that Member States establish national authorities that will carry out statistical analyses professionally and independently so that their credibility is not called into question.  I consider it even more important to apply and unequalize the methodology when processing data, and for this to be the case, all member state institutes and other governmental authorities responsible for this must be coordinated. In my view, Eurostat must remain an independent body that will guarantee effective control over all statistical institutes of the Member States, in order for Union citizens to have easy access to data.  The adoption of the report will provide up-to-date and credible statistics in all Member States on the basis of which investors will also be able to efficiently obtain the necessary information, which can lead to an increase in investments in the Member States of the Union.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal as it limits possible efforts by governments to falsify statistics.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Improvements in the way statistics are carried out are steps in the right direction.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of the recommendation, as all efforts to ensure the professional independence of the European statistical authorities should be supported, just as the easily comparable and accessible statistics of the Member States must be expected. There are Member States where the heads of national statistical offices are decided on the basis of political considerations, or where they time or refuse to publish certain reports on the basis of political decisions. These practices should be stopped. Workers in statistical offices may be selected solely on the basis of professional criteria, who must carry out their duties independently of pressure from any political or other interest group. The Recommendation contributes to meeting these expectations by providing high-quality, regularly updated statistical data that provide a reliable basis for responsible decisions.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text of my eminent colleague Hugues Bayet, which was once again in the image of the work presented this afternoon: irreproachable. Its text on the Council's position at first reading for the adoption of the Regulation of the European Parliament and the Council amending Regulation (EC) 223/2009 on European statistics was also easily accepted by the whole assembly.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Our position is in favour of this proposal, which has been approved without a vote. This is the final phase of a legislative process that seeks to ensure the independence and reliability of statistical agencies in different countries.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The lack of European standards for official statistics was clearly a matter of concern in several Member States in the run up to the crisis. I hope that this regulation will help to correct this situation, but we shall remain vigilant to ensure that the mistakes from the past are not repeated.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (NI)
text: In writing. The manipulation of statistics will always remain, but basic framing, coordination and advertising can make it more difficult. There also remains the concrete content of the indicators which is not the subject of the report but is obviously linked to the objectives pursued. Is GDP still relevant as a measure of prosperity? What are the alternative indicators?  The same remarks may exist for unemployment and how to measure it. I choose the ABSTENTION on this text.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 This is a very important area. The report examines at second reading the recommendations for the collection and systematization of European statistics. Any initiative to strengthen the independence of statistical offices should be supported at European level. Credible and comparable data are the basis for establishing a credible economic situation. I voted in favour of the recommendation.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Our position is in favour of this proposal, which has been approved without a vote. This is the final phase of a legislative process that seeks to ensure the independence and reliability of statistical agencies in different countries.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. We are talking about a positive Recommendation when requesting a review of the current basic legal framework for European statistics, focusing on the professional independence of both the national statistical authorities and Eurostat.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report concludes the tripartite dialogue process on improving the quality of European statistics. The changes introduced will improve the quality of the statistics provided by the NSO and other State statistical authorities participating in Eurostat, ensure their compatibility with those developed by the Bank of Spain and allow the Commission to monitor and inspect violations or manipulations committed by political interference in the definition and measurement of socio-economic variables.  We value the final agreement on an issue of particular relevance in the Spanish State, for the violations committed in measuring the public deficit or unemployment and the dubious adjustments in indicators such as poverty or inequality, with the aim of hiding the serious consequences of the neoliberal economic model.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Regulation (EC) No 223/2009 sets out a regulatory framework for the development, production and dissemination of European statistics, including general provisions on the protection and access to confidential data. In addition to simplifying and stabilising the budgetary planning of statistical activities, the proposal aligns the programming period of the European Statistical Programme with the Union's multiannual financial framework. Finally, the proposed amendment to Regulation (EC) No 223/2009 takes into account the necessary adaptations to the Treaty of Lisbon, with regard to the conferral on the Commission of delegated powers and implementing powers. The decision was involved and the participation of the National Statistical Institutes.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. The proposal to amend the regulation on European statistics is not only an important step in maintaining correct statistical data, but also in the production and verification of data and statistics, which would make it easier to get to the bottom of any irregularities or to avoid them, as in the case of Greece. In addition, the independence of the statistical institutes from the government would be welcome, in order to avoid falsification or euphemism of certain data. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, I believe that the Wałęsa report concerning the Commission proposals for a Baltic multiannual plan for the stocks of cod, herring and sprat is a step forward. In the last term, Parliament was responsible for shaping an improved Common Fisheries Policy and I would like to commend my colleague, Chris Davies, who is no longer with us, for the significant role that he played in shaping the improved Common Fisheries Policy. But now I believe our role in this Parliament is to ensure the effective implementation of the reforms that we agreed.  I am particularly pleased that Amendment 30, which asks that the most recent scientific advice be taken into account, was adopted. I also agree with the target fishing mortality range, which is calibrated from zero to FMSY, which is the fishing mortality consistent with achieving maximum sustainable yield. I was disappointed that Amendments 64 and 55 were narrowly defeated, which would have protected juveniles and also spawning fish and would also have minimised the incidental capture of seabirds and marine animals.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: - Mr. President, the Marine Strategy Framework Directive is a comprehensive and demanding act that is essential in implementing a harmonised policy of The Member States with a view to sustainable management of the marine environment based on an ecosystem approach.  The management of stocks of commercial species, as well as species exposed to secondary catches, is essential for the sustainability of ecosystems. At a time when fish harvesting opportunities have far surpassed the ecological balance, and harvesting is greater than the potential of natural species restoration, without respecting the ecosystem approach in fisheries management, we will not achieve the desired objectives of good environmental status by 2020, nor ensure sustainability in this significant branch of the economy that should ensure future generations of benefits that we use today.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report refers to the multiannual fisheries management plan for the Baltic Sea which applies to cod, herring and sprim stocks. This management plan replaces the previous one for cod stocks. Cod, herring and sprim are the subject of important fish in the Baltic Sea. Until now, there was no management plan for herring and sprcy, which made it difficult to sustain its stocks and the stability of fishing opportunities for its fishermen. However, this plan does not sufficiently guarantee the protection of various marine species. It is not guaranteed that they will not exceed the lower limit corresponding to the maximum sustainable yield for the adoption of delegated acts relating to specific conservation measures for the conservation of flox, sole, turbot and remol and to minimise bycatch of marine birds, mammals or reptiles, as the ICES scientific opinion has indicated that the current operating rates of some of these populations are not consistent with the achievement of maximum sustainable yields. However, the amendments were not adopted. That's why I voted against it.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. This multi-year plan for Baltic Sea cod, herring and sprat stocks and fisheries is once again setting up heavy technical measures that knock out fishermen. Scientists are giving negative opinions on this plan. The current exploitation of stocks would be inconsistent with the goal of maximum sustainable yield.  Moreover, it is a breach of the democratic aspect of the European institutions. Indeed, the European Parliament delegates many technical measures to the Commission, but this goes against the principle of regionalisation of the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP). The chairman of the fisheries committee, Alain Cadec, even talks about an institutional conflict. So I abstained.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation to preserve our alleutical resources.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to set up a multiannual plan for the management of cod, herring and sprat stocks in the Baltic Sea and the fisheries plan for those stocks. In 2014, the EC published a multiannual plan for the management of cod, herring and sprat stocks in the Baltic Sea and the fisheries of those stocks. The new rules take into account the interaction between these species, the impact of cod on herring and sprat stocks and the impact of the latter on cod stocks. I believe that different types of management plan are more effective than one type of management. The plan must ensure a balanced and sustainable exploitation of these stocks and the stability of fishing opportunities and, at the same time, the livelihood of fishermen. It is also important to ensure that governance is based on the latest scientific advice. The European Parliament will continue to negotiate this plan with the Council.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. I abstained on this text which, despite interesting proposals, aims to establish too many constraints for fishermen and too many delegated acts that undermine the sovereignty of the Member States.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. This plan aims to develop a multi-species approach to cod, herring and sprat stocks in the Baltic. This plan will take into account biological interactions, environmental conditions and will be scientifically monitored. It also provides for a more flexible approach to resources by establishing fishing opportunities annually. This should allow for a balanced and sustainable exploitation of stocks.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. This multiannual plan is the first we voted on after the adoption of the reform of the common fisheries policy and will set a precedent for all those plans that come from now on. I did not follow the line of my group in Amendment No 30, which referred to fishing mortality and the establishment of a percentage. I agree that scientific studies have to establish the situation in each catch, but at all times, and not by establishing a double clause. On the other hand, Parliament is going to have to be very firm in the division of competences which, after the adoption of the Lisbon Treaty, is given to Parliament on fisheries.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. This report essentially indicates that due to overfishing; stocks of cod, herring and sprat in the Baltic Sea are at risk. There are two problems. First, particularly on the current exploitation of stocks which is incompatible with the goal of maximum sustainable yield according to the opinion of several scientists. Secondly, one can question the delegation to the Commission of many technical measures which excludes states from decision-making despite the principle of regionalisation of the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP).  The National Front had asked the Fisheries Committee by an amendment for the Commission to take scientific studies into account before adopting technical measures to prevent fishermen from being knocked out by heavy restrictions and regulations.  I abstained on this report.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. One of the main elements of the new Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) is the multiannual management plans, which will enable long-term programming to be adopted and the specificities of each EU region, an essential element in the CFP's new regionalisation strategy, to be applied to fisheries. The objective of today's multiannual plan is to establish a single management for the stocks of cod, herring and spurin in the Baltic Sea, through their sustainable exploitation and stable fishing opportunities, ensuring management based on the latest scientific information.  Spain has no direct interests in this multiannual plan; however, it is important, given that it will serve as the basis for those who will come next, and for the sake of coherence in the way EU waters are managed. In this vote, the Spanish Socialists defended the establishment of a range of 0 to FMSY (maximum sustainable performance) according to the latest scientific data.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it supports the establishment of a multiannual plan for sustainable fishing in the Baltic Sea. This plan will take into account the regeneration potential of certain fish stocks and any restrictions or authorisations for fishing activities will be based on up-to-date scientific data.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. I support this report, as this is the first multiannual plan in line with the reformed common fisheries policy and will serve as such as a model for other upcoming multiannual fisheries plans. The plan aims to ensure the sustainable exploitation of cod, herring and sprat stocks in the Baltic Sea, as well as to ensure the stability of fishing in line with all aspects of ecosystem and environmental protection.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 This multiannual plan is the first of its kind in the context of the reform of the common fisheries policy (CFP) and has been considerably modified by the European Parliament. It is the first opportunity for us Members to demonstrate parliament's real role in implementing the CFP. This plan will serve as a model for the next plans and must therefore be in line with the objectives of the common fisheries policy in ensuring environmental, economic and social sustainability and compliance with the precautionary principle. The basic regulation clearly states that multiannual plans must include conservation measures to restore and maintain fish stocks above levels capable of producing maximum sustainable yield (MSY).  However, this criterion has not been taken into account in the Commission's proposal. Our group has tabled a number of amendments to this effect, which were adopted by a large majority in the Committee on Fisheries. It is important to follow the line already marked in order not to completely undermine the efforts made so far. We must continue to act in the name of sustainability and the ecosystem approach in fisheries management in order to meet the objectives set by the CFP.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. Overfishing poses a serious threat to cod, herring and sprat stocks in the Baltic Sea. Various scientific studies have determined that the intensity of the exploitation of the affected stocks is not sustainable and does not guarantee stock renewal. However, Member States are not sufficiently involved in the stock management process and Parliament, by requesting a vote on many delegated acts, is relinquishing its role as co-decision-makers and monitoring the decisions taken by the Commission. Finally, it seems that the Commission will not wait for the conclusions of the most recent studies before implementing restrictions and regulations that will weigh heavily on fishermen. That is why I abstained on the vote of this text.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstained. The measure introduces a new approach applied to a fishing area outside our sector. I do not want to support initiatives based on an unclear method for assessing stocks.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The Multi-Year Management Plan for the Baltic Sea is the first management plan for the Reformed Common Fisheries Policy, thus providing a model for future management plans on which fisheries resource management is based. I welcome the adoption by the European Parliament of a plan that implements its objectives, including managing stocks above the sustainable maximum yield. In setting mortality targets, we need to rely on the latest available scientific advice. In the forthursing negotiations, I will defend the prerogatives of Parliament, which is a co-decision maker on all elements of this regulation.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this legislative resolution as, while there were a number of positive improvements to the Commission proposal, they were not nearly robust enough to prevent the destruction of the Baltic ecosystem.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The aim of the multiannual plan is to establish a framework for multispecies management of Baltic Sea stocks of cod, herring and sprat. This approach is considered more effective than management of single species and hence for the livelihoods of fishermen. It aims to consider inter-species interactions, such as the influence of cod on herring and sprat stocks and other aspects related to ecosystem and fisheries based on the most updated scientific knowledge. In view of these reasons I could vote in favour of this plan.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The multiannual plans under the common fisheries policy aim to replenish and maintain fish stocks above levels capable of producing maximum sustainable yield.  It is no longer possible to ignore this point, which is expressed very well in the report; The multiannual baltic plan is the first application and an important test of this. The idea of treating fish stocks as if they were endless has led to a serious crisis in stocks and fisheries itself, which is why the trend must be reversed.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. I preferred to abstain on this text because, while it raises a real problem - overfishing leading to shortages - the Commission's plan is in complete contradiction with the objective of maximum sustainable performance. In addition, the Commission is increasingly giving itself prerogatives with regard to technical measures relating to fisheries, despite the principle of regionalisation of the Common Fisheries Policy. Result? Not only do member states lose their decision on this policy, but also, as Alain Cadec, chairman of the European Parliament's Fisheries Committee, has pointed out, the European Commission is thus exposed to a real institutional conflict with the elected representatives of Parliament. That is why I welcome the adoption of the amendment tabled by patriotic Members Jean-Marie le Pen and Sylvie Goddyn which will help to stem the Commission's appetite on this subject by asking it to take into account the latest scientific studies before adopting technical measures.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The multiannual plan for cod, herring and sprat stocks in the Baltic Sea and for fisheries exploiting these stocks was published by the Commission in October 2014.  The aim of the proposal is to establish a framework for the multispecies management of cod, herring and sprat stocks in the Baltic Sea where fishing is mainly aimed at these three species. The plan should also allow for the balanced and sustainable exploitation of these stocks and ensure the stability of fisheries opportunities and, consequently, of fishermen's livelihoods. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this multiannual plan because it aims to keep the size of cod, herring and sprat in the Baltic Sea above a minimum level, known as precautionary biomass. Cod, herring and sprat are important components of the Baltic Sea ecosystem and there are strong biological interactions between them. I therefore believe that the prospect of a precautionary approach is the right way forward in the future, because proper management of the stock would avoid the risk of the reproductive capacity of the stock being compromised.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as a multispecies approach is the most effective way to ensure the balanced and sustainable exploitation of Baltic fish stocks, while protecting the livelihood of fishermen. This multiannual plan for the Baltic Sea will ensure that management measures reflect the most up-to-date scientific advice to keep stock sizes within safe biological limits and will take into account the interaction between different species and the ecological needs.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the multiannual plan for cod, herring and sprat stocks in the Baltic Sea and for fisheries exploiting these stocks, believing that the multispecies management approach, as provided for in the text to be voted on, is much more effective than managing a single species at a time.  The plan should, in particular, allow for the balanced and sustainable exploitation of these stocks by ensuring a constant level of potential fishing and, consequently, the livelihood of fishermen. At the same time, the aim of the new plan is to promote more conscious management of stocks, fisheries and ecosystem through expert advice and the support of scientific advice.  Finally, I believe that the decision to use a regionalised approach, with regard to the introduction of detailed measures to achieve maximum sustainable yield, will allow a more timely reaction to sudden changes affecting the state of the stocks in question.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Multiannual plans for fisheries management are an essential tool to ensure the sustainable exploitation of fish stocks and marine ecosystems, and also offer fishermen increased predictability over the long run. The multispecies management approach is considerably more effective than management of single species. The plan should provide for balanced, sustainable exploitation of stocks and thereby for the livelihoods of fishermen. I have thus voted in favour

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against because the CFP provides for multiannual plans for fisheries management in the various areas.  The plans place fishing limits on the various species, so that stocks remain above maximum sustainable yield. The Baltic Plan is very important because it is the first and will act as a 'model' for everyone else. The European Parliament has amended the table with the limits prepared by the Commission, with a more restrictive and scientific data-based approach produced at the end of March, which is therefore very up-to-date.  I voted against because one of the objectives of the CFP is the phasing out of all discards (i.e. fish caught and thrown away, dead, because they are not marketable). This is something completely new and that is why the debate on this draft regulation has been very complex. After the trialogues, this act turned into a missed opportunity. The result has been to distort nature itself and has made the results very poor.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report refers to the multiannual fisheries management plan for the Baltic Sea which applies to cod, herring and sprim stocks. This management plan replaces the previous one for cod stocks. Cod, herring and sprim are the subject of important fish in the Baltic Sea. Until now, there was no management plan for herring and sprcy, which hindered the sustainability of its stocks and the stability of fishing opportunities for its fishermen. However, this plan does not sufficiently guarantee the protection of various marine species. It is not guaranteed that they do not exceed the lower limit corresponding to the maximum sustainable yield for the adoption of delegated acts relating to specific conservation measures for the conservation of flox, sole, turbot and remol and to minimise bycatch of birds, mammals or marine reptiles, as ices' scientific opinion has indicated that the current operating rates of some of these populations are not consistent with the achievement of maximum yield Sustainable. However, the amendments were not adopted. That's why I voted against it.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal for a regulation establishing a multiannual plan for cod, herring and sprat stocks in the Baltic Sea and for fisheries exploiting these stocks aims to ensure that fisheries and aquaculture activities are economically and environmentally sustainable in the long term.  The multispecies management plan established by the Regulation requires greater account to be taken of the different ecological functions and roles of the species covered by the plan. Over and above the apparent technicality of the matter, this is an important vote because it seeks to protect an important part of our ecosystem. Safeguarding the sea from indiscriminate fishing is the best way to protect the balance of the system and ensure its long-term sustainability.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Commission proposal and in favour of moving the vote about the legislative resolution to a later stage. I believe that, being the first multiannual plan under the reformed Common Fisheries Policy, it must ensure environmental, economic and social sustainability and respect the precautionary and the eco-system-based approach to fisheries management.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the main orientation of the Commission's proposal that a multi-species management plan is needed in the Baltic Sea is correct.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report aims to implement the Multi-Year Management Plan for the Baltic, for cod, herring and spart. This is the first multi-year plan designed under the new Common Fisheries Policy. In particular, this report allows the Commission to propose targeted mortality targets to regulate the catch rate based on the latest available scientific advice and allowing stocks to be exploited above the maximum sustainable yield. It should be noted that the negotiation was difficult due to an institutional conflict over the legal basis of the report, as the Council wished to decide alone in a special legislative procedure, while Parliament and the Commission advocated a codecision procedure, and a judicial procedure was under way. Considering that both on the substance and on the form of the report, it is important that the political agreement reached in the last Parliament and ratified by the vote on the reform of the Common Fisheries Policy is respected on the one hand, and on the other hand, that the new powers in the European Parliament in fisheries policy be exercised under the Lisbon Treaty. , I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I support an innovative approach to managing cod, herring and sprat stocks that takes into account inter-species interactions. This puts us on the path to exploiting ecosystem-friendly stocks in the Baltic Sea.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The aim of the proposal is to establish a framework of rules for the multispecies management of cod, herring and sprat stocks in the Baltic Sea where fishing activity is mainly aimed at these three species.  The Baltic Sea is a virtually closed body of water in which cod, herring and sprat are ubiquitous and continuously interact with each other. I voted in favour of this proposal because it was essential to have legislation to protect these three species that are fundamental to the Ecosystem of the Baltic Sea.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. By voting on the multi-year plan for the Baltic Sea cod, herring and sprat stocks and fisheries exploiting these stocks, the European Parliament voted for the first time on the deployment of tools from the new Common Fisheries Policy, as reformed in 2014.  Today, European fisheries resources, including in the Baltic Sea, are threatened by overfishing. This plan must therefore aim to organise a more sustainable fishery in the Baltic Sea, in order to preserve this important economic sector of the European Union in the medium and long term.  This plan also recognizes and preserves traditional fishing techniques, which will allow small-scale, artisanal and coastal fishing to be perpetuated under good conditions.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. Since 2008, we have had a plan to manage cod stocks in the Baltic to keep stocks within reasonable limits. In other words, maximum catches are determined and a series of technical measures are adopted taking into account the characteristics of each stock, the fisheries in which it is located and the economic impact of the measures on the fisheries concerned. The 2008 plan did not cover herring and sprat. The new plan therefore replaces the previous provisions, which is justified insofar as the stocks concerned are interdependent (cod eat sprats and herring, while herring and sprat sometimes feed on cod eggs). This new plan is an important step in the implementation of the reform of the Common Fisheries Policy. Multi-year management and the fact that these three interacting species will now be managed by a single plan should make fishing in the Baltic Sea more sustainable by increasing predictability, which I agree.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the multiannual plan for stocks of cod, herring and sprat in the Baltic Sea and their fisheries.  It is clear from this report that 30% of the earth's seas are overfished and that the survival of marine fish stocks could be at risk. Justified steps to maintain marine fish stocks will result in a continuous and significant reduction in the amount of marine fish fish fished. Therefore, the common fisheries policy should pay much more attention to sustainable fish farming, i.e. aquaculture, and in particular freshwater fish farming. A significant number of fish ponds in Hungary are located in Natura 2000 sites. These farms do not pose any threat to the natural assets of these areas. Moreover, in many cases it is precisely because of our closed-system fish ponds that they have created or preserved individual wetland associations. Consequently, freshwater aquaculture should be freed from unduly stringent and unnecessary sustainability standards, which are justified only for sea fishing. Efforts should already be made to clearly define the concept and regulation of freshwater aquaculture.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. I abstained on this multi-year plan for the Baltic Sea cod, herring and sprat fisheries. Many technical measures are delegated to the Commission, which is a problem for many Members. Mr Cadec, Chairman of the Fisheries Committee, mentions an inevitable institutional conflict between the Commission and Parliament, because Parliament is giving up too much of its prerogatives to entrust them to the Commission, despite the principle of regionalisation of the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP). In fact, an amendment by the National Front, adopted in committee, calls on the European Commission to take more account of recent scientific studies in order to more precisely adapt quotas to the reality on the ground.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. – The British Conservative delegation recognises that there is a need for a fisheries management plan in Baltic waters and approves of the multi-species approach taken in this plan.  However, the British Conservative Delegation has concerns that the Baltic Plan is not consistent with Article 3 (b) and (f) of the reformed CFP which advocates a regional approach and the involvement of the appropriate Advisory Councils. Whist we have no opposition to the Baltic Sea Plan, we believe that only the eight Member States with direct fishing interests in the Baltic Sea, along with the Baltic Advisory Council, should be involved in establishing specific FMSY ranges, lists of exploited species and eco-system management.  We are alarmed by the variety of FMSY ranges which have been tabled by three different political groups and do not believe that this process is the best approach to regulating fishing activity in the Baltic Sea; we believe the establishment of such ranges is best left to those who work in an expert capacity on Baltic Sea stocks. For this reason, the British Conservative delegation has abstained on all elements of this vote as well as the final vote.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the Commission's proposal, as amended by the European Parliament, because I agree on the need for adequate protection of fish stocks and on the subsequent adoption of legislative measures to exploit and maintain the sustainability of our fishing fleets.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This vote was of a special value since it was the first multiannual plan in the context of the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) after its restructuring. This vote is therefore an opportunity to ensure Parliament's role in implementing the CFP reform and to reduce overfishing of species above their minimum population regeneration threshold.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. The amendments tabled deserve my agreement as they give more consistency to the initial text, namely creating conditions for greater control in the capture and identification of new species or species at risk of extinction. Moreover, with this new wording, greater attention is paid to the different roles of the species covered by this diploma and, at the same time, a decision on the priority of the species to be captured is envisaged.

name: Edouard Ferrand (NI)
text: In writing. I abstained on this report because, in general, the power given to the Commission in the area of control of fisheries resources is exorbitant in relation to Parliament's prerogatives.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report imposes amendments to what will be the first multiannual regional plan produced in accordance with the reformed Common Fisheries Policy and which, to some extent, will condition those that follow it. The plan enables a regional approach from the point of view of the Member States, even if always under the responsibility of the Commission and the Council, and they are ultimately responsible for defining sub-sector measures. Aligned with the philosophy and central objectives of the CFP, it assumes its restrictive and reductive view, although adjusted to the available scientific knowledge, with measures of conditioning, or even stopping, of catches. It neglects the involvement of the sector and the different actors as privileged agents interested in the management of resources on which they depend. It also neglects the economic aspect, from the point of view of the implementation of measures enabling the recovery of fish, as a contribution to management by reducing fishing effort.  Containing appropriate measures for the management of the resources of that region but leaving aside aspects that we consider relevant, we believe that abstention would be the most appropriate sense of vote.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 In view of the strong impact of biological interactions and environmental effects on cod, herring and sprat stocks in the Baltic Sea, it is necessary to adapt their rates and techniques to new scientific knowledge on interactions and changes in environmental conditions. Such an approach would also be in line with the ecosystem approach to fisheries management. The European Commission's proposal also foresees that the regulation will include rules on by-catches of plaice fish, which may appear in significant quantities as by-catches when cod is caught.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the failure of the CFP and the damage caused by the centralisation of Brussels, I will remain cautious about the 'multispecies' approach.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the Amendment proposed by the European Parliament to the Commission's report, because I agree with the adequate protection of fish stocks and the subsequent adoption of legislative measures to exploit and maintain the sustainability of fishing fleets.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ A management plan for the Baltic Sea cod stocks has been in place since 2007, but the stocks of herring and sprat are not yet subject to a management plan. The current proposal is the first multiannual plan under the reformed common fisheries policy (CFP). It aims to ensure sustainable exploitation of stocks of cod, herring and sprat, and provide stability for fishing opportunities, while ensuring that management is based on the most up-to-date scientific information on interactions within and between the stocks and with other aspects of the ecosystem and environment. This is the first multiannual plan under the reformed CFP which will serve as a model for upcoming multiannual plans. I support the adoption of the report, as it is in line with the objectives of the CFP to ensure environmental, economic and social sustainability and respect the precautionary and ecosystem-based approach to fisheries management.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the objective of the proposal, which is to establish a multi-specific management framework for the stocks of cod, herring and spreck in the Baltic Sea, where fishing activity is mainly focused on the three species mentioned. Cod, herring and sprim have made up more than 94% of Baltic catches in recent years. It is of the utmost importance to develop a regulation that takes into account the interactions between the affected species. It is necessary to monitor the rates and patterns of exploitation of these populations based on advances in scientific knowledge of interactions and changes in environmental conditions.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. I agree with the proposal by Jarosław Wałęsa and the Committee on Fisheries on the proposal to adopt, as soon as possible, a multiannual plan for cod, herring and sprat stocks in the Baltic Sea.  In fact, I believe that being able to think about multispecies management of these stocks, which account for 94% of catches in a sea with an exceptionally sensitive ecosystem, is a truly innovative concept of the fisheries plan. I am therefore voting in favour, particularly because of the strong experimental nature of the project, which aims to achieve balanced and sustainable exploitation of stocks, while also guaranteeing a stable fishing opportunity.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I have today voted in favour of the remittal of the multiannual plan for cod, herring and sprat stocks in the Baltic Sea and for the fisheries that fish these stocks to the competent committee, partly because it sets out management plans that specifically impose fishing days, closed seasons, mesh sizes and minimum dimensions on fishermen. I mean, it must be left to the fishermen when they want to fish the quantity allocated to them. Once they have used up their fishing days – currently, for example, there are 147 days for cod – they have no way of using their quota. No fisherman can feed his family.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ President, I gave my support to the Wałęsa report because it is vital that we ensure the sustainable exploitation of cod, herring and sprat while providing stability for fishing opportunities.  I applaud the fact that through this report, for the first time, we have implemented the principle that the amounts of fish caught are limited to their capacity to reproduce, and that these values are based on the latest scientific advice.  I hope the Council will prove it has grasped the urgency for a more sustainable approach by backing the ambitious measures called for by this house and support its use as a blueprint for the next management plans for fish stocks in other regions.

name: Julie Girling (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ As the first multi-annual plan under the reformed CFP, the Baltic Sea plan will set a precedent – intended or not – for future multi-annual plans. It is therefore essential that the Baltic Sea plan maintains the ambition set out in the CFP, and is effective in its overall objective of restoring stocks of cod, herring and sprat, as well as ensuring that there are plans in place to maintain healthy stock levels of the compromised species of plaice, flounder, turbot and brill.  I was initially concerned that the Commission’s proposal did not make any allowance for FMSY ranges and indirectly appeared to condone overfishing – in contravention of the objectives of the reformed CFP.  I strongly supported the position of the Fisheries Committee to set the upper limit of fishing mortality rates as FMSY, and therefore I have supported all amendments to Article 4 which improve the Commission text. The inclusion of exploitation rates of FMSY as the upper limit for mortality is urgently required to promote sustainable fisheries in Baltic waters.  I have also supported a number of amendments which promote the protection of sea birds and marine mammals in keeping with the EU’s Marine Strategy Framework.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the multiannual plan (MAP) for the stocks of cod, herring and sprat in the Baltic Sea and the fisheries exploiting those stocks. The Baltic MAP should ensure that the negative impact of fishing activities on the marine ecosystem is minimised and avoid destruction of the marine environment. This includes minimising the impact on seabirds, marine mammals and the integrity of the seabed.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report because it is very important to ensure that the ultimate goal of restoring and maintaining fish stocks above maximum sustainable yield is effectively and fully enforced.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council establishing a multiannual plan for stocks of cod, herring and sprats in the Baltic Sea and fisheries exploiting these stocks, amending Council Regulation (EC) No 2013/2013. 2187/2005 and on the repeal of Council Regulation (EC) No 2187/2005. 1098/2007 It is an important multiannual management plan that takes into account several species that are interconnected and interacting. It is also important because these three species - cod, herring and sprats in the Baltic Sea account for over 94% of catches in recent years, and there are risks of overfishing and ecosystem consequences due to baltic sealing. Such a plan may serve to develop other fish stock management and exploitation plans in other seas and in fish interacting with each other.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. I abstained on this multi-year plan for the Baltic Sea cod, herring and sprat fisheries. Many technical measures are delegated to the Commission, which is a problem for many Members. Mr Cadec, Chairman of the Fisheries Committee, mentions an inevitable institutional conflict between the Commission and Parliament, because Parliament is giving up too much of its prerogatives to entrust them to the Commission, despite the principle of regionalisation of the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP). In fact, a National Front amendment selected in committee commits the Commission to take more account of recent scientific studies in order to more precisely adapt quotas to the reality on the ground.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Jarosaw Wasa's report on the Multi-Year Plan establishing a framework for the management of cod, herring and sprat stocks in the Baltic Sea. This plan, based on the latest scientific advice, should enable the sustainable exploitation of stocks, thus guaranteeing livelihoods for fishermen, which is why I hope that an agreement will be reached quickly with the Council and the European Commission.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which provides for a multi-year plan for the stocks of cod, herring and sprat in the Baltic Sea.   This plan should ensure the achievement of the objectives of the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) and enable sustainable exploitation of fish stocks.
