In addition, this plan should contribute to the conservation of other marine species such as plaice, beard, flounder and turbot. Finally, it must help to stop releases and reduce accidental catches.

name: Jarosław Kalinowski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Fishing in the Baltic Sea was heavily intensified in the second half of the 20th century. By the end of the century, this had led to over-exploitation of herds, as can be seen from more than 400,000 tonnes caught each year in the early 1980s to around 40,000 tonnes ten years later. In recent decades, studies have shown that overfishing concerns dozens of fish species living in the Baltic Sea, which threatens their extinction and biodiversity imbalance. Therefore, the common fisheries policy (established in the 1970s as part of the common agricultural policy and formally in place since 1983) is intended to manage EU fish stocks and to ensure a fair income and a level playing field for fishermen from the Member States. As herring, cod and sprat are the main fish species caught in the Baltic Sea, the proposed multiannual plan for these stocks has become multi-species. This will make it possible to develop a broader approach to fisheries control issues, taking into line with the relationship between these species. This is certainly a good strategy, allowing for the efficient management of fishing quotas and guaranteeing a balanced approach, based on the most up-to-date scientific data on stocks and the Baltic ecosystem.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI)
text: Writing. As this report aims at more sustainable management and fishing of the Baltic Sea, it is necessary to vote in favour of this motion.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Committee on Fisheriesʼ report on the Commission proposal for a regulation establishing a multiannual plan for the stocks of cod, herring and sprat in the Baltic Sea and the fisheries exploiting those stocks (2014/0285 (COD)).  I am relieved as the report showed its understanding of regional particularities. The Baltic Sea, and especially the Gulf of Riga, has a very particular ecosystem. This was recognised from the start in the provisions which guaranteed within the framework of the Treaty of Accession implementation of specific measures to safeguard resources in the Gulf of Riga – a sensitive eco-region of the Baltic Sea. The Commissionʼs original proposal to open up the Gulf to all fishing fleets would have seriously damaged and possibly even destroyed the fragile ecosystem with a consequent direct threat to the existing cod, herring and sprat stock.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as a multispecies approach is the most effective way to ensure the balanced and sustainable exploitation of Baltic fish stocks, while protecting the livelihood of fishermen. This multiannual plan for the Baltic Sea will ensure that management measures reflect the most up-to-date scientific advice to keep stock sizes within safe biological limits and will take into account the interaction between different species and ecological needs.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, as for the first time we have implemented the principle that the amounts of fish caught are limited to their capacity to reproduce and that these values are based on the latest scientific advice. In that sense, the multiannual plan for the Baltic Sea could serve as a blueprint for the next management plans for fish stocks in other regions. Multiannual plans under the reformed common fisheries policy (CFP) must be in line with the objectives of the CFP to ensure environmental, economic and social sustainability and respect the precautionary and the ecosystem-based approach to fisheries management.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the multiannual plan for stocks of cod, herring and sprat in the Baltic Sea and their fisheries.  It is clear from this report that 30% of the earth's seas are overfished and that the survival of marine fish stocks could be at risk. Justified steps to maintain marine fish stocks will result in a continuous and significant reduction in the amount of marine fish fish fished. Therefore, the common fisheries policy should pay much more attention to sustainable fish farming, i.e. aquaculture, and in particular freshwater fish farming. A significant number of fish ponds in Hungary are located in Natura 2000 sites. These farms do not pose any threat to the natural assets of these areas. Moreover, in many cases it is precisely because of our closed-system fish ponds that they have created or preserved individual wetland associations. Consequently, freshwater aquaculture should be freed from unduly stringent and unnecessary sustainability standards, which are justified only for sea fishing. Efforts should already be made to clearly define the concept and regulation of freshwater aquaculture.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. We are well aware of the situation in Nigeria. This nation is the largest economy on the African continent, as well as one of the EU's main trading partners.  I strongly condemn, together with Parliament's strong voice, the increasingly alarming acts of violence and call for concerted efforts to be made at international level to put an end to the bloodshed. We support the Nigerian Government in its efforts to combat the threat of Boko Haram, calling on it to conduct a thorough investigation and to take appropriate measures, in accordance with the rule of law, against those involved in human rights abuses.

name: Philippe Loiseau (NI)
text: In writing. Abstention. The aim of this report is to put in place measures to combat the effects of overfishing that endanger stocks of cod, herring and sprat in the Baltic Sea. This is a reality based on scientific studies. Having said that, we criticise the fact that Parliament is once again ensuring that Member States are given the opportunity to participate in decision-making. However, the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) provides for a regionalization of the management of fisheries-related problems. In addition, the measures taken correspond to an accumulation of constraints for fishermen. MEPs Sylvie Goddyn and Jean Marie Le Pen have tried by amendment to ensure that the measures are only taken after recent scientific studies. This would have had the advantage of consistency. Parliament has decided otherwise. For these reasons I abstain.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. Cod, herring and sprim are the subject of important fish in the Baltic Sea. The aim of the proposal is to establish a single management plan for cod, herring and sprpadine stocks in the Baltic Sea. This plan will promote the sustainable exploitation of the populations concerned and offer stable fishing opportunities, while ensuring management based on the latest scientific information. Spain has no direct interests in the Baltic Sea; however, this process is followed to ensure that there is consistency in how EU water populations are managed regardless of their location. In fact, there is a widespread view that this plan is important, as it will serve as a 'template' for those who will come next.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report refers to the multiannual fisheries management plan for the Baltic Sea which applies to cod, herring and sprim stocks. This management plan replaces the previous one for cod stocks. Cod, herring and sprim are the subject of important fish in the Baltic Sea. Until now, there was no management plan for herring and sprcy, which hindered the sustainability of its stocks and the stability of fishing opportunities for its fishermen. However, this plan does not sufficiently guarantee the protection of various marine species. It is not guaranteed that they do not exceed the lower limit corresponding to the maximum sustainable yield for the adoption of delegated acts relating to specific conservation measures for the conservation of flox, sole, turbot and remol and to minimise bycatch of birds, mammals or marine reptiles, as ices' scientific opinion has indicated that the current operating rates of some of these populations are not consistent with the achievement of maximum yield Sustainable. However, the amendments were not adopted. That's why I voted against it.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ 94 percent of total Baltic Sea harvests are cod, herring and sprats. This report aims to ensure a balanced exploitation of stocks, while taking into account the interaction and impact of these three species and the sustainability of the entire ecosystem. I support mp Wałęsa's report agreeing with the Commission's proposal that a management plan for all fish species in the Baltic Sea is needed as this approach is more effective.  Such a plan should ensure optimal exploitation of harvesting and stability of fishing in the Baltic Sea. Detailed scientific research should be done to determine the current state of fish species in the Baltic Sea, their role in the ecosystem and to determine the period when fishing is prohibited. As this is a lengthy process, we can conclude that this is only the beginning of the creation of a single marine ecosystem management plan, which should be an example for other seas.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 The report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a multiannual plan for the stocks of cod, herring and papalina in the Baltic Sea and for the fishing activities of those stocks, amending Regulation (EC) No 1782/2003 laying down detailed rules for the application of Council Regulation (EC) No 1782/2003 as regards the common agricultural activities of the European Union This Regulation should therefore be repealed. It is insufficient because the stocks of herring and papalina are not yet covered by a management plan. Cod, herring and papalina are important elements of the Baltic ecosystem. Since cod is a predator of herring and papalina, the size of the cod stock affects the size of herring and papalina stocks, and vice versa. The effects on flat-footed fish in particular of cod fishing should also be covered by the plan.

name: Dominique Martin (NI)
text: In writing. Dominique Martin abstained on this vote. Although progress has been made since the original text, this plan still presents too many constraints for fishermen. Member States are excluded from the decision-making process in favour of the European Commission, which we cannot support.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In October 2014, the Commission published its multiannual plan for cod, herring and sprat stocks in the Baltic Sea and for fisheries exploiting these stocks. The aim of the proposal is to establish a framework for the multispecies management of stocks in the Baltic Sea where fishing activity is mainly aimed at these three species. Cod, herring and sprat account for 94% of catches in the Baltic Sea in recent years. I supported the Wałęsa report which, in addition to agreeing with the general orientation of the Commission's proposal with regard to the need for a multispecies management plan in the Baltic Sea, agrees with the approach adopted by the Commission that the further specification of the measures necessary to achieve maximum sustainable yield for the stocks concerned should take place on the basis of the regionalised approach provided for in the reform of the common fisheries policy.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the proposal to establish a multiannual plan for the stocks of cod, herring and sprat in the Baltic Sea and for the fisheries that fish these stocks, as this will ensure the sustainable management of these stocks and the constant fishing opportunities and, therefore, a constant livelihood for fishermen.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as a multispecies approach is the most effective way to ensure the balanced and sustainable exploitation of Baltic fish stocks, while protecting the livelihood of fishermen. This multiannual plan for the Baltic Sea will ensure that management measures reflect the most up-to-date scientific advice to keep stock sizes within safe biological limits and will take into account the interaction between different species and ecological needs.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The general thrust of the Commission proposal, that there is a need for a multi-species management plan in the Baltic Sea, is right. The multi-species management approach is much more effective than a management of single species. The plan should provide for a balanced, sustainable exploitation of those stocks and the stability of fishing opportunities – and thereby of the livelihoods of fishers. At the same time it should guarantee that the management would be based on the most up-to-date scientific advice regarding the status of stocks covered, interactions between species and other aspects related to ecosystem and fisheries.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Cod, herring and sprat are the subject of important fisheries in the Baltic Sea. Although a management plan for Baltic Cod stocks has been in place since 2007, herring and sprat stocks are not yet subject to a management plan. This hinders the sustainable management of these fisheries and does not guarantee the stability of fishing opportunities for fishermen operating in these fisheries. The proposal aims to establish a management plan for cod, herring and sprat stocks in the Baltic Sea. This plan should ensure the sustainable exploitation of these stocks and ensure the stability of fishing opportunities, while ensuring that management is based on the latest scientific information regarding interactions within stocks, between stocks and with other elements of the ecosystem and environment. It is regrettable that other marine species (turtles, seagulls, etc.) are not included in this plan, but this initiative is in the direction of better conservation of resources. I vote FOR

name: Joëlle Mélin (NI)
text: In writing. Many technical measures are delegated to the Commission, which is a problem for many MEPs. Mr Cadec, Chairman of the Fisheries Committee, mentions an inevitable institutional conflict between the Commission and Parliament, because Parliament is giving up too much of its prerogatives to entrust them to the Commission, despite the principle of regionalisation of the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP).     In fact, a National Front amendment selected in committee commits the Commission to take more account of recent scientific studies in order to more precisely adapt quotas to the reality on the ground. I abstained.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The multiannual plan for stocks of cod, herring and sprat in the Baltic Sea and for fisheries exploiting these stocks was published by the European Commission in October 2014. The aim of the proposal is to establish a framework for the management of multiple species of cod, herring and sprat stocks in the Baltic Sea, where fishing focuses mainly on these three species. Cod, herring and sprat account for more than 94 % of catches in the Baltic Sea in recent years. The Baltic Sea is a nearly closed body of water, in which these three species are ubiquitous and interact continuously. It is therefore extremely important to ensure regulation to recognise the interactions between the species concerned, in particular the influence of cod on herring and sprat stocks and the reverse. The plan should provide for a balanced and sustainable exploitation of these stocks and the stability of fishing opportunities, and, consequently, of the livelihoods of fishermen. At the same time, it shall ensure that management is based on the most recent scientific advice on the state of the stocks concerned, interactions between species and other aspects related to ecosystems and fisheries. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it supports the Commission’s multi-species management approach. It takes into account the balanced and sustainable exploitation of the species concerned but also the livelihoods of those employed in the fishing sector. The rapporteur also highlights the level of flexibility presented by the Commission, which is crucial for the ecosystem and also to allow new scientific approaches and data to be quickly taken on board and alter the management approach for the better.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this plan, which is the first multiannual plan under the reformed CFP. It aims to ensure the sustainable exploitation of the stocks of cod, herring and sprat, and provide stability of fishing opportunities, while ensuring that management is based on the most up to date scientific information on interactions within and between the stocks and with other aspects of the ecosystem and environment.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The main objective of this report in the Committee on Fisheries is to establish a multi-species fishing plan taking into account the existing dynamics of cod, herring and sprat stocks, as well as species caught as by-catches in fisheries of those stocks, in particular flounder, rosehead, stone flounder and Baltic Sea turbot.  I support the report in question, arguing that the Multiannual Plan should contribute to rebuilding, reaching and maintaining the populations of the species concerned at acceptable levels of sustainability, in addition to minimising, as far as possible, the impact on other species such as seabirds and the marine environment in general. I also believe that the European Commission should take into account the opinion of the advisory councils when it comes to the adoption of technical measures to monitor the multiannual plan.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. This report warns of the risks of overfishing of the Baltic Sea cod, herring and sprat stocks, which are at risk.  There are two problems to be identified. The first relates to the current exploitation of stocks, which is inconsistent with the goal of maximum sustainable yield in the opinion of several scientists. The second concerns the delegation to the Commission of many technical measures, which excludes states from decision-making, despite the principle of regionalisation of the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP). However, an amendment had been tabled in the Committee on Fisheries for the Commission to take scientific studies into account before adopting technical measures, in order to prevent fishermen from being knocked out by heavy restrictions and regulations. I therefore abstained in the vote on this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Baltic multiannual plan is the first of its kind (a multi-species plan, rather than a single species plan) under the new common fisheries policy. Given that this plan sets a number of precedents for the forthcoming plans (including the larger and more complicated North Sea plan), there is a great desire from all parties to ensure this first plan is according to their vision.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text on the multi-year management plan for cod, herring and sprat stocks in the Baltic Sea. These 3 species account for more than 94% of the catch in the Baltic. The management plan takes into account the biological interactions between the three species (cod being predators of the other two) and will allow for a more balanced and sustainable management of stocks.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome the general orientation of the Commission's proposal with regard to the need for a multispecies management plan in the Baltic Sea.  The plan should be able to allow for the balanced and sustainable exploitation of these stocks and ensure the stability of fishing opportunities and, consequently, of fishermen's livelihoods. At the same time, it should ensure that management is based on the most up-to-date scientific advice regarding the state of the stocks covered, interactions between species and other aspects related to the ecosystem and fisheries in general. We therefore consider it essential, in order to achieve maximum sustainable yield for the stocks concerned, to refer to a regionalised approach, enshrined in Article 18 of the basic regulation.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Cod, herring and sprat are the subject of important fishing activities in the Baltic Sea.  The scientific opinion of the International Council for the Exploration of the Sea (ICES) indicates that for some of these stocks the current exploitation rates are not compatible with the achievement of maximum sustainable yield. This proposal therefore pursues the specific objective of ensuring the sustainable exploitation of stocks of these species in the Baltic Sea, in accordance with the principle of maximum sustainable yield and in line with the ecosystem approach to fisheries management. The plan will apply to all EU fishing vessels operating in the Baltic Sea. In the light of the above, I have decided to support the proposal because, in my opinion, the common fisheries policy must contribute to the protection of the marine environment, to the sustainable management of all commercially exploited species and, in particular, to the achievement of good ecological status by 2020, as provided for in Article 1(1) of Directive 2008/56/EC.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union is a Contracting Party to the United Nations Convention of 10 December 1982 on the Law of the Sea. The Convention lays down obligations to maintain and conserve certain fish species so that they can be exploited at levels that ensure maximum long-term production.  I voted for this report on the EP regulation and the Council because it introduces a number of amendments aimed at restoring, achieving and maintaining the populations of the species concerned above the levels that allow maximum sustainable production for those stocks.

name: James Nicholson (ECR)
text: in writing. – This proposal intends to establish a framework for the fisheries management of cod, herring and sprat (the three primary catches in the Baltic Sea). Previously, each of these three had been managed separately. This multiannual plan (MAP) is the first management plan since reform of the common fisheries policy (CFP) and is the Baltic Sea’s first multi-species plan. Northern Ireland does not have any direct fishing interests in the Baltic, but securing progress on this management plan will aid the development of any multiannual plans directly relevant to Northern Ireland. The Commission intends to produce a multiannual plan for the North Sea, so this MAP for the Baltic Sea is important in that it sets a precedent for future MAPs. I was therefore happy to support the report.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. The multiannual plan for stocks of cod, herring and sprat in the Baltic Sea is the first new plan among the new common fisheries stocks. This plan is intended to bring clear objectives and predictability for fishermen. The common fisheries policy pursues the common objective of long-term economic viability. Fisheries and aquaculture must be environmentally sound and socially sustainable. Only in this way will European citizens benefit from healthier food and a better quality of life. That is why I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Considering the Commission's proposal to the European Parliament and the Council and the report by the Committee on Fisheries, I voted in favour.

name: Florian Philippot (NI)
text: In writing. Many technical measures are delegated to the Commission, which is a problem for many MEPs. The Chairman of the Fisheries Committee, Mr Cadec, mentions an inevitable institutional conflict between the Commission and Parliament on this issue. The text also provides far too many constraints for fishermen and does not take enough account of their difficulties. This plan is symptomatic of a Parliament that renounces its prerogatives and entrusts them to the Commission and excludes states from decision-making, despite the principle of regionalisation of the Common Fisheries Policy. However, to the extent that the situation of fish stocks is really very worrying, I prefer to abstain.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support the report on the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council establishing a multiannual plan for cod, herring and sprat stocks in the Baltic Sea and fisheries exploiting these stocks amending Council Regulation (EC) No 2013/2013. 2187/2005 and repeals Council Regulation (EC) No 2087/2005. 1098/2007. This is the first multiannual plan that will serve as a model for all upcoming as part of the Common Fishing Policy of the European Union, as the primary objective contains measures on the protection of fish species above the level enabling the sustainability of them based also on a principle based on the sustainability of the overall eco-system and the management of fish stocks.  While the rapporteur advocates a 'softened' version of the proposal to conserve stocks of these species, this report certainly deserves our support and will serve as an appropriate model for future proposals to set out a multiannual plan for fish stocks and in other European seas.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support a multiannual plan for fishing in the Baltic Sea. According to the reports of the current state of fish species and their inter-relationship in the ecosystem, it is evident that there is a need to revise the regulations adopted in 2009. A plan with priority is three starting points: 1. biological relationship between three main fish species: cod, herring and sprat, 2. accurate determination of maximum harvesting that does not endanger reproductive stock units and 3. harvesting determined by the time period.  In addition to these criteria, it is good that proposals have been proposed to implement detailed monitoring measures for fish species in the Baltic Sea with the emphasis on the supervision of the Advisory Body (BSAC).

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that, in line with what the experts in this field have said in their reports, having a multispecies management plan in the Baltic Sea is correct. In this way, with the implementation of the plan, a more balanced and sustainable exploitation of stocks should be achieved.  At the same time, the stability of fishing opportunities and a more favourable environment for fishermen are also guaranteed. The implementation of the plan means that there are more up-to-date views on the state of the stocks covered, on ecosystem aspects and on fishing activities. It is also, of course, important that cod is protected during the breeding period and that small-scale fishing is protected. In any case, the multispecies management plan is a new concept and its review in a short time can correct any discrepansties and give it more flexibility.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. At a time when some marine species are endangered and in a context where illegal fishing remains very active, the Union must regulate and control this activity in order to ensure transparent fishing and to protect certain endangered species.  The European Parliament adopted the Walesa report on the management plan for cod, herring and sprat stocks in the Baltic Sea. I voted in favour of this text. This proposal aims in particular to concentrate fishing activities on these three species in the Baltic Sea. This plan is flexible and will adapt annually to fishing opportunities in order to better regulate and manage stocks.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament adopted an important report for the management of fisheries resources this afternoon. In this case, the Baltic Sea was chosen as the first example of the implementation of the new Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) adopted in 2013 in its multi-species management plan component.  The plan is expected to allow for a balanced and sustainable use of these stocks, particularly cod, herring and sprat, which account for more than 94% of catches in the Baltic Sea, as well as fishing opportunities and therefore resources for fishermen.  The message sent by the plenary is the right one: not only does it strengthen the Committee on Fishing in its desire to put an end to overfishing and to promote management plans, as key tools of the CFP, but it also gives the Parliament's delegation the means to negotiate in a trilogue with a strong position and to free itself from the national interests expressed in the Council.  Let us hope that the final agreement will be ambitious, as it will set precedents for all future fish stock management plans in the North Sea, the Mediterranean and the Northwest and Southwest Atlantic.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and the Council establishing a multiannual plan for stocks of cod, herring and sprat in the Baltic Sea and for fisheries exploiting those stocks is at all relevant as it establishes a specific table on the subject in question. It is important to legislate in such a way as to show that sea policy is not forgotten or ignored. The Regulation shows specific measures that will contribute to balancing the ecosystem and species concerned.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. One of the main elements of the new Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) is the multiannual management plans, which will enable long-term programming to be adopted and the specificities of each EU region, an essential element in the CFP's new regionalisation strategy, to be applied to fisheries. The objective of today's multiannual plan is to establish a single management for the stocks of cod, herring and spurin in the Baltic Sea, through their sustainable exploitation and stable fishing opportunities, ensuring management based on the latest scientific information.  Spain has no direct interests in this multiannual plan; however, it is important, given that it will serve as the basis for those who will come next, and for the sake of coherence in the way EU waters are managed. In this vote, the Spanish Socialists defended the establishment of a range of 0 to FMSY (maximum sustainable performance) according to the latest scientific data.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. The multi-year plan voted today aims to establish a framework for the multi-species management of cod, herring and sprat stocks, which account for more than 94% of the catches in the Baltic Sea in recent years. This long-awaited plan is expected to allow for a balanced and sustainable stock use and provide livelihoods for fishermen. At the same time, it should ensure management based on the latest scientific advice on the status of the stocks concerned, the interactions between species and other aspects related to the ecosystem and fisheries.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Common Fisheries Policy lays down a set of rules that apply to the management of European fishing fleets and the conservation of fisheries resources. To this extent, since stocks of fish resources are finite and others are overexploited, measures to ensure the sustainability of resources and the fishing sector itself need to be taken. The aim of this plan is: to establish an urgent framework for the management of multiple species of baltic sea stocks, cod, herring and sprat representing more than 94% of catches in the Baltic Sea in recent years. This multi-specific management approach is noticeably more effective than managing a single species and takes into account interspecies interactions. That is why I agree with this plan and believe that it should provide for the balanced and sustainable exploitation of stocks, based on responsible and foresight management, based on up-to-date scientific advice

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the multiannual plan as I agree with the objective of establishing a framework for the multispecies management of cod, herring and sprat stocks in the Baltic Sea where fishing is mainly aimed at these three species.  The Baltic Sea is a virtually closed body of water in which these three species are ubiquitous and interact continuously. It is therefore essential to draw up legislation to recognise interactions between regulated species, including the influence of cod on herring and sprat stocks and vice versa.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report refers to the multiannual fisheries management plan for the Baltic Sea which applies to cod, herring and sprim stocks. This management plan replaces the previous one for cod stocks. Cod, herring and sprim are the subject of important fish in the Baltic Sea. Until now, there was no management plan for herring and sprcy, which hindered the sustainability of its stocks and the stability of fishing opportunities for its fishermen. However, this plan does not sufficiently guarantee the protection of various marine species. It is not guaranteed that they do not exceed the lower limit corresponding to the maximum sustainable yield for the adoption of delegated acts relating to specific conservation measures for the conservation of flox, sole, turbot and remol and to minimise bycatch of birds, mammals or marine reptiles, as ices' scientific opinion has indicated that the current operating rates of some of these populations are not consistent with the achievement of maximum yield Sustainable. However, the amendments were not adopted. That's why I voted against it.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal to establish a framework for the multispecies management of cod, herring and sprat stocks in the Baltic Sea.  This is the first multiannual plan of this kind defined under the reformed common fisheries policy (CFP). I am sure that the approach adopted can ensure a more sustainable and balanced exploitation of these stocks on the basis of the most up-to-date scientific data on interactions between different fish species and with other elements of the ecosystem and the environment. In order to improve the stability and predictability of catches, I believe that it is nevertheless necessary to guarantee the plan a certain level of flexibility that will allow rapid changes to be made in the light of the evolution of the fish population envisaged. Today's vote is certainly a test case for adapting stock management to the principles of maximum sustainable yield and régionalisation on which the new CFP is based. I therefore hope that this proposal will set an example for future regional plans and help to redefine measures for the conservation of our precious marine resources and for the maintenance of stable and profitable fishing activities.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I congratulate the rapporteur on the work done and the speed of it. The European Union committed in 2002 to maintaining and restoring fish sources to levels that can produce a Maximum Sustainable Yield, on a then urgent basis and if possible no later than 2015. Now we are voting on the first Multiannual Plan and it is our obligation to make this precedent accurate and appropriate.  Many of the fish stocks need to rebuild their biomass. Thus, the fishing rate must be established at a maximum sustainable catch mortality level to ensure that current economic income does not impair its stability for the future. To ensure that maximum sustainable economic yield is resilient, a precautionary approach should be used to keep catches at levels of 10-20 % below the maximum calculated rate for fishing mortality.    Setting a target of 80 % of fishing mortality to maintain maximum sustainable yield will ensure more future than was promised in 2002. Because this report safeguards these positions, I voted positively.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted with the majority in favour of the Multiannual plan for the stocks of cod, herring and sprat in the Baltic Sea and the fisheries exploiting those stocks. The Baltic MAP should ensure that the negative impacts of fishing activities on the marine ecosystem are minimised and to avoid destruction of the marine environment. This includes minimising the impact on seabirds, marine mammals and the integrity of the seabed.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. The multi-annual fisheries management plan is very important as it will regulate the various fishing factors in the EU. At this point, I would like to highlight, above all, sustainable fishing. This is crucial for ensuring fishing activity and the long-term viability of the fisheries sector. An integrated process of collecting information, carrying out analyses, planning and consultation with fishermen is important. Only in this way will it be able to provide an environmentally friendly and sustainable way of fishing. However, I would also like to mention the importance of ecologically sustainable fisheries management. The latter is very important in order to reduce the impact of fishing on the marine environment, bearing in mind that a certain level of influence of fishing within reasonable limits is unavoidable. It should be borne in mind that pollution, excessive hunting and unsustainable fishing methods have a significant negative impact on fisheries. Pollution has been shown to cause significant damage at various stages of the marine food chain, with serious consequences also for commercial species, which therefore need to be protected. I am therefore in favour of fishing methods that respect the environment, but at the same time it is necessary to leash the possibilities of overfishing, and also to adopt measures in the event that a particular species of fish becomes threatened by excessive fishing. For this reason, I supported the report and voted in favour of its adopted by the European Parliament.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The multiannual plan for stocks of certain fish species in the Baltic Sea, for which I voted in favour, is the first such plan approved under the new Common Fisheries Policy (CFP), which entered into force in 2014. The multiannual plans should allow for balanced and sustainable long-term management of stocks of various species of fish, ensuring greater certainty for fishing activities and the controlled exploitation of fishery resources by creating the conditions for their recovery. To achieve this, multiannual plans are based on the concept of maximum sustainable yield (MSY), which consists of setting, on the basis of the latest scientific data, catch rates that allow stocks to reproduce in order to ensure their exploitation under economically and environmentally sustainable conditions. In view of the future preparation of the long-term plan for the Mediterranean and given the particular level of overfishing in this basin, it is important that we have voted on this first plan, thanks to which Parliament presents itself with a strong position to protect the environment and fisheries in negotiations with the Council.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported a multiannual plan for cod, herring and sprat stocks in the Baltic Sea and fisheries exploiting these stocks. The Union has an obligation to preserve, including the maintenance or restoration of populations of caught species at levels capable of producing maximum sustainable yield. The aim is to lay down a fisheries plan for a large number of species taking into account the dynamics between cod stocks, herring and sprats and the treatment of species in fisheries on these stocks, i.e. leaf of goldpies, chipboard, sheaths and leaf smooth in the Baltic.  The objective of this plan should be to restore, achieve and maintain populations of the species in question above levels capable of producing maximum sustainable yield for the stocks in question by reducing, as far as possible, the impact on other species such as seabirds and on the wider marine environment.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as a whole. The new Baltic multiannual fisheries plan is the first of its kind and will be beneficial in a number of areas, for example on conservation and minimising the impact of fisheries on the wider environment.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. – Fisheries are one of the core branches of the economy for most Baltic countries. It is subject to the influence of various biotic and abiotic factors that condition its unfolding and direct its development. In order to properly manage and protect renewable resources, it is necessary to take into account biotechnological, technical, economic, legal and all other aspects, which decisively affect the development of fisheries. In the last few years, large-time fishing of undersea specimens has been recorded, which calls into question the diversity of species and the devastation of the underwater world. Cod, herring and sprats in the Baltic Sea are the subject of important fisheries. The current exploitation rates for some of these stocks are incompatible with achieving the highest sustainable yield, and the best possible solution is needed to ensure sustainable exploitation of stocks without harming fishermen by introducing unchievable quotas.  I therefore support the proposal to establish a plan for the management of cod, herring and sprat stocks in the Baltic, as the plan should ensure sustainable fisheries while paying attention to biological and environmental benefits. That is why it is necessary to cooperate with the profession and base the management on the latest scientific information.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal because it contributes to a more efficient functioning of the current legislation on the fish in question and, in view of the possibilities feasible in practice, also leads to the realisation of some provisions of the multiannual plan.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The protection of fish stocks and the adoption of legislative measures to exploit and maintain the sustainability of fishing fleets are actions moving in the right direction.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the multiannual plan for stocks of cod, herring and sprat in the Baltic Sea and their fisheries. It is clear from this report that 30% of the earth's seas are overfished and that the survival of marine fish stocks could be at risk. Justified steps to maintain marine fish stocks will result in a continuous and significant reduction in the amount of marine fished. Therefore, the common fisheries policy should pay much more attention to sustainable fish farming, i.e. aquaculture, and in particular freshwater fish farming.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Regulating fisheries rules in the Baltic Sea area is of extraordinary importance. It is a small body of water with relatively limited natural resources. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the proposed draft regulation. However, I believe that it is important not only the rules themselves, but also the adoption of fair standards and their distribution among the countries benefiting from the benefits of the Baltic Sea. When implementing the new standards, it is also necessary to ensure effective control of fisheries so that the adoption of legislation at European Union level has a measurable effect both for businesses and consumers and for the environment.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I agree with the general idea contained in the Commission's proposal that a multi-species management plan in the Baltic Sea is necessary. The multi-species approach is much more effective than a single-species approach. The plan is expected to allow for a balanced and sustainable use of these stocks as well as stable fishing opportunities - and therefore resources for fishermen. At the same time, it should ensure management based on the latest scientific advice on the status of the stocks involved, the interactions between species and other aspects related to the ecosystem and fisheries.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report aiming to restore and maintain conservation of Baltic cod, herring and sprat and to ensure that stocks are exploited sustainably so that maximum sustainable yield can be achieved as soon as possible.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the report setting out a multiannual plan for cod, herring and sprat stocks in the Baltic Sea and fisheries exploiting these stocks, as I believe it properly regulates the framework for managing these stocks.  This is necessary because it is these three species that account for more than 94 per cent of catches in the Baltic Sea in recent years. In addition, this regulation is very important given that these three species lead continuous interaction in the Baltic Sea, therefore it is useful to recognize the impact of cod on herring and sprat stocks and vice versa. In particular, I support that this report does not grant any new powers to the Commission other than those set out in the Basic Regulation and gives the Member States concerned the opportunity to submit recommendations in order to agree appropriate solutions in line with their current situations.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (NI)
text: In writing. This report aims to put in place measures to combat the effects of overfishing that endanger stocks of cod, herring and sprat in the Baltic Sea. This is a reality based on scientific studies. Having said that, we criticise the fact that Parliament is once again ensuring that Member States are given the opportunity to participate in decision-making. However, the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) provides for a regionalization of the management of fisheries-related problems. In addition, the measures taken correspond to an accumulation of constraints for fishermen. MEPs Sylvie Goddyn and Jean Marie Le Pen have tried by amendment to ensure that the measures are only taken after recent scientific studies. This would have had the advantage of consistency. Parliament has decided otherwise. For these reasons I choose the ABSTENTION.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 We have a responsibility to our environment, including fisheries related to our seas. Maintaining the Baltic Sea ecosystem and maintaining the ecological balance of fish that can be fished is an important European task. That is why I supported the report in favour of a balanced plan for fishing, which is constantly checked by scientific methods.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this regulation concerning the management of fish stocks in the Baltic Sea because guaranteeing sustainable fish stocks is essential, since fishing activities offer massive benefits to the EU, not only financial ones but also in terms of job creation. Better management of the Balticʼs wealth of fish species by establishing a new plan for larger stocks of some very popular table fishes, such as cod, herring and sprat, will bring us one step closer to implementation of the common fisheries policy. This regulation can also ensure the prosperity of local fishing companies, local economies and employment, as well as guaranteeing the ecological balance of the Baltic seabed.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report refers to the multiannual fisheries management plan for the Baltic Sea which applies to cod, herring and sprim stocks. This management plan replaces the previous one for cod stocks. Cod, herring and sprim are the subject of important fish in the Baltic Sea. Until now, there was no management plan for herring and sprcy, which hindered the sustainability of its stocks and the stability of fishing opportunities for its fishermen. However, this plan does not sufficiently guarantee the protection of various marine species. It is not guaranteed that they do not exceed the lower limit corresponding to the maximum sustainable yield for the adoption of delegated acts relating to specific conservation measures for the conservation of flox, sole, turbot and remol and to minimise bycatch of birds, mammals or marine reptiles, as ices' scientific opinion has indicated that the current operating rates of some of these populations are not consistent with the achievement of maximum yield Sustainable. However, the amendments were not adopted. That's why I voted against it.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This legislative proposal proposes to establish a framework for the management of cod, herring and sprat stocks in the Baltic Sea, i.e. to implement a policy for the recovery and maintenance of species with an optimal harvest volume that can be harvested annually without threatening the reproduction of the species. I congratulate the adoption of the amendment calling for the targets to be achieved by 2015, at the latest in 2020. However, it is necessary to go further and act in a comprehensive way to maintain the balance of the ecosystem. I therefore regret that the amendments proposed by my group concerning both bycatch and the possible impact of overfishing on other species (birds, marine mammals, etc.) have been rejected. The opposition between the interests of fishermen and the ecosystem is dummy and sterile.  The interest of fishermen lies in the protection of marine resources and the ecosystem and therefore requires responsible fishing that respects the rights of fishermen and takes into account smallholders in particular. The rapporteur has asked for the text to be referred to committee to take into account the latest scientific advice, and I am in favour of it.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Regulation (EU) No 1380/2013 of the European Parliament and the Council lays down the rules of the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) in line with the Union's international obligations. The multiannual plan for stocks of cod, herring and sprat in the Baltic Sea and for fisheries exploiting these stocks was published by the European Commission in October 2014. The aim of the proposal is to establish a framework for the management of multiple species of cod, herring and sprat stocks in the Baltic Sea, where fishing mainly affects these three species. The Commission's proposal points to a need for a multi-species management plan for the Baltic Sea. The multispecies management approach is much more effective than managing individual species. The plan should provide for a balanced and sustainable exploitation of these stocks and the stability of fishing opportunities, and, consequently, of the livelihoods of fishermen. At the same time, it shall ensure that management is based on the most recent scientific advice on the state of the stocks concerned, interactions between species and other aspects related to [...].

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the proposal to establish a multiannual plan for the stocks of cod, herring and sprat in the Baltic Sea and for the fisheries that fish these stocks, as this will ensure the sustainable management of these stocks and the constant fishing opportunities and, therefore, a constant livelihood for fishermen.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The proposal aims to create a framework for the multi-species management of cod, herring and sprat stocks in the Baltic Sea, which accounted for nearly 94% of all catches in the Baltic Sea in recent years. This plan should help to ensure the sustainable, sustainable exploitation of these stocks and the stability of fishing opportunities and thus the stability of the livelihood of fishermen. Experts and fishermen in Poland are alarmed about the dramatic situation in the Baltic Sea and the damage to the marine ecosystem, which is why I voted in favour of the regulation.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a multiannual plan for the stocks of cod, herring and papalina in the Baltic Sea and the fishing activities for the exploitation of these stocks because I believe that there is a need nowadays for a modern catch management plan in the Baltic Sea. The text covers the need for effective management of these species and lays down rules for the most efficient, balanced and sustainable exploitation of the region's fishing wealth.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE).
text: – I supported this report, which brings loosening of the rules on fishermen's landing obligations. This obligation is now set for 2015 only. The practice shows that there is a whole range of problems in the implementation of this directive, and I therefore agree that fishermen will have to be very careful in the preparation of the new document, which will be in force from 2015 onwards. In fishing countries such as Slovenia, where only a few hundred tonnes of sea fish are caught per year, such regulations are becoming such regulations, such fisheries rules are a huge burden and to a large extent also make fishing impossible, which is also part of our tourism offer. It is therefore necessary to be very careful about such regulations.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. One of the central objectives of the reform of the current common fisheries policy is the progressive elimination of discards throughout Eu fishing by introducing the landing obligation. This is designed to make better use of available resources and meets public expectations of ending the practice of throwing marketable fish into the sea.  In addition, high levels of discards are recognized as a key point in the PPC's lack of environmental sustainability in the CFP's own impact assessment. Following the vote in the Committee on Fisheries of the European Parliament and the negotiations on the three-way dialogue, points which I consider very important, such as the Commission's obligation to draw up annual reports on the measures taken by Member States and producer organisations to comply with the landing obligation, could be included in the final document , on its socio-economic impact on job security on ships..., as well as other measures aimed at facilitating fishermen, especially small fishermen, from implementing this obligation by avoiding over bureaucracy. That's why I voted for it.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. This proposed regulation aims to introduce a landing obligation on January 1, 2015 to eliminate fish releases. While this measure is important, the proposed regulation remains unclear as to the fate of the landed. It also imposes strong material and financial constraints on fishermen. This will have to make many additional journeys, while not being able to use these fish releases for human consumption. In addition, landed catches being charged on quotas, and involuntary catches to land to be separated materially from other catches, would consequently lengthen the fishermen's working time and the cost of their work. The proposed regulation would, among other things, classify any breach of duty as a serious offence. Due to the increase in the weight of vessels, these measures pose a risk to fishermen in rough seas. Small-scale fishing could fall under the weight of these constraints. It would appear, therefore, that although the intent of this proposed regulation is legitimate, the measures envisaged are far too restrictive and difficult for fishermen to implement. So I voted against the text.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to oblige fishermen to land all catches. Under current rules, fishermen must throw the catch wrong to sell back into the sea. The new regulation on the common fisheries policy obliges all catches to be landed. This requirement will gradually enter into force between 2015 and 2019. If the quota is not allocated or the minimum conservation reference amount is not reached, fishermen will have to land all unintentional by-catches and sell inappropriate catches. I support the proposal to give fishermen more time to prepare for the requirement not to throw away, but to land all catches in ports. The multiannual Baltic Sea management plan aims to ensure that catches do not exceed their regeneration. It also allows for an increase in the predictability of fishing, as it focuses on a period of several years. The Commission has proposed to include non-compliance with the landing obligation in the list of serious infringements and to apply penalty points in the event of such infringement. However, in order for fishermen to have sufficient time to adapt to it, I support the proposal to implement it only gradually by 2019.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this text, which proposes only the development of the landing obligation and not its removal, which I consider necessary because it subjects fishermen to too heavy constraints, especially artisanal fishermen.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The obligation to disembark involuntary, non-marketable catches is one of the main thrusts of the reform of the common fisheries policy. It will gradually come into force between 2015 and 2019. As this obligation is at odds with several existing European regulations, the Commission has proposed a so-called "omnibus" regulation that amends these texts in order to replace discharges to the sea with landing.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I welcome the adoption, following a tough negotiation with the Council, of the Regulation on the landing obligation. This Regulation comes from the last legislature and will affect only the obligation to land the minies concerned as of 1 January 2015, and the legal harmonisation of the pesqueria subject to that obligation should subsequently be carried out in connection with the new framework of technical measures which the Commission has to propose in a few months.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. This Cadec report on the landing obligation proposes to phase out fish releases by instituting a landing obligation on 1 January 2015 with very limited tolerance will still be granted to fishermen in the coming years. While the desire to reduce fish releases is welcome, the proposal does not specify the fate of landed fish. This proposal also subjects fishermen to severe financial (landed catches) and material constraints (e.g. involuntary catches to land must be separated materially from other catches). Finally, it puts fishermen at risk by increasing the weight of vessels, which can be a danger in rough seas. Instead, we should focus on improving the selectivity of fishing methods and gear, and I have therefore voted against this report.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstained in the vote on this text which, while presenting positive elements of simplification regarding the methods of landing the catch, does not give way to strong critical elements (such as, for example, the "serious" infringement on non-compliance with the obligation).

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. The landing obligation is one of the fundamental pillars of the new Common Fisheries Policy (CFP), in force since the beginning of the year, which has been prohibiting any type of return of catches to the sea (discards). Thus, from January 2015, and progressively according to an annual timetable established by species, fishermen have an obligation to land all their catches.  In order to implement this measure, it was necessary to amend certain provisions referred to in the existing Regulations on technical measures, management and control measures which are contrary to the landing obligation and require fishermen to discard fish. The Commission has therefore made a proposal for a Regulation which removes, on a transitional basis, all legal and practical obstacles to its implementation while developing a new regulatory framework for technical measures. This is the 'bus' regulation which we adopted today with my vote in favour.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it supports the amendment of the 7 regulations relating to fisheries policy to bring them into line with the recently adopted new fisheries policy and not to oppose it. Article 15 of the basic Regulation on the Common Fisheries Policy requires the landing of all catches and, under the 7 regulations in question, fishermen must discard catches which are unfit for sale. The Commission has therefore submitted a proposal for an Omnibus Regulation, which aims to amend the seven Regulations at the same time in order to bring them into line with the basic Regulation on the common fisheries policy, while postponing sanctions for infringements of the new framework Regulation until 2017, in order to ensure an appropriate transitional period for fishermen.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support this report which is compromised and gives fishermen the opportunity to adapt, after which the dumping of unwanted catches back into the sea will be sanctioned. In any case, one should strive to eliminate this harmful behavior of fishermen at sea, and landing sites for such fish are one of the ways in which this problem can be solved. We must take into account the needs of fishermen in order to be able to successfully carry out their work, but also take into account the protection of marine flora and fauna.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (NI)
text: In writing. The Common Fisheries Policy introduced fundamental changes to the rules previously in force in 2013, with an obligation to land catches. The Fisheries Committee considered that the amendments introduced by the European Commission's draft regulation, known as the "omnibus", should be strictly limited. Obligations impose strong constraints on fishermen, particularly financial and material ones. In addition, one may wonder about a parallel market, inherent in this landing obligation. So I voted against it.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report since I think that the incompatibility between the provisions regarding the landing obligation and those pertaining to discarding create a contrast that should be remedied as soon as possible, in order to better manage the fish stocks.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We are very pleased with the agreement reached with the Council on the Omnibus Regulation because we have completed a necessary step to implement the reform of the common fisheries policy and make it a reality. The omnibus regulation, after lengthy and cumbersome negotiations, will remove all obstacles to the ban on discards and will give the obligation to land the most solid bases. The proposed amendments update the Commission's proposal with the new Regulation No 1380/2013, which is the pillar of the CFP; In particular, we have repeatedly reaffirmed the principle of regionalisation as a simplification tool for the proper management of marine resources and the de miminis rule. We have in fact introduced a minimum limit of 10% of the live weight, below which the landing obligation does not apply, and I am sure that this measure will help small-scale fishing vessels, which will therefore be relieved of excessive administrative burdens. In this way, we are making the environmental sustainability of the CFP effective without sacrificing the economic sustainability of fishing activities operating in the craft sector.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. The proposed regulation aims to phase out fish releases by instituting a landing obligation on 1 January 2015. The search for a reduction in fish releases, while laudable, should not be a pretext for the adoption of an incomplete regulation, particularly on the fate of waste landed by fishermen.  In addition, the proposed regulation places new constraints on fishermen: financial constraints since landed catches will be charged on quotas; material constraints since landed catches will have to be physically separated from consumable catches.  Rather than considering exclusively binding legislation, it would have been preferable to support the improvement of fishing techniques. As such, the renewal of equipment, made necessary by these new regulations, must be taken over by the FEAMP. Out of support for the fishermen, I voted against this text.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the adoption of the measure. I am in order to debureaucratise on-board operations and I am opposed to the system for managing minimum retention sizes.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The implementation of the landing obligation stems from the adoption of the reform of the Common Fisheries Policy, which came into force on 1 January 2015. This landing obligation is being phased in in accordance with the timetable set out in Article 15 of the Basic Regulation of the Common Fisheries Policy.  While the landing requirement is a generous measure, it remains very difficult to implement especially for semi-coastal and artisanal fisheries.  It is therefore necessary to make fishing gear more selective. The annual reports on the implementation of the landing obligation will allow an analysis of the impact of this measure and the difficulties faced by professionals. Failure to comply with the landing requirement will become a serious offence from 1 January 2017.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of this proposal to give fishermen two years to adapt before the new ban on discarding fish comes into force. The obligation on fishermen to land unwanted catches and not throw them back into the water is the main objective of the new common fisheries policy (CFP). These new rules oblige fishermen to land all fish caught during a fishing trip. It will be extremely difficult to implement, especially for multispecies and small-scale fishing. My concern is to conserve fish stocks while maintaining a sustainable economy. The compromise we have reached helps to mitigate some of the negative effects of the new rules for fishermen.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this legislative resolution which concerned landing obligations for fishermen. Although the landing obligations alongside the Baltic multiannual plan can be of potential environmental benefit, it is still of paramount importance not to neglect the socioeconomic factors and possible negative impact this will have on small fishermen. I also have serious concerns about any European blanket implementation of intrusive monitoring of fishermen; the Commission’s agenda, for example, is the introduction of a system where remote electronic monitoring is forced upon small fishermen. This approach needs to be revised as it operates under a presumption of guilt. My party, Sinn Féin, highlighted that most small fishermen will struggle to adapt to such changes if they are blindly enforced without regard for their welfare. Any inevitable implementation of landing obligations must be done gradually to accommodate fishermen. The landing obligations are very comprehensive and so our fishermen must be given all the supports and clarification they need.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The reform of the common fisheries policy saw fundamental changes being made to the rules applicable to fisheries, including a landing obligation for all catches. The goal is to gradually forbid discards over the period 2015 to 2019. Until recently discarding was common practice in the EU common fisheries policy As this landing obligation conflicts with seven other EU regulations currently in force, they need to be amended in parallel so as to bring them in line with the basic Common Fisheries Policy Regulation. Under the current rules, fishermen have to discard any non-marketable catch or fish caught in excess of quota. This situation is at odds with the landing obligation. I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 It could have been a first step towards what must be the ultimate objective, namely the total elimination of the possibility of discarding part of the catch at sea. On the other hand, it remains a wasted opportunity, as it does not fully meet expectations, and indeed, in many respects, strongly weakens the initial idea; this is particularly the case with regard to the exception concerning small-scale fishing (which affects as much as 80% of cases), i.e. the hypothesis that catches are less than 50 kilograms.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. I preferred to vote against this proposed regulation which, if it pursues a laudable objective, offers bad solutions to the excessively massive releases of fish. Indeed, in addition to the fact that this proposal for a regulation is flawed because it does not specify the fate of landed fish, it in my opinion presents solutions that are far too restrictive for fishermen. With this regulation, they would be subject to new financial pressures since landed catches would be charged on quotas.  Another unjustified financial constraint: fishermen will have to make additional journeys to disembark, which means more fuel used, a work time extended therefore in the end a blow of the work that increases.  In addition to these obligations, the solution of the landing is not without risk for the fisherman since it will necessarily lead to the increase in the weight of the vessels, which can be dangerous in rough seas.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The reform of the common fisheries policy adopted during the previous parliamentary term introduced some fundamental changes to the rules applicable to fishing activities.  In particular, Article 15 of the basic Regulation of the common fisheries policy imposes a landing obligation for all catches. This obligation will enter into force gradually between 2015 and 2019. Fishermen will therefore have to discard all unwanted catches that are not marketable either because of a lack of a quota or because their size is less than the minimum reference size for conservation. However, this obligation runs counter to a number of regulations currently in force. The European Commission has decided to present an "omnibus" regulation in order to make these regulations compatible with Article 15. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution introducing the landing obligation, as I am convinced that the practice of discarding species subject to catch limits and species with minimum sizes is harmful to fish stocks, the marine environment and costly for fishermen. It consists in returning to the sea unwanted live or dead catches.  On the contrary, I believe that the gradual introduction of the obligation to land all the fish caught could be a solution to the problem. The introduction of this measure will also make it possible to eliminate the contradictions in current fisheries legislation resulting from the reform of the common fisheries policy, which has imposed the obligation to land. In order to align the various regulatory sources, the Commission has introduced this 'omnibus' regulation to make the regulations compatible with Article 15 of the basic regulation of the common fisheries policy.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal to ban, from 2015 and by 2019, the dumping of fish caught at sea, if this is unsuitable for sale, for example because it is made up of specimens that are too small or in excess of the authorised quotas.  Thanks to the introduction of the land landing obligation, it will be possible to limit waste, make a more accurate selection of the catch and collect more reliable data on the amount of fish taken from the sea.  The new legislation, which lays down specific rules on how to treat fish, both on board and after arrival in port, as well as control procedures and possible penalties for fishing vessels, will ensure higher food quality and consumer safety.  Finally, it is hoped that the new discipline will promote a more effective protection of marine flora and fauna both off the Atlantic coast and in our Mediterranean Sea.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Fishermen are now obliged to land all their catches that are unintended and non-marketable either because they do not have the quota for this or because they fall under the minimum conservation reference size, thus ending the practice of ʽdiscardingʼ fish. This landing obligation conflicts with several EU regulations currently in force. The proposed package of amendments to existing legislation seeks to review the specific measures which conflict with this new obligation. I have thus voted in favour of the report.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this regulation as it provides for the application of the obligation to land all catches (the so-called 'omnibus') by applying the measures provided for in the reform of the common fisheries policy (CFP). I am, of course, in favour of putting an end to the unacceptable practice of throwinging of valuable and limited marine resources, not even in order to give fishermen an incentive to increase selectivity, collect data and increase control. Firstly, the 50 kg threshold for logged in the logbook could create gaps in the application of the regulation. I would like all catches to be recorded taking into account that one of the expected benefits of the landing obligation has been improved registration). Secondly, in the trialogue the reference to 'remote sensing' was totally gone. Finally, the introduction of several derogations from Article 15 of the reform of the common fisheries policy which weaken the proposal by creating gaps.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. One of the central objectives of the reform of the current common fisheries policy is the progressive elimination of discards throughout Eu fishing by introducing the landing obligation. This is designed to make better use of available resources and meets public expectations of ending the practice of throwing marketable fish into the sea.  In addition, high levels of discards are recognized as a key point in the PPC's lack of environmental sustainability in the CFP's own impact assessment. Following the vote in the Committee on Fisheries of the European Parliament and the negotiations on the three-way dialogue, points which I consider very important, such as the Commission's obligation to draw up annual reports on the measures taken by Member States and producer organisations to comply with the landing obligation, could be included in the final document , on its socio-economic impact on job security on ships..., as well as other measures aimed at facilitating fishermen, especially small fishermen, from implementing this obligation by avoiding over bureaucracy. That's why I voted for it.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Commission proposals and the legislative resolution, since they provide for the elimination of the wasteful practice of discarding. This creates planning and legal certainty for fishermen until new legislation in line with the reformed Common Fisheries Policy is in place.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report is one of the last milestones in the implementation of the reform of the Common Fisheries Policy, as voted in the previous Parliament. Indeed, this text aims to phase in the obligation to disembark or ban the rejection of all catches from 1 January 2015 to 1 January 2019. Removing existing contradictions with current legislation, it introduces a series of measures regulating on-board storage, opportunities for landed species, control and sanctions for non-compliance, and a series of exemptions for de minimis catches. Considering that this text respects the political agreement that was reached during the vote on the reform of the Common Fisheries Policy, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. The landing obligation under the new Common Fisheries Policy is intended to avoid the significant rejection of dead-leaved catches, which undermines the viability of stocks. Mandatory landings will also allow for better monitoring of the actual amount of catches in fishing areas.  Like the rapporteur, I support the idea of an omnibus regulation that applies only to fishing areas affected by the landing obligation in 2015, and not for subsequent years, in order to remain consistent with all the legislation on this subject.  Finally, while I support mandatory landing, I remain mindful of the fact that it must be accompanied by measures to find opportunities for non-marketable catches, in order to avoid waste, and to control those opportunities.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The obligation for fishermen to land unwanted catches and not throw them back into the water has been in force since 1 January and is the main objective of the new common fisheries policy. With the adoption of this measure today, the regulation on how to enforce this ban is being amended and the application of the relevant sanctions is postponed for two years. In this way, fishermen will have more time to 'adapt' to the 'discard' regulations of waste fish.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. This proposed regulation aims to introduce a landing obligation on January 1, 2015 to eliminate fish releases. While this measure is important, the proposed regulation remains unclear as to the fate of the landed. It also imposes strong material and financial constraints on fishermen. This will have to make many additional journeys, while not being able to use these fish releases for human consumption. In addition, landed catches being charged on quotas, and involuntary catches to land to be separated materially from other catches, would consequently lengthen the fishermen's working time and the cost of their work. The proposed regulation would, among other things, classify any breach of duty as a serious offence. Due to the increase in the weight of vessels, these measures pose a risk to fishermen in rough seas. Small-scale fishing could fall under the weight of these constraints. It would appear, therefore, that although the intent of this proposed regulation is legitimate, the measures envisaged are far too restrictive and difficult for fishermen to implement. So I voted against the text.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report because it leaves some fields uncovered.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the obligation to unload catches.
