It is clear from this report that 30% of the earth's seas are overfished and that the survival of marine fish stocks could be at risk. Justified steps to maintain marine fish stocks will result in a continuous and significant reduction in the amount of marine fish fish fished. Therefore, the common fisheries policy should pay much more attention to sustainable fish farming, i.e. aquaculture, and in particular freshwater fish farming. A significant number of fish ponds in Hungary are located in Natura 2000 sites. These farms do not pose any threat to the natural assets of these areas. Moreover, in many cases it is precisely because of our closed-system fish ponds that they have created or preserved individual wetland associations. Consequently, freshwater aquaculture should be freed from unduly stringent and unnecessary sustainability standards, which are justified only for sea fishing. Efforts should already be made to clearly define the concept and regulation of freshwater aquaculture.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The above proposal clarifies the rules applicable to the landing obligation, giving fishermen a two-year adaptation period. What is proposed is the requirement for fishermen to land all non-marketable involuntary catches, either due to the absence of a quota or the minimum size of conservation reference, which several European regulations currently in force prevent. The text states that discards to the sea are a considerable waste and jeopardise the sustainable exploitation of marine organisms and ecosystems and, since general compliance by operators of the landing obligation is essential for it to have the expected effects, non-compliance with the landing obligation should be categorised as a serious infringement, but given two years of adaptation to the new rule.

name: Edouard Ferrand (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this text which does not sufficiently protect the Fisheries sector, which can endanger fishermen, because this report puts fishermen at risk: that of increasing the weight of vessels. Indeed, it is a danger factor in rough seas. In addition, it weakens small-scale fishing, which is already under great pressure.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. It was the rapporteur's option, which we think is appropriate, to restrict the provisions introduced by the Omnibus Regulation to what is strictly necessary, with a view to implementing the landing obligation provided for in the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) basic regulation adopted at the time of its last reform. Thus, only fisheries subject to landing obligation from 1 January 2015 are covered. The other fisheries should be regulated later, accompanied by a new framework of technical measures. The Commission is expected to put forward a proposal to this effect in the coming months. Fish discards overboard, with no chance of survival, are an unsustainable and cause of just revulsion.  A practice with very diverse causes, ranging from the absence of commercial value of the fish that would be in good condition to be consumed to an unsuitable management of resources. These causes should be assessed in each case and the solutions found to meet the landing obligation should take them into account. The implementation of the PROVISIONS of the CFP entails completely different requirements, for example in the case of multi-specific and predominantly artisanal fisheries prevailing in countries such as Portugal, in the face of monospecific and predominantly industrial fisheries in the North. Overall, it does not seem to us that the proposed regulation fully take this into account.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The reform of the common fisheries policy introduces fundamental changes to the rules on fisheries. In 2015 and 2019, a regulation imposing an obligation to land all catches will enter into force. This is an obligation when fishermen will have to land all unwanted catches that are unsaleable, whether due to insufficient quotas or size. However, this landing obligation is contrary to a number of European regulations and therefore, in fact, there is a proposal to amend 7 regulations in parallel so that they are compatible with the article of the basic Regulation on the common fisheries policy.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against and lamenting the vote in "blocks", which does not allow us to go into the merits of the individual elements of the proposal, without prejudice to its positive elements.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report amending Regulations (EC) No 1493/1999 and (EC) No 1493/1999. This Regulation should therefore be amended accordingly. This Regulation should therefore be amended accordingly. This Regulation should therefore be amended accordingly. This Regulation should therefore be amended accordingly. This Regulation should therefore be amended accordingly. This Regulation should therefore be amended accordingly. Council Regulation (EC) No 1224/2009 and repealing Council Regulation (EC) No 1224/2009 laying down detailed rules for the application of Council Regulation (EC) No 1224/2009 as regards the application of Council Regulation (EC) No 1224/ It is therefore necessary to ensure compliance with the rules on landing, which is directly related to respect for and protection of the total wealth.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ One of the central objectives of common fisheries policy (CFP) reform is the gradual elimination of discards in EU fisheries through the introduction of a landing obligation. All catches must be brought and retained on board the fishing vessels, recorded, landed and counted against the quotas where applicable, in accordance. The ʽomnibusʼ regulation serves to make the landing obligation operational and to remove any legal and practical impediments to its implementation by removing or amending certain provisions within the current regulations on technical, management and control measures. I voted in favour of the landing obligation, as it provides for the implementation of one of the central objectives of the CFP reform: the elimination of the wasteful practice of discarding. It creates planning and legal certainty for fishermen until new legislation in line with the reformed CFP is in place.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. Article 15 of the Basic Regulation of the Common Fisheries Policy imposes an obligation to disembark all catches. This obligation will enter into force progressively between 2015 and 2019. Fishermen should therefore land all unintentional catches that are not marketable because the corresponding quotas do not exist or because the catches are less than the minimum reference size for conservation. Current regulations require fishermen to apply discarding to non-marketable catches. That contradiction with the landing obligation is therefore eliminated.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the proposal tabled by the Committee on Fisheries to make a fundamental change to the CFP, the reform of the common fisheries policy adopted in 2013.  I therefore support the committee in its request for approval of the revision of the reform through the adoption of the so-called 'omnibus regulation', which provides for the obligation to land all unwanted catches for non-marketable fishermen and which contains the exceeding of as many as seven of the previous legal criteria for fishing activities (large and small pelagic fishing). , industrial fishing and fishing in the Baltic Sea) carried out between January 2015 and 2019.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the EP and Council regulation, which introduced important elements of coherence with existing legislation on discards, because its ultimate aim is to phase out discards. This regulation further improves and specifies the previous regulation establishing the introduction of an obligation to land catches of species subject to catch limits and species subject to minimum sizes in the Mediterranean. Since discards are a considerable waste and undermine the sustainable exploitation of marine organisms and ecosystems and because compliance with the landing obligation by operators is essential to produce the desired results, it is particularly important that this regulation should set the objective of classifying violations of the landing obligation as a serious infringement under the regulation. As the landing obligation represents a substantial change for operators, it is appropriate to postpone the application of the rules on serious infringements of the Regulation by two years. Finally, the final text represents a significant step forward in relation to the Commission's proposal, which had not fully considered certain undesirable effects of the landing obligation, the possible appearance of parallel markets that do not comply.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I have today opposed the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulations (EC) No 850/98, (EC) No 2187/2005, (EC) No 1967/2006, (EC) No 1098/2007, (EC) No 254/2002, (EC) No 2347/2002 and (EC) No 1224/2009 of the Council and the repeal of Council Regulation (EC) No 1434/98 with regard to the landing obligation, as I consider further exceptions to the inshore fishing necessary. It is absolutely absurd for our Baltic fishermen to have to destroy young, viable by-catch simply because they cannot tip it back into the sea – that does not spare our fish stock, it destroys it.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I gave my support to the Cadec report because it is crucial that we finally bring an end to the discarding of marketable fish back into the sea, which has been proven to be bad for fish stocks, bad for the marine environment and costly for fishermen.  Crucial in gaining my support was the fact that the legislation will allow fishermen to adapt to the change, since it creates planning and legal certainty for commercial fisheries until new legislation in line with the reformed Common Fisheries Policy is in place.

name: Julie Girling (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ Without taking sensible measures to ensure that our fish stocks are sustained, our fish stocks will eventually be depleted entirely, which will damage the UK fishing industry in the long term as well as negatively impacting consumers through higher prices due to reduced supply of fish and costs of imports. Measures to ensure that fish stocks remain healthy and to prevent wastage are beneficial to consumers and the industry. I have stressed the need for a regionalised approach to these proposals as it is clear that a one-size-fits-all policy will not work and could negatively affect fishing regions that require a different approach to sustainability. I am also pleased to support the proposals that allow fisherman enough time to adapt to these new measures that will benefit the South-West fishing industry and fisheries in the long run.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: in writing. European fisheries policies have a major impact on the activities of our fishermen and not always in a very positive way.  The contradiction between the possibility of discarding at sea and the obligation to land risked complicating working conditions and confusing the sector. Clarity was necessary, which is why I voted in favour of the report. It is now clear from the Omnibus Regulation that fishermen must bring all catches ashore and land, including non-marketable catches. I think it is very important that these forecasts are valid for 2015 alone, which will thus be a test year to test the implementation of the new obligation.  Finally, I would like to stress that the attention paid to small-scale fishing and the easing of bureaucratic and administrative obligations for vessels under 10 metres are to be welcomed. When imposing new obligations, the EU has a duty to consider the different realities.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report amending existing legislation to bring it into line with the common fisheries policy. The prohibition of discarding, or 'landing obligation', is an essential objective of the reformed CFP, approved by the European Parliament in December 2013. Discards are catches that are thrown back into the sea because they are of an uns permitted/desired species or size. Most of the discarded fish die. At the same time, mechanisms are introduced to prevent the development of a clandestine market with catches not allowed. The ultimate goal is to move towards a sustainable fishing model compatible with the protection of the marine environment.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which provides for elimination of the wasteful practice of discarding. This will create planning and legal certainty for fishermen until new legislation in line with the reformed common fisheries policy is in place.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour because I think it is very important to ensure that fisheries operators have legal certainty when applying the landing obligation. I believe this regulation will allow that.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report amending existing legislation to bring it into line with the common fisheries policy. The prohibition of discarding, or 'landing obligation', is an essential objective of the reformed CFP, approved by the European Parliament in December 2013. Discards are catches that are thrown back into the sea because they are of an uns permitted/desired species or size. Most of the discarded fish die. At the same time, mechanisms are introduced to prevent the development of a clandestine market with catches not allowed. The ultimate goal is to move towards a sustainable fishing model compatible with the protection of the marine environment.

name: Carlos Iturgaiz (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 I vote in favour of this report of the Committee on Fisheries which allows the management and implementation of the landing obligation, and thereby a legal harmonisation of fisheries subject to the landing obligation, and which proposes to extend the period initially proposed by the Commission, allowing the fisheries sector to adapt to the current regulations.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the report on the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council amending the Council Regulations (EC) No 2012/2013. 850/98, (EC) No. 2187/2005, (EC) No. 1967/2006, (EC) No. 1098/2007, (EC) No. 254/2002, (EC) No. 2347/2002 and (EC) No. 1224/2009 and on the repeal of Regulation (EC) No 1224/2009. 1434/98 as regards the obligation to land catches, although I consider that one such proposal is very difficult to apply in particular to small fishermen, but I want to believe that compulsory landing also means sustainability in fisheries.  I support the proposed amendments as the changed proposal also introduces a transitional period for the full implementation of mandatory disembarkation and that selectivity and flexibility are introduced when applying them. I believe that in accordance with the commissioner's discussion, other regulations will follow to help fishermen. This aims to eliminate the practice of throwing fish into the sea and contribute to the preservation of the marine ecosystem, eliminate incidental unwanted or unnecessary catches. Ultimately, the aim is to strengthen fisheries in the long term.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. This proposed regulation aims to introduce a landing obligation on January 1, 2015 to eliminate fish releases. While this measure is important, the proposed regulation remains unclear as to the fate of the landed. It also imposes strong material and financial constraints on fishermen. This will have to make many additional journeys, while not being able to use these fish releases for human consumption. In addition, landed catches being charged on quotas, and involuntary catches to land to be separated materially from other catches, would consequently lengthen the fishermen's working time and the cost of their work. The proposed regulation would, among other things, classify any breach of duty as a serious offence. Due to the increase in the weight of vessels, these measures pose a risk to fishermen in rough seas. Small-scale fishing could fall under the weight of these constraints. It would appear, therefore, that although the intent of this proposed regulation is legitimate, the measures envisaged are far too restrictive and difficult for fishermen to implement. So I voted against the text.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Alain Cadec's report on the implementation of the landing obligation. The landing obligation is a laudable measure that aims to better preserve resources, but its implementation remains complicated. I therefore welcome the provisions introduced which will assess the real economic and social impact of the implementation of this measure.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the landing obligation. Article 15 of the Common Fisheries Policy Regulation imposes an obligation to disembark all catches. This obligation will come into force gradually between 2015 and 2019.  As a result, fishermen will have to disembark all involuntary non-marketable catches. Given that the landing requirement is a fundamental change for fisheries, the report stressed that 2015 would be a test for its implementation.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I am pleased to support this agreement on the landing obligation for fisheries so that applicable regulations are modified to comply. Additionally, it is a positive step that the Commission will publish reports every year on the implementation of the obligation to land as it is vital to see the impact that such an obligation will have on both fishermen and national authorities. I am also pleased to see that the agreement has included good controls to ensure that all parties comply with the landing obligation, and also to prevent parallel activities devoted to catching organisms below the minimum conservation reference size from developing.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the regulation as it provides for the implementation of one of the central objectives of common fisheries policy (CFP) reform – the elimination of the wasteful practice of discarding – and creates planning and legal certainty for fishermen until new legislation in line with the reformed CFP is in place.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Mr Goffredo Maria Bettini's report because I believe it is right to suspend the tariff benefits, established by Regulation (EC) No 1215/2009, with Bosnia and Herzegovina from January 2016, in the form of an agreement with the Union, as has already been done by the other Balkan states.  Indeed, the Commission has extended these benefits until 2020 to all the remaining balkan countries.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This report aims to provide additional time in the implementation of the new obligation on sinners to disembark all fish caught. Previously, they simply landed fish for resale, discarding those that did not fit into size or species criteria. These releases caused a considerable waste of the resource at a time when the signals about its sustainability are increasingly alarming. I had therefore supported in a previous vote the end of these practices, while wishing for greater flexibility for sinners. Small-scale fishing must have time frames to implement this necessary reform, but without it jeopardy an already delicate financial balance. By allowing a gradual adaptation by 2019 to the obligation to stop releases, this report responds to these two imperatives: the preservation of resources and the maintenance of activity in often peripheral areas. On the other hand, concessions made for the benefit of fishermen must not allow them to abuse them and therefore nullify the effects of this regulation, hence my abstention.

name: Philippe Loiseau (NI)
text: In writing. This report obliges fishing vessels to stop throwing fish caught in trawls involuntarily, to keep them with an obligation to disembark them. There is a risk that various species will be caught while they are protected, or that the fish caught are too young. Until now these fish were released into the sea. Even if it appears that this measure is a measure of common sense, Parliament's decision poses a number of problems: these catches will reduce the permitted fishing quotas, force fishermen to make more journeys and thus increase their costs (fuel, crew salaries, etc.), to make adjustments on boats since accidental fisheries will have to be separated from others. It would have been desirable if, for the same purpose, Parliament should have moved more towards the possibility for fishing bosses to equip themselves in order to improve selectivity (nets calibrated according to the targeted fish). That is not the case. However, it is important that this new obligation be accompanied by funding, which is not provided for. For all these reasons, I am voting against Parliament's plan.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. This new CFP prohibits all discards (sea returns of catches that either do not reach the minimum allowed size, or are not within the quota allocated to the fisherman). Instead, as of January 2015, and progressively according to an annual timetable established by species, fishermen are required to land such catches at port.  However, this principle of the CFP creates certain inconsistencies arising from the fact that there is a wide range of secondary regulations that directly collide with this landing obligation. Hence the importance of this 'bus' regulation, since it basically seeks to avoid the legal uncertainty faced by the fisheries sector since the beginning of the year.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. One of the central objectives of the reform of the current common fisheries policy is the progressive elimination of discards throughout Eu fishing by introducing the landing obligation. This is designed to make better use of available resources and meets public expectations of ending the practice of throwing marketable fish into the sea.  In addition, high levels of discards are recognized as a key point in the PPC's lack of environmental sustainability in the CFP's own impact assessment. Following the vote in the Committee on Fisheries of the European Parliament and the negotiations on the three-way dialogue, points which I consider very important, such as the Commission's obligation to draw up annual reports on the measures taken by Member States and producer organisations to comply with the landing obligation, could be included in the final document , on its socio-economic impact on job security on ships..., as well as other measures aimed at facilitating fishermen, especially small fishermen, from implementing this obligation by avoiding over bureaucracy. That's why I voted for it.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 This is a very technical issue that is part of the change in fisheries policy. I am not in favour of a single fisheries policy and I do not believe that changing it will bring about improvements either.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 These changes represent a step forward towards the efficient and sustainable exploitation of the marine ecosystem. The new regulation will present to fishermen the obligation to land and store "unintended catches" (catches that are less than the reference minimum), and a breach of that obligation would be characterised as a serious infringement. As the obligation to land and store unintended catches would be a burden on fishermen, I support the proposed introduction of a two-year adjustment period.   For small fishermen, who have vessels up to 12 metres in length, which do not have sufficient capacity and opportunities to select unintended catches and travel to remote storage facilities, these changes would be a major obstacle to continuing to work. Since an exemption was introduced for them, I supported this report.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulations (EC) No 1493/1999 and (EC) No 1493/1999. This Regulation should therefore be amended accordingly. This Regulation should therefore be amended accordingly. This Regulation should therefore be amended accordingly. This Regulation should therefore be amended accordingly. This Regulation should therefore be amended accordingly. This Regulation should therefore be amended accordingly. Council Regulation (EC) No 1224/2009 and repealing Council Regulation (EC) No 1224/2009 laying down detailed rules for the application of Council Regulation (EC) No 1224/2009 as regards the application of Council Regulation (EC) No 1224/ On the one hand, the social and economic impact of the Regulation on small fishermen in the EU Member States is not taken into account, since the operating costs of small-scale and traditional fisheries are increased and, on the other hand, because additional investments are needed which will lead to an increase in labour costs.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. – The reform of the common fisheries policy adopted by the legislator during the previous parliamentary term saw fundamental changes being made to the rules applicable to fisheries. More specifically, Article 15 of the basic Common Fisheries Policy Regulation imposes a landing obligation for all catches. That obligation will enter into effect in a stepwise manner over the period 2015 to 2019. As a result, fishermen will have to land any catch that is unintended and non-marketable either because they do not have the quota for this or because it is under the minimum conservation reference size.  Since this landing obligation conflicts with several EU regulations currently in force, the Commission has brought forward an ‘Omnibus’ regulation which seeks to amend seven regulations in parallel so as to bring them into line with Article 15 of the basic Common Fisheries Policy Regulation. Under the current rules, fishermen have to discard any non-marketable catch. This situation is at odds with the landing obligation and must therefore be remedied.

name: Dominique Martin (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this project. Although it is laudable to want to phase out fish releases, this obligation will impose strong constraints on fishermen: catches will be blamed on quotas, fishermen will be forced to make additional journeys to disembark and the involuntary catches to land will be separated materially, which will be a financial and material loss. I could only vote against such a project.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I agree with the report on the obligation to disembark.  This is a procedure for implementing transparency in order to facilitate efficient monitoring. The fact that fish caught have to be landed entirely, even if they are non-marketable or smaller than the reference species, make it possible to carry out comprehensive studies on the richness and concentration of fish and their trends in order to carry out even more complete studies. This obligation, which will become fully operational in 2019, is in opposition to a current rule of obligation to reject certain species, which must be resolved at regulatory level after numerous discussions and decisions related to combating the phenomenon of discards. Making policies uniform without conflict within them is one of the duties of the institutions and certainly favours the usability of effective rules by workers in the sector, who will thus be able to adapt more easily to the new rules.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission, following the reform of the common fisheries policy, which imposes the obligation to land, has presented an "omnibus" regulation aimed at making amendments parallel to seven regulations, so as to make them compatible with Article 15 of the basic regulation of the common fisheries policy.  Since the current rules require fishermen to discard non-marketable catches, I supported the Cadec report, which considers it appropriate to eliminate this contradiction with the obligation to land.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that there is an urgent need to move towards a sustainable fishing model compatible with the protection of resources and the marine environment. One cannot ignore the fact that most of the fish that is returned to the sea dies.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. The landing obligation means that fishermen will still have to land any unintended catches which are not marketable due to a lack of quotas or a size below the reference minimum for conservation. In principle, I think the regulation is sensible, but there are still a few points that need to be revised. That is why I refused to give my assent.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. One of the main objectives of the reform of the current Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) is to phase out discharges in all Fisheries in the European Union (EU) by introducing a landing obligation. I was voting for the CFP when it was adopted with two reservations, one concerning the necessary modernization of the fleet for obvious issues of safety at sea and energy sobriety of ships, the other relating to zero rejection which I formulated as follows: "[...] if the so-called "Zero Rejection" measure is intended to increase the selectivity of fishing gear, it must not condemn the sector. Its application should be conducted by fishery, on a case-by-case basis, after feasibility and socio-economic impact studies. This report proposes, without going back on the scheme, a gradual and adapted implementation of the landing obligations, I vote for.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report and the amended Commission proposal as they suggest that the Commission’s omnibus regulation should only be concerned with the implementation of the landing obligation for the fisheries concerned in 2015. This will allow 2015 to be treated as a test of the landing obligation’s efficacy.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I support this report for two reasons.  Firstly, the Commission's proposal for a regulation is part of the objective of the reformed Common Fisheries Policy of phasing out discharges in all EU fisheries by introducing an obligation to disembark involuntary non-marketable catches, either because of the absence of a quota or less than the minimum size of conservation reference.  Secondly, this initiative was welcome as this obligation to disembark was at odds with several European regulations currently in force.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have supported the report on landing obligation. The ‘omnibus’ regulation on the landing obligation provides for the implementation of one of the central objectives of the CFP Reform: the elimination of the wasteful practice of discarding. It creates planning and legal certainty for fishermen until new legislation in line with the reformed CFP is in place.

name: Bernard Monot (NI)
text: In writing. It is important to focus on improving the selectivity of fishing methods and gear rather than putting in place an overly complex landing requirement.  It should have been foreseen that the renewal of equipment would have been supported by the FEAMP, since these new equipment are made necessary by a European regulatory development. Small-scale fishing should also be granted a waiver or, at a minimum, an extended transition period, so that it has time to adapt.  As it stands, the vote is therefore negative on this proposed regulation.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report concerned consists of phasing out discards of all EU fisheries on the high seas by introducing an obligation to land catches of species.  I support this report, which has been intensively discussed in the European Parliament's Committee on Fisheries, stressing that the change here requires a two-year adaptation period before infringements of the landing obligation are considered serious.  It should also be noted that the landing obligation is a fundamental change for fisheries and that 2015 will be a test of its implementation. Subsequently, it will be necessary to examine the process for post-2015 implementation for the fisheries concerned.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. This report on the landing obligation aims to phase out fish releases by introducing a landing obligation as of January 1, 2015.  Fishermen will be given a low tolerance in the coming years. While the stated desire to reduce fish releases is commendable, it is regrettable that there is no detail on the fate of the landed fish.  In addition, fishermen would also be subject to significant financial (landed catches) and material constraints (for example, involuntary catches to land must be separated materially from other catches). The increased costs of vessels can also pose a danger to fishermen in rough seas.  Considering that there is a need to encourage more emphasis on the selectivity of fishing methods and gear, I therefore voted against this report.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The landing obligation was one of the great successes of common fisheries policy (CFP) reform and fishers across Europe have been preparing for its implementation for many months (it applies from January 2015). It is our duty to ensure that the process of tidying up previous laws that conflict with the reform is done in the clearest and most coherent way, without delay. The new rules will ensure that fishers have greater legal clarity on the situation.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text on the obligation to disembark all fishing catches. This obligation, which will come into force gradually between 2015 and 2019, is at odds with several European regulations which therefore needed to be amended.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome this proposal for a regulation, which has become necessary as a result of the changes introduced to the rules on fishing activities, in particular with regard to Article 15 of the basic regulation, which imposes the landing obligation for all catches and which will enter into force gradually between 2015 and 2019. Fishermen will therefore have to land all unwanted catches that are not marketable, either because of a lack of a quota or because their size is less than the minimum reference size for conservation.  Together with the rapporteur, however, we believe that the legal alignment for fishing activities subject to the obligation to land after 2015 will have to be implemented later, in line with the new framework of technical measures that the Commission will propose in a few months' time. Therefore, the measures accepted today must have only a provisional value: 2015 will represent a test year in order to assess the consequences of the implementation of this new obligation.  We express, in particular, our concern about the possible emergence of a parallel market which no provision of the current framework allows us to control. We therefore propose, in this regard, to strengthen the responsibility of producer organisations in the context of production and marketing plans.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the reform of the common fisheries policy (in force since 1 January 2015) which imposes the obligation to land all fish in port, the European Commission has presented a new regulation called "omnibus" aimed at amending 7 regulations currently in force to make them compatible with Article 15 of the basic regulation on the subject.  The proposal therefore aims to eliminate contradictions with the current legislation, and to transform the obligation to discard non-marketable catches or fish caught above sea, into an obligation to land such catches. In the light of the above, I voted in favour of Mr Cadec's report.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this report because it provides for the introduction of a landing obligation for catches of species covered by rules on catch limits, but also on other species subject to the 'minimum dimensions' provisions in the Mediterranean, which aim to phase out the practice of discarding in all fishing activities in the European Union. At the same time, I believe that these measures are extremely necessary to protect the marine ecosystem.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on this report because it does not include objectives and timetables. Furthermore, the report on the loading obligation conflicts with other fisheries regulations and does not contain sufficient enforcement instruments or adequate measures to prevent the selection, capture and loading of juvenile fish, as well as quota overruns.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The reform of the common fisheries policy in 2013 amended many provisions in the fisheries sector. Among other things, the SINGLE FISHERIES REGULATION introduced a landing obligation for all catches. The commitment will take effect gradually between 2015 and 2019. I supported the regulation, which will take the first steps in this direction and repeal many of the provisions that are incompatible with the CFP Regulation.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The 2013 CFP reform introduces fundamental changes to fisheries rules: in particular, an obligation to disembark all catches is imposed; meaning that fishermen will have to land all involuntary non-marketable catches due either to the absence of a quota or to a size below the minimum conservation reference size. The compromise reached allows for a good balance between the need to implement this landing obligation and the need to give fishermen some flexibility to implement this obligation. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Considering the introduction of an obligation to land catches of species subject to catch limits and species to which minimum sizes apply in the Mediterranean, a number of provisions should be abolished or amended in the current regulations on technical and control measures which conflict with the landing obligation as they require fishermen to return certain types of catches to the sea.  For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The reform of the Common Fisheries Policy adopted in 2013 had profound changes to the rules applicable to fisheries. More specifically, regulation of the basic common fishing policy (Regulation (EC) No 1380/2013) imposes an obligation to land for all catches. This Regulation will gradually enter into force between 2015 and 2019. As this Landing Obligation Regulation conflicts with several existing EU rules currently in force, the Commission has sought to amend seven rules to bring them in line with the regulation of the basic common fishing policy. The landing obligation represents a radical change for fisheries, so 2015 will be a trial year in terms of implementing this change, from which messages need to be extracted for further application.  An adjustment period of two years during which landing infringements will not be considered a serious infringement has also been granted.

name: Florian Philippot (NI)
text: In writing. Reducing fish releases is a laudable objective, but the proposed regulation, even if amended in the right direction, remains far too restrictive for fishermen on whom all obligations and risks lie. Thus, landed catches are charged on quotas and cannot be used for human consumption (hence a lower selling price); fishermen will have to make additional trips to disembark; any violation of the landing obligation will be classified as a serious offence (points system). In addition, involuntary landing catches must be physically separated from other catches and increased vessel weight is a danger factor in rough seas. I therefore speak out against this text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒According to UN figures, a quarter of the fish caught are dumped in the European Union, the most in the world, because they are not the species that the fishing fleets wanted to catch. The way member states throw surplus fish has caused outrage to the public and environmental organisations for years. The problem is particularly acute in the north of Europe. There, fishermen target individual species, and others for which they do not have a quota or permit, and find themselves in their nets, are thrown into the sea.  You don't catch a lot of unwanted fish in Croatia. We have in trawler catch maybe ten to twenty percent of that catch, in the swimmer almost nothing, and in other nets and so on that catch is quite negligible. Regardless, while we limit the catch of any fish to small fishermen for personal use, the large ones discard tons of fish they do not want back into the sea. This system is absolutely unacceptable, which is why I support a new proposal that will harmonise European regulations on this issue and I hope that it will actually lead to a reduction in the amount of discarded fish.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 I support the obligation to land catches in order to control as much as possible the application of existing regulations as well as the smaller harvesting and conservation of the fish population. This application is of particular importance to me, as a representative from Croatia, where the life of many fishing families is directly related to the regulation and implementation of regulations regarding overfishing. The implementation of technical measures in fisheries and control for the purpose of sustainable development and the prevention of further harvesting is essential.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. Illegal fishing is now a major problem within the UNION threatening the survival of several marine species. The Union must intervene to protect biodiversity and preserve these endangered species.  Faced with the urgency of the situation, Parliament adopted by a very large majority the report on the implementation of the landing obligation. I am pleased to have voted in favour of this key measure. However, while the proposed landing requirement will help to preserve marine resources, it remains difficult to implement and control. As a result, Parliament has agreed on gradual control, with a system of sanctions only applicable from 2017. In addition, it stresses the responsibility of member states to put in place adequate measures to manage non-marketable landed catches.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted positively on this report which seeks to create a regulation with a view to the normative harmonisation of the landing obligation, because the regulations in force now oblige fishermen to land all non-marketable involuntary catches and require fishermen to return non-marketable catches to the sea, so that it is necessary for this regulation to be actually created in order to eliminate this contradiction.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In an area as sensitive as fisheries, we must be careful that the rules and legislation emanating from the European Union do not conflict with each other. Clarification should always be a priority.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. The landing obligation is one of the fundamental pillars of the new Common Fisheries Policy (CFP), in force since the beginning of the year, which has been prohibiting any type of return of catches to the sea (discards). Thus, from January 2015, and progressively according to an annual timetable established by species, fishermen have an obligation to land all their catches.  In order to implement this measure, it was necessary to amend certain provisions referred to in the existing Regulations on technical measures, management and control measures which are contrary to the landing obligation and require fishermen to discard fish. The Commission has therefore made a proposal for a Regulation which removes, on a transitional basis, all legal and practical obstacles to its implementation while developing a new regulatory framework for technical measures. This is the 'bus' regulation which we adopted today with my vote in favour.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. The text voted today, already informally approved by Parliament and the Council, now obliges fishermen to land unwanted catches rather than throw them out to sea. Among the measures taken, the European Commission will have to prepare an annual report on the implementation of this landing obligation. A two-year delay was provided before sanctions for failing to comply with this obligation. And a mechanism has been set up to prevent the development of a parallel market for non-marketable catches.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The objective of the Basic Regulation of the Common Fisheries Policy, adopted in December 2013, imposes the obligation to land all non-marketable involuntary catches gradually between 2015 and 2019, either due to the absence of a quota or the size below the minimum conservation reference size. The Regulation also clarifies certain rules on the landing obligation and gives fishermen a period of two years (until 2017) of adaptation. As this landing obligation is contrary to several Existing European regulations and needs to be harmonised with seven other regulations, the Commission has proposed the so-called Omnibus Regulation with a view to eliminating this contradiction and clarifying how the landing obligation is implemented. However, it is necessary, for the time being, and as the rapporteur says, to address the pressing problem of implementing this landing obligation for fisheries in 2015, and this will be the test year for assessing the consequences of this measure in the future. A final word to mention the side effects that this measure may have in relation to some multi-specific fisheries in Portugal and which, for this reason, should be the subject of careful analysis and control by the European Commission.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation because the recent reform of the common fisheries policy adopted by the legislator during the previous legislature introduces some fundamental changes to the rules applicable to fishing activities that conflict with previous regulations.  We therefore need a so-called 'omnibus' regulation aimed at making changes parallel to seven regulations in order to make them compatible with Article 15 of the basic regulation of the common fisheries policy.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. I have chosen to vote against because the text 'omnibus', proposed by the Commission, does not give way to strong critical elements regarding the way in which the catch is landed, such as, for example, the 'serious' infringement on non-compliance with the obligation. Furthermore, I am opposed to the 'system' and the management of minimum retention sizes, and the text does not provide for the debureaucratisation of on-board operations.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report amending existing legislation to bring it into line with the common fisheries policy. The prohibition of discarding, or 'landing obligation', is an essential objective of the reformed CFP, approved by the European Parliament in December 2013. Discards are catches that are thrown back into the sea because they are of an uns permitted/desired species or size. Most of the discarded fish die. At the same time, mechanisms are introduced to prevent the development of a clandestine market with catches not allowed. The ultimate goal is to move towards a sustainable fishing model compatible with the protection of the marine environment.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. One of the central objectives of the reform of the current common fisheries policy is the progressive elimination of discards throughout Eu fishing by introducing the landing obligation. This is designed to make better use of available resources and meets public expectations of ending the practice of throwing marketable fish into the sea. In addition, discards are a key point in the PPC's lack of environmental sustainability according to the CFP's own impact assessment. Following the vote in the EP Committee on Fisheries and the negotiations on the three-way dialogue, points which I consider to be very important, such as the Commission's obligation to produce annual reports on measures taken by Member States and producer organisations to comply with the landing obligation, on their socio-economic impact, could be included in the final document , on occupational safety on ships, as well as other measures designed to make it easier for fishermen, especially small ones, to implement this obligation by avoiding over-bureaucracy. Although the intentions are positive, I abstained because I have many doubts as to the effectiveness in implementing this measure.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. It seems very important to me to stress that this Regulation will effectively mark the transition from the previous Common Fisheries Policy, aimed at maximising catches, to the new Common Fisheries Policy, which is focused on environmental sustainability and income optimisation. Finally, the old rejections will be taken into account in the management of the springs, which I applaud from a scientific point of view.  However, this new approach will have side implications that should merit attention. In context, in Portugal there are several multi-specific fisheries. In such cases, it is sufficient to have a species with a depleted quota or zero quota in case, the whole fishery can close. This is the specific case of black swordfish fishing, a centuries-old artisanal fishery in Portugal, which will be blocked by the impossibility of catching the cat-sandpaper shark that has zero quota. A similar scenario may occur with demersal fishing in the Azores because of the limited quotas of goraz. The consequences will have to be paid for by the Union's executive body.   In emphasising these considerations, I voted positively for this proposal.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in support of the landing obligation. It will be phased in from this year onwards and will end the discarding of marketable fish back into the sea, which has been proven to be bad for fish stocks, bad for the marine environment and costly for fishermen. The act of discarding used to occur in cases where fishermen would accidently catch fish which they did not have quota for, catch damaged or less profitable fish, or catch undersized fish which they could not sell.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the amendments to the regulation on how to enforce the ban on the 'discard' of discarded fish or landing obligation, which is one of the central objectives of the new common fisheries policy (CFP) and which was approved by the European Parliament in 2013. The obligation to land fishermen is to land unwanted catches (usually non-commercial species or species of unwanted or prohibited size) and not to throw them back into the water, in order to avoid the economic and environmental damage resulting from the death of most fish discarded in this way.  The rules approved by Parliament meet the needs of fishermen, inso far as they will now have two years to 'adapt' before the entry into force of the new ban on discarding waste fish, and also limit the requirements for small fishermen to keep fishing newspapers at the most substantial quantity catches. This is another important step in the implementation of the new CFP, with a view to achieving the objective of sustainable management of fishery resources and their recovery.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the European Parliament's resolution on the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council on the landing obligation. The main objective of the regulation is to progressively eliminate discards in all fisheries in the European Union by introducing an obligation to land catches of species subject to catch limits and species covered by the smallest sizes in the Mediterranean Sea.  In order for the landing obligation to become operational for catches of those species to which it relates as of 1 January 2015, certain provisions under the current regulations concerning technical and control measures contrary to the landing obligation and under which fishermen are obliged to discard fish must be deleted or amended.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on the landing obligation. This will end the discarding of marketable fish back into the sea, which will bring benefits to fish stocks, the marine environment and be financially beneficial for fishermen.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. - I supported the Commission's proposal to land catches since it is complementary to the European Parliament's proposal in February 2013 on the progressive implementation of landings with a view to reducing waste, preserving marine flora and fauna, which entered into force in the Member States on 1 January 2015.  It is a good thing that the Regulation provides for gradually implemented measures to eliminate discards by 2019, as not all Member States have the same fishing fleet and technical predispositions to immediately remove discards and fully comply with the Regulation.  Given that discards constitute a significant part of marine litter and have a negative impact on the sustainable exploitation of marine biological resources and marine ecosystems, and given that general observation of the landing obligation by operators is important for its success, it is important to define an infringement for breaches of obligation, but in this case also requires an adjustment period for our fishermen.  That is why I believe that a step-by-step accession and a gradual adaptation of legislation can make a significant contribution to the success of this Regulation, namely the achievement of the final objective, namely the protection of the blue economy and the protection of our seas.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 It is necessary to comply with the landing rules in the light of respect for and protection of maritime wealth.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Fish is a staple food for billions of people. If we fish today at a faster rate than we are regenerating fish stocks, billions of people will be starving tomorrow. It is a simple reasoning like the concept of not cutting the tree on which we are sitting: yet the depletion of fish stocks is a reality. In the EU, the vast share of fish stocks is overfished and the fishing fleet is oversized. So-called accidental catches of fish of different species from the one desired, or even too small and young to be marketed, play a considerable (but certainly not exclusive) role in the depletion of European fish stocks. The obligation not to throw accidental catches back overboard, but to bring them back to shore, is a good incentive to reduce this practice. I said no to all the amendments which tried in various ways to water down and postpone this obligation.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text.  Indeed, I agree with Mr Cadec that the legal alignment for fisheries subject to the landing obligation after 2015 will have to be carried out at a later date, in line with the new technical framework that the Commission will propose in a few months' time. The omnibus should therefore only be concerned with the urgent problem of the implementation of the landing obligation for the fisheries concerned in 2015.  I agree with the proposal to remove the provisions for other fisheries. He points out that 2015 will be a test year to assess the consequences of implementing the landing obligation.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the regulation on landing requirements for fish. One of the main objectives of the reform of the common fisheries policy (CFP) is to phase out discards in all fisheries, by bringing in a landing obligation for all catches of fish.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report amending existing legislation to bring it into line with the common fisheries policy. The prohibition of discarding, or 'landing obligation', is an essential objective of the reformed CFP, approved by the European Parliament in December 2013. Discards are catches that are thrown back into the sea because they are of an uns permitted/desired species or size. Most of the discarded fish die. At the same time, mechanisms are introduced to prevent the development of a clandestine market with catches not allowed. The ultimate goal is to move towards a sustainable fishing model compatible with the protection of the marine environment.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (NI)
text: In writing. This report obliges fishing vessels to stop throwing fish caught in trawls involuntarily, to keep them with an obligation to disembark them. There is a risk that various species will be caught while they are protected, or that the fish caught are too young. Until now these fish were released into the sea. Even if it appears that this measure is a measure of common sense, Parliament's decision poses a number of problems: these catches will reduce the permitted fishing quotas, force fishermen to make more journeys and thus increase their costs (fuel, crew salaries, etc.), to make adjustments on boats since accidental fisheries will have to be separated from others. It would have been desirable if, for the same purpose, Parliament should have moved more towards the possibility for fishing bosses to equip themselves in order to improve selectivity (nets calibrated according to the targeted fish). That is not the case. However, it is important that this new obligation be accompanied by funding, which is also not planned. So I vote AGAINST the text.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report amending existing legislation to bring it into line with the common fisheries policy. The prohibition of discarding, or 'landing obligation', is an essential objective of the reformed CFP, approved by the European Parliament in December 2013. Discards are catches that are thrown back into the sea because they are of an uns permitted/desired species or size. Most of the discarded fish die. At the same time, mechanisms are introduced to prevent the development of a clandestine market with catches not allowed. The ultimate goal is to move towards a sustainable fishing model compatible with the protection of the marine environment.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it does not provide any solution to the problem of a ban on the marketing of part of fishing because it exceeds quotas or does not have the allowed size.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. One of the central objectives of the reform of the current common fisheries policy is the progressive elimination of discards throughout Eu fishing by introducing the landing obligation. This is designed to make better use of available resources and meets public expectations of ending the practice of throwing marketable fish into the sea. In addition, high levels of discards are recognized as a key point in the PPC's lack of environmental sustainability in the CFP's own impact assessment. Following the vote in the Committee on Fisheries of the European Parliament and the negotiations on the three-way dialogue, points which I consider very important, such as the Commission's obligation to draw up annual reports on the measures taken by Member States and producer organisations to comply with the landing obligation, could be included in the final document , on its socio-economic impact on job security on ships..., as well as other measures aimed at facilitating fishermen, especially small fishermen, from implementing this obligation by avoiding over bureaucracy. That's why I voted for it.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – One of the central objectives of the reform of the current Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) is the progressive elimination of discards in all European Union (EU) fisheries through the introduction of a landing obligation. This is designed to make better use of the available resources, and responds to public expectation to end the practice of throwing marketable fish back into the sea. High levels of discards are identified as an important driver of the lack of environmental sustainability of the CFP in the impact assessment carried out for the proposal for the Basic Regulation for the CFP. The changes made by the omnibus regulation should be strictly limited to implementation of the landing obligation, and only to the fisheries concerned as from 1 January 2015 (small pelagic fisheries, large pelagic fisheries, fisheries for industrial purposes, fisheries for Baltic Sea salmon). The legal alignment for the fisheries subject to the landing obligation after 2015 should be performed subsequently, and in conjunction with the new technical measures framework that the Commission will bring forward in the coming months. The omnibus regulation should, as a result, only be concerned with the urgent issue of the implementation of the landing obligation for the fisheries concerned in 2015.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. The landing obligation means that fishermen will still have to land any unintended catches which are not marketable due to a lack of quotas or a size below the reference minimum for conservation. In principle, I think the regulation is sensible, but there are still a few points that need to be revised. That is why I refused to give my assent.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. It was the rapporteur's option, which we think it is appropriate to restrict the provisions introduced by the omnibus regulation to what is strictly necessary, with a view to implementing the landing obligation laid down in the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) Basic Regulation adopted at the time of its last reform. Thus, only fisheries subject to landing obligation from 1 January 2015 are covered. The other fisheries should be regulated later, accompanied by a new framework of technical measures. The Commission is expected to put forward a proposal to this effect in the coming months. The discards of fish to the sea, without possibilities of survival, is an unsustainable practice and cause of just revulsion. This practice has very diverse causes, ranging from the absence of commercial value of fish that would be in good condition to be consumed to an unsuitable management of resources. These causes should be assessed in each case and the solutions found to meet the landing obligation should take them into account.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. For the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Council Regulations (EC) No 850/98, (EC) No 2187/2005, (EC) No 1967/2006, (EC) No 2187/2005, (EC) No 1967/2006, (EC) No 2187/2005, (EC) No 1967/2006, (EC) No 2187/2005 I voted in favour of the landing obligation and (EC) No 1224/2009 and repealing Regulation (EC) No 1434/98 as regards the landing obligation because the reform of the common fisheries policy has significantly changed the rules in the field of fishing. Thus, between 2015 and 2019, the obligation to land all catches will apply, obliging fishermen to land any unintended catch that is not suitable for the market. Since the landing obligation is contrary to many of the applicable European regulations, a summary regulation is needed to amend these previous Regulations and bring them into line with the Regulation on the common fisheries policy. The current rules stipulate that fishermen must throw non-market catches back into the sea.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Recommendation in favour of granting approval for the conclusion of the Protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement establishing cooperation between the European Communities and its Member States on the one hand, and the Russian Federation on the other, as a technical amendment to that EU-Russia Agreement, which has to be updated to take account of accession to the European Union of the Republic of Croatia.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. On 1 July 2013, Croatia became the 28th Member State of the European Union. For this reason, Croatia will now be included as a party to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Commission, the EU Member States and the Russian Federation and the protocol will also be published in Croatian. The agreement was concluded in 1997 for a period of 10 years and has been automatically extended for one year since 2007. This includes, among other things, regulations in areas such as trade, education, energy and political dialogue. I welcome this step, especially as the agreement is particularly important because of its framework role for Euro-Russian relations.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. This agreement is a simple compliance with Croatia's agreement between the EEC and Russia on 24 June 1994 and entered into force on 1 December 1997, which aims to promote trade and investment between EU Member States and the Russian Federation, trade and strategic cooperation to which we are in favour. I therefore voted in favour of a protocol which therefore consists of integrating Croatia into this agreement because of its accession to the EU on 1 July 2013

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to conclude a Protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Community and Russia, which takes account of Croatia's accession to the EU. The Partnership and Cooperation Agreement signed with the Russian Federation aims in particular at promoting trade and investment, including trade in transport services, and establishes a framework for cooperation in different sectors, limited to general cooperation on economic, financial and technical matters. This agreement needs to be renewed following croatia's accession to the EU.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which approves the Council's conclusion of a protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement with Russia. Signed on 24 June 1994 between the EEC and Russia, this agreement came into force on 1 December 1997: it is about promoting trade and investment between EU Member States and the Russian Federation, a cooperation to which we are in favour, as we have repeatedly stressed throughout the Ukraine crisis, while others have tried to deteriorate our relations with our Russian partners. The protocol in question is simply to integrate Croatia into this agreement, so it was not yet a stakeholder because of its recent accession to the EU on 1 July 2013, so it was a logical compliance.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. Through the Protocol, Croatia will be included in the EU-Russia Partnership Agreement, which aims to promote trade and investment and establish economic, financial and technical cooperation.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. The report in question gives Parliament's approval to the Council's agreement on behalf of the EU with a memorandum to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement establishing a CE-Russia partnership. This agreement aims to promote trade and investment between EU Member States and the Russian Federation, which I am in favour of.  This protocol is simply intended to integrate Croatia into this agreement since it joined the EU on 1 July 2013. Nevertheless, I remain committed to the sovereignty of the nations in the context of trade agreements, but with the agreement in place and with a strategic partner for Europe and France, I voted for this text.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstained in the vote on this text.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Recommendation so that the Republic of Croatia can participate fully as a member of the European Union in the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Communities and the Russian Federation, signed in 1994 and in force since 1997.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it endorsed the Protocol to the EU-Russia Cooperation and Partnership Agreement, which would take account of Croatia's accession to the European Union on 1 July 2013.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Croatia's accession to the European Union necessitates updating the agreements concluded by the EU and its forecurdies in the new situation. Hungary, including the Fidesz-KDNP, has consistently argued for the adoption of Croatian integration efforts, and I therefore voted in favour of the council's draft decision on the conclusion of the Protocol to the PARTNERSHIP and Cooperation Agreement establishing the EC-Russia Partnership to take account of Croatia's accession to the EU.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Russia is an important trading partner for Croatia, but also for other EU countries. Croatia must be taken into account in existing agreements between the EC and Russia.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this recommendation because it is important that Croatia has the status of Member State also vis-a-vis third parties, such as the Russian Federation.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. This form text is of no substantial interest. It grants Parliament's approval that the Council, on behalf of the European Union, will conclude a protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement establishing an EC-Russia partnership. The agreement aims to promote trade and investment between EU Member States and the Russian Federation. This protocol is only a compliance that I am in favour of. That is why I voted for this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The conclusion of the Protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement establishing a partnership between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and Russia, of the other part, to take account of Croatia's accession to the European Union is a significant moment for Croatia as part of the EU.  The Protocol includes the Republic of Croatia as a Contracting Party to the Agreement and represents the EU's commitment to provide the authentic version of the Agreement in the new official language of the European Union. The Partnership and Cooperation Agreement with the Russian Federation includes, inter alia, the promotion of trade and investment, including trade in transport services, and establishes a framework for cooperation, which is limited to general economic, financial and technical cooperation, in different sectors. I voted in favour of this report, which symbolizes a normal stage in the current context of Croatia's full accession to the European Union.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstained, technical vote, the protocol commits the EU to provide the version of the agreement also in Croatian following the entry into force of Croatia in the EU.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. As Croatia has been a member of the European Union since July 2013, its international treaties with third countries must now take this new accession into account. This report takes into account Croatia's accession in the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement with Russia. I voted in favour of this text which approves this protocol change.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This report is a technical file. In a nutshell it is a formalistic procedural matter which acknowledges the accession of Croatia to the EU and does not change the content of the agreement as such. Therefore, I voted in favour of this report.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Following the accession of Croatia to the European Union, Parliament has been called upon to give its consent to the Protocol incorporating the Republic of Croatia as a contracting party to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement with Russia. The Protocol contains a clause specifying that the Agreement is amended following the entry into force of the Treaty of Accession of Croatia to the European Union on 1 July 2013. I voted in favour.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because there are no controversial aspects to the text.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which gives Parliament's approval to the Council's agreement on behalf of the EU with a memorandum to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement establishing a CE-Russia partnership. This agreement, signed between the EEC and Russia on 24 June 1994 and entered into force on 1 December 1997, aims to promote trade and investment between EU Member States and the Russian Federation, trade and strategic cooperation to which I am in favour. The protocol in question therefore consists of integrating Croatia into this agreement as a result of its accession to the EU on 1 July 2013, which is a logical compliance procedure. However, I remain resistant to the principle of comprehensive partnership agreements under the patronage of the EU, even of a trade type, and would like us to favour bilateral agreements according to the own interests of each Member State.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This measure concerns the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and all its Member States, of the Protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement establishing a partnership between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the Russian Federation, of the other part, to take account of Croatia's accession to the European Union. , as the 28th Member State, which took place on 1 July 2013. I have therefore chosen to vote in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution because incorporating the Republic of Croatia as a contracting party to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the EU Member States and the Russian Federation thus broadens as far as possible the general principles underlying the partnership, namely respect for democracy, the market economy, the principles of international law and human rights.  It should be noted that this is a formal change, due to the enlargement of the EU and therefore croatia's participation in the agreement.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Partnership and Cooperation Agreement with the Russian Federation aims to promote trade and investment, and establishes a framework for global, exclusively economic, financial and technical cooperation in a number of areas. I have therefore chosen to vote in favour of the proposal for a protocol which, taking into account croatia's recent accession, specifies the amendment of the aforementioned agreement in force.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This vote reflects the accession of Croatia to the EU, which as a Member State is to enjoy the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Communities and their Member States and the Russian Federation. I have thus voted in favour.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Recommendation in favour of granting approval for the conclusion of the Protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement establishing cooperation between the European Communities and its Member States on the one hand, and the Russian Federation on the other, as a technical amendment to that EU-Russia Agreement, which has to be updated to take account of accession to the European Union of the Republic of Croatia.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I consented to the Protocol which takes into account the accession of Croatia to the EU and the need to reflect this change in the existing Partnership and Cooperation agreement with Russia.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. The purpose of this report is to authorize the ratification of an amending protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between Russia and the European Union, which, signed in 1994, has established privileged economic relations since 1997 between the two parties to the agreement. The purpose of the amending protocol in question is to take into account Croatia's accession to the European Union in 2013. As Croatia is a member of the European Union in its own right, it is necessary to gradually change the European conventional acquis in this direction. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. As Croatia is a new Member State, it must align its situation with that of the other 27 states in terms of the Union's external partnerships.  That is why I voted for this text, which allows us to review the relationship between Croatia and the Russian Federation, with which the European Communities has concluded a partnership and cooperation agreement.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. This agreement is a simple agreement signed between the EEC and Russia on 24 June 1994 and entered into force on 1 December 1997, which aims to promote trade and investment between EU Member States and the Russian Federation, which we support. I therefore voted in favour of a protocol to integrate Croatia into this agreement because of its accession to the EU on 1 July 2013.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the recommendation because Croatia has always pursued a consistently anti-Greek policy on all issues of interest to Greece at local, regional and international level, such as the issue of the name of Skopje, economic policy at Community level, etc.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Protocol includes Croatia as a Party to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Community and Russia with retroactive effect from the date of accession of Croatia. This is a necessary technical amendment, which I voted in favour of. As far as EU-Russian relations are concerned, I would like to draw the Commission's attention to the fact that the third round of EU compensation for the damage to the fruit and vegetables market caused by the Russian agricultural embargo at the end of last year Hungary also omitted, as were Croatia, Slovenia and Romania.
