In Hungary, the volume of preliminary applications received last September was more than 10 000 tonnes, i.e. in order of magnitude higher than the quantity envisaged for the country in the second round. To alleviate this, the free-to-use 3,000-ton frame provided in the second round was Hungary only partially exploited due to the shortness of time. This framework is no longer available to my country, and it would be very justified.  On the basis of the above, on the one hand, I demand that the Commission provide hungarian, Croatian, Slovenian and Romanian farmers with additional compensation in order to reduce their losses caused by the overproduction crisis. It may do so by extending the period of use of the second-round framework or by announcing a new freely usable 3 000-ton limit.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament thus makes it possible to conclude the agreement enabling the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the Protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Communities and their Member States, on the one hand, and the Russian Federation, of the other part, to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union.

name: Edouard Ferrand (NI)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text because it is a logical follow-up. Indeed, since Croatia joined the Union on 1 July 2013, it would seem abnormal that Croatia would exclude itself from the EU-Russia Trade Agreements. However, we can only deplore the fact that this type of agreement, which is generally infringing on national sovereignty.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 With this cooperation protocol with the Russian Federation, the EU aims to promote trade and investment, trade in transport services and establishes a framework for exclusively economic, financial and technical cooperation in different sectors.  Following Croatia's entry into the EU, croatia undertakes to provide the Croatian version of the agreement as well.

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I am a supporter of Croatia's full, full membership of the European Union. It would seem that the extension of the EU Partnership and Cooperation Agreement with the Russian Federation to Croatia is only a slight procedural correction. However, it sends an undesirable political signal, implying acceptance of Russia's status as a partner country. Meanwhile, it is the country responsible for the illegal annexation of Crimea, the armed aggression against eastern Ukraine and the application of elements of hybrid warfare to its neighbours, including EU members. The Partnership and Cooperation Agreement with the Russian Federation, which is trying forcibly to rebuild the zone of influence from the Soviet Union or the Russian Empire, should be suspended and, if the aggression continues, terminated.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Croatia has always pursued a consistently anti-Greek policy on all issues of interest to Greece at local, regional and international level, such as the issue of the name of Skopje, economic policy at Community level, etc. I am voting against amending the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement establishing a partnership between the EC and Russia to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This is a technical report that takes into account the accession of Croatia to the EU and the need to reflect this change in the existing Partnership and Cooperation Agreement with Russia.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement establishing cooperation between the European Communities and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Russian Federation, on the other hand, to take into account the accession to the European Union of the Republic of Croatia.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. The Landsbergis report on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Protocol to the Partnership Agreement with the Russian Federation allowing Croatia to be integrated as a contracting party is an important sign of the Balkan country's further inclusion in the Eu ropean Union's trade and economic structures and multilateral relations.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I gave my consent to the Landsbergis report given it concerns a simple procedural amendment of the Protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement establishing a partnership between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the Russian Federation, of the other part, to take account of the accession of Croatia to the European Union.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in FAVOUR of the draft Protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement establishing a collaboration between the European Communities and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Russian Federation, on the other, to take account of the accession to the European Union of the Republic of Croatia.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Protocol which takes into account the accession of Croatia to the EU and the need to reflect this change in the existing Partnership and Cooperation agreement with Russia.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because following the accession of Croatia to the EU it is necessary to update the existing Partnership Agreement and have legal accuracy.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in FAVOUR of the draft Protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement establishing a collaboration between the European Communities and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Russian Federation, on the other, to take account of the accession to the European Union of the Republic of Croatia.

name: Carlos Iturgaiz (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting in favour of this Resolution which benefits cooperation and accession to the European Union of the Republic of Croatia.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted to recommend the draft decision of the Council on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the Protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement establishing partnerships between the European Communities and their Member States, on the one hand, and the Russian Federation, on the other, in order to take into account the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union, as it is a , as the Republic of Croatia has become a member of the EU.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. This agreement is a simple compliance with Croatia's agreement between the EEC and Russia on 24 June 1994 and entered into force on 1 December 1997, which aims to promote trade and investment between EU Member States and the Russian Federation, trade and strategic cooperation to which we are in favour. I therefore voted in favour of a protocol which therefore consists of integrating Croatia into this agreement because of its accession to the EU on 1 July 2013

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the recommendation of my colleague Gabrielius Landsbergis on the partnership agreement with Russia. This report aims to take into account Croatia's accession to the EU and to integrate it into the partnership agreement so that it can benefit from its provisions. The recommendation was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported the recommendation to conclude a protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement establishing a partnership between the European Communities and their Member States, on the one hand, and the Russian Federation, on the other, to take into account the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union.  As this agreement was concluded before the enlargement of the Union to Croatia, it is therefore necessary to add to the agreement a new protocol to take account of this accession.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of the proposed Protocol which calls for Croatia to be incorporated as a party to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the EU and Russia, taking into consideration Croatia’s accession to the EU in 2013.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as it is of a technical nature taking into account the accession of Croatia to the EU and the need to reflect this change in the existing Partnership and Cooperation Agreement with Russia.

name: Philippe Loiseau (NI)
text: In writing. Positive vote. Parliament wants to integrate Croatia, a member of the European Union since 1 July 2013, into an agreement signed on 24 June 1997 on trade and investment between EU member states and Russia. This seems to us to be a good initiative. The National Front believes that this cooperation reinforces a rapprochement already undertaken with a highly strategic country.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. This is a technical, non-political report that takes into account Croatia's accession to the EU and the need to reflect this change in the existing Partnership and Cooperation Agreement with Russia.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Recommendation in favour of granting approval for the conclusion of the Protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement establishing cooperation between the European Communities and its Member States on the one hand, and the Russian Federation on the other, as a technical amendment to that EU-Russia Agreement, which has to be updated to take account of accession to the European Union of the Republic of Croatia.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the proposal as I believe that, following Croatia's accession to the European Union on 1 July 2013, Croatia should be part of the Protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement establishing collaboration between the European Communities and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Russian Federation on the other.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 Croatia is the newest member of the EU and it was therefore necessary to update the treaties to count on it as part of one contracting party. This will enable Croatia to join trade and investment under the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement of the European Communities, the Member States and the Russian Federation.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support Rapporteur Landsbergis's recommendation to promote trade in goods and is a framework for cooperation in different sectors between the EU and Russia. Unfortunately, following Russian aggression in Ukraine, the European Union has imposed sanctions on Russia, and the Republic of Croatia as a full Member State approaches international agreements signed or concluded by the European Union and implements the decisions taken. We believe that in the shortest time Russian aggression will be ended and an annexed part of Crimea returned to the administration of Ukraine, which will create the conditions for lifting the embargo and resuming trade between the EU and Russia.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I abstained from voting on the recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the Protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement establishing a partnership between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the Russian Federation, of the other part, to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union , because I believe that this recommendation does not adequately address the issues under consideration.

name: Dominique Martin (NI)
text: In writing. Vote for this report. In place since 1 December 1997, this agreement aims to promote trade between Member States and Russia. The new protocol we are voting on today aims to integrate Croatia, which has recently joined the EU. We are in favour of this trade and strategic cooperation between the EU and Russia, and this integration of Croatia is a logical continuation that we can only support.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this agreement on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the Protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement establishing a partnership between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the Russian Federation, of the other part, to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the recommendation concerning the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Croatia-Russia agreements. Given the current state of EU-Russia relations, such an agreement tends to promote a necessary balance with countries that are part of the European Community and therefore comply with certain directives, including relations with the Russian Federation. The signing of a partnership agreement also promotes market conditions between countries, supporting trade, and sectors that can enjoy economies of scale by exploiting products that exploit international trade.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This document serves as a legal instrument necessary for the signing of a protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement establishing a partnership between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the Russian Federation, of the other part, to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union.  The partnership and cooperation agreement with the Russian Federation aims, in particular, at promoting trade and investment. In view of the fact that the main objective of this agreement is to promote growth and rational exchange of resources between countries, I have decided to support the Landsbergis report.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. The Partnership and Cooperation Agreement with the Russian Federation is intended to strengthen trade and investment, promote trade in transport services and regulate the framework conditions for cooperation on economic and financial issues. However, important issues have remained unanswered, which is why I abstained.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. An EU-Russia partnership agreement has been under way since 1997. To take account of Croatia's accession to the EU, the Memorandum of Understanding should be amended to include Croatia. Opposed to both free trade agreements and any new EU membership, I can only oppose this amendment, even if it remains purely technical. I'm voting against it.

name: Joëlle Mélin (NI)
text: In writing. This agreement is a simple compliance with Croatia's agreement between the EEC and Russia on 24 June 1994 and entered into force on 1 December 1997, which aims to promote trade and investment between EU Member States and the Russian Federation, trade and strategic cooperation to which we are in favour.  So I voted FOR.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this technical measure, as Parliament must give its consent before new Member States can be recognised by signatories of the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement. In this case Parliament had to give its consent to the agreement being amended to take into account the Treaty of Accession of Croatia.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this report that takes into account the accession of Croatia to the EU and the need to reflect this change in the existing PCA with Russia.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 With Croatia's accession to the EU, it became necessary to include Croatia as a contracting party to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement establishing the EC-Russia Partnership. The Protocol may be adopted by the Council only with the approval of Parliament.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. The aim of this report is to approve the PROTOCOL and the partnership and cooperation agreement establishing an EC-Russia partnership, which was concluded by the Council on behalf of the Union. This agreement aims to encourage trade and investment between the Member States of the Union and the Russian Federation, which I support. However, the only purpose of this protocol is to update the list of parties to the agreement, including Croatia, since it joined the Union on 1 July 2013.  I remain committed to the sovereignty of the Member States in the framework of trade agreements, but the agreement is already in place, and moreover with a strategic partner for Europe and France. So I voted for this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the procedural amendment as it takes into account the accession of Croatia to the EU.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this purely technical text on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement establishing a partnership between the European Communities and their Member States, on the one hand, and the Russian Federation, on the other hand, to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome the conclusion of the protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement with the Russian Federation, which must now also take into account the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union. Since this is a mere technical amendment, devoid of any political considerations, we have no comment/objection to make in this regard.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I gave my approval to the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the Protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement establishing a partnership between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the Russian Federation, of the other part, to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union.  The proposal for a protocol includes the Republic of Croatia between the contracting parties to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement, and commits the European Union to providing the authentic version of the agreement in the new official language of the EU. The Protocol also contains a clause specifying that the agreement has been amended following the entry into force of the Treaty of Accession of Croatia to the European Union on 1 July 2013.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the Protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement establishing a partnership between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the Russian Federation, of the other part , in order to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union, having regard to the necessity and importance of this Protocol relating to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. A partnership between the European Community and the European Community continues to point to the important common relations and interests, but I would have found it time to rethink and adapt our partnership system in general. On the basis of these considerations, I abstained.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the draft because croatia's accession treaty to the EU provides for Croatia's accession to the International Agreements concluded by the European Union by means of a protocol.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Having regard to the draft protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement establishing a partnership between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the Russian Federation, of the other part, to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union (11513/2014) and having regard to the recommendation of the Committee on Foreign Affairs (A8-0129/2015), I voted in favour.

name: Florian Philippot (NI)
text: In writing. This text is the mere extension to Croatia if a partnership agreement between the European Community and Russia. This is therefore a logical compliance after Croatia joins the European Union. That is why I am voting in favour of this report.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. I support the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the Protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement establishing partnerships between the European Communities and their Member States on the one hand and the Russian Federation on the other, in order to take into account the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union.  The Republic of Croatia has been a full member of the European Union for almost two years, fully aligned with the European Union's policies towards Russia, which is why it is also important that the Agreements of the European Union, in this case with the Russian Federation, align with Croatia's accession to the European Union.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the recommendation of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, the conclusion of the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement establishing a partnership between the European Communities and their Member States, on the one hand, and the Russian Federation, on the other, is an automatic act because it simply takes into account the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union and therefore a new member in addition to the partnership.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. At the moment, relations between the European Union and Russia are currently very tense, particularly in relation to the Ukraine issue. As part of the deepening of relations between these two partners, the European Parliament voted in favour of the recommendation on the EC-Russia Partnership and Cooperation Agreement, to take account of Croatia's accession to the EU. I have spoken in favour of this recommendation and I believe that it is necessary for Russia to recognise the entire territory of the Union in order to be able to consolidate our diplomatic and economic relations in the future if the geopolitical context permits.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. Relations between the European Union and the Russian Federation have recently been somewhat troubled. I believe that establishing a protocol of agreement and partnership, even with regard to the accession of another sovereign State to the European Union (Croatia) may somehow avoid some future friction.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this recommendation so that the Republic of Croatia can participate fully as a member of the European Union in the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Communities and the Russian Federation, signed in 1994 and in force since 1997.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. This is a technical report on a draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement establishing a partnership between the European Communities and their Member States, on the one hand, and the Russian Federation, on the other, to take into account the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union. This afternoon, Parliament gave its approval to the conclusion of this agreement.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal for a recommendation on the conclusion of the Protocol incorporating the Republic of Croatia as a Contracting Party to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the Russian Federation, of the other part, and establishing the amendment of the agreement after the entry into force of the Treaty of Accession of Croatia to the European Union , on 1 July 2013.  In fact, with the act of accession, Croatia is acceding to international agreements signed or concluded by the EU and its Member States, by means of a protocol attached to those agreements. This is just one more, alrelated to economic, trade and investment cooperation, and there is a separate process in relation to matters within the competence of the European Atomic Energy Community.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation concerning the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Partnership Protocol because of the strategic importance of this agreement.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in FAVOUR of the draft Protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement establishing a collaboration between the European Communities and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Russian Federation, on the other, to take account of the accession to the European Union of the Republic of Croatia.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained in the vote on this Recommendation, in favour of granting approval for the conclusion of the Protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement establishing cooperation between the European Communities and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Russian Federation, on the other. Apparently, this is a technical amendment to this EU-Russia agreement, which has to be updated to take account of the accession to the European Union of the Republic of Croatia, but I am not sure that this change has a negative impact on the populations it affects.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 With today's vote, the European Parliament approves the draft Council decision on the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Communities and their Member States on the one hand and the Russian Federation on the other to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union. On the basis of the protocol, I voted in favour.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted with the Socialists & Democrats Group in support of the recommendation to consent to the conclusion of the Protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement establishing a partnership between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the Russian Federation, of the other part, to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the recommendation on the protocol with the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement establishing a partnership between the European Community and the Russian Federation, in order to take into account the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union. Given that this Agreement concerns overall economic, financial and technical cooperation, Croatia's accession to the European Union greatly changes the entire economic picture of the Union.  If we add the recent sanctions imposed by the European Union on Russia, trade, as well as the investment of signatories to the treaty further change the economic situation. The aforementioned package of sanctions changed the economic picture of Croatia itself, bearing in mind that Croatia lost approximately 1.5% of total exports of agri-food products worth between $20-25m.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Taking into account Croatia's accession to the EU under the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Communities and Russia is a logical step for the EU. Croatia is a country that has successfully mastered the integration process and can set an example for the current candidate countries, especially the Balkan countries.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. In this proposal, for which I voted positively, the Council was invited to take a decision with a view to approving, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, a protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement establishing a partnership between the European Community and their Member States, on the one hand, and Russia, on the other, in order to take into account Croatia's accession to the European Union.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which takes into account Croatia’s accession to the EU in the conclusion of the Protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Communities and Russia.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. – Croatia and Russia have traditionally developed trade cooperation. Croatia has seen a sharp increase in exports to the Russian market in the past few years, and Russia has become one of the leading export partners to Croatia. Last year was also one of the best export years of Croatia to Russia, with exports of about US$420 million.  By joining the EU, Croatia has become part of the EU single internal market where other legislation is relevant. Among other things, trade agreements regulated between Croatia and other member states have ceased to apply. In particular, in order to better understand the legislative powers of trade, I believe that existing EU legislation needs to be adapted or made understandable to all beneficiaries.  That is why I support the adoption of the protocol with the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement establishing partnerships between the European Communities and their Member States, on the one hand, and the Russian Federation, on the other hand, taking into account the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal as it only aims to update the current legal situation in view of Croatia's accession to the EU.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Avoiding conflicts, diplomatic and non-diplomatic, is of enormous importance and becomes even more important when it comes to Russia, a country that is on European soil and cooperates with several Member States. We believe that the European Parliament's consensus to include Croatia in the cooperation protocol with Russia, after its first accession to the EU, is a positive step.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Croatia has always pursued a consistently anti-Greek policy on all issues of interest to Greece at local, regional and international level, such as the issue of the name of Skopje, economic policy at Community level and more.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I supported the Council's draft decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement establishing a partnership between the European Communities and their Member States, on the one hand, and the Russian Federation, on the other hand, to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement establishing a partnership between the European Community and the Russian Federation to take into account Croatia's accession to the EU. The adoption of this protocol achieves the necessary form governing trade relations, transport, investments as well as technical cooperation frameworks and apply to the common market, establishing an orderly partnership with the Russian Federation. Regulated relations and additional investments, as well as greater economic cooperation are extremely important for the further continuation of the development of relations between Croatia and Russia, and are welcome as an incentive and opportunity for domestic businessmen for export. Therefore, as an MP from the Republic of Croatia, I support this step towards further strengthening economic relations and cooperation between the two countries. As a member of the European Union, Croatia should fully engage in its acquis.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in FAVOUR of the draft Protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement establishing a collaboration between the European Communities and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Russian Federation, on the other, to take account of the accession to the European Union of the Republic of Croatia.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (NI)
text: In writing. Parliament wants to integrate Croatia, a member of the European Union since 1 July 2013, into an agreement signed on 24 June 1997 on trade and investment between member states and Russia. This seems to us to be a good initiative. The National Front believes that this cooperation reinforces a rapprochement already undertaken with a highly strategic country. Croatia joined the European Union on 1 July 2013. So I'm voting FOR.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour; the parliamentary approval by Parliament of the draft Council Decision on the conclusion of the Protocol on behalf of the European Union and its Member States to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union annexed to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement establishing a partnership between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the Russian Federation, of the other part.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in FAVOUR of the draft Protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement establishing a collaboration between the European Communities and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Russian Federation, on the other, to take account of the accession to the European Union of the Republic of Croatia.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Recommendation in favour of granting approval for the conclusion of the Protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement establishing cooperation between the European Communities and its Member States on the one hand, and the Russian Federation, on the other hand, as a technical amendment to that EU-Russia Agreement, which has to be updated to take account of accession to the European Union of the Republic of Croatia.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This text, which was put to the vote of the European Parliament, was intended to revise the protocol establishing an EC-Russia partnership to take account of Croatia's accession to the EU. This vote was, in fact, a purely legal formality. But such a vote is also at the limits of the absurd, since it completely ignores the international context and the tense relations between the European Union and Russia because of the situation in Ukraine, even though, in the Chamber, anti-Russian interventions sometimes border on hysteria. Beyond this particular context, however, I voted for this text, which allows me to reaffirm my opposition to any breakdown of diplomatic ties with Russia. Like all members of my group, I oppose this bellicose obsession and this one-sided view of the cold war-like conflict and primary anti-communism that the right of the Chamber feeds. This is not the way to find a solution to the Ukrainian conflict. Quite the opposite. The GUE/NGL calls more than ever for the resumption of dialogue with Russia, without complacency or enmity, taking into account the violations of human rights and fundamental freedoms committed by all the belligerents.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the Protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement establishing a partnership between the European Communities and their Member States, on the one hand, and the Russian Federation, on the other, stems from the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union, against which we have nothing but for which the Croatian people will not fail to pay a high price if the current eu policies remain.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. The Partnership and Cooperation Agreement with the Russian Federation is intended to strengthen trade and investment, promote trade in transport services and regulate the framework conditions for cooperation on economic and financial issues. However, important issues have remained unanswered, which is why I abstained.

name: Kosma Złotowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Russia is not currently a party with which the EU should in any way move to normal diplomatic relations. Although this amendment concerns only technical aspects and is not intended to modify the substance of this agreement, until Russia's illegal activities in Ukraine have ceased, Crimea has been returned and Russian troops have been withdrawn from the territory of an EU-affiliated country, we should freeze any such action. Even if it is an insignificant gesture, it is needed to manifest our outrage at Moscow's violation of international law. That is why I voted against this recommendation.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \ , as parliament's approval was necessary for the conclusion of the protocol. In accordance with the Act of Accession of Croatia, it should accede to international agreements signed or concluded between the European Union and its Member States by means of protocols there to those agreements. Council Decision of 14 September 2012 authorised the Commission to open negotiations with the third countries concerned with a position to conclude the relevant protocols. As negotiations with the Russian Federation were successfully concluded, a Protocol involving the Republic of Croatia as a Party to the Agreement had to be concluded on behalf of the European Union and obliges the EU to provide a credible version of the Agreement in the new official language of the EU.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Mr President, thank you for being able to comment on this report, which was supported today by a large majority of the European Parliament. It concerns the follow-up to the implementation of the Bologna process. This report was prepared by my colleague Krystyn Łyback, and I would like to thank her very much for the very comprehensive report and the cooperation that was with her on this report. Unfortunately, there was no possible debate in the Plenary of the European Parliament and it could not be emphasised that this report focuses mainly on promoting further development and funding by the European Union towards improving the quality of higher education within the so-called European higher education area. The report was also prepared in the context of the forthcoming Ministerial Conference on the Bologna Process, which will take place in Yerevan in May and is therefore a mandate for this ministerial conference. I therefore thank my colleagues for their cooperation on this report.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI).
text: – 15 years ago, the Bologna Process for the reform of Higher Education in Europe was launched. We would have expected this report to produce a real balance sheet, what was successful, what was a failure, what needs to be changed. Unfortunately, this has not happened, but we have to face the fact that the most important objective, the establishment of a training system in line with labour market demand, has failed. And not precisely because the Bologna system was used to dismantle the two-tier dual higher education system, which had worked well until then, the college and university system. And here the report says that stronger consultation is needed to end the opposition to the Bologna reforms within the higher education community. We don't need marketing, we need real balance sheeting, valuation and change.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, I voted against the report on the implementation of the Bologna Process, because this process has been used to promote the undermining of the public character of higher education in Greece and the other countries of the European Union. This paved the way for the privatisation of a purely public good, such as higher education, and tuition fees were imposed on the postgraduate programmes of HEI in Greece. The Bologna Process was supposed to make a significant contribution to employment, but youth unemployment is soaring. In Greece it has reached 51.7% and 200,000 young scientists, i.e. 2% of the Greek population, migrated to the countries of the hard core of the European Union. At the same time, the reduction in education funds imposed by the Memorandums on the countries of the European south, combined with the Bologna requirements, is driving education towards a purely commercial approach.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE).
text: – Mr. President, the main message of this report is that a reform of the Bologna Process and the development of new models of education are needed, which I fully agreed with.  The Bologna process began in 1999 and is now being implemented in the 47 countries that make up the European Higher Education Area. It was introduced with the aim of raising the quality and standardization of higher education, and enables recognition of qualifications and diplomas and mobility of students and professors. It is precisely the exchange of knowledge, experience and practices at different universities that is the best way to improve quality.  When we draw the line today and look at the results of fifteen years of work on the Bologna Process, we see positive changes in terms of better organization of higher education and opportunities to compare the education system in the Member States. But the big drawback persists, which is a lack of connectivity to labour market needs. As a result, urgent changes are needed.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE).
text: – Comparability of the quality of educational attainment and overcoming the language barrier create opportunities for many young people to use their talents and knowledge. Regardless of whether they are citizens of Germany, France or Slovakia. Together with the rapporteur, I would therefore like to highlight the important link between the Bologna Process, research support and Erasmus+. I support the report that has been tabled. However, high unemployment among young graduates should not interest us and lead to uncritical support for scientific and technological fields of study. The low application of graduates of the humanities is more related to a long-term decrease in their quality. The technique itself does not put us to a good time, because in the end there is always a search for a relationship with people. And understanding man is the domain of the humanities.

name: Milan Zver (PPE).
text: – Allow me to thank the rapporteur here, who has produced a very good report on the progress of the Bologna process, Mrs Łybacki. And the way the work was introduced in the preparation of the report was also very correct. We have also worked with other shadow rapporteurs on the text. I think it is right that there is a bit more talk about the Bologna process. There was not much room for this on Monday night, and it is right that we can say a word about this in the context of the explanation of the voice. The Bologna reform is one of the most important reforms that has outgrown the borders of the European Union, and if we continue with it, as we have started, I am convinced that in the future we will reduce the great gap between what the university is producing today and what the market needs.

name: Eleonora Forenza (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted against mr Łybacka's own-initiative report because I believe that, fifteen years after the entry into force of the Bologna Process, we need a serious and thorough budget.  We believe that the report before us today lacks a fundamental point, namely the profound insurgement, not only economic, to which a great many of the counter-reforms applied in the Member States have contributed and which have been variously invoked in the Bologna Process. I am thinking of the Italian university system, which was brought to collapse first by the tremonti cuts, then by the Gelmini reform, and I say this having experienced first-hand the dimension of precariousness in university research.  We are based the knowledge system on the logic of competition. We believe that we need to change course and move it in the direction of cooperation, the right to study and the right to university research free from market constraints.

name: Lars Adaktusson (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 Carrying out higher-level studies compatible and comparable within Europe is important and facilitates cross-border movement in terms of study and work. It is important that the Bologna process be developed. At the same time, it should be mentioned that the text contained paragraphs which I believe should not be decided at EUROPEAN level, such as the increase in student grants. Nevertheless, I chose to vote in favour of the report.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The vote is against for a simple reason.  We are tired of words alone, now more than ever we need action. The M5S supports the public nature of education and the enhancement of the social dimension of knowledge. Education is an inalienable right and is present in all national constitutions. The fundamental function of the European higher education area must be human, social and cultural development, while the final text shows the desire to bend universities to the interests of business. I have called for the elimination of public funding for private universities, avoiding support for processes of privatisation of knowledge. The answer was to put as the cornerstone of the report the implementation of the Juncker plan, in respect of which the Commission itself confirmed to us that 'Private investment in the plan could have the effect of transferring majority control from the public to the private sector'. Access to education must be open to all, funds for private individuals should be invested in the future of our young people, favouring the most disadvantaged students and increasing the number of scholarships.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against the report on the implementation of the Bologna Process since I reject the measures being taken in its implementation, as well as the 2020 Strategy, which leads to the commodization and privatization of higher education and competition between universities. I also reject the involvement of companies in the development of educational programmes and the submission of education to the dogma of free competition and market interests. I believe that the responsibility of the education system should lie with the State and that it is the Member States which must ensure true recognition of diplomas. The budget for education and research should increase, as should the number and amount of scholarships. In addition, I am convinced that educational diversity, including linguistic diversity, must be respected in Europe. Therefore, since I are defending a public, universal, free and quality education that meets the needs of society and not markets, I have only been able to vote against this report on the Bologna Process.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. In 1999, 29 European countries committed themselves to the establishment of a European Higher Education Area under the Bologna Declaration. Sixteen years later, the process is now evaluated and then revised. Particular successes have been achieved in the field of harmonisation and recognition of studies, the associated increase in the mobility of European students and transnational employability. In addition, Europe-wide higher education systems are now more transparent and offer easy and quick access to information. The European Higher Education Area now has 47 members. I welcome the evaluation of the implementation of the Bologna Process and its further development, in particular in order to ensure Europe-wide quality and to optimally coordinate the various measures, such as Horizon 2020 and Erasmus+.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. This is a process of bringing European higher education systems closer together. Its main objective is to support mobility and internationalisation as well as to make the standards and quality of the various higher education systems compatible and comparable. It thus aims to harmonize European higher education, which goes hand in hand with its anglicisation. The anglicisation it highlights calls into question the European spirit of equality of cultures and languages. It also marks the commodification of higher education, which he sees only through the prism of economic growth. In addition, it would allow the European institutions to have more and more control over institutions that reduce their intellectual autonomy. Excessive anglicisation, as well as interference by the European Union in the name of supposedly advantageous financial aid, runs counter to the authenticity of French higher education. So I voted against the text.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation because the Bologna process has, in its end, enabled greater student mobility in Europe. I call for the same success in the future for apprentices.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to assess the implementation of the Bologna Process. In 1999, 29 European countries signed the Bologna Declaration, which aimed to create a European Higher Education Area by 2010. It identifies how and using the tools to create a common European higher education area by choosing a system of clear and comparable degrees based on two cycles in higher education, introducing a credit system, promoting mobility of students and teachers, and ensuring the quality of higher education. I agree that today we need even stronger political commitment and cooperation between the countries of the European Higher Education Area. It is important to develop additional tools and new working methods, such as clustering, which could help countries in difficulty to make better progress, while encouraging others to achieve even higher targets. It is also necessary to exchange best practices, to make greater use of the Bologna Network of Experts and to involve academia more widely. I agree that the educational paradigm should be shifted from what is taught to what students need to learn. In addition, there is a need to constantly invest and make more efficient use of the available funds.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. The Bologna process is a process of bringing European higher education systems closer together, which began in 1998 and led to the creation in 2010 of the European Higher Education Area of some 50 states. This process leads de facto to the commodification of higher education, a decrease in social justice, and a loss of intellectual autonomy of institutions. Higher education is seen only through the prism of economic growth. And it is to make students more "competitive" in the global job market that the Bologna process leads to a forced anglicization of higher education.  That is why I am opposed to it.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The Bologna Declaration, signed in June 1999, aimed to create a European higher education area by 2010. Today, 47 states are part of the Bologna process. Its aim was to improve student mobility, the quality of education and the employability of young teaching graduates. Although Bologna is a success overall, it is necessary to breathe new life into it to overcome the challenges that lie ahead, particularly in terms of youth employment. To achieve the goal of consistent, transparent and good quality higher education, it is crucial to focus on implementing all the tools at our disposal and to place the student at the centre of the educational paradigm. It is therefore to improve the quality of higher education in Europe that I have decided to support this report.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the follow-up report on the implementation of the Bologna process, as the Lybacka report shifts the current situation and the development of the process which at the time generated much criticism and crunch in the European education sector. Europe's future is for young people who need to be able to access the best quality higher education systems.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. The report on the implementation of the Bologna process is a text that does not meet the expectations of the world of higher education and research or young Europeans looking for work. While the European Union should trust its academics to best train students and thus offer them a better chance of finding a job, this report aims to force the university to adapt to ultraliberal globalisation in the greatest disregard of academic freedoms and teacher-researchers. Moreover, I can only underline the cynicism of this text, which seeks to promote university exchanges through the Erasmus programme, in particular, while at the same time the European Union is depriving Swiss students of this scheme in retaliation for the favourable vote of the Swiss people in the referendum restricting mass immigration in February 2014. Very positive for students, university exchanges should not be used as a means of pressure from the European Union against the sovereign peoples. For all these reasons, I am voting against this text.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported with my vote this measure that aims to eliminate the bureaucratic delays necessary for the development of the Bologna process whose aim is to converge, not standardize, higher education systems thanks to the development of common rules of cooperation to offer students a wider and more transparent range of opportunities.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. The Bologna Process was born with the aim of ensuring a coherent, transparent and high quality higher education, which would ensure high common standards to facilitate student mobility. Although 47 countries are currently participating and some of the objectives set out have been achieved, much remains to be done in meeting them, while new challenges have arisen, such as high youth unemployment, economic constraints or demographic changes, which demand new developments. The report, promoted by the S&D Group, calls for an objective and critical review of progress and setbacks in achieving the priorities set for the period 2012-2015 in order to further consolidate the European Higher Education Area, boost the Bologna Process in the face of new challenges such as those described and encourage higher targets , with the participation and commitment of all stakeholders, including the social partners. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it is being advocated by the European Parliament for further action towards the creation of a single European Higher Education Area. 1999 European countries have signed the Bologna Declaration, which aims to create a European Higher Education Area (EUROPEAN HIGHER EDUCATION AREA) by 2010. EHEA). The aim was and continues to provide students with a wider and more transparent choice of high-quality education opportunities and to create a simplified internal and external recognition process for participating national higher education systems. In the meantime, all 47 members of the Bologna Process have made major reforms to their education systems. Parliament notes, however, that much remains to be achieved in order for the European higher education system to meet its current challenges. Parliament considers that the concept of education is more student-centred and results-oriented, and it is also important to strengthen the links between higher education and research by facilitating dialogue between researchers and society and promoting useful ways of using technological innovation for teaching and learning.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Krystyna Lybacka's report adopted a comprehensive report on the monitoring of the implementation of the Bologna Process. In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I believe that progress in the field of higher education can be expected through the targeted proposals in the report.  As a result of the Bologna reforms, the European Higher Education Area has been launched and significant achievements have been made over the last 15 years in making higher education systems more comparable, enhancing mobility, ensuring quality assurance systems and recognition of diplomas, improving the quality of education systems and increasing the attractiveness of Higher Education in Europe. Within the Bologna Process, much still needs to be done to adapt education systems to labour market needs, improve overall employability and competitiveness, and improve the attractiveness of Higher Education in Europe.  The European Parliament calls on the countries of the European Higher Education Area to implement jointly agreed reforms aimed at accelerating the achievement of the objectives set by the Bologna Process and enhancing the credibility of the European Higher Education Area. Unfortunately, some Member States and their higher education institutions still do not recognise each other's diplomas and qualifications in the European higher education area, which can have disadvantages. I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Each country's education sector is central to social and economic development and its improvement must be placed among the priorities of policies that aim for growth. Sixteen years have passed since the bologna declaration was signed. Since then, this process has started, with due regard for the autonomy of the Member States and universities, to harmonise the European higher education system. There has been a great deal of progress, but the objective of supporting student mobility and the internationalisation of training courses through the guarantee of a system based on compatibility and comparability of standards remains very topical. Through this resolution, which I support, Parliament is giving a strong signal both to the Member States that must implement the objectives of the process and to the Community institutions that must support those countries that are experiencing difficulties in this process. Among the main challenges that the resolution highlights, I believe that the enhancement of innovative technologies in the educational field and the work to be done to combat the phenomenon of the skills gap in relation to job vacancies are particularly important.  All this also with a view to verifying the steps taken and to be taken at the Conference of Ministers to be held in Yerevan in May.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. I support this report by my colleague Łybacke as an initiative towards the upcoming ministerial conference in Ereen on 14-15 May. Although many achievements have been achieved in the areas of implementation of the Bologna Process, there are major differences in its implementation in the participating countries. Given that youth unemployment is the biggest problem in the EU, I think it is very important that the European Parliament sends a clear message towards the upcoming conference in Ereen, in order to stand up even more for young people and thus contribute to better and better education for young people in the future.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this text on the implementation of the so-called 'Bologna' process, which has been aimed at 47 countries in the field of higher education since 2010. It can be noted that the Committee on Culture and Education, of which I am an alternate member, believes that "much remains to be done in the bologna process".

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: i scríbhinn. – Cé go raibh rudaí dearfacha le fáil sa tuarascáil seo cosúil leis an ngá atá ann níos mó infheistíochta a dhéanamh in oideachas, mar shampla, ní raibh mé ábalta tacaíocht a thabhairt di de bharr gur tháinig an tuarascáil seo go mór faoi phróiseas Bologna, próiseas i ndáiríre a chiallaíonn príobháidiú an oideachais, comórtas idir ollscoileanna agus baint a bheith ag comhlachtaí gnó le boird srl. Mar sin, chaith mé vóta i gcoinne na tuarascála seo. Chuir mo chomhghleacaí tairiscint i gcomhair rúin cun tosaigh ina áit agus chaith mé vóta i bhfabhar a rúin, ach ar an drochuair níor glacadh leis an tairiscint sin. Sa rún sin, chuir sí béim faoi leith ar an dóigh gur chóir freagracht i gcúrsaí oideachais a bheith ag na Ballstáit, gur chóir na héagsúlachtaí teagaisc ar fud fad na hEorpa (éagsúlachtaí teanga san áireamh) a chaomhnú agus gur chóir don oideachas a bheith saor, ar fáil go poiblí agus éasca teacht air do gach uile dhuine.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I decided to vote in favour of this report because implementation of the Bologna Process, with the creation of a European Higher Education Area (EHEA), plays a big part in the process of unification since an integrated education system would increase the mobility of students and faculty members in the EU and would have a very positive impact on scientific cooperation.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. The Bologna process aims to bring European higher education systems closer together, which began in 1998 and led to the creation of the European Higher Education Area in 2010. It aims to make Europe a globalised competitive space for the knowledge economy, the European higher education area. The Bologna process formalizes the anglicization and commodification of higher education. I supported France's disengagement from this process and voted against it.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 On 19 June 1999, one year after the Sorbonne Declaration, the ministers responsible for higher education in 29 European countries signed the Bologna Declaration, agreeing on six important common objectives for coherent and harmonious development in the field of higher education for 2010.  The Bologna process has meant deep reforms of higher education for all participating states, marked by changes in the relevant legislation and reconsideration of the basic principles of the educational process for a knowledge-based society.  The role of the Bologna process underlines once again that education and research are the main pillars of our society in promoting skills development, growth and job creation. I voted in favour of this report because I am convinced that investment in education is essential to combat poverty, social inequalities, social inclusion and unemployment, especially among young people. In this regard, Member States are welcome to offer more mobility opportunities and step up the implementation of the 2020 Mobility Strategy, as well as to take into account the effective promotion of Erasmus+ and Horizon 2020 programmes.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour. It is important to remember that the aim of the Bologna Process is not to standardise higher education systems, but to bring them together through the development of common rules for cooperation, while always taking into account the diversity and autonomy of individual countries and universities. I welcome the intention of the Bologna Process to eliminate the red tape of the system.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. If we want to create a single market that is consistent with fundamental freedoms such as freedom of movement of people and freedom of establishment, we must go through the recognition of Member States' university degrees. The Bologna process, established in 1999, brings some harmonisation of higher education. This harmonisation was necessary given the increasing mobility of European students mainly within the Erasmus and Erasmus frameworks. A student must be able to receive an equivalent quality of education regardless of the European country in which he is studying. I voted in favour of this report, which takes stock of the implementation of the Bologna process.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the follow-up to the implementation of the Bologna Process, which provides European higher education with the essential means of meeting today's challenges.  I believe that in today's context of economic and financial crisis, culture plays an even more strategic role with its profound impact on society and in particular on young people. It is also essential for a sense of European identity and cohesion and is one of the instruments that can help to reduce youth unemployment. It is therefore necessary to implement the correct use of available resources, finalizing existing tools on the useful result, while reducing deficiencies and promoting merit, with an increasingly results-oriented approach. It is also possible to receive important help from new technologies, with which it is also possible to acquire skills by teleconference and on the move. The links between higher education and research must also be strengthened, facilitating dialogue between the scientific world, society and SMEs. For all these important objectives, it is essential to promote synergy between actions in support of the Bologna process, such as Horizon 2020 and Erasmus+, in order to contribute to the "immaterial" implementation of the thinking of national, European and global civilisations.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: and scríbhinn. – Cé go raibh rudaí dearfacha le fáil sa tuarascáil seo cosúil leis an ngá atá ann níos mó infheistíochta a dhéanamh in oideachas, mar shampla, ní raibh mé ábalta tacaíocht a thabhairt di de bharr gur tháinig an tuarascáil seo go mór faoi phróiseas Bologna, próiseas and ndáiríre a chiallaíonn príobháidiú an oideachais, comórtas idir ollscoileanna agus baint a bheith ag comhlachtaí gnó le boird srl. Mar sin, chaith mé veóta i gcoinne na tuarascála seo. Chuir mo chomhghleacaí tairiscint and gcomhair rúin cun tosaigh ina áit agus chaith méóta i bhfabhar a rúin, ach ar an drochuair níor glacadh leis an tairiscint sin. Sa rún sin, chuir sí béim faoi leith ar an dóigh gur chóir freagracht and gcúrsaí oideachais a bheith ag na Ballstáit, gur chóir na héagsúlachtaí teagaisc ar fud fad na hEorpa (éagsúlachtaí teanga san áireamh) a chaomhnú agus gur chóir don oideachas a bheith saor, ar fáil go poiblí agus éasca teacht do air gach uile duine.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The purpose of the Bologna Declaration was to create a European Higher Education Area (EHEA) by 2010 and a great deal has been accomplished, but more needs to be done. This particular report focuses primarily on reinvigorating the Bologna Process to meet new challenges as well as to ensure the quality and transparency of the EHEA. It also represents Parliament’s position for the upcoming Ministerial Conference in Yerevan in May concerning the European Standards and Guidelines for Quality Assurance (ESG). I particularly believe that in view of pursuing the EU goals of growth and a knowledge-based economy, the Bologna Process can play an important role in revision of the Europe 2020 Strategy, and in implementation of the Investment Plan for Europe. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Bologna Declaration of 1999, which gave rise to the creation of the SEIS – European Higher Education Area – aimed to create recognition of higher education internally and externally in all signatory countries and the possibility of providing students with a higher quality of higher education. However much progress has been made, there is still much work to be done, especially with regard to the delicate transition of students to the world of work, promoting dialogue with employers at a time of crisis such as the one in the EU area. In addition, this system particularly affects universities and functionalities to market demands.

name: Jean-Marie Cavada (ALDE)
text: In writing. I welcome the adoption of Mrs Lybacka's report on monitoring the implementation of the Bologna process for several reasons.  Education is a foundation of European citizenship. This report emphasizes this crucial point, demonstrating on the one hand that higher education is a source of growth and job creation, and, on the other hand, that it is an indispensable tool to reduce inequality, combat youth unemployment and stimulate social inclusion. I have always supported the Bologna process. At present, it remains essential to the modernization of higher education institutions and systems. Nevertheless, the implementation of the reforms needs to be further implemented, in particular to facilitate better recognition of diplomas in Europe by universities as well as by employers.  I am convinced that Mrs Lybacka's report is part of this view and that it will allow us to make further progress in consolidating the European higher education area.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this motion for a resolution as I challenge the beneficial effects of the Bologna process on French higher education. Indeed, the Bologna process aims to bring European higher education systems closer together. In addition to opposing this desire for uniformity, which is at the expense of national peculiarities in education, the mechanisms of rapprochement have led to an anglicization of teachings at the expense of the Francophonie, one of the treasures of French cultural heritage. Moreover, the philosophy underlying the Bologna process is that of a commodification of education: higher education is now thought in terms of competitiveness, competition and performance, to the detriment of the student's learning of real intellectual autonomy.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Bologna Declaration was signed by twenty-nine European countries in June 1999, with the aim of creating a European Higher Education Area (SEIS) by 2010.  The aim was and remains to offer students a wider and more transparent range of high-quality education opportunities, as well as to create a simplified recognition procedure, both internally and externally, in all the national higher education systems involved. Meanwhile, all the current 47 members of the Bologna Process have introduced major reforms into their higher education systems. Over the past fifteen years, the Bologna process has achieved remarkable results in terms of quality of education, mobility and academic recognition. This measure analyses the main aspects of the Bologna process and is the European Parliament's contribution to the interministerial conference to be held in Yerevan in May. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the implementation of the Bologna Process because I am convinced that the effective creation of a European Higher Education Area could lead to the solution of some important contemporary problems.  Up to now, the objectives which inspired and inspired the process have not been achieved uniformly in the various participating countries and, above all, have not been pursued with the necessary impetus to achieve truly satisfactory results.  In fact, the Bologna process, if properly implemented, could lead to a development of levels of knowledge and innovation, ensure the compatibility and comparability of standards and quality of the different higher education systems. It could also be a response to the problem of youth unemployment, given that almost one in three employers in the European Union experiences problems in finding suitably qualified workers and the imbalance between supply and demand is one of Europe's challenges, to which a more homogeneous labour market could respond strongly.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. This report unequivocally demonstrates the importance of the Bologna process over the last 15 years and the achievements achieved by it in particular in terms of the quality of education, mobility and recognition of academic qualifications. I support the Lybacka report because, in addition to recognising achievements, it advocates the need for crucial developments and improvements to revitalise the Bologna Process, including a more student-oriented approach and outcomes, strengthening links between higher education and research, facilitating dialogue between science and society, promoting the beneficial use of technological innovations in teaching and learning, and focusing attention on better synchronisation of actions bologna process, such as Horizon 2020 and Erasmus+. .

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. A coherent, transparent and high-quality higher education is a crucial factor in Europe's cultural, economic and social development. This report gives a good overview of developments since the Bologna Declaration, which was signed in 1999. The intention of the Bologna Process was to modernise, harmonise and adapt higher education to current challenges. However, there is still much to be done to achieve this objective. The reform of higher education improves the quality and reputation of European educational institutions and promotes mobility and internationalisation. It is therefore absolutely essential that countries continue to promote structural reforms and reforms to modernise and internationalise higher education in Europe. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of approving the progress report on the Bologna process, concerning priorities, results achieved, member states' failures and suggestions on how to proceed with the implementation of the established framework. In particular, I agree with the founding principles and support the primary objective of achieving the highest possible level of knowledge and innovation for European citizens. Education and research must be recognised as the pillars of our society and, above all, as the instruments necessary for job creation. This awareness, in particular, should give young students, as well as jobs, the opportunity to enjoy quality continuing training and to put them in a position to compete with anyone worldwide. Finally, I hope that efforts to adapt education systems to the labour market will be stepped up in order to promote employment. It is therefore important for States to act in a coordinated manner, to exchange information and good practice, to promote international training programmes and to facilitate the mutual recognition of qualifications. Much has yet to be done in this respect.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Nowadays the Bologna Process brings together 47 European countries in a common effort to make their higher education systems compatible and comparable. The report focuses on the importance of maximising the use of the funds available and finding new models of funding, on the need to reinvigorate the Bologna Process in the important role it can play in the revision of the Europe 2020 Strategy and in the Juncker Investment Plan for Europe. Another important issue raised is the proper implementation of quality assurance (QA) systems and the strengthening of cooperation on QA across the European Higher Education Area (EHEA). The report also calls for proper implementation of the European credit transfer system. I thus voted in favour of the report which will now present Parliament’s position in view of the Ministerial Conference in Yerevan.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against because I believe that the Łybacka report functionalizes the higher education system to the needs of the market. Indeed, its central objective is the implementation of the Juncker Plan (EFSI), where the European Commission has recently stated directly in the fields of education and training that leverage over private funding, as a central aspect of the plan, 'could have the effect of transferring majority control to the hands of the private sector'.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against the report on the implementation of the Bologna Process since I reject the measures being taken in its implementation, as well as the 2020 Strategy, which leads to the commodization and privatization of higher education and competition between universities. I also reject the involvement of companies in the development of educational programmes and the submission of education to the dogma of free competition and market interests. I believe that the responsibility of the education system should lie with the State and that it is the Member States which must ensure true recognition of diplomas. The budget for education and research should increase, as should the number and amount of scholarships. In addition, I am convinced that educational diversity, including linguistic diversity, must be respected in Europe.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Strengthening and improving the Bologna process, concerning the European higher education system with its annexes, is a key step towards enabling the creation of a European knowledge area functional to the new global challenges facing Europe. A great deal of work still needs to be done to implement one of the guiding principles of the Bologna Process, namely that cultural growth is rightly identified as one of the means of combating social inequalities and unemployment, especially youth unemployment. In conclusion, promoting culture means promoting social inclusion. That is what the Member States will have to work on, and that is why the vote in favour is of fundamental importance.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Today, the European Parliament adopted a comprehensive report on monitoring the implementation of the Bologna Process. The targeted proposals will help to make progress in the field of higher education.  The Bologna reforms have resulted in the creation of a European Higher Education Area and significant achievements have been made over the last 15 years in making higher education systems more comparable, enhancing mobility, ensuring quality assurance systems and recognition of diplomas, improving the quality of education systems and increasing the attractiveness of Higher Education in Europe.  Within this process, the adaptation of education systems to labour market needs is expected to be implemented in the future, helping to improve European employability and competitiveness; similarly, further increase the attractiveness of Higher Education in Europe.  Parliament calls on the countries of the European Higher Education Area to implement jointly agreed reforms aimed at achieving the objectives set by the Bologna Process as soon as possible and enhancing the credibility of the European Higher Education Area.
