For the time being, the negative experience of the existence of Member States and higher education institutions, which create obstacles to the recognition of diplomas and qualifications, is also known. In some cases, there is undue mistrust towards central European systems. The elimination of existing and unjustified differences and the conseparation of free movement in the internal market should be in the common interest. I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ There is still much to be accomplished in fulfilling the goals of the Bologna Process. Therefore, I voted in favour since it is imperative that the next Ministerial Conference in Yerevan in May 2015 undertakes an objective and critical review of the progress and setbacks in achieving the priorities set out for 2012-2015. This review can help to further consolidate the European Higher Education Area and to boost the Bologna Process with the full support of the EU.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I think it is very welcome that some Member States have developed a comprehensive strategy to include students from disadvantaged socio-economic backgrounds in higher education, thus addressing the issue of the so-called 'social filter', and I hope that it will set an example for all Member States.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report presents the European Parliament's position for the Yerevan Ministerial Conference, which, as part of the Bologna process to create a European higher education area, will strengthen cooperation in quality assurance of European university systems and maximise the use of available funds. Considering that it is necessary to find new funding models for a sector as strategic as bringing the European education and university sectors closer together and that links need to be developed between the Bologna process, the Juncker Plan and the Europe 2020 strategy, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. With this vote, Parliament supports the establishment of a European higher education area, as part of the Bologna process launched in 1999. Since then, much progress has been made.  However, there are new challenges for higher education institutions and students.  As the report states, at the end of 2014 there were five million unemployed people in the EU under the age of 25. Also, by emphasizing the much-needed work to improve the employability of young people, the report is moving in the right direction.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Over the past fifteen years, the Bologna process has achieved remarkable results in terms of quality of education, mobility and academic recognition and has made information on European higher education more transparent and easily accessible. While these results are laudable, there are still some areas in need of further development.  I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution in order to give new impetus to the Bologna Process. It will be crucial to focus on adopting a more student-centred approach and its results, strengthening the links between higher education and research, facilitating dialogue between the scientific world and society, and promoting the benefits of using technological innovations in teaching and learning.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Krystyna Lybacka's report adopted a comprehensive report on the monitoring of the implementation of the Bologna Process. In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I believe that progress in the field of higher education can be expected through the targeted proposals in the report.  As a result of the Bologna reforms, the European Higher Education Area has been launched and significant achievements have been made over the last 15 years in making higher education systems more comparable, enhancing mobility, ensuring quality assurance systems and recognition of diplomas, improving the quality of education systems and increasing the attractiveness of Higher Education in Europe. Within the Bologna Process, much still needs to be done to adapt education systems to labour market needs, improve overall employability and competitiveness, and improve the attractiveness of Higher Education in Europe.  The European Parliament calls on the countries of the European Higher Education Area to implement jointly agreed reforms aimed at accelerating the achievement of the objectives set by the Bologna Process and enhancing the credibility of the European Higher Education Area. Unfortunately, some Member States and their higher education institutions still do not recognise each other's diplomas and qualifications in the European higher education area, which can have disadvantages. I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. In June 1999, 29 European countries signed the Bologna Declaration, which aimed to create a European higher education area for 2010, expand the choice of educational opportunities and ensure the compatibility of higher education systems in Europe. I voted for the report on monitoring the implementation of the Bologna process because it urges the countries of the European Higher Education Area to implement the agreed reforms and stresses the importance of ensuring mutual recognition of university degrees. Education is one of the pillars of our society. It is also a privileged tool to combat social inequalities and youth unemployment. This is why Member States should be encouraged to increase scholarships and to continue to intensify partnerships in order to achieve the European higher education area.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Krystyna Lybacka's report adopted a comprehensive report on the monitoring of the implementation of the Bologna Process. Unfortunately, some Member States and their higher education institutions still do not recognise each other's diplomas and qualifications in the European higher education area, which can be detriments. I voted in favour of the adoption of this report

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. This is a process of bringing European higher education systems closer together. Its main objective is to support mobility and internationalisation as well as to make the standards and quality of the various higher education systems compatible and comparable. It thus aims to harmonize European higher education, which goes hand in hand with its anglicisation. The anglicisation it highlights calls into question the European spirit of equality of cultures and languages. It also marks the commodification of higher education, which he sees only through the prism of economic growth. In addition, it would allow the European institutions to have more and more control over institutions that reduce their intellectual autonomy. Excessive anglicisation, as well as interference by the European Union in the name of supposedly advantageous financial aid, runs counter to the authenticity of French higher education. So I voted against the text.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Bologna Implementation Report highlights the achievements of this process over the past 15 years. Examples include higher education structures that are becoming more comparable, increasing student mobility and making progress in quality assurance. The report also highlights the issue of skills mismatch across Europe and the need for better synergies between education and business needs. Further efforts to improve mobility, mutual recognition and comparability of standards, while respecting the autonomy of universities, are also of utmost importance. There is a collaborative approach that is needed by Member States and other stakeholders to continue the positive contribution of the Bologna Process to higher education in Europe. I am pleased with the positive nature and tone of the document presented and therefore supported it.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report, although I consider education and research to be important in promoting skills development, economic development and job creation, because I do not agree with certain aspects of the report such as the internationalisation of education, the participation of students in higher education governance, the strengthening of European citizenship and the further liberalisation of residence permits for recognised refugees seeking specialised professional activity.

Unfortunately, some Member States and their higher education institutions still do not recognise each other's diplomas and qualifications in the European higher education area, which can have disadvantages. I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report is functional at the Ministerial Conference to be held in 2015 to assess the progress of the implementation of the Bologna Process, the aim of which would be the creation of the European Higher Education Area, a common frame of reference for the 47 countries that have joined.  As usual, however, delays in achieving objectives such as increasing student mobility in Europe and comparability of European education systems have been measured by 2010. The problem with this report, which is why I voted against it, is that it designs a private higher education system, thus not giving due emphasis to the importance of education as a public education and, on the contrary, deleting any amendment aimed at abolishing public funding for private institutions.  In short, the fear that the implementation of the Juncker plan could transfer the education sector into the hands of private individuals seems to be justified.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. One in three employers in the EU has problems looking for employees with the right qualifications and, with a view to reducing the lack of adequacy of qualifications in the EU (the gap between a person's professional qualifications and labour market requirements), bologna's retirement has so far not been very successful. The problem of youth unemployment has not improved much since the crisis began in 2008, with around 5 million unemployed young people under the age of 25 in the EU. The real objective of the Bologna Process is to support mobility and internationalisation, as well as to ensure the compatibility and comparability of standards and the quality of different higher education systems. It is essential that countries implement agreed common reforms, improve and update the assessment of higher education institutions, increase scholarships and strengthen quality assurance, with a view to achieving a European area of higher education that improves their attractiveness as a benchmark of academic excellence worldwide.

name: Edouard Ferrand (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this text. for my part, I believe that France should disengage from the Bologna process. It is actually a process towards the uniformity of minds and intelligence. A forced march towards the anglicization of higher education and I cannot accept it. The European Union, instead of enriching itself with the culture of the various member countries, prefers to despise them. Parliament should consider in time changing its motto by: "United in diversity... Anglo-Saxon"

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Bologna process, due to its visible consequences, has become unavoidable in addressing the situation of higher education systems in the various Member States. This report recognises some of the serious consequences of Bologna. It points to the failure of the so-called "student mobility goal", which has stood by the way, and mobility rates remain low. What was not on the way was the disinvestment of states in the sector and the significant increase in frequency costs. The report proposes a regenerative bath in Bologna. Of course we voted against it. The difficulty of access to higher education for those with fewer economic conditions, the creation of an army of cheap labour and the loss of a perspective of integral training of the individual, which higher education institutions tended to confer, are consequences of Bologna, among others, for which we warned and warned. What is needed, as we advocated in the alternative motion for a resolution, is cooperation between Member States at the level of higher education, but that this is done by guaranteeing everyone's right to free and quality public higher education.

name: Raffaele Fitto (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report because the implementation of the Bologna Process is an essential means of addressing today's challenges of higher education. In order to increase the attractiveness and competitiveness of the European Higher Education Area, it is necessary to give new impetus to the Bologna process so that it can meet the new challenges and ensure the quality and transparency of European education.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The introduction of the Bologna Process into national higher education systems was unquestionably the right step for Europe. Only by investing and improving the academic and educational process for students in the European Union will we achieve economic growth, a reduction in youth unemployment in the future, and we will also have a chance to face the demographic changes to which the European Union will be exposed in the future as a result of an ageing population. The Bologna Process has achieved a great deal over the last 15 years, but it needs to be revived in order to respond together to the new challenges facing Europe. We must work hard to bring higher education systems closer together in the Member States of the European Union through common rules of cooperation. We must learn from the Bologna Process, the objectives of which have been achieved to a different extent in the participating countries. The financial and economic crisis has shown us that it is very important that higher education systems prepare students for those areas of the economy where they have a chance to assert themselves. Universities in the Member States must stop producing thousands of young non-employees every year who are not prepared for labour market demand. It is also important to strengthen the link between higher education and research by facilitating dialogue between science and society and promoting the beneficial use of technological innovation in teaching and education.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the Bologna process and it is important to remember that its intention is not to standardise higher education systems, but to bring them together, thanks to the development of common rules for cooperation, while always taking into account the diversity and autonomy of individual countries and universities. We in the Committee on Culture have long supported the need to eliminate the red tape that the Bologna Process would like to eliminate.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Although I consider education and research to be important in terms of promoting skills development, economic growth and job creation, I do not agree with certain aspects of the report such as the internationalisation of education, the participation of students in higher education governance, the strengthening of European citizenship and the further liberalisation of residence permits for recognised refugees seeking specialised professional activity. My vote is against.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today, ensuring comparability and compatibility in the standards and quality of higher education qualifications, supporting mobility of students and internationalisation, and providing students with a wider and more transparent choice of high-quality educational opportunities are matters of the outmost importance, not only for European students, but also and especially for the recovery of the European economy. These are powerful means to tackle issues like youth unemployment, economic constraints and demographic changes. This is why I support the adoption of this report in the Plenary, as I believe that it will boost the Bologna Process and provide the necessary means to accomplish the fulfilment of its goals.

I voted in favour of the adoption of this report

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. The goal of the Bologna Process was to create a European Higher Education Area by 2010. The aim is to provide students with a broader and more transparent offering of quality educational opportunities, as well as to create a simplified recognition process, both internal and external, across all national higher education systems. It is necessary to continue the implementation of Bologna to create the conditions for greater mobility, adapt education systems to the needs of the labour market and improve overall employability and competitiveness.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. Mr Łybacka has the merit of restoring attention and value to the Bologna Process just a few weeks before the Ministerial Summit in Yerevan.  I would like to highlight an important step that I consider to be particularly significant for the future of university cooperation in Europe: it is really important to call for increased economic and social efforts to enhance social inclusion, opening up fair access for all to quality education, facilitating the recognition of academic and professional qualifications, periods of study abroad and previous training, cross-cutting skills programmes and non-formal and informal learning. , as well as offering relevant education to a diverse student population, through lifelong learning.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because we are hearing nothing but news about stability, budgetary constraints and economic parameters. Our newspapers and our citizens call it the Europe of banks. So I ask myself: where has the Europe of culture gone? It is necessary to speak in numbers, in percentages, but when will we devote the same attention to culture, education and training?  The Bologna process marked the way towards the creation of a European training area, envisioned a Europe in which students were "European" first of all, who had the opportunity to enrich themselves with experiences in all the Member States, study at any university, experiment with different courses and languages. That road must not be abandoned, it is vital for Europe to grow up and train the new European citizens. To be united in diversity you need to know each other, to get to know each other you have to study, to live. Let us give our young people the right to European education, they will give us a better Europe.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted AGAINST this report, which seeks to give impetus to the Bologna Process, which we oppose, since its 'great objectives' – the establishment of a European Higher Education Area that harmonizes its administrative and curricular procedures, facilitates mobility and adapts the training criteria to the new global challenges – mask a change of priorities: moving from a knowledge-generating entity to the service of society to being , as is the case in all areas likely to generate profit, at the service of economic profitability as defined by markets, despising the effect this criterion has on increasing social inequality.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Over the past 15 years, the Bologna Process – aiming at ensuring comparability in the standards and quality of higher education qualifications – has accomplished a great deal in terms of the quality of education, mobility and academic recognition. Overall, the Bologna Process has achieved a greater transparency and made information about European higher education easily accessible, using benchmarking of national performance against common objectives. While these accomplishments are commendable, some areas still need further development, and it is crucial to revitalise the Bologna Process to meet new challenges as well as to ensure the quality and transparency of the European Higher Education Area. Therefore, I voted in favour of this report as I believe it is crucial in view of pursuing the EU goals of sustainable growth and a knowledge-based society investing in quality education and learning.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the report on monitoring the implementation of the Bologna Process because I believe that the approach is a good one.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Łybacka report given it represents a crucial contribution to achieving sustainable growth and a knowledge-based society investing in quality education and learning through the Bologna process.  Over the past 15 years, the Bologna Process has accomplished a great deal in terms of the quality of education, mobility, and academic recognition. In the face of new challenges in the field of education, it is imperative the process is revitalised to ensure the continued quality and transparency of the European Higher Education Area, a crucial foundation for our ambitious agenda on jobs and growth.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. The Bologna Process is a common effort that aims to make it possible to compare the quality of qualifications in higher education in the 29 participating countries. Since its inception in 1999, it has contributed to the launch of the European Higher Education Area, the recognition of diplomas and, therefore, the mobility of students within the EU and the participating countries. Despite these achievements, much remains to be done. In particular, education systems need to be adapted to the labour market, young people's skills to obtain jobs improved, and the attractiveness of higher education in Europe increased. Since around five million young people under the age of 25 are out of employment in the EU, one of the main priorities of the Bologna Process should be the development of the highest possible level of knowledge for citizens through ample access to education that addresses youth unemployment and the mismatch between supply and demand for qualifications.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D)
text: In writing. I gave my full support to my colleague LYBACKA's report, as it defends the development of high-quality higher education as a key factor in the cultural, economic and social development that is essential for the growth of our economies.  The continuation of the Bologna process should thus enable the development of mobility, encourage internationalisation and improvement of employability, and make the European Higher Education Area more attractive. This message will need to be heard by higher education ministers at the Yerevan meeting, so that more efforts can be made to support countries that are struggling to implement it.  We need the commitments made to finally translate into actions to relaunch the process, make it more efficient and define its future objectives in a context that has changed significantly since its inception. Indeed, with 5 million young people under the age of 25 unemployed, the question of the inadequacy of skills with the needs of the labour market is more than ever.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour because I strongly support the aim of providing students with the possibility of a wider and more transparent choice of high-quality education to choose from. It is very important that the Bologna Process helps to converge educational systems by developing common rules of cooperation in order to improve the quality of higher education.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Krystyna Lybacka's report adopted a comprehensive report on the monitoring of the implementation of the Bologna Process. In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I believe that progress in the field of higher education can be expected through the targeted proposals in the report.  As a result of the Bologna reforms, the European Higher Education Area has been launched and significant achievements have been made over the last 15 years in making higher education systems more comparable, enhancing mobility, ensuring quality assurance systems and recognition of diplomas, improving the quality of education systems and increasing the attractiveness of Higher Education in Europe. Within the Bologna Process, much still needs to be done to adapt education systems to labour market needs, improve overall employability and competitiveness, and improve the attractiveness of Higher Education in Europe.  The European Parliament calls on the countries of the European Higher Education Area to implement jointly agreed reforms aimed at accelerating the achievement of the objectives set by the Bologna Process and enhancing the credibility of the European Higher Education Area. Unfortunately, some Member States and their higher education institutions still do not recognise each other's diplomas and qualifications in the European higher education area, which can have disadvantages. I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report on the follow up of the implementation of the Bologna process. In particular, I support paragraph 21 which stresses the role of the STEM subjects, Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics for their importance for the employability of some. It is crucial that we include the number of female students taking STEM subjects as woman are disproportionately under-represented in engineering, technology and the science sectors. The Bologna process can also be used to measure the skills mismatch and provide useful information to policy makers. I am also very supportive of the need to validate and recognise learning achieved in the non-formal and informal ways.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. Since my time as president of the Leibniz Association and my more than 10 years as an honorary professor at the University of Mannheim, I have been both an active designer and a victim of the so-called Bologna Process. Certainly, the standardisation of the European educational landscape can be seen as beneficial. But, as is so often the case with European projects, "Bologna" has become a bureaucratic monster. Time and again, professors, university administrations and students report on increasing reporting requirements, bureaucracy and gears, which are at the expense of education and research. The fact that "einfalt" precedes "diversity" can also be seen in the fact that.B, for example, the German educational location advantage "Diplomingenieur" has fallen under the wheels and, above all, humanities subjects with "Bachelor" and "Master" often have nothing to do with "Bachelor" and "Master". Incidentally, if education policy is not a matter for the federal government, but for the Länder, why is Brussels taking this responsibility for it? Of course, I had to vote against this proposal!

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Krystyna Lybacka reports that the European Parliament has adopted a comprehensive document on monitoring the implementation of the Bologna Process. In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I believe that progress in the field of higher education can be expected through the targeted proposals in the report.  As a result of the Bologna reforms, the European Higher Education Area has been launched and significant achievements have been made over the last 15 years in making higher education systems more comparable, enhancing mobility, ensuring quality assurance systems and recognition of diplomas, improving the quality of education systems and increasing the attractiveness of Higher Education in Europe. Within the Bologna Process, much still needs to be done to adapt education systems to labour market needs, improve overall employability and competitiveness, and improve the attractiveness of Higher Education in Europe. The European Parliament calls on the countries of the European Higher Education Area to implement jointly agreed reforms aimed at accelerating the achievement of the objectives set by the Bologna Process and enhancing the credibility of the European Higher Education Area. Unfortunately, some Member States and their higher education institutions still do not recognise each other's diplomas and qualifications in the European higher education area, which can have disadvantages. I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted AGAINST this report, which seeks to give impetus to the Bologna Process, which we oppose, since its 'big objectives' – the establishment of a European Higher Education Area that harmonizes its administrative and curricular procedures, facilitates mobility and adapts the training criteria to the new global challenges – mask a change of priorities: moving from a knowledge-generating entity to the service of society to being , as is the case in all areas likely to generate profit, at the service of economic profitability as defined by markets, despising the effect this criterion has on increasing social inequality.

name: Carlos Iturgaiz (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 I vote in favour justifying the importance of a coherent, transparent and quality higher education sector, which is essential for cultural, economic and social development. Bologna's objectives provide the essential means for European higher education to meet current challenges. This document proposes an improvement in the processes of implementation of the structure and current elements, as well as correcting its shortcomings and making the educational approach more student-oriented and results-oriented.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. I voted for the report on monitoring the implementation of the Bologna Process because I support the attached analysis of the situation, numerous initiatives and proposals, priorities and challenges outlined therein and the prominent role of the Bologna Process. Harmonised, transparent, quality higher education is crucial for cultural, economic and social development, and Bologna's goals should ensure the achievement and realization of successful European higher education in the current challenges of modern development.  In this sense, it is necessary, among other things, to realistically look at the current situation, the realization of goals, then the changes that are happening faster in society and the economy, it should strengthen ties with research and development, promote the possibilities of applying new technologies and in addition harmonize the activities of European programs that support the Bologna process.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this text. I recognise the positive intentions that originally led to the implementation of the Bologna process, namely to make Europe a globalised competitive space for the knowledge economy by harmonising European education systems. However, from the outset, too, this process was open to more than fifty countries, not all of which should have been part of it.  One of the consequences of this process was the anglicization of education systems, thus tending to standardize the world, in defiance of French national identity and language. Above all, the Bologna process aims at a commodification of higher education and a loss of intellectual autonomy for studies and academic institutions. France is therefore suffering from this process which compromises the equality of cultures and languages in the Union.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Krystyna Lybacka's report on the implementation of the Bologna process, an important element of European higher education policy. The text calls for better use of allocated funds and for strengthening its place in the Europe 2020 strategy as well as in the Investment Plan presented by Jean-Claude Juncker. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Josu Juaristi Abaunz (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In the vote on monitoring the implementation of the Bologna Process, I voted against the European Parliament's Resolution, as that text supports or fuels the trend towards a higher education system marked by cuts and privatisations, obsessed with competitiveness, which leads to young people caught up in full time and drowned out by fees that many and many can no longer afford.  EH Bildu advocates a truly own educational model, of quality, inclusive, non-exclusive and participatory, capable of creating critical students; a model where the right to study fully in Basque in all cycles of teaching is fully guaranteed. That is why I voted in favour of the alternative text proposed by the GUE/NGL Group, a full-rule amendment to the entire adopted resolution.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this report on the implementation of the Bologna process.  This process has led to the establishment of a European higher education area and has made significant progress possible, notably in the implementation of systems to ensure the quality of education systems, the recognition of diplomas and the attractiveness of higher education in Europe. However, much remains to be done, particularly in terms of adjusting education systems to the needs of the labour market.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI)
text: Writing. The Bologna Process points to the unification of Europe's multifaceted university system and must therefore be rejected. Member States must enjoy the freedom to adapt their university systems to their own traditions and regional and cultural differences. A one-size-fits-all approach, as glorified in this report, does not work, and I reject it.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The Bologna Process has had a major impact on higher education across Europe. Since the Bologna Declaration in 1999 there has been significant progress towards the harmonisation of higher education structures, culminating in the European Higher Education Area (EHEA), established in 2010. Irish students have benefited greatly from the mobility and enhanced employability offered by the EHEA, as well as from the introduction of quality guidelines, with the Irish Higher Education Quality Network being established in 2003. I fully support the assertion of this report: that the proper implementation of quality assurance standards across the EHEA must be its next key goal. Strengthening our education system by providing students with high-quality mentoring, learning outcomes and resources is key to Europe’s further growth and development and is central to our 2020 goals. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Bologna Process has accomplished a great deal in terms of the quality of education, mobility and academic recognition. It has achieved a greater transparency and made information about European higher education easily accessible, using benchmarking of national performance against common objectives. However, some areas still need further development and it is crucial to revitalise the Bologna Process to meet new challenges as well as to ensure the quality and transparency of the European Higher Education Area. I therefore voted in favour of this report as I believe it is crucial in view of pursuing the EU goals of sustainable growth and a knowledge-based society investing in quality education and learning.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Krystyna Lybacka's report adopted a comprehensive report on the monitoring of the implementation of the Bologna Process. In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I believe that progress in the field of higher education can be expected through the targeted proposals in the report.  As a result of the Bologna reforms, the European Higher Education Area has been launched and significant achievements have been made over the last 15 years in making higher education systems more comparable, enhancing mobility, ensuring quality assurance systems and recognition of diplomas, improving the quality of education systems and increasing the attractiveness of Higher Education in Europe. Within the Bologna Process, much still needs to be done to adapt education systems to labour market needs, improve overall employability and competitiveness, and improve the attractiveness of Higher Education in Europe.  The European Parliament calls on the countries of the European Higher Education Area to implement jointly agreed reforms aimed at accelerating the achievement of the objectives set by the Bologna Process and enhancing the credibility of the European Higher Education Area. Unfortunately, some Member States and their higher education institutions still do not recognise each other's diplomas and qualifications in the European higher education area, which can have disadvantages. I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Miapetra Kumpula-Natri (S&D)
text: Written. \u2012 I voted in favour of this follow-up report because, although the Bologna Process is not really an EU policy, its key elements are included in the EU's education policy framework. Although Parliament does not have any real competence in matters relating to Bologna, I believe that it is important – as a former Erasmus student myself – to discuss the European dimension of education. Student mobility, for example, is even seen as a positive thing in EU-sceptical circles.  Both in the structure of new education and at work, education is seen as key to improving the employment situation in Europe. This is very understandable and worth supporting. However, it is important that the role of the Bologna Process as a measure aimed at quality assurance and better recognition of qualifications at European level remains clear. Bologna, or other elements and objectives of education policy, must not be subjudalise to employment policy or its instruments. It is particularly positive that, according to the report, the objectives of the process must be achieved before new ones are defined. It is also important to recognise that the effects of the Bologna Process have been positive. Today, however, the Bologna Process and its objectives are seen as too self-evident, although there is still work to be done.  Although the report mentions the social dimension and accessibility of education as neglected elements of the Bologna Process, the Social Dimension Strategy of the EHEA has not been mentioned at all.  I believe that social impact assessment is important in all EU activities and will hopefully also be on the agenda at the Council meeting.

name: Gabrielius Landsbergis (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Bologna Process and its implementation have gone a great way, many Member States have implemented reforms, updated education systems and introduced amendments. Today, however, we still face challenges in Europe: high youth unemployment, people who are not ready for the labour market, and the education systems of the Member States are not harmonised. I therefore advocate the need for the bologna process to be renewed, emphasising its compliance with the evolving challenges and ensuring the quality and transparency of the European Higher Education Area. I agree that the educational paradigm should be shifted from what is taught to what students need to learn, and i therefore believe that the Member States and the European Commission should continue the process, taking into account changes and better adapting to relevant needs.

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The Bologna Process is an intergovernmental initiative designed to enable the sustainable development of higher education in the European Union. It aims to harmonise the quality of education, promote student mobility and enable them to choose a wider educational path. High-quality higher education is essential for cultural, economic and social development and for providing young people with an education that will enable them to succeed. Much remains to be done, but I believe that the implementation of bologna reforms will enable European higher education to meet the challenges of an ever-changing labour market.

name: Philippe Loiseau (NI)
text: In writing. Vote against. The Bologna process is a process that aims to create the European higher education area. The Lisbon Convention has changed the objectives of the programme. France is a victim of this process because it affirms the formalization of the anglicization of higher education. This is because the European Union considers the language barrier to be one of the obstacles that students face. But the Bologna process will also have several negative consequences: the commodification of higher education, a reduction in social justice, a loss of intellectual autonomy of institutions because higher education is seen only through the dogma of economic growth. Again, there is a desire to homogenize what does not correspond to the higher education project championed by the National Front. The Europe of cultures and languages is likely to suffer. For this reason I am voting against this project.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. The S&D Group decided to prepare this initiative report for the EP to be clearly positioned before the next Ministerial Conference on the Bologna Process in Yerevan, Armenia, in May 2015, as it is important that an objective and critical review of progress and setbacks in achieving the priorities set for the period 2012-2015 be carried out in order to further consolidate the European Higher Education Area ( USA) and drive the Bologna process in the face of new challenges (such as high youth unemployment, economic constraints and demographic changes). The report focuses on the evaluation of the Process and the identification of key priorities in the coming years, based on adequate political commitment and cooperation from the EEES, strengthening the "downstream" approach, developing new tools and methods, such as groups to help countries facing challenges, and encouraging others to achieve higher goals , with the participation and commitment of all stakeholders, including the social partners.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against the report on the implementation of the Bologna Process since I reject the measures being taken in its implementation, as well as the 2020 Strategy, which leads to the commodization and privatization of higher education and competition between universities. I also reject the involvement of companies in the development of educational programmes and the submission of education to the dogma of free competition and market interests. I believe that the responsibility of the education system should lie with the State and that it is the Member States which must ensure true recognition of diplomas. The budget for education and research should increase, as should the number and amount of scholarships. In addition, I am convinced that educational diversity, including linguistic diversity, must be respected in Europe. Therefore, since I are defending a public, universal, free and quality education that meets the needs of society and not markets, I have only been able to vote against this report on the Bologna Process.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. In June 1999, 29 European countries signed the Bologna Declaration, which was in the goal of creating a European Higher Education Area (EEES) by 2010.  This proposal calls on Member States, EEES countries and the EU as a whole to promote public understanding and support for the Bologna Process, including basic measures, in order to achieve more effective and dynamic participation in achieving their objectives. I voted favourably on this proposal because I believe that increased investment in education is essential to effectively combat poverty, social inequalities and unemployment, in particular youth unemployment, and to promote social integration.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I think the strategy of increasing the number of undergraduates at all costs has not worked. There is an increase in the percentage of people who get a diploma, but this does not mean that there is a demand for so many undergraduates in the market. On the contrary, crafts and practical disciplines are proving to be lacking as states and schools increasingly push pupils into higher education. Furthermore, I believe that education is a matter for individual states and schools, and any calls for centralisation are only detrimental and move away from people's needs.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The levelling of higher education sectors of the signatory countries of the Bologna Process at institutional, national and European level is a means by which we can provide our country's students with quality education and experience through mobility, taking into account the diversity and diversity of studies in the participating countries. Knowing the differences and specificities of study is attractive and attractive to students, but it can also be a driver in the development of education and thus in the competitiveness of the whole union.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ A coherent, transparent, and high-quality higher education sector is essential for cultural, economic and social development. The Bologna objectives provide the essential means for European higher education to face current challenges. However, there is still much to be accomplished in fulfilling the goals of the Bologna Process. While it is clear that many achievements and significant structural convergence have been realised, new challenges have arisen. In order to face them and to reinvigorate the Process, it is crucial to focus on the correct implementation of the current structure and tools, correct their shortcomings, and shift the educational approach to a more student and outcome-oriented one. It is also important to strengthen the links between higher education and research via the facilitation of dialogue between science and society and the promotion of beneficial uses of technological innovations in teaching and learning. In addition, there is a need to focus on better synchronisation of actions supporting the Bologna Process such as the Horizon 2020 and Erasmus+ programmes.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the report on the follow-up to the implementation of the Bologna process. In view of the problem of the gap between supply and demand for skills and the related problems in finding suitably qualified workers, it is clear that efforts are needed to improve the situation. This report can encourage an increase in the commitment dedicated to this theme and also invites to focus the organization on the figure of the student, with a more curated approach towards a complete culture that then prepares for the next challenges.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The scourge of youth unemployment has plagued most Member States of the European Union since the outbreak of the economic and financial crisis in 2008.   This situation is exacerbated by the fact that many European employers find it difficult to recruit suitably qualified staff. In this context, university universities must offer their students less theoretical training, which prepares them for entry into the world of work.  I supported the Łybacka report, which calls on the parties concerned to make greater efforts, with the aim of achieving full implementation of the Bologna Process, as I believe that a rationalisation of curricula is desirable, with a view to providing young European graduates with adequate general and professional skills.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. The Bologna Declaration and the creation of a European Higher Education Area have enabled students to be provided with a broader and more transparent offer of quality educational opportunities, as well as to create a simplified process of recognition, both internally and externally, of all existing national higher education systems. However, I agree with the report we have adopted in the plenary session of the European Parliament that the achievements of this process have been uneven in the participating countries and that we must improve in this regard, as well as establish new tools and working methods to further improve. It is also essential to advance more student-centered learning and ensure that adequate funding exists to achieve all Bologna's goals. I believe that the report which we have adopted, and which I have also supported, reviews the outstanding achievements and challenges, and I hope that its conclusions will be taken into account.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. The Freedom Party of Austria continues to oppose the Bologna Process and calls for a (partial) exit. That is why I rejected the resolution.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Youth unemployment in Europe is at record highs. The Bologna process, which began in 1999, has yet to yield results.  Its real objective is not to provide access to quality higher education for all, but to liberalise universities. The applications of "Bologna" in France, such as the Pécresse Act of 2007, the University Freedoms and Responsibilities Act, known as the LRU, are the direct application of the principle of the "knowledge economy". Knowledge becomes a commercial good like any other. The crisis and "budgetary constraints" serve as a perfect excuse for the call for private investment in education.  The report itself notes the cuts in education and the increase in youth unemployment, but without questioning the options chosen as a possible cause of this. He does not even dispute the reform of Erasmus, which provides, among other things, a bank lending mechanism that leads to the indebtedness of students at the beginning of their studies. I'm voting against it.

name: Joëlle Mélin (NI)
text: In writing. I recognise the positive intentions that originally led to the implementation of the Bologna process, namely to make Europe a globalised competitive space for the knowledge economy by harmonising European education systems. However, from the outset, too, this process was open to more than fifty countries, not all of which should have been part of it.  One of the consequences of this process was the anglicization of education systems, thus tending to standardize the world, in defiance of national identity and the French language. Above all, the Bologna process aims at a commodification of higher education and a loss of intellectual autonomy for studies and academic institutions. France is therefore suffering from this process which compromises the equality of cultures and languages in the Union.  I voted AGAINST this text.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The Bologna Process set in motion the creation of a European Higher Education Area (EHEA) and whilst this did much to improve the comparability of higher education structures across the Union, more needs to be done to adjust educational systems to labour market needs. This adjustment would further the mobility already achieved by improving employability and competitiveness. Improvements need to be made to ensure that our higher education institutions can adapt quickly to the economic challenges posed for the labour market and modern society as a whole. I therefore voted in favour of this report as it urges the Commission and other stakeholders to work together to revitalise the Bologna Process.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. The main objective of the Bologna Declaration, drafted in June 1999, was to create a European higher education area by 2010. The aim of this new European space was to offer students a wider choice of quality training and a simplified procedure for recognising both internal and external titles.  It is good, after more than ten years, to carry out an evaluation and follow-up of the implementation of the Bologna process. Quality higher education is essential to the cultural, economic and social development of the European Union.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ A coherent, transparent, and high-quality higher education is essential for cultural, economic, and social development. The Bologna objectives provide the essential means for European higher education to face current challenges. However, there is still much to be accomplished in fulfilling the goals of the Bologna Process. While it is clear that many achievements and significant structural convergence have been realised, new challenges have arisen. It is important that the next Ministerial Conference in Yerevan in May 2015 undertakes an objective and critical review of the progress and setbacks in achieving the priorities set out for 2012-2015 with a view to further consolidating the EHEA and boosting the Bologna process with the full support of the EU. That is why I have voted in favour of this report.

name: Bernard Monot (NI)
text: In writing. In our view, France must disengage from the Bologna process, which risks leading to a massive anglicisation of education in the European Union, thus challenging the European spirit of equality of cultures and languages to the detriment of French. In the name of harmonizing curricula and the competitiveness of our higher education in a globalised educational market, France and the French are victims of this process that formalizes the anglicization of higher education.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. The Bologna Process entered into force in 2006 and is currently in force in 47 European countries.  I support this report which is critical of the implementation of the Bologna reform, as it has not yet been fully implemented and has not yet contributed, decisively to facilitating the hiring of people from a Member State other than the one in which they are natural. It should be noted that one in three employers in the EU has problems looking for people with the right qualifications and that it is essential to reduce the gap between acquired qualifications and labour market requirements. I believe it is necessary to facilitate the recognition of skills, speed up academic degrees and contribute to the creation of a European labour market in which young people have effective job opportunities.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. This report on the implementation of the Bologna process is far removed from the aspirations of the world of higher education and research, nor does it meet the expectations of young people in the various EU countries who expect more jobs.  This report aims to adapt the university system of the Member States to globalisation, following the American model, instead of allowing university staff to train students as best they can. On the one hand, we cannot deplore the unprecedented unemployment rate of young people, who are forced to resort to bending effects to delay their entry into the labour market, and, on the other hand, impose the austerity that generates economic gloom.  The Union has therefore chosen to hide its face by increasingly promoting Erasmus and thus to create a transnational and European elite. This is funny, however, when we know that the Union is depriving Swiss students of this scheme because of the will of the Swiss people, expressed by direct universal suffrage, to question the dogma of free movement with the countries of the Union.  This blatant hypocrisy justifies me voting against this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Over the past 15 years, the Bologna Process – aiming at ensuring comparability in the standards and quality of higher education qualifications – has accomplished a great deal in terms of the quality of education, mobility and academic recognition. Overall, the Bologna Process has achieved a greater transparency and made information about European higher education easily accessible, using benchmarking of national performance against common objectives. While these accomplishments are commendable, some areas still need further development and it is crucial to revitalise the Bologna Process to meet new challenges as well as to ensure the quality and transparency of the European Higher Education Area.  Therefore, I voted in favour of this report as I believe it is crucial in view of pursuing the EU goals of sustainable growth and a knowledge-based society investing in quality education and learning.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on monitoring the implementation of the Bologna process. This process, which began in 1999, aims to create a European area of higher education, including better teaching quality, greater mobility and mutual recognition of university credentials. Since 1999, all 47 current members of the Bologna process have implemented major reforms within their higher education system. The report calls for the evaluation of the Bologna process to give it a new lease of life, for example by further developing the mobility of university staff and teachers.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 With a view to pursuing the EU's objectives for growth and a knowledge-based economy, we believe that the Bologna Process can play an important role in the review of the Europe 2020 strategy and in the implementation of the Juncker Investment Plan for Europe. Considerable results have been achieved so far in terms of quality of education, mobility and academic recognition. However, there are still gaps and areas which require further impetus. The objectives of the Bologna Process have not been achieved uniformly in the various participating countries, and it is therefore a priority to implement the reforms by consolidating not only the bottom-up approach, but also ensuring adequate and constant political commitment and cooperation on the part of all the main actors.  The development of additional tools and new working methods, such as the formation of clusters and the exchange of good practice, should be encouraged, which could help countries in difficulty to achieve more and at the same time encourage others to make further progress. We can no longer accept budget cuts on higher education.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In June 1999, twenty-nine European countries signed the Bologna Declaration whose aim was to create a European Higher Education Area (SEIS) by 2010.  Today's report analyses the important achievements over the last fifteen years in terms of improving the comparability of higher education structures, greater mobility, adapting education systems to the needs of the labour market and improving employability and competitiveness, as well as the attractiveness of higher education in Europe.   As education is one of the main pillars of our society in terms of promoting growth and employment and it is essential to invest more in education to combat youth unemployment, I voted in favour of this report because it underlines the important role of the Bologna Process in creating a Europe of knowledge and is the European Parliament's contribution to the next interministerial conference to be held in Yerevan next month.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Bologna process has meant deep reforms of higher education for all participating states, marked by changes in legislation and reconsideration of the basic principles of the educational process. My country signed the Bologna Declaration in 1999, committing to include in the priorities of Romanian higher education the objectives set out therein. I voted for this report because, through its text, it reiterates the importance of this 'process' in the development of education and education at European Union level, but at the same time it involves the entire academic community, the social partners and 'calls for the political commitment and cooperation of SEIS ministers in developing a common strategy for the implementation of the reforms of the Bologna process' and, therefore, the education objectives set out in the 2020 Strategy.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: i scríbhinn. \u2012 Cé go raibh rudaí dearfacha le fáil sa tuarascáil seo cosúil leis an ngá atá ann níos mó infheistíochta a dhéanamh in oideachas, mar shampla, ní raibh mé ábalta tacaíocht a thabhairt di de bharr gur tháinig an tuarascáil seo go mór faoi phróiseas Bologna, próiseas i ndáiríre a chiallaíonn príobháidiú an oideachais, comórtas idir ollscoileanna agus baint a bheith ag comhlachtaí gnó le boird srl. Mar sin, chaith mé vóta i gcoinne na tuarascála seo. Chuir mé tairiscint i gcomhair rúin cun tosaigh ina áit, ach air an drochuair níor glacadh leis an tairiscint sin. Sa rún sin, chuir mé béim faoi leith ar an dóigh gur chóir freagracht i gcúrsaí oideachais a bheith ag na Ballstáit, gur chóir na héagsúlachtaí teagaisc ar fud fad na hEorpa (éagsúlachtaí teanga san áireamh) a chaomhnú agus gur chóir don oideachas a bheith saor, ar fáil go poiblí agus éasca teacht air do gach uile dhuine.

name: Péter Niedermüller (S&D)
text: Writing. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you The Bologna Process is a great new stream of European education, resulting in the development of a new, free and effective network of higher education, interconnected with many, many threads, which can compete globally with other large higher education systems and also contribute to strengthening the common European spirit.  I agree that this process has made significant progress over the last 15 years.  Among the report's recommendations, it is particularly important to me that scholarships should be used to ensure that higher education is as widely accessible as possible to young people. I also consider it essential to make further progress in the areas of credit transfer, interoperability, student and academic mobility and quality assurance. The positive effects of the Bologna process can also help the development of the public education system if ideas for teacher training and the involvement of secondary school teachers are realised. Overall, the continuation, broadening and deepening of the Bologna process is in our common interest: a path towards a more successful, educated and cohesive Europe.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. The so-called "Bologna Treaty" comprises 47 Member States. With this process, students have the opportunity to participate in an exchange semester and develop further. The aim of this process is the further development and comparability of the study structures (Bachelor and Master). Uniform standards and directives have also been established (e.g. the European Credit Transfer System (ECTS). I am already critical of this, since there is certainly a right to exist for individual degrees. Unfortunately, it has also been shown in recent years that the Bologna process also supports the exploitation of trainees. Bachelor's graduates are treated like graduates and in many cases are paid like those. I expect a fair assessment and treatment in the workplace. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Launched in 1999, the Bologna process was intended to create the conditions for better mobility in education, greater competitiveness and adjustment to the labour market. This report, although it presents positive points such as the demand for more investment in education and the goal of greater student mobility; also presents critical elements, including the predominant place given to businesses in education, the fact that studies should follow the interests of markets, or the lack of solutions to the problem of inequalities in access to education. My group has proposed a very comprehensive alternative resolution, but one that has not been adopted. For these reasons, I abstained in the vote.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal because it aims to promote the education system. In particular, the education system aims to adapt to the needs of the labour market and to improve opportunities and competitiveness in general.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE)
text: in writing. In June 1999, a total of 29 European countries signed the Bologna Declaration. The aim was to establish a European Higher Education Area (EEES) with a wider and more transparent offer of quality educational opportunities and to promote labour and citizen mobility. However, in countries such as Spain, Bologna has served as a pretext for policies that have damaged equal opportunities. University fees are much more expensive and scholarships have been eliminated for the second cycle or master's degree, while the list of European accreditations is very short and is as difficult as before to approve degrees between EU countries.  Only talent can generate prosperity and take the countries of the Union out of the crisis with dignity, and that is why we must denounce that we have not been efficient so far.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI)
text: Writing. – The report supports and promotes those restructurings that capital needs in the education systems of the EU Member States, restructurings leading to the degradation of studies, the dismantling of scientific subjects, the decoupling of a degree and profession, the adaptation and subordination of the whole structure and functioning of higher education to the objectives of monopolies. The EU emphasises so-called procedures for the recognition and certification of professional qualifications, quality assurance systems through evaluation and so-called mobility. The aim is to increase the competitiveness of capital, through new mechanisms of exploitation of graduates, through constant job insecurity and through the wandering of young workers from sector to sector and from country to country. The JRC also voted against the alternative report tabled because it accepts and embellishes the objectives of the Bologna Process for the creation of a 'single market for educational and research products and services' and for the intensity of the work and educational wandering of young people, depending on the needs of monopolies. The identification of the Greek co-government with the directions expressed by this "gospel" of the chapter on higher education that is the Bologna Process is also revealing for the unpopular plans of co-government for education in our country.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Whereas, in the current economic context, the importance of the Bologna Process should lie in the pursuit of the highest possible level of knowledge and innovation development objectives for citizens through broad access to education and its continuous updating, and whereas this should be reflected in the review of the Europe 2020 strategy and in the implementation of the Juncker Investment Plan for Europe , I voted in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. The report focuses on the importance of making the most of the available funds and finding new funding models and reviving the Bologna process in its important role as it can play in the revision of the Europe 2020 strategy, but also in the Juncker Investment Plan for Europe.  A high priority for many countries is improving the quality of higher education and establishing quality assurance systems. European standards and guidelines for quality assurance and a key objective of the European Higher Education Area were revised and are subject to approval at a ministerial conference in May 2015. My assessment is that the success of the Bologna process is partial, recognition of diplomas and mobility of young people is the greatest success achieved by this process, but the process is characterized by the emergence of new higher education institutions and programs that have failed to provide adequate quality of education.  This is confirmed by the fact that we have more and more highly educated young people who cannot find their place in the labour market. Knowledge qualification remains the best insurance against unemployment, so in countries with a focused education system in deficit occupations and with a structure that ensures a greater representation of professional, technical and scientific directions aimed at future work in the economy, employment of highly educated young people is extremely good and their model should be looked up to.

name: Florian Philippot (NI)
text: In writing. The Bologna process is a process of bringing European higher education systems closer together, which began in 1998 and led to the creation in 2010 of the European Higher Education Area of some 50 states. It aims to make Europe a globalised competitive space for the knowledge economy, the European higher education area. Since the Lisbon Convention, the objectives of the programme have evolved. The first step is to harmonize national systems by generalising a division into three cycles and, since 2007, to implement quality assurance in both institutions and training. The goals of lifelong learning and mobility are constantly being reminded. The Bologna process aims at a commodification of higher education, a reduction in social justice, a loss of intellectual autonomy of institutions and a possible shortening of certain studies.  Everything shows that the harmonisation of European higher education goes hand in hand with its anglicisation. In my opinion, France must disengage from this process which, in the name of pseudo-benefits, will lead to anglicization, thus calling into question the equality of cultures and languages. So I'm speaking out against it.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Over the past fifteen years, the Bologna Process, signed by twenty-nine European countries in 1999 with the aim of creating a European Higher Education Area (SEIS) by 2010, has achieved remarkable results in terms of quality of education, mobility and academic recognition. I believe, however, that there are still some areas that need further development, and that is why it is essential to give a new impetus to the process so that it can face up to the new challenges, as set out in this resolution that I supported.  Education and research are one of the main pillars of our society and it is essential to invest more in education in order to effectively combat poverty, social inequalities and unemployment, particularly youth unemployment, and to promote social inclusion. This resolution is intended to send a strong signal to the Ministers for Higher Education to make greater efforts to achieve the objectives of the Bologna Process, to support those countries that are experiencing difficulties in its implementation, to strengthen the links between higher education and research, and to promote the benefits of the use of technological innovations in teaching and learning.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒Coherent, transparent and quality higher education is essential for cultural, economic and social development. The objectives of the Bologna Process provide essential resources to successfully cope with the current challenges of European higher education. However, there is still much to achieve to fully meet these objectives.  For example, the system of recognition of higher education diplomas among member states has not yet been fully implemented, so Croatian citizens, for example, face difficulties in recognising their qualifications in certain EU member states. It is important that the upcoming ministerial conference in Erecan in May 2015 provides an objective and critical review of progress and backs downs downs towards priorities for 2012-2015 with a view to further consolidating the EHEA and strengthening the Bologna Process.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 I support MP Łybacka's report on the need to monitor and analyse the implementation of the Bologna Process. The launch of the Bologna Process in 1999 gave further meaning to a European project that has since pursued a more integrated and coherent education system among european higher education countries. I expect a good assessment of the impacts achieved over the past 15 years, not least in terms of the competitiveness and employability of graduates, mobility, guarantees of recognition of academic achievements and uneven application of the Bologna system in the Member States. The first moves of the new Juncker Commission put the focus on growth and jobs measures, in particular young people who remain around 5 million in the EU without a job. Therefore, in the upcoming period it is necessary to upgrade the Bologna system through the objectives of this resolution. The biggest challenge before national governments, in agreement with universities and other institutions, is to adapt education systems to the real needs of the labour market and to offer young people knowledge that can lead them to jobs.  It is important that the EU's seven-year financial framework does not reduce development funding for education, innovation and research, in particular those envisaged through Horizon 2020, in order to reach the objectives of the Europe 2020 Strategy. I also believe that support is necessary for countries such as Croatia, where the bologna system is being revised, because in the past years the qualifications of bachelors with employers have not been achieved.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am glad that the European Parliament has adopted the resolution proposed by our political group on the so-called Bologna Process. The Bologna Process supports the development of quality higher education to achieve the cultural, economic and social development of European countries. On the one hand, there is a need to cope with the different levels of education systems between EU countries, to promote mobility and exchange of international experience, but on the other hand to maintain the exceptionality and specificity of national education systems. I am convinced that even the best-developed education system will not benefit if it is not directly linked to labour market requirements, which is one of the key messages of the resolution adopted today. The objectives set by the Bologna Process have not yet been met and, in this context, we must say that the Member States are running very late. The resolution therefore comes at the right time, just days before the Ministerial Conference in Yerevan, and is a clear message from the European Parliament to the Member States: education is a key priority for the EU and Member States must do much more in this area if they are serious about Europe's growth and competitiveness. In particular, I consider the dismantling of barriers to the mutual recognition of qualifications between Member States to be an essential obstacle to achieving the objectives set. Without this, any common strategy will be meaningless.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Bologna process has allowed more and more qualified education opportunities to be offered to students and at the same time the creation of a simplified recognition procedure in all national higher education systems.   This has created the conditions for greater mobility, the adaptation of education systems to the needs of the labour market and the strengthening of the competitiveness and attractiveness of higher education in Europe. I welcome the subsequent implementation of the Bologna Process in order to adapt it to the new challenges it faces, such as youth unemployment, economic constraints and demographic changes. I believe that the Bologna Process can make a significant contribution to the pursuit of the EU's objectives for growth and a knowledge-based economy, to the review of the Europe 2020 strategy and to the implementation of the Juncker Investment Plan for Europe.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The objective of the Bologna Process is, inter alia, to ensure the rapprochement of different higher education systems in order to create more transparent systems. The result of this process should be not only ensuring a high quality of teaching and integrating the European dimension into higher education, but also an established system of academic degrees that are easily recogitable and comparable, promoting the mobility of students, teachers and researchers. The prosperity of our European society depends to a large extent on cultural, scientific and technological development, and we should do everything necessary to help this development. I therefore join the call on the EHEA countries to implement jointly agreed reforms aimed at speeding up the achievement of the objectives of the Bologna Process.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report, which assesses the progress of the Bologna process in the field of education, has my support because I consider the permeability of education systems and European cooperation in the field of education to be one of the key spheres of European integration. Personally, Although I am reticent about trying to make all subjects compulsory for bachelor's and follow-up master's studies, I generally consider the progress in the Bologna process to be positive and worthy of further support.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. In the face of rising youth unemployment and the growing lack of opportunities faced by young graduates in the EU, it is important to rethink and revitalise European policies targeting young people, such as the Bologna process on higher education in the Union.  The European Parliament adopted the report on the monitoring and implementation of the Bologna process, stressing the importance of adapting and updating this measure in relation to the context and new challenges of the Union. I voted in favour of this text. If this process is a success in many respects, it is necessary to revise and improve it so that it more closely coincides with the EU 2020 targets and the new Juncker Commission.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This is a report on monitoring the implementation of the Bologna Process, which aims to be correct in order to foster mobility. This needs to be strengthened by recognition procedures and the improvement of the quality of services for students in host universities. It is also intended to establish a financial support mechanism, ensure the transfer of grants and credits, promote foreign language learning and encourage participation in European programmes such as Erasmus+. For these reasons, and because it is crucial to revitalise the Bologna Process in some areas so that new challenges can be addressed, I voted in favour of this document.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. The Bologna process is essential to the development of societies. The European Parliament intends today, by its ambitious vote, to restore colour and energy to a process that is running out of steam. While the main priority for many countries is to ensure the quality of higher education, there is also an urgent need to put the student back at the centre of learning, guaranteeing financial support, international mobility and improving social inclusion. Twenty-nine countries signed the Bologna Declaration in 1999.
