Today, more than 47 countries are determined to create a genuine European Higher Education Area (EEES) by basing growth and the economy on knowledge. Fortunately, there are successes - the recognition of university titles or the three-cycle structure (licence-master-doctorate) - but we are still far from the primary objectives. Other interesting avenues to explore on the new technology side, such as the online courses accessible to all, the very popular MOOC (Massive Open Online Course). It is also crucial to focus on synchronizing financial measures taken in support of the Bologna process, such as Horizon 2020 and Erasmus, to meet new European challenges.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. The importance of the Bologna Process in the current economic situation should focus on the development of knowledge and innovation, as well as on strengthening citizenship, through broad access to education and its continuous updating. I recall that education and research are one of the main pillars of our society when it comes to promoting skills development, growth and job creation. Investing in education is essential to effectively combat poverty, social inequalities and unemployment, including youth unemployment, and to foster social inclusion. This is a vision that should be reflected in the review of the Europe 2020 strategy and the implementation of Juncker's Investment Plan for Europe. I also agree with the Rapporteur that improvements in the implementation of Bologna are needed, particularly those concerning more student-centred learning; strengthening collaboration between institutions; the importance of social aspects; public awareness of bologna reforms; new funding models; the credit system; mobility of teachers and pupils and the creation of quality assurance systems.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. The Bologna Process was born with the aim of ensuring a coherent, transparent and high quality higher education, which would ensure high common standards to facilitate student mobility. Although 47 countries are currently participating and some of the objectives set out have been achieved, much remains to be done in meeting them, while new challenges have arisen, such as high youth unemployment, economic constraints or demographic changes, which demand new developments. The report, promoted by the S&D Group, calls for an objective and critical review of progress and setbacks in achieving the priorities set for the period 2012-2015 in order to further consolidate the European Higher Education Area, boost the Bologna Process in the face of new challenges such as those described and encourage higher targets , with the participation and commitment of all stakeholders, including the social partners. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. In June 1999, 29 European countries signed the Bologna Declaration, which aimed to create a European higher education area by 2010. One of the first objectives of the Bologna process is that a student enrolled in a European university has the right to obtain a diploma in any Member State and to have it recognised throughout the European Union. Progress has already been made on higher education structures, harmonisation and quality, mobility and employability. The voted report focuses in particular on the importance of making the best use of available funds and finding new funding models, and on the need to once again strengthen the Bologna process in the important role it can play in the revision of the 'Europe 2020' strategy and, above all, in the investment plan for Europe presented by Jean-Claude Juncker.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. The Bologna Process gave the necessary impetus to the creation of a European Higher Education Area (EHEA), stimulating student mobility, providing quality assurance systems, recognition of diplomas and promoting a generic improvement of education systems across Europe.  However, as this Own Initiative Report, which I voted in favour of, demonstrates, this 'Process' needs a new impetus, namely: in adapting education systems to new labour market needs and as education for citizenship, updating and developing the highest levels of knowledge - and that these objectives should be reflected in the revision of the Europe 2020 strategy and the implementation of the European Fund for Strategic Investments. Priorities should also include improving the quality of higher education, increasing scholarships, mutual recognition and compatibility of academic degrees, strengthening national/cross-border cooperation on programmes/traineeships between universities and businesses, focus on teacher training/mobility and new funding opportunities. I also believe that, while I am in favour of deepening the EHEA, that Member States should never do without preserving pedagogical diversity, including the diversity of languages in their schools and at different levels of education.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution because of the importance of increasing cultural, economic and social development, which necessarily requires a coherent, transparent and high-quality higher education sector.  The objectives of the Bologna Process provide European higher education with the essential means to meet today's challenges. However, achieving these objectives still requires a lot of work. It is also necessary to promote synchronisation between actions supporting the Bologna process, such as the Horizon 2020 and Erasmus+ programmes.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. I chosen to vote in favour because the purpose of the Bologna Declaration was and remains to offer students a wider and more transparent range of high-quality education opportunities, as well as to create a simplified recognition procedure, both internally and externally, in all the national higher education systems involved. Furthermore, I think it is right to point out that the aim of the Bologna Process is not to standardise higher education systems, but to bring them together, thanks to the development of common rules for cooperation, while always taking into account the diversity and autonomy of individual countries and universities.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted AGAINST this report, which seeks to give impetus to the Bologna Process, which we oppose, since its 'great objectives' – the establishment of a European Higher Education Area that harmonizes its administrative and curricular procedures, facilitates mobility and updates the training criteria to the new global challenges – mask a change of priorities: moving from a knowledge-generating entity to the service of society , as is the case in all areas likely to generate profit, at the service of economic profitability as defined by markets, despising the effect this criterion has on increasing social inequality.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although many of its objectives towards achieving a coherent, transparent and quality higher education have already been achieved since the Bologna Process was created in 2000, the process needs to be revised to meet current challenges such as youth unemployment, economic problems or demographic changes in society. Increasing the social inclusion of underrepresented and disadvantaged groups, ensuring equal opportunities for access to higher education and promoting their international mobility remains a challenge for the Bologna process. It is therefore important that the Ministers of the EHEA countries pay attention to this issue at their next meeting in Yerevan and subject the current form of the Bologna system to objective and critical evaluation. I therefore supported krystyna Łybacké's report and would also like to thank her for her work as rapporteur.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against the report on the implementation of the Bologna Process since I reject the measures being taken in its implementation, as well as the 2020 Strategy, which leads to the commodization and privatization of higher education and competition between universities. I also reject the involvement of companies in the development of educational programmes and the submission of education to the dogma of free competition and market interests. I believe that the responsibility of the education system should lie with the State (or the governing level which has the competences according to the Member State) and that it is the Member States which must ensure true recognition of diplomas. The budget for education and research should increase, as should the number and amount of scholarships. In addition, I am convinced that educational diversity, including linguistic diversity, must be respected in Europe. Therefore, since I are defending a public, universal, free and quality education that meets the needs of society and not the markets, I have only been able to vote against this report on the Bologna Process.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have decided to vote in favour of this report as I believe it clearly represents Parliament's position on the salient aspects of the Bologna process and makes a valuable contribution to the next interministerial conference to be held from 14 to 15 May 2015 in Yerevan.  It will be appropriate to focus on the scenario changes for the European higher education area, including the main priorities, such as strengthening the links between higher education and research, protecting the diversity of teaching, using technological innovations in learning or even a more student-centred approach and its results.  Over the past fifteen years, the Bologna process has achieved remarkable results in terms of quality of education, mobility and academic recognition. However, there are still many areas that need special attention in order to be able to meet the new challenges and thus ensure the strengthening and improvement of the European higher education area.

name: Czesław Adam Siekierski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The objectives of the Bologna Process have been achieved unequally by the Member States. The priority is to carry out the jointly agreed reforms. Achieving this requires political commitment and cooperation, and it should be important to develop additional tools and methods that would help countries facing challenges to make more progress. There is also a need to focus more on the student, his needs and what he or she should learn. The social aspects of the Bologna Process are believed to be among the most neglected features. The majority of students participate in programmes in accordance with the three-stage structure of bologna process studies. Creating such a structure of study is a way to better prepare graduates for labour market requirements and societal challenges. In order to achieve the objectives of the Bologna Process, it is necessary to properly implement the European Credit Transfer and Accumulation System (ECTS). The recognition of qualifications acquired abroad needs to be improved, which would bring more direct benefits to students. Another important aspect is the joint programmes, which are also a key aspect of the internationalisation of higher education. Work needs to be made to develop mobility in the Bologna system, both for students, teachers and educational staff.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today, along with my Labour colleagues, I voted in support of the implementation of the Bologna process. The aim of the Bologna process was and remains to provide students with a wider and more transparent choice of high-quality educational opportunities as well as create a simplified process of recognition both internally and externally throughout the participating national higher education systems. In view of pursuing the EU goals of growth and a knowledge-based economy, the Bologna Process can play an important role in the revision of the Europe 2020 strategy.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of adopting a resolution on the follow-up to the implementation of the Bologna Process. Over the last 15 years, the Bologna Process has made a major contribution to the mobility of young people and to improving the comparability of the structure of higher education. I consider student mobility to be an important tool for improving the qualifications of young people, which is crucial in reducing their unemployment. It is therefore necessary to increase efforts to promote this mobility and mutual recognition and comparability of educational standards, thus ensuring the quality and transparency of the European Higher Education Area.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the Bologna Monitoring Report, as it is one of the fundamental public policies aimed at strengthening the European spirit and creating European citizenship. Unfortunately, in most Member States, this cleverly conceived policy does not experience a successful implementation. The change in knowledge and education of young people, as well as the different educational experiences of young people, are key elements on the road to successful and long-term economic development.  The Croatian market does not know the true difference between a bachelor's degree and a master's degree, and in 90 percent of cases graduate bachelors are not recognized on the labour market, so they continue with an additional level of education. Education is one of the main pillars of our society, so I call on european and national authorities to have more administrative and financial support for the process.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. – In 1999, 29 European states signed the Bologna Declaration, the purpose of which was to create a European Higher Education Area (EHEA/ by 2010). This intergovernmental initiative, at the initiative of the EC, has tried to find a common response to existing problems, such as creating the conditions for greater mobility, adapting education systems to the needs of the labour market,... Today, after evaluating the last 15 years, we can say that the Bologna Process has achieved a great deal in terms of the quality of education, mobility and recognition of academic degrees. Overall, the Bologna Process has achieved greater transparency and facilitated access to information on European higher education. Despite the results achieved, the link between higher education and research and innovation and, above all, with the needs of the labour market, remains to be strengthened. According to the analyses, one in three employers in the EU has difficulty finding suitably qualified employees. That is why Member States have a political commitment to become more actively involved in the Bologna Process in order to improve higher education and enable as many applicants as possible to study in order to apply them to the labour market.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Thanks to the Bolone Process, a European area of higher education has been created, which has made it possible to improve the quality of education and its comparation between different EU Member States, increase mobility and facilitate the recognition of diplomas. Nevertheless, there are still many problems in the field of education. It is important to adapt our education systems to the needs of the labour market and to improve overall employment and competitiveness. Following the current high level of youth unemployment, it is also essential to support young people in their studies, including through readily available student loans, and to promote more studies abroad and programmes aimed at educate specialists needed in the labour market.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported a resolution to monitor the implementation of the Bologna Process, which calls on Member States to further improve and update the assessment of higher education institutions against standards previously set out under education systems at international level, rewarding excellence in the advancement of knowledge, research and science. It is important to preserve the diversity of teaching, including linguistic diversity, and to encourage Member States to increase scholarships and ensure their easy accessibility.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Over the past 15 years, the Bologna process – which aims to ensure comparability in the standards and quality of higher education qualifications – has been greatly successful in permitting a greater transparency and improved access to information in the field of European higher education. However, this is an area which it is important to develop.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. – The Bologna Declaration is the cornerstone of the unison of the education system in European countries, which was signed in June 1999 with the aim of creating a European Higher Education Area (EHEA) by 2010.  It worked, but not completely. I must cite the example of Croatia where all universities work on the foundations of "Bologna" and where progress has been made in the structure of higher education, harmonisation and quality and student mobility, but not enough care is yet taken about the employment of assistants and non-teaching staff, there is insufficient financial resources and equipment, international cooperation is underdeveloped, and the allocation of the four largest universities hinders a clear definition of the mission and policy of future development.  All of these problems significantly affect the quality of the university's work. For these reasons, I supported this report, as it speaks of the maximum use of EUROPEAN Union funds for the full implementation of the Bologna strategy with a view to finding new funding models, and I look forward to the fact that President of the European Commission Juncker has also put emphasis on improving the quality of higher education and establishing its quality in his Investment Plan for Europe.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained from voting on the report. While I agree with many of its objectives of increasing the efficiency of education, I do not agree with the emphasis on formal objectives, such as the objective of fulfilling by 2020 a 40% quota of highly educated young people or a call for an increase in funding without further criteria for their usefulness.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the Report on the review of the implementation of the Bologna Process. Education is a public good. The Bologna Process has been initiated in order to improve the quality and recognition of qualifications and the duration of studies at European Union level. The Bologna process should also contribute to improving the employment situation of young people. Today we see that there are still a lot of reserves in this area. There is still a major mismatch between the supply of skilled staff and demand in the EU. Since the beginning of the crisis in 2008, the problem of youth unemployment has not improved much. I support the report on the review of the implementation of the Bologna process because it calls on all stakeholders involved in the implementation of the Bologna process to improve quality assurance in order to achieve the realisation of the European Higher Education Area.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Our goal is to strengthen public and free education that will offer young students multi-level and multidimensional knowledge, so that they too can offer to the development of society. In order to achieve this, public funds for education must be strengthened and the promotion of the interests of companies in universities must be prevented.  Unfortunately, the Bologna Process is trying to adapt knowledge to market measures while opening the doors of universities to private companies. Moreover, the attempt to create a common framework for reform finds us opposed, as each Member State has a right and must define its policy on education and education.  For the above reasons we voted against this report.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Although we consider education and research to be important in promoting skills development, economic development and job creation, we do not agree with certain aspects of the report such as the internationalisation of education, the participation of students in the governance of higher education, the strengthening of European citizenship and the further liberalisation of residence permits for recognised refugees seeking specialised professional activity.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. How do I vote against such a report? It is also an opportunity to reiterate that our desire for a coherent, transparent and good quality higher education sector is essential to cultural, economic and social development. The Bologna objectives provide the necessary tools to enable higher education in Europe to meet the challenges of our time.  However, there is still a long way to go before we can claim to have fully fulfilled those objectives. While the process has many successes to its credit, including strong structural convergence, new challenges have taken the place of the old ones.  To take them to the next level and breathe new life into the process, it is essential to focus on the proper implementation of the current structure and tools, to correct their shortcomings and to move towards an educational paradigm that puts the student and the skills acquired at the centre of learning.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the implementation of the Bologna Process which is an essential tool to develop education though Europe. Over the past years, if there has been some progress made regarding quality, mobility and mutual recognition of qualifications between universities, there are still a number of areas that require further development. In this context, it is essential to respond to the new challenges that education is facing in Europe and this report is a first step.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I supported a report on monitoring the implementation of the Bologna Process, which points to the need to adapt the education system to the labour market, focusing primarily on strengthening skills and knowledge and improving education. As I have already pointed out, employment mobility cannot be supported, as emigration of working age power certainly cannot have a positive impact given the demographic and economic consequences that emigration can cause to individual countries, especially poorer members, but the mobility of learners and students with the aim of acquiring knowledge and training can only represent a positive trend.  The effects of the Bologna Process presented in the report indicate that the experiences students gain by studying abroad or performing professional practice certainly contribute to their independence, cultural enrichment, knowledge of foreign languages and ability to work in multicultural environments. Therefore, I support any form of youth initiative that will enable them to have an entrepreneurial spirit education and ultimately contribute to a better understanding of the real needs of the missing market and staff.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted AGAINST this report, which seeks to give impetus to the Bologna Process, which we oppose, since its 'big objectives' – the establishment of a European Higher Education Area that harmonizes its administrative and curricular procedures, facilitates mobility and adapts the training criteria to the new global challenges – mask a change of priorities: moving from a knowledge-generating entity to the service of society to being , as is the case in all areas likely to generate profit, at the service of economic profitability as defined by markets, despising the effect this criterion has on increasing social inequality.

name: Giovanni Toti (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The vote stresses that cultural, economic and social development requires a coherent, transparent and high-quality higher education sector.  The objectives of the Bologna Process provide European higher education with the essential means to meet today's challenges. However, much still needs to be done to achieve these objectives. It is therefore essential to focus on their correct use, remedying the shortcomings that still exist.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Access to education should not only be universal but it must be good in order to be more competitive as a society and avoid the high rates of unemployment that exists in some European countries. The Bologna process and the Europe 2020 strategy must face the inadequacy of current occupational qualifications, as one of three employers find cannot find skilled workers in some sectors. Mobility, internationalization, and support to university education between EU countries should give the same equal opportunities for European citizens. Needed reforms must be taken as soon as possible so that will be a benefit to us all, that is why I supported this resolution. I encourage all institutions and governments involved in making this possible.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (NI)
text: In writing. The Bologna process is a process of bringing European higher education systems closer together, which began in 1998 and led to the creation in 2010 of the European Higher Education Area of some 50 states. It aims to make Europe a globalised competitive space for the knowledge economy, the European higher education area. The goals of lifelong learning and mobility are constantly being reminded. France and the French are victims of this process which formalizes the anglicization of higher education. The European Union recognises many obstacles to student mobility, technical barriers but also language barriers. These barriers have never been commented on in evaluation reports, particularly in language reports. The Bologna process aims at a commodification of higher education, a reduction in social justice, a loss of intellectual autonomy of institutions and a possible shortening of certain studies. Higher education is seen through the dogma of economic growth and its harmonisation goes hand in hand with its anglicization. In our opinion, France must disengage from this process which calls into question the European spirit of equality of cultures and languages.

name: Mihai Țurcanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on monitoring the implementation of the Bologna process, especially in view of the social dimension of this process.  Education is one of the areas most affected by the economic difficulties facing the EU. As a result, I believe that a considerable financing effort is needed so that the target set for 2020, i.e. a share of 3% of the Union's GDP allocated for research and education, is achievable.  Furthermore, the fact that one third of European employers face difficulties in recruiting employees with appropriate qualifications, despite unemployment seriously affecting the younger generation, obliges Member States to make education policies more efficient in order to agree the vocational skills training system with the requirements of the labour market.  Last but not least, the mutual recognition of professional and academic qualifications can facilitate the movement of the workforce and the proper integration of European workers. Access to education and the stimulation of lifelong improvement, including through appropriate retraining programmes, can effectively contribute to combating the economic crisis, inequalities and unemployment, as well as, in the long term, to ensuring a dynamic that is inclusive of social inclusion and economic growth.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The implementation of the Bologna process is crucial to have a high-quality, coherent and transparent higher education sector, which exists in an excellent way. This document summarises the European system of higher education, and I fully support the S&D position on Bologna process in an understandable, accessible and credible way in order to ensure compatibility and comparability of standards and quality across different higher educational systems, support mobility and internationalisation, while respecting the diversity and autonomy of individual countries and universities.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted AGAINST this report, which seeks to give impetus to the Bologna Process, which we oppose, since its 'big objectives' – the establishment of a European Higher Education Area that harmonizes its administrative and curricular procedures, facilitates mobility and adapts the training criteria to the new global challenges – mask a change of priorities: moving from a knowledge-generating entity to the service of society to being , as is the case in all areas likely to generate profit, at the service of economic profitability as defined by markets, despising the effect this criterion has on increasing social inequality.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the follow-up to implementation of the Bologna Process because it represents a step forward towards the coordination of European education systems. It is crucial that all Member States carry out the agreed reforms and ensure the compatibility of higher education systems in Europe by guaranteeing the mutual recognition of academic degrees. Education is key in fostering employment and social inclusion and it should remain one of the main priorities of EU Member States; it is the only way that we can guarantee the prosperity of our societies. Europe has historically been a pioneer in culture and education and should continue being a point of academic reference.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. Education and research are one of the main pillars of our society in relation to the promotion of skills development, growth and job creation. It is important to adopt this document so that the Bologna Process contributes to a better education for Europe.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against the report on the implementation of the Bologna Process since I reject the measures being taken in its implementation, as well as the 2020 Strategy, which leads to the commodization and privatization of higher education and competition between universities. I also reject the involvement of companies in the development of educational programmes and the submission of education to the dogma of free competition and market interests. I believe that the responsibility of the education system should lie with the State and that it is the Member States which must ensure true recognition of diplomas. The budget for education and research should increase, as should the number and amount of scholarships. In addition, I am convinced that educational diversity, including linguistic diversity, must be respected in Europe. Therefore, since I are defending a public, universal, free and quality education that meets the needs of society and not markets, I have only been able to vote against this report on the Bologna Process.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report, recognising some of the serious consequences of the Bologna Process, proposes to remedy what is not repairable. Until the so-called "student mobility goal", which has gone down the road because mobility rates remain low, it is recognised in the report itself. What is needed, as we have argued in our alternative motion for an alternative resolution, is that there is, yes, cooperation between Member States at the level of higher education, but that this is done by guaranteeing everyone's right to free and quality public higher education. It is the responsibility of the Member States to education their citizens, and it is their responsibility to ensure universal and free public access that responds to the needs of society and not economic groups.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. The Freedom Party of Austria continues to oppose the Bologna Trial and calls for a (partial) exit. That is why I rejected the resolution.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour because I believe it is essential that the Group of Socialists and Democrats pushes for action by parliament to standard out an area such as higher education. At a time when all we are talking about is economic growth, where the issue of education is also often bent to the logic of pure financial expediency, it is crucial to ensure centrality and cohesion between the different European education systems. We must also network in this area, in order to ensure greater circulation of knowledge and training. Above all, we must give a concrete signal that progressive politics develops the education system and seeks to strengthen it.

name: Henna Virkkunen (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 Mr President, in accordance with its objectives, the Bologna Process has promoted student mobility and internationalisation. The Erasmus programme has enabled young people to study exchanges and learn foreign languages and cultures. It is very important to invest in the development of education and research in the future as well. A single European higher education area, comparability of the scope and grades of qualifications and recognition of qualifications are prerequisites for the effective and full realisation of the free movement of students. Freedom of movement and knowledge recognition are also of paramount importance in order to promote growth and competitiveness in Europe. Continuous updating of skills and lifelong learning improve employment opportunities and help to meet changing working life needs. When developing education, emphasis must be placed on working life orientation, student-centredness and the quality of education.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Over the past 15 years, the Bologna Process – aiming at ensuring comparability in the standards and quality of higher education qualifications – has accomplished a great deal in terms of the quality of education, mobility and academic recognition. Overall, the Bologna Process has achieved a greater transparency and made information about European higher education easily accessible, using benchmarking of national performance against common objectives. While these accomplishments are commendable, some areas still need further development and it is crucial to revitalise the Bologna Process to meet new challenges as well as to ensure the quality and transparency of the European Higher Education Area. Therefore, I voted in favour of this report as I believe it is crucial in view of pursuing the EU goals of sustainable growth and a knowledge-based society investing in quality education and learning.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that we must constantly strengthen higher education in Europe by every possible means that promotes science, knowledge, research, academic innovation and student skills. This initiative highlights the role of the Bologna Process, assesses and highlights the concerns that have arisen and highlights the priorities and new challenges that we as Europe must face for the development, modernisation and support of higher education in order to reduce disparities between Member States.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI)
text: Writing. – The report supports and promotes those restructurings that capital needs in the education systems of the EU Member States, restructurings leading to the degradation of studies, the dismantling of scientific subjects, the decoupling of a degree and profession, the adaptation and subordination of the whole structure and functioning of higher education to the objectives of monopolies. The EU emphasises so-called procedures for the recognition and certification of professional qualifications, quality assurance systems through evaluation and so-called mobility. The aim is to increase the competitiveness of capital, through new mechanisms of exploitation of graduates, through constant job insecurity and through the wandering of young workers from sector to sector and from country to country. The JRC also voted against the alternative report tabled because it accepts and embellishes the objectives of the Bologna Process for the creation of a 'single market for educational and research products and services' and for the intensity of the work and educational wandering of young people, depending on the needs of monopolies. The identification of the Greek co-government with the directions expressed by this "gospel" of the chapter on higher education that is the Bologna Process is also revealing for the unpopular plans of co-government for education in our country.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported this initiative because I believe that a single, transparent and high-quality area of higher education is essential for any development in Europe, whether cultural, economic or social. In my view, the Bologna Process is essential, in particular, because it plays a very important role in reducing skills mismatches in the EU. First of all, when we talk about the differences between graduate qualifications and the very demand in the EU labour markets. I therefore unequivocally support the standardisation of the diploma system, as it will certainly increase the employment of graduates in the labour market within the European Union.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution underlining the importance of continuing the Bologna Process, which also draws attention to the need to make greater efforts to reform higher education systems to meet the needs of the labour market.  The Bologna Process aims to make higher education more compatible across Europe so that different higher education systems do not create barriers to labour mobility and that European universities become more attractive to non-European students as well. This is voluntary cooperation between states, so reforms are implemented at different paces and to varying degrees. In relation to Slovakia, it is important to note that the two-tier system of education – the division of study into bachelor's and master's degrees – has not yet fulfilled its purpose. Bachelor's degree does not prepare graduates for the labour market, most of them continue with master's degrees.  We also have gaps in student mobility. We are the country from which most students go to study abroad, but we are failing to attract foreign students to our universities. Studying at a foreign university is still not a reality for many students whose families are unable to finance costs not covered by student grants. The recognition of credits also remains problematic.  When studying in higher education, there is still a strong social filter. The extent to which parents are educated significantly affects their children's educational level. Poor children often do not study because of inadequate state support in higher education institutions.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The so-called "Bologna process" is now a central theme, whatever the approach to the situation in higher education systems in the various Member States, not only because of the consequences that it already has in the lives of universities and polytechnics, but above all because of what it represents in the pursuit of the federalist objective by the European powers. This report, recognising some of the serious consequences of the Bologna Process, until the failed achievement of the so-called "student mobility objective", which has stood by as mobility rates remain low, proposes a regenerative bath, trying to give a new air to a process that cannot be renewed.  All the consequences, such as the difficulty in accessing higher education for those with less economic conditions, the creation of an army of cheap labour and the loss of critical formative culture that traditional higher schools tended to confer, can never be reversed or mitigated with more private investment, with a faster implementation of the process, with the establishment of more companies within universities , with the aim of the studies being done in accordance with the demands of the markets, leading to the privatization of education, as advocated by the rapporteur. We voted against it.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \ I voted in favour of the report on the review of the implementation of the Bologna Process, in which I was rapporteur for the Group of the European People's Party, as the report represents the European Parliament's contribution to the Ministerial Conference on the European Higher Education Area, which will begin in a few days' time in Yerevan. This conference will contribute to an even greater consolidation of the European Higher Education Area and will also aim at a critical review of the implementation of the Bologna process for the period 2012-2015. The Bologna reform can make a key contribution to making young people more employable in the European Union and to promote social cohesion, economic growth and a stronger commitment to a 'Europe of knowledge'. In 16 years, a single European higher education space was created, and almost all universities introduced a system of three cycles: undergraduate studies, master's degree and doctorate. Studies at various universities have become more compatible. However, we still have a lot of work to do, as the Bologna Reform has not achieved one of the most important objectives: greater employability of young people. At the end of 2014, there were still around 5 million unemployed people in the EU under the age of 25, with a huge number of unococable jobs. In order to improve this situation, higher education must be more flexible, it must provide competences and knowledge that are more useful and take into account the needs of students, the labour market, the economy and society in general.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I am glad that the European Parliament has adopted this report on European film in the digital era, because film is indeed a great cultural asset, but also an economic force. I also welcome the fact that the European Parliament sees the importance of cinemas as meeting places and supports the preservation of small independent cinemas.  The resolution does not forget media literacy, which helps users sort this information at a time when we are literally overwhelmed with information. I support and also welcome the efforts to create a European Film Forum. Among producers and distributors, I have noticed possible concerns about the continued existence of the film industry. Last but not least, this report supports the European Parliament's LUX Prize, which has gained great prestige over the years and promotes European creation.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, I voted in favour of the report on European cinema because cinematographic films are cultural and economic goods which make an important contribution to the development of the European economy, while at the same time being able to contribute to the preservation of the cultural tradition of the Member States of the Union. Although the European film industry is one of the world's largest producers, it is nevertheless moving, because of European cultural and linguistic diversity, into a de facto fragmented market. This is why promotion, cross-border distribution and accessibility, which is fully combined with audience development, must be ensured. It is important, however, that the Media programme ensures access to new sources of funding. We must ensure the operation of small and independent cinemas, especially in small towns, and in this context, sources of funding should be provided for Greece for the operation of summer cinemas which are an important cultural capital for my country.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D).
text: – Dear Mr President, one of the main challenges facing the European film industry is the need for more efficient and better advertising of films. By comparison, in the US this funding represents 50% of the film's budget, and in Europe from all film production only 1% goes to targeted marketing. I call on the Member States to make more efficient use of the European Structural Funds in order to make optimal use of digital financing, film heritage distribution and film repositories. The construction of media and film literacy must be stimulated from an early age in order for adolescents to acquire a sense of culture and the arts and to stimulate their own creative development.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE).
text: – Mr. President, the 2014 data shows that twice as many American films as European films have been shown in Europe. European films are most often seen only in the country where they were created.  It is necessary to strengthen the European film industry, and these are alarming data that point to this, and to develop quality funding instruments. We have one of the sources of funding, it is the Union's Creative Europe programme, which has a budget of €1.5 billion for the period 14-20, but for the entire Film Industry of the European Union and the entire cultural sector at european union level. Under the media programme, the development of new films, the search for partners and promotions beyond national borders are financed. This subroutine co-finances the development and distribution of thousands of films per year and I am glad that users from the Republic of Croatia managed to achieve four projects.  I supported this report, which encourages the creation of legal frameworks for public and private investment and promotion of the European film industry.

name: Lars Adaktusson (PPE)
text: Written. I voted against the report because there were several paragraphs in violation of the principle of subsidiarity. These paragraphs express support for more public funding for the European film industry and the addition of more film literacy to school curricula.  Whether Member States want to increase public funding for the film industry must, of course, be decided at national level. Spending Eu public money, especially at times like these, on partly financing an industry that should be driven by demand is a wrong priority.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 My vote on the report could only be negative. There are too many critical issues in the text, we have tried to remedy some of them with serious and concrete proposals, but unfortunately all our changes have not passed. It has been decided to ignore the enormous difficulties of access to credit for European cultural and creative enterprises, at a time when national authorities are granting millionaire derogations on the obligation to invest in European productions, in favour of multinationals, mortifying European workers and creators. We are talking about multi-territorial licences, but we are avoiding talking about geo-blocking, by making every attempt to guide Parliament's position in support of the creation of a digital single market that is really good for citizens and not yet another farce.  The report as a whole should have focused on the social function of the whole subject, but instead it was preferred to emphasise how to maximise revenue, probably of those who already have a significant position in the system. As spokesman for the European Parliament, the only voice I want to bring here is that of the citizens, if we were to do so, we would certainly be able to silence that of the multinationals.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report responds to a Communication from the European Commission entitled 'European cinema in the digital age – building bridges between cultural diversity and competitiveness'. While I reject the approach to the commodivity of culture, I supported this report by Parliament which, unlike the European Commission communication, which emphasizes the competitiveness aspects of the film industry, stresses the importance of the cultural aspect and calls for increased public funding for this sector.  I am also convinced of the importance of preserving European cultural heritage by digitizing its cinema, promoting the cultural and linguistic diversity of films. That is why, since Parliament's report improves the European Commission's approach by escaping consumer logic and highlighting the importance of promoting cultural education in non-formal schools and institutions, I have decided to vote in favour of it.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. European film is an important medium for promoting and disseminating Europe-wide cultural diversity. Films from smaller Member States in particular are struggling on the international market. Therefore, particularly targeted investments are needed to improve the cross-border availability of plants. This is mainly ensured by the promotion of subtitles and synchronizations. In addition, it is essential to ensure a comprehensive digitization of films in order to prevent the loss of works – as unfortunately happened with many silent films. I welcome measures in the field of European film and, in particular, events such as the Brussels Short Film Festival, which is currently taking place, in order to facilitate the distribution of film works throughout Europe.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. I abstained on these new provisions regarding cinema in the digital age. Some provisions consist of simple adaptations to technological change such as the digitization of cinemas, distribution or accessibility and visibility of films. However, other elements do not correspond to the national cultural interests of member states as the National Front wishes. While the VAT rule has been revised (destination country applies) but this is still not the case for audiovisual creation. Current legislation allows VOD services to apply the legislation of the country of origin of the service and not that of the destination country. We can take the example of Netflix: the headquarters is in the Netherlands and therefore escapes the obligation to contribute to the financing of creation in France.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to distribute European cinema. In Europe, marketing and advertising funds often account for just 1% of total production costs. And the US film marketing budget keeps pace with the cost of production. In addition, most European films are shown almost exclusively in the country of origin. I agree that public funding needs to be better balanced and should focus more on expanding the European film audience and increasing support for activities such as project development, promotion and international distribution. The Creative Europe programme, with a budget of EUR 1.5 billion for 2014-2020, is a key objective of the european programme. The audiovisual sector is a major source of funding for the audiovisual sector. More than half of the budget of this programme is allocated to the MEDIA sub-programme, which supports the development, distribution, training sessions and innovation of European cinema. It should be noted that the financial guarantee facility, which will be launched in 2016, will enable cinematographers to take out bank loans.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. This report focuses on the evolution of cinema within the European Union and mainly on the process of digitising cinemas, distribution, accessibility and visibility of films, funding and programmes to support the audiovisual sector (Creative Europe), the media and the means of promoting and distributing films produced in the European Union (such as the LUX prize). The report's inventory of film industry practices and data in Europe tells us, for example, that in the EU, 62.5% of cinema releases come from European films and 19.8% from American films. In contrast, 32.9% of cinema admissions are from European films and 65.1% from American films. In addition to its shortcomings, this report aims to promote a "European cinema" by ignoring precisely the tax problems posed by member states's video-on-demand platforms (VàD or VsD in English, VOD), of which the most emblematic example is the American Netflix: now having its European headquarters in the Netherlands, it escapes the obligation to contribute to the financing of creation in France.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The world of cinema plays a key role in building a European cultural heritage. In 2014, European cinema broke a new record: 1,500 European films were circulated in the EU. That's twice as many American films. However, a shadow remains in the picture, that of the number of spectators which is much lower than that of films from across the Atlantic. To solve this problem, it is necessary to extend the distribution of European films to new distribution channels such as video-on-demand services and streaming. There is also a need to invest more money in the promotion of films and in their international distribution. The Creative Europe programme, which has a budget of 1.5 billion euros for the period 2014-2020, aims to improve the distribution, visibility and accessibility of European films. It is therefore in support of European culture and the film industry that I voted in favour of this report.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the European film report in the digital age because of the importance of this industry in economic activity. The European film industry must continue the development of innovative services, new business models and distribution channels to improve the cross-border availability of European films in the Union and also allow viewers across the Union to have access to a growing catalogue of films across a growing number of platforms. In addition, it proposes in this regard that the European film industry draw lessons from best practices outside the Union.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. This report focuses on the evolution of cinema in Europe and mainly on the process of digitising cinemas, distribution, accessibility and visibility of films, funding and programmes to support the audiovisual sector (Creative Europe), film and media education and instruments for the promotion and distribution of European films (such as the LUX prize).  It is also envisaged to amend the SMA (Audiovisual Media Services) Directive, which repeals the 1989 TSF Directive, in order to adapt to the transformations taking place in the audiovisual media landscape. Apart from the fact that the motion for a resolution on the report promotes a European culture and identity (Lux Prize...) while I think it is up to the Member States to promote their national cultures, it remains too partial, especially on taxation or audiovisual media. Thus, the current legislation allows VOD services to apply the legislation of the country of origin of the service and not that of the destination country (e.g. Netflix). I therefore abstained on this report.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported this measure with my vote as I am in favour of the development of European-produced films.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. I've dropped my voice. This own-initiative report highlights European cinema and the importance of receiving public support. It describes problems in the digital age, the importance of protection for authors, and the importance of audiovisual archives. All this is positive. But there are also wordings about the importance of 'learning' from the US 'business model', as well as wordings on harmonisation of requirements and also VAT rates. That's why I choose to abstain.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. The European film industry is diverse and creative and has great potential, as it is a successful and inspiring film heritage around the world, and given its capacity for growth and employment generation. However, the industry faces new opportunities and challenges in the face of the digital revolution, which require adaptability to develop innovative services, new business models and better distribution channels to reach new and wider audiences. The Resolution recognizes the impact of illegal use of content on the creative cycle and the rights of creators, and stresses the need to combat these uses, while inviting the development of more quality legal offers and greater awareness, especially of young people, of illegal uses. It also calls on Member States to promote initiatives to facilitate the production, distribution, availability and attractiveness of European films, and believes that the application of reduced VAT rates to cultural audiovisual works can promote the growth of new services and new platforms. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it has made the European Parliament a position on the development of European cinema in the digital age. The report notes that films are both cultural goods and economic goods that contribute significantly to Growth and Employment in Europe. European cinema thus contributes to the formation of a European identity in order to convey cultural and linguistic diversity, promotes and simplifies cultural exchanges between citizens and contributes to the formation and development of critical thinking among citizens. Parliament therefore encourages the European film industry to develop innovative services, new business models and distribution channels in order to increase the cross-border accessibility of European films in the Union and, on the other hand, to enable viewers across the Union to enjoy an even greater variety of films. The report also recognises that the illegal downloading of creative works has a negative impact on the creative cycle and on creators' rights, and considers that this requires a wider quality of legal supply and awareness raising for young people.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The aim of the report "European cinema in the digital age" is to support European film and to increase its promotion, distribution and awareness so that all people can benefit from their cultural heritage.   The film also has cultural and economic value in society. An audiovisual sector that contributes to economic growth, create new jobs and stimulate innovation in the European digital market. Film literacy can have a significant impact on individuals, as it can affect the personal development of young people and how they perceive the outside world. The introduction of film literacy at all levels of education in the Member States therefore plays a very important role and has long-term benefits. Contact with European films is the best way to learn about the history, culture, traditions and language of our European neighbours. In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. The text recognises European film as an important cultural, social and economic dimension. Copyright protection is placed at the centre. I support the proposal.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (NI)
text: In writing. The text on 'European cinema in the digital age' becomes aware of the emergence of new actors, upsetting the traditional 'tripartite' relationship. This essential data was also identified by the Committee on Culture and Education, of which I am an alternate member. I abstained on a text that wanted to regulate a moving matter, at a time when new technologies are emerging, which often render outdated texts that have barely come into force.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I endorsed this report because Europe has been a key player in this industry ever since the invention of cinema, in Paris in 1895. Cinema is a huge part of our culture and our identity. It is of paramount importance, therefore, that we support the transition of the European film industry in the digital era.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. This report discusses the evolution of cinema on the European continent, and in particular the digitisation of cinemas, distribution, accessibility and visibility of films. It is first and foremost an inventory of cinematography practices and data in Europe. The proposal to amend the directive includes the participation of VOD platforms in the promotion of European works through a financial contribution. However, nothing has been done regarding the financial contribution for audiovisual creation. That is why I abstained on this vote.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 European films are economic and cultural goods, contributing substantially to the growth of the Union's economy and job creation.  European cinema funds allocate €2.1 billion annually to support the European audiovisual industry. Of this amount, EUR 110 million comes from the MEDIA sub-programme of the Creative Europe programme.  Around 1,300 films were produced in the EU in 2012, compared to more than 800 in the US, but only 8% of European films are distributed in cinemas in non-EU countries.  However, 2014 brought the most impressive number of European films distributed throughout Europe: 1,500 films were broadcast, which is double the number of American films, but unfortunately the number of viewers recorded in European films proved to be inversely proportional. In this way, I welcome this report on European film in the digital age because I believe that the European Film Forum will pave the way for the representatives of cinema, the Member States and the European institutions to find appropriate solutions that lead to a better distribution of European films.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour. The measure is in favour of the development and support of Films produced in Europe. The challenge in this area is between European and American films, and I certainly share the support for European production.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. European cinema is a guarantee of quality. Nevertheless, it could increase its competitiveness with the rest of the world by adapting to current challenges. Digital technology would greatly increase the accessibility of European cinema from the point of view of creation as well as distribution and financing channels. We must also promote European initiatives such as the LUX Prize. The LUX award allows some European films to obtain visibility equal to their quality. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on European cinema in the digital age.  The report stressed the essential economic role that cinema plays in Europe. The sector contributes to economic growth, creates new jobs and promotes innovation in the European digital market. The digital revolution has transformed the European film industry, reducing distribution costs and thus increasing the number and diversity of European films screened around the world. Nevertheless, digitalisation presents risks that should be limited. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution because, in addition to encouraging the European film industry to pursue the development of innovative services, it recognised the impact that the un authorised use of creative works has on the creative cycle and the rights of creators and underlined the need for more high-quality legal offers and raising young people's awareness.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This own-initiative report follows a Communication from the Commission entitled ʽEuropean film in the digital era – Bridging cultural diversity and competitivenessʼ from February 2014. Most of its preliminary remarks and the analysis is good. It notes that Europe’s film industry is diverse and creative but that most European films do not reach all their potential audience in Europe and even less so in the global market. It also proposes ways to address the challenges related to the digital shift, an opportunity for cultural diversity and film heritage preservation. It was for these reasons that I voted in favour of this report.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that the European film industry is an important facet of European culture that needs to be promoted and encouraged. This report aims at achieving this goal. The report aims to support European films, and strengthen its promotion, distribution and visibility so that all Europeans may reap the benefits of their cultural legacy. It contains a number of political priorities that focus mainly on the potential of the European film industry, promotion and cross-border distribution, audience development, funding and programmes supporting the audiovisual sector, film and media literacy especially for young people, instruments of production and circulation of European films. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report aims to protect, safeguard and increase the value of European cinema and to promote its development and promotion as a cultural heritage for future generations. What is not highlighted, however, is the difficulty of SMEs in the sector in accessing credit and, above all, it does not focus on the social function of cinema, which must not only be preserved, but above all protected, with the creation of a single digital market as the final goal.

name: Jean-Marie Cavada (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of Mr Wenta's report, whose proposals help boost the competitiveness and diversity of the European film sector.  Indeed, improving the overall efficiency of film financing instruments in the EU requires the search for a better balance between public funds for the promotion and distribution of European film works. Moreover, the competitiveness of the European film sector must now be based on the development of innovative services, such as legal video-on-demand services, as they improve the cross-border availability and distribution of European films, but also effectively combat piracy.  Finally, in order to perpetuate the diversity of European cinema, it is necessary to encourage the large-scale digitisation of European films, as well as their increasing availability in original subtitled versions. By making all of these points political priorities in his report, Mr Wenta lays the foundations for better exploitation of the potential of the European film industry.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. I have chosen to abstain on this report which, while it makes good observations on the practices of the European film sector, goes in the direction of a uniformity of cultural practices in Europe through the field of cinema.  In addition to this attempt to encroach on the prerogatives of Member States that must be able to promote their own cultural identities, the motion for a resolution proposes incomplete solutions to the challenges and challenges of the film industry.  Thus, in the tax chapter, the report supports the SMA Directive. However, it provides a financial contribution from VOD services to finance cultural creation. A good idea at first, except that the current legislation allows VOD services to apply the legislation of the country of origin of the service, not that of the country of destination. Once again, even the best inspirations of European legislators are marred by its lack of common sense.

name: Nessa Childers (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In Europe, we have always had a prominent film heritage, which boasts our cultural diversity on screen. In recent times we have seen how technology is moving incredibly fast and we believe that support measures are needed in order to keep up with the constant innovation in this digital era. We are confident that the creation of growth and jobs that can also benefit other sectors of the economy, such as that of the film industry and my Dublin constituency, is a good example of this, proving that Europe can compete at a global level.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This measure stresses the need to increase not only the production and development, but also the distribution of European films. 2014 saw the circulation of 1 500 European films, twice as many films produced in the USA. However, the number of spectators was inversely proportional. The challenge is to ensure a true and efficient distribution of European cinematographic works, ensuring their visibility and reaching a wider audience.  The 'Creative Europe' programme, with a budget of EUR 1.5 billion for the period 2014-2020, is an important source of funding for the audiovisual sector. The programme devotes more than half of its budget to the MEDIA sub-programme, which strengthens the development of European cinema, distribution, training sessions and innovation. European cinema needs public funding that places greater emphasis on marketing. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because it lays the foundations for increasing not only the production and development, but also the distribution of European films. I believe that Member States should promote incentives to facilitate the production of films produced on this side of the Atlantic, and also to apply the same VAT rates, as this can stimulate the growth of new services and platforms. I particularly welcome the expectation of increasing the availability of European films in the original language with subtitles, thus facilitating the circulation and understanding of European cultures and languages.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of approving the report on European cinema in the digital age based on the communication sent by the Commission and indicating a strategy to increase the popularity of European films.   Indeed, I fully share the view that cinematographic works are both cultural and economic assets and that, therefore, they can make an important contribution to the European economy in terms of growth and employment, while promoting the identities, customs and traditions of the Member States. Given that the potential of the cultural and creative sectors in Europe, and in particular of the European film industry, is not yet fully exploited, the desire to create an investment-friendly climate is appreciated, for example through a new regulatory text on the subject. I welcome the priority actions identified in the text of the report, and I think it is good to give them programmatic value, in the hope that they will soon become a concrete political commitment. Among the various proposals are: the development of innovative services and economic models; the balanced and judicious use of European, national and regional public funding; the dissemination of European films in an original version with subtitles; the promotion of a film literature that promotes the understanding and critical use of works; digitization of formats.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The report calls for a new strategy for the film-making industry which aims to improve competitiveness in the digital age through better promotion and distribution of European films, balancing the production and distribution of funding from public sources, the development of new business models that increase the availability of cross-border European films, facilitating the translation strings and the introduction of film education in schools. The report also focuses on copyright and licensing as essential issues for digital film distribution throughout the EU. It also highlights the role of film heritage and small cinemas in promoting cultural content. I thus voted in favour.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against because the Wenta report was designed exclusively for those who already occupy important positions in the system, while there is no advantage for access to credit for small and medium-sized enterprises in the cultural and creative sector, directly and indirectly operating in the film sector.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report responds to a Communication from the European Commission entitled 'European cinema in the digital age – building bridges between cultural diversity and competitiveness'. While I reject the approach to the commodivity of culture, I supported this report by Parliament which, unlike the European Commission communication, which emphasizes the competitiveness aspects of the film industry, stresses the importance of the cultural aspect and calls for increased public funding for this sector.  I am also convinced of the importance of preserving European cultural heritage by digitizing its cinema, promoting the cultural and linguistic diversity of films. That is why, since Parliament's report improves the European Commission's approach by escaping consumer logic and highlighting the importance of promoting cultural education in non-formal schools and institutions, I have decided to vote in favour of it.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution on European cinema in the digital age addresses one of the most important cultural issues. The European film market is by far one of the largest. At the same time, however, its fragmentation makes it weak compared to non-European productions. That is why innovation must be promoted as much as possible in both production and distribution so as not to lag behind and, above all, so as not to become residual in cultural production.  It also considers that the film productions of many European countries are made up of its internationally recognized qualitative specificity. The vote in favour of this resolution is therefore essential to support this important segment of cultural production but also to keep pace within the film market itself with the latest technological innovations.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EP report on European film is about supporting European films and promoting them and facilitating their distribution. As a result of the easier accessibility of European films, as many EU citizens as possible will benefit from our diverse cultural heritage. Film has cultural and economic value in our society. An audiovisual sector that contributes to economic growth, create new jobs and stimulate creative innovation in the European digital market. Film literacy can have a significant impact on individuals, affect the personality development of young people and how they perceive the outside world. The introduction of film literacy at all levels of education in the Member States therefore plays a very important role and has long-term benefits. Contact with European films is the best way to learn about the history, culture, traditions and language of other European Member States, and is also a tool for us to convey our own culture to the rest of Europe. European film plays a prominent role in preserving linguistic diversity by bringing to the fore every language in Europe in addition to "big" languages.  I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the European focus on our continent’s film industry as I believe that there is great potential that still needs to be tapped. The potential of the cultural and creative sectors in Europe, and in particular of the European film industry, can help promote European cultural and linguistic diversity and heritage. They can also create growth and jobs, providing the EU with a competitive advantage in this regard. Therefore, I voted in favour of this.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The potential of the cultural and creative sectors in Europe and in particular of the European film industry is not fully exploited in promoting the diversity and heritage of European culture.  The preparation for an audiovisual world, characterised by full convergence, calls for the need to combine tradition and modernity by creating a bridge between cultural diversity and competitiveness. In a multimedia context, the harmonisation of the rules governing the digital single market serves to create an environment conducive to doing business, which will protection intellectual property and users. We must therefore make the best use of programmes such as Creative Europe, create synergies between funding funds to facilitate the production and distribution of European films and media and film literacy, not only to offer a competitive advantage on the world stage. It is crucial to develop confidence in the Internet and to increase access to legal audiovisual content in order to encourage investment in European cinematographic works. The EU must take action to accompany the affirmation of the cross-border portability of audiovisual services, in view of the rapid growth of VoD and online transactions, in order to ensure access to platforms consistent with EU financial and fiscal interests.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report aims to support the European Commission's strategy to broaden the audience of European films and emphasise the need to improve the overall effectiveness of financing instruments to promote competitiveness and diversity in the sector. Considering that in order to defend its cultural peculiarities, the European Union must put in place effective financial instruments, such as the Creative Europe programme in its media component, to help European cinema promote the potential of its industry, promote cross-border promotion and distribution and expand to a wide range of audiences. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. Creation cannot flourish without an adequate cultural funding program. From this point of view, I welcome the importance of the Creative Europe programme and the MEDIA sub-programme. These are programmes of financial support to the cultural sector, particularly audiovisual, which are part of the European Union's multi-year financial framework.  Despite this, more needs to be done to support the distribution of European films. We are fortunate in Europe to have a dynamic and varied cultural and creative life, we must put it in the digital age while respecting the work of creators.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Most films produced in Europe are distributed almost exclusively in their home country and only 8% are distributed outside the EU despite the EU producing more films than the US. I supported this resolution because it aims to support European cinematographic works and to promote their promotion, distribution and visibility, so that all European citizens can reap the benefits.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The aim of the report "European cinema in the digital age" is to support European film and to increase its promotion, distribution and awareness so that all people can benefit from their cultural heritage.   The film also has cultural and economic value in society. An audiovisual sector that contributes to economic growth, create new jobs and stimulate innovation in the European digital market.
