Film literacy can have a significant impact on individuals, as it can affect the personal development of young people and how they perceive the outside world. The introduction of film literacy at all levels of education in the Member States therefore plays a very important role and has long-term benefits. Contact with European films is the best way to learn about the history, culture, traditions and language of our European neighbours. In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. The European film industry has a major impact on the European cultural landscape as well as on employment and economic growth. However, most films produced in Europe only come out in their home countries (only 8% are distributed outside the EU). Faced with American films that are much more widely distributed in Europe, securing a wider audience for European productions is a challenge for European cinema. The distribution of public subsidies is one of the explanations for the distribution problem: almost 70% of these subsidies are devoted to production, leaving little means for marketing/distribution. The report I supported contains several suggestions to stimulate the dissemination of European cinema: encouraging subtitling of films (rather than translating them), supporting small cinemas and enabling them to equip themselves with digital projections, funding the digitisation, preservation and online availability of European film heritage and supporting European co-productions to lead to wider distribution of films.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report "European cinema in the digital age" aims to support European film and to increase its promotion, distribution and awareness so that all people can benefit from their cultural heritage.   The film also has cultural and economic value in society. An audiovisual sector that contributes to economic growth, create new jobs and stimulate innovation in the European digital market. Film literacy can have a significant impact on individuals, as it can affect the personal development of young people and how they perceive the outside world. The introduction of film literacy at all levels of education in the Member States therefore plays a very important role and has long-term benefits. Contact with European films is the best way to learn about the history, culture, traditions and language of our European neighbours. In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. I abstained on these new provisions regarding cinema in the digital age. Some provisions consist of simple adaptations to technological change such as the digitization of cinemas, distribution or accessibility and visibility of films. However, other elements do not correspond to the national interest in cultural matters as the National Front wishes. While the VAT rule has been revised (the destination country applies) this is still not the case for audiovisual creation. Current regulations allow VOD services to apply the legislation of the country of origin of the service and not that of the country of destination. We can take the example of Netflix: the headquarters is in the Netherlands and therefore escapes the obligation to contribute to the financing of creation in France.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is banal to repeat that in times of crisis every investment in our production, in any sector, is completely necessary, but this is a fact and it is our duty to be encouraged. The digital market is evolving at full strength and needs to be stimulated, but also well regulated.  This report considers that a flat reduced VAT rate should be applied to cultural audiovisual works sold online and offline, but I believe that the debate here needs to be more detailed. An in-depth analysis of the immediate impact on digital goods that are more easily sourced across borders is needed. I support this report by stressing that such an analysis is imperative. Copyright here is also of great importance and the necessary remuneration must be guaranteed for the rightholders and especially for the authors themselves. This will really lead to production that stimulates the economy and growth.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report because it is absolutely necessary to promote European cinema, which is part of our culture and which must keep up with its time and become more competitive.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The aim of the report "European cinema in the digital age" is to support European film and to increase its promotion, distribution and awareness so that all people can benefit from their cultural heritage. The film also has cultural and economic value in society. An audiovisual sector that contributes to economic growth, create new jobs and stimulate innovation in the European digital market. Film literacy can have a significant impact on individuals, as it can affect the personal development of young people and how they perceive the outside world. The introduction of film literacy at all levels of education in the Member States therefore plays a very important role and has long-term benefits. Contact with European films is the best way to learn about the history, culture, traditions and language of our European neighbours. In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. – In the digital age in which we live, the film industry is greatly affected by the change taking place in the production and distribution chain, as well as in consumer habits.   In order to deal seriously with this problem, which is also aggravated by strong competition from the United States, it would be necessary to think, at European level, of multi-level governance in order to design a system that values the film industry not only as a source of revenue, but also and above all as an essential source of culture. It is precisely because of the lack of this type of vision that I voted against this text, which is, moreover, a long way from the idea of creating a digital single market, given that geo-blocking is not even mentioned as a serious limitation of the current legal framework.   Furthermore, I found it indicative that there was no mention in the text of the 2013 survey on access to credit for the creative industries, which shows that there is a financial hole of between EUR 8 billion and EUR 13.3 billion. There is also no critical mention of the mea small sum of EUR 130 million made available by the Creative Europe programme as the Commission's only measure to tackle the serious problem of access to credit for SMEs in the cultural sector.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. The year 2014 stood out for the large number of European films distributed in Europe: 1,500 films circulated, representing twice as many films in the US. Nevertheless, the number of European film viewers was inversely proportional. Although there is still a need for financial support for smaller rooms, the process of digitising cinemas is nearing its end. According to the European Audiovisual Observatory (OAS), around 87% of the eu's total 30 000 cinema screens were digitised at the end of 2013. The next challenge for the audiovisual sector is the need to ensure a genuine and effective distribution of European films, which ensures their visibility and reaches wider audiences. With a budget of EUR 1.5 billion for the period 2014-2020, the Creative Europe programme is an extremely important source of funding for the audiovisual sector. The budget appropriations for the coming years will support the circulation of more than 800 European films, both within and outside The European area. In addition, the programme aims to provide ongoing support to more than 80 European film festivals, which promote films in the region.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 There are fewer and fewer film promotion festivals supported by public funds, including the EU. Some of the oldest Portuguese festivals have lost support and ended. This is the case of Festroia.   Advocating a shift in the way european cinema is being promotioned, the report argues that "good examples" come from the American and Canadian film industry, i.e., it supports a market-focused and little approach to people, to the role of entertainment, without taking into account the social, cultural and educational role of cinema.  Considerations are certainly made, such as the defence of cultural diversity, as a facilitating factor for the promotion of cultural exchanges and critical thinking, the support and promotion of national cultural policies, increased public funding for greater distribution and better promotion of European cinema, and support for subtitling in all EU languages.  However, we do not agree with the perspective that directs Creative Europe funds only to the distribution and promotion of films, since in several countries, including Portugal, producers are experiencing serious difficulties. We agree that distribution is also supported, but only in the case of those who do not have the means and not in the case of large distributors. Promotion should also be supported.

name: Raffaele Fitto (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 European cinema must be supported because it is a key sector for European culture. The report promotes European cinematographic works and promotes their distribution and visibility. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The process of digitising cinemas is slowly coming to an end and we need to focus on the effective promotion and distribution of European films and attract many more people to these performances, because the problem is not so much the quantity of european films mentioned above but the number of visitors who like to go to these films. Both national and Pan-European support for the production of European films is not inconsiderable, but it is only involved in the production process, not in distribution, which causes significant limited distribution possibilities for European films. It is very sad that Europeans, in their 500 million-strong market, much prefer to pay to see American films that earn disproportionately more in Europe than European ones. I am therefore very happy that, even at a time of economic and social crisis, the European Film Prize of the European Parliament LUX is being awarded, which stimulates the debate on European film and cinema every year.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of development and support for European-produced films. The challenge in this area is between European films and American films. In addition to cultural differences, the big difference is in budget – for production but above all for marketing. We in the Committee on Culture have long supported these European policies.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on European cinema in the digital age because it is absolutely necessary to support European cinema, since it is part of cultural creation and since it also needs to keep up with its time and become more competitive.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This own-initiative report comes in response to the Commission Communication on ʽEuropean film in the digital era, bridging cultural diversity and competitivenessʼ. Europe’s film industry is diverse and creative, and has a great potential as its film heritage is successful and inspirational worldwide. However, the digital revolution offers new possibilities, as well as posing new challenges. It is therefore essential to adapt to the digital era and use its potential to reach new and wider audiences. The potential of the cultural and creative sectors in Europe and in particular of the European film industry is yet to be fully exploited in the promotion of European cultural and linguistic diversity and heritage within and outside Europe, as well as the creation of growth and jobs that can also benefit other sectors of the economy, providing Europe with a competitive advantage at a global level.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report "European cinema in the digital age" aims to support European film and to increase its promotion, distribution and awareness so that all people can benefit from their cultural heritage.   The film also has cultural and economic value in society. An audiovisual sector that contributes to economic growth, create new jobs and stimulate innovation in the European digital market. Film literacy can have a significant impact on individuals, as it can affect the personal development of young people and how they perceive the outside world. The introduction of film literacy at all levels of education in the Member States therefore plays a very important role and has long-term benefits. Contact with European films is the best way to learn about the history, culture, traditions and language of our European neighbours. In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report "European cinema in the digital age" aims to support European film and to increase its promotion, distribution and awareness so that all people can benefit from their cultural heritage. The film also has cultural and economic value in society. An audiovisual sector that contributes to economic growth, create new jobs and stimulate innovation in the European digital market. Film literacy can have a significant impact on individuals, as it can affect the personal development of young people and how they perceive the outside world. The introduction of film literacy at all levels of education in the Member States therefore plays a very important role and has long-term benefits. Contact with European films is the best way to learn about the history, culture, traditions and language of our European neighbours. In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. The role of cinema in society has a cultural and economic aspect of good. The audiovisual sector contributes to economic growth, creates new jobs and drives innovation in the European digital market. Without a creative economy there is no creation. To make the most of its cultural and economic potential, the European film industry needs a stable legal framework that encourages investment and diversity and enables the development of new online services. Copyright is an important element to consider and should ensure adequate remuneration to rightholders. The challenge we face is the need to ensure a real and effective distribution of European films that ensures their visibility.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. I welcome and welcome mr Bogdan Brunon Wenta's report, which frames cinema as an important cultural and economic resource for Europe, both at the level of large industry, which has a large number of workers at its service, and therefore large amounts of employment, and at the great exercise and exceptional tradition on which it has grown and continues to develop at an autoral level. It is precisely in order to safeguard this precious source of training and human growth that cinema often represents, and to facilitate wider access and wider dissemination to the European audiovisual industry in the Member States and third countries, that there is therefore a call for greater commitment to financial support for films not only linked to the production stage, but also to that of the distribution and promotion of titles.  Therefore, to continue along the lines of what is being committed to the European Film Forum, to provide for an increase in incentives for the market and marketing of the European audiovisual sector in the world, to allow access to the financial guarantee instrument for filmmakers and to launch and promote by all means festivals and events that widen the links of the visibility of our cinema , as well as supporting legal offers on the net (streaming or video on demand) are therefore all operations that I feel I fully support so that our culture can increase the great works of cinema and above all can spread and reach beyond our borders, talking about Europe and investing in it.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on European film in the digital age today because I welcome its approach and believe it makes sense to promote both the European film industry and the digitisation of valuable programme cinemas in Europe.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the Wenta report because the European films sector has the ability to make a very significant contribution to the realisation of the EU’s ambitious goals on culture, education and job creation and growth in the real economy. In order to tap the full potential of the sector, it is crucial we provide the support needed to assist it in grasping opportunities, as well as tackling the challenges, offered by the digital revolution. Therefore it is imperative that the efficiency of funding systems be thoroughly evaluated, as well as the impact of European television stations of film production on SMEs that are active in the sector. Understanding the importance of film literacy skills furthermore is vital for developing critical thinking in our education policies.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because in Europe's vast cultural heritage we cannot forget the 'seventh art'. Although European film production is of major size – 1 500 European films were circulated in 2015 – what is apparently missing are the viewers, who far prefer US cinema.  De gustibus not disputandum est, of course, but here the problem is that our citizens do not know the European alternatives because they are poorly marketed or promoted, activities in which, as we know, the Americans are very good. European cinema does not have the resources to be translated or dubbed, and this is a serious loss for viewers. The Italians are denied the chance to watch the Dardenne brothers, the Dutch are barred from watching ozpetek's. Among the young directors could be the new Fellini, to us the responsibility to support it and bring it out.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report by the European Parliament's Committee on Culture, which takes place in the context of a debate on the promotion of European cinema initiated by a Communication from the Commission. The increased dissemination that American cinema receives, as well as the dilemmas generated for creators by the new modes of distribution, set the framework for the debate. The European Commission's position placed a strong emphasis on promoting a model favourable to the big industry and focused on the co-financing of film production. This Resolution dodges the most controversial points when it comes to the business model. However, it promotes public aid to the distribution and promotion of cinema and promotes the access of all citizens to culture through subtitling, the creation of public archives, etc.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ European cinema is at the heart of the cultural development of the EU and touches directly upon the identity of European citizens. The economic weight of the European film industry is also significant. To make full use of its cultural and economic potential, the European film industry needs to thrive in the right environment, spurred on by a stable and adaptable legal framework which encourages investment and diversity, and allows new services to develop online. I voted in favour of this report as I believe it sets up a good foundation to achieve the above.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D)
text: In writing. Cinema faces immense challenges such as non-European competition and digitisation. That is why I supported this report, which proposes a balanced approach, emphasizing the importance of actions to promote and distribute works, particularly through subtitling or the development of co-productions.  European and national support for small independent cinemas should be encouraged so that they can acquire the equipment necessary for the distribution of digital productions. Moreover, if the legal online supply of European films is to be diversified and increased to support the film industry, the issue of respect for copyright must remain a priority. Member States should be more supportive of travelling festivals and cinemas and take advantage of MEDIA and Creative Europe programmes.  Finally, I believe that film education needs to be developed in order to bring a film culture that is purely consumer of works.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report "European cinema in the digital age" aims to support European film and to increase its promotion, distribution and awareness so that all people can benefit from their cultural heritage.   The film also has cultural and economic value in society. An audiovisual sector that contributes to economic growth, create new jobs and stimulate innovation in the European digital market. In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. Today, a draft law on European film has been presented. Of course, the digital age requires a European Digital Single Market. But when it came to "European film," I got stupid. I know German films, mostly better French films, exciting Hollywood movies, enigmatic films from Japan, but I haven't seen a "European film" yet. I don't want to see him. The very thought of it triggers a yawn reflex for me. This reminds me of the failed attempts by the car industry to sell a 'European car'. Soon there will be European cheese or a European football team. I'd rather stick with my HSV. What are they doing in Brussels? We want cultural diversity, not a Single European. One could say something polemical: the opposite of diversity is simplicity. I just had to vote against this bill!

name: Carlos Iturgaiz (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting in favour of this report on European cinema in the digital age. It aims to support European films and promote their promotion, distribution and visibility so that all Europeans can reap the benefits of their cultural legacy.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Digital Film Europe Report, as films are both economic and cultural goods and contribute to the growth of the European economy and employment and the shaping of European identities by reflecting cultural and linguistic diversity, promoting European culture across borders, facilitating cultural exchange and understanding.  This report takes into account various important aspects such as encouraging the European film industry to continue developing innovative services, new business models and distribution channels; audience development; cross-border distribution and availability; considers that anyone with an economic benefit, even indirect, from works of European cinema through direct commissions, marketing or dissemination, including video-on-demand links or commissions, should contribute financially to the creation of European films; funding proposals; calls on the Member States to strengthen their efforts to improve film literacy; distribution and archiving, etc.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. I abstained on these new provisions regarding cinema in the digital age. Some provisions consist of simple adaptations to technological change such as the digitization of cinemas, distribution or accessibility and visibility of films. However, other elements do not correspond to the national interest in cultural matters as the National Front wishes. While the VAT rule has been revised (destination country applies) but this is still not the case for audiovisual creation. Current legislation allows VOD services to apply the legislation of the country of origin of the service and not that of the destination country. We can take the example of Netflix: the headquarters is in the Netherlands and therefore escapes the obligation to contribute to the financing of creation in France.

name: Danuta Jazłowiecka (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 No one doubts that the potential of the European cultural and creative industries is not being fully exploited. Europe – which until recently inspired other countries and continents – is increasingly losing its position not only to America, but also to Asian countries. The example of South Korea, India or Turkey closer to us shows that, using appropriate mechanisms, a leading export product can be made of regional works. Tv series and films from these countries conquer the world, including Europe. That is why I was pleased to support the report. The rapporteur rightly points out that the problem lies not in the quality of European production or its containment, but above all in the lack of effective promotional activities. A Europe producing one and a half thousand films in dozens of languages every year is not able to encourage its citizens to watch them or even to give them the opportunity to do so. If today we are asking ourselves how to create new jobs in the Union, it is the cultural sector that is a good place. By changing the funding model for film production and channelling some of the money into their broader promotion – including language translation – we can increase the potential of this industry and create new jobs in a very short time.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Bogdan Wenta's report on cinema in the digital age. This report takes stock of the situation in European cinema and highlights a number of proposals to strengthen the viability of European production, which is very important but which suffers from difficulty in moving outside the Union. The report thus proposes to better distribute the aid enjoyed by European cinema in order to increase the chances of success of the film once released, and supports the European Commission's initiative to organise a European film forum so that the actors of the channel can exchange on how to make their sector more efficient. The report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on European cinema in the digital age. This report takes stock of the situation of the European film sector in order to identify its strengths and weaknesses, particularly in the face of American competition. For example, the report mainly calls on Member States to increase public funding to support the distribution and promotion of European films abroad.  I welcome this vote.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI)
text: Writing. European film is one of the continent's most important cultural exports, but given the financial resources and popularity of Hollywood films, it is difficult for European films to gain worldwide notoriety. The digital era offers new opportunities to support European film, which is why I fully support this proposal.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I fully support this report, drafted by Parliament’s Committee on Culture and Education. The report aims to support European cinema by improving its promotion, distribution and competitiveness through cross-border distribution, audience development, media literacy, innovation in distribution methods, and funding issues. However cinema is not just about profits, it is about cultural exports and diversity too, and this report also addresses these issues. European films account for more than 60% of releases in the EU but represent only one third of ticket sales, so I am in favour of this resolution and its goal to increase the audience for European films. It is important also that the report looks at copyright and licensing as essential issues for digital film distribution throughout the EU.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The potential of the European film industry has yet to be fully exploited in the promotion of European cultural and linguistic diversity and heritage within and outside Europe, as well as the creation of growth and jobs that can also benefit other sectors of the economy, providing Europe with a competitive advantage at a global level. I voted in favour of this report as I believe it sets up a good foundation to achieve the above.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The aim of the report "European cinema in the digital age" is to support European film and to increase its promotion, distribution and awareness so that all people can benefit from their cultural heritage.   The film also has cultural and economic value in society. An audiovisual sector that contributes to economic growth, create new jobs and stimulate innovation in the European digital market. Film literacy can have a significant impact on individuals, as it can affect the personal development of young people and how they perceive the outside world. The introduction of film literacy at all levels of education in the Member States therefore plays a very important role and has long-term benefits. Contact with European films is the best way to learn about the history, culture, traditions and language of our European neighbours. In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The film industry can also serve to strengthen the Europe of nations by preserving diverse cultural treasures and inging them to a wide audience. A counterweight must be created against us-based, largely worthless cinema. This is facilitated by the fact that the budgetary appropriations for the coming years support the distribution of more than 800 European films, both inside and outside Europe. The programme also aims to provide ongoing support to more than 800 European film festivals promoting regional films. I voted in favour of this report because the funding it provides a new audience for European audiovisual works and protects cultural and linguistic diversity.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Wenta report, which would further focus European public funding on culture towards expanding the audience for European films, including increased support for promotion, international distribution and co-production.  The adoption of this report by the European Parliament is an important step towards a better distribution of European films around the world. It will participate more broadly in the international promotion of Europe's cultural diversity.

name: Andrew Lewer (ECR)
text: in writing. – The ECR Group supports much of the content in this report, such as the recognition of the importance of rightholders and improving access to digital content. However we are cautious on raising the issue of VAT into this particular text, in terms of offering the same reduced VAT rates for online and offline content. This forms part of a much wider debate that must be duly considered – we support a legal framework that encourages entrepreneurship in the digital environment, but need to consider and understand the direct effects on digital goods which are easier to source across borders than physical goods. We also disagree with the notion that those organisations benefiting financially from European Film should by default reinvest the proceeds into the making of European Films. If they generate profit on the film rights they have legally obtained (such as by purchasing them), then how they distribute this revenue is their decision.  The ECR Group supported this report but we wish to put on record our reservations regarding certain issues contained within it, such as those outlined above.

name: Philippe Loiseau (NI)
text: In writing. I abstained. The aim of this report is the evolution of cinema in Europe, including the process of digitising cinemas, distribution, accessibility and visibility of films. Funding and programmes to support the audiovisual sector (Creative Europe), film and media education and instruments for promoting and distributing European films are also among the topics covered. He tells us that European aid is mainly devoted to production (69%) while in the United States the effort is focused on marketing and 62.5% of cinema releases are European films, 19.8% of American films. The aim is to amend the SMA (Audiovisual Media Services) Directive to adapt to the transformations that the audiovisual media landscape is currently undergoing. I criticise the fact that there is no reference to the defence of national cultures but essentially to European culture. The tax aspect and the contribution to national creations are also too little developed.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. This own-initiative report emerges in response to the Commission's communication on 'European cinema in the digital age – building bridges between cultural diversity and competitiveness'.  The European film industry is diverse and creative, and has great potential as a successful and inspiring film heritage around the world, as well as in creating growth and jobs that can also benefit other sectors of the economy, giving Europe a global competitive advantage. While the digital revolution offers new possibilities, it also poses new challenges. It is therefore essential to adapt to the digital age and use its potential to reach new and wider audiences.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report responds to a Communication from the European Commission entitled 'European cinema in the digital age – building bridges between cultural diversity and competitiveness'. While I reject the approach to the commodivity of culture, I supported this report by Parliament which, unlike the European Commission communication, which emphasizes the competitiveness aspects of the film industry, stresses the importance of the cultural aspect and calls for increased public funding for this sector. I am also convinced of the importance of preserving European cultural heritage by digitizing its cinema, promoting the cultural and linguistic diversity of films. That is why, since Parliament's report improves the European Commission's approach by escaping consumer logic and highlighting the importance of promoting cultural education in non-formal schools and institutions, I have decided to vote in favour of it.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. The role of cinema in society has a double aspect: it is a cultural and economic asset. An audiovisual sector united in diversity contributes to economic growth, creates new jobs and drives innovation in the European digital market. The report on European cinema in the digital age, for which I voted, aims to support European films and promote their promotion, distribution and visibility so that all Europeans can reap the benefits of their cultural legacy, and the European Parliament's LUX Prize is a perfect example of how European cinema should be promoted.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I fundamentally disagree that the European Union should be able to force service providers to promote any film. Art is always a matter of the taste of the viewer and not of a politician or official. Especially at a time of enormous debt for the whole of Europe, I am against the use of taxpayers' money to finance films that do not enforce themselves.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the decision to dynamically develop European and not American cinema.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The development of film production in the current period of digitisation plays an important role in several levels – cultural, social and economic. In addition to facilitating knowledge of mutual cultures between countries and creating cultural heritage as a source of knowledge and education for future generations, film production is an important economic and economic sector and employer. Further support for film development must be directed primarily towards the distribution of European films to other countries, which, in addition to raising the profile of European culture, can also bring about economic growth and increased employment.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on European cinema in the digital age, because I believe that films are cultural and economic goods that make an important contribution to preserving the cultural heritage of the Member States of the Union. The European film industry, although one of the world's largest producers, is nevertheless obliged to move, because of the cultural and linguistic diversity of the continent, into a de facto fragmented market. Promotion, cross-border distribution and accessibility must therefore be ensured, which goes hand in hand with attracting an even larger audience. We must ensure the operation of small and independent cinemas and we must also, through the MEDIA programme, provide sources of funding for Greece for the operation of summer cinemas, which are an important cultural capital for my country.

name: Dominique Martin (NI)
text: In writing. I abstained on this vote. Indeed, this proposal promotes a European culture and identity, while it is up to the Member States to promote their own culture. Moreover, although progress has been made, current legislation still appears to be inadequate with respect to Video on Demand (VOD) services that apply the legislation of the country of origin (where their head office is based) rather than that of the destination country.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ ʽEuropean film in the digital eraʼ aims to support European film-making, and boost its promotion, distribution and visibility so that all Europeans may reap the benefits of their cultural legacy.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the report on European cinema in the digital age. There are many positive contributions from the world of cinema in our lives; It should be stressed that, in any case, there are a number of potential improvements in dissemination and effectiveness. The structure is still heterogeneous today, both in terms of funding and types of production, and one of the aspects that needs a profound and effective improvement is that of diffusion: integrating and promoting European products is certainly a way to give more prominence and promote visibility towards products from non-European competitors, thus reaching a wider audience.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European film industry stands out for its quality and originality. However, in Europe, the potential of the film industry is not yet fully exploited as a means of promoting the Community's cultural heritage.   I welcomed the Wenta report, which urges film producers to finance subtitled works, because I believe that a more rational cross-border circulation of European cinematographic works would help to increase the degree of cultural awareness on the part of our citizens.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 I support the report on European cinema in the digital age, which we have discussed and voted on in plenary, in order to support European films and promote their promotion, distribution and visibility so that all Europeans can reap the benefits of their cultural legacy. It has been shown that 2014 has been the most prominent year in terms of the number of films distributed in Europe, about 1,500, a figure that doubles that of American films. However, the number of spectators of European films has turned out to be inversely proportional to the previous one. This means that we must improve to make European cinema, whose quality is indisputable, increasingly appreciated by viewers.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. The report on European film in the digital age is worthy of support, as film plays an important role in society as a cultural and economic asset, contributes to economic growth, creates new jobs and promotes innovation in Europe's digital market. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Emma McClarkin (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The ECR Group supports much of the content in this report, such as the recognition of the importance of rights holders and improving access to digital content. However we are cautious of raising the issue of VAT into this particular text, in terms of offering the same reduced VAT rates for online and offline content. While we may have sympathy with this idea in certain circumstances, this forms part of a much wider debate that must be duly considered – we support a legal framework that encourages entrepreneurship in the digital environment, but need to consider and understand the direct effects on digital goods which are easier to source across borders. We also disagree with the notion that those organisations benefiting from European Film should by default reinvest the proceeds into the making of European Films. If they generate profit on the film rights they have legally obtained, then how they distribute this revenue is their decision.  The ECR Group supported this report but we wish to put on record our reservations regarding certain issues contained within it, such as those outlined above.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. 1,500 European films were shown in 2014 in our cinemas, twice as many as American films. But the number of spectators is inversely proportional.  One can, as the report proposes to improve the marketing and promotion of European films, in particular by increasing public funds, but, to copy the United States too much, the risk is to weaken the SMEs of distribution in favor of a few behemoths that will make law. As part of the economic boom in video-on-demand, the report nevertheless asks providers such as Netflix, which set up their headquarters in countries with less restrictive regulations, to contribute financially to the European film industry. It also calls for improving the digitization of films as only 1.5% of this heritage is currently digitized. The report also calls for European harmonisation, including on European VAT on these goods, with a view to revising the Audiovisual Media Services Directive, without specifying on what basis. From the top? or from the bottom? I am not convinced by these tinkered proposals. I abstain.

name: Joëlle Mélin (NI)
text: In writing. Some provisions consist of simple adaptations to technological change such as the digitization of cinemas, distribution or accessibility and visibility of films. However, other elements do not correspond to the national interest in cultural matters as the National Front wishes. While the VAT rule has been revised (destination country applies) but this is still not the case for audiovisual creation. Current legislation allows VOD services to apply the legislation of the country of origin of the service and not that of the destination country. We can take the example of Netflix: the headquarters is in the Netherlands and therefore escapes the obligation to contribute to the financing of creation in France. I abstained.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I welcome the Commission’s initiative to establish a European Film Forum which would lead to a structured dialogue with all stakeholders in the audiovisual sector. The report also notes the important role that Parliament’s LUX Prize plays in promoting European cinema. It is important that we continue to do our utmost to continue supporting the audiovisual sector. I also support the rapporteur’s suggestion that Member States take steps to improve media literacy, and in particular film literacy, in school curricula and institutions of cultural education.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. Unlike the American film industry, European cinema is currently characterized by a heterogeneous structure in terms of both financing arrangements and production types. As a result, distribution is largely limited to the country of origin, but, above all, it complicates promotion outside the European Union.  However, the film sector has a direct impact on the European cultural landscape, as well as on employment and economic growth. I therefore welcome this report, which underlines the importance of boosting the circulation of European cinema and making full use of its cultural and economic potential.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European film industry is one of the world's largest producers with 1,500 films put up for distribution in the last year. Despite their artistic quality and originality, European films have a relatively low audience, resulting from poor European marketing in a market that is highly fragmented due to national preferences and language barriers, and at the same time from strong international competition, particularly from the United States.  Targeted efforts must therefore be focused on improving the Pan-European promotion of films from individual Member States and on overcoming distribution difficulties in Europe. I believe that the circulation of international European films in the EU is woefully low, and of the thousands of films produced, only a very weak fragment will reach the viewer. We should therefore learn from the effective techniques of non-European production, which is widely distributed in the Union, so that European audiences can be enriched by the diversity of European films and therefore of European culture as a whole. Finally, I consider it necessary to extend legal access to audiovisual works in the digital world today.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report on the European Film industry in the digital era. Potential of the cultural and creative sectors in Europe and in particular of the European film industry is yet to be fully exploited in the promotion of European cultural and linguistic diversity and heritage within and outside Europe, as well as the creation of growth and jobs that can also benefit other sectors of the economy, providing Europe with a competitive advantage at a global level.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. The European film industry is one of the world's largest producers, having released more than 1,500 films last year. It is also common knowledge that European films are characterised by their quality, originality and diversity but face limitations in promotion and distribution in the European Union. I support this report which calls on the Union to promote, distribute and facilitate access to European film productions, and the digital single market should contribute decisively to this incremental improvement. I also believe that the Creative Europe Programme, with a budget allocation of EUR 1.5 billion by 2020, should be of fundamental importance in the further production and dissemination of European cinematography.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. The Wanta report relates to the evolution of cinema in Europe. It focuses on the process of digitising cinemas, distribution, accessibility and visibility of films, as well as funding methods, programmes to support the audiovisual sector (Creative Europe), film education and media, instruments for the promotion and distribution of European films (such as the LUX Prize). The amendment of the SMA (Audiovisual Media Services) directive repealing the 1989 TSF Directive, in view of the ongoing changes in the audiovisual media landscape, is also under consideration.  This report only superficially addresses issues relating to taxation or audiovisual media and promotes an almost uniform European culture and identity (through the LUX Prize), whereas I believe that Member States need to promote national cultures more. Another criticism is that the current legislation allows VOD services to apply the legislation of the country of origin of the service and not that of the destination country (e.g. Netflix).  I therefore abstained in the vote on this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ European cinema is at the heart of the cultural development of the EU and touches directly upon the identity of European citizens. The economic weight of the European film industry is also significant. To make full use of its cultural and economic potential, the European film industry needs to thrive in the right environment, spurred on by a stable and adaptable legal framework which encourages investment and diversity, and allows new services to develop online. I voted in favour of this report as I believe it sets up a good foundation to achieve the above.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on European cinema in the digital age. The text takes stock of the situation of the European film sector in the digital age in order to identify its strengths and weaknesses. While 1,500 European films were released in 2014, the report makes several proposals to strengthen the competitiveness of European cinema (optimization of public funding, adoption of incentives) and broaden its audience (strengthening the legal online offer, increasing the availability of subtitled films).

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome this report, which aims to support European cinematographic works and promote their promotion, distribution and visibility so that all citizens can reap the benefits of their cultural heritage.  The challenge facing the audiovisual sector is precisely the need to ensure the true and efficient distribution of European cinematographic works, which will ensure their visibility and reach a wider audience. Unfortunately, we cannot forget that, in Europe, funds devoted to the marketing and promotion of cinematographic works often amount to only 1% of total production costs. Moreover, the majority is then projected almost exclusively in their country of origin. It is therefore necessary to give new impetus and impetus to their distribution and circulation outside Europe, not only for the potential financial gains, but above all for the cultural values that European films express.  We believe that the role played by the 'Creative Europe' programme is fundamental, which, with a budget of EUR 1.5 billion for the period 2014-2020, is certainly an extremely important source of funding for the audiovisual sector. We look for the implementation of new pilot projects to investigate possible alternative funding and crowdsourcing possibilities.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report lays the foundations for increasing not only the production and development of European films, but also their distribution. In fact, despite the FACT that the EU produces more films than the US, the European film industry struggles to export its works (only 8% is distributed outside the EU). In order to help Europe in this challenge, the report emphasises the possibility of using public funding for European cinema for marketing purposes as well. As the visibility and promotion of European films in the digital world is an essential component in reaching a wider audience, I have decided to support the report as a more balanced distribution of funding between production, promotion and distribution is crucial to achieving the goal.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The promotion of European cultures across borders, but also the facilitation of cultural exchanges, is also done through film. The film, an economic and cultural good, also contributes substantially to the development of the European economy.  I voted for this report because, through its text and the amendments tabled, 'encourages the European film industry to aim to create innovative services, new distribution channels', thus encouraging film distributors to ensure greater visibility and availability of films from all European countries with a view to the widest possible public access to them and to the implicit knowledge of the culture and civilisation of European peoples.

name: Péter Niedermüller (S&D)
text: Writing. – The report takes into account the significant cultural and economic importance of the film in Europe and takes into account, on this basis, the work to be taken by the Member States and the European institutions in order to support the preservation of this prominent role.  The report provides a clear picture of what sectoral strategies and regulations are needed to achieve this goal. I consider it particularly important to propose that Member States pay more attention to the development of 'audiovisual literacy', so that future adults can better navigate the new digital and image-based world and maintain a knowledgeable audience of culture, including cinema, in Europe.  I also welcome the creation of the Creative Europe Guarantee Fund, which allows smaller businesses to successfully participate in the creation of cultural productions, while at the same time supporting the entrecing of the European cultural scene with the involvement of new and new artists.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because European film plays an important role in society as a cultural and economic asset. However, I also believe that the film industry in the Member States contributes to economic growth and promotes the creation of new jobs.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which focuses on promoting the cultural aspect of the film industry. The report respects the diversity of European cinema, suggests increasing public funding for the development, promotion and distribution of films, especially in small towns and less developed regions. It also promotes digitization as a means of preserving heritage; Film festivals; and greater availability of captioning.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal because it deals with greater development, funding, cross-border distribution and also accessibility in European film industry. It also deals with the production and distribution of TV series and the optimisation of the price of cinema tickets.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI)
text: Writing. – The European Parliamentary Group of the Communist Party of Greece voted against the resolution on "European cinema in the digital age", because it includes measures that strengthen the monopolistic enterprises that control the film industry and make the position of small independent creators worse. In order to strengthen the position of European monopolies vis-à-vis American ones, Community funds are provided, such as from the MEDIA programme in the context of Creative Europe, and other facilities relating mainly to the distribution of works, but also to network services for the distribution of audiovisual material (VOD and SVOD services), while it is difficult to produce small independent authors who are called upon to cover its large costs. At the same time, cinema, given its dynamics in shaping social consciousness, is used as a propaganda tool for integrating the popular masses into the objectives of capital. In this direction of ideological manipulation, the introduction of "cinematic and multi-media literacy" contributes to the education in which the way young people perceive the content of audiovisual works is shaped, while at the same time paving the way for the profitability of the cultural industry. Once again, the need to socialise the means of production of culture is confirmed in order to enable both creators and the popular public to "breathe" freely.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. Whereas cinematographic works are both cultural and economic assets and make an important contribution to the European economy in terms of growth and employment, while helping to shape European identities by reflecting cultural and linguistic diversity, promoting European cultures across borders and promoting cultural exchanges and mutual understanding between citizens, and also contributing to the formation and development of critical thinking; Whereas the potential of the cultural and creative sectors in Europe, and in particular of the European film industry, is not yet fully exploited in promoting the diversity and heritage of European culture and in generating sustainable growth and jobs that in turn also benefit other sectors of the economy, giving Europe a competitive advantage at world level; For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Today we rightly refer to today as the media age. The media allows public communication. Taking into account the cultural and economic potential of the audiovisual sector, the European film industry should thrive with a stable and adaptable legal framework that encourages investment and diversity, develops media literacy and allows new services to develop online.  Film culture is also part of the culture. Therefore, film in Europe is not only a product to be earned on, but it is a clear reflection of the identity of one country or the value of one nation. In addition to being fun, the film should also be educational and have its own message. In order for the film to reach the audience, adequate promotion and a place to present is needed, and these places are still cinemas. Therefore, the closure of small and independent cinemas, in particular in small towns and less developed regions, has led to limited access to European cultural resources, heritage and dialogue, and in this context I support the call for the Commission and the Member States to support the equipping of all screens with digital projection and sound technology in order to preserve such cinemas.

name: Florian Philippot (NI)
text: In writing. This report is primarily initially an inventory of practices and data on the film sector in Europe. It is envisaged to amend the SMA (Audiovisual Media Services) Directive, which repeals the 1989 TSF Directive, in order to adapt to the transformations taking place in the audiovisual media landscape. Apart from the fact that the motion for a resolution on the report promotes a European culture and identity (Lux Prize...) while I think it is up to the Member States to promote their national cultures, it remains too partial, especially on taxation or audiovisual media. The VAT rule has indeed been revised (destination country applies) but this is still not the case for audiovisual creation. Current legislation allows VOD services to apply the legislation of the country of origin of the service and not that of the destination country. For example, Netflix is headquartered in the Netherlands and is exempt from the obligation to contribute to the financing of creation in France. So I prefer to abstain.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The potential of cultural and creative sectors in Europe, in particular the European film industry, has yet to be fully exploited by promoting European cultural and linguistic diversity and heritage both inside and outside Europe, as well as creating growth and jobs that can also benefit other sectors of the economy while providing Europe with a competitive advantage globally. I am pleased that the rapporteur recognised this and highlighted in her report why I supported it.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support Romanian MEP Brunon Wenta's report on European film in the digital age. I believe that the problems of uncompetitiveness of European film, limited distribution and promotion, lack of funds and market fragmentation are well recognised. The cultural and creative industries can be an important growth and employment factor, accounting for over 4 per cent of the Union's GDP and having 7 million employees. It is essential to create a stronger financial base for greater production, distribution and circulation of European films in order to be more competitive with the non-European film industry.  The Commission should continue to facilitate access to finance for SMEs in cinema through media sub-programme guarantees and encourage tax relief for audiovisual works. This should take into account better copyright protection, disincentives to piracy and a level playing field for service providers.  New projects such as parliament's "Lux" award for cinema achievements are also important to increase the visibility of European film. The resolution encourages faster digitalisation and media convergence to promote European films outside the EU, safeguard film heritage and more innovation and flexibility. This will also see the European film industry part of juncker's plan to create a European digital market.  As Vice-President of the EP Foreign Affairs Committee, I continuously stress that europe's full cultural heritage needs to be better used as a tool of cultural diplomacy that can strengthen the external activity of the European Union.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am a strong supporter of the dual role that cinema plays in a country, both economically and culturally.   For this reason, a dynamic and up-to-the-time audiovisual sector contributes to economic growth, creates new jobs and acts as a driving force for innovation in the European digital market. The EU must therefore invest in cinema and increase the visibility of European films outside the borders of the country of production and the EU, giving greater impetus to the distribution and circulation of European works outside Europe for a better economic return, but also to convey the cultural values that European films express.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. In an age of globalisation and the standardisation of arts and cultural media, it is important to defend European culture. The European Parliament adopted the Wenta report on the film sector and the new challenges it faces on Tuesday. I support this report and stress the importance of adapting our European sector and making it more competitive at European and international level. European cinema needs to make greater use of new digital means of broadcasting in order to reach a wider European audience.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution on European cinema in the digital age, designed to support the European film industry and encourage its promotion, distribution and visibility, so that all citizens of Europe can reap the benefits of their cultural legacy.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. "Culture shapes the soul of Europe. A film induces a sense of identification like no other media, it is the very reflection of our society, its values, its hopes and its fears." It is perhaps inspired by Wim Wenders that the European Parliament has this lunchtime encouraged the European film industry to continue the development of new business models to improve the distribution of its films. In 2014, Europe produced and distributed nearly 1,500 works in its own market, where the United States did half as well on its territory. Poor promotion and fierce international competition explain why, despite everything, European productions are struggling to cross their national borders. Fast and easy to access, on-demand videos and online files could be an innovative way to make it easier for viewers to access European films. It is essential to continue to develop film education in school curricula, festivals, as well as awards such as the Lux Prize. In 2014, the European Parliament awarded "Ida". This film allowed thousands of citizens to share the extraordinary destiny of this young Polish nun in search of identity.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. Trying to reconcile cinema as a cultural and economical good and monetising the potential of the European film industry is an excellent idea. But this will only be possible with credible investment in the development of innovative services, new business models and distribution channels to improve the availability of European films outside the EU and allow viewers access to an even larger range of films on an increasing number of platforms. It is necessary to invest in the promotion, distribution, digitisation of content and in the creation of a film culture (in connection with schools). Unfortunately, the scant investment made in creating a strong European film industry is to counter this desire. In this regard we still have much to learn from the good business practices that come to us from the USA.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. The European film industry is diverse and creative and has great potential, as it is a successful and inspiring film heritage around the world, and given its capacity for growth and employment generation. However, the industry faces new opportunities and challenges in the face of the digital revolution, which require adaptability to develop innovative services, new business models and better distribution channels to reach new and wider audiences. The Resolution recognizes the impact of illegal use of content on the creative cycle and the rights of creators, and stresses the need to combat these uses, while inviting the development of more quality legal offers and greater awareness, especially of young people, of illegal uses. It also calls on Member States to promote initiatives to facilitate the production, distribution, availability and attractiveness of European films, and believes that the application of reduced VAT rates to cultural audiovisual works can promote the growth of new services and new platforms. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. The report voted today aims to broaden the audience of European films. It emphasizes the need to improve the overall efficiency of existing financing instruments to promote the competitiveness and diversity of the European film sector. Given the cultural and economic potential of the audiovisual sector, the European film industry should evolve within a stable and adaptable legal framework that encourages investment and diversity and allows the development of new online services. The adopted text therefore stresses several points, such as the development of the sector, cross-border promotion and distribution, funding and programmes supporting the audiovisual sector, film and media education, instruments for the production and distribution of European films, etc.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this own-initiative report, following the Commission Communication entitled "The European Film in the Digital Age: a Bridge between Cultural Diversity and Competitiveness", because I agree overall with the political priorities set out therein, on promoting innovation, whether at the level of services, new business models or distribution channels, financing, mechanisms for facilitating the production and distribution of films , tax incentives, audiovisual training and education.  The Commission Communication, which led to this motion for a resolution, presents a strategy to increase the public for European cinema, including by increasing cross-border promotion and distribution, while stressing the need to enhance the effectiveness of existing funding instruments in order to promote the competitiveness and growth of the European film sector and its diversity. I would remind you that Europe has an important cultural heritage (and also heritage and economic) in terms of audiovisual, which is why I share the view that the European film industry must thrive in a stable and comprehensive legal framework that promotes investment, diversity and higher levels of competitiveness for the sector.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Cultural is a very important industry in Europe, which is facing many challenges, both cultural and technological.  Supporting not only the production, but also the promotion and distribution of European film products, as well as supporting our economy will strengthen cultural diversity and mutual knowledge.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. I have chosen to vote in favour of the development and support of Films with European production. The challenge in this area is between European films and American films. In addition to cultural differences, the big difference is in budget, for production but above all for marketing.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report by the European Parliament's Committee on Culture, which takes place in the context of a debate on the promotion of European cinema initiated by a Communication from the Commission. The increased dissemination that American cinema receives, as well as the dilemmas generated for creators by the new modes of distribution, set the framework for the debate. The European Commission's position placed a strong emphasis on promoting a model favourable to the big industry and focused on the co-financing of film production. This Resolution dodges the most controversial points when it comes to the business model. However, it promotes public aid to the distribution and promotion of cinema and promotes the access of all citizens to culture through subtitling, the creation of public archives, etc.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report responds to a Communication from the European Commission entitled 'European cinema in the digital age – building bridges between cultural diversity and competitiveness'. While I reject the approach to the commodivity of culture, I supported this report by Parliament which, unlike the European Commission communication, which emphasizes the competitiveness aspects of the film industry, stresses the importance of the cultural aspect and calls for increased public funding for this sector. I am also convinced of the importance of preserving European cultural heritage by digitizing its cinema, promoting the cultural and linguistic diversity of films. That is why, since Parliament's report improves the European Commission's approach by escaping consumer logic and highlighting the importance of promoting cultural education in non-formal schools and institutions, I have decided to vote in favour of it.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I fully support the report on European cinema in the digital age.  I consider cinematographic works to be valuable cultural assets which could also make an important contribution to the European economy.  In 2014, the number of European films in circulation was 1,500, twice as many as in the United States. However, the number of viewers in cinemas has largely rewarded Us films, which have more resources for commercialization. Europe has ample room for growth in this respect, as funds devoted to the promotion of films often amount to barely 1% of total production costs. I therefore welcome the fact that public funding for European cinema will also be used for marketing purposes.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ S&D MEPs voted in support of the report on European film in the digital era. To make full use of its cultural and economic potential, the European film industry needs to thrive in the right environment, spurred on by a stable and adaptable legal framework which encourages investment and diversity, and allows new services to develop online.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the convention on European film in the digital age, as the aim of this resolution is to promote European film and strengthen its promotion, distribution and visibility so that all Europeans can draw on our common cultural heritage.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. – I supported the report on European cinematography in the digital age, as it aims to promote European film and strengthen its promotion, distribution and visibility so that all Europeans can benefit from their cultural heritage. In 2014, the European film industry produced 1 500 films that became cultural but also economic goods, while at the same time helping to shape European identities by reflecting cultural and linguistic diversity, promoting European cultures across borders and facilitating cultural exchange and mutual understanding among citizens. Currently, 87% of all film screens have already undergone digitisation. Film literacy has a major impact on individuals, especially young people. Watching European films is one of the best ways to get to know the history, traditions and language of Europe's neighbours. This is also why individual Member States should step up their efforts to improve media literacy, and in particular film literacy within school curricula and cultural education institutions.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on European cinema in the digital age, which addresses the challenges and opportunities for the European film industry caused by the rapid pace of technological evolution. A major challenge is in particular distribution, as, although the EU produces more films than the US, most of them are distributed almost exclusively in their home country and only 8% are distributed outside the EU. In order to improve the cross-border availability of more films for European viewers, the resolution encourages European cinema to pursue the development of innovative services, new business models and new distribution channels, while suggesting the possibility of considering the development of cross-border portability of audiovisual services; It also recommends that there should be a greater availability of subtitled works, also in order to increase awareness among viewers of Europe's cultural and linguistic diversity. In order to improve the circulation of European films on both European and international markets, the resolution considers that public funding for production and distribution should be better balanced, in order to increase support for development, promotion and international distribution.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 European films are part of Europe's cultural heritage. They give us a great opportunity to promote cultural diversity and reveal the history and traditions of our neighbours. It is therefore crucial to ensure their better distribution, to increase expenditure on their promotion and advertising and to integrate them into education. Of course, it is a matter of course to incorporate subtitles or ensure dubbing in case we want to break into the world and thus distribute European film abroad. The creation of a digital single market will thus also create the conditions for better promotion of European films in the digital era.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the European Parliament's resolution on European film in the digital age, as films and economic and cultural goods contribute greatly to the growth of the European economy and employment, while helping to shape European identities by reflecting cultural and linguistic diversity, promoting European cultures across borders and facilitating cultural exchange and mutual understanding between citizens, and contributing to the shaping and development of critical thinking.  The European film industry, with 1,500 films released for distribution in 2014, is one of the world's largest film producers and is one of the key objectives of the Digital Single Market to build trust in the internet and improve access to legal audiovisual content, contributing to investment in European films.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on the European film industry. European cinema is vital in allowing the cultural development of the EU, impacts on the identity of European citizens and has a significant economic weight. It is important that legislation such as this is adopted in order to provide a stable and adaptable legal framework to encourage investment and diversity in the film industry.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. - I believe it is of great importance to support the strengthening of the efficiency of existing funding tools in order to achieve better competitiveness and diversity of the European film sector, in particular in the development, promotion and distribution of films.  The European film industry has every predisposition to development, but we must also not ignore the sector's cultural and economic potentials that contribute to the growth of the European economy and employment, while helping to shape European identities by reflecting cultural and linguistic diversity, promoting European cultures across borders and facilitating cultural exchange and mutual understanding among citizens.  They also contribute to the design and development of critical thinking. It is also necessary to define a stable and adaptable legal framework that encourages investment and diversity. Better cross-border availability of European films on European and international markets should be ensured.  The European film industry is a potential for the development of cultural and creative sectors in Europe that would greatly help promote European cultural diversity and heritage, but also most importantly that troubles Croatia and many European countries, would contribute to achieving sustainable growth and job creation, which would benefit other economic sectors and provide Europe with a competitive advantage on a global scale.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the Report on European Film in the Digital Age. Films represent cultural heritage. There is an urgent need to strengthen the European film industry. Promoting quality film production is particularly important for smaller EU Member States, such as Slovenia, with a small number of language speakers. We also need to develop quality funding instruments. In order to better distribute European films on the European and international market, public funding must be more balanced in order to increase support for development, promotion and international distribution.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Today's European Parliament resolution on film in the digital era is particularly important because it emphasises the role of culture in the process of creating a united Europe while putting one part of the cultural sector in the current context. I believe that there remains a need to call for the introduction of new business models and distribution channels which, in this case films, will make them available to as many viewers as possible. Similarly, I believe that work needs to continue to develop the cross-border availability of audiovisual services. In the future debate on territoriality or portability, which we will lead first within the JURI Committee, we need to focus equally strongly on the protection of rightholders and on a balanced solution.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 European cinema is part of european cultural heritage and needs to be modernised and made more competitive in order to broaden its awareness.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text.
