The report on European cinema in the digital age aims to support European cinema and encourage its promotion, distribution and visibility so that all Europeans can benefit from their cultural heritage. The European Parliament's LUX Prize is a perfect example of how European cinema should be promoted. Each year, this award puts films in the spotlight that address issues affecting European public opinion. The ability of cinema to convey cultural values within different cultures makes it the ideal tool for a debate on Europe and its future. In the context of the current economic, political and social crises, which also threaten art, culture and cinema, the LUX Prize offers European creativity a solid springboard.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. I supported the Report on European Film in the Digital Age, as it highlights the need to advance the European film industry by fostering a stable and adaptable legislative framework. I also support efforts to better promote and distribute European films and promote European cultural and linguistic diversity through film production. I also support the need for digitalisation and media convergence, as this can create new opportunities for distributing and promoting European films across borders and greater potential for innovation and flexibility.  I find it extremely useful to encourage local and national investment in film production and a pronounced focus on the importance of the film industry as part of the creative industry in the wider economy. In addition, I consider it clear that copyright must guarantee adequate remuneration for the holders of these rights and recognises the possibility of contributing to the growth and creation of new jobs of places.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report by the European Parliament's Committee on Culture, which takes place in the context of a debate on the promotion of European cinema initiated by a Communication from the Commission. The increased dissemination that American cinema receives, as well as the dilemmas generated for creators by the new modes of distribution, set the framework for the debate. The European Commission's position placed a strong emphasis on promoting a model favourable to the big industry and focused on the co-financing of film production. This Resolution dodges the most controversial points when it comes to the business model. However, it promotes public aid to the distribution and promotion of cinema and promotes the access of all citizens to culture through subtitling, the creation of public archives, etc.

name: Giovanni Toti (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Thanks to today's vote, the European Parliament has given a strong signal in support of the film industry, focusing on a system of support for the distribution and promotion of film products, subtitling, dubbing and co-productions.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Films are a cultural asset that contribute to improving the European economy and strengthen collective identity reflecting the cultural and linguistic diversity in Europe. Promoting films is especially important in those areas where minority languages are spoken or not recognized as official languages in the EU, as in the case of Catalan. I supported this resolution to facilitate the movement of the whole film material which will increase awareness of the cultural and linguistic diversity in Europe and will help to have more respect between cultures.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (NI)
text: In writing. This report focuses on the evolution of cinema in Europe and mainly on the process of digitising cinemas, the distribution, accessibility and visibility of films, funding and programmes to support the audiovisual sector (Creative Europe), film and media education and instruments for the promotion and distribution of European films. The motion for a resolution on the report promotes a European culture and identity when we believe that it is up to the Member States to promote their national cultures. It also remains too partial, especially on taxation or audiovisual media. I choose the ABSTENTION.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree with the report that creation is a real team effort in the audiovisual sector, as in sport, where all participants contribute to the ultimate success of the team. Promoting European cinema is a common European value. Each EU institution must play its part and its part in this. I think it is very important that, as part of the cultural heritage, we must also support the digitisation of films. The film has a dual role and cultural and economic value. An audiovisual sector that unites in its diversity contributes to economic growth, the creation of new jobs and encourages innovation in the European digital market. I therefore supported the adoption of this report.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report by the European Parliament's Committee on Culture, which takes place in the context of a debate on the promotion of European cinema initiated by a Communication from the Commission. The increased dissemination that American cinema receives, as well as the dilemmas generated for creators by the new modes of distribution, set the framework for the debate. The European Commission's position placed a strong emphasis on promoting a model favourable to the big industry and focused on the co-financing of film production. This Resolution dodges the most controversial points when it comes to the business model. However, it promotes public aid to the distribution and promotion of cinema and promotes the access of all citizens to culture through subtitling, the creation of public archives, etc.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. We are talking about a report that has as its main objective the promotion of European cinema in the digital age. Any action prepared to promote European cinema and culture must be welcomed and approved in this Parliament.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report responds to a Communication from the European Commission entitled 'European cinema in the digital age – building bridges between cultural diversity and competitiveness'. While I reject the approach to the commodivity of culture, I supported this report by Parliament which, unlike the European Commission communication, which emphasizes the competitiveness aspects of the film industry, stresses the importance of the cultural aspect and calls for increased public funding for this sector. I am also convinced of the importance of preserving European cultural heritage by digitizing its cinema, promoting the cultural and linguistic diversity of films. That is why, since Parliament's report improves the European Commission's approach by escaping consumer logic and highlighting the importance of promoting cultural education in non-formal schools and institutions, I have decided to vote in favour of it.

name: n/a
text: in writing. This report advocates a shift in the way european cinema is promoting to take account of the "good examples" of the American and Canadian film industry, i.e. an approach that is too market-focused and little for people, to the role of entertainment without taking into account the social, cultural and educational role that cinema should also play.  An example is set after an example where production is getting smaller and smaller, but distribution and promotion is done in bulk, with more films being produced in Europe but only 32% are distributed and promoted in all EU countries. Some concerns and proposals that we certainly follow are reflected, such as ensuring the promotion of cultural differences, facilitating the promotion of cultural exchanges and critical thinking, supporting and promoting national cultural policies, increasing public funding for greater distribution and better promotion of European cinema, support for subtitling in all EU languages in order to preserve not only cultural aspects , but also for improving access to all people, including those with hearing impairments.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. The report on European film in the digital age is worthy of support, as film plays an important role in society as a cultural and economic asset, contributes to economic growth, creates new jobs and promotes innovation in Europe's digital market. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the situation of the film industry in the digital age because I believe that this is a strategic sector from which to restart the entire cultural industry of the continent.  Furthermore, I believe that our political direction must be supported precisely because this industry develops all the innovative strategies to meet the challenge with much larger film industries such as the United States. Both because of the traditional role that these industries have in the cultural life of individual Member States (think of the importance in the history of Italian neorealism, the nouvelle vague French and German expressionism, for example), and to take the challenge to a later level by networking and promoting the creation of strong infrastructures for the near future.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ European cinema is at the heart of the cultural development of the EU and touches directly upon the identity of European citizens. The economic weight of the European film industry is also significant. To make full use of its cultural and economic potential, the European film industry needs to thrive in the right environment, spurred on by a stable and adaptable legal framework which encourages investment and diversity, and allows new services to develop online. I voted in favour of this report as I believe it sets up a good foundation to achieve the above.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – Cinema, part of European culture and civilisation, enjoys SUPPORT from the EU. Every year, the EU allocates EUR 2.1 billion in European funds for cinema to support the European audiovisual industry. In this context, I voted for the Report on European film in the digital age. I welcome the adoption of colleague Bogdan Wenta's report, agreeing with him that, in order to make full use of its cultural and economic potential, the European film industry must develop in an appropriate environment, stimulated by a stable and adaptable legal framework that encourages investment and diversity and allows the online development of new services.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this initiative, both at the plenary session of the European Parliament and at the meeting of the Committee on Culture and Education of which I am a regular member. This report deals in depth with the multifaceted dimension of cinema, as part of the European cultural heritage but also as an important sector of the European economy. The creative industry can be an important driver of growth and employment in times of crisis, and according to relevant data, the film industry has not been sufficiently exploited, despite its dynamics as an industry. I believe that the text satisfactorily covers the multifaceted contribution of cinema to the lives of citizens because it promotes its exploitation as a cultural and social good and as an efficient product, and because it enhances accessibility across borders across Europe.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI)
text: Writing. – The European Parliamentary Group of the Communist Party of Greece voted against the resolution on "European cinema in the digital age", because it includes measures that strengthen the monopolistic enterprises that control the film industry and make the position of small independent creators worse. In order to strengthen the position of European monopolies vis-à-vis American ones, Community funds are provided, such as from the MEDIA programme in the context of Creative Europe and other facilities relating mainly to the field of distribution of works and network services for the distribution of audiovisual material (VOD and SVOD services). At the same time, of course, production conditions are difficult for small independent creators because of the high costs they have to cover. Given its ability to shape social consciousness, cinema is used at the same time as a propaganda tool to subjugate the masses to the objectives of capital. In this direction of ideological manipulation, the introduction of "cinematic and multi-media literacy" contributes to the education in which young people perceive the content of audiovisual works and at the same time lay the ground for the profitability of the cultural industry. Once again, the need to socialise the means of production of culture is confirmed, because that is the only way for creators and the popular public to "breathe" freely.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In my opinion, film literacy has a very significant impact on individuals, and I am not afraid to say that film shapes who we are like no other medium. I can say with certainty that watching European films is one way to get acquainted with the history, culture, traditions and languages of Europe's neighbours. I am therefore clearly in line for more balanced public funding to strengthen support for activities such as project development, promotion and international distribution.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report appears at a time when fewer and fewer film promotion festivals are supported, as is the case with some of the oldest Portuguese festivals, such as Festroia.   Advocating a turning point in the way european cinema is promoting, the report argues that the "good examples" come from the American and Canadian film industry, i.e. it supports an approach that is too market-focused and little to people, to the role of entertainment without taking into account the social, cultural and educational role of cinema.  Some concerns and proposals we are certainly accompanying are mentioned, such as ensuring the promotion of cultural differences, facilitating the promotion of cultural exchanges and critical thinking, supporting and promoting national cultural policies, increasing public funding for greater distribution and better promotion of European cinema, and supporting subtitling in all EU languages.  However, we do not agree with the perspective that directs Creative Europe funds only to the distribution and promotion of films, since in several countries, including Portugal, producers are experiencing serious difficulties. We agree that distribution is also supported, but only for those who do not have the means, and not the major distributors.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted for the report on European film in the digital age of the rapporteur Bogdan Wenta because European films are of good quality and represent an economic and cultural asset that contributes to the growth of the economy and employment, helps shape European identity, promotes European culture outside the EU, promotes cultural exchange and mutual understanding among citizens, and contributes to the design and development of critical thinking. Nevertheless, non-European films are distributed on a much larger scale in the EU than European ones. Due to strong international competition and fragmentation of the European film market, the promotion and distribution of European films in the EU is limited, audience levels are relatively low and export problems are also difficult for exports outside the EU. I voted in favour of the report because it supports initiatives that will help to exploit the untapped potential of European films, such as the recently adopted preparatory action for the mass subtitling of European works. This would improve the cross-border accessibility of European films in the EU and beyond, and viewers would have access to a growing range of films across the Union on an ever-increasing range of platforms. I am pleased that my supplement has also been included in the report, which underlined the importance of promoting quality film production in particular for smaller EU Member States with a small number of language speakers, such as Slovenia.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE).
text: – I congratulate my colleague Elisabeth Köstinger on her excellent report and also on ing this report, which I was happy to support. Forestry, woodworking are very important industries, especially in such lands, where we have a large proportion of the area covered by forests. Slovenia belongs to a group of countries, the three countries with the highest forestedness, over 60 percent. More than 3.5 million jobs in the forestry sector are created. Forestry and wood is also one of the key renewable sources and contributes to the sustainable development of the Republic... europe as a whole. It is also important that, in addition to forestry, the strategy also highlights the environmental note and also the importance of woodworking as building materials, as well as wood as material used in construction, industry and creating a whole range of new jobs.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I originally intended to support this strategy. In the end, I did not support the strategy, I abstained because the amendments of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Safety have passed. In my opinion, these proposals, as well as those of experts from the Czech Republic, strongly favour the environmental element of forest protection over the interests of owners, who must be able to make some use of the forest and must therefore have some economic viability. I did not support this element. In the Czech Republic, for example, the Association of owners of municipal and private forests in the Czech Republic, with whom I consulted professionally. In my opinion, we must find a compromise between the protection of the forest and the interests of the owner who takes care of the forest and also has to live from the forest. Only balanced interests can sustain the strategic development of the forest area in the long term.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D).
text: - Mr. President, although not responsible for developing a common forestry policy, certain European Union policies may have an impact on national forestry policies. Wood is a renewable resource, but often inadequately exploited, so intelligent and sustainable use of this raw material needs to be ensured. I think the new forest strategy should also strongly emphasise their conservation.  Examples from Croatia show that the theft of forests, the devastation of paths built over decades and the like are the result of a vague division of competences. Authorities often do not respond to warnings under the pretext of outdated cadastral plans or assistance to the disadvantaged while real business is developing in the meantime. We often say that someone "does not see the forest of trees". Today it's worth more that "we don't see the forest for profit." The European Union's new forest strategy must not have only an agricultural dimension. Forests are far more important; they are the lungs of Europe, a source of energy, a guardian of climate and biodiversity, and we should respect them according to their importance. Because unfortunately, it's much easier to create a desert than a forest.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, the European Union's forestry strategy must focus on sustainable forest management, with the main objective of protecting the environment, especially at a critical stage marked by climate change. In this context, the risks of forest fires must be reduced, especially in view of the advent of the summer season. That is why the European Union must financially support Greece and the other States of the European Union in tackling forest fires. Mr President, forests and forestry not only ensure good quality of life but contribute to economic growth, job creation and added value. But the economic exploitation of forests, if we really want to aim for sustainability, must be carried out in such a way that we have long-term planning, strengthen the principle of sustainability, apply new technologies and respect the limits of sustainable supply. This is not provided for in the report and that is why I abstained.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D).
text: – Dear Mr President, the forest fund is a source of woody and non-woody raw materials such as herbs, berries and mushrooms. These resources serve as a raw material for the food, pharmaceutical and cosmetic industries. The sustainable collection and full use of these non-wood raw materials are an opportunity to tackle acute problems such as high unemployment, depopulation and an ageing population reaching critical levels – especially in rural and mountainous areas – throughout the European Union. I therefore call on the European Commission and the Member States to make efforts to develop a strategy for the sustainable development of this potential. I strongly believe that the European Commission must also draw up a European strategy for medicinal plants that will help to find a more coordinated Community and European approach to the use of this hidden forest potential.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: – Mr. President, the economic use of forests must always be directed towards the sustainability of forests and forest space, in order to preserve their quality and economic potential for future generations. Forests can be a generator of the green economy in rural areas, they are a source of timber and a source of renewable energy.  Forests are also an important element in the fight against kilmatic changes, and it is this contribution of forests, although known to everyone, that has not been adequately valued until now. Forests are equally the richest reservoir of biodiversity, and the ways in which forests are managed have a significant impact on the quality of the environment and ultimately on human health and well-being.  Croatia has a long history of good forest management, and that is why I want the implementation of concrete measures contained in forest management and management plans to remain subject to national regulations. This is what this strategy foresees, and I thank Mrs. Köstinger, who incorporated this proposal into it.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE).
text: Mr. President, the forestry sector employs more than 3 1/2 million people. Given the social, economic and environmental role of forests, it is extremely important to invest in R&D in this sector, sustainably manage forests, promote their multifunctional role and use resources efficiently.  The increasing use of energy sources, wood biomass and the growing need for wood demand even more responsible sustainable forest management. This report raises awareness of the importance of the forestry sector for the European Union, and Croatia with its scientific achievements and expertise, which are based on a long-standing forestry tradition, can greatly contribute to the sustainable development of this industry as a driver of employment, year-on-year growth and the survival of rural areas, which is our goal.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Forests cover more than 40% of the EU's area and are an essential resource for improving quality of life and job creation, particularly in rural areas, while maintaining ecosystems and combating climate change. Amendments were tabled that reflected the need to place criteria for social and environmental improvement above the logic of financial gain, agroforestry activities, biodiversity and the multifunctional nature of forests, the creation of specific support measures to prevent and combat fires that allow early intervention, avoiding soil erosion , and recovery of plant cover. In the end, the vast majority of our amendments were rejected by the committee, although some improvements were made in relation to the initial document, so we abstained in the final vote.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This report deals with the new EU strategy for forests and the forest-based sector. There were a number of positive aspects to this report. However, I abstained on this vote because of environmental concerns, especially in the context of bio-energy. Moreover, there was no reflection in the report of concerns in relation to biodiversity problems, the multifunctional nature of forests, the creation of specific support measures to prevent and fight fires enabling early intervention or avoiding soil erosion and the recovery of vegetation cover. For these reasons I abstained in the vote.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. I support the Kostinger report. In the absence of a common forestry policy, the forestry strategy allows for coordination and coherence of European and national policies that are linked to forestry. Through its guidance and recommendations to Member States, this strategy enables the sustainable development and management of The European forest resource, which is often poorly exploited and under-exploited and potentially rich in growth and jobs. It is an important lever for biodiversity and in the fight against global warming. I am delighted to find one of my amendments in this report, calling on the Commission to analyse the difficulties of supplying logs downstream from the sector and to help this sector. Indeed, in recent years, exports of unprocessed logs to third countries, such as China, to be converted into furniture then resold in the European Union were problematic: in the absence of market regulation, many European primary processors found themselves deprived of supply and faced with higher prices for the raw material they need to run their businesses. , putting them in difficulty, with the known consequences for employment in rural areas.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. Sustainable forest management and a functioning and balanced ecosystem guarantee us and future generations quality of life, sustainability, jobs and lasting added value. I therefore welcome the measures under the new EU forestry strategy, in particular to strengthen cooperation between the individual Member States without having to interfere too much with national sovereignty.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. This text promotes a new strategy for forests. Under the principle of subsidiarity, it is not for the European Union to legislate in this area, as the ENVI Committee admitted in its opinion, although it asked the Commission "to assume its leadership role in promoting a sustainable forestry policy". This new strategy ignores concrete measures since, although the "environmental value" is often stressed, nothing is proposed in this area. In this case, the French wood sector is doing well, although it would benefit from better governance at the national level: again, the Community level is inadequate.  Protectionist measures would nevertheless be a means of protecting French and European timber, but, of course, such a policy is unthinkable by the Commission. So I voted against it.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because it embodies a subtle mix between the environmental and economic vocation of European forests.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Union is the only part of the world where forest area has been steadily growing for the last two decades. Over 40% of the EU territory is covered by forests and wooded lands. Our daily lives are affected by it in many different ways, both in rural and highly urbanised areas. Apart of wood, which is certainly the most common type of energy resource extracted from forests, forest products and by-products are also used in the manufacturing process of medicine, cosmetics and detergents. What the EU needs now is an effective and sustainable forest management system that would be able to address efficiently the challenges that forest-related industries are currently facing. It is essential to boost the potential of our forests and encourage rural development, innovation in forest based industries, and resilience to climate change. But even though it is crucial to have an active forest management, we must not forget that due to different types of forests and forest ownership, legally binding rules would restrict forest product-related markets. I believe that the Köstinger report underlines all these issues and I am in favour of it for exactly this reason.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to evaluate and improve the new EU forest strategy. The EU forestry sector has created 3.5 million tonnes of aid. Jobs. 451 820 forest-related enterprises are boosting economic growth by 7%, while only 60% of the forests that are growing each year are harvested. This proposal further strengthens the societal, economic and ecological role of the forest and forestry sector and focuses on sustainable timber raw materials as an important Resource for Europe. I agree with the proposals made that the new EU Forest Strategy must focus on better coordination, that forestry and forests are more emphasised in individual European strategy papers and that a more coherent approach can be achieved. This diverging approach in the Commission could be avoided by strengthening the Standing Forestry Committee. However, it is important to bear in mind that forest owners and foresters cannot be burdened with a higher bureaucratic burden.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. This report is characterised by the desire to increase the EU's role at the expense of member states and welcomes the Commission's desire to strengthen its power over forestry. This "new strategy" does not take into account the trade problems related to the abuses of certain third countries, in particular with regard to the export of logs to China and the re-shipment of processed products from that country to the EU, to the detriment of the timber sector in the member countries. So I voted against it.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The forestry sector is crucial to the well-being of the European economy. Indeed, with 3.5 million jobs, the forestry sector is the third largest sector in terms of employment in the European Union, just after metallurgy and the food industry. In a context where a growing number of policies (energy, environment, climate, etc.) influence the management of our forests, it is essential to adopt a new European strategy for forests in order to ensure coherence and coordination between the different actions. This strategy will provide a comprehensive view of actions in the field of European forestry. It is therefore for the sake of coherence and protection of our natural heritage that I voted in favour of this report.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: in writing. The European forestry strategy highlights the importance of forests and forestry not only from an environmental point of view but also from an economic and social point of view. It also proposes improving the coordination of the different European policies involved (energy, research and development, employment, climate, etc.), so as to promote the creation of a more coherent approach. That is why we have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. This resolution, which first recalls the autonomy of the Member States and their legitimacy to carry out their forestry policy, indicates, secondly, that the implementation of the European Union's forestry policy should take several years and be coordinated and that Parliament's opinion should be taken into account. The report also places too much emphasis on the environmental value of the forest at the expense of its economic value, as it ignores proposals to defend the sector, including the problem of exporting raw wood abroad and the importation of higher value-added processed products. This problem is particularly present in Lorraine in particular.  Similarly, the report makes no mention of proposals for protectionism in the face of China's unfair competition in the sector. The ecological impact of these back-trips should also be questioned, since it contradicts the environmental value and the desire to reduce greenhouse gases. So I voted against this report.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this measure. Noting that today, forest support and the development of disadvantaged areas are poorly pursued by the EU, the path contained in the text could be useful for reviving the sector.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. In September 2013, the European Commission Communication entitled 'Forest and forestry support: a new approach to a new EU forestry strategy', which reviews and updates the 1998 forestry strategy, was published.  The European forestry strategy aims at 2020, interless, for forest management to be carried out in accordance with sustainability principles and to reduce the deforested or degraded area, the setting out a number of priority areas of action, such as coordination and communication on forest-related issues, forest sector support for rural and urban society , improving the competitiveness of forest-generated goods and services, the relationship between forest areas and climate change or the development of innovative initiatives in the sector. The Resolution on a new EU strategy for forests and the forestry sector is committed to a new strategy focused on coordination, so that forestry and forests better fit the different European policies (energy, environmental and climate protection, and R&D) and a more coherent approach can be defined, calling for the strengthening of the Standing Forestry Committee. That's why I voted for it.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it presents the European Parliament with a position that should further strengthen the societal, economic and environmental role of the forest and forestry sector and focus on sustainable timber raw materials as an important resource for Europe. The report notes that forests and forestry are a good pillar of the economy and, consequently, the best guarantee of quality of life, sustainability, jobs and added value. For the forestry sector, which has created more than 3.5 million people, the forestry sector is a 10-year-2013 member state. employment in Europe, immediately after the metal and food industries. Wood is an important resource; its economic importance for rural areas is significant. Forestry enterprises and more than 16 million tonnes of forest aid. Forest owners shall ensure a sustainable ecological, economic and social function in the closely maintained and management of European forests.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The report on the new EU Forest Strategy has caused divisions and significantly different opinions among political groups from the outset in policy committees. This applies in particular to the decision of the rapporteur on the AGRI committee to disregard the opinion of the environment committee.  I could not support the document in the form in which it came to the vote in plenary, but thanks to the amendments of the S&D group, the text was last minute changed and improved. Thanks to this, the strategy will have a holistic approach with more emphasis on sustainability and smart resource use, which I can certainly support.  Nevertheless, I must express reservations about the part of the text relating to the habitats directive, i.e. its unnecessaryness.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (NI)
text: In writing. The European Union is one of the largest exporters and consumers of wood products in the world. In September 2013, the European Commission presented a renewed strategy for wood, which is supposed to "improve the coherence of forest measures and enable synergies with other sectors related to forest management". I voted against this text which strengthens the competence of Brussels to the detriment of France and which does not take into account the trade problems linked to the abuses of certain third countries, in particular China.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This report deals with the new EU strategy for forests and the forest-based sector. There were a number of positive aspects to this report. However, I abstained on this vote because of environmental concerns, especially in the context of bio-energy. Moreover, there was no reflection in the report of concerns in relation to biodiversity problems, the multifunctional nature of forests, the creation of specific support measures to prevent and fight fires enabling early intervention or avoiding soil erosion and the recovery of vegetation cover. For these reasons I abstained in the vote.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on a new strategy of the European Union for the forestry sector since sustainable development of our forests is very important, not only on an environmental level but also on the socioeconomic one.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 When we talk about forests there are many aspects that can be talked about: economic, environmental, social, village, cultural, energy, tourism... It is important for Europe to bring all these aspects together with a comprehensive strategy focused on sustainability.  Forests play a fundamental role not only in protecting the environment and protecting biodiversity, but also in supporting the economy of rural communities and mountain territories. The conditions must be created for an exchange of good practice at European level. The management of forests, in fact, can become a factor in combating the abandonment of the hinterland. Public and private owners must be encouraged to manage the forest heritage with a participating approach, stimulating integrated and sustainable management and promoting the opportunities that the forest can offer. For example, new jobs can be created by expanding the market for forest products or by identifying innovative forms of wood enhancement.  Finally, looking beyond our borders, I would like to stress the importance of the amendment calling on the Commission to develop an action plan to combat deforestation in the tropics.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. Forestry policy is the sovereign responsibility of the Member States. Yet the European Commission is seeking control of forestry. Moreover, the text focuses exclusively on the environmental value of forests and abandons economic value. And for good reason, the motion for a resolution does not address the problem of exporting raw wood abroad and re-importing processed products with higher added value. Moreover, nothing is proposed regarding the necessary protection at European level against China's aggressive practices and no reflection is being carried out on the carbon impact of these exports and re-imports. However, it is this priority that would justify better coordination of forestry policies at European level. I voted against it.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the new EU strategy on forests and forestry because I believe that forests and forestry are a good solution for an additional economic pillar and are also the best guarantors of quality of life, sustainability, jobs and value generation. With more than 3.5 million jobs, the forestry sector ranks third in Terms of Employment at European level, immediately below the metallurgical and food industries. More than 451,820 forestry companies contribute 7% to economic growth and use only 60% of the wood that can be used annually. Wood is an important resource with a major economic role for rural areas. The EU strategy aims to further strengthen the social, economic and ecological role of forests and the forestry sector and to bring wood to the fore as a sustainable raw material, considered an important resource for Europe.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour. The measure also calls for a Community framework for a forest management strategy, and the text emphasises the exclusive competence of the Member States, stressing the importance of national and, above all, local logic with regard to their use.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the new European strategy for forests and the forestry sector. It is undeniable that we need a European strategy in this area for all aspects of security and the environment. We do need some coherence between the European Union and the Member States in the forestry sector. However, forest and forestry policies must remain national jurisdiction, in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the eu's new forestry strategy, which must focus on sustainable forest management, promoting the efficient use of their raw materials, increasing the competitiveness of the forestry industry. I think it is essential to increase the use of sustainable materials such as wood, one of the EU's key raw materials, not only to protect the environment, but also to increase employment. I believe that the new EU forest strategy is a long-awaited response to significant social and political changes that have affected forests over the last fifteen years. This proposal makes it possible to tackle many cross-border problems through a joint strategy: forest fires, climate change, natural disasters and invasive alien species.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This report deals with the new EU strategy for forests and the forest-based sector. There were a number of positive aspects to this report. However, I abstained on this vote because of environmental concerns, especially in the context of bio-energy. Moreover, there was no reflection in the report of concerns in relation to biodiversity problems, the multifunctional nature of forests, the creation of specific support measures to prevent and fight fires enabling early intervention or avoiding soil erosion and the recovery of vegetation cover. For these reasons I abstained in the vote.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Following tough discussions at EU committee level a compromise text has been presented underscoring the need for the strategy to focus on the sustainable management of forests and their multifunctional role from an economic, social and environmental point of view. It strongly rejects direct EU competence for forestry, but calls for coherence between the roles of the EU and the Member States in forestry-related policies. It acknowledges that the EU has a role to play in strengthening cooperation to tackle transnational challenges such as fires, climate change, natural disasters or invasive alien species. Finally, the report states that the implementation of the measures contained in forest management plans at the forest holding level must remain subject to national regulations and that bureaucratic burdens for EU forest owners are rejected. I can fully concur with this report and voted in favour.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 A positive strategy, which involves the protection of biodiversity, the use of natural resources and which protects the environment and our forests, thus combating hydrogeological failure and climate change. Forests must and will be at the heart of the environmental issue, thanks to them, over time, it will be possible to guarantee not only energy but also employment.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this report, which shows once again the inconsistency and even dishonesty of the European institutions when it comes to respecting the competence of Member States. Indeed, if the rapporteur starts by recognising the prerogative of The Member States in the field of forest policy, there is a desire to give the Commission more weight in this area. Moreover, even on the substance of the report the proposals lack coherence. On the one hand it is argued that the primary objective lies in the environmental aspect, on the other hand we refuse to question the measures that could be taken to curb the massive import of Chinese products, especially wood, while these imports are blowing the environmental cost! In this logic, nothing is proposed to protect our companies from this Asian competition, not even at European level.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This measure draws attention to the forestry and wood sector as a sustainable raw material and resource for Europe.  With more than 3.5 million people employed, the forestry sector is the third largest sector of employment in Europe, just behind metallurgical and food sectors. The more than 450 000 companies in the sector contribute 7% to economic growth, reducing only 60% of annual forest growth. Since many EU policies, such as energy, environmental and climate policies, also affect forest management, it is important that the european Union's new forestry strategy is designed to improve the coordination of individual policies and avoid imposing bureaucratic obstacles on forest owners – more than 50% of Europe's forest heritage is privately owned – and on foresters. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it aims to further strengthen the economic and ecological role of forests and the forestry sector and to draw attention to wood as a sustainable raw material and an important resource for Europe. I believe that we must ensure that the woody resources and materials of forests are used efficiently, both as a source of reducing the EU's trade deficit, by improving the EU's self-sufficiency in timber and by relaunching the competitiveness of the forestry sector, and as a contribution to reducing unsustainable forest management, preserving the environment and reducing deforestation in third countries. Bearing in mind that, although this is a matter for the Member States, there are advantages that the forestry sector can obtain through better and more active coordination and a higher positioning of this important economic sector, which provides jobs at European level, particularly in rural areas, while protecting ecosystems and offering ecological benefits for all , without prejudice to the competence of the Member States.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of the report on the new forestry strategy for the European Union, which builds on the communication sent by the Commission and the accompanying working documents. I believe, in fact, that the sustainable management of forests and the awareness of their multifunctional role from an economic, social and environmental point of view are of primary importance. I particularly welcome the desire to improve the coordination of national policies directly or indirectly linked to the forestry economy, while respecting the competence of the Member States in this area.  I believe that the development of forests, as a source of wealth, is also functional to the preservation of jobs in rural areas and therefore useful in preventing the depopulation of these areas. I also believe that a society based on the bioeconomy also benefits human health, environmental and climate protection and that the preservation of forests and their care are an essential prerequisite for its implementation. Finally, I welcome the intention to ensure that wood resources and materials from forests are used and reused efficiently in order to reduce the EU's trade deficit by improving its self-sufficiency in timber and by reviving the competitiveness of the forestry sector.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Forests are a valuable asset, serving economic, social and environmental purposes. Forests and wooded land cover over 40% of European Union territory, and represent 5% of the world’s forests. The EU is one of the biggest traders and consumers of wood products in the world. The report stresses that the EU forest strategy should focus on sustainable management of forests and their multifunctional roles from an economic, social and environmental point of view. It rejects direct EU competence for forestry but acknowledges that the EU has a role to play in strengthening cooperation to tackles national challenges such as fires, climate change, natural disasters and invasion by alien species. The report calls for the efficient use and reuse of wood but opposes legally-binding rules for prioritising the use of wood. I thus voted in favour.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Forests cover more than 40% of the EU's area and are an essential resource for improving quality of life and job creation, particularly in rural areas, while maintaining ecosystems and combating climate change. Amendments were tabled that reflected the need to place criteria for social and environmental improvement above the logic of financial gain, agroforestry activities, biodiversity and the multifunctional nature of forests, the creation of specific support measures to prevent and combat fires that allow early intervention, avoiding soil erosion , and recovery of plant cover. In the end, the vast majority of our amendments were rejected by the committee, although some improvements were made in relation to the initial document, so we abstained in the final vote.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which touches on all aspects of forestry. I was also satisfied that the ENVI amendments which were tabled directly to plenary were voted in. The report deals with employment in the sector and sustainable use of forest resources. It also addressed the need for people in Europe to better understand the importance of our forests.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the EU's forest strategy must focus on sustainable forest management and their multifunctional role from an economic, social and economic perspective, and must ensure better coordination and communication of European policies aimed directly or indirectly at forestry.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted with conviction in favour of Parliament's resolution on a new EU forestry strategy for forests and forestry. The resolution has the merit of emphasising the importance of ensuring sustainable management of forests that have always been a fundamental element of every ecosystem, source of biodiversity and wealth. The resolution clearly highlights the importance of forest areas not only for rural development, but also for the environment, biodiversity, forestry industries and trade in their derivatives, bioenergy and the fight against climate change. The resolution also stresses the importance of sustainable forest management, which play an important role in achieving the EU's socio-political objectives, such as the energy transition, the fight against global warming and the achievement of the Europe 2020 strategy objectives and those relating to biodiversity.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report aims to establish a clear position of the European Parliament on what the European strategy should be in the forestry sector. The text here voted is balanced. It calls for a holisitic consideration of forest-related issues at European level, while preserving the principle of subsidiarity since forest management plans remain established at the national level to take account of the geographical specificities of each forest area. I therefore voted in favour of this text.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. With this vote, Parliament wanted to focus on forestry, the third largest provider of jobs in Europe after metallurgy and the food industry. The European Union, through its policies on the environment, agriculture or rural development, can have an influence on the forestry sector - hence the need for a European strategy on this issue.  However, I would like to reiterate the importance of the principle of subsidiarity in forest management, as was underlined in the report.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union's new forestry strategy will focus on forest management in a more sustainable way.  Forests have enormous potential for job creation, which is why the new strategy will promote the sustainable use of timber and other forest materials without adding bureaucracy to those working in this sector. I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution because better forest management in Europe will increase rural employment.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. With the vote of the report on a new EU strategy for forests, the forestry sector and the timber industry, the European Parliament calls on Member States to work for sustainable forest management, promote the efficient use of their raw products and increase the competitiveness of the forestry industry, which brings many jobs. Forests play an important role in protecting biodiversity. Member States need to design their forest policy by implementing actions to leverage this lever in the forest-forest sector, particularly in the area of reforestation, improved forest management and the optimised use of products.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report which stresses the importance of sustainable forest management and ensures better coordination and communication of EU policies related to forestry. This report also raises the difficult question of the plundering of European forest resources by emerging countries. It was time for Europe to address this critical issue for the economy of this sector. Indeed, while all the other major countries are introducing export taxes to protect their sector no action was being taken at European level. So I think this report is a step in the right direction for the future of our forests.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D)
text: In writing. I support the Kostinger report. In the absence of a common forestry policy, the forestry strategy in question allows for coordination and coherence of European and national policies that are linked to forestry. Through its guidelines and recommendations to member states it enables the recovery and sustainable management of the European forest resource, which is often poorly exploited and under-exploited and potentially rich in growth and jobs. It is an important lever for biodiversity and in the fight against global warming. I am delighted to find one of my amendments in this report calling on the Commission to analyse the difficulties of supplying logs. In my region Limousin, we are witnessing a real hemorrhage of our logs which are exported to China by traders outside Limousin. Consequences: there has been an increase in the price of raw materials for our first and second processing companies; added value does not remain and does not benefit the territory; the future of some units is threatened in the short term, because they cannot source supplies, with its deadly consequences for local employment.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. We need a new common forestry strategy (the current strategy has been in place since 1998) focused on sustainable management, promoting the use of raw forest products and increasing the competitiveness of the forestry industry. Forests cover about 40% of the EU. 60% are private. The forestry sector employs more than 3 million people. A new strategy is needed to address cross-border challenges such as forest fires, climate change, natural disasters, but also to strengthen forest industries and improve the efficient use of raw materials such as wood and its derivatives. A new strategy will boost the competitiveness of EU logging, improve its wood self-sufficiency, reduce its trade deficit and boost employment in the sector. In addition, as energy demand increases, forests are expected to play a greater role in the EU's future energy mix. There is also a need to finalise the effectiveness of the timber regulation to combat illegal logging and the placement of illegal timber on the EU market. Finally, an action plan should be developed to prevent deforestation and forest degradation.

name: Jørn Dohrmann (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ We certainly need better coordination of our policy for forests because a number of EU policies such as energy, environment and climate have an impact on the management of forests. Forests employ over 3.5 million people in Europe, so they are the third-largest EU employer behind the metal and food industries; better coordination means that a coherent approach between the national strategies should be found. Forests could also become a part of the energy solution. Although a new strategy is welcome we should avoid any centralisation, that is why any attempt to make forestry a matter of EU policy should be resisted: the competence of Member States in this area must be respected. The urbanisation of our society is leading to a gradual loss of knowledge about forests; that is why we should integrate this issue in the classrooms, encouraging closing the gap between towns and forests.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. I decided to vote against this text promoting a new strategy for forests. Firstly, because it is not for the European Union to regulate in this area, as the ENVI Committee admitted in its opinion, although it called on the Commission to "assume its leadership role in promoting a sustainable forestry policy". Moreover, this new strategy does little to consider concrete measures since, although the "environmental value" is often stressed, nothing is proposed in this area. In this case, the French wood sector is doing well, although it is gaining better governance at national level: again, the European Union is inadequate.  Protectionist measures would nevertheless be a means of protecting French and European timber, but, of course, such a policy is unthinkable by the Commission.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the new EU forest strategy.  I also support the main thesis expressed in the report that we urgently need a systematic, planned and new approach to forest sector management.  Furthermore, I would also like to stress that forest policy should be a national priority and there is no need and proper introduction of common European regulation. However, I agree that on some issues that indirectly concern the forest sector, we need common measures at EU level. As such, I would identify investment in the forestry sector, create more jobs and support the sector that can give us greater added value.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour, because I welcome the, albeit belated, reaction and the establishment of a common framework to address the issues and serious problems that threaten Europe's forests.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution setting out the main directions of the EU forest strategy. The directions in it are in the same way as the Hungarian ideas and interests. I am particular pleasure that the report states in the first place that any attempt to bring forestry to Community level is unacceptable to the European Parliament. Hungarian foresters are also asked to respect the local and regional character of the sector and the competences of the Member States. I fully agree with the fact that the EU should support national policies in order to achieve active, multifunctional, sustainable forest management, including management of different types of forest and strengthening cooperation against cross-border challenges such as forest fires, climate change and natural disasters. Forests and forest managers play a prominent role in the life of the countryside, without them the development of the countryside is inconceivable. Forestry should therefore be adequately supported within rural development programmes under the 2014-2020 CAP. The Hungarian rural development programme adequately supports our forest. Finally, it is also thanks to my contribution that the report deals with the prioritising of wood as a sustainable raw material in a separate chapter. I support the resource-efficient use of wood and there should be no legally binding prioritising of wood use.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. European forests represent ecosystems on which essential services for the protection of terrestrial biodiversity and the human species itself depend. Their preservation has a much higher economic value than can result from the use of the wood that can be obtained from it. On the other hand, with more than 3.5 million people employed, the forestry sector is the third largest sector of employment in Europe, accounting for more than 50% of Europe's privately owned forests. In order to combine different, but not necessarily divergent, needs to be combined, it is necessary to ensure that Europe's forests are managed in a conscious and sustainable way in the short, medium and long term. The document on the forestry strategy, with the adoption of a number of amendments improving the original text, lays the foundations precisely so that we can guarantee the prudent management of European forests, which is why I have decided to support the document put to the vote.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union does not have the competence to develop a common forestry policy, but certain Union policies are likely to have an impact on national forestry policies. Wood is a renewable resource that is often underused in Europe and the smart and sustainable use of this raw material must be guaranteed, including through the development and exchange of know-how. The forestry sector currently employs more than three million European citizens and its long-term competitiveness will only be possible with a skilled workforce. Given that many EU policy areas, such as energy, environmental and climate protection policy, influence forest management, I agree that a new EU forestry strategy, focusing on better coordination, is urgently needed so that forestry and forests are better positioned in the different European strategies and a more coherent approach can be found.

name: Edouard Ferrand (NI)
text: In writing. The European Union continues its policy of absolute free trade... but in one sense, to its sole detriment. While Asian countries impose protectionism on their borders, the EU perpetuates its "free trade" policy that is destructive to European jobs. This as well as China sells us wood (processed logs) - imported from Europe - cheaper than our own products. The situation turns absurd. The European Union shows its true face: a machine at the service of all but the peoples of Europe.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The "new strategy" for forests presents some positive aspects, such as the recognition of the multifunctionality of forests. This strategy fails, however, in the non-recognition of the growing conflicts between the various sectors that depend on the forest. Although some of our proposals are reflected in the report, such as the defence of biodiversity, the creation of specific support measures for the prevention of forest fires and pests, the need and function of the forest for the protection of soil erosion and the need to recover much of the plant cover lost by poor and unsustainable forest management , we regret that several other proposals have not been considered. This report is under pressure from large groups linked to timber production and the energy sector.  There is a need for an effective defence of biodiversity, the preservation of ecosystems, the protection of all services provided by the forest and its recovery; clarify the impacts of the various uses of forest biomass for energy production in the greenhouse effect. Forest policies are needed to take into account the importance of forests in protecting biodiversity, preventing soil erosion, carbon fixation, air purification and maintaining the water cycle.

name: Raffaele Fitto (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Köstinger report because it further strengthens the social, economic and ecological role of forests and the forestry sector.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Forestry has always been a very important part of the lives of the people of the European Union living in the countryside. Even today, in the modern era of technology and science, the forestry sector still employs 3.5 million people and is the third largest Pan-European employer. The European Union should pay much greater attention to research and development and invest in the development of new effective production and design opportunities for new products. These investments will also have a very positive impact on the European Union's environmental and climate objectives in the future. The European Union should remove existing barriers for forest managers and not create any new ones, such as the obligation for forest owners to draw up natura 2000 plans. It is very important that the European Convention on Forests be adopted as soon as possible. In order to adopt clear and comprehensible legislation in the future that does not burden forest managers, the Standing Forest Committee needs to be strengthened. The European Commission must work very hard and carefully to maintain quality forestry for future generations.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the proposal because it rightly points out that exclusive competence is the responsibility of the Member States. However, it is also important at European level to promote a forest management strategy as an ecosystem to be protected also in the context of the protection and enhancement of cultural and natural heritage and the promotion of sustainable ecotourism.

name: Eleonora Forenza (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have chosen to abstain from voting on this resolution because, while I agree with the general structure, in particular the focus on the protective role of forests in the prevention of environmental disasters and the recognition of the importance of sustainable forest management and coordination of national policies in this regard, I believe it is essential that we look at forest management with a view to environmental and social protection. , putting these interests above the logic of profit.  Therefore, an appropriate forestry strategy should invest in research in order to make the best use of the potential of forests, to be put at the guarantee of the environment, to improve the training of workers, in order to make the workforce more aware and informed, on the adoption of a protection system for small local producers.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the new EU strategy for forests and the forestry sector, because I welcome the, albeit belated, response and the establishment of a common framework to address the issues and serious problems facing Europe's forests.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the very positive aspects that have been introduced in the report and especially the more holistic approach from the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development on the subject, with more stress on long-term sustainability, resource-efficient use, a multifunctional approach in forest management and future challenges because of wood scarcity and threats from climate change, emphasis on the pan-European forest agreement and an action plan with specific measures and funding. I believe it is important, when dealing with such multidimensional issues, to ensure that we are dealing with them in the most comprehensive way. I appreciate therefore the introduction of very important issues such as employment in the sector and the sustainable use of forest resources. I believe that this report goes in the right direction, by ensuring that people in Europe understand better the importance of their forests and will be able to benefit from them in many ways.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Despite the increasing levels of deforestation worldwide, more than 42% of the EU's territory is covered by forests and biomass (essentially wood) is half of the renewable energy used in the EU. This important resource is protected by the EU's new forestry strategy, which focuses on sustainable use of forests and wooded areas, increasing competitiveness and creating jobs. I voted in favour of this report because I believe it is important to increase recreational activities linked to forest areas in order to improve the quality of life of EU citizens, while at the same time not harming biodiversity, the environment and ecosystems.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. Forests and forestry are an important economic pillar in rural areas of the EU, while ensuring environmental sustainability and employment. There are currently more than 3.5 million jobs in the European forestry sector and more than 50% of European forests are privately owned. This report proposes to contribute to the further development of forests and the forestry sector in their role in the social, economic and environmental fields.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. Mr Köstinger gives us a very important report, which welcomes the Commission communication on a new forestry strategy at European level, stressing that it must focus on the sustainable management of forests and their multifunctional role in economic, social and environmental and energy terms.  This is the most appropriate profile within which to proceed with the development of this sector, which is so strategic for Europe's environmental and cultural heritage.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the new EU forestry strategy for forests and forestry. Forests guarantee a quality life, environmental protection and air quality and represent great added value from an economic point of view. The forestry sector, with more than 3.5 million people in employment, is the third largest sector of employment in Europe and has a threefold ecological, economic and social function. I agree with the importance given to the sustainable management of forests whose resources, such as wood, are fundamental to rural areas and must be managed diligently for conservation for future generations. It is therefore crucial that Member States implement national policies for sustainable forest management in order to respond to daily challenges such as forest fires, climate change, natural disasters and tree diseases.  These policies must look at the many possibilities offered by forests for the development of the green economy, such as the processing of materials for the creation of textile fibres, the bioeconomy, renewable energies and biofuels, supporting research and innovation in the sector.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of Mrs Köstinger's report on 'A new EU forest strategy: for forests and the forest-based sector', because I believe that sustainable management of our forests is an absolute core issue for future generations.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. As an MEP for western Lower Saxony, rural areas are particularly close to my heart. I therefore supported the EU-wide forestry strategy. It aims to make better use of all the potential of the forestry sector; both its achievements for nature and the environment, as well as its economic value to society. The new strategy aims to reconcile the diverse and sometimes contradictory demands on forests from the various EU policy areas such as .B nature conservation, energy, climate protection and the economy. As Christian Democrats, we have spoken out against unnecessary bureaucracy and over-regulation in the legislative process. To this end, I rejected three amendments in plenary which stood in the way of the holistic approach to sustainable forest management. Subsidiary and meaningful management criteria must be the objective. We all benefit from our forests, which, incidentally, occupy 40% of the EU's surface area. They are an important resource for improving the quality of life and creating jobs.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ President, I supported the Köstinger report because it's crucial we tap the full potential of forest management to mitigate climate change and create employment in rural areas, both in actual woodlands and in wood processing facilities, timber transport, as well as research and innovation facilities.  Given that the extensive use of wood opens up new possibilities for employment but also poses challenges in terms of supplying adequately educated and trained workforce, it's vital we now focus on the development of dedicated education and training to familiarize  (future) workers in the sector with new technologies as well as constraints associated with the sustainable use of wood.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: in writing. I am convinced that the European Union must formulate a coherent strategy for forests for a number of reasons.  First of all, for the number of actors involved and the size of the sector. The forestry sector employs more than 3.5 million workers in 450 000 companies. It is therefore vital for rural economies, but also for related urban economies. Secondly, because of the need to safeguard the ecosystem. The presence of "healthy" forests is able to avoid natural disasters such as avalanches, landslides and floods. And finally, because even though more than 50% of forests are privately owned, the presence of forests benefits all citizens.  Forests therefore have an ecological, economic and social function, even if they are less and less well known. The European Union should therefore implement the strategy soon, not to impose new bureaucracy and new obligations, but rather to promote knowledge of forests and to shorten the distance between cities and rural areas.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against the motion for a resolution calling for a new European Union strategy for forests. Firstly, forest management is the responsibility of the Member States, which, given the great diversity of European forests, are the best level of action. A common strategy is not essential.  Economically and ecologically, this strategy, which is not one of them, lacks the main objective: to defend our forests and our wood sector. This sector requires a complete restructuring, in order to have all the wood trades in the Union and especially in France.  We are sorely lacking in transformational actors. We export our logs of noble gasoline to China to then re-import processed products, at the cost of our jobs and an ecological disaster in terms of flow.  Finally, I deeply regret that our forests are seen only as "economic tools" that should be exploited and given market value.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We abstained because, although there have been some improvements from the original wording of the report, the amendments to establish criteria for the social and environmental revaluation of forests in the face of the strictly economic interest were rejected by the committee.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted against the report on the eu's new forestry strategy for forests and the forest and wood sector because I believe that it does not present the concept of sustainable development. The new EU strategy must not only serve the interests of private forest owners, leaving aside state forests. It should be stressed that state forests guarantee the principle of sustainability of forests and their resources by carrying out forest management increasing the area of forests and harvesting wood on a scale not exceeding the biological capacity of the forest. The rapporteur, Mrs Köstinger, did not take into account the important amendments on the m.in. carbon seestration mechanism that I tabled with my colleagues in the Polish delegation in the ECR Group.  As a Member of the European Parliament Polish, where forests are the wealth of all citizens, I cannot agree to such a strategy. That is why I voted against this resolution.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which touches on all aspects of forestry. The report deals with employment in the sector and sustainable use of forest resources. It also addresses the need for people in Europe to better understand the importance of our forests. Indeed, forests are major contributors to our climate-change mitigation efforts. One of the approaches to tackle climate change is to maximise the contribution of our forests which currently deliver a 10% mitigation factor . Management of forests is equally important from the point of view of creating employment in rural areas, both in actual woodlands and in wood processing facilities, timber transport, research and innovation facilities, etc.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. On Tuesday 28 April, I voted in favour of the European Union's new forestry strategy. The economic dimension of Europe's forests has often been underestimated, while they cover 40% of the EU's territory and account for nearly three million jobs. I therefore welcome the Commission's emphasis on sustainable management and the efficient use of forest resources, as well as support for the forest industry as a vehicle for competitiveness, growth and jobs. Such a strategy will strengthen the preservation of our forests and consolidate the economic, social and environmental benefits of the forest sector.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour because we need active and sustainable forest management if we want to boost the potential of forests in the EU. In addition, I also think that it is important to leave the practical management of forests to the discretion of Member States.

name: Jytte Guteland Anna Hedh Olle Ludvigsson Jens Nilsson och Marita Ulvskog (S&D)
text: Written. We Swedish Social Democrats voted in favour of 'The report on a new EU forest strategy: for forests and the forest-based sector (2014/2223(INI)'. The resolution confirms that forestry policy is a national competence and that forests have great potential to contribute to new green jobs and innovations, fully in line with the EU's objectives of smart, sustainable and inclusive growth.  Sustainable forestry and the use of forest raw materials offer the EU a source of new green jobs and a response to today's climate challenges. We therefore regret the three amendments that were voted through by an extremely small margin. Above all, we are opposed to the questioning of the climate neutrality of biomass and the notion that the use of forest raw materials would have negative effects on the environment.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this strategy because it identifies many of the key principles needed to strengthen sustainable forest management. It also looks at job-creation potential of the forestry sector as well as the opportunities to improve competitiveness.
