Forests have a multifunctional role and in the report we call for better coordination by EU bodies, a review of the effectiveness of the Timber Directive, active forest management and the sustainable resource-efficient use of timber. Given the different types of forest and forest ownership across the EU, practical management of forests has to be left up to the individual Member States while taking the forest strategy into account.

name: Anja Hazekamp (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This report deals with the new EU strategy for forests and the forest-based sector. However, in this report there are several environmental concerns that are not included in the text, like the biodiversity problems and the multifunctional nature of the forest. Furthermore, the report advocates using forestry and forestry resources for biomass production by the energy industries, which then should be an important part for a future EU energy mix. For these reasons, the Party for the Animals cannot vote in favour here, therefore I have abstained on the final vote.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We abstained because, although the amendments to establish criteria for the social and environmental revaluation of forests in the face of the strictly economic interest were rejected by the committee, there have been some improvements to the original drafting of the report.

name: Carlos Iturgaiz (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting in favour of simplifying and improving legislation by recommending a detailed examination of the Commission's internal structures. Strengthening the Standing Forestry Committee would counteract these divergences and overlaps within the Commission. I also stress once again the desirability of an implementation with as little bureaucracy as possible of the new EU forestry strategy, so that the sector can be strengthened without imposing new burdens.

name: Anneli Jäätteenmäki (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the EU forest strategy. The strategy takes quite a balanced approach between the different roles and functions of forests. Sustainable forest management ensures that environmental, social and economic viewpoints are all well presented. There is a clear need for better coordination between the Member States. For example, biodiversity protection practices and experiences in different Member States should be circulated. Knowledge is to be shared. Forests have a central role in providing jobs for remote areas, ensuring the preservation of biodiversity and having a positive impact on managing climate change. However, coordination and deepening cooperation in the forest sector neither necessitates a uniform EU approach nor a single legal base. Member States should continue to have the competences for the management of their forests. Managed wisely, the forest sector is a sustainable industry, providing valuable jobs at the core of the bio-economy.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the New EU Forest and Forest Strategy Report, as I believe that such a strategy is necessary even though the European Union is not responsible for developing a common European policy and the issue of forests and forestry is within the political competence of the Member States.  The wording of the strategy is good enough to improve this important economic sector (3.5 million employees) but also an important resource for maintaining the local and global ecosystem. It is important to ensure intelligent and sustainable management of forest resources.  I support the fact that the competence for this issue should continue to have the characteristics of a local and regional or national character with the need to align with common European interests and needs.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. I decided to vote against this text promoting a new strategy for forests. Firstly, because it is not for the European Union to legislate in this area, as the ENVI Committee admitted in its opinion, although it called on the Commission to "assume its leadership role in promoting a sustainable forestry policy". Moreover, this new strategy does little to consider concrete measures since, although the "environmental value" is often stressed, nothing is proposed in this area. In this case, the French wood sector is doing well, although it is gaining better governance at national level: again, the European Union is inadequate.  Protectionist measures would nevertheless be a means of protecting French and European timber, but, of course, such a policy is unthinkable by the Commission.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on a new European Union strategy for forests and the forestry sector. The adopted text stresses that the strategy must focus on sustainable forest management, but also highlights their role from an economic and social point of view.  The text also calls for greater coherence between the role of Member States and that of the European Union, while rejecting the increased bureaucratic burdens on forest owners, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the European Union's new forestry strategy. This strategy emphasizes the essential role of sustainable wood production and use in promoting sustainable economic models and encouraging the creation of green jobs. This strategy will also emphasize the need for sustainable forest management. I welcome the adoption of this text.

name: Jarosław Kalinowski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Forests are one of europe's greatest riches. In many countries, they account for more than half of the area. They are part of the landscape, home and shelter for animals, "green lungs" for urban centres, as well as a workplace for more than 3.5 million Europeans. I therefore agree that we should approach strategy planning and management of this natural resource with greater care and precision. The most important aspect of this strategy is the sustainable development of forest management and the timber industry, so that current and future generations can both benefit from and enjoy it. I share the rapporteur's view that the strategy should not impose additional bureaucratic guidelines for forest owners and foresters, but should, because of their heterogeneity, set up individual criteria for specific areas. Innovative research and ideas should also be used to help the timber industry grow in a novel way and provide the economy with even more jobs.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI)
text: Writing. The report is balanced and designed for the sustainable economic use of European forests. I can only agree with the proposals as they are being made here.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of a new European Union forest strategy for forests and wood-based industries at the European Parliament plenary session in Strasbourg. Forests cover about 40% of the eu's land area, and almost 50% of all land cover in Latvia is covered with forests, making the forest industry a very important industrial sector in Latvia. I believe that the amount of forests in the European Union provides us with an excellent opportunity to further develop the forest industry, which in turn will create new jobs and promote growth. In my view, this strategy, as a key point, highlights a very important point that the EU needs to focus on the management of forests that ensure sustainable and efficient use of resources. The more orderly this sector is on the PART of the EU, the better opportunities our entrepreneurs have.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I am pleased to support an EU forest strategy based on the principles of sustainable and multifunctional forest management, global forest responsibility and efficient use of forest resources. Developing forests sustainably brings opportunities for job creation and possibilities for additional income sources for landowners. Sustainable forest management principles ensure our resources are managed efficiently and economically. Sustainably increasing our forest area goes a long way towards maintaining a clean and healthy environment.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Forests are major contributors to our climate-change mitigation efforts and one of the approaches to tackling climate change is maximising the contribution of our forests which currently deliver a 10% mitigation factor. Management of forests is also important from the point of view of creating employment in rural areas, both in actual woodlands and in wood processing facilities, timber transport, and research and innovation facilities. I therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: Elisabeth Köstinger (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the new EU forest strategy because it recognises the multifunctional role of forests from the economic, social and environmental viewpoint and thus supports the sector as a very important economic pillar in Europe. It also strongly opposes legally binding rules for prioritising the use of wood, mandatory forest management plans and new burdens on forest owners regarding Natura 2000. There is a strong focus on better coordination, so that forestry and the forests are given a higher profile among the individual European strategies without jeopardising Member Statesʼ competences. The weak majority for amendments tabled by the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (ENVI) – Amendment 1 on loss of biodiversity and the degradation of ecosystem services (361 in favour, 316 against and 11 abstentions), Amendment 2 (329 in favour, 327 against and 29 abstentions) and Amendment 3 on the greenhouse impacts of various uses of forest biomass for energy (340 in favour, 332 against and 14 abstentions) – also show that the report from the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Affairs (AGRI) was strongly supported throughout the plenary and new obstacles for the sector are very much questioned.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. – More and more people are realming that carbon quota trading and storage procedures are a huge scam and a waste of money. One of the real solutions is forestry. Our forests provide not only jobs and timber, but also a place to live for animals, good air for people and spiritual recharge. Despite its shortcomings, I supported the report. We should also remember that from the source we used for carbon quotas and storage, tropical rainforests could have been saved from eradication, and the Earth's atmosphere would be balanced.

name: Miapetra Kumpula-Natri (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the forest strategy as an environmentally, economically and socially balanced strategy, which enables better coordination of the different EU-level strategies influencing the forest sector. I strongly opposed, however, Amendment 3 by the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (ENVI), as it needs clarification about the carbon neutrality of biomass. Biomass is carbon neutral. The International Panel for Climate Change under the United Nations gives a 0.0 CO2-emissions factor for biomass. The EU should not differentiate itself from this international standard. Losing carbon neutrality would shake the fundamentals of the EUʼs renewable energy policy. It would endanger the achievement of EU renewable energy targets and bring uncertainty to the industry covered by the EU Emission Trading Scheme. Moreover, the EU must not have double emissions counting for biomass. In the international climate change framework the emissions are reported in the Agriculture, Forestry and Other Land-Use (AFOLU) sector (previously the LULUCF sector). Moreover, we should not examine the mitigation within a ʽpolicy timeframeʼ. Instead, we should examine mitigation based on the significantly longer natural carbon cycle and base our policies on a natural timeframe.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Mr De Clercq's report. Mr Köstinger, as he intends to strengthen the social, economic and ecological role of forests and to emphasise the importance of wood as a sustainable raw material.  Forestry occupies 40% of the EU's surface area, playing a very important multifunctional role, and forest biomass is the main source of renewable energy, accounting for around half of total renewable energy consumption in the EU. For these reasons, I support the report and thank Mr McNdt for his excellent report. Mr Köstinger for his excellent work.

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 This report touches on all aspects of forestry, with an emphasis on more sustainable long-term development, resource efficiency, the multifunctionality of forest management, the future challenges of wood scarcity and the risks posed by climate change, and most importantly, calling for an action plan accompanied by specific measures and funding. A better and more efficient use of forest resources and the maintenance of employment in the sector will allow European citizens to better understand the importance of forests for the environment and the economy of the European Union.

name: Philippe Loiseau (NI)
text: In writing. Vote against. The report rightly stresses the economic importance of the forestry sector. But the Commission is looking at this issue mainly from an environmental perspective, which is certainly important but will not solve the crisis in the sector. Indeed, for the French forestry sector, despite its economic weight it has a chronic deficit of 6 billion euros. This is mainly due to the fact that France sells its logs to countries like China which transforms them into furniture and France buys these finished products made with its resources. This is a significant shortfall for our industries, which need investment to modernize. No decision is taken by Parliament to protect our market, which is the key problem. Parliament which, moreover, wants to increase its authority to the detriment of the Member States.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. In a comprehensive resolution, the Kostinger report highlights a new Union forestry strategy focused on coordination, so that forestry and forests better fit the different European policies (energy, environmental and climate protection, and research and development) and a more coherent approach can be defined, calling for the strengthening of the Standing Forestry Committee.  Our position on the EU gaining forestry skills has been even more minority than in previous reviews. In this regard, the report adopted in the AGRI Commission highlights in several paragraphs the fact that we are dealing with an area of competence of the Member States. It should be noted that the Delegation's amendment calling for more attention to the problems caused by "dry" disease in the cork oaks of Spain had been contained in paragraph 16 of the Resolution. However, the prohibition on building on burnt surfaces has not been approved.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Forests cover more than 40% of the EU's area and are an essential resource for improving quality of life and job creation, particularly in rural areas, while maintaining ecosystems and combating climate change. Amendments were tabled that reflected the need to place criteria for social and environmental improvement above the logic of financial gain, agroforestry activities, biodiversity and the multifunctional nature of forests, the creation of specific support measures to prevent and combat fires that allow early intervention, avoiding soil erosion , and recovery of plant cover. In the end, the vast majority of our amendments were rejected by the committee, although some improvements were made in relation to the initial document, so we abstained in the final vote.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 Forests and forestry provide timely responses for the establishment of an additional economic pillar, while optimally ensuring quality of life, sustainability and employment. The report proposes to contribute to further development of forests and the forestry sector in their role in the social, economic and environmental fields. On the other hand, it places particular emphasis on wood as a sustainable raw material and an important resource for Europe, as it is of great economic importance, especially for rural areas.  The Union's new forestry strategy must therefore focus on improving coordination procedures, so that forestry and forests better fit into different European strategies and a more coherent approach can be defined.  That is why I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I do not agree with the centralisation and intervention of the EU in the field of forestry. Forests work best when they have a specific owner who takes care of them, not under the administration of a central authority.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The forestry sector is the third largest employer in the European Union. Wood is an important sustainable and environmentally friendly raw material that has an impact on other sectors of the economy, in particular the wood-processing industry and the production of renewable energy. It is therefore necessary to establish a framework for economic activity in forests so as to maintaining their ecological and environmental function, while at the same time ensuring efficient and economic management of timber as an important sustainable raw material. Measures should be taken by the Member States of the Union to take account of regional specificities of forest management, while at the same time encouraging increased employment in forestry and downstream sectors.

name: Ernest Maragall (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. Despite the risk of moving from non-logging to over-exploitation, and also an excessive emphasis on what should be the last forest use in the form of energy, this report deserves my vote in favour since at all times it maintains the criterion of its sustainability, which can be understood as consumption in no case higher than that of its natural reproduction rate. In the specific case of Catalonia, the second forester European region, only its sustainable exploitation can save the forest from recurrent fires such as those we have suffered in the past, while it can lead to a decline in our exports and can settle populations and generate employment in areas now threatened with abandonment.

name: Dominique Martin (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this new strategy, which will increase the role of the EU to the detriment of the member countries, which is a blatant attack on the sovereignty of states. Moreover, this strategy does not take into account the trade problems related to the abuses of certain third countries.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Sustainable forest management means guaranteeing the long-term safety of the forest for future generations. Indeed, this was the underlying principle of the UN Environmental Conference in Rio de Janeiro in 1992: Sustainable development is development that meets the needs of the present without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their own needs and choose their own life style.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on "A new Eu ropean Union forestry strategy: for forests and the forestry sector" agrees with me. Wood is indeed an important resource for the European Union, both as a renewable resource and as a raw material with developable potential. Effective forest management is an important point, given the size, characteristics and capabilities of our forests.  It should also be borne in hand that forest biomass is a very important source of renewable energy, as European forests absorb around 10% of the EU's carbon emissions, and that managed forests have a higher effective capacity than unmanaged forests. Finally, it should be stressed that, in view of the increasing urbanisation, we need policies aimed at raising public awareness and enticeing them to discover and care for this type of resource.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 European forests currently absorb and store around 10 % of carbon emissions from EU Member States. It is therefore a priority to ensure sustainable management of forest biomass, given that it is an important source of renewable energy.  I voted in favour of the Köstinger report, which refers to the need to adopt, at EU level, a forestry strategy focused on the sustainable management of forests, and their multifunctional role from an economic, social and environmental point of view, as I believe that greater coordination of European policies linked, directly or indirectly, to the forestry economy is desirable.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. The report on a new EU strategy for forests and the forestry sector, which I have supported, is a commitment to further development of forests and this sector in the EU, as its social, economic and environmental contribution is critical for Europe. We must also improve coordination so that an appropriate policy in this area is also in addition to EU policies on key issues such as energy, the environment and climate protection, as well as economic growth and employment. Wood remains an important resource for Europe today, and a sustainable raw material, and we must also help our foresters and forest owners to develop their activity effectively and without further bureaucratic obstacles.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report because the proposals and improvements it contains are commendable and not only provide for quality of life, sustainability, jobs and added value for forests and forestry, but also guarantee them.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report as a new EU forest strategy is needed to deal with cross-border challenges such as forest fires, climate change or invasive alien species.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Forests cover more than 40% of the EU's land area. The general situation is characterized by the growing demand for wood and therefore threats to forests. The EU's new forest and forest strategy focuses on the bioeconomic aspects. And even if it has "sustainable development" goals, it allows the short-term exploitation of the forest via "short-rotation forestry."  Moreover, the recommendation of forest management plans may remain wishful thinking because it will have to be done "without creating unnecessary bureaucratic burden". Faced with such a narrow vision of forest issues that avoids issues of biodiversity, impact on agriculture and employment, I abstain.

name: Joëlle Mélin (NI)
text: In writing. This text promotes a new strategy for forests. Firstly, because it is not for the European Union to legislate in this area, as the ENVI Committee admitted in its opinion, although it called on the Commission to "assume its leadership role in promoting a sustainable forestry policy". Moreover, this new strategy does little to consider concrete measures since, although the "environmental value" is often stressed, nothing is proposed in this area. In this case, the French wood sector is doing well, although it is gaining from better governance at national level: again, the European Union seems to be inadequate.  Protectionist measures would nevertheless be a means of protecting French and European timber, but, of course, such a policy is unthinkable by the Commission. So I voted AGAINST.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report as it not only recognises the need for the new EU forest strategy to be in sync with the European Union’s environment and climate policy, but also stresses that forestry should remain a national competence due to the sector’s local and regional nature. Instead it suggests coherence between the European Union’s goals and the Member States’ competences. It is also important to see the new forest strategy as a means of addressing the need for increased investment in the sector and its workforce to ensure competitiveness in the long-term.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. The importance of forests and their benefits to our society are no longer to be demonstrated. Wood, as a sustainable raw material, is an important resource in Europe, and 40% of Europe's territory is covered by forests.  In this context, it was important to strengthen the European Union's forestry strategy to deal with new cross-border challenges. This will include promoting the sustainable use of wood and other forest materials to create jobs and growth, as well as improving logging management and logging, while reducing bureaucracy.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this report, which touches on all aspects of Forestry. The S&D Group worked with others to ensure the report was as comprehensive as possible in a number of areas, such as employment in the sector, sustainable use of forest resources, and ensuring that people in Europe understand better the importance of their forests and will be able to benefit from them in many ways.

name: Bernard Monot (NI)
text: In writing. This report does not propose any concrete proposals to promote a form of protectionism, even in Europe, to deal with the "aggressive" policies of some countries such as China.  However, this is the central problem for the wood sector, especially with regard to France.  As the numerous parliamentary reports on the issue point out, the problem is due to the obsolescence of the sawmills but also to the fact that it exports its logs and imports, in particular to China, finished products (parquets, furniture, etc.).  The vote is, among other reasons, negative.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union does not have the competence to develop a common forestry policy, but certain and certain Union policies are likely to have a specific impact on national forest policies. I am voting in favour of this report which stresses the importance of sustainable forest management and its multifunctional role from an economic, social and environmental point of view, as well as the positive impact it has on biodiversity and climate change mitigation. I also highlight the need for forest resources to be used and reused efficiently, contributing decisively to a correct sustainable management of forests

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. This resolution aims to adopt a new strategy for forests.  It is first of all recalled that this strategy remains at the discretion of the Member States, which are autonomous and competent to carry out their forestry policy. However, the Union is interfering in the long-term attempt to become a coordinating force for these policies and by insisting that it will be necessary to consult Parliament's opinion.  This report focuses too much on the ecological value of the forest and abandons the economic aspect it can represent. Indeed, nothing is said about the export of raw wood abroad and the importation of processed wood with higher added value.  It would have been wise to consider a certain protectionism to address unfair competition from certain countries, including China, in order to remedy this problem. Since the report touts the ecological value of the forest, it would also be appropriate to recall the disastrous impact of such a globalized production process on the environment.  So I voted against it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Forests are major contributors to our climate-change mitigation efforts. One of the approaches to tackling climate change is maximising the contribution of our forests, which currently deliver a 10% mitigation factor. This contribution however has the potential to be bigger still – in three specific ways: through the enlargement of European forest cover, by the active management of our forests and by increasing the use of wood, of timber in both traditional ways and in new ways. The reasons why we need to manage our forests are not only limited to climate change mitigation. Management of forests is equally important from the point of view of creating employment in rural areas, both in actual woodlands and in wood processing facilities, timber transport, research and innovation facilities, etc. Nevertheless, extensive use of wood opens up new possibilities for employment but also poses challenges in terms of supplying an adequately educated and trained workforce, familiar with new technologies as well as the constraints associated with sustainable use of wood.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. Forests and other forested areas cover more than 40% of the EU's territory and forest area has increased by 0.4% per year in recent decades. I voted in favour of this text setting out a new EU strategy for forests and the forestry sector. This strategy recognises the competence of Member States in forest management (subsidiarity principle) and focuses on strengthening cooperation between Member States to address transnational challenges such as fires, climate change, natural disasters or invasive alien species. The report I voted on also stresses the need to ensure that forest resources and forestry materials are used and reused effectively. Finally, the increased administrative burdens for forest owners are rejected throughout the text.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 With over 3.5 million employees, the forestry sector is the third largest sector for employment in Europe.  With the adoption of this report we intend to further strengthen the social, economic and ecological role of forests and the forestry sector and we want to draw attention to wood as a sustainable raw material and an important resource for Europe. Since many Eu ropean Union policies, such as energy, environmental and climate policies, also concern forest management, we consider it essential that the european Union's new forestry strategy should first and foremost aim for better coordination, so that the forestry economy and forests are better integrated into individual European strategies and a more coherent approach is followed.  In this respect, we must encourage simplification and the quality of the regulation of the sector, avoiding imposing further bureaucratic and administrative obstacles. Thanks to research and technological development, it will be possible to exploit the full potential for innovation and development of the bioeconomy, promoting a sustainable use of raw materials and rendering a significant service to environmental and climate protection.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The current EU forestry strategy dates back to 1998. Based on cooperation between the EU and the Member States (subsidiarity and co-responsibility), it has established a framework for forest-oriented actions to support sustainable forest management. Today, however, we need a new framework capable of responding to the growing needs of forests and the considerable changes that have affected forests over the last fifteen years.  The new strategy aims to create a policy framework that promotes forest coordination and the creation of synergies with other sectors influencing forest management, including rural development, business, environment, bioenergy, climate change, research and development. At the same time, with a related initiative, the Commission has also proposed an activity plan aimed at drawing attention to wood as a sustainable raw material and an important resource for Europe. In the light of the above, I voted in favour of this report because it highlights the need to adopt a holistic approach, recalling the importance of forests not only for rural development, but also for the environment and biodiversity, for the forestry industries, bioenergy and the fight against climate change.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The forestry sector provides jobs for 3 million European citizens. The report brings a number of measures complementing the Commission's efforts to sustainably boost employment and generate wealth in Europe's forestry sector.  I voted for this report because, the amendments tabled, it underlines the need for 'a specific long-term action plan, highlighting the importance of mobilising and sustainable use of wood, with the aim of creating added value and jobs in this sector'.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This report deals with the new EU strategy for forests and the forest-based sector. There were a number of positive aspects to this report. However, I abstained on this vote because of environmental concerns, especially in the context of bio-energy. Moreover, there was no reflection in the report of concerns in relation to biodiversity problems, the multifunctional nature of forests, the creation of specific support measures to prevent and fight fires enabling early intervention or avoiding soil erosion and the recovery of vegetation cover. For these reasons I abstained in the vote.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this text as it is a much-needed first step towards a more cohesive approach between EU Member States to the preservation, development and sustainable use of their forestry resources. My country, Romania, is the country with the richest forests in the EU and I believe they represent a huge economic potential, in terms of sustainable tourism and recreation, of high-quality timber production. More should be done to not only protect but increase Europe’s forest, and we must remember that this resource can have a direct impact on other fields as well, including CO2 emissions on a continent-wide basis.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the AMENDMENTS of the ENVI Committee, which went beyond the report of the Main Committee of the AGRI and scheming the balance of the pillars of forest management in favour of the ecological and social aspects of forest management. I believe that this non-equatable approach will not become the basis for EU policy-making in this area.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. The proposals and improvements contained in the report are commendable: forests and forestry not only provide quality of life, sustainability, jobs and added value, they also shape the face of my homeland and must be promoted. I therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This initiative report aims to put forests and the forest sector at the heart of the evolution towards a green economy and to appreciate the value of the benefits that forests can offer in a sustainable way, while ensuring their protection. It covers areas such as rural development, bioenergy, climate change, ecosystems and biodiversity, wood knowledge, innovation or governance. The current EU strategy dates back to 1998, and a new European framework is needed for forests, which are facing new challenges a result of environmental, societal and political change. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. – I supported the proposal, given that 40% of the territory of the European Union is forested. Forest and forestry are therefore an important source of improvement in quality of life, as well as job creation, particularly in rural areas. At the same time, it is necessary to ensure that ecosystems are adequately protected.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE)
text: in writing. The European forestry strategy highlights the importance of forests and forestry not only from an environmental point of view but also from an economic and social point of view. It also proposes improving the coordination of the different European policies involved (energy, research and development, employment, climate, etc.), so as to promote the creation of a more coherent approach. That is why we have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI)
text: Writing. – The JRC voted against the report because it subjugates forests and their management to the competitiveness of the industry's monopolistic groups supported by EU funds (from Horizon 2020) and other facilities, within the framework of the EU's energy self-sufficiency policy and its competition with other imperialist centres. The resolution of forest problems (biodiversity reduction, illegal logging) is entrusted to forest owners, contractors and monopolies in the sector who cooperate with governments that invest on the basis of the profit of forestry enterprises and strike at the rights of foresters, in practice undermining and completely invalidateing the right of the people to recreation. References to sustainable development, the green economy, climate change, forest biomass as a renewable energy source and the protection of biodiversity hide nothing but new areas of profitability for monopolies that turn land and forests further into a multi-exploited commodity. Forests are social property and the integrated protection and management of forest ecosystems for the benefit of the people can only be realised when power and economy are in the hands of the people.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. Whereas the European Union has no competence to draw up a common forestry policy, but whereas certain Union policies may have implications for national forestry policies, it is up to the Member States to decide on the policy to be followed with regard to forestry and forestry; Whereas wood is a renewable and often under-utilised resource in Europe and it is necessary to ensure the intelligent and sustainable use of this raw material, including through the development and exchange of know-how; For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. This year in Croatia we are marking 250 years of organized forestry, and today the total area of forests and forest land in the Republic of Croatia accounts for 47.5 % of the land area of the country. The forests of the Republic of Croatia are known for their great biodiversity and the fact that 95 % of the forest area is of natural composition, which is the result of a long forestry tradition of sustainable management.  This is the potential by which the Republic of Croatia contributes to the European average, and the experiences of forest management according to the specifics of individual regions are valuable knowledge possessed by our foresters. I am committed to keeping forestry policy control within the competence of the Member States due to the specificity of the development and forestry opportunities of each Member State. The main characteristic of Croatian forests is their naturalness due to the management of native species in a way of natural rejuvenation.  This way of managing is not used in all EU countries and therefore I believe that as a Member State we should have control of forestry policy, using everything that the EU Common Forestry Policy can usefully bring us, as the global dangers that threat forests know no national borders.

name: Florian Philippot (NI)
text: In writing. This text poses two major problems: on the one hand, it subjects forestry policy to the Commission's will and thus again infringes on the sovereignty of the Member States. On the other hand, it presents an absurd vision of forestry: seeing above all in the forests beautiful recreational and ecological green spaces, it does nothing to protect the wood economy while the Member States, and in particular France, are subject to a dramatic situation: logs are exported to China and return as processed products. The timber sector in Europe is thus subject to unfair competition, not partly because of China's protectionist policies, and the ecological cost of these round trips does not seem to be of much concern to the Commission, despite its claim to have an interest in environmental protection.  So I can only vote against this report.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support Köstinger's report and the Proposal for a European Parliament Resolution on the New EU Forest strategy and the forest-based sector.  Forests cover more than half of the territories of some Member States such as Sweden, Finland, Slovenia and Estonia. In particular in these countries, but also throughout the Union, it is of utmost importance to manage forests sustainably. This creates added value at local, regional, European and international level in the form of job guarantees in rural areas, contributes to a bioeconomy-based society, has a positive impact on human health, but also protects the environment and climate, as European forests currently absorb and store around 10 % of the Union's carbon emissions. Forests today also play a crucial role in the bioeconomy, a sector of the economy that generates a turnover of more than €2 billion and offers 20 million jobs, which is 9% of total jobs in the Union. Investment in research and development of the Bioeconomy under Horizon 2020 should continue, as the Commission estimates that each euro invested will generate around €10 added value. A key part of the Strategy is a skilled and well-trained workforce. Therefore, the Commission and the Member States should prepare measures and preferably take advantage of a wide range of existing European instruments (EAFRD, ERDF, ESF and ET 2020).

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is important that there is a new and more precise EU forestry strategy. The forestry sector is the third largest sector of employment in Europe. Sustainable forest management must, of course, be carried out in order to conserve forest resources and to expand the social, economic and ecological role of forests and the forestry sector. That is why I believe that we need to strengthen the Standing Forestry Committee and conclude a European Forestry Convention. Better coordination can give greater attention to research and development, enabling the forestry sector to exploit new opportunities and efficient production ideas. Furthermore, with the further development of the bioeconomy and the sustainable use of raw materials, there would be significant environmental and climate protection.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. Today, almost 40% of Europe is covered by forests and logging-related industries employ more than 3.5 million people in Europe. The forest is a source of wealth and growth that is not insignificant to the Union." With this in mind, the European Parliament adopted the EU's new forest strategy, replacing the 1998 text. I have spoken in favour of this text. It emphasizes forest management, sustainable development, intelligent and respectful use of forest raw materials, and the use of the economic potential represented by forest areas. Forest areas are now an important source of employment and it is necessary to frame this development.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This document is a new Strategy of the European Union for forests and the forestry sector, which aims to focus on better coordination, so that forestry and forests are better positioned in the different European strategies and a more coherent approach can be found. For all this and for the importance of this sector for the economy and society, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. The preservation of our forests is one of the major challenges of the 21st century.  The urbanization of society is gradually leading to a loss of knowledge about forests and forestry. However, their benefits for man are numerous and essential to its survival: jobs, climate, environment, health, food, consumer goods... We are dependent on our forests. In the middle of our overcrowded cities, far from the small woods of our childhood, it is not always easy to realize it... That is why I have been an outs and all my support this afternoon of the Union's new strategy for forests and the forestry sector. By adopting this new strategy, the European Parliament fully reaffirms its policy of sustainable forest management with a view to ensuring their long-term conservation for future generations.  These real lungs of the Earth cover 159 million hectares, or 40% of the European territory. Generating more than 3.5 million jobs, they are a real economic pillar, just behind the metal industry and the food industry.   Clearly, European forests deserve more than just attention and their management is a priority. From their good preservation will be built the world that we will bequeath to our children.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which is part of the development of a European strategy for the forest and forestry sector. We highlight the three areas of work that we believe are essential for the years to come in this sector: the prevention of fires and natural disasters, the fight against climate change, and the sustainable management of forest raw materials (wood, cork, textile fibres).  Moreover, as the forest is an ever-changing sector, we encourage innovation through research and training in forestry, including the support of European programmes and funds.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 With more than 3.5 million jobs and taking third place at European level in terms of employment, immediately after the metallurgical and food industries, the forestry sector will undoubtedly be an additional economic pillar and a good way to ensure quality of life and employment. It is important that the Commission has a new EU strategy for forests, but it is important to safeguard the sustainable and responsible management of forests by balancing its multifunctional role in terms of economic, social and environmental.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. In September 2013, the European Commission Communication on "Forest support and forestry: a new approach to a new EU forestry strategy" was published, reviewing and updating the 1998 forestry strategy.  The European forestry strategy aims to target 2020, interless, forest management in accordance with sustainability principles and reducing the deforested or degraded area, setting out a number of priority areas of action, such as coordination and communication on forest-related issues, forest sector support for rural and urban society , improving the competitiveness of forest-generated goods and services, the relationship between forest areas and climate change, or the development of innovative initiatives in the sector. The Forest Strategy Resolution calls for a new strategy focused on coordination, so that forestry and forests better fit into different European policies (energy, environmental and climate protection, and R&D) and a more coherent approach can be defined, calling for the strengthening of the Standing Forestry Committee. That's why I voted for it.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. Forests and other wooded areas cover more than 40% of the European Union's territory. Forest area has increased by 0.4% per year in recent decades. The text voted today establishes a policy framework that promotes forestry coordination and the creation of synergies with other sectors that have an impact on forest management. The text focuses in particular on sustainable forest management and ecosystem services, ways to meet the growing demand for renewable energy and raw materials used in products, the challenges facing the forest industry, and the management of transnational threats to forests, such as fires and forest pests. The adopted report also stresses the need to ensure that forest resources and forestry materials are used and reused effectively, but opposes legally binding rules favouring the use of wood.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported this proposal. It is good that we do not give up forests within the EU and that each Member State will continue to manage independently. Of course, some principles need to be common throughout the EU.  The document should be improved by emphasising the importance of forests as one of the main elements of the countryside. In many western European countries, the natural forest landscape is already lost. It is possible to allow each country to choose a way to improve that landscape (regulation of the number of platens, the aim of greater forest diversity, etc.), but the objective must be general – to naturalise the forest landscape, thereby increasing their attractiveness; the role of forests as a supplier of "ecosystem services" and to assess this in material terms. In the scientific literature, ecosystem services are defined as services that ecosystems provide to humanity (reduction of air pollution, regulation of climate and groundwater levels, favourable living environments, forest goods that we use, etc.); the need for adaptation to climate change in the forestry sector. Forests cannot change as rapidly as the climate is changing now, so in many areas of Europe, different types of trees are starting to disappear. There are more favorable conditions for the spread of diseases and pests, and extreme weather phenomena make forests even more vulnerable. Measures to adapt forestry to climate change should be included in each forest management plan. We should develop European forests that are ready to withstand the challenges of climate change by achieving the widest possible naturalness of forests (diverse and heterogeneous forests).

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. The forests are an absolutely central asset of our Union, which should be preserved and managed in a sustainable way. In terms of employability, more than 3.5 million Europeans currently work in the forestry sector, ranking third at European level, immediately after the metallurgical and food industries. Given its cross-cutting nature, it is necessary for the Union to have an integrated strategy for sustainable forest management (together with energy, environmental and climate protection policy, for example) and to develop an action plan on deforestation/forest degradation, encouraging the conservation and management of existing forests, as well as the reforestation of previously deforested areas. As regards support for Member States, I share the view that the EU should assist national policies for sustainable forest management and strengthen prevention and cooperation with regard to increasingly frequent cross-border challenges such as forest fires, climate change and natural disasters. Finally, I would also like the rapporteur to stress the importance of producing and sustainable using materials such as wood or cork for the creation of green jobs and as a means of promoting greater research and innovation in the sector.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 More than 40% of the EU's territory is covered by forests, which are a valuable resource that we cannot underestimate. That is why I voted in favour of the EU's new forestry strategy, which aims at sustainable forest management, highlighting their multifunctional role from an economic, social and environmental point of view. Forests and forest industries offer good answers for a new pillar of the economy, as well as being the best guarantors of a good quality of life, sustainability, jobs and value creation.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. I have chosen to vote in favour because, although a 'Community' framework for a forest management strategy is called for, the text emphasises its exclusive competence of the Member States, and also underlines how important national and, above all, local logics are, with regard to their use. Today, support for the forestry sector and, more generally, the enhancement of 'disadvantaged areas', are poorly pursued by the EU (despite the 2014-2020 CAP) and the path described in the measure could be useful, except then a "substance" reasoning that will have to be made on the concrete proposals.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We abstained because, although the amendments to establish criteria for the social and environmental revaluation of forests in the face of the strictly economic interest were rejected by the committee, there have been some improvements to the original drafting of the report.

name: Anne Sander (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which lists Parliament's priorities for sustainable forest management and competitiveness of the forestry industry. Forests cover more than 40% of the EU's territory, and wood is a natural, renewable, reusable and recyclable raw material. Forests have an economic, social and environmental role and account for 3.5 million jobs.  With this report, Europe is finally addressing the dramatic problem of the plundering of European forest resources by emerging countries. Indeed, Europe does not protect its forest resources, while all the other major countries introduce export taxes. This open access increases the price of wood for European industry, especially for sawmills, which can no longer source. The number of sawmills has fallen by 15% in France since 2000. Thus, the report explicitly asks the Commission to analyse the difficulties of supplying the downstream of the sector, linked to the increase in demand in third countries in particular logs, and to support this sector.

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the Kostinger report on the EU's forestry strategy.  Forest plays an important role, both economically and in protecting the environment, through the absorption of carbon dioxide. It is therefore necessary for Member States to be encouraged to manage forests in a sustainable manner. Rural development funds can be used in this regard, and I hope that government and local authorities will show greater responsibility when it comes to logging.  I believe that the implementation of the new forestry strategy should compensate for the lack of specific provisions on forestry policy in the EU Treaty. It should also ensure coordinated positions between EU and Member State policies on international forestry issues.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Forests cover more than 40% of the EU's area and are an essential resource for improving quality of life and job creation, particularly in rural areas, while maintaining ecosystems and combating climate change. Amendments were tabled that reflected the need to place criteria for social and environmental improvement above the logic of financial gain, agroforestry activities, biodiversity and the multifunctional nature of forests, the creation of specific support measures to prevent and combat fires that allow early intervention, avoiding soil erosion , and recovery of plant cover. In the end, the vast majority of our amendments were rejected by the committee, although some improvements were made in relation to the initial document, so we abstained in the final vote.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report adopted today has the merit of drawing attention to the importance of forests for the European Union and their economic, social and environmental role: 16 million forest owners, 3.5 million workers, 451 820 companies representing 7% of manufacturing GDP in the EU are numbers that make us understand the high value of the European forestry sector.  Given the extremely heterogeneous nature of Europe's forests, which differ considerably in ownership, size, nature and the challenges to which they are exposed, it is important that the principle of subsidiarity and the competences of the Member States are respected. However, we should not underestimate the benefits that the forestry sector can derive from better and more active coordination at European level. I have therefore chosen to vote in favour of the report.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The update of the European Forest Strategy should take into account the need to safeguard the multifunctional role of forests and contribute to their sustainable management. These should be the central aspects of this strategy and the monitoring of its implementation. In this context, forest management plans and natura 2000 management should follow an integrated approach. The former are fundamental instruments for the conservation, recovery and promotion of natural capital, biodiversity and ecosystems, explaining the management objectives of the Natura Network. The evolution of the context of climate change enhances new risks, such as the higher occurrence of fires and pests and diseases, which require the greatest attention of public policies.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs voted in favour of the report on a new EU forest strategy. Forests are major contributors to our climate-change mitigation efforts. One of the approaches to tackling climate change is maximising the contribution of our forests which currently deliver a 10% mitigation factor. This contribution however has the potential to be bigger still – in three specific ways: through the enlargement of European forest cover, by the active management of our forests and by increasing the use of wood, of timber in both traditional ways and in new ways.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 Forests and wood as a sustainable raw material play an irreplaceable role in the ecosystem. For this reason, I voted in favour of this resolution on a new strategy for forests and the forestry sector. Forests need to be developed because they are the cultural and economic heritage of both the EU and the Slovak Republic.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the adoption of a new forestry strategy, as I think an effective European approach is essential to address current challenges and potential threats that know no borders in a sustainable and competent way. As a shadow rapporteur of the Greens/ESS Group on the Opinion of the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety Committee on the report, I am extremely pleased with the distinguished amendments I have proposed. I specifically advocated the multifunctional role of forests in preventing soil erosion, water treatment and retention, flood prevention, etc. I have achieved the adoption of a European approach to combat diseases, pests and pests that seriously affect European forests, and pose a particular challenge to smaller Member States such as Croatia, which is currently facing the disappearance of species such as elms, chestnuts or ash trees. Croatian citizens have lived in symbiosis with forests for centuries and it is necessary to maintain this relationship on the principles of sustainable development.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. – I supported the new EU forest strategy because forests make up half of the EU's territory and are also a source of unique flora, fauna and fungi. Only healthy and stable forests can fully fulfil the function of protecting people and nature by preventing avalanches and mudslies and serving as a natural flood protection. When forest management, we must also bear in mind their multifunctional role in the economic, social and environmental considerations. The pace of deforestation and illegal logging must be eliminated and, where possible, prevented. Wood is an important resource of major economic importance, especially for rural areas. Although 50% of Europe's forests are privately owned, owners must ensure that forests fulfil their ecological, economic and social function on a permanent basis. Sustainable forest management means the long-term guaranteed conservation of forest cover for future generations.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the resolution on the eu's new forestry strategy, which underlines the importance of sustainable management and the socio-economic value of the forestry sector. With more than 3.5 million people employed and 40% of the land emerging in Europe covered by forests, the forestry sector is the third largest sector for employment in the EU, after metallurgical and food sectors. Given the great environmental and economic importance, the resolution argues that forests and forestry should play a greater role in other European policies. From the point of view of energy and environmental policies, intelligent forest management could help to achieve the objectives of energy transition and adaptation to climate change, through both CO2 absorption capacity and the efficient use of timber, as a renewable and versatile raw material.  The resolution also calls for an urgent clarification of the greenhouse effects caused by the different uses of forest biomass for energy production and for identifying the uses that can produce the greatest mitigation benefits within the time frame laid down in the relevant policies. The new strategy should also help address cross-border challenges, such as forest fires, natural disasters and invasive alien species.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the EU's new forest and forest sector strategy, which calls on Member States to support forest owners in their efforts to preserve and grow the indigenous mixed forests that are common for a particular area. Around 60% of EU forests are privately owned and have around 16 million private owners, and I support all measures to enable stakeholder associations to engage in dialogue on the development and implementation of sustainable forest management and better exchange of information.  The use of wood and other products made of used wood as renewable and environmentally friendly raw materials on the one hand and sustainable forest management on the other hand play an important role in achieving the EU's socially political objectives such as the energy transition, climate change mitigation and adaptation, and the achievement of the Europe 2020 objectives and biodiversity targets.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report on a new EU forest strategy for forests and the forest-based sector. It is important to manage our forests as not only are they major contributors to our effects to mitigate climate change, but they also create employment in areas such as in woodlands and in wood processing facilities.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. – Forests are natural habitats of many animal and plant species, which provide humanity with a large range of benefits. Forests are our oxygen factories, the best means in the fight against climate change, protect against soil erosion and help preserve and regulate geographic climates. Forests also have great social and economic importance in the production of industrial and food products.  With this in mind, it is of utmost importance to ensure a balanced and sustainable way of managing forest resources, but also to ensure a multifunctional role of forests, i.e. forests. contribute to the development of the rural area through the forest sector and the creation of educational programmes to prepare people in the sector for new challenges in forestry and job creation.  Forests in Croatia occupy 37% of the total area of the state territory, of which more than 90% is a self-made natural forest, which puts Croatia at the very top in terms of quality and healthy forest conservation in the European Union. Furthermore, wood raw material from natural forests has exceptional quality, which is reflected in quality wood processing and creation of recognition and competitiveness in the European wood industry.  It is therefore of utmost importance to support the report on new forest strategies that are in line with smart management that result in the development of rural environments, improved quality of life, cleaner air, more jobs and ultimately ensuring the health of planet Earth for us, but also future generations.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal because it seeks to reduce administrative burdens and reduce any administrative burden in the future in relation to the ownership and management of forests, which is certainly beneficial for forests and also for the economy.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the new EU forestry strategy. The European Union does not have the power to formulate a common forestry policy, but it can influence individual member states' forestry policies through other policies. Wood is a renewable energy source which, unfortunately, is not sufficiently exploited in Europe. It is necessary to ensure the smart and sustainable use of wood. I also welcome the report on the new EU forestry strategy because it stresses that the strategy should take into account that in some Member States forests cover more than half of the territory, including Slovenia, and that sustainable-managed forests are of paramount importance for added value at local and regional level and an important source of jobs in rural areas, while contributing significantly to the protection of the environment.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Establishing a common framework to address the issues and serious problems facing Europe's forests is a move in the right direction.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on a new EU forest management strategy for forests and the forestry sector. In my opinion, this gives us the opportunity to create a framework for more efficient forest management and to increase competitiveness, thereby creating additional jobs. The new EU forestry strategy takes into account established social and political expectations and the huge employment and growth potential of forestry. In addition to these elements, forestry, of course, has a major role to play in the fight against climate change, natural disasters or invasive species, and these points are therefore also a priority in the resolution adopted. In my opinion, the strategy also places due emphasis on the role of forestry in energy production, R&D and forest training. In order to implement this, the European Parliament encourages the European Commission, in close cooperation with Member States, local authorities and forest owners, to develop a comprehensive, objective set of criteria and implementation for sustainable forest management.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. As in committee a few weeks ago, I voted for this report. It is essential, for the proper implementation of the strategy, to have a specific long-term action plan that emphasizes the importance of mobilizing and sustainable use of forest timber, to create added value and jobs while providing means to strengthen private logging and support the organized structures of forest owners.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the non-legislative resolution asking for ambitious and objective criteria for managing forests sustainably and in close collaboration with Member States, local authorities and forest owners. While the EU can help to improve coordination of its forestry-related policies, forestry must remain a matter for Member States. The report also underlines that the EU forest strategy should enhance the competitiveness of the forestry industry to create jobs, which is an important point.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the report on the new EU Forest strategy and the forest-based sector, as I think it is very well emphasised that the European Union is not responsible for developing a common forestry policy, but certain policies can have an impact on national forestry policies and member states are allowed to take their own decisions on political approaches to forestry and forests. I also find it very useful to highlight several areas of activity such as sustainable forest management through rural development support, strengthening the competitiveness of forest-based industries in the wider green economy, improving fundamental knowledge about forests and fostering innovation in the forestry sector. While different models of ownership have been recognised in the Member States and highlighted the importance and multifunctional role of forestry as an ecological, economic and social resource, it also highlighted the need for increased cooperation on cross-border challenges such as forest fires, pests and illegal logging.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We abstained because, although there have been some improvements from the original wording of the report, the amendments to establish criteria for the social and environmental revaluation of forests in the face of the strictly economic interest were rejected by the committee.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (NI)
text: In writing. The report rightly stresses the economic importance of the forestry sector. But the Commission is looking at this issue mainly from an environmental perspective, which is certainly important but will not solve the crisis in the sector. Indeed, for the French forestry sector, despite its economic weight it has a chronic deficit of 6 million euros. This is mainly due to the fact that France sells its logs to countries like China which transforms them into furniture. France imports these finished products made with its resources. This is a significant shortfall for our industries, which need investment to modernize. No decision is taken by Parliament to protect our market, which is the key problem. Moreover, Parliament wants to increase its authority at the expense of the Member States. I vote AGAINST this text.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The importance of the forestry economy is shown by the fact that it ranks third in terms of employment with more than 3.5 million jobs across Europe, directly behind the metals and food industries. A deliberately structured and coordinated forestry strategy is very important in EU agricultural policy. The reporter has collected in detail almost all important areas of forestry. I agree with the finding that more resources should be devoted to research and development. I supported the adoption of this report.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We abstained because, although there have been some improvements from the original wording of the report, the amendments to establish criteria for the social and environmental revaluation of forests in the face of the strictly economic interest were rejected by the committee.

name: Владимир Уручев (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the EP resolution on a new EU forest strategy that celebrates their important societal, economic and environmental role.  Forests are important for rural development and in this regard I encourage the recognition of the role of forestry and agro-forestry in the RDPs for the period 2014-2020.  The forest sector is of important economic importance, providing over 3.5 million jobs at European level. In this regard, it is important to explore the potential of this sector to create green jobs, especially in rural areas.  Forest biomass will play an increasingly important role as a source of renewable energy, given the growing demand for energy. In this respect, research and innovation in the forest sector should be encouraged under European funds and programmes with a view to achieving the rational use of biomass and the development of fast-growing energy crops. The data show that every euro invested in research and innovation in the field of the bioeconomy and sustainable use of raw materials under Horizon 2020 will generate around EUR 10 in added value.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. I welcome this report on a new EU strategy for forests and the forestry sector, as it is an important element that the rest of the Community institutions must take into account when delimiting the role of forests, forestry and the forestry sector in the economy and society in Europe.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Forests cover more than 40% of the EU's area and are an essential resource for improving quality of life and job creation, particularly in rural areas, while maintaining ecosystems and combating climate change. Amendments were tabled that reflected the need to place criteria for social and environmental improvement above the logic of financial gain, agroforestry activities, biodiversity and the multifunctional nature of forests, the creation of specific support measures to prevent and combat fires that allow early intervention, avoiding soil erosion , and recovery of plant cover. In the end, the vast majority of our amendments were rejected by the committee, although some improvements were made in relation to the initial document, so we abstained in the final vote.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Forests cover 40% of the EU's territory Since 1998, a European forest strategy has been implemented as part of cooperation between member states. In the face of increasing threats to forests due to climate change, biodiversity loss, urban sprawl and the growing demand for bio-sourced products including from forests and wood, the EU's forest strategy needs to be revised to ensure sustainable forest management. In its resolution the European Parliament proposes a renewed framework that reaffirms the imperative of sustainable forest management to ensure the maintenance of biodiversity and eco-systems while allowing the multifunctional use of forests, the development of the wood sector and the production of materials for the development of new products and materials. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution of the European Parliament, without illusion, however, of the reality of its impact, because they do not have any obligation for the Member States.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This new strategy shows some improvements, in particular with regard to the recognition of the multifunctionality of forests, i.e. the recognition that the forest serves the social, environmental and economic interests, as well as the interests of all ecosystems that exist in it. This strategy fails, however, in terms of the recognition of the growing conflicts between the various sectors that depend on the forest and the growing demand for biomass from the energy sector. We regret that several of the proposals we have made in the Committee on Agriculture have not been considered with regard to the need to create criteria reflecting the great diversity of the type of forests in Europe, criteria for environmental and social enhancement above any logic of financial profit, the need for recognition of the various agroforestry activities and their social and economic function.  Parliament's report today comes under pressure from large groups linked to timber production and the energy sector, visible in the amendments adopted by the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, as is the case with point k (whereas, due to the growth of the world's population, there is an increasing demand for energy, so forests must play a more important role in the EU's future energy mix).

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report because the proposals and improvements it contains are commendable and not only provide for quality of life, sustainability, jobs and added value for forests and forestry, but also guarantee them.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the new strategy for the protection and protection of our forest heritage, because Europe must have a great ecological footprint of environmental sustainability. Forests can no longer be used as a "basis" for future cementing nor can they be left to themselves by virtue of a "geographic divide" whereby there are those who live in the city and those who do not live in the city. The construction of a new Europe also involves being able to exploit its heritage intelligently and strategically; not to phase it out (less cement, more sustainability), but to use it as a resource for the community and as a possibility for the future: from clean energy to heritage protection.

name: Henna Virkkunen (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 Sustainably managed forests are of great importance for the well-being of the whole of Europe. Forests are important places for recreation, but also sources of growth and jobs. European timber and forestry companies are therefore aiming to create 80 000 new jobs in the sector. Forests are of particular importance to my own country: 76% of Finland's area is forest and forests account for 4% of GDP. Finland also has the highest proportion of protected forests in Europe: we have far fewer forests being felled than they grow in a year.  It is good that the EU forestry strategy is now looking at forests in a more diverse way. Forests are important carbon sinks and play an important role in the fight against climate change. However, that is no reason not to exploit and care for forests, quite the contrary. Sustainable forest management also enables the economic exploitation of forests, even more extensively than at present. Sustainably managed forests are the source of renewable energy, the creator of growth and jobs, and the engine of rural development. It is important to invest in research and product development in the field. For example, we should increase wood construction in Europe. Although the member states have the power to take decisions on forestry policy, as they should be, the national forest databases of the various Member States should be merged at European level. In this way, we would have better and more up-to-date knowledge of our forests at EU level.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the new EU forestry strategy for forests and the forest-based sector. The European Union should contribute to supporting national policies in achieving active and sustainable forest management. It is very important to support the management of different types of forests and to strengthen cooperation in the face of existing cross-border threats. Let us remember that the responsibility for forestry lies with the Member States, so the principle of subsidiarity must be respected and the differences of preferences between countries, their regional conditions or ownership models must be respected. The European Union should stop imposing new market restrictions on forest and wood-based products and, through these measures, ensure the application of the principles of market freedom. An additional valuable asset will be the European Forest Information System, which aims to support the exchange of data, best practices and up-to-date knowledge of forests in individual Member States, which will contribute to the active development of this sector of the economy.

name: Glenis Willmott (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This vote concerns the proposed new EU forest strategy, which would replace the now outdated 1993 version. The new strategy focuses on sustainable forest management and establishes objectives for the industry up to 2020, including job creation and contribution to a bio-based economy. It also addresses new issues like climate change, over-exploitation and loss of biodiversity. Forests are major contributors to our climate-change mitigation efforts and have the potential to make an even greater contribution.
