Labour MEPs voted in favour of this report because this new forest strategy will increase European forest cover and enable us to actively manage our forests, creating skilled jobs while helping to combat climate change.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted for the Report on 'A new EU strategy for forests and the forestry sector'. I welcome colleague Elisabeth Köstinger's initiative to produce a report recommending to the Commission the strengthening of the Standing Forestry Committee, which, in her view, could hinder parallel and divergent approaches at European level with regard to this sector. I believe that the EU's new forest strategy must focus on better coordination so that forestry and forests are better positioned in European strategies and have a more coherent approach. I believe that our country is directly interested in promoting a coherent strategy in this area at European level.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The report on the new forestry strategy aims to update the European framework for action on forests that support sustainable forest management. In reality, however, it represents the interests of private forest owners, disregarding the interests of state forests. Meanwhile, Polish forestry is a model for the concept of sustainable development, a concept that the EU relies on in almost every document. The fact that this is the case is evidenced by the UNESCO Award awarded to Polish State Forests in 2013. Furthermore, the objectives of the strategy do not take into account the relevant objectives. It must be borne in mind that carbon dioxide is the gas of life, and the management of this gas is the basis of ecological engineering for the regeneration of agricultural and forestry soils, the production of a renewable energy source such as biomass and the development of the desired biodiversity. The rapporteur also did not include in the compromise text important amendments for the state forests, which were tabled by PiS Members at a meeting of the Committee on Agriculture. I therefore voted against the report.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI)
text: Writing. – The JRC voted against the report because it subjugates forests and their management to the competitiveness of the industry's monopolistic groups supported by EU funds (from Horizon 2020) and other facilities, within the framework of the EU's energy self-sufficiency policy and its competition with other imperialist centres. The resolution of forest problems (biodiversity reduction, illegal logging) is entrusted to forest owners, contractors and monopolies in the sector who cooperate with governments that invest on the basis of the profit of forestry enterprises and strike at the rights of foresters, in practice undermining and completely invalidateing the right of the people to recreation. References to sustainable development, the green economy, climate change, forest biomass as a renewable energy source and the protection of biodiversity hide nothing but new areas of profitability for monopolies that turn land and forests further into a multi-exploited commodity. Forests are social property and the integrated protection and management of forest ecosystems for the benefit of the people can only be realised when power and economy are in the hands of the people.

name: Kosma Złotowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Wood is a strategic national good which, like deposits of other natural resources, should be protected and treated particularly. The fact that it is a renewable good should not result in its exploitation in an irrational manner, placing the current economic interest above a rational approach to the use of resources. State-owned forest companies play an important role in protecting against forest robbery. Compared to private companies, they are a model for the concept of sustainable development, which is widely present in the European Union's environmental policy. The Polish State Forests operating in my country are the best example of this, as evidenced by the UNESCO Award awarded to this company in 2013. For this reason, I cannot support a report which puts the interests of private forest owners at the fore, disregarding the interests of state forests.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report refers to the new European forest strategy presented by the European Commission. This new strategy presents some improvements, in particular in the recognition of the multifunctionality of forests, i.e. the recognition that the forest serves the social, environmental and economic interests, as well as the interests of all ecosystems that exist in it. This strategy fails, however, as to the non-recognition of the growing conflicts between the various sectors that depend on the forest and the growing demand for biomass from the energy sector However, the report presented to us today by the European Parliament comes amid pressure from large groups linked to timber production and the energy sector, visible in the amendments adopted by the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development , as is the case with point k. We abstained.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the new EU forestry strategy (for forests and the forestry sector) because some Union policies may affect individual member states' forestry policies, even though they have the power to decide on forestry and forests by the Member States themselves. Although more than half of the territory in some countries is covered by forests, EU citizens know little about forestry and the impact of forests on health, climate, environment and jobs due to urbanisation. Sustainable managed forests are of paramount importance for the local, regional, European and international levels and for the provision of jobs in rural areas, while also providing benefits for human health, and make an important contribution to the protection of the environment and climate and to biodiversity. Wood is a renewable resource and its sustainable use can also be ensured through the exchange of expertise. Cross-border exchange of information is also important for spreading awareness that only healthy and stable mountain forests can fully perform their function of protection for people and nature by stopping avalanches and falling rocks and acting as natural flood protection. More than 3 million European citizens are employed in the forestry sector, and the long-term competitiveness of this sector will only be achieved through a properly trained workforce.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the debate on the Commission statement on the decision adopted on the European Security Agenda (2015/2625(RSP)).

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, all European states and all European citizens should have the right to live their lives in safe, secure and tolerant societies, but we are painfully aware that there are constant and evolving threats to our internal security. The recent terrorist attacks in Brussels, Paris and Copenhagen shocked us all. Europeans were united in the response to terror. We will fight terrorism jointly and we will stand firm in defending European values, freedoms and the rule of law.  Instability in Europe’s neighbourhood and radicalisation in our societies at home mean that the terrorist threat is real and present. Organised crime groups continue their illicit activities and will find ways to exploit evolving technologies, changes in the economy and societal developments to make money by robbing law-abiding communities, by the trafficking of people, drugs and firearms, or by facilitating illegal migration or any number of cross-border criminal activities.  The internet and e-commerce offer huge advantages for Europeans as individuals and for our companies, but it is also a new playground for cyber- criminals. These criminal activities increasingly feed each other: a terrorist cyber-attack on critical infrastructure, firearms trafficking that provides weapons for criminals, and drugs money that ends up financing terrorism. Dirty money is the fuel that keeps all these criminal activities going.  These criminal and terrorist networks also operate very effectively across borders, so whilst national security remains primarily a matter for Member States, there is clear added value in European cooperation to address the nexus between these criminal activities. Today, we present a European security agenda which updates and renews the former internal security strategy, and I call on this House and on Member States to sign up to it and share it as our agenda for working better together on security. Because in this area, no single European country is able to effectively tackle the challenges on its own.  Over the past decade the EU, with great help from this House, has put in place a European security framework for information exchange, for operational cooperation, for pooling of knowledge and expertise, for better coordination, including via European agencies such as Europol and Eurojust. It is a framework that complements and enhances the essential work that national authorities do every day and helps them to be more effective in fighting cross-border crime and terrorism.  There have been numerous success stories. In 2014, Operation Archimedes brought thousands of police officers from several Member States together in a joint one-week exercise which delivered impressive results: 1 150 criminals arrested, out of them 90 human traffickers and 170 facilitators to illegal immigration; one million euros in cash seized and tonnes of various types of drugs seized. This is just one example of what can be achieved when law enforcement follows a multidisciplinary and multinational approach.  But our analysis suggests that Member States are still under-using this framework for coordination, information exchange and cooperation. There is still mistrust and reticence to cooperate even more closely by using the tools in place to the full. We need to change the culture and modus operandi of our law enforcement community. So the most important message of the agenda is that, together, we need to make an effort to be more effective in providing security to our citizens. The Lisbon Treaty has given us the right basis by bringing this area into the normal Treaty structure, and giving this House the responsibility which you are effectively seizing, to co-decide legislation and exercise democratic scrutiny in this area. Working better together means also in full compliance with fundamental rights and respecting the principles of necessity and proportionality. Our agenda is very concrete and detailed on what needs to be done. As this House has suggested in its resolution on the future internal security strategy, the focus is on the better use or sharpening of the existing instruments before proposing new ones.  Firstly, we have a number of ongoing legislative proposals that need to be agreed by the co-legislators as soon as possible – the reform of Europol, Eurojust, and CEPOL, as well as data protection reform, without forgetting EU PNR and PNR sharing agreements with third countries.  Secondly, we have identified a number of legislative instruments that need to be reviewed – our 2008 terrorism framework decision, which currently does not cover foreign fighters, and our Firearms Directive which the ongoing evaluation shows is clearly not stringent enough. It is unacceptable that a Kalashnikov can be bought easily on the internet. We also need to update our main legal tool in fighting fraud and counterfeiting non-cash means of payment, which dates back to 2001, to today’s reality in financial payments, virtual money included. If we want to be ahead of fast-evolving environmental crimes, we will need to have a fresh look at the legislative framework on sanctions. The exploratory work, as requested by co-legislators, on the non-conviction-based confiscation of criminally acquired property, will also continue. The existing criminal record sharing database needs to be improved, because we need to share these data better so that we can also cover third-country nationals who have committed crime in Europe.  As you see, there is quite a lot of work on the table, also for the European Parliament, so anybody who complains that Timmermans is not giving you enough work, please look at this agenda. Thirdly, the agenda will require extra effort from the full national and European law enforcement community to transform it into operational reality. We need more sharing of data, effective operational cooperation and additional trust—building measures. In particular we should develop judicial cooperation to complement law enforcement cooperation. The existing European agencies need to be sufficiently equipped and work together more closely. The Commission will align the available financial resources to the priorities of the agenda.  Whilst this framework is of course suited to tackling all sorts of threats to internal security, given today’s challenges we need to focus our attention on the three challenges I have mentioned – terrorism, organised crime and cybercrime. The challenges are not new but they have become more varied and complex. We need to do better. Our existing law enforcement tools and cooperation methods are not sufficient. We need to do better.  Both the European Parliament and the national parliaments will be part of the monitoring process of the implementation of the agenda. We are proposing a twice-yearly discussion with this House on the implementation of the agenda. Such a regular joint stocktaking will allow us to be more forward-looking and easily adaptable to evolving situations. I think it is now important, if you permit, Mr President, that I hand over to Dimitris Avramopoulos who is primarily responsible for this file as Commissioner.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members I am particularly happy to present to you here in the European Parliament the Agenda, as adopted by the Commission just three minutes ago. It could not be fresher!  The European citizens expect from all of us that we work together, in a coordinated way, in order to ensure their security and protect their rights and freedom. They expect from us that we trust each other, share information and effectively work together to coordinate concrete actions and operations. Because new and complex security threats have emerged, that are increasingly cross-border and cross-sectorial in nature, we cannot but face them together. This is the meaning of the shared Agenda that we put to your and to Member States’ consideration. It is a common Agenda based on principles and priorities, on which we should all – Parliament, Member States, the Commission and its Agencies – play our role in ensuring our citizens’ security. That is why we are asking you to evaluate and endorse this agenda. We will have the opportunity of debating and working together on each specific element of this Agenda in the next five years, but today I think it is important to agree on a common European Agenda on Security in order to meet citizens’ expectations. The Agenda sets out five key principles that should guide EU action on security. Firstly, full compliance with fundamental rights. Secondly, transparency, accountability and democratic control for citizens’ confidence. The European Parliament plays a key role in this. Thirdly, better application and implementation of existing instruments, as this House has as well requested many times, before assessing whether additional EU tools are necessary, in full compliance with the principles of necessity and proportionality. Fourthly, full use of EU agencies and all EU policies that contribute – directly or indirectly – to security. Fifthly, to bring together all internal and external dimensions of security with a targeted coordination of our internal and foreign policies. For instance, we will present a consistent EU approach for all future PNR requests from third countries. The Agenda sets out concrete actions to turn these key principles into a political reality. For example, in December 2014, this House adopted a resolution on what it considered the necessary elements of an EU strategy on internal security and you made clear that the utmost priority was to use better the existing instruments, both at legislative and operational level. We have listened very carefully and put this principle into action in this Agenda. Look for example to our proposal for enhancing the existing capacities of Europol. It is not a question of creating new information networks, but to make sure that all information already available in the Member States is also put at the disposal of Europol, under its strict framework for data protection. The Centre would therefore assemble in one single structure the functions already existing in the Agency on terrorist financing, illicit trafficking of firearms and foreign terrorist fighters, as well as on detection of violent extremist content online. Eurojust will also be associated with the Centre. This new capacity will support more effectively the action of Member States in their investigations and prosecutions of terrorist cases. This is our main goal: to make sure that the Agency is able to fully implement its mandate. Let me now present the three main priorities we will address in the next five years. Firstly, tackling terrorism. As you will see, we will not only work on repressive measures but we will also focus on prevention. Social cohesion policy, education, employment, justice, but also the cooperation with key third countries, are crucial for the EU response to address the root causes of extremism and radicalisation. The Commission will set up a Centre of Excellence to collect and disseminate expertise on anti-radicalisation, building upon the Radicalisation Awareness Network. This will strengthen the exchange of experience among practitioners directly engaged in preventing radicalisation and violent extremism at local level. We plan to update the Framework Decision on Terrorism: to provide a more coherent legal framework to deal with the foreign fighters phenomenon. This will allow for intensified cooperation with third countries on this issue. We will also launch an EU Forum with major IT companies to counter terrorist propaganda on the Internet and in social media. Secondly, disrupting organised crime: we go through various forms of organised crime linked by one principle: cutting the financing of criminals. The cooperation between competent authorities in Europe, in particular national Financial Intelligence Units, which will be connected to Europol, will be strengthened while we will assess the necessity of new legislation to counter terrorist financing and improve confiscation of property derived from criminal activities. We plan to strength the legal framework on firearms to address the illegal trafficking and reactivation of weapons, to establish common standards, share more information and boost cooperation with third countries. And I cannot today refrain from mentioning our priority to fight the organised criminals exploiting the need of some people for protection and better life perspectives, in other words, smugglers and traffickers. Thirdly, fighting cybercrime: one of our priorities is to assess whether the current tools for the law-enforcement authorities are sufficient to address online investigations notably on issues of competent jurisdiction and rules on access to internet-based evidence and information. These three areas are interlinked and have a strong relevance to cross-border crime. It is exactly here where the European Union and its actions can make a real difference for ensuring security. The Agenda also proposes steps to strengthen the pillars of EU action on internal security: better information exchange; increased operational cooperation; more targeted support through training, funding, research and innovation. It is through these actions that the European Union gives added value to the work of Member States.  These three pillars are the ones based on which this Agenda can evolve in the course of five years to adapt to new threats and challenges. This was just a brief presentation of the European Agenda on Security adopted, as I said at the beginning, by the Commission today. I want to stress, to underscore again: this Agenda is not just the response to the recent tragic events. This Agenda has been a priority for President Juncker and this Commission and defines the Union’s approach to internal security that is based on our common values, including the rule of law and fundamental rights. It also has to be seen in conjunction with the future Agenda on Migration which will further develop issues of border management and smuggling of migrants. I look forward to a deep and, as always, sincere cooperation with you in order very soon to be in a position to deliver what we have assumed as a responsibility in the eyes of European public opinion, European citizens, to guarantee their safety and security.

name: President. –
text: Thank you, Commissioner, and also for the news coming from the College on better inter-institutional regulation. We are happy about this strong link between the Commission and the European Parliament.

name: Monika Hohlmeier
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Commissioners, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Commissioners for their excellent work and for the work she has First of all, I would like to express my sincere thanks to the two Commissioners – you, Mr Timmermans, and you, Mr Avramopoulos – for presenting your priority to us so promptly and so quickly in this Parliament. I was the first to take on board the fact that the Commission wants to make the issue of security a priority. Secondly, I have welcomed the fact that existing instruments should be strengthened and optimised and that they should be used in an improved way. There are certainly opportunities in the area of Prüm, as well as in other areas of data exchange, for optimisation, improvement and a strong stringency in terms of data exchange, which this House has called for across party lines. I also think it is very positive that you want to review and address the European crime record EPRIS with cross-border access to information from national criminal records, as well as to see a common information space for the maritime sector increasingly optimised. However, I have one more question in this regard – or I am keen to make it very clear: I sometimes have the impression that the Commission is very cautious about the staff for the organisations that are supposed to make this true, such as Europol. We have an EC3, now we want to add a counter-terrorism centre or a platform, whatever, but they also need the staff to be able to deal with the relevant processes in the first place. Europol is already unable to handle almost 50% of Member States' requests due to a lack of staff. And these are not innocuous requests. Hence the specific request to consider the necessary staff for the steps for which we need it.

name: Birgit Sippel
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr Avramopoulos has started his speech by saying that, of course, fundamental rights must be respected and that we need democratic control. I strongly agree with that. At the same time, however, I have the impression that it is extremely dramatic that we have to mention such self-evident things over and over again. Mr Timmermans said: "Everyone wants to live safely." I would add that this certainly applies to at least 99% of all people who are legally resident in our Member States. Living together safely and peacefully – I think everyone agrees with me – is a very bad guide to fear, intolerance and ignorance. I therefore welcome the fact that the Commission also wants to take a step forward in the area of integration and social inclusion, because radicalisation is directed in both directions: some become Islamists and plan attacks, and on the other hand, the other people in our states are also radicalising themselves by rejecting everything foreign. That is why inclusion is a task that is addressed to many groups in our population. I therefore also welcome the issue of centres of excellence, because I believe that it is right to put our finger in the wound and make it clear where there is still some catching up to do in our Member States, but we must also promote with the best examples of how things can be brought forward. First of all, the Commissioners have made it clear that the full implementation of existing measures should be concentrated. I agree with that. And I hope that this Commission will actually have the strength to raise its fist on the table with the Council, too, so that this actually takes place. I have a group of visitors and, unfortunately, I cannot follow the debate to the end. But I find it highly dramatic that our Member States, together with us, are passing legislation here and then forgetting the whole thing on the way to the capitals and not implementing it. We need clear mechanisms for this. It is true that we must combat trafficking in human beings. We have adopted a directive on this here at European level. But to mention migration in this context of security policy, so that we get the impression that refugees are a problem, I do not think that is very clever.

name: Timothy Kirkhope
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, never has a coherent and effective security strategy been more important to the security and safety of our citizens. The threats we face are evolving, growing and diversifying. We need a strategy that places both the protection of people’s lives and their liberties at its heart. My priorities are clear: the adoption of the EU PNR Directive before the end of the year, as committed to by this Parliament.  In order for us to address the root causes of radicalisation, our fight against terrorism needs to be dynamic and diverse. We need to look at combating radicalisation in prisons, recruitment online, in schools and in communities, as well as equipping ourselves with essential law-enforcement tools to prevent and prosecute terrorist offences across borders. Child exploitation online is on the increase and we need to make sure that Europol has the resources to ensure that it can do the incredibly important work that it is charged with. Member States need to start sharing information better, and they need to do it more quickly and more effectively.  The Commission needs to ensure that the legislation we already have is being implemented consistently across all countries and that we do not have weak links in our fight against criminality.

name: Sophia in 't Veld
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, firstly I note that, as usual, the Council is absent. But then they do not have to be here because they probably already read about the document, that was adopted 30 minutes ago, last weekend in the German newspaper Die Welt where the Commission was extensively quoted. My Group thinks that there are very positive elements in the paper – such as the focus on better information sharing and the importance of fundamental rights and data protection – but unfortunately the paper is short on concrete proposals. One glaring omission in this paper is the evaluation of existing measures. Commissioner Timmermans referred to it, but where is the evaluation? Maybe this will also be in Die Welt next weekend – I can't wait. So rather than proposing a whole raft of new measures, we should start with evaluating the existing toolkit, because you are the champion of better lawmaking, and I think evaluation is a part of better lawmaking. Proposals to expand the role of Europol are certainly interesting, but setting up this whole new structure must be done in a proper parliamentary process in the context of the current revision of the Europol statute, and not sneakily via the back door of a mere Commission communication. The revision of the Transparency Regulation is long overdue, but the Commission and the absent Member States stubbornly defend the old culture of secrecy, deliberately keeping citizens at a distance and refusing accountability. So I hope you are going to include this in your paper as well. My Group is also worried about the increasingly blurred lines between policing and intelligence and security tasks, and the inflationary use of the term ‘national security’, without any proper legal definition. The proposals in the package also create a strange hybrid of national and European powers that leave citizens in the dark as to the applicable law. The proposals further weaken checks and balances, the very core of the democratic rule of law. ALDE firmly supports the achievement of a fully-fledged European area of freedom, security and justice, but always based on the principle of no new powers without more safeguards.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, who says security also speaks of respect for freedoms and justice, three axes which are inextricably linked. In your program, beyond words, the security prism largely predominates. There can be no security and security without respect for fundamental rights. In the European Union, we are regressing in this area. We all know why, as has already been said. The Member States are keeping our hands, we are increasingly favouring repression over prevention and terrorism is becoming an obsession, to the detriment, whatever you say, of the fight against organised crime. However, the two, as we all know, are inextricably linked.  Priority has been given to the fight against radicalisation and thus jihadist networks, and the link is being made to migration issues. These attacks mark public opinion: they are violent, the deadliest, but they represent only 5% of terrorist attacks in the European Union. Are the priorities really tailored to the need for citizens' security, or are they a short-term response to media pressure that also overestimates Islamic terrorism? The key is police cooperation. However, beyond the rhetoric we know that it is not working well, including because budgetary and human resources are being reduced. However, the Commission has new powers. In the event of non-compliance with fundamental rights, particularly by Member States, how does it really intend to combat the questioning of these rights by security policies? This is the European Patriot Act. Yet when we look at what is happening in the United States, we see that that is not the key. It is time to return to the fundamentals of the rule of law and respect for citizens' rights. It must be remembered that the principles of necessity and proportionality must be at the heart of security policies.  Since you have been Commissioner, Mr Avramopoulos, you have been feeding us your speeches. As for the deeds, I am skeptical!

name: Judith Sargentini
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – I think it is time for a reappraisal of old-fashioned police investigations. Let me remind you that in the terrorist attacks of late, the terrorists were known and, until some point, followed by the police and not after that. Instead of revaluing old-fashioned police investigations, the European Commission seems to want to store flights in more data. I don't think that's a productive way. In fact, I think that is dangerous because it diverts attention from following individuals who are suspected. To then return to PNR (storing passenger data), while the European Parliament has been asking for years for papers to show that this helps, does not seem to me to be the right way forward. Then judicial cooperation. Yes, of course there will have to be more cooperation between Member States in detecting terrorists and criminals. But this includes a solution to the problem of 'trusting each other', because until now European Member States do not trust each other. We've also seen what happens to suspects falling between shore and ship. My question to the Commission is: do you have any plans to improve that? Cybersecurity. What is the European Commission's position on the individual's right to protect himself from government-run? After the Snowden revelations and the NSA affair, it seems necessary to protect yourself better. But that means that Member States may be less able to monitor their own citizens. I have the impression that it is not appreciated if citizens are going to protect themselves better. Finally, Mr President, more European internal security means more cooperation. But that calls for more democratic control at European level. Does the European Commission also have a proposal on how we can increase the democratic content of our security policy?

name: David Borrelli
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the vulnerability of advanced democratic societies, based on respect for rights and freedoms, is clear to everyone.  The threats are multiple and often unsuspected: think of the use of drones for civilian use, or the common and widespread use of so-called "dual use" chemicals. There are inconsistencies in our security systems that cannot yet be overcome. One of the biggest problems is undoubtedly the illegal arms trade, which is strictly prohibited in respect of states considered to be at the origin of terrorist activities, and it reappears in legitimised forms in the trade in arms components. Great efforts have been made at European level to harmonise and strengthen the rules on arms control, but when we move towards the effectiveness of the implementation and control mechanisms, we see that harmful differences persist. Effective cooperation at European level is still an unfinished objective.  The dynamics of the events in Paris are clear: the threat of this new 'domestic terrorism', which is often intertwined with organised crime, makes use of structures, contacts and armaments from other countries. These terrorists use our fundamental freedoms to hide, move and strike. This is happening both within Europe and in neighbouring countries, both in the East and in the Middle East.  I am referring here to another disturbing aspect of this affair: foreign fighters. As is well known, the 'negative added value' of these is the ability to travel and move easily within and outside Europe's borders. It is clear, therefore, that without active police and intelligence cooperation – I am thinking, for example, of strengthening the automatic fingerprint identification system – we will not be able to monitor these criminals effectively. The obstacles preventing or slowing down this cooperation must therefore be identified and removed decisively.  But beware of the "Trojan horses". Fear must not be an alibi for compressing our fundamental freedoms. Terrorism is not combated by preventing our citizens from travelling, nor by systematically violating our privacy. We need greater efficiency in the coordination of police forces and greater exchange of targeted information. This synergy must also involve the private sector and NGOs active in this field.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI). Mr President, Europe faces many risks, visible and not. Old and new threats form an extremely uncertain international environment, where asymmetric and hybrid threats have now been added to conventional threats. If we add to them the economic crisis, the outbreak of terrorism, illegal immigration and errors in the implementation of European policies, then the connection and interaction of all these factors make up an extremely unstable and unpredictable security environment. The causes many and the security problems even more. The rise of religious fundamentalism, civil conflicts, large flows of illegal immigrants, the collapse of the concept of state in adjacent areas and their substitution by extremist organisations such as ISIS, combined with economic, political and social differences and inequalities, globalisation and many others, are only part of the problem. A calm and decisive response is needed at national but above all at Community level. We need constructive dialogue and a climate of trust, projects are needed, not words. Without cooperation and solidarity in the field of defence and security, Europe will not be able to cope with the threats that null and void any attempt to establish an environment of peace, development and sustainability.

name: Agustín Díaz de Mera García Consuegra (PPE).
text: – Mr President, as regards the document, I share the substance, I agree with it; The way, no. It is not only a question, Mr Vice-President and Commissioner, of being able to listen, but of being able to read. And I am not worth the argument that the Commission approved it three minutes ago, at the moment, half an hour ago. No, no, because the media is called up for immediately after. We want to read the document in depth. So, after a superficial reading, what can I say? I can say that I agree with what are called 'priorities in terms of threat', namely terror, organised crime and cybercrime. I also agree with the five lines underpinning the philosophical principles, of course: fundamental rights, democratic control and transparency, monetisation of existing instruments, coordination of internal and foreign policies, and strengthening the control and cooperation of European agencies, which are too many in the field of security and which are not all well coordinated. Anyway, I approve of the substance, but I think it's insufficient. Insufficient why? Insufficient because we have to present, Commissioner, Mr Vice-President, as soon as possible, the Internal Security Strategy 2015-2019. It is a commitment that must be fulfilled, as soon as possible, as a complement to the Agenda. And finally, a curiosity. Look, the 25 pages mention the words "fundamental rights" 27 times – it's fine; 'border control' once; "migration", three times; "trafficking of human beings", eight times; and "PNR", 14 times.  It's a very hasty analysis. The machine—the machine!—has given me this answer. But in any case, as soon as possible, Mr Vice-President and Commissioner, the Internal Security Strategy 2015-2019.

name: Tanja Fajon (S&D).
text: – In the fight against terrorism, our most powerful tool is awareness and education for young people. I agree that we need a coordinated and comprehensive response and that human rights protection must be at the heart of the security strategy. As well as making better use of existing security policies. New measures such as PNR, smart borders, must be considered with clear data protection safeguards. In the strategy, however, I miss the social aspect, poverty, inequality, the importance of family, school, peers. These are the first to detect the first symptoms of radicalization. I also miss the strategy for returning young people who want to leave Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, and a clear analysis of the roots of the new phenomenon of European foreign fighters. As a last but no less important, I call on the Commission, among other things, to include on the agenda the issue of introducing parental permission to travel minors abroad.

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The security of the European Union requires close cooperation between states. However, the Treaty principle of the member state's responsibility for national security has already been violated by regulations such as the asylum package. There are two fundamental factors of external security that affect our internal security: one is Daesh and its consequences, but the other is the aggression of the Russian Federation on Ukraine. Fortunately limited, but with elements of hybrid warfare, with political destabilization, with aggressive propaganda. This situation requires adequate countermeasures on our part.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD).
text: – In view of developments in the security situation in Europe due to new conflicts and upheavals in the immediate neighbourhood, increasing radicalisation, violent violence and the risk of terrorism, the updating of the European Union's internal security strategy is a major challenge in eliminating dangerous processes that are taking on new features.  The focus must be on areas such as cybersecurity, trafficking in human beings, the fight against terrorism, organised crime, money laundering and corruption. However, even in this difficult period, the strategy should maintain the fundamental human rights and freedoms: that is, the privacy of private life, the right to have one's say and to express it in public. The new strategy and new challenges cannot lead to unjustified surveillance and suspicion of every citizen, universal control of electronic means of communication and prejudices regarding the loyalty of one or another citizen to their country and the idea of a Europe of nations.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI).
text: Mr President, on 7 January, 17 people were killed in France in the attack by Islamist terrorists on Charlie Hebdo and then on a kosher grocery store. French Jews were killed because they were Jews, policemen because they represented the republican order, the press and freedom of expression were attacked by bloodthirsty lunatics. Since these deadly attacks, François Hollande has launched a grand plan against Islamophobia, but has done nothing against the proven culprit of the attacks: radical Islamism. Nothing has been done to strengthen our borders. Terrorists and weapons always pass without any control from one European country to another. Nothing has been done to combat illegal immigration and we hear voices calling for even more immigrants on our soil. However, the President of Libya's Constituent Assembly and Italy's Foreign Minister have said that the European Union underestimates the risk of islamist militants infiltrating Europe, hidden among refugees. Nothing has been done to control Salafist preaching in mosques and nothing has been done in schools to restore authority and discipline or to assimilate young immigrants by teaching, in history, the national novel, the crucible of a thousand-year-old France. Seventeen dead plus a young woman, still, a few days ago, killed by a fundamentalist, but nothing to permanently stop Islamist terrorism.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I, too, would like to join those who thank you for coming to discuss this with us today, and next time I would like us to get this strategy on the table really early and to be able to study it. However, my message is not critical, but positive. As I have said several times here, ensuring the safety of European citizens is an absolute priority for me. This new security programme must therefore have a clear objective. Objective one is to combat terrorism, organised crime and cybercrime effectively. But objective two is also to focus on the very essence of human rights.  Commissioner, the security strategy must be such for the citizens of the European Union that it guarantees them freedom and not restrictions in any form. I do not want to repeat what has already been said here. We all know that the European strategy has no chance of success without working closely with third countries. Therefore, I would like to add one thing to your strategy, which you did not mention. I want you to establish cooperation with less attractive countries such as Egypt, Israel, Jordan, Tunisia, Morocco and Ukraine, in addition to the traditional partners with whom we cooperate in the field of security. These countries, too, have great experience in the fight against terrorism and have a lot to offer us.

name: Knut Fleckenstein (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Of course, we welcome the Commission's ambitions to improve coordination at European level, particularly in this important area. The approach is right that the agenda on security must be a common agenda – from the Member States and the Union. However, I do not want to hide the fact that we are a little disappointed with the foreign policy part, which has largely been left out, probably by pointing out that there will be additional work in the context of the revision. We would have liked to have had a jointly coordinated report. We welcome the fact that the Commission wants to cooperate even more preventively with third countries. It is a good example that the work of the RAN Centre of Excellence on de-radicalisation will also be available to countries such as Turkey, the Western Balkans, the Middle East and North Africa in the future and will be expanded. Counter-terrorism measures must, as you said, Mr Vice-President, we agree with, go hand in hand with a dialogue on human rights and the rule of law. Otherwise, we may otherwise be providing the breeding ground for radicalisation. At the end of the day, we must look at one point in particular, namely how to stop the arms trade and the financing of terror. However, I am very surprised that you have yet to examine the need for further action in the area of terrorist financing. I'm sure this is a typo that can be fixed in the next issue.

name: Georg Mayer (NI).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The cooperation of the security authorities is certainly a very important contribution to the fight against crime on this issue. However, I would like to mention two things that i have missed from the Commission's agenda here. One is that it must be borne in mind that crime is now mobile and very flexible. Cross-border is part of the daily business of criminals and terrorists. I therefore believe that there is an urgent need to reintroduce border controls in order to remove criminals from circulation. I stress this: border controls are also introduced from time to time in the Schengen area, it should be noted. And you have probably forgotten to mention that much of these problems go hand in hand with the migration problem, be they European jihadists or gang criminals. We also know that a good proportion of the smuggling gangs that carry the refugees across the Mediterranean channel much of the funds they are pouring into terrorism in Europe. In other words, it is an imported problem. Please do not forget this in your deliberations.

name: Michał Boni (PPE).
text: – Mr President, we need a comprehensive action plan that covers the internal and external dimension of security and horizontally connects various sectors under clear rules as described in the document. Fighting against cybercrime is a key challenge; with the loss of more than EUR 300 billion every year, each of us can become a victim of cybercrime. I am pleased to see that cybercrime is one of the top three priorities in the European Agenda on Security. Very often now, cyberspace creates the framework for organised crime and terrorism. We need to set the rules, use modern technologies to find appropriate tools and build public-private cooperation. There are new technological possibilities which allow for processing the data – not personal data: frequencies of data set transfers, photos by spectrum of colour analysis – and preventing crimes. Research and innovation can be a successful source for new forms of security. This is the new concept of data-driven security. The fight against organised crime remains high on the agenda, but we need to make the anti-terrorism policy more effective by adoption of the PNR Directive, by more resources dedicated to fighting radicalisation, and by better use of algorithms supporting the early warning system. We need the synergy of cooperating EU institutions to be able to gather enough resources and to efficiently exchange information under clear rules of privacy protection. I believe that the European Cybercrime and Counter-Terrorism Centres in Europol should be further strengthened.

name: Jörg Leichtfried (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I would like to mention three things in a nutshell. As has already been said, why has the Commission not evaluated what has worked so far and what has not worked? I always have the feeling that we are pushing ahead with thousands of new regulations, but to see if this really does bring anything, we need to know what has already worked and what has been good and what has been bad. That is a point that I would like to ask for. The second point is this: I refuse and do not want such things to be introduced through the back door in Europe. When we talk about an anti-terrorist centre or a reporting centre for Internet content, whatever that is, it must come to the European Parliament before such a thing comes. It is not acceptable for the Commission to set up such things through any legal acts that pass us by. My third point is this: how can I understand it when the paper refers to consideration for the needs of law enforcement in the development of new technologies? Can I imagine that when I download a Candycrush app, that app has a back door that then sends all my data to law enforcement? No, I certainly do not want that, ladies and gentlemen. We still have something to discuss.

name: Mario Borghezio (NI).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, faced with the reality that hundreds and perhaps thousands of foreign fighters are quietly moving across internal borders, a fundamental fact emerges: the Schengen system – as we have always said – especially from the point of view of combating Islamic terrorism, is totally inadequate to defend European citizens and their security. This must be admitted, Commissioner, with internal freedom of movement, Europe has become a ploy. That is the reality today, in the light of what is happening.  With regard to the external borders, the continuous influx, now unstoppable to the Italian coast and also to other Mediterranean coasts of illegal immigrants or suspected refugees, allows thousands, in future those who know, tens of thousands, hundreds of thousands – just read Ratier's prophetic book – of possible terrorists – today the Italian Ministry of the Interior also admits this – to enter Europe without any police identification.  Finally, the application of the rules for the control of financial transactions through the Mechanism of Islamic Offerings and the flow of money from immigrants in Europe to Libya is inadequate. It has been documented by an Italian weekly: money arrives to finance the smugglers, the traffickers of human flesh. We must put an end to this shock.

name: Heinz K. Becker (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the As security spokesman for our Austrian delegation, I would like to thank the Commission, the Vice-President and the Commissioner for the excellent security agenda. I can see that the three main areas of the scope of action have been defined very precisely here. These are terrorism, which has been taking place on our doorstep for a long time, organised crime – think of mafia structures and the criminal smuggling gangs that are part of it – and cybercrime. It is unacceptable that cyber crimes should remain unsolved. I would also like to thank you for not forgetting, in all measures, that the fundamental rights of all citizens must be respected and that security and freedom are two equal pillars on which our building is to be built. I would like to express a certain dissatisfaction with what has been said about data retention. Further action could be useful here, bearing in mind that there is longer storage in the financial and banking sectors, and very precisely and neatly. And we want the Internet not to be a lawless space. We want this to be regulated at European level and regulated in accordance with fundamental rights. Compliant with fundamental rights! And I do not want to make excuses: constitutional lawyers should lock themselves up overnight and resolve this. In addition, I would like to see not only the fight against online hate speech being an issue here, but also offline hate speech. I think that a review of existing legislation is needed here.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the security agenda is particularly important today.  The threat of terrorism is obvious, but equally serious, because of its spread in all states is the threat of organised crime, which cannot be underestimated, and is becoming increasingly concerned about cybercrime. Freedom, security and justice are objectives to be pursued in parallel, while always guaranteeing respect for rights.  In the fight against terrorism, I am convinced that we need to make better use of existing regulatory instruments, strengthen police and judicial cooperation, improve the exchange of information and mutual trust. In this regard, I welcome the establishment at Europol of the European Centre for the Fight against Terrorism and the IRU unit, which will have to combat the threats and violent radicalism that are developing on the Internet.   With regard to organised crime, I believe that further legislative progress is also needed, for example on confiscation, and I hope that the Commission can play a driving role with Parliament in this regard.

name: Axel Voss (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the First of all, I would like to thank you for tackling this issue of security more comprehensively here, and the question is therefore also right: how do we actually want to guarantee security in Europe in the future? I do not think that we are good enough in terms of security policy. However, I believe that European security policy-making power will depend on two factors: firstly, on efficiency – civil and military – but also on the political will, which we should also use to shape it together. What I still lacked in your good presentation of a security agenda, however, was the question of a kind of overall concept, the question of security also by the military, NATO, intelligence services, counter-espionage or even the use of new technologies. While this should deter competences, it is part of a comprehensive approach. How do we really want to counter the growing threat – including through cyber attacks – to our economy, to our infrastructures? We also need a defence here that will secure our foundations. According to a new study, many European companies are also affected. Do we not want to think about military matters from time to time, about solutions, how a civilian cyber defence system can also work? I believe that this must go beyond the current situation. In order to do this, we must also approach the structures in order to achieve better results in the end. Cooperation and data exchange are a good start, but we must not stop there. Today, modern security also depends on data analysis. For this we need bank data, travel data, but also communication data. This is a central part of our security in order to be able to guarantee it in the future.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: – The Security Agenda rightly emphasises the need to articulate the resources of the Member States and the Union and their internal and external policies under strategic guidance. But it's time to get past theoretical exercises. We need to put into practice the instruments we already have and those that the Treaty of Lisbon provides us with at the service of an intelligent, comprehensive, capable and under democratic control security strategy.  Fundamental is the awareness that there is no internal security without external security. The bridge between internal and external is well present in the terrorist threat, cyber security, money laundering, this has to be a central axis for the security of the Union, states and citizens.  It is time for states to understand that, as far as security is, it is of no use to think and act for themselves. As seen in the Tragedy of the Mediterranean, in combating trafficking in persons, weapons, drugs, terrorism and organised crime, we need a united Europe that shares information, coordinates policies and resources, respecting fundamental principles and values. We must share the instruments that are now in the hands of the States at the service of the Union. We need to ensure interoperability of systems and technologies and articulate the work of specialised agencies such as Europol, Eurojust, Frontex, etc., with consistent, adequate and resource-appropriate mandates, human and financial resources, for the collective security of the Union and for global security.

name: Γεώργιος Κύρτσος (
text: PPE). Mr President, I think that the European Commission, with its new measures and initiatives, has moved quickly, effectively and institutionally because it is also operating in an environment that is constantly changing and understandably forcing it to develop new initiatives. I believe that most of us want to support such initiatives and I think that one complements the other. In my view, there are two main problems that we have to deal with. The first is this leveling perception of fiscal consolidation that prevents the financing of sound initiatives. We are all complaining, for example, about Europol's limited capacity, but what exactly are we doing to finance it sufficiently to enable it to develop its activity? The second problem we all face together is, I think, national egos in the sense that the Member States alone cannot cope with the problems, and at the same time hesitate to make the necessary European opening and also contribute to the necessary common European solutions.  I think that the issues we are discussing will go up and higher in the range of priorities of public interest, because they concern the average European citizen and because they are expected to concern him even more. This must require us to cooperate more closely and constructively.

name: Kati Piri (S&D).
text: – We are talking today about security in Europe and the Commission's new security agenda. We all agree here that security and protection of fundamental rights must go hand in hand. Here and in the media there is a lot of attention for the European jihadists, but what about the stay-at-home, radicalised young people who do not travel to IS territory but can be at least as dangerous? Is the Commission also paying attention to this group? I welcome the Commission's emphasis on prevention and countering radicalisation. Much more energy needs to be put into this. In addition, potential terrorists are often already known to the intelligence services. The focus should therefore be on better tracking these suspects. Instead of collecting more and more data, cooperation between Member States should be improved, with information shared more frequently and better. Finally, an open democratic society must also be protected from extremists who do not share our values. That is why I ask the Commission whether it is prepared to come forward with a proposal on a joint European ban on entry into the country of hate preachers who come from outside Europe in order to radicalise our young people in our cities.

name: Anna Maria Corazza Bildt (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I welcome the Commission’s agenda for the security of European citizens. First, we should not give up our fundamental freedoms and the open society. To combat terrorism, trafficking and cybercrime we need a joint and coordinated response, and cooperation with third countries; criminal networks are sophisticated and operate across borders. Let us use all of the tools available: the European Arrest Warrant and the Investigation Order; let us strengthen Europol, Eurojust, Eurodac and the Schengen Information System; passport checks at external borders must be improved; and the common databases must be updated with fingerprints and details of stolen and lost passports. We also need to combat the smugglers who exploit desperate migrants. Let us be clear here: opening up legal ways of entry is not enough to reduce illegality and to avoid the tragedies in the Mediterranean. The threat of terrorism in Europe is real and foreign fighters are a reality. It is time for responsibility. We should therefore quickly adopt the EU PNR. Common rules give better protection for privacy and transparency. Member States will continue anyway to access the data, but with fewer safeguards. Of course, short-term measures go hand-in-hand with long-term measures to prevent radicalisation, to promote integration and give access to jobs. I conclude by saying that there is a difference between fundamentalism and the religion of Islam. In Europe there should be zero tolerance against discrimination, hate speech and hate crime.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, although the European Union does not have the typical characteristics of a state in its own sense, it has its roots in democratic values and the rule of law. Our institutions have a duty to regard the security of European citizens as a primary interest, as is a fundamental right.  The worsening of certain conflicts, the advance of Daesh to the gates of our borders, the ideological drift that inspires the action of foreign fighters, require a conscious and long-term response. Because of anti-Europeanism fuelled mainly by national populism, European citizens are bewildered, they have lost confidence in the European institutions. Therefore, I hope that the Commission will make effective use of this opportunity to define precisely the scope of its commitment, aimed at strengthening the Schengen system to support countries most exposed to terrorism.  In order to ensure that the objectives contained in the new European Security Agenda do not remain a dead letter, let us ensure that the all-out fight against terrorist groups and those who use religions as a pretext for sowing hatred and death is fought without hesitation.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I welcome the Common European Agenda, which finally contains issues that we have touched on in isolation since the beginning of this parliamentary term: the Mediterranean, terrorism, Isis, the European PNR, the European Public Prosecutor's Office, which we will be addressing after this debate. Finally together and trying to harmonise.  I – precisely because the Commissioner has also addressed the priority issue of cybercrime – want to say that just these days in Italy, they are shooting videos by so-called terrorists where they appear written saying 'we are on your streets' in Rome and Milan. Therefore, we really must address these issues so that Parliament and the institutions can keep up and even precede the serious problems that European society and citizens are facing.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the old security strategy has expired, but yesterday's priorities are the same, while the risk factors have increased exponentially. Terrorism, first of all, of course, but the strategy for a secure Europe must be 360 degrees and must go through an effective immigration policy, through foreign policy, in cooperation with all the agencies involved and in real cooperation with the national institutions, not forgetting, of course, that terrorism is also fought on the Internet, where information of all kinds is exchanged. In short, action must be global, and many previous speakers have also spoken about this. The old strategy reserved, among other things, an important chapter in the resilience of territories and natural disasters. I believe that this is a fundamental point on which we can continue to work because we are still unprepared in the face of natural disasters whose damage, for example throughout Europe, is not even quantifiable this year. So let us increase our capacity to respond, but also our ability to prevent these phenomena.

name: Christine Revault D'Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D).
text: Mr President, the European Security Programme rightly focuses on the fight against terrorism and cybercrime. The internet and social networks are now among the channels favoured by terrorist groups for the recruitment and dissemination of their hate speech. The internet is also the site of large-scale terrorist attacks, as TV5 Monde, France, recently reported. These attacks deliberately target our freedom of expression and our right to information. The European counter-terrorism strategy must involve the development of real coordination of cyber security between the Union and its Member States, but also with the major internet operators, to counter online terrorist propaganda, under the control of the judicial authorities and while ensuring full respect for freedom of expression. Finally, it is essential to develop counter-speech in order to deconstruct the ideology of violence and hatred propagated by terrorists. Faced with individuals who wish to divide us, let us respond with more common actions and solidarity.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Presidente, ha pronunciato molto bene il mio cognome, cosa che normalmente non si fa in italiano, devo dire. Mr. President, I would like to stress in particular that of course I support this intention to fight terrorism, cross-border crime, all that has been talked about when it comes to internet abuse, but I want to stress that it is important that the freedom of the citizens of Europe remains protected. This is something that is in the blood of our group and I trust all of us in this Parliament and that is why I want to highlight it in particular.  One more thing I want to point out in particular, that's why I asked for my word, which is the fact that in our neighbourhood, in the Balkans, we still have major threats of terrorism. we certainly have very well organised crime and I would ask the Commission to work closely with both Europol and Eurojust and all other institutions with countries and their institutions, candidate countries and potential candidate countries in the Balkans, as I think this is important for our security.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, the EPP MEPs and other colleagues eloquently outline the ways in which police forces and intelligence services can – and should – cooperate in order to combat terrorism, cybercrime, people trafficking and the rest. But this is not the point. Police forces can – and do – cooperate, and have done so for very many years, long before the European Union was even thought of. For example, the UK has been a member of Interpol since 1923. There is also no cooperation greater than that which takes place between the UK and United States intelligence services and security services. The fact of the matter is that the police and intelligence services of all countries can cooperate – and indeed cooperate better – without the paraphernalia of a political union. It is a pity that point is never properly understood nor addressed.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as promised, I am a good man, so I am speaking in a normal way.  My shirt speaks clearly: stop illegal immigration is a bit of a Problem of Europe, that of trying to limit the damage compared to what is happening in Africa, to what are the problems of all these people who arrive in Europe and first of all arrive in Italy.  I just want to make a point. Africans probably need help as adults have to help a child because if when the Renaissance was there we did the Renaissance and many in Africa collected coconuts, today we are in 2015 and many of them still collect coconuts. So we must educate them, we must ensure that they are there, we must help them there, we must ensure that Europe protects itself well, protects its citizens and all these people must help it at home and not at home, or even with a Mediterranean that has become a graveyard, so that the hypocrites and the bad are the ones who encourage these people to come to us. Let's help them there and leave them there.

name: Presidente. –
text: Mr Buonanno, it is not that all the inhabitants of Africa are coconut pickers, there is also an Africa that grows and develops.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I support the report on the adoption of the European Agenda on Security. In fact I think that this Agenda – and I am addressing the First Vice-President of the Commission, Mr Timmermans – should be more ambitious. I do not understand why we, the European Union countries, do not set up a counter-terrorism agency, a European Union agency to fight terrorism.  We know that Member States are currently sharing only a maximum of 50% of the information relating to terrorism. Can we afford to continue in this way? Can we afford to have more terrorist attacks in Europe? It is probably time that we set up together a real counter-terrorism European agency to fight terrorism. We can see that this threat is spreading in Europe and we are going to face tremendous situations in the future if we do not increase cooperation to fight terrorism.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the prime responsibility of any Member State is to provide security for its citizens – and that security is being challenged. The EU strategy is a welcome holistic framework of security policies and tools in place to ensure a joint increased effort to address the rise in terrorism, organised crime and cybercrime. Cross—border cooperation and exchange of information between Europol, European agencies and Member States must be strengthened whilst upholding the right to freedom of movement and privacy of EU citizens.  On the question of radicalisation, it must be stressed that there is a greater need to tackle the underlying causes and the complex nature of radicalisation. It must not only be tackled at EU level, but more so on the ground, at local level. Transmitting values through education, together with the need for inter-faith and inter-cultural dialogue are key components of anti-radicalisation. No minority must feel threatened. This is a fundamental value whatever the belief, faith or background. Hope, peace and security are a must for all European citizens.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D).
text: – The European Security Agenda not only concerns the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime, but requires a comprehensive approach. We need clear rules and effective instruments. We need rules and tools to combat crime in cyberspace, and this has been said several times. If you will allow me, I will address policies that go beyond the security policy agenda. This is, in particular, an overlap in external policy in a way that is essential for the European Union. We must learn to find solutions to intervene better in a case such as Ukraine, in a case such as Syria. We need to better manage immigration and asylum policy. Once again, colleagues have spoken several times about the situation that we have at the moment. Yes, the truth is that we must also learn to explain to our citizens in the Member States of the European Union why it is not possible to close the European Union cyber, why we need to look for ways to help these people in their countries and, consequently, how to find a solution, let us say, to redistribute these immigrants to the European Union, to all Member States, so that it is not only Italy and other countries that are burdened.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. –  Mr President, Honourable Members, first of all I would like to express my thanks for your comments. My very first conclusion is that finally we agree on the basic lines. I am, of course, looking forward to discussing this agenda thoroughly with you in the coming weeks. This House is a crucial partner in the implementation of this shared agenda. Let me answer some of your remarks. First, on Europol, Mrs Hohlmeier asked me a question. I agree that in certain areas it is necessary to reinforce human resources. We have more to do and, as I said at the beginning in my initial remarks, we are moving in that direction. Ms Sippel also made a point. I really understand what you say, but let me reassure you that the Europol Centre will operate within the existing mandate. The ongoing revision of the Europol regulation will reinforce both the data protection framework and the oversight powers of Parliament. This will also apply to the Centre. As I said, this House has made clear that the utmost priority was to use the existing tools better – the existing instruments – both at legislative and operational level. This is exactly what we are doing with the Europol Centre. You also said something about the evaluation and better regulation of current instruments. The First Vice-President, Mr Frans Timmermans, sitting next to me, is the most appropriate person to further elaborate on this. Evaluation has become a major element of all the Commission’s policies. I assure you that the Commission’s Better Regulation Agenda now obliges us to make evaluations every time before we come forward with new proposals.  I would also like to answer Ms Vergiat’s point. I want to assure you that we are working according to the work programme. Actually we have accelerated it. This agenda is our agenda for the next five years. I am looking forward to working with you on this basis. Mr Devedjian, as I said, the issues of migration and border management will be further developed in the agenda on migration. As far as Ms Fajon’s points are concerned, social division and poverty – the root causes of extremism – are addressed and will be developed in cooperation with the competent colleagues. As I said, we will not only work on repressive measures – we will also focus on prevention. Social cohesion policy, education, employment, justice – but also cooperation with key third countries – are crucial for the EU response to address the root causes of radicalisation and extremism.  Mr Fleckenstein, you are right. I agree with you. We do need to bring together, in an effective manner, all internal and external dimensions of security. You know that we are already doing this. We work closely with Federica Mogherini, and you will see many targeted actions in this agenda. I mentioned some: legalisation and firearms are two examples. Then there is the Western Balkans, Turkey and the arc of countries which are facing instability right now. We travel around, and of course we exchange views and work together.  Let me conclude by telling you that European citizens expect us – as I said at the beginning – to trust each other, to share information effectively and to work together to coordinate concrete actions. So we must face all these threats together. When I say together, I mean among all institutions and all Member States – with everybody. Nowadays security matters, and what the citizens of Europe demand and expect from us is to assure them that they can live in a well-protected Europe. Safety, in my view, is also one of the fundamental rights required in order to live in peace.

name: Presidente. –
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. – (2) I welcome today the Commission's "European Agenda for Security", a structured document, with an approach that goes beyond the inflammatory reactions that followed the terrible attacks in Paris and Copenhagen. The communication contains two points that I consider key. First, it recognises that only by preserving our rights and freedoms are we really protecting our citizens from terrorists. A security policy that did not respect them would be a policy that makes terrorists victorious.  Secondly, member states share information. As I have already been advocating, a genuine European area of cooperation based on the exchange of information needs to be stimulated. In this context, the Schengen Information System, the cornerstone, remains with its potential yet to be fulfilled; the same is said of Prüm or the "Swedish Initiative". Despite the debatable reference to new data collection instruments - such as PNRs - the Commission puts its enphematics on those. In a background, a genuine security agenda should promote effective operational cooperation, with information sharing and processing and mutual trust, respecting the fundamental rights of citizens it aims to protect.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE)
text: in writing. – The Commission has come forward with a European Security Agenda (ESA) that aims to create an EU area of internal security, based on a shared agenda between the Member States, and their mutual cooperation. Addressing the need for an inter-agency and cross-sectorial approach and bringing together internal and external dimensions of security is important. The Agenda also points out a general EU weakness. Whereas in principle it has a wide set of different regulations, directives and agreements in place, those are often not applied or implemented in a proper and efficient manner. I hope to see success here when it comes to security.  Speaking about terrorism, the ESA is very much in line with the PPE proposals from January 2015 in aiming at better sharing among Member States, tracking money transfers, strengthening the PNR and other systems. The ESA also proposes a good set of anti—radicalisation measures that aim both to prevent and to rehabilitate. What is missing in my opinion are possible initiatives to counter cyber-terrorism. The need for enhanced external and internal cooperation is self-evident and I would like to see concrete measures proposed.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – "Systematic identification, capture and destruction of vessels used by human traffickers, dismantling of their network, sequestration of their assets": this seems to be the task of the mission of EU High Representative Federica Mogherini. Very clear task, but at the very least, difficult to implement in the Mediterranean where it is intended to locate and destroy the vessels in Libyan ports, before they are used by traffickers, or to capture them if they have already left for the sea. On the EU's responsibility to complete the destabilisation of an entire region, with particular emphasis on Iraq, Libya and Syria, not a word. Much less on how to pay a priceless moral debt, because human lives are priceless, which whose burden could and should be mitigated with a consequent political intervention aimed at contributing to restoring peace and financing reconstruction, ending the arms trade.

name: Janusz Zemke (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I welcome the fact that the European Commission is increasingly dealing with matters of internal security of the Union. Reducing crime requires better cooperation between all eu countries. We are facing growing challenges such as terrorism, organised crime and cybercrime. They are increasingly threatening societies across Europe. Crime must be combated primarily by the Member States. However, cooperation within the Union brings tangible added value. In this area, two actions are particularly important. Firstly, facilitating the exchange of information between law enforcement authorities and Union agencies, such as information on stolen documents or vehicles. Secondly, the rules for the transmission of criminal records information need to be amended.
