Today, the 26 EU Member States transmit more than 100 000 messages every month about eu citizens being punished. However, this system does not cover penalised nationals belonging to non-EU countries. This is a serious problem, as they are increasingly forming international criminal groups involved in the illegal metastasis of people or drug trafficking. It is useful that information about these criminals is known to law enforcement authorities in all EU countries.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the interim report by Monica Macovei, on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, on the proposal for a Council regulation on the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor’s Office (COM(2013)0534 – 2013/0255(APP)) (A8—0055/2015).

name: Monica Macovei
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, we discussed terrorism in the previous hour and we are all against terrorism. I want to say that terrorism is financed by fraud, organised crime, corruption and, yes, terrorism is also financed by fraud from European funds. We are talking in the European Union about fraud of our citizens' money of EUR 3 to 5 billion per year. It's an enormous amount, so far in numbers on paper. It's probably a lot bigger.  They steal money for jobs, for young people, for research, for innovation. They're stealing our money. It steals from our lives. Poverty is growing. All these are consequences of the fact that today, unfortunately, at European Union level, we do not have an effective mechanism to fight fraud with European money. The investigation of fraud with European money today is carried out by every Member State, not at Union level. Some Member States do it effectively for fraud with funds allocated to their country, but other Member States do not do it at all or do it very little effectively – very badly, to say the least. This distinction between the way european fund fraud is investigated in the Member States makes it absolutely necessary for a single european-wide office to investigate fraud with European funds. That is why the European Prosecutor's Office is needed. The result will be that fraud with European funds will be investigated more quickly, better, faster and to a much greater extent, and the recovery of money, obviously, will mean much more. Much more money will be returned to the pockets of our citizens.  Let us not forget that all of us here and in the European institutions are the guardians of our citizens' money. That's what the European Prosecutor wants to be. Through the investigation he is doing from start to finish and bringing to trial those who are guilty or suspected of having stolen European money, the European Prosecutor can guard public money, European money. We need the European Prosecutor's Office, which is made up of independent people, prosecutors specialising in the fight against fraud. Some will be in the central office, some will be at home in the Member States, but all will be part of the European Prosecutor's Office and will work together.  Let us make a comparison and see that the only answer is a European anti-fraud office. If we are struggling with an organised group of people who are defrauding European funds and they are doing it from several Member States, how can we respond differently than we do through a group of prosecutors from all the Member States, working together, efficiently, flexibly, quickly and annihilating these fraud groups against European funds. The report shall provide for means of investigation. An investigation will always be carried out in any Member State, with the authorisation and in accordance with the law of that country and, of course, with respect for the individual rights of the suspects.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, let me start by expressing my gratitude to Ms Macovei and to all the shadow rapporteurs for their intensive work on this file. This interim report sets out the position of Parliament in the clearest possible way. And I am pleased that it is supportive of the Commission’s overall objective: to create a European Public Prosecutor’s Office which will be able to make a decisive difference in combating fraud on the EU budget. I am committed to put it in place by 2016. Creating this Office will lead to a real change in how crimes against the financial interests of the Union are tackled. However, we are not there yet. Negotiations are still ongoing in the Council and they are very complex. We try hard to fully secure the independence and efficiency of the European Public Prosecutor’s Office (EPPO). In that regard, I would like to thank you for supporting an open, objective and transparent appointment procedure for members of the EPPO. In addition, I agree that we need clear rules on national competences as well as strong competences for the EPPO. The EPPO’s workload attribution should be organised based on objective criteria, and its working procedures need to be in accordance with the Treaties, the Charter of Fundamental Rights and the European Convention on Human Rights. I plead that we all keep an open mind: there is no template or precedent for the EPPO; there are no ready-made solutions which we could just replicate. In this context, the Commission has doubts whether the cross-border investigation regime applicable to the EPPO should follow the regime established by the European Investigation Order Directive. This is an instrument with great added value for the judicial cooperation between the Member States. But it seems less suitable for an EPPO working as an indivisible, European body – as a single Office. In our view, the transfer of the competence to investigate and prosecute EU fraud requires a simple and efficient sui generis regime for the EPPO’s cross-border investigations which operates in full respect of procedural rights and the Charter. It should reflect its operational needs and thus depart from the traditional intergovernmental cooperation instruments, in particular with regard to the grounds for refusal and the regime of judicial authorisation. In the area of justice, where the EPPO will act as an indivisible and single European body, there is no need for a duplication of judicial authorisations for investigative measures. A similar question applies to the proposal that it should be up to the European Court of Justice to ensure the judicial review of all EPPO acts. This would certainly overburden the Court. We are not talking about a dozen cases a year: we are talking about hundreds, if not thousands of cases! The Treaty allows and calls on us to create a specific system which is adapted to the EPPO’s specific nature. What we have proposed fully respects the right of effective judicial protection and the institutional position of the European Court of Justice as the supreme interpreter of Union law.

name: Victor Negrescu
text: Rapporteur for opinion Committee on Legal Affairs. – Madam President, first of all, I am pleased that this report on the creation of the European Prosecutor's Office is to be adopted, and I am glad that I was able to be the rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Legal Affairs in the European Parliament. I would like to thank my colleagues in the committee for the fact that together we have been able to adopt this report in record time and have thus demonstrated the support of the Committee on Legal Affairs for the creation of this body, which is to combat crime at European level. I note, however, with sadness that three of our ideas were not taken up in the final report. The first idea concerns the independence of the European Public Prosecutor from political parties and the absence of any link between those appointed to hold these positions and national or European political formations. The second concerns the explicit integration of principles of law such as fairness, justice or the guarantee of equality and freedom of the individual. The third idea concerns the emphasis on the role of the European Public Prosecutor in combating and preventing cross-border crimes. However, I will vote on this report, because I believe that the European Prosecutor's Office will help to make the fight against corruption more effective at European level.

name: Ingeborg Gräßle
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. We have a debate on an important issue and the most important interlocutor is missing, namely the Member States, that is, the Council. Madam President, perhaps you can see why the Latvian Presidency is not taking part in the debate with us on such an important point, where we are only in the hearing and the Council is in sole decision. It is one of the few opportunities to have this debate. I would like to tell you that what is on the table so far with the European Public Prosecutor is not enough in the Council's consideration and debate. We are doomed to success in this matter, and we are there to remind the Council that we need an efficient authority, that we do not need an authority that decides cumbersomely and cannot do exactly what it is supposed to do, which is to combat cross-border crime. I am disappointed with what has been said. I myself am co-rapporteur on the material legal basis for what the European Public Prosecutor then has to do. We have done five trialogues so far and we are struggling to move this issue forward with the Member States. We see that there is constant work to ensure that the European level is not given competences in precisely the area where this level needs competences, namely in everything that is cross-border crime. I hope that this House will not agree to any legal basis which excludes VAT. We need the competence of the European Public Prosecutor's Office for cross-border VAT fraud, which has so far suffered from the fact that the Member States are not doing their job and their work here. I would like to tell you that the dossier of the European Public Prosecutor's Office is in a dramatic state. That is why it is important that we get the Council to talk to us. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mrs Gräßle, I welcome the fact that, in principle, if I have understood you correctly, you are opposed to the introduction of the European Public Prosecutor. However, if I have understood correctly, you welcome it for cross-border crime. Is that right? Do you think that, in cross-border crime, there is a need for a public prosecutor for a state that does not exist? The EU is not a state. That's why she can't have a prosecutor. I believe that this is a point that you should perhaps explain again. I may have misunderstood you. The EU is not a state and cannot have a public prosecutor, either for national or international persecution.

name: Ingeborg Gräßle (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. – Dear Mrs von Storch, we know that angular advokature is your domain. I would like to tell you that I am firmly in favour of the introduction of the European Public Prosecutor. It has its own legal basis in the Treaty of Lisbon, whatever your opinion. This European Public Prosecutor must come and will come. That is the current legal basis. I would like to tell you that what we need is a chief prosecutor. And a chief prosecutor is needed, with or without a state, for cross-border crimes.

name: Sylvia-Yvonne Kaufmann
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done It is not known how much annual damage is to the EU budget, and thus also to the detriment of European taxpayers from fraud in the Member States. EUR 500 million, or even EUR 2 to 3 billion, is estimated. What we do know, however, is that the prosecution of crimes such as fraud of EU funding by national authorities leaves something to be desired. Against this background, it is time for the creation of the European Public Prosecutor's Office – yes, as provided for in the Treaty of Lisbon, and Mrs von Storch can read this again – and for this Public Prosecutor's Office to be able to start its work. Crimes against the EU's financial interests, which often take place across borders, must be vigorously combated. They are not cavalier offences. Europe must act in its own interests and that of its citizens. In principle, our group is in favour of the creation of a European Public Prosecutor's Office. It would be an important step towards effective protection of the EU's financial interests, and it would be equally important for strengthening the common European judicial area. The Member States are currently negotiating the design of the European Public Prosecutor's Office, and in the end the Council must decide unanimously. Unfortunately, Parliament is not involved in this issue through the ordinary legislative procedure, but the Council must know – even if it is not present, I hope the message will be sent to it: it needs the assent of this House. That is why Parliament's second interim report, which we are debating today, comes at just the right time, because it sends clear messages to the Member States and their negotiators. I would like to make it quite clear on our group that we are not giving the Member States a blank cheque for our assent. Firstly, we want a European Public Prosecutor's Office that is independent, regardless of any influence by the Member States. This requires not only a transparent procedure for the appointment of European Public Prosecutors, but also the involvement of Parliament in the selection of persons – the Prosecutor General and the European Prosecutors. Secondly, we want a clear delimitation of competences between the European Public Prosecutor's Office and the competent national authorities. Thirdly, the European Public Prosecutor's Office must be able to operate efficiently. But it is at least as important that the procedural rights for accused persons must not be allowed to get under the wheels. And, of course, a high level of data protection must be ensured. Moreover, contrary to what seems to be the view in many capitals, we do not believe that the job of a European Public Prosecutor can be a part-time part-time job. We will therefore pay close attention to whether parliament's and other demands of Parliament are taken into account by the Council, and on which, I will make it very clear, our approval of the project will ultimately depend. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Marek Jurek (ECR)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The European Union does not have any of its own money in its budget, but only money from member states' contributions from the citizens of our countries. Are you not concerned that the creation of the European Public Prosecutor's Office, which is to have a clear separate competence from the public prosecutors' offices of nation states, will limit the possibility for national prosecutors to act to defend the money that we have transferred to the European Union? Is this not yet another misappropriation of state competences by the central institutions of the European Union?

name: Sylvia-Yvonne Kaufmann (S&D)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mr President, I would like to thank my colleague for his work It's the other way around. Experience in recent years shows that, unfortunately – as the rapporteur, Mrs Macovei, has also pointed out – there is no efficient investigation in a number of Member States and that we have quite large sums of fraud. That is why we have this project of the European Public Prosecutor's Office. I am glad about that, and I have to tell you that. At the time, I was involved in the Constitutional Convention in arguing that this public prosecutor should be created to combat fraud against financial interests.

name: Timothy Kirkhope
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, we all agree that the fight against fraud must be a political priority. Fraud and corruption undermines our democracy and our freedoms. However, I believe we should focus on enhancing and implementing the many tools we already have at our disposal such as OLAF, Eurojust, Europol, the EIO and the PIF directive. We should not be committing more money, more resources and more national sovereignty when instead Member States and the Commission should enforce what we already have available. The most effective means of countering fraud is to stop it happening in the first place – I think we are all agreed about that. By simplifying the rules which govern the different sectors of the EU budget and improving the oversight of the budget we are best able to achieve that. Another law, another agency, another one-size-fits-all policy to a very diverse problem is not really the best solution. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – I want to ask you, how will we control the money given by the European Union not only to member states, but also to those countries that are not members and get our money and can cheat us, and these are all those countries that are yet to become members and that we finance?  So it's my question, and I want Mrs. Macovei to hear the same thing. My question is: Do you agree with me that whoever gives money has the right to control how this money is spent and has the right to also penalize those who do not spend their money properly?

name: Timothy Kirkhope (ECR)
text: blue-card answer. – I did make it clear in my remarks that we already have a considerable number of agencies available. I would be the first to criticise those agencies. I criticise them regularly because I do not think that they are always doing the job that they are meant to do. Of course, the protection of European monies and resources is a matter of some priority, but I do not say that this particular idea and this new agency will make any difference, probably, to the need and the ability of those other agencies to fulfil their obligations. Let us concentrate on what we have now, and get it right.

name: Louis Michel
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Madam President, the European Parliament, by adopting this report, will send a strong message to the Council. Indeed, we say yes to the European Public Prosecutor's Office but no to an expensive, inefficient and dependent bureaucratic structure of the Member States, which too often take refuge behind the principle of sovereignty, Mr Kirkhope, to do nothing.  The fight against fraud is above all an ethical issue, which aims to strengthen the rule of law and to put an end to situations of impunity, which are still far too numerous. It is up to Europe to defend its financial interests without having to depend on the goodwill of the Member States. The European Public Prosecutor's Office will give the Union the means to set out its ambitions. Many states play a double game: they praise European justice in public, but in the backyard they empty it of its substance by maintaining almost total control over its exercise. Only the independence of the European Public Prosecutor's Office will bring real added value. I am pleased that the European Parliament is proposing, in this report, a series of concrete measures that go in this direction.  Independence is mainly reflected, as Mrs Kaufmann said, in the process of appointing prosecutors, in the division of powers giving priority to the European Public Prosecutor's Office and in its structure, where chambers composed of several prosecutors hold real power.  I just want to remind the Council that the European Parliament will have the final say on this issue. It would be appropriate for him to take into account the views of this House.  (The speaker agrees to answer a question "blue card" (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I am a little surprised that in these voices, including in the voice of Mr Michel, there is such a great distrust of the Member States and national legal traditions. But I would like to ask about a very specific thing. The Regulation on the European Public Prosecutor's Office cannot be adopted without the consent of all the Member States, since such a procedure was established by the Treaty. If you are pushing a solution so centralist and so distrustful of the Member States... (The President has received the speaker's vote)

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: "blue card" answer. Madam President, the question is whether I am suspicious of the Member States. Yes, I am clearly suspicious of some Member States. A whole series of fraud cases are still in the status quo, awaiting trial in the Member States. Too often they play the card of their interests, their vision of sovereignty to escape - or to allow some to escape - judgment and, therefore, to establish impunity. That is why I am indeed in favour of centralisation, so as to establish an increasingly unique case law.

name: Rina Ronja Kari
text: gue/NGL Group. Madam President! I really think it is incredible that this proposal keeps circulating. The fact is that 11 Member States have drawn the yellow card because the national parliaments believe that this is a violation of the principle of subsidiarity and that it goes far, far too far. For example, they point out that the proposal makes it difficult for each Member State to prioritise the crimes they will focus on. Others point out that the proposal goes beyond legal certainty. It should therefore be remembered that we are not just talking about cooperation between the countries' public prosecutors. No! We are talking about a genuine EU prosecutor who alone must be able to sustain the indictment. That is why I fully support the criticisms of the national parliaments. Of course, the European Union should not be equipped with its own public prosecutor, who can bypass the national prosecutors. That is why the Commission's proposal must not only be given the yellow card, but totally rejected.

name: Jan Philipp Albrecht (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her For the first time, thank you very much to the rapporteur, Mrs Macovei, for her hard work. It is true that we have a result, an interim report, which is now being forwarded to the Council. Because we in the European Parliament are not in codecision here, but can say yes or no in the end. That is why the signal is clear: if the Member States, which are unfortunately not here again in this debate, do not accept the message that we are sending out here and do not include in their proposal the amendments that we are proposing in it, then there will be no agreement for such a public prosecutor in any case. The Member States need to know this. On the other hand, it is also clear that a very large majority in this House has been in favour of the establishment of such a public prosecutor's office for some time. We are sticking to that. But the conditions must be right, and this includes, above all, uniform high procedural standards. These must be taken into account. This must be reliable, and it must be clear what this public prosecutor is doing its job for. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr Albrecht, I would like to thank Mr Albrecht for his They welcome the introduction of the European Public Prosecutor's Office, particularly because there is a problem in individual Member States in pleading for fraud, the waste of EU funds. Is it right that, when individual Member States have problems prosecuting breaches, we need to introduce a new authority at European level that is not linked to any state because we have problems in individual countries? I do not understand how you can welcome that. I consider this to be a massive interference with the sovereignty of a state. A prosecutor is an intense interference with sovereignty.

name: Jan Philipp Albrecht (Verts/ALE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mrs von Storch, I believe that your question is full of ignorance of the further development of state law. We do, of course, have state structures at European and international level. The European Union is created by sharing the sovereignty of different states. We take responsibility together. The same is true at international level, by the way. Or will you deny that, for example, an International Criminal Court with its own prosecutor is, so to speak, a step backwards or an interference with the sovereignty of our states? No, it is progress! That is why it is right to go down this road!

name: Laura Ferrara
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the fight against corruption and crime and the commitment to the proper use of public resources are certainly among the cornerstones of the political action of the 5-Star Movement.  For these reasons alone, we welcome the establishment of a European Public Prosecutor's Office independent of political power, which will deal with overcoming the current inefficiencies that favour the impunity of those who indirectly defraud the European taxpayer. Let us remind the Council, which is unfortunately not here today, that an efficient European Public Prosecutor's Office must have a solid legal basis in order to operate, and that is why we hope that the PIF directive will be adopted promptly and include a list of clearly defined offences, including VAT fraud.  We also believe that it is extremely important to extend the scope of the European Public Prosecutor's Office to offences other than those affecting the financial interests of the Union, as provided for in Article 86 of the Treaty, extending it to the fight against organised crime and mafias of all kinds.

name: Florian Philippot (NI).
text: Madam President, through the classic small step method, Brussels proposes the creation of a European justice system with a hand in the control of whole sections of the Member States' judicial systems. The long-term objective, of course, is for this so-called European justice to become all-powerful and completely replace national justices. A supranational law must then be strengthened, which will eventually erase French law and all national rights from history. Justice is part of the regal functions, consubstantial to the very notion of state, from antiquity to the present day. To remove this nuclear heart would be to leave the citizen alone in the face of an institution that is beyond all ties with the people, and therefore with democracy, and to leave the state destitute in the face of internal threats. Justice in France is and always will be done, as it is written in the judgments of our courts, "in the name of the French people". In the face of criminals and weapons who pass without any difficulty from one European country to another, we simply have to find borders and demand that our national justices cooperate better in the resolution of international affairs. The European Public Prosecutor's Office, this bureaucratic monster, is a project as useless as it is undemocratic. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: "blue card" question. Madam President, dear colleague, I have heard your speech, but I must tell you that in Romania and Bulgaria, for example, we have created the cooperation and verification mechanism, and this has helped us to strengthen our justice system.  Justice has no political colour, as it has no nationality. Do you think that European justice cannot deal with things properly? Do you think justice has a nationality? I don't think so! What is your opinion on this subject? Do you think there will be no proper justice at European level?

name: Florian Philippot (NI)
text: "blue card" answer. Madam President, I believe that justice, such as borders, the budget, money and the law - normally - is one of the essential and first attributes of a state.  As long as there is no European people, there can be no European justice, as there should be no European currency, European supranational law, a European budget that is higher than national budgets, etc. It is an essential and consubstantial element to national sovereignty, to the sovereignty of peoples, and we know that if we detach justice from the reality of the peoples, we will go against the tide of what a democracy is.

name: Milan Zver (PPE).
text: – First of all, my sincere congratulations to the rapporteur, Monica Macovei, for her work in this area. The proposal for a regulation establishing a European Public Prosecutor's Office is in its own right. As has already been pointed out, half a billion euros of alleged fraud affecting the financial interests of the European Union, or rather European taxpayers, is a huge amount of money. Moreover, the Member States are not responding sufficiently to these problems, as we have heard. Less than a third – a third of OLAF's recommendations – are converted into indictments. That we're not even talking about convictions and recoveries. In short, you have to react. The establishment of the prosecution is the way to go. If we set it up as a truly independent, powerful service that can investigate and prosecute uneasyly, so only if it exists as a sui generis, it will be an important tool for protecting the European Union's financial interests. However, if the Council changes it into a body that will operate solely on the basis of coordination, we will get another paper tiger, a dry branch in the structure of European institutions. The European Public Prosecutor's Office needs the highest legitimacy. This will be the case if its composition is decided by the European Parliament. Besides, dear colleagues, the European Union will have to delimit the functioning of OLAF, EUROJUST, EUROPOL and so on in the future. It should also take a step forward in supplementing the legal framework for the functioning of the European courts. (The speaker agreed to accept the question raised by raising the blue card (Rule 162(8)).

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. –In fact, I wanted to ask my question to Mrs Grassle, also from the People's Party, but it will fit here too. As long as there is no European Public Prosecutor's Office, there is fraud. What do you think, when the government of a country operates corruption at system level, because there is such a thing unfortunately in the European Union, this is my country in Hungary, the Hungarian Government, the Fidesz sits in your ranks, what do you intend to do about it?

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: The answer to the question raised by raising the blue card. – Therefore, the European Public Prosecutor's Office, as a sui generis authority, would precisely prevent such cases where a Member State does not react well enough or does not investigate fraud. And we have said before that only 31 per cent of olaf's recommendations are taken seriously by Member States and converted into indictments. The question is, how many of these things get an epilogue. That percentage is much less. This means that we really need one body such as the European Public Prosecutor's Office.

name: Péter Niedermüller (S&D).
text: - Commissioner, I would like to thank you for your support. Unlike one of the previous speakers, we believe that the European Public Prosecutor's Office is very much needed. This is partly because, in many European Community Member States, the squandering of EU and Community funds, politically motivated corruption, the indemissible intertwining of politics and the economy are serious problems. This merger, this type of corruption, undermines the trust of citizens, of the electorate, of trust in the European community. They do not see the European Union helping them achieve their goals. We believe that we do need the European Public Prosecutor's Office, we need a European Public Prosecutor's Office that is completely independent of the Member States, because we know that there are a number of European Member States that refuse to comply with the common rules, who refuse to comply with the principles of the fight against corruption. That is why we need an independent and independent European Public Prosecutor's Office.

name: Helga Stevens (ECR).
text: I am in favour of effective anti-fraud and efficient use of public funds. However, this does not mean that the creation of the European Public Prosecutor's Office as an independent European Public Prosecutor's Office is the right solution. We already have Eurojust, which is responsible for judicial cooperation, and OLAF, which is responsible for combating administrative fraud. In other words, this can be handled differently and better. In fact, the creation of the EOM amounts to a waste of taxpayers' money. Moreover, Article 86 of the EU Treaty explicitly stipulates that the EOM must result from the existing Eurojust. In addition, it can only be established that the PIF Directive, which identifies crimes which would be within the competence of the EOM, is still stuck in the trialogue negotiations. The angle and timing of the European Commission's proposal are therefore wrong. What is the point, then, of directing a number of recommendations to the Council on the margins as a condition for our agreement?

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, just yesterday the French President flaunted his deep contempt for MEPs when he said ‘France will never authorise any modification of Parliament’s seat’. It seems therefore that the wasteful EU baggage train will roll in and out of Strasbourg just about forever, and this waste would seem to be a suitable subject for the proposed prosecutor to address. But of course it will not happen. The President of France can go on being as contemptuous as ever. This report is also contemptuous of democracy. Those who drafted the Lisbon Treaty knew perfectly well that a proposal for a European Public Prosecutor would be unacceptable to national governments and, indeed, 14 national parliaments have signified their veto. But a clause was inserted – disgracefully – so that Member States could, via enhanced cooperation, proceed with a European Public Prosecutor. This is deplorable. However, the report does remind us of the corruption and fraud relating to EU funds: apparently more than EUR 3 billion a year. What this demonstrates is that the EU is analogous to a species of parasite: the EU feeds off the taxpayer and, as the report says, EU money funds the costs of the EU’s own internal corruption. This proposal is a Trojan horse: it would solve nothing and it destroys yet more national sovereignty. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Ingeborg Gräßle (PPE)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr Dartmouth, I would like to thank Mr Dartmouth for his work on this Would you be prepared to take note of the fact that the French President is merely defending European law, because it is stated in the Treaties that Strasbourg is the seat of the European Parliament? It merely refers to the current legal structure of the European Union.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: blue-card answer. – The question was typically gracious, but of course one of the complaints that my party makes is that European law is made superior to English common law, which is a far superior system. I would also say to anybody who is serious about the European Parliament, and people like you are – I am not, I think it is a waste of time and a waste of money – that it is amazing that you can solemnly support the President of France in pursuing this disgrace of meeting in Strasbourg twelve times a year.

name: Vicky Maeijer (NI).
text: – We pay at the request of Brussels, we make cuts at the request of Brussels and we will soon continue at the request of Brussels. In order to achieve the Europhile dream of a United States of Europe, you need not only a European flag, a European currency and a European national anthem, but also a European Public Prosecutor's Office. The Netherlands and ten other countries drew a yellow card and received a middle finger back from Brussels. And even before the European Public Prosecutor's Office is set up, a discussion is beginning on the extension of powers. Not only should we cede fraud to the EU, but in the future we must also prosecute terrorism, child abduction and other cross-border crime. Investigation and prosecution are a national matter. The EU has no interest in this. This is not about tackling fraud or fighting terror, this is about power. We are being rumbled into the United States of Europe, where there is no place for the nation state. I hope that my colleagues will think about this when they vote on this report tomorrow.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the establishment of a European Public Prosecutor's Office is one of the most ambitious legislative initiatives of recent years in the fight against fraud in the European Union budget.  I would therefore like to thank Mr Macovei for his work, because I believe that Parliament must make its voice heard on this matter, drawing up lines that must be respected for the proper functioning of the Office, including, above all, the independence of the public prosecutor's office and all its Members with regard to all the influence of the European institutions or the Member States; competences that allow effective action and avoid overlaps with other Member States; effective mechanisms for investigating, collecting and using evidence, and last but not least, full respect for the rights of suspects and defendants at every stage of the procedure.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab This matter must be dealt with with great delicacy and, as I said in my polemic with Mr Michel, with respect for the Member States and their legal traditions. I therefore cannot accept Mrs Macovei's report, which goes in a completely different direction. In the case of the Regulation establishing the European Public Prosecutor's Office, nine Member States reported a 'yellow card'. I would like to remind you that this institution can only be created with the consent of all the Member States and must be act very gently. However, the report calls for the establishment of a super centralised body, which is properly superior to the Member States, with two competences at the very least – not only the fight against fraud at the expense of the European Union, but also the competences to combat cross-border crime, and this was supposed to be, according to the Treaty, the second step in building the European Public Prosecutor's Office. And you, by striving for centralism, are acting with the result that the European Public Prosecutor's Office will not be, that it will only be established in a few countries. Centralism is the enemy of common sense and Europe.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The need to set up a European Public Prosecutor's Office has been under discussion for more than ten years. I would like to remind the absent Council, but especially all doubters, of the famous Greek maize case. In this regard, the Court has recognised that the Member States are obliged to protect European interests in a way that is equivalent to the protection of national interests. So European interests, like their own national interests, must be protected. In this respect, the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor's Office is a logical development of this fundamental judgment. I am therefore fully behind the objective of protecting the financial interests of the European Union and combating corruption, and I think that this is only logical for all Members of this House. I would also like to remind the doubters that I have now exercised in this context of the legal basis – the Treaty of Lisbon – which places particular emphasis on combating serious financial and economic crimes, and I think that Mrs Macovei has done valuable work in this regard.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Nation states are the foundation of the European Union. If we undermine their role, we will really undermine our cooperation. Because who will be her party? We have seen recently how, for example, monetary union has changed its character. Originally, the single currency was supposed to be a tool for exchange, today it becomes a tool for controlling the economic policies and budgets of the Countries of the European Union. The same is true of the European Public Prosecutor's Office. The speaker has just referred to the Treaty of Lisbon , Article 86 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. But paragraph 4 has already been added to this Treaty, which extends the powers of this institution. Once again, I will repeat this warning, which has been formulated by many colleagues. If we forget that the EU should have as many common institutions and competences as it has common values and interests, if we create unnecessary institutions, we will only undermine the trust of the peoples of Europe and the citizens of the peoples of Europe in the EU institutions – we will undermine the foundations of our cooperation.

name: Axel Voss (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her First of all, I would also like to confirm once again that the introduction of a European Public Prosecutor is important. That is why we are going to do it. In this overall context, Of course, I myself would have liked an overall concept, not only to simply implement a public prosecutor, but also to perfect the connections and the structures accordingly, namely: what happens to Eurojust? What exactly does that look like there? Then there is a proposal. But how do we deal with Europol and OLAF? How are we going to regulate this by procedure? None of this is entirely clear. That is why it would have been nicer if this overall concept had been followed. In particular, it would have been nice to have provided clarity in this whole procedure – which, of course, is not so easy now, as regards the Council and also Parliament in connection with the reform of Eurojust. That is why it would have been nicer to set up the overall concept.

name: Lucy Anderson (S&D).
text: – Madam President, our delegation is still formally reserving its position on the European Public Prosecutor’s office because we have not yet had the chance to scrutinise the details of the drafts in Council, as was said earlier. In principle, however, the arguments in favour are compelling as long as proper safeguards on the issues of independence of prosecutors and defendants’ rights are in place. Hundreds of millions, if not billions, of euros are lost each year due to fraud against the European Union funds. In the UK, I am sorry to say, in contrast to things you have heard earlier, we do not take this issue seriously enough. In fact, if you compare it, for example, 38 issues were referred by the German government to the European Fraud Office in 2013 compared to only 4 by the UK. It is absolutely unacceptable that we do not have proper accounting lines within our indicators for statistics on EU fraud in the UK. The idea that the UK is a good example in this matter is completely untrue.

name: Janusz Wojciechowski (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The idea of establishing a European Public Prosecutor's Office is an expression of a very bad trend in the European Union. A trend that can be described in a nutshell as follows: less and less money, more and more power, less and less aid, and more and more repression. Let us recall that the European Union budget is less than 1% of the EU's gross domestic product, and the European Union's power is moving very quickly towards 100% control over everything that is happening in the Member States of the European Union. We absolutely do not agree with this direction of evolution of the European Union. The European Union should be an institution that, above all, helps its citizens, which comes to the rescue, not with repression. That is why the idea of the European Public Prosecutor's Office is wrong. Our political group and I are personally opposed to national institutions being served by the European Public Prosecutor's Office.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to express our support for the establishment of this European Public Prosecutor's Office because it will help to better pursue, more independently and effectively, corruption offences which harm the European Union.  I propose and support the incorporation into its functions of the prosecution of cross-border crimes committed by international terrorism. I bet on the collegiate structure proposed by the Commission if we really want independence: I believe it will encourage police coordination by avoiding incomprehensible vetoes in investigations of terrorism and fraud affecting the Union. I hope, therefore, that there will not be embarrassing shows at European level, such as those lived in Spain and thus a contrast will be offered to help improve. There, the defendant's proximity to the government party generates outrageous favourable dealings and even means that, in the midst of judicial instruction, the files of the computers in which the treasurers of the People's Party allegedly kept all their accounts can be erased. It is our responsibility to address these problems.

name: Benedek Jávor (Verts/ALE).
text: – The setting up of a European Public Prosecutor's Office is essential to curb crimes and corruption affecting the European budget and across borders. Most people, at least those who support European integration, seem to agree with this. Unfortunately, however, quite a few Member States are trying to undermine this proposal out of fear. Out of fear, because some member state governments may be inconvenienced by such an institution, for governments that are themselves implicated in corruption. For this reason, the watering down of the proposal has also started. There have been suggestions for the creation of a network-type public prosecutor's office or organisation. This must be strongly rejected. This would create the institution of the public prosecutor's office in name, but it would not work in practice. Similarly, the exception of VAT fraud from the competences has been raised, although these are precisely the cases where action by the EPPO is most decisively needed. Our proposal is that Parliament should only adopt a proposal for a European Public Prosecutor's Office that can actually act. The rest is a waste of money.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, thank you for your discussion, for all the opinions, and of course my special thanks to those who expressed support for the proposal to establish the European Prosecutor’s Office (EPPO). I would like to assure you that the fight against corruption and fraud is the highest political priority of the Commission and of myself. I am truly convinced that we need an independent EPPO which will bring harmonised procedures and ensure the fair investigation of criminal offences infringing the financial interests of the EU; I believe it will bring tangible results. I am convinced that the taxpayers of the EU deserve to have such an institution which will safeguard their money. Taking a very conservative estimate, I would say that some EUR 1 to 2 billion a year could be secured and brought back to European treasuries and the European budget, or be refunded to the Member States, by which I mean used in honest projects in the context of EU structural funds. When we are speaking about such a large amount of money to be secured versus the costs of the European Prosecutor’s Office, I think we can say there is a good cost-benefit balance in this case. We need the EPPO as a specialised institution functioning alongside OLAF and Eurojust, and Mr Voss was right when he spoke about the need for a very precise description and plan of the procedures and the cooperation between the EPPO, Eurojust and OLAF because this must operate in a very efficient way. There is still a lot of work to do. We must secure a clear division of competences at the central and national levels, and ensure the transparent selection of people for the positions. We have already introduced the conditions and criteria of integrity, independence and professionalism of the people to be selected. Those of you who said that the procedural rights of the criminal procedure of the Member States must not be sacrificed, are right. They must also be secured in the EPPO procedure. A last comment regarding the yellow cards which the EPPO received from several Member State parliaments. I do not consider the question of these yellow cards to have been concluded, so I have been addressing all these parliaments, in some cases making a personal visit. I have tried to explain how we can go forward with the proposal, that there are safeguards to ensure that the principle of subsidiarity is not infringed, that a decentralised structure is foreseen and that the jurisdiction of the national courts will be maintained… among many other things. I must say that I have had some quite positive reactions from the members of the national parliaments and I hope that through this enhanced communication we will be able to conclude that there is in fact no breach of subsidiarity. I thank you once again and I would ask you to vote in favour of the EPPO in tomorrow’s vote.

name: Monica Macovei
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, it was a very interesting discussion. I will try to answer some of the issues raised.  Firstly, I ask rhetorically, because I already have this information, those in the Member States or in certain political groups who oppose the European Prosecutor's Office: how much money have they recovered through their own investigations in their countries from fraud with European funds? Have they recovered a lot? Did they recover a little? Maybe they don't really want anyone to interfere, they don't want anyone to see if they worked well or not.  This has to do with the second thing I want to say, and that is very important: European money, our citizens' money, is in a common basket. As long as they are together in one basket, they must be protected from all of us. If in one country things are going very well and investigations are being concluded in other countries, no, know that the citizens of countries where things are doing well are also being stolen. I would like to give this answer mainly to the colleagues in the Netherlands who have invoked this, namely that they are doing good investigations at home. Sure! Only in other countries it is not made, and the money is in this common basket. Further a third point: the independence of prosecutors from politics. I think it was so, just a word from Mr Negrescu, to show that he cares about this independence, while at home, now in Romania, on the contrary, they vote the other way around in Parliament. I want to put it this way: the independence of European prosecutors, both those in the Member States and those in the central office, is clearly ensured from the outset in this report on the European Prosecutor's Office.  Very briefly: four – yes, we want to include VAT offences and also fraud with European funds in the candidate countries and in other countries to which we give money. We must be ambitious to reduce fraud with European funds.

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 29 April 2015. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. – The EU budget is shortened by hundreds of billions a year as a result of fraud and corruption in some Member States. In many cases, however, no charges are brought or no investigation is launched against the perpetrators. This is a particularly big problem in Hungary, where since 2010 EU funds have landed in the pockets of pro-government businessmen with the active involvement of the government. This is evidenced by the recent suspension by the European Commission of HUF 700 billion in EU funds, as after 2010 fraud or pricing practices and irregularities were detected in one third of EU projects. It is no surprise, therefore, that the Hungarian Government, which has sunk to the level of corruption, is opposed to the Commission's proposal to set up an independent European Public Prosecutor's Office. Only with the independent European Public Prosecutor's Office can we put an end to institutional corruption orchestrated by the current ruling parties. MEPs in the DK want a European guarantee that those currently in power will not be able to avoid impeachment. The European Commission should consider a future granting of EU funds only to Those Member States that accept the exclusive jurisdiction of the European Public Prosecutor's Office, which will be set up from 2016. Otherwise, EU funds in Hungary will not Hungary up, but will serve to further enrich people close to the government.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. I believe that the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor's Office is now necessary and urgent. There is currently an overlap between the competences of some 450 authorities which, depending on the Member State, may be administrative or judicial. Cooperation between the Member States must be central. On the other hand, the time limits for limitation differ between Member States and there is no agreement on cases of crime. National legal systems alone cannot counteract the transnational nature of Community fraud in respect of the principle of territoriality of procedural criminal law. OLAF also has the task of investigating fraud and illegal activities, but its powers are limited to administrative investigations.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. – I think that we should invest much more energy in European political integration, in our unity, not on giving up pieces of our national sovereignty when we are making decisions that are in the interests of European citizens. As we know, fraud affecting the EU's finances is worth more than EUR 500 million per year. This is one, but not the only, reason why I support the creation of a European Public Prosecutor's Office within the EU. It is simply a fact that Member States are in many cases unable to act effectively against transnational infringements or financial manipulations, and this new institution is therefore necessary. Of course, we need to define the precise powers of how they will be distributed between the Public Prosecutor's Office and the individual Member States, and we must include guarantees so that the new institution is truly independent. I believe that we must work tirelessly to combat fraud within the Union, not only to reduce abuses and crimes, but also to increase the confidence of European taxpayers and to return to the EU institutions.

name: Емил Радев (PPE)
text: in writing. – The entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon was a step towards a stricter protection of the European Union's financial interests. With its subsequent proposals for the European Public Prosecutor's Office and a directive to combat fraud by european means through punitive means, the EC has put better fund management at the heart of the effective implementation of its policies.  Actively combating fraud with European funds will allow more people to reach EU financial support, break vicious practices such as VAT fraud and improve the Union's image as a driver of growth and prosperity in the Member States. It is therefore necessary for the Council to approve as soon as possible the EPPO Regulation as well as the Directive on combating fraud by European means. These two dossiers must cover a maximum number of financial crimes with EU funds and ensure the independence of investigations.  The proposals will not lead to a conflict between the European approach and national enforcement, but will strengthen cooperation and trust between Member States. The adoption of the EPPO Regulation and the Directive on combating fraud by European means will be a clear signal that the EU has the will to protect its financial interests and ensure that the funds reach those who really need them, namely European citizens.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the debate on the Commission statement on recent revelations on mass organised spying by NSA, and the implication of the Bundesnachrichtendienst, against EU citizens, politicians and companies (2015/2676(RSP)).

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I welcome the opportunity to address today an issue that the media have been reporting on extensively recently: the cooperation between the German and US intelligence services. Let me start by saying that many details still need to be confirmed. According to the print media, many facts remain unclear, for instance the extent to which the German intelligence service, the BND, was involved, intentionally or not, in the US National Security Agency’s spying on companies in Western Europe, in violation of German law. The activities of intelligence services aim to ensure national security. The area is within the sole competence of the Member States and thus exempt from the applicability of EU law, including the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union as the Charter only applies to Member States where they implement EU law. Having said this, the concept of national security needs to be interpreted restrictively when used by a Member State in order to claim the non-applicability of EU law. The case law of the Court of Justice also clarifies that, in such a case, the Member State needs to substantiate such a claim. It is not sufficient to simply invoke it. Any problems of cooperation between the intelligence services of the Member States or between a Member State and the intelligence service of a third country is a matter to be resolved firstly by the Member State or Member States. This has to be done in compliance with relevant national legislation within the framework of the rules of the European Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms.

name: Axel Voss
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The Mirror writes this week: "The NSA apparently spied on companies and authorities in Germany or the rest of Western Europe with the knowledge of the BND." So far, this is a claim, a headline, a newspaper report, nothing more and nothing less. So far, we do not have any facts about this. So what are we actually talking about here? That intelligence services are doing what they are doing, that perhaps a European service is supporting a friend of another service in this? It is generally good that we keep reassuring ourselves that we are positioning ourselves against mass surveillance and that we do not accept spying on citizens, politicians and even companies. That is also unacceptable. But we have already established all this. That is why I do not think the timing of this debate is the right one, it is wrong, too early, and I also think that the place is wrong. The Commissioner had already said that we are not the place responsible for this. We should therefore not somehow pretend to the European public that we can really change the intelligence services here in the European Parliament or make a difference in this matter. We do not have these powers for intelligence, let alone competence for a national intelligence service. So far, we really do not have any confirmed findings. That is why this discussion takes place within a framework in which we can only express conjectures or interpretations. For so far there has been no evidence or evidence of mass or general surveillance. There is also no evidence of intra-European surveillance. As always, it is a question of spying on communications data from or in crisis regions. We should therefore focus on how we can improve the control of intelligence services.

name: Birgit Sippel
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Let me make a preliminary remark. Dear Mr Voss, there have been not only newspaper reports, but the members of the German NSA Committee – including the chairman who comes from your party – have confirmed that there has been misconduct. But for the reason, the turmoil following the Snowden revelations has left no trace in the Member States, as we can see once again. The spying continues. In its final report, this Parliament not only criticised the United States, but also called on the Member States to stop mass storage without cause and to create stronger supervisory bodies for intelligence services. Even then, for example, we named British and German intelligence services, because there were suspicions that not everything was going well. Yes, not all the facts are on the table yet. However, as has been shown, it is also a serious matter for the members of the committee. Anyone who, without the knowledge of the Chancellery and Members of Parliament, passes on news, not for the fight against terrorism, but for completely different purposes, is acting wrongly, exceeds his powers, and if no one supposedly knew this, it is very frightening, because control – including parliamentary control – has obviously not worked. The only correct response now is a comprehensive investigation of all allegations by the German NSA Investigation Committee. As all members have called for, the Chancellor's Office must also provide appropriate support and ensure that the investigation can take place as quickly as possible. A special role is played by the much-discussed selectors, according to which our secret service has sought out information that the NSA wanted for different purposes. However, it also shows – and I will end here – that the European Parliament must continue to deal with this issue. This is also demonstrated by the new legislation in France, which actually seems to be taking on the dimensions of a French Patriot Act. We must continue to push the discussion forward.

name: Zdzisław Krasnodębski
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I think that a colleague from the European People's Party is trying a little bit about this problem, as it is said in German, verhamlosen. After all, it was the Spokesperson of the German Government who started this whole debate, and she is not just an intra-German. It seems to me that this is not just an issue that should interest us as europeans or europeans. This is not just a matter of the BND providing information on European citizens, businesses and politicians. Moreover, the Commissioner has said only about Western Europe in a characteristic way. I think this applies to the whole of Europe. The problem, It seems to me, however, is not only the BND's cooperation with the NSA, but also in many press reports that the problem of the BND itself, which so extensively collects information about European citizens, about businesses, about politicians, is revealed. As the German debate shows, it does not take place with proper democratic control. I must say that I would like to know more as a parliamentarian, as a citizen ... (The President has received the speaker's vote)

name: Sophia in ‘t Veld
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, how many times have we been here discussing illegal eavesdropping, spying on our citizens, spying on politicians, spying on journalists and harassing whistle-blowers? Can we repeat all the hashtags: NSA, prison, Belgacom, Gemalto. Mr Voss, would you be just as complacent if we were not talking about the American secret services here but the Chinese secret services? Would you then say: well, hey, that is what secret services do, they spy on people? Get over it!  We happen to have rules on this continent. Who is going to protect the right of our citizens? Who is going to protect the privacy of our citizens, Mr Voss? Clearly the EPP does not care about privacy, the rule of law or international law. The citizens should not expect any protection from your side. I understand that the Commission is saying it is the sole competence of the Member States and there is not a whole lot we can do. Incidentally, I note that the Council – again – is absent. If there is any institution that does not care very much about citizens’ rights, it is the Council. Somebody needs to do it and I refuse to accept that all of this is legal and acceptable. When are we finally going to get some answers? Because if this is what friendly nations do to us, then I wonder what unfriendly nations are going to do to us. Mr Voss said: we have no proof. Of course we have no proof. They are called secret services for a reason because what they do is secret. That is why we have oversight, Mr Voss – Mr Voss who is not listening. We need oversight urgently; we need to have European rules that apply to the cross-border activities of secret services, because we must stand up for the rights of our citizens.

name: Cornelia Ernst
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her What we have always suspected has simply been revealed: that of course all the secret services, including the bnD, are heavily involved with the NSA, on the principle of "a friend, a good friend". That is the point. Against any right, with the knowledge of the chancellor's office even! So the governments, they are all there, are also making their eyes heard in the spying on European citizens, on the authorities of the Member States, and even on business enterprises. This is economic espionage! Under EU law, prohibited under national law! What else? What else is to happen? Free house the selectors are regularly transferred from the Americans to us, then to Germany or anywhere else over the big pond and information is delivered. We all know the facts. I say to you: when we were busy discussing the NSA affair, the intelligence agencies were sitting elsewhere and laughing at each other. That is surely the truth that we need to talk about here! It is not an isolated case. It's not the NSA. It's system. This is a system of monitoring citizens, businesses, all laws millions of times. And in some contexts, this is called treason. That is the bill for the lack of control of the intelligence services, who can do what they want. And governments are covering up this scandal! I ask you: how long do we want to endure this? How long will this fraud continue? How long will we allow the Council to offer this? I think it's over!

name: Jan Philipp Albrecht
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, if these media reports are shown to be true, then this is a new dimension of this surveillance scandal which shows very clearly that it is not only the NSA or the United States, but also our own intelligence services which are not complying with our standards, our fundamental rights and our values based on the rule of law.  I have to say, Commissioner Jourová, that now is the time to really do some work on investigating whether the term of ‘national security’ in the Treaty of the European Union is being overstepped by the Member States. Obviously this is the case. At the time of the Snowdon revelation, Angela Merkel said ‘spying on friends, that's a no-go’. We could either say that EU Member States are not seen to be friends for Germany, or we could say that she does not mean her words – that she does not take her words seriously. I think that this is exactly the point for all the Heads of State. We need the Commission and Parliament to clearly urge the Member States to deliver rules and standards on how they conduct their national security work, on not spying inside the European Union – the Charter of Fundamental Rights and the Treaty apply here – and to safeguard the rights and standards we have in our Treaties.

name: Gilles Lebreton (NI).
text: Madam President, since 2001, the German secret services have spied on European companies and personalities, particularly French ones, on behalf of the United States. This information, revealed by Der Spiegel magazine, has just been confirmed by Mrs Merkel. The Chancellor is trying to discard her responsibility by accusing her secret services of having , I quote - "technical and organisational weaknesses". This case is serious because it proves that Germany has betrayed France and its European partners for the benefit of the United States. It also tends, in my view, to prove that Germany is exploiting the European Union to put it at the service of American interests. The consequences must be drawn and the proposed transatlantic partnership must be called into question.

name: Milan Zver (PPE).
text: – We have discussed the alleged espionage of the US NSA in Europe countless times and have already adopted a resolution on this subject. I believe that today's debate is completely unnecessary. With a series of hacker intrusions and attacks, the cybersecurity debate would be much more necessary. The proponents of this point yesterday set a storm in a glass of water for alleged collusion, and I quote, collusion between German and American intelligence services. What would it be like, if not secretly? And i'm the first to support this kind of surveillance, because it's about the safety of all of us. Dear Sirs, it is clear that the protection of personal data is one of the central rights, human rights. So let's do something about it. Let us speed up the adoption of the EU data protection regulation to replace the different standards and rules in the 28 Member States. And once the regulation is adopted, it will have to be respected and enforced by everyone: at home and abroad. We also need a successful conclusion to the negotiations with the US on a framework agreement on data protection in the fight against crime, as this is the only way to harmonise standards and determine the modus operandi of data management in these cases. Let me conclude with the conviction that no country, not even the European Union, can formulate an effective security policy for the good of citizens, including parliamentary scrutiny, if it does not provide law enforcement authorities with the right tools to act. And finally, one more thing. I believe that the so-called big brother is not of German or American descent.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the question was asked of why we are discussing this today. Let us be very clear that, following the very tortuous and difficult NSA inquiry, even the United States has begun a journey of international norms against economic espionage and is trying to protect citizens against this deeply unnecessary spying. Spying against terrorism and our genuine security needs is important but, as the Commissioner said, here we are dealing with companies in Western Europe and dealing with potential violation of – in this case – German law and European law.  What are we talking about? We are talking about what the Washington Post and Der Spiegel said was a very big deal indeed. We are talking about two of our big Member States – Germany and France. While I am loathe to deal with individual Member States, just as I had to deal with my own Member State in relation to the NSA inquiry, we must as a Parliament deal with the protection of our citizens against unnecessary violations of their privacy. That is what we are doing today. We are dealing with many allegations, and they are a big deal, as the Washington Post and Der Spiegel said. What must we do? We must ensure that we have oversight procedures. We do not have competence in this area but, as we said in the NSA inquiry, we must ask the Member States to make progress in this area. They are clearly not doing this, and we are serving a reminder today that we must ask the Member States to make concrete steps ahead. I also remind people that it was the Bundestag and the individual Member State that made progress here, not just journalists. It was individual members of the German Parliament who tried to make progress and uncovered many of these revelations. They were right to do so, and Members of the European Parliament are right to do so when European law and fundamental rights are threatened.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I am afraid that this is not the last time that we have to deal with such things and shed light on them. Intelligence services operate in the dark, and the dark scares many people. We, as a Parliament, stand for guaranteeing a Europe of freedom, security and justice. It is precisely a strength of our rule of law that the powers of the police and intelligence services are clearly defined. Any interference with fundamental rights must be justified on a case-by-case basis and must not go beyond what is necessary, and above all it must not be systematic. So what do we need? We need parliamentary control – that is good what we are doing here. We need intensive investigations throughout Europe, in all the Member States where this is happening. Secondly, we finally need the completion of the data protection reform – that is overdue. Thirdly, in order to achieve more network and IT security in Europe, we finally need a European infrastructure and a legal framework for a European cloud. Fourthly, we need protection for whistleblowers, for people like Edward Snowden, who have uncovered all these things. Fifthly, we need an anti-espionage agreement. Bilateral agreements obviously have no value. All EU Member States must make a binding commitment not to engage in economic espionage against each other. Sixthly, we finally need the courage to review the international agreements that we have entered into. SWIFT and Safe Harbour agreements must be put to the test. We have taken clear decisions here. It is clearly the Commission's turn to draw the consequences of our decisions. I believe that a free society is recognised by its willingness to investigate violations of fundamental rights without any ifs and buts and not simply to accept them.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Madam Chairman, I am always very careful when speaking in Parliament, someone refers to the media and sources coming from the media. However, there are too many clues here, there are too many doubts here, too much has been said that this discussion would not make sense.  In fact, this debate also makes sense that this debate should also be in support of the German Parliament in the diluting and controlling of everything that was happening, in investigating what was happening when we talk about the work of the NSA and the GNI. What I also want to stress is the need for a multilateral agreement in Europe.  We really don't need to spy on each other, so I guess we can have enough mutual trust, trust in our citizens, in our institutions, trust in ourselves and thus protect actually citizens and protect our economy, to protect simply the political system in which we believe.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you very much for this discussion. It really made sense and it is good that we have raised this issue here. My opening speech was rather dry and modest because I only said that we do not have enough evidence on the table. We do not have enough facts – only news from the media. For me, as for lawyers, this is quite a decisive condition for making conclusions or not making conclusions. I also spoke about the lack of European competence, referring instead to the competences of the Member States.  However, I must tell you that since I heard this information about the alleged new scandal involving the abuse of data by the American NSA, my vigilance has really been raised. You all know that we are now in a hot phase of negotiations with the American authorities on the Safe Harbour system in which we are negotiating the exceptions under which the American intelligence service can use the data of the European citizens or legal persons flowing to the United States. This will not make the negotiations easier – quite the opposite. If we have achieved some sort of fragile trust, hearing this news puts us back in a very different situation. However, we are tough in the negotiations. We want to see the rules and the competences, which are varied on the American side, but we also want to obtain very concrete guarantees from the American authorities that the rules are going to be obeyed and fulfilled. The written rules are one thing and the execution of these rules is another. These negotiations are very tough, and this will mark the future weeks. We wanted to finalise the negotiations by the end of May and to achieve the concrete written set of rules which will be maintained in dealing with the data under Safe Harbour. These negotiations are continuing, as is the parallel procedure of the finalisation of the Data Protection Regulation. This will hopefully come to the June Council for the general approach taken by the Council together with the Police Directive. I mention this so that you can get the fresh information on what is happening in the data protection sphere.

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the report by Neena Gill, on behalf of the  Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on Money Market Funds (COM(2013)0615 – C7—0263/2013 – 2013/0306(COD)) (A8-0041/2015).

name: Neena Gill
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, Commissioner Hill – the Council is absent – colleagues, tomorrow we vote on a critical piece of financial legislation: the regulation of money market funds (MMFs). This is a EUR 1 trillion industry too big to be ignored. The financial crisis has made it abundantly clear that these funds pose systemic risks and can lead to financial instability and recourse to the public purse. During the crisis, the key vulnerability was when investors wanted to liquidate funds quickly. These so-called runs meant that the asset managers had to close them down and the investors lost their money.  The previous Parliament failed to find an agreement on this file.
