From the beginning, when I took over, it was clear to me that this was an issue that strongly divided this House. Between the supporters of the CNAV MFF and the VNAV MFF, each camp has about 50% of the market, and is supported by at least one Member State and opposed sometimes by another – a bit like when you have two strong football teams in one city. The divisions experienced in this House are also mirrored in the Council. Therefore, I would like to remind colleagues that it is not our role as legislators to decide which team we should be supporting. Both have their value to different investors. Our role is to ensure that any type of MMF is transparent, liquid and stable so that we do not face the burdens of the 2008 financial crisis again, while recognising that MFFs are of value to many types of businesses, local authorities and non-profits that support our economy and use MFFs as a cash management tool. Salaries and other funds are placed in MFFs as these offer an easy return both in terms of interest and of liquidity. They can, and do, make a positive contribution to the real economy. However, it would be an understatement if I said that achieving a degree of understanding of each other’s point of view was straightforward when we looked at this report. But I am pleased that we did manage to find a compromise between the S&D, the EPP and ALDE in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs. What we have achieved, apart from strengthening the viability of the MFF sector, is to introduce three new categories of funds – LVNAV, Retail CNAV and Public Debt CNAV. These solutions would not have been possible had it not been for the cooperation and flexibility demonstrated by many colleagues and especially the shadow rapporteurs. However, I have to say that I am disappointed that, despite taking many concerns of the GUE/NGL, the Greens and the ECR on board, that they did not support the proposal in committee. I do find it ironic that their preferred positions, for whatever reasons, would result in a totally unregulated MFF sector being allowed to continue, which would put our fragile economic recovery at risk. I do find this baffling. For me it is important to get this on the statute books sooner rather than later. Therefore, I would urge them to reconsider their positions and support this report so we can move to a trilogue stage from a greater position of strength. On that, I would also say to the Council Presidency – which is absent – that it is being made an offer that it cannot refuse in terms of achievements for the Latvian Presidency. I would thus ask Commissioner Hill to take this up with the Presidency to ensure that it does move forward quickly. I would also like to take this opportunity to thank the earlier Italian Presidency, which made considerable progress on this dossier and was instrumental in introducing me to the concept of LVNAV.

name: Jonathan Hill
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I am very glad to be here today because it means that we have got to the point of a plenary vote and that is an amazing achievement. A huge amount of hard work has been needed to get this far and I am very keen to congratulate publicly Ms Gill on the part she has played in getting us here. Money market funds are important as a source of short-term financing in our economy, but they also have systemic implications and that is why we need to make money market funds in Europe safer. The Commission proposal stressed the role of safeguards for MMFs, covering authorisation, supervision, transparency and limits on what MMFs can invest in, and most of that is not contentious. It will reduce risks, but also allow MMFs to continue their essential role for Europe’s companies. I know that there are some outstanding issues that still need to be resolved, but I believe that the ECON compromise has helped provide a new impetus and Member States have signalled a fresh willingness to resume negotiations. In her proposal, Ms Gill has wisely concluded that MMF reform does not have to take a one-size-fits-all approach. MMFs serve many purposes, so to acknowledge that fact we need a variety of types, and that seems to me to be a good principle for us to uphold. I believe that Parliament’s proposal for a low-volatility MMF to replace the current stable redemption MMF is a good basis for discussion with the Council. And as the LVNAV MMF is a direct successor to the CNAV, we will of course monitor how it develops and ensure it both provides a useful service to the economy and deals with risks in an appropriate way. The Commission is examining whether the proposed 20 basis point spread is appropriate to avoid investor runs. Ms Gill has also proposed two alternative fund models – government and small investor CNAV MMFs – and these two types of MMF will continue operating under the classic CNAV model. I think it is right that we should have a broader range of choices available, including government CNAV MMFs, small investor CNAV MMFs, LVNAV MMFs and VNAV MMFs (try saying that after you have had a drink!) in line with our diverse marketplace and national traditions. The Commission wants to ensure that MMFs continue to provide a stable, secure tool for our companies to manage their cash without posing a threat to our financial system. We will continue to provide all the technical support that may be needed to both Parliament and the Council. I hope that we can maintain our current momentum. I will certainly work with the Presidency to make as rapid progress as possible, and conclude this important file in the near future by adopting what I believe is a credible MMF reform.

name: Brian Hayes
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, firstly can I congratulate Neena Gill for her work as rapporteur on this very important file, and I would also thank other shadow rapporteurs who worked with me on what has been a difficult and contentious file – not just during this mandate but also under the previous mandate. I think we have a workable compromise that we can now bring forward to the Council in intense trilogue negotiations. I also think it was very important that in the compromise on this file, two distinct parts of this industry are reflected – the CNAV and the VNAV industries. It is crucially important for Europe that we keep the EUR 1 trillion MMF investment in Europe at a time when we are trying to make sure that we have long-term investment in our companies and businesses, big and small, here within the European Union. So that was crucial. It is also crucially important that we are behind the curve by comparison to the United States which has already regulated in this area. So we do need to get our act together, we do need to regulate, but we need to do it in a proportionate and a reasonable way to ensure that these funds remain within the euro system. In the LVNAV proposal I think we have many new features, additional safeguards, daily and weekly liquidity requirements, regular reporting transparency, fees and gates. A totally new system, a transparent system is now put in place to deal with the systemic shock issues that Commissioner Hill spoke of. There is one outstanding issue and it concerns the review/sunset clause which I know has been the cause of some contention. In conclusion, I would be interested in hearing the views of Commissioner Hill as he responds to this debate as to the viability of a sunset clause for the new LVNAV product. If we want the LVNAV product to work, to sustain itself, to move forward, we do need to ensure that there is a review after a few years. I would be interested in his view on the sunset proposal contained within the current compromise and the Commission’s position on this issue. Congratulations again to Neena Gill for her work in this area.

name: Roberto Gualtieri
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I think that what Parliament is going to vote on tomorrow is a good compromise, which has the main merit of defining a text that can really be the basis for equipping the European Union with legislation governing the Money Market Funds, which is urgent and necessary.  I do not need to repeat the elements of this compromise text which Mrs Gill has explained very well. The creation of the VNAV is important, that mechanism that I think can work to go from two to four digits, which will also have a limited importance for retail, public debt and other aspects.  I would like to stress, also in reply to Mr Hayes, that the sunset clause is an integral part of this compromise, it is an integral part of the political compromise and therefore it is a crucial element in having the broad consensus necessary and then starting a trialogue successfully.  Finally, I welcome Commissioner Hill's positions on the need to proceed after our vote with progress and as far as possible in order to start a trialogue. I therefore call on the Council to proceed quickly, on the basis of Parliament's text, in order to really start negotiations on this text as soon as possible. I would, of course, ask the Commission to use all its moral suasion force towards the Presidency of the Council, because after tomorrow's vote we can really have a change in timing and content and finally start the necessary regulation of shadow banking.

name: Kay Swinburne
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, the nearly EUR 1 trillion currently invested in European money market funds serve an important purpose in our economy, providing corporations, governments and public bodies with a short-term investment vehicle that is a trusted alternative to bank financing. At a global level, the FSB has recommended measures to improve the safety of money market funds (MMFs) and to avoid runs through improved rules on transparency and diversification for MMFs, as well as limits on sponsored support.  The initial proposals from the Commission would have seen an end to the CNAV industry, whilst failing to convince anyone that VNAVs offer a wholly better or equivalent option. The ECR has argued consistently for both CNAV and VNAV MMFs to be able to continue, as they offer necessary and different services to our businesses and public bodies. They are not mutually exclusive, and we do not believe that one model is better than another. However, national bias has played an irresponsible role here. The alternative, low-volatility NAV proposed by the rapporteur seems to be a workable compromise, and I thank her for her work on it. However, it is undermined by the review clause calling for an end for this authorisation within five years. That makes such vehicles unviable for providers and investors. Improving diversification and transparency rules while allowing MMFs to function would serve the European economy and should be our sole goal.

name: Petr Ježek
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, money market funds in the EU have systemic relevance as they are worth approximately EUR 1 trillion, as we have already heard, and constitute around 15% of the EU funds industry. It was thus of crucial importance to allow the European economy and its investors to continue benefiting from both CNAV and VNAV funds. I am happy to say that this text answers our initial objectives by offering a balanced approach. These new rules will make sure money market funds do not threaten financial stability nor mislead investors by continued financing of the real economy in Europe. The newly-created category of low volatility NAVs will be able to use the same valuation method as CNAVs as long as the value of the fund does not deviate too much from the market value. This means more transparency for investors and will prevent run risk in the case of adverse market conditions. The task was not easy at all. Those who followed the files during the previous and current mandate can confirm that. The negotiating team and the European Parliament can be proud of having managed broad agreement on such a polemical and critical file. It is high time that the EU fulfilled its international commitment in this field and provided some answers that are up to the challenge in order to address the possible systemic risk posed by MMFs while offering the industry a workable solution. Parliament has done its job, I hope. I believe this unexpectedly positive outcome will send a strong signal to the Council that it has now to fulfil its mission and deliver.

name: Fabio De Masi
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her If we want to regulate the banks, the lobbyists tell us that if you do, business will move to the shadow banks. Shadow banks were one of the causes of the banking crisis, and now we have the chance to regulate part of it – the MMFs. Now we hear that if you do that, you will destroy the one trillion euro industry, or the business will go to the United States. But the European market is important and – yes – liquid enough to regulate decisively. CNAVs guarantee investors every euro of their investment. But they are not as safe as cash, but risky financial products. It is really rare for my colleague Eva Joly or I to represent the positions of our governments. But Germany and France, as well as international regulators, have called for CNAVs to be buried or subject to banking regulation. Neena spoke earlier of an offer that we cannot reject. This is a quote from Marlon Brando from the mafia film "The Godfather". I say to you: do not allow yourself to be blackmailed. I therefore appeal in particular to the German and French Members of the majority groups to vote in favour of our amendments.

name: Eva Joly
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, Commissioner, Madam Rapporteur and dear colleagues, the Europeans in the G20 have pledged to act quickly and hard to regulate the growing amount of credit managed outside the traditional banking system. Our main commitment is to limit the systemic risk of VLC funds and their false promise of a constant value repayment.  I am sorry to say that the text voted in the ECON committee does not meet our international commitments. The FSB and IOSCO recommended the conversion of constant-value funds to variable value funds or, where this was too difficult, to apply the same rules to these funds as to conventional banks. The removal of the capital buffer proposed by the European Commission led to the rejection of the second option. However, the conversion of the VLCs was not carried out to the end. By creating three new categories of VLC, only one of which would be subject to a transition clause, it was the choice to preserve a certain risky sector that was made.  That is why, if the text remains unchanged, the ecological group would have to vote against it. That is why we have tabled a new set of amendments, one of which proposes to extend the transition clause to the three newly created categories of VLC. If our amendment to Article 27 were to be adopted, the Green Group as a whole would be prepared to vote for the amended text.  Madam Rapporteur and ladies and gentlemen, I do not believe that the text voted in the ECON committee really reflects the political balance in this House. The pressure of lobbies and the determination of some colleagues not to act has greatly distorted our perception. I believe that in this House a majority of parliamentarians want to limit this systemic risk which threatens all European economies in the long run.

name: Steven Woolfe
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, money market funds: not a single one caused a systemic risk during the course of the crash. Money market funds: not a single person lost any money throughout the crash in Europe. Money market funds are essential for the real economy to work. But if you listen to the people in this Chamber – such as the previous speaker we have just heard – money market funds were the cause of all the crises, the jobs, the unemployment, and the people dying and suffering in Europe today. Nothing could be further from the truth. But what is the truth? It is that in Europe we have a crisis in our economies and we have a crisis of unemployment which is caused, firstly, by the euro itself and the impact it has on our economies and, secondly, the meddling of this Chamber in the financial markets and business as a whole.  We already know that in the United Kingdom HSBC is considering leaving to go to Asia because of EU regulations. Asia is succeeding because Europe is failing.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI).
text: Madam President, Commissioner Hill, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work and for the work she has The reform and regulation of MMFs has already been discussed in this House during the last parliamentary term. The rapporteur has certainly succeeded in reaching a compromise that is acceptable to large parts of the House and which is also feasible for the industry concerned. What points were highlighted in the report? These are the systemic risks – this has already been mentioned today: the close networking of banks, insurance companies and the real economy with MMFs and the risk of contagion, liquidity component, credit assessment, portfolio structure and transparency. One thing is clear: it is only through strict banking regulation and low interest rate policy that systemic risks increasingly shift to the shadow banks. That is why we need to regulate here, and this House has started with the MMFs. The market structure has been addressed. I am going here with Commissioner Hill. Different investors need different funds and different structures. There is diversity in the report here, and that is a good thing. Stress tests are provided quarterly, which is indeed groundbreaking. You remember, the Federal Reserve's lieutenant governor, Fisher, recently said how important it is to conduct stress tests. This is important for the United States, it is important for Europe. That is why these funds create transparency, liquidity and stability. The report is positive.

name: Burkhard Balz (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her First of all, I would like to express my sincere thanks to the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs. They did a good job. We have certainly made a long way in regulating banks, insurance companies and fund managers in recent years. But in order to be successful in regulation, we must also target possible evasive movements. This necessarily includes the so-called shadow banks, which are no longer allowed to move in the shadows. We therefore very much welcome the fact that the European Parliament is moving forward with the call for the first Europe-wide regulation of MMFs. We are further here than the Member States. It is clear to us that the risks of MMFs must be tackled swiftly and comprehensively. MONEY market funds must be prepared against an unexpected investor storm, a fund run. For this, the value and reliability in the share valuation is particularly important. It must be a matter of risk-adequate regulation. MMFs need strict transparency and liquidity rules that can ensure their resilience in stressful situations. They must ensure a high quality of assets in their books and not rely on external support. Adjustments will be needed in the existing markets, up to and down to the examination of whether certain products can survive or not. But for that to happen, regulation must now get its way. We are now ready to negotiate with the Member States and will continue to work towards the objective of shedting light on the shadow banking sector.

name: Jakob von Weizsäcker (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Even if Mr Woolfe does not want to see it, after the Lehman bankruptcy, multibillion-dollar money market funds were a central fire accelerator of the crisis. The MONEY market funds suddenly did not want to lend money to the banks for fear of further bank failures. And money market fund investors panickedly withdrew their money from the funds. In the end, the taxpayer had to step in with money market funds and banks with gigantic sums or guarantees. MmFs are therefore shadow banks in the narrower sense: in dangers similar to banks, but much less regulated. This is particularly true for MMFs with a constant net asset value – the so-called CNAV funds. We must finally change that! Unfortunately, the particular interests of the MMFs – and we have now heard this again in plenary – were over-represented at the negotiating table, which did not exactly facilitate the work of my esteemed colleague Neena Gill as rapporteur in the interests of European taxpayers. I would like to take this opportunity to thank her warmly for her demanding and nerve-racking work. As a result, less has been achieved than is actually necessary. This makes it all the more important that Parliament clearly defines its red lines. The dangerous CNAVs must not have a future, and the problematic compromise construction of the LVNAVs must end after five years at the latest. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Steven Woolfe (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – You asked me a question, sir. It is very simple. Did one European VNAV fund collapse? Did any investors in any European VNAV funds lose any money? Did any countries lose out or have to bail out VNAV funds? I think you will find that the answer to all of them is no. You are simply creating a problem that did not exist, are you not?

name: Jakob von Weizsäcker (S&D)
text: blue-card answer. – I would just like to point out that Lehman was an American bank, very much funded by American money market funds. I just wonder about the counterfactual: what if Lehman had been a European bank funded by European money market funds?

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I think it can be argued that CNAV funds are particularly vulnerable to runs. In this respect, I welcome the work that has been done in Parliament, although I am not convinced that we have already come to a close with the solutions of wisdom. Overall, of course, the reason for possible runs is not to be found in the fund as such, but in other characteristics of the underlying real economies. What we have is the phenomenon of a situation, particularly in Europe, in which markets have sometimes moved very far from their equilibrium, and allocations off balance are vulnerable to rapid adjustments to exist and emerge in the area of financial relations. We have interest rates that are so low that they greatly support private debt. We have a situation of state over-indebtedness in various countries. All this is something that is actually the cause of the crisis. And that's where the problems need to be fixed!

name: Gerolf Annemans (NI).
text: – Given the nature of the money market funds, there is a high risk of contagion to the real economy. I doubt whether yet another extension of the tasks and powers of the European Union is a good solution here, I doubt on principle, even though the considerable buffers provided for here are more transparency and, more obvious measures, are. But at the same time, it is argued that it is 'the external ratings that can make runs'. Well, this seems like a bit of a shoot at the pianist. It is naïve to think that the internal rating will suddenly be able to solve all problems, such as asymmetric information and adverse selection, by EU standards. So I am not standing here today as a bellboy of the banking lobby, but as a sober MEMBER who wants to warn against naïve views. I can already see it, the long-term path that one wants: a kind of socialist politburo, a.k.a. EU rating agency that is going to rate ratings of, for example, Greek government bonds and consortia as 'top' and 'extremely safe' – in accordance with official EU policy – and which external credit rating agencies must keep quiet about. Then I say, "No thanks."

name: Theodor Dumitru Stolojan (PPE).
text: – Madam President, with this regulation we aim to achieve two major objectives: firstly, to ensure greater protection for investors in mutual funds, which act on the money market by investing in short-term financial assets, and, secondly, to strengthen financial stability by addressing an industry of around EUR 1 000 billion. I would like to thank the colleagues who worked on this report because, after a long negotiation, they have managed to reach compromise amendments, which enable these objectives to be achieved. In particular, I highlight the amendments limiting the scope of the concept of the constant value of net assets, those concerning their liquidity, as well as the prevention of risk caused by an unexpected flight of investors, the standards on avoiding risky concentration of the investment portfolio and the necessary transparency.

name: Markus Ferber (PPE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has This is a very trivial question which we in the European Parliament must answer. Firstly, do we need such instruments? If so, how can we make the instruments so secure that the taxpayers do not end up holding their heads to them? Let me just say it. One must, of course, ask ourselves whether a fund – an MMF – whose asset value is permanently guaranteed on the capital side really reflects market events. This is an issue that needs to be addressed. And who stands for the fact that even in the event of a run on a bank or in this case an MMF, it is possible to pay out here? We have taken an approach here to resolve this somewhat. I am not happy with that, I say quite frankly. I tabled amendments in committee which went much further. I do not yet know whether we have a balanced approach to the negotiations with the Council. We need to see two sides. Not only those who offer these funds, but also those who invest their money in these funds. That is why the flexible funds are certainly the more manageable ones. That is why the question of capital buffers still needs to be answered. I hope that the Council will make appropriate proposals here. That is why, as far as the review of capital-linked funds is concerned, we should have a review of the time as a whole. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – These money market funds have been identified as acting as shadow banks and are, therefore, susceptible to different risks. In fact, the liquidity and diversification requirements for these money market funds have been strengthened, as have transparency and reporting requirements. However, they are not overseen like normal banks. Do you not think that all these funds should be overseen by the national banks – like all the other banks – with the same requirements?

name: Markus Ferber (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mr President, you are now asking me this question because you absolutely wanted to have speaking time, because that has nothing to do with my speech. I have expressly said that I do not yet go too far in the present area. Maybe we'll find ourselves somewhere.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE).
text: – Honourable colleagues, Madam President, i would like to thank the Rapporteur for her excellent work. In my opinion, we, as legislators, have one main task: it is to ensure the rules of the game in business so that there are as many investments and more jobs as possible in the European Union as a whole. We need to ensure Europe's competitiveness in virtually all areas of the world market in the best possible areas , which means digital, energy, industry, the services sector, including the financial sector.  In this directive, we are talking about money market funds. One composition of the financial market. That is to say, we are talking about variable and constant asset value funds. This proposal and the idea that one such fund in Europe should be restricted is, in my view, the opposite of our goal for Europe to maintain and develop its competitiveness. Why? If we limit Europe, this market, this activity will leave, leave the European Union, go to Asia and the United States. Therefore, I think colleagues, the idea of restricting the functioning of these funds in the European Union is not productive. We must defend jobs and europe's overall competitiveness. Thanks for the attention!

name: Frank Engel (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I was marvelling earlier at your juggling with the many abbreviations relating to this file and I will not attempt to do anything akin to that, so I will try to leave the abbreviations out of what I am going to say altogether. I belong to the category of those who are content with what has been achieved in terms of compromise because the text that we are now contemplating, at least in Parliament, gives us better regulation, gives us encompassing regulation and does not prematurely close doors that need not necessarily be closed.  Many colleagues on the left seem to perceive these instruments as if they were the devil in disguise, if in disguise at all. I do not see that proven. Yes, they may be systemically relevant; but where has the systemic accident been, at least on the European continent, during the last years? I am not aware of one. Yes, there might have been difficulties in the United States with different regulation; but in Europe I do not recall anything like that. Let us provide for more guarantees and more regulation right now, but let us give the Commission a serious opportunity to re-evaluate a certain type of money market funds in the years to come before we decide out of the blue – or what appears to me to be not totally irrelevant in this matter, because we hate them – to abolish a certain category of money market funds altogether.

name: Pervenche Berès (S&D).
text: Madam President, the European Parliament had made an attempt on this issue under the previous Parliament. Clearly, his courageous position did not lead to an agreement with the Council. However, we are here on a very essential issue, which puts Europe at the forefront of the international scene. The treatment of money funds is something that we are asking to act on, all international organizations that are interested in market stability or the fight against the shadow banking system. This is the case for the IOSCO and the Financial Stability Board, but it is also the case for the European institutions that are members of the ERS. The position that this European Parliament is going to take must be a courageous position, which allows us to effectively fight against this important part of the shadow banking system, let us not be afraid of words. This position will be all the more crucial as we enter into discussions with Commissioner Hill on the establishment of a capital market. However, I would not want us to approach this discussion on a future European Capital Union without having a clear strategy in relation to these monetary funds, whose volatile characters must disappear.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, at a time when the European Central Bank has EUR 60 billion a month under the credit easing programme, Draghi and his team are continuing their blackmail policy against the Greek people. So, while we here in the European Parliament are discussing mutual funds and short-term financing of businesses and governments, Draghi continues to apply credit suffocation against Greece. In early February, Draghi illegally excluded Greek government bonds from Eurosystem operations, where Greek banks used them as collateral to finance them from the ECB. The ECB subsequently banned Greek banks from increasing purchases of Greek government T-Bills. In Riga, Draghi announced that he would tighten the noose even further around Greek banks. The goal of Dragi and his company is to force Greece to back down on the demands of the lenders. But he will not succeed, because the Greek people will win and throw the Troika out of our country.

name: Paul Rübig (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I believe that this debate is not only important for the major international players. Of course, they very often have their own banking systems and often find it much easier to finance themselves, because they have very different conditions from small and medium-sized enterprises. I believe that it is particularly important for us to remember that small and medium-sized enterprises need risk capital in order to grow. And the key question is: how can we help small and medium-sized enterprises to get risk capital, to be able to take on liability? How do we deal with guarantees given by family, friends? How can we organise this for tax time? How can we support growth, especially among those who have good products and services that can be sold worldwide? The funds play a very special role here. The key question is: how can we format them so that they can be better supported in the future?

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Madam Chairman, Dear Mr. Commissioner, that we need MMFs, we need opportunities to finance our economy in the short term and of course without them, and if they leave, it will be more difficult for the European economy.  But at the same time we also need a European legislature, because the European Legislature must guarantee around MMFs the right stability for these funds to actually function properly. And I agree that we especially need such MMFs that will allow retail investors, and that is why I support these two basic principles, the principle of clearness or transparency, as the principle of diversification is also liked.  I think that based on and starting from this that we have European legislation, transparency and diversification, MMFs will be, in the way they are conceived, generally accepted and for the benefit of the European economy.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to ask Commissioner Hill, who is British, given that the City of London, brokers are at the heart of the economy and finance, whether he is truly independent of these things because he has been talked about so much, but you have only helped the big groups, the banks and the small ones.  In Italy there is a saying that says: "banks offer you an umbrella when the sun is there, when it rains the umbrella requires it back". That is, when you don't need the umbrella they offer it to you and when you need it they take it away from you. So I think that you, here, really have to do something quite different, help the little ones, the families, the small businesses and not just think about the big groups because the only umbrella that the citizens make of it is this. This is the umbrella they can do to you because Europe is in no way in the interests of small and small businesses and families. This is the umbrella that Europe and Italy make you.

name: Jonathan Hill
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, it seems to me there is a very clear linkage between the operation of the markets and small businesses, namely: if you can make them work properly, you can get more money in investment flowing to the small businesses that we all want to see growing in Europe. It has been a very interesting debate, if short. My admiration for Neena Gill has been increased through listening to the divergence of views that we have heard here, articulated very clearly and with equal passion. It confirms in my mind the importance of trying to make progress on the compromise that has been agreed so far. It is also a reflection of the broader challenges we face in looking at financial regulation as to how we can best balance growth and risk mitigation. I am confirmed in my support and admiration for the work that Neena Gill has done. I will certainly underline to the Latvian Presidency the importance of making progress with this proposal. We have an opportunity now to get some momentum going, and if we do not take it, I fear that we will find it hard to get it back again. As far as the specific question I was asked about a sunset clause is concerned, it is the case, obviously, that the phasing out of CNAV funds was not something that the Commission included in its original proposal. The most important issue for us – our bottom line, if you like – is that we get a sufficiently robust regime in place to deal with credit and interest rate risks for all money market funds, including CNAVs. If we can get the risk management regime right overall, that would deal with the question of the sunset clause. That is something we will be monitoring closely in the Council process, and obviously during the trilogue process that will follow. We need to get a deal on money market funds. It would represent a significant step in moving closer to finalising the post-crisis reform agenda. A positive vote in tomorrow’s plenary would itself be a significant step towards securing that final deal.

name: Neena Gill
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I would like to thank Commissioner Hill and all my colleagues for their remarks. I strongly believe that we do have a sound and stable agreement.  On the clause: we have to recognise that this agreement is the result of lengthy negotiations which entailed give and take by all. I have stated from the beginning that this clause is a red line for my group. I am not convinced that it will prevent the LVNAV (low-volatility net asset value) from taking off. I think the financial sector is very innovative and I am sure they will make it work.  I also wanted to raise the issue the Greens and the GUE/NGL Group have pointed out. I think they have a very fundamentalist view on this file. It is all about their point of view and nothing else. When you look at it broken down, it means protection of one part of the industry and not the other. What really concerns me is that this approach will lead to nothing at all and a continued unregulated MMF sector. Even if I have sympathy with some elements of your proposals, I do not believe this is the place where they should be included. On other issues, I am frustrated by the inconsistent approach because earlier you wanted a clause at ten years and then it came down to five years, which is what we have at the moment.  I want to take this opportunity to thank everybody who has been involved. I want to start by thanking Brian Hayes, Petr Ježek, Eva Joly, Fabio De Masi, Syed Kamall and their teams for spending a huge amount of time in a fishbowl-shaped room for hours negotiating on this. Thank you to them. I would also like to thank my coordinator, Elisa Ferreira, for all the support and engagement that she has had, Roberto Gualtieri for his engagement, Stine and the Secretariat and my own assistant, Jan Moens, for their support. Without you I would not have got here.

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 29 April 2015. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D)
text: Writing. The compromises before us create European rules in a hitherto unregulated financial sector. These include increased control over shadow banks, increased transparency and strict liquidity rules. We all know that the financial industry has been looking for evasive manoeuvres and loopholes to shift its financial operations to the unregulated world. Thus, the volume of shadow banks has more than doubled since the crisis! This regulation fills a further regulatory gap. The only downside is that the expiry clause could not be extended to all MMFs. A review by the Commission after four years would have been desirable for all the proposed forms of MMFs!

name: Alfred Sant (S&D)
text: in writing. – Many experts have argued that trying to model European legislation on MMFs on that in the US, would be a mistake. Still, it needed to be updated. The financial crisis had demonstrated that MMFs were vulnerable to liquidity problems at tough times. The update would set a framework within which MMFs could operate competitively. It would carry suitable protection for investors during financial crises and ensure ongoing flexible servicing of the short term financial needs of European business. Prudential requirements needed to be strengthened without burdening unduly the financial services on offer in the European economy. The increasing variety by which such services could be packaged needed also to be taken into account. It balances the need for regulation with the need to enhance the competitiveness of financial services. The latter must remain a priority, if the overall aim of stimulating more new investment in Europe is going to be achieved. Equally, there will be a need in coming years to keep a watch on developments worldwide in money market and related funds sectors. Given globalisation, European legislation cannot afford to lag on what is happening elsewhere, in both prudential and competitive terms.

name: Ingeborg Gräßle
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Madam Vice-President, President of the Court of Auditors, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, I would like to thank the President-in-Office of the Council for her work on Welcome, we are glad that you are here and appreciate that! I am campaigning today for the Commission to grant discharge for the 2013 financial year in the Commission's discharge. I can make this request with a clear conscience. I am also seeking support for the resolution. At the heart of my motion for a resolution and that of the Committee on Budgetary Control is the shared management of funds and the weaknesses in the management systems of the Member States, which have existed for many years. These weaknesses are disclosed in my report and a remedy is proposed. I would ask the political groups and all my fellow Members not to water down the text in tomorrow's vote and to stand behind it, especially those on the margins of this House who claim to be acting for the taxpayer. We must strengthen the Commission's supervisory role, and That is what I have tried to do. The Commission has begun to look closely at the figures from the Member States that report them to Brussels. Directorate-General AGRI is a pioneer, but regional policy must follow. Because there is no value in glossing over the mis-spending. I would ask you, Commissioner, Madam Vice-President, to step up your efforts to ensure that DG AGRI, but above all DG Regional Policy, receives truthful and reliable figures for management and control systems. DG REGIO must do more on the ground and not just control the audit authorities. These are long-standing demands of the European Court of Auditors. If the motion for a resolution is adopted, the Commission will have a strong position with regard to the Member States when it pushes for better results and better controls. That is why I am again asking for urgent reasons. My great disappointment was and is once again the S&D Group. It is good that the majority of the committee rejected their amendments. I would ask that this be done in plenary tomorrow too, because these amendments are watering down the text, thereby weakening the influence of the European Parliament and the Commission in the Council. The importance of the report, the resolution, clearly lies in shared management. But there were only two paragraphs of foreign aid, and here the camp in Tindouf first. It is horrible to spend 40 years in the desert, and it is unacceptable to have to pay money as a refugee for aid. I thought fraud remains scam, even for supposedly good purposes. There is a motion from the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance and the S&D Group, which wants more money for Tindouf and puts additional pressure on the budget. I would like to tell you that aid for newborn Syrian babies had to be halved. At least that is what the German Minister for Development said. There is now an ECHO mission on the ground in Tindouf, which is now under way. That is why I propose that we stick to the compromise text that is now in the resolution and let ECHO report further in our committee. I don't want a position on the matter, I'm neutral. I am neither on one side nor on the other. But I think it is important to keep going on things on the ground, precisely for the sake of refugees and their fate in the desert. So please don't argue ideologies, but argue on the substance. The same applies to IMG, the International Management Group, which has only been recognised as international in the sense of international law by only two Directorates-General. There is no decision by the College on this, although the Financial Regulation provides for such a route. However, there is extensive disinformation here in the house by IMG itself, extensive links between high and former high-ranking Commission staff and the IMG. This conflict of interest must not be left unrefurbishing. But today I ask you not to follow this false information. Today we are going through the first discharge debate by the new Parliament. My first thanks go to you, Mr Court of Auditors, to you, Madam Vice-President, and to all the Commission services, who have tried very credibly to answer our questions during the procedure. My third point is to thank the CONT secretariat, Mrs Castillo and Mr Ehlers and Mr Godts, who have been very supportive of me, and, of course, all the shadow rapporteurs and the advisers to the political groups.

name: Martina Dlabajová
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, President of the Court of Auditors, before approving the report on the discharge to the European Development Fund that I am presenting, is this perhaps the right time to reflect on what we actually expect from this development fund? Its importance and importance could have been inadvertently recalled quite recently in another tragedy off the coast of the Italian island of Lampedusa. In the hot debate on the European Union's migration, asylum and development policy, it may not have been clear enough that the European Development Fund is exactly the instrument that should help prevent this from happening again.  Yes, we mainly expect the Fund to use its limited resources to overcome the causes of huge poverty in countries with unsustainable economic developments and failing public institutions, in countries hit by political and social crises. The European Development Fund cannot completely eliminate this pmalving situation, but it can systematically help prevent some undesirable events, such as the rising and life-threatening emigration of desperate people to European countries. As regards the discharge of the European Development Fund, I consider them to be relevant for at least three reasons: the first is an evaluation of its functioning to date. Let's learn from our mistakes and insuspill ourselves with what's been done. The second reason is the need to prioritise the Fund in the light of the changing needs of the developing world in relation to the European Union. Finally, the third reason is our recommendations for the further functioning of the Fund in the longer term. Of course, on the basis of efficiency and transparency. We have a lot of experience and insights about how the support system has worked so far. In my opinion, it is time to abandon some stereotypes. For example, as regards risks in the countries of the beneficiaries. The risk was simply considered a given fact and this corresponded to a relatively high error rate of the projects being dealt with, which, moreover, did not have the desired effect. Likewise, the monitoring and control system did not always lead to the elimination of the identified deficiencies. Despite the overall great contribution of the aid, this was certainly not an optimal situation in some cases. I therefore consider it necessary to take the following steps: let us assess the strategic priorities of the European Development Fund set together and focus on the really important areas in which we will implement further projects to promote entrepreneurship, infrastructure development or address pressing social issues. To do this, it is necessary to significantly reduce the error rate, to focus on content priorities and to choose the financial instrument and project management that best leads to the goal. In implementing aid, we must perceive the difference in conditions between developing and European countries. We cannot rely solely on local intermediaries, but the solution is not a complete takeover of European practice. We should really sensitively and objectively balance economic and political motives and motives for assistance, because it is also our duty to monitor the effectiveness of financial instruments. European Development Fund funds must be seen as a meaningful returnable investment, not just a gift from a "rich European uncle." Our report agrees that we need a precise, transparent and strategic definition of priorities that meet real and current needs. The use of modern financial instruments can lead to increased efficiency and transparency. We recommend the adoption of a functional system of management, monitoring and control. Last but not least, we recommend that the European Development Fund become an integral part of the European Union budget. Then we will be able to use the means immediately and quickly to help where it is urgently needed. I thank all the shadow rapporteurs for their exemplary and creative cooperation and thank you for the amazing cooperation of both the Commission and the European Court of Auditors.

name: Gilles Pargneaux
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Mr President of the Court of Auditors, Madam Vice-President, Mr President-in-Office, as rapporteur for parliament's discharge for 2013, my primary objective is to ensure that public taxpayers' money is used as best as possible in the European Parliament. I have been fully supported in my approach by the shadow rapporteurs, whom I would particularly like to welcome this afternoon.  In these times of crisis, we must give our support to European citizens by showing them that we are capable of improving, at all possible levels, the efficiency of Parliament's day-to-day work. The European Parliament must continue its efforts in areas where the quality and efficiency of public finance management can still be improved. That is why, in my report, I call for further efforts in certain areas, such as, firstly, the strengthening of controls on the recruitment of local assistants - the number of local assistants per Member of the European Parliament varied from 0 to 43 in 2013 - and then the payment of subsidies to visitor groups, which are mostly cash- 73% in cash and only 27% by bank transfer in 2013.  The third improvement I would like is to pay for the mission costs of staff at the Information Offices of the European Parliament, which increased by 7% in 2013. Video conferencing should be preferred over expensive travel.  I also note the need to go further in parity. I note a lack of parity in senior positions in the administration of Parliament: women represent only 29% of unit heads, 33% of directors general and 34% of directors.  It is also worth stressing the need to reach an agreement on the joint management of the Houses of Europe, between Parliament and the European Commission, in order to share the costs of these houses between the two institutions.  Let us also improve the transmission to the CONT committee of the results of the assessment of the status of accredited parliamentary assistants.  We must also recognize the successes of our administration and, for this reason, I would like to welcome the effective implementation of the ban on Members of Parliament from recruiting family members or their spouses. We must also welcome the 5% reduction in MEMBERS' travel expenses, which resulted in savings of EUR 4 million in 2013. We welcome the savings of 25 million euros in 2013 made by the Directorates General of Interpretation and Translation, as well as the reduction in the budget of the EuroparlTV channel, 8 million euros in 2013 compared to 5 million euros in 2014, in parallel with the increase in the number of videos viewed: between 2012 and 2014, the number of videos viewed rose from 53,000 to 400,000. We must welcome the good preparation for the end of the contracts of the 1,700 accredited parliamentary assistants. I also think we must highlight the effectiveness of the programme to reduce the impressions of documents in Parliament, Paperless, which is a significant improvement which I would like to welcome.  In the plenary vote tomorrow, I will support the amendments calling for more transparency in the management of the overhead envelope by Members. It is an amendment co-signed by the EPP Group and the S-D Group and supported by other groups here, including the ALDE and ECR groups.  Finally, I would like to say that tomorrow I will be defending tighter controls on Members' declarations of interest. On the other hand, as rapporteur, I will oppose the amendments in favour of a single seat for the European Parliament and the abolition of the LUX prize. That, Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, is what I wanted to say in this report.

name: Ryszard Czarnecki
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President of Parliament, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Madam Vice-President of the European Commission, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Schwab, Mr President of the Court, I would like to begin by thanking I have to say six minutes, this will be my longest speech in the European Parliament, and I am in it for the eleventh year. But there is something to talk about, because we will assess how the main institutions of the European Union, including its agencies, control their finances. This is of particular interest to the European taxpayer, the European voter. As far as the European Council is about, unfortunately, we are once again not ready to cooperate with the European Parliament. The Council must participate fully in good faith in the annual discharge procedure, as must other institutions. It cannot be "equal and equal" as in Georges Orwell's novel "Animal Farm", where all animals are equal, but some are more equal. And, by translating Orwell into the European institutions, the Council is such a more equal animal. That cannot be the case. The previous President of the Council came from Belgium, now he is Polish. I don't see any major changes. There is also a Secretary-General from Germany who is leaving and will take up the post of new Secretary-General from Denmark in July. Will it be a new quality? You have to hope so, but it's really not good in that respect. We are still waiting for our questions to be answered, nothing is changing here and many documents are still missing, particularly relating to council building policy.  European Court of Justice – excessive length of proceedings, need for better synergies in translation and interpretation. Note: the need for a real, real geographical balance. Because there is still a problem that the so-called 'new Union', the countries that joined the Union in 2004, are such a poor cousin. Not only in the ECJ, but also – perhaps especially – in the European External Action Service, our EU diplomacy. It must not be the case that, as it is said, the countries of the 'new Union', including my country, Poland, are as if they are from a stepmother, that is, they are immediately in a worse situation, their representatives are less and they occupy worse positions than the representatives of the 'old Union'. This is a real problem that I am once again signalling. With regard to the European Court of Auditors in question, there is certainly a need to improve the quality of audits on the state of implementation of the budget, flexibility is needed in applying audits to certain problems that suddenly arise. The average time taken to create special reports should, of course, be reduced.  As far as I am concerned, here I am returning to this subject, the European External Action Service: the problem is the so-called heavy administration, a large number of high-level posts that should be reviewed in order to simplify decision-making; competences, the responsibilities of the so-called Special Representatives of the Union are still unclear. I would like to stress once again, Ceterum censeo Carthaginem delendam esse, the need for geographical balance, that is to say, the opening of the door to representatives of the 'new Union', including my country, Polish. As regards the agencies, there are 32 agencies that are subject to the discharge procedure. The European Institute of Innovation and Technology is facing the same problems as it did a year ago, and somehow there is no qualitative improvement. In this context, the Court of Auditors assessed the quality of audit certificates issued by independent audit firms as insufficient, despite the fact that the European Institute of Innovation and Technology had previously given appropriate guidance to the companies concerned. The fact that these ex ante checks are not effective is obviously a problem and that must finally be said. As a result, the European Institute of Innovation and Technology has had to cancel some of the agreements already concluded and this money must go back to the budget. Next, the issue of joint ventures, i.e. ECSEL. We can say that, in general, these joint ventures – of course we are also talking about ARTEMIS and ENIAC – which, it can be said, 'gave birth' to ECSEL, because the merger of the two projects took place last year – mainly had problems relating to the reliability of the accounts, the legality and regularity of transactions, internal controls and the implementation of the budget.  When it comes to IMI – a medical area of great interest to our taxpayers and voters – for the second year in a row, errors are above the material threshold of 2%. I hope that tomorrow's vote will send a signal to our voters that we want more transparency when it comes to monitoring the EU institutions.

name: Anders Primdahl Vistisen
text: Rapporteur. Mr President! Thank you to the Court of Auditors, which is why we are all working overtime this evening with 52 reports. I have the pleasure of being shadow rapporteur for some of them for the ECR, and then I have two reports myself. So I have to get through a lot, and I hope you forgive me.  Firstly, in relation to the report on the Commission, I would like to thank you for the hard work done by the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteur. I think it heralds a new and more objective way of assessing where there are problems in the Commission's accounting. We in the ECR Group are very pleased that the line taken by the rapporteur in the report also became the line that went through the Committee on Budgetary Control. We hope that this will also be the line that goes through Parliament when we vote tomorrow. With regard to the European Parliament's own accounts, I would like to thank you for the constructive dialogue that has taken place around the areas that could be attacked or considered problematic. We in the ECR Group are pleased that many of the inputs we provided have been included in the report we are voting on tomorrow. Here, too, we hope that the problematic places will survive tomorrow's vote, so that we can show that budgetary control is something we take seriously, even when it is within our own house.  In relation to my two own rapporteurs, I would like to thank everyone who has been involved. As for one, SESAR, there are not any major comments or problems. I personally fully agree with the group in this House who believe that they should be granted discharge. With regard to the other, ITER, I would have liked a slightly better negotiation with the way the process has been handled. I welcome the support that the S&D Group and the ALDE Group chose to give to my recommendation in the report, and I still hope that tomorrow the PPE Group will choose to look at the guarantees and explanations given in relation to ITER.  In addition, I would just like to say, by way of aside, that I think that some in this House have judged a great deal politically in relation to the fact that we are actually talking about budgetary control, for example as far as ITER is concerned. I think there has been a certain inconsistency in how you assess the things you may not like much about politically compared to the things you are politically in favour of. That cannot and cannot be the point of a committee on budgetary control! Our primary task should be to ensure that citizens' money is spent properly, correctly and in accordance with the political decisions that are available. It must be in the context of the adoption of the policies that the fight over how the money should be distributed should be taken - not subsequently in the context of the discharge procedure. But beyond that, I think overall it has been a positive course of action. I think that the Committee on Budgetary Control has exercised its mandate in a very sensible way. I hope that this will also be evident when the final reports are available tomorrow. Unfortunately, it is still the case that the Commission is above the important point of no more than about 2% of waste, fraud and fraud in the overall budget. As long as it does, neither I nor the ECR Group can vote to grant discharge, but we very much hope and would like to support the rapporteur in the fact that the report on the Commission remains as it stands. We think it's a very reasonable result. We might have wished for a little more, but in the sacred name of compromise it is a much better result than we are used to on that front. Thank you for your cooperation.

name: Jānis Reirs
text: President in office. – Mr President, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur Commission environment president, Mrs Georgieva, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mrs Georgieva, for his excellent work. Honourable Members of the European Parliament, i would like to thank the Rapporteur for his excellent work. Mr Caldeira, President of the Court of Auditors, i would like to thank mr Caldeira for his excellent work. Ladies and Gentlemen! On 23 February, I had the honour to submit to the Committee on Budgetary Control the Council recommendations on unloading to the Commission in respect of the implementation of the 2013 budget. On 23 March the Committee on Budgetary Control also decided to propose that the Commission be discharged for the implementation of the budget. This plenary vote will take place tomorrow, and I trust that it will approve the committee's vote. I am pleased to note that the European Parliament and the Council agree on this important issue. The European Parliament included a number of reservations in its motion for a resolution on the quality of the European Union's financial management. The Council also pointed out in its recommendations that many shortcomings still need to be addressed. The Council is concerned that a large part of payments remains at a high level of error, accounting for 4.7% in 2013. The materiality threshold of 2% is breached in all areas except the administration. The Council regretted that supervisory and control systems were still only partially effective in ensuring the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions and that in a large number of member states of the transactions, the authorities had sufficient information to detect and correct these errors. At the same time, the Council notes that the Error Rate estimated by the Court of Auditors as such does not indicate fraud, wasted or wasted European Union funds. In addition, the Council welcomes all the efforts and actions taken by the Commission and the Member States to implement the Recommendations of the Court of Auditors in recent years. It is all the more appreciated that this was done in the context of a significant increase in the level of duties made. In conditions of limited resources, it is clear that budgetary discipline and the efficient and efficient use of European Union funds should be given greater attention. Sound financial management is important not only from the point of view of public opinion. We have a legal obligation to implement the European Union budget in accordance with the approved rules. All actors involved in the management of European Union funds, including the Member States, must fully assume their share of responsibility. The Council calls on the Commission and the Member States to further improve the effectiveness of management and control systems, while ensuring that the benefits of controls and their costs are in balance. In order to ensure full protection of the Union's financial interests, it is also particularly important to implement corrective measures in a timely way. Finally, I would like to address the issues relating to budgetary management. In this context, the Council considers that clear, comprehensive and timely information on the needs of annual payment appropriations is necessary. It calls on the Commission to provide a reliable forecast of future payment needs, both in the short and long term. Ladies and Gentlemen! The new multiannual financial framework has just begun, and I am pleased that, in the discussions on the new programming period, particular attention has been paid to the creation of a result-based legal framework, both from the Commission, the Council and the European Parliament. This is an excellent opportunity for all of us to achieve a more efficient and qualitative use of EU funds. Of course, the Council is aware that a positive immediate effect of the new elements incorporated is not possible. However, in its recommendations, we call on the Commission to report on progress on the progress to be achieved in a good time and regularly in order to use this information in the negotiations on the next eu multiannual budget. The Council stands ready to engage constructively in all discussions on how to further improve the EU budget implementation framework. Ladies and Gentlemen! Honourable Members, i would like to thank the Rapporteur for his excellent work. Thanks for the attention!

name: Kristalina Georgieva
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, we are here on a core accountability procedure for the European Union – the discharge procedure. It started in November with the Court of Auditors report and it has gone through very thorough discussions. From the Commission side, I want to state very clearly that we take this responsibility very seriously. We take it seriously when we build our control systems, we take it seriously when we communicate to this House when questions are addressed to us, we take it seriously at political level, with my fellow Commissioners engaging this year in an exchange of views with the Committee on Budgetary Control as well as at technical level. We take the vote of the Council and the vote in the Committee on Budgetary Control to grant discharge to the Commission for the year 2013 as an encouragement. It is an encouragement to us as the Commission and an encouragement to our staff. I want to thank Members for that and I hope tomorrow’s vote will confirm their recommendation. For the Commission, budget implementation is built on multiple blocks – setting—up of control systems, selection of projects, publication of tenders, signature of contracts, verification of payment claims and the transfer of many thousands of payments. It is part of a multi-year process and it will not finish tomorrow, even if, as I hope, the accounts for 2013 will be closed. Mrs Gräßle’s report, and before that the report of the Court of Auditors, gave us a nuanced picture. There are positive elements. The accounts of the European Union were signed off for the seventh year in a row. The Court concluded that EU revenue, all commitments and expenditure, were free from material error and that the previous year’s trend of an increase in the error rate had been arrested: 4.7% in 2013 versus 4.8% in 2012. But we do not take this to be the focus of our attention. The focus of our attention is where we have to do more and where we have to do better.  We need to do more and better in compliance with the rules in the areas of shared management, agriculture and cohesion – we heard that from the rapporteurs – in the controls operated by national authorities in Member States to detect errors early so that they can be addressed early, and we do not get to the point of interrupting payments. We, on the side of the Commission, first and foremost take as our goal to protect the budget against fraud. We have discussed today Mrs Macovei’s report on the European Public Prosecutor’s Office. I am co-responsible for it. It is part of a system we want to build that helps us to stop fraud and deter wrongdoing in respect of our budget. There are also a lot of things we can do to improve the way we protect our taxpayer’s money. I want to stress that in the Juncker Commission we are concentrated on four critical points.  First, simplify the rules. Make them more understandable, easy to apply and easy to control, with fewer errors. The Court is very clear – simple rules mean fewer errors. This year we will pursue work that we have already started. I will present an updated administrative simplification scoreboard to show what has been achieved and what else we have to do.  Simplification is important for our second objective – to improve the cost effectiveness of management and control systems. We now spend between 2% and 7% of the total costs on controls. Obviously, we want effective controls and we want to think of the best way to use taxpayer’s money.  For this, the third element is to further improve the reliability of information, especially that which we collect from Member States, to make sure that we actually apply the most important recommendation of the Court which is a single audit chain: do not do multiple audits when we can actually have one. For that we have to have credible information. National declarations are important. We hope we will see more of them. Fourth and last, it is of utmost importance to take into account the multiannual nature of our problems and to improve our corrective capacity. We are using this seriously. Over the last five years the amount of financial corrections was on average 2.2% of all payments.  In 2013 we opened 265 new interruption cases with a value of almost EUR 5 billion. We are now in the new multi-year perspective, a new financial period. Obviously, as the Minister said, we have to focus on compliance, but equally or even more on what we get for our taxpayers’ money. In this sense, the use of the performance reserve, the leverage of our budget, how we can get more from it, the use of macroeconomic conditionality, are all building blocks of our commitment to a budget that delivers the highest possible value to our citizens. We have committed to an EU budget focused on results as part of our work programme. I look forward to the interinstitutional working group on performance budgeting that would help us all to go in this direction. I apologise for overstepping my time. I want to finish by making a sincere commitment to work with the institutions – with Parliament, the Council and the Court of Auditors – for the sake of making our citizens proud of the work we do for them.

name: Vítor Manuel da Silva Caldeira
text: President of the European Court of Auditors. – Mr President, I would like to thank this Parliament for this opportunity to say a few words on this particular occasion when we are starting an important debate that will close the discharge procedure for the financial year 2013. I would also like to congratulate all the rapporteurs for their reports and, in particular, the Committee on Budgetary Control. It is very gratifying for us in the European Court of Auditors, and all those who work there, to see such an extensive and thorough use of the work we have done in this particular field. As the final year of the last spending period, 2013 followed the same pattern as previous years. The accounts of the European Union for that year are reliable – and Vice-President Georgieva has underlined this clearly. However, too many payments – although correctly recorded and accounted for – should not have been made because they did not meet the conditions for payment. This is an area where we need to work, because there is room for improvement along the European Union accountability chain from those that are responsible at the first level for ensuring that there are indeed cost-effective systems in place.  More could be done by the Member State authorities that are responsible for this primary management and controls, mainly because there is information already available to make sure that payments fully comply with the rules. The European Commission can also further improve its reporting at the EU level on the estimated errors, financial corrections and recoveries. These are two elements where we think we can do better. But, as has been emphasised previously, the pressing need is to improve the information on the results we achieve. This is a symptomatic, underlying problem of the European Union budgetary system. We need to pay more attention to the results achieved with the funds available from the European Union. That is the single key message I would like to emphasise again today from our annual report. This is particularly important as we are now starting a new financial framework period. We have new systems in place for the 2014 to 2020 period. This is again an opportunity to put these things right from the beginning and to strengthen the EU accountability chain. In this context, we should welcome the plans already disclosed by the European Commission to foster a performance culture in the EU’s financial management. That culture needs to be based, in our view, on a genuine commitment by the financial management at all levels to achieve results. It also requires there to be clear targets and effective incentives for achieving them. Finally, we note that this House has taken heed, in the report on the discharge, of all our warnings and recommendations on a number of issues, not least regarding the need for adequate transparency and accountability arrangements for financial instruments, namely those designed to fund investment. This is also an issue we have raised in our recent opinion on the ‘Juncker plan’. The EU cannot afford for the achievement of results to be an afterthought. It should be the focus of EU spending. As a Court, we look forward to continuing to work closely with your institution, this Parliament, to help ensure that best use is made of European Union funds to deliver results for citizens.

name: Anneli Jäätteenmäki
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Foreign Affairs. – Mr President, I am speaking on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs. I would like to raise two points. The first is cost-effectiveness and the means to save EU and EU Member States money, as well as the fact that citizens are valued for their tax money from common EU services. Consular services should be able to be provided by EU delegations. It would save money. Unfortunately, consular services must now be sought on the side of each Member State, there is no common one.  The second point I would like to draw attention to is that the staff of the External Action Service could say distortions. From the outset, the situation there has been, and still is, that there are many more staff from the old Member States and large Member States, including in relation to the population. Moreover, there are very few women in the External Action Service, contrary to what Lady Ashton promised when she set up the External Action Service. He promised to pay attention to this issue, but there is much to be done.

name: Norbert Neuser
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Development. Mr President, Vice-President, President-in-Office of the Council, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has As a development politician, I am speaking out on an issue of humanitarian aid. It concerns the Tindouf refugee camp in Algeria. I fear that, if you follow this report, humanitarian aid in Tindouf will be significantly reduced. The Committee on Budgetary Control refers to an incident in 2003 that was resolved in 2007. And year after year, it is now being checked whether the measures that we have taken as the Commission are in order. The number of aid recipients there in Tindouf is known. This has been confirmed again by the scientific service. I am afraid that the debate here between two countries – between Algeria and Morocco – will lead to a shortfall in humanitarian aid for the refugees in Tindouf. That is why you would like to vote in favour of Amendment No 27 tomorrow.

name: Reimer Böge
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on International Trade. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which First of all, the Committee on International Trade notes positively that the most likely error rate has decreased in 2013. However, we have to note that 29% of all the transactions audited in the fields of external relations, external aid and enlargement were flawed, mainly due to procedural violations, non-existent eligibility for expenditure and loss of performance. We believe it is necessary for the Court of Auditors' comments on the issue of preferential trade agreements to be taken very seriously by the Commission. There is still a lack of an adequate overall economic impact assessment by the Commission. We support the Court of Auditors' recommendation on the rectification of deficiencies in ex ante and ex post evaluations and on weaknesses in customs controls. Here, of course, the Member States are first and foremost responsible for their original responsibilities. This must be improved. We also believe it is necessary to control all SME support activities in third markets and to identify ways of better cooperation between the various actors, including in the sense of a sound budget.

name: Markus Ferber
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which The Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs has, of course, paid particular attention to the three supervisory authorities – banking supervision, securities supervision and insurance supervision. We welcome, in principle, the work of these supervisory structures, because they were urgently needed in order to contribute to achieving uniform application of rules in the European Union and bringing together Europe's fragmented financial market. On the other hand, we are already criticising the fact that all three supervisory authorities, within the framework of directives, go far beyond what they have been mandated by the legislator for. That is why we are asking the three supervisory authorities to comply here with what they have also been given a mandate from the legislator – that is, the European Parliament and the Council of Ministers. I think it is in all our interests to do so here. We would therefore be pleased if these comments by the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs were also supported in plenary tomorrow.

name: Marian Harkin
