text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. – Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Czarnecki, for taking on board most of my suggestions in regard to the four agencies under our remit in the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, namely: Cedefop, Eurofound, the European Training Foundation and EU-OSHA. While there are still some minor issues with regard to prevention and management of conflicts of interest, good progress has been made. In regard to internal audits, all recommendations that have been taken on board are either completed or on track. Good progress is also being made with regard to the implementation of the Commission’s approach on EU decentralised agencies and the related roadmap, which should help foster the performance culture referred to by Mr Caldeira. Finally, I want to highlight the fact that the Court of Auditors report showed a slight decrease for estimated error rate in the area of employment and social affairs, down from 3.2% in 2012 to 3.1% in 2013, which is the second lowest among all policy areas. However, it is important to say that we expect these improvements to continue.

name: Giovanni La Via
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as draftsman of the opinion on discharge on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy, I wanted to say a few words about the annual discharge for the 2013 budget of the five agencies that fall within our competence.  In general, both with regard to implementation and with regard to the correct and regular management of the resources made available by the agency, our opinion is positive. Specifically, we wanted to point out that for the European Environment Agency we welcomed the fact that the Agency has a comprehensive strategy for managing and preventing conflicts of interest.  For EFSA, we welcome the efforts made in the area of conflict of interest management and prevention to safeguard independence and transparency in all operational areas of the authority, covering both external and internal staff. For ECDC, we welcomed the Centre's efforts to complement corrective actions taken on the basis of previous assessments by the Court of Auditors.

name: Georgi Pirinski
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Transport and Tourism. – Mr President, the Committee on Transport and Tourism welcomes the high implementation rate for transport and mobility and the fact that the error rate is below 2% for most of the programmes. Nevertheless, we are concerned that for research the error rate remains above 2%, and that compliance with public procurement rules remains a continuing problem. Furthermore, for the sake of transparency we strongly feel that the Commission should publish an annual list of transport projects co-financed by the Union with the exact funding amounts for each project. It is also of major importance to ensure strong synergy and cooperation between different sources of EU funding in order to avoid duplication and to guarantee their most effective and efficient use. The draft resolution on the Commission's discharge is marked by frequent extreme criticism based on unilateral selection of examples and biased assessments, an approach that is proving welcome for Eurosceptics. This approach is underlined with regard to Bulgaria and other countries of Eastern and Southern Europe. The data presented for these countries suggest that they only make mistakes and failures in the absorption of European funds. Their good results and positions on a number of indicators, as well as progress in problem areas, have been deliberately ignored. The common interests of our citizens clearly require the opposite – balanced and objective – approach. It is this approach that is enshrined in the proposals of the Socialists and Democrats. However, I am not entirely disappointed in Mrs Gresle as she has found it possible to join two of our important amendments.

name: Искра Михайлова
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Regional Development. – Mr President, I am taking part today in this debate on the 2013 discharge of the Commission in my capacity as Chair of the Committee on Regional Development and at the same time rapporteur for the procedure thereto. I congratulate Mrs Gresle as rapporteur for the precise, detailed and focused report, and I would like to point out that I am very pleased that some of the REGI committee's proposals have found a place in the final version of the report.  Central to us is the Commission's focus on a culture aimed at delivering results – results to take into account, above all, the efficiency, effectiveness and impact of cohesion policy. I am pleased to see such an understanding on the part of the Court of Auditors and the European Commission. I draw attention to the fact that extreme measures to interrupt payments can bring unintended results behind them.

name: Peter Jahr
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture. Mr President, I would like to thank the The Committee on Agriculture and Industrial Policy took part in the budget discharge for the first time in an opinion I drafted, because the Committee on Agriculture and Industrial Policy cannot ignore the report from the Court of Auditors and does not want to ignore it, because it has a direct impact on our political work. Three brief comments. Firstly, I still call for a uniform system for determining the error rate between the Commission and the Court of Auditors, as the error rates identified vary considerably and cause political confusion overall. Secondly, an increased error rate, which I also fear with the new common agricultural policy, often reflects too bureaucratic a policy. We now have two types of errors. Some are user-related, the others are made in the system. Thirdly, I was very surprised at the unreliability of information coming from the Member States. As the Commission had to correct the error rate in 43 out of 67 cases in 2013.

name: Alain Cadec
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Fisheries. Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to recall the crucial role of the European Fisheries Control Agency in Vigo. It has a fundamental role to play in monitoring the proper implementation of the reform of the common fisheries policy, and in particular the landing obligation, which we adopted this morning. Since its inception, the Agency has achieved very good monitoring results. It also ensures coordination and implementation of monitoring activities in all Member States. I am satisfied with the statement of the Court of Auditors regarding the legality and regularity of the transactions relating to the Agency's annual accounts for the 2013 financial year. I should also congratulate the Agency for its excellent engagement credit execution rate (99%) and the proper execution of payment credits (84%). I also welcome the level of consumption of deferred credits, with an execution rate of 90%. For all these reasons, as rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Fisheries, I have proposed to give discharge to the Executive Director of the European Fisheries Control Agency.

name: Fernando Maura Barandiarán
text: draftser of the opinion of the Committee on Culture and Education. – Mr President, I would first like to say that I have been pleased that this year the budgetary implementation rate for the Erasmus+ and Creative Europe 2007-2013 programmes has been 100%. But, on the other hand, in relation to other programmes of the Committee on Culture and Education, I note that, unfortunately, Europe with Citizens, which is a direct link between the European Union and citizens in supporting civil actions, petitions and rights, has an excessively low level of funding. Further, as mentioned in a Eurobarometer report on access to culture, I am concerned about how public budgets for safeguarding and promoting cultural heritage are declining significantly at European level. I therefore consider it necessary to strengthen the Union's instruments aimed at supporting the European Agenda on Culture.

name: Sylvie Guillaume
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. Mr President, as every year, the Court of Auditors has scrutinized the annual accounts of the nine agencies whose activities fall within the jurisdiction of the LIBE Committee. Budget discharge notices do not always generate delirious enthusiasm ... However, on closer inspection, this dump is of great political importance. A large number of agencies have been set up in the area of freedom, security and justice. The financial risk associated with the agencies is relatively low compared to the total EU budget, but the risk to the Union's reputation is high. Agencies enjoy a high profile in the Member States and have a significant influence on policy-making, decision-making and programme implementation, all in sectors that are very sensitive to the daily lives of our fellow Europeans. For all the budgets of the various entities subject to the LIBE committee's assessment, the overall balance sheet is positive. In general, there is an improvement over the previous year's comments and criticisms. That being said, agencies must continue to be encouraged to improve their budget planning, transparency in their budgetary functioning and the optimal use of their budgets.

name: Iratxe García Pérez
text: draftser of the opinion of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality. – Mr President, gender equality is a fundamental principle of the European Union and must therefore be a priority in all policies implemented and also in budgetary implementation. From the Committee on Women's Rights we have been claiming for quite some time the need for impact studies to see how the implementation of the various European programmes and projects has the effect and achieves equality between men and women in the European Union, in all the instruments existing in the programmes dedicated to the European Cohesion Funds , the European Social Fund and all those programmes that collaborate with organisations working in this area. We value in a very positive way the budgetary implementation of the European Institute for Gender Equality, which we believe should be boosted, supported and improved in order to allow us to have the maximum chance of having studies in this regard.

name: Markus Pieper
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, I would like to thank the I have changed my place here briefly, to the Commission. Thank you, Inge Gräßle, thank you for this very valuable report, which picks up exactly the right points. As a former rapporteur, I am particularly pleased that the Commission is now taking on more responsibility directly in the Member States through structural fund controls. The Commission is also serious about the repayment of funds, see France and Agriculture. Structural and agricultural expenditure, however, remain our children of concern. The Commission must state more clearly what data it bases in the Member States, and it must look more closely at those countries that have problems, but which do not overrun all countries with stricter rules. With regard to Parliament's budget, there are many positive signals here, for example in building management and in saving ongoing costs. Nevertheless, in order to make a real difference, we need more transparency. In the case of personnel development and expenditure, we have now requested a number of reports setting deadlines. But the costs of our flagship projects – the House of History and the LUX Prize – are also better valued. We need to rethink the efficiency of funding and review it again and again. That is what the citizens expect of us, and we owe it to our political mandate.

name: Inés Ayala Sender
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, I would like to thank President Caldeira, who makes the Court of Auditors evolve with us, discharge after discharge, fine-tuning procedures and wisdom to assure taxpayers that the European budget, while dwindling, is increasingly being used correctly. I would like to thank in a special way the presence of Mr Reirs of the Council, even if we still do not agree on the different role of our two institutions in discharge. I don't lose hope of reaching an agreement someday. And, of course, I would like to warmly welcome Commissioner Georgieva, who is launching in this process of discharge and who I am sure will be of great help with her good practice, her rigour and her ability to distinguish the important from the superfluous. This 2013 financial year was simple and complex at the same time, as it was a question of approving the management of a Commission that no longer exists, that of Mr Barroso, after also adopting all the Regulations relating to the new budget for the period 2014-2020. New systems, then, and was therefore about taking stock, expressing our concerns, recognising progress and making the necessary recommendations to a new Commission, Mr Juncker's. It was not, then, a usual business ace. That is why Mrs Grule was given the mandate as chairman of the Committee on Budgetary Control. We gave him the mandate, all the groups, mine too. Hence it should have been an exercise in bringing positions closer, of obtaining a rigorous but truthful, impartial and balanced report. With increasing astonishing we have attended an exercise in the face of a few scapegoats, these always being the weakest: the Saharawis of tinduf field or the engineers and workers on the front line of fire of the IMG organization, not to mention others. However, there is a double standard, since with great surprise we discovered that, on the other hand, Mrs Grule was prepared to justify and explain a risk well above 2%, and on the rise, for the R&D&I sector. I have to say that this drift we stop quickly in the vote in committee. That is why I must say, with some sadness, that the rapporteur's use of OLAF's reports has not been exemplary and that we hope that in the future this will not be repeated.

name: Bernd Kölmel
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the According to the findings of the European Court of Auditors, the EU budget has been largely properly implemented. For this we, the ECR Group, thank all THE EU officials, and in particular, of course, the European Court of Auditors for its audit. In addition to regularity, it is of central importance to us that the EU budget is only used for necessary tasks and that it is carried out economically and sparingly. Subsidiarity is needed. This is not always the case. We still, or almost increasingly, have tasks in the EU that we carry out. The EU would not have to take advantage of this, and the Member States can do the same. For example, the more than 40 agencies. We ask ourselves: does all this have to be with the EU? Is it economic that we also have agencies in addition to a Commission? For example, the Institute for Gender Equality. We are therefore asking us to consider whether this institute is necessary at all. In our opinion, not.

name: Michael Theurer
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ALDE Group. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. First of all, a thank you from the ALDE Group to the European Court of Auditors. It is crucial for us to uncover the misappropriation of funds and to look into the administration. All in all, we would like to say that the central demand of the ALDE Group in the past – namely better budgetary control – has been taken up by the Commission and implemented with the Member States. Reservations and corrections have been applied to make better use of the funds, since 80% of the EU budget is used by the Member States. We encourage the Commission to continue along this path, because the error rate remains too high in some areas, such as regional and structural policy and also in agricultural policy. The Court of Auditors' reports show that there is a need for action here, above all in the Member States. I shall therefore address the representatives of the Council on this point. There are Court of Auditors reports which show that the procurement procedure in particular is too complicated. And that is what the proposers are telling us, the Members, are telling us. Making applications is very difficult for many, especially non-governmental voluntary organisations. We in the ALDE Group are therefore calling for efforts to make the budget simpler, so that the bureaucratic burden can be reduced. Better use of funds must be the top priority in the EU agenda. Better budgetary control also requires a change over our budget to a result-oriented budget. Here, Mrs Georgieva, we expect you to make good on your promise and to get concrete proposals. We want the Member States to take the lead, for flat rates and small limits to be implemented. Administrative simplification is the best way to reduce the error rate.

name: Rina Ronja Kari
text: gue/NGL Group. Mr President! I would like to start by thanking colleagues in the committee who have produced some very good and critical reports. I think again this year we have had a very good cooperation. Although we may not agree on everything, the result has been good. I would also like to thank the auditors for the very thorough reports that come from there. Unfortunately, again this year there are good reasons to be critical, especially when we look at the error rate, which remains far too high. This year it has reached as much as 4.7%, and that is, of course, unacceptable. The many billions of euros that are affected by either errors, fraud or fraud could have been spent on good things, such as creating jobs or on the environment. That is why we cannot support granting discharge to the Commission this year either. We need to get this right.  We must also note again this year that the Council clearly does not want to contribute to more openness and democracy in the European Union. Now the Council has had the chance to grant discharge for 2007, 8, 9, 10, 11, 12 and now again for 2013. However, the Council will still not respond to Parliament's questions on their accounts, which is why we in the Committee on Budgetary Control have refused to grant discharge. I really hope that the whole House will back it. It is nothing short of a scandal that the Council continues to deny us access to information. And it is frankly completely incomprehensible that they can bring themselves to refer to a gentleman's agreement from the 1970s. Dear friends, we should not just try to take democracy a little more seriously than that! We owe it to the citizens. It is also important! It is important for the citizens that we in this House unite in this rejection. It is important for the citizens that we in Parliament send a clear signal that we will not accept that the Council will not answer our questions. Transparency is needed and the money must be managed.

name: Bart Staes
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – This discharge, ladies and gentlemen, is the culmination of the last budget period of the multiannual budget which ended in 2013. Time to draw conclusions. The margin of error, averaging 4.7 percent, remains significantly above the acceptable figure of 2 percent. It is very important to note that the error rate in the policy areas with shared management is 5.2%. We all know that the Member States should have known or knew that certain sums should not have been paid. I therefore agree with Mr Caldeira when he says that we must act against it. It is very important – as Mrs Gräßle nicely points out in her report – that we hold the Member States to account and that we make national or regional ministers who fail to take their political responsibility and act very clearly in this area.

name: Marco Valli
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the discharge procedure unfortunately points to, once again, the stalemate in the European project, blocked by the interests of lobbies and parties in all the Member States, which over the years have swallowed up a flood of money without creating added value to the detriment very often of taxpayers, some EUR 140 billion of the Union's 2013 budget. , less than 1% of GDP for a European who wants to aspire in words to be the Europe of common policies, but who apparently does not have the backbone to stand up and then drags on, like an invertebrate, swallowing up resources for the approval of the parties and Of Europe, ready to share the cake, starting with the scandalous contributions in the budget of this Parliament.  In 2013, European foundations and political parties received a total of more than 30 million euros, 22.3 million euros per party, 11.3 million for foundations. The budget for political parties and foundations increased by 167% between 2009 and 2015 without adequate justification. However, we want to be involved in this discharge. Therefore, one thing above all, for our group, the funds, especially those with regional management, must be managed in a more transparent way, with the help of the Member States and the Commission.  Above all, we need to create performance in terms of employment and innovation. No more work programmes that no longer generate employment or development funds for useless works or projects. However, I would like to thank all my colleagues in the Committee on Budgetary Control and the chairman who have a clear position in the fight against fraud and corruption. I therefore hope that many of the issues in the report will be implemented later by the Commission and the Member States. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – You speak very nicely of political parties, as if you are not from a political party. You're talking about political groups as if you're not part of a political group. You're talking about the money spent by the European institutions as if you don't take your salary from the European Parliament. Why these criticisms?  We need to work together so that the European institutions use this creative and useful money for citizens. That's where I agree! But I don't think we need to use populist arguments against democratic principles.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: Answer to a blue card question. I would like to remind you of who we are. We are a political movement born in Italy, which has refused as much as EUR 40 million in contributions precisely for the parties, since we are a movement and we do everything with voluntary fundraising by the citizens.  So this is our first push to try to bring politics closer to the citizens. We can also finance ourselves in different ways and we in the 5-Star Movement have given up as a delegation to be part of these parties and foundations because, precisely, we believe that there are other ways of financing political activity.

name: Louis Aliot (NI).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the discharge report calls for the following observation. The systematic questioning of the management of the budget by The Member States and the Commission, questioning this shared management, calls for a substantive debate on the future of the European institutions.  These error rates are no longer acceptable, whether it is regional policy or rural development. The European Court of Auditors has serious doubts about the data provided by the Member States. But some institutions also knowingly provide erroneous data, which proves that this system does not work, because the repetition of errors not corrected in time discredits the functioning of the whole and demonstrates the sclerosis of this scheme. The most recent cases of fraud concern agencies and, in particular, the procurement of public contracts or conflicts of interest among some experts.  Finally, could we clarify the case of the IMG, a specialized agency that has been under investigation since 2011 and of which little is known? This international organisation has benefited from European funds without ever having participated in tenders. Between 1994 and 2014, it received 135 million euros! OLAF notes that this agency does not have a legal existence. In the interests of transparency, MEPs are asking for all the necessary information.

name: Claudia Schmidt (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the In my opinion, development aid, which has so far been largely financed and instrumentalised by the European Development Fund, needs to be completely rethought. In any case, the error rates reported by the Court of Auditors are far too high in most areas. If we are spending money in the poorest regions of the world to give people a better life, local governments must also play along and meet certain performance indicators. If this does not happen, the payments must also be suspended. It is unacceptable for payments to be made where it is not possible to understand what is then being done within the framework of the national budgets with the funds. Equally problematic are the multi-year payment obligations, for which it can then only be settled after the entire period. Clear criteria for interim accounting and success criteria must be defined, complied with and monitored. In addition, the European Development Fund clearly needs more flexibility in order to be able to respond quickly and sustainably to humanitarian disasters. Especially now, with the refugee disaster off Lampedusa and the tragic conditions in Nepal, people urgently need our sustainable help. It is not enough to inject money and then hope for the best. Instead, specific projects are to be supported to help people on the ground in a sustainable way.

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D).
text: – We are debating the 2013 discharge, the last year of the 2007-2013 financial perspective, but at the same time the discharge to the Commission, which is simply gone because its term of office is over. That is, one of the essential functions of discharge that could decide the Commission's further simply disappears. But it is particularly important to assess the use of funds in kind with a particular focus on the level of errors. Indeed, this error rate, which is often between 4 and 5%, is much higher than what we would like to have. As for the lessons and lessons of the financial and economic crisis, I think we should probably learn a little more here. Subsequently, a performance orientation – this is particularly important here, the verification of priorities and the assessment of their degree of achievement and, finally, the methodology common to the European Court of Auditors and the European Commission for the preparation of reports and measures. I think that here the methodology and contribution of the ECA deserve great recognition.  What are we definitely missing or unsustainable in this report? This is, on the one hand, an indication of shortcomings, but, on the other hand, for sustainability, to show where improvement has taken place and how the European Commission can control the Member States.

name: Richard Ashworth (ECR).
text: – Mr President, we are operating with a significantly reduced MFF so our priority has to be to make sure that the money we do have works harder. That means a significant change in attitude and culture amongst many of the European institutions with spending responsibilities. In future the yardstick by which we measure performance must be added value and value for money.  Much of that was evidenced in this audit report and I particularly thank the auditors for highlighting the need for greater transparency and accountability, for budget discipline and for compliance. I suggest that this can be best achieved by this House adopting a greater role over quality and performance auditing. In taking this opportunity to thank the President and members of the Court, can I express a wish that we can find ways to work together to achieve a much more outcome-driven budgeting performance; better, more informed prioritisation; better performance monitoring and better value for money. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. –  Mr Ashworth, would you agree, when we discussed the budget and budgetary control (which you did mention rather well), that there is in fact a fault line that cannot be bridged between the 11 Member States of the European Union that pay out money and the 17 Member States or so of the European Union that receive money? That fault line cannot be bridged. There is a basic conflict of interest and an insuperable one. Would you agree?

name: Richard Ashworth (ECR)
text: blue-card answer. – If you insist on maximising fault lines you will never achieve a European Union of 28 states which choose to work together. I suggest we find the elements we have in common, the areas where we wish to work together, and maximise those and stop talking about fault lines and where we do not cooperate.

name: Nedzhmi Ali (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, we support the envisaged proposal for the Parliament resolution on the discharge in respect of the EU agencies for 2013. In the report regarding the implementation of financial management and control, the main aspects of agencies’ functioning in 2013 are covered. Talking about the agencies and their activities we should be aware that their main tasks must not be to spend a percentage of the funds but to spend in an optimal way to implement their missions and to provide added value for European citizens.  Based on this and the recent migration issue, I would like to draw your attention to the case of the Frontex Agency. The agency’s mission is to promote, coordinate and develop European border management in line with the EU Charter on Fundamental Rights. In this regard I would like at the end of each financial year to know to what extent the agency has been effective and has contributed to the coordination and implementation of joint operation at external borders, and analysed intelligence on the situation at the external borders, providing rapid response capabilities and assisting Member States in joint return operations. These issues have become more important in recent years in connection with the change in the overall EU strategy on resources and the worsened security environment and problems concerning migrants to the EU.  For me, as a representative of Bulgaria, one of the countries with external borders upon which there is a dramatically increased migration pressure, two main aspects are essential – growth in the agency’s budget and an improved strategy that fits distribution management.  It is a relationship like this between the amount of money spent and the actual results achieved in the implementation of agenciesʼ missions that should guide the discharge at the end of the financial year.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE).
text: – I would like to thank Mrs Gräβle for her excellent report and, of course, my colleagues in the CONT Committee and, of course, also the Court of Auditors. We have heard many times today that the Court of Auditors' report has found quite a few important things, notably the level of error that has fallen, but not as much as we would have liked. However, I think that the clear objective in the European Parliament is to ensure that public funds are used as correctly and transparently as possible. That is true, but one of these joint ventures cannot say that. It is an ITER project. I would particularly like to highlight poor planning here. The project's estimated costs have increased from €5 billion to €16 billion from 2006 to today. Delays in achieving the targets: instead of 2006, the project is expected to be completed by 2027. And some other examples of mismanagement, as also identified by the Court of Auditors, in particular the change in the scope of the project results and the unrealistic timetable. All this, of course, convinces us that it would be irresponsible to grant the 2013 discharge to the project. Because if we were to grant discharge, we would in some way ignore the effort and, of course, the findings of the Court of Auditors and also what we have adopted at CONT. And I sincerely hope that members in this plenary will not give discharge to this project.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, in the EUR 155 billion budget there are lots of budget lines that are worthy of discussion. For the moment I will leave aside the budget line relating to the 35 staff members, including an usher, that are allocated to the President of Parliament. These are the baubles, bangles and beads of that office, an office which itself is a form of political costume jewellery.  I am specifically going to address the budget line that relates to the instrument for pre-accession that is paid out to candidate countries. This was EUR 11.5 billion for the years 2007-2013 and another EUR 11.7 billion has already been allocated for 2014-2020. The context for candidate countries is, as Mr Juncker has stated, and I quote: ‘in the next five years no new members will be joining us in the European Union’. It is therefore very hard to understand why candidate countries will be receiving pre-accession funding at this level. Indeed, it is hard to understand why they are receiving pre-accession funding at all.  One egregious abnormality in this is the amount of pre-accession funding that is going to Turkey. Today’s Turkey systematically violates human rights and in a further outrage has yet to acknowledge what happened a hundred years ago. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – I want to ask you: Why do you get so much hostility towards those countries that receive help from the European Union, who want to become our members? Why did you get so many such unpleasant words when here my colleagues and I, who was minister for European integration in the Republic of Croatia, received help from the European Union and here I came to this Parliament and became your colleague? I feel like you have something against us.  I don't think it's right how a respected colleague performs.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: blue-card answer. – I was simply pointing out the very large sums of money allocated under the Instrument for Pre-Accession Funding, which incidentally most people are not aware of, certainly not in the UK. This is despite the fact that, as I indicated, and Mr Juncker has said – it is not me saying it – no new members will be joining in the next five years. It makes absolutely no sense at all and it is a large waste of money, and it is anticipating an eventuality that probably may not arise. I very much hope that it does not, especially in the case of Turkey. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Timothy Kirkhope (ECR)
text: blue-card question. –  Lord Dartmouth, do you not think there is just a little tinge of hypocrisy in your contribution this evening, bearing in mind the financial issues which have attended upon the United Kingdom Independence Party over the last few years? Do you really feel particularly secure in the remarks you are making and the details in particular?

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: blue-card answer. – I would just say one thing: that is a cheap debating point which has got no validity and is unworthy of your political group, unworthy of your political party and unworthy of you who, in other contexts, I have tremendous respect for.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, President of the Court of Auditors, first of all, let me warmly thank you for the excellent report by Mrs Gräßle, who has done a really excellent job.  I've been involved in agencies. A large number of the 32 European agencies face various challenges. From conflicts of interest to low transparency and internal integrity to poor implementation and budget planning. Many of the agencies are trying to solve these problems, others are trying to solve them less successfully. Therefore, discharge should be postponed to the EIT, whose budgetary performance was very unconvincing in a given year and, as we already know, this will be the case in the following year, that is in 2014. The state of the agency's account was very disappointing. Budget implementation was low and the agency had problems with ex ante verification of subsidy transactions. The European Court of Auditors has even revealed weaknesses in public procurement and conflicts of interest with low absorption capacity. There is a lot of room for improvement.  On the contrary, Frontex, which has had problems with subsidy contracts, should obtain discharge despite its weaknesses. I think this is very important, especially because of what is happening now in the Mediterranean.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank the Court of Auditors for the work it has put into the discharge. As one of the shadows on the agencies report I wanted to concentrate on that in my contribution and to thank the rapporteur for his work. The S&D Group will be following the Budget Control Committee’s position and vote to grant discharge on all the agencies except the European Institute of Innovation & Technology (EIT). However I would hope that the EIT can show enough progress in the coming months to allow us to grant it discharge also later this year. The S&D Group has put down a number of amendments to the horizontal report, mainly relating to staffing issues. For example, we oppose the imposition of extra staffing cuts above those already-agreed targets. Additionally we would oppose cuts which would mean that the agencies would have difficulty in fulfilling their mandates. Indeed some of the agencies, according to the agencies network, are already having difficulties because of a lack of staff. We believe staffing budgets should be based on how each agency has to fulfil its mandate and not based on arbitrary figures or indeed arbitrary cuts. We also believe that agencies which get their funding from fees should have greater flexibility in their staffing requirements.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR).
text: – The European Court of Auditors has a budget of EUR 140 million per year. For this, we will receive one report that has virtually nothing to do with it, and, in addition, some of the complaints about suspected corruption that are being filed with OLAF. For 2014, the European Court of Auditors lodged 14 complaints with OLAF. That is exactly as much as I have given – I have also made 14 complaints in a year. And it is in the European funds that there is a huge amount of corruption, because people think that this money has fallen from the sky. I consider it a makeover for all European taxpayers if the European Court of Auditors, with a budget of EUR 140 million, make 14 complaints in one year, and corruption exists in virtually every single project. The European Court of Auditors itself is the best example of the waste of European taxpayers' money.

name: Gerben-Jan Gerbrandy (ALDE).
text: I too would like to thank the Court of Auditors for its annual report, especially as the Court of Auditors has discovered a fundamental problem in the European budget. It is, in that view, far too little focused on results. The Court of Auditors states that the Member States use a method they call 'use it or lose it'. The possible results of expenditure hardly play a role. I will give you two examples of special reports from the Court of Auditors last year in which expenditure was found to have no demonstrable results. That is, firstly, the programme for the food processing industry, with a total budget of EUR 5.6 billion, and secondly, the rural nature-promoting measures programme: EUR 10.5 billion. More than €16 billion combined over the total seven-year budget period. Incredibly! So awful a lot of money with no results. We must therefore address the failure to deliver results with the utmost urgency. A fundamental change in the European budget is very much needed. I am therefore pleased that my idea has been adopted in the Committee on Budgetary Control to create a special advisory group to this end.

name: Benedek Jávor (Verts/ALE).
text: - Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. On the discharge of Parliament, I would like to draw attention to two things. One is the issue of transparency. The current report or report is a small step on the road to strengthening transparency, but it needs to go further. We need to be transparent and accountable not only to the institutions, but also to ourselves. The transparency of the available frameworks for Members of Parliament should be further strengthened. There are proposals in the text in this regard, they need to be voted on, and I think that further steps are needed. I would also like to draw attention to the fact that, in the case of Parliament, we should not only discuss the issues of the paris climate summit at the end of the year and adopt resolutions in this connection, but we should also make progress ourselves in greening Parliament's functioning, reducing CO2 emissions, and this could also mean budgetary savings through energy efficiency.  With regard to the agencies, I would just like to highlight two elements, one of which is the issue of Frontex, which is also mentioned by others. The tragedies of the past have highlighted the need for greater funding for Frontex, and in particular for helping refugees, but at the same time we see that its accountability and transparency are inadequate. Frontex's budget can only be increased if we see with complete clarity how and how the money is spent.

name: Marian-Jean Marinescu (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the PPE Group supports the public-private partnership. European partnerships have been shown to have had notable results and have helped to address important requirements of European citizens. The system is a positive one and should be encouraged further. We are talking today about the budgetary discharges of seven EPPs. The Court of Auditors issued qualified opinions for three of them, IMI, ENIAC and ARTEMIS for the third time: 2011, 2012 and 2013. As a result, the Committee on Budgetary Control proposes to postpone the budgetary discharge. The PPE Group supports this postponement and calls for the shortcomings raised by the Court, in particular those relating to ex-post audits, to be resolved by autumn this year. We are also awaiting the Commission's reports on the 3 EPPs, in view of the unification of ARTEMIS with ENIAC and IMI 2. SESAR, Clean Sky and FCH received a budget discharge vote from the Committee on Budgetary Control. Information was requested from all EPEs on partners' contributions as well as the practical results of the work to date. I suggest to the Court a uniform approach to the contributions of the partners, by mentioning them in all control acts. I hope that the replacement of the directors of ITER and F4energy will lead to very close cooperation and lead ITER towards the achievement of the proposed objectives.

name: Karin Kadenbach (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done. Today we have shed a great deal of light on what may not have gone well in the 2013 budget. A 4% error rate is really not something we can look forward to. We must derive from this, for the future: a control report – and I am particularly grateful for the good cooperation with the Court of Auditors in particular – shows mistakes in the past. But it also shows a mandate for action for the future. I would therefore also like to look at the 96% that have gone well, where the programmes have met the expectations, where the Member States and the agencies have met the expectations that have been placed in them and have lived up to their legal mandates and also to the programme mandates. We also need to look at what went well and learn from it. Where mistakes have taken place, we really deduce what we can do better in the future. We have heard today: cutting red tape. We need bureaucracy, access to European funding, which is not a mistake in itself. In this direction, I would ask you to continue working, to think further. We need control, but above all we need orders for the future, which we derive from these controls.

name: Joachim Zeller (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The good news for the Commission is that the discharge for the implementation of the budget of 8th, 9th and 10th European Development Fund for 2013 can be granted, despite the still too high level of error in the implementation of the project, which the Court of Auditors has noted, and many doubts as to whether the intended development policy objectives have really been achieved in the beneficiary countries. In particular, the budget support instrument should be more closely reviewed in the future and not applied to the current scale. However, the European Development Fund is still managed as a special fund of the European Union, while the other foreign policy financial instruments are already integrated into the EU's overall budget. The European Year of Development 2015, which we have just launched, the negotiations on the replacement of the Millennium Goals by the Sustainable Development Goals at UN level, an early start of negotiations on the future of the Cotonou Agreement beyond 2020 and the new multiannual financial framework should give us cause to strive for greater stringency and coherence of the development policy of the European Union and its Member States. For me, this includes the integration of the European Development Fund into the overall EU budget for democratic management of the budget and better transparency of budgetary implementation.

name: Андрей Новаков (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I was only eight years old when Bulgaria went through one of the worst crises in its modern history. Few of the state's systems and mechanisms worked at the time, people faced challenge after challenge and problem after problem. Since then, however, a long way has come and many lessons have been learned.  It is exactly eight years since Bulgaria is also a member of the European Union, and if I look back, in the past programming period, I see results. I also see success. It is the results and successes that should be the subject of our debate today, because many of the numbers lead us in this direction. According to European Commission data, almost 75% of the agreed funds Bulgaria absorbs. On average, 80% are those for the Union and the Bulgarian percentage does not stop growing.  The rural development programme is also criticised fairly. Only a year later, after this report, hundreds are the beneficiaries who are supported by it. Almost seven million have been paid to beneficiaries by the European Fisheries Fund alone. The systems for the control and verification of European funds in the country are working. Any subsequent report from now on will be proof of my words.  I would like to finally, but not least, thank Mrs Gresle for her high professionalism and diligence in her work on the report.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, today's debate gives me the opportunity to refer to the life and state of ENISA, the European Network and Information Security Agency, based in Heraklion, Crete.  MP for Heraklion in 2012 and 2013, I witnessed the efforts of various circles to get ENISA out of Crete and Greece. We then all fought together with the local authorities of Heraklion to stop these methods, methodologies that initiate the division of ENISA into two sections, an administrative service in Heraklion with 8-10 people, special specifications, in a building of 4,500 square meters, with the operational department in Athens without serious infrastructure and with branches in Brussels and other cities. The ultimate objective of the method is to transfer ENISA's headquarters to Brussels. But everyone must know that their methods will fall into limbo.  I therefore call mrs. Georgieva and, above all, the Court of Auditors to give serious serious considering what is happening in the operation of ENISA. For my part, I say that I will not vote for the ENISA discharge and I call on colleagues to do the same.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Mr. President, talking about 52 statements in one minute is really not possible, but on the other hand it is very good to study these proposals for divorces, because there is really a lot to learn from this and find out what is really going on within the bodies of the European Union.  There are a number of things that have gone through all the reports, but what I have taken the word for is the question of the credibility of the European Union in these cases. Credibility first through the work of agencies, all those disputes that exist in various cases are not a reason not to give a decision, but I warn about the credibility of the European Union precisely in the work of all these agencies. The second credibility of the European Union is also the problem of interruption of payments in terms of cohesion policy funding.  They are competing for European Union money those who perhaps want Europe the most. Let's help these people, because the cessation of payments has put many entities in the Eurpian Union in big trouble.

name: Michèle Rivasi (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, I welcome this report from the Court of Auditors, in particular his remarks on a file that I am familiar with - a European delegation that travelled to Cadarache - that of the financial and administrative management of the ITER project. Not only do we see that the Committee on Budgetary Control did not vote on the itER discharge, but we also realize that it is an opaque project (there is no transparency on the precise timetable of the work), very expensive (its cost has increased, since 2006, from 5 billion to 16 billion euros), which requires an extension of 290 million euros and which requires an extension of 290 million euros and which , in addition, requires an additional 30 years to finance and enable the construction of this first ITER project, which is also hypothetical. I find that not voting on discharge will allow the ITER organisers to answer the European Parliament's questions about this administrative and financial management. I think the Court of Auditors' analysis is a very good tool for parliamentarians to have precise answers to their questions.

name: Karin Kadenbach (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I do not just want to speak on my own behalf today. I am speaking here on behalf of a great many people who have sent me mail, once again in connection with Amendment No 27, which has already been mentioned today, on aid for the Sahrawi refugees in the Tindouf camp. I would like to ask my fellow Members once again to vote in favour of this amendment that we have tabled tomorrow. This is simply a matter of not leaving people who have been dependent on humanitarian aid from abroad for years, supporting them and really making our contribution as Europeans.

name: Vítor Manuel da Silva Caldeira
text: President of the European Court of Auditors. – Mr President, allow me to make just a few points to close this debate on behalf of the European Court of Auditors. My first point would be to send thanks to those in the Court who have contributed to your scrutiny on the European Union budget, its agencies and institutions. Critically, improvement on the European Union budget is a challenge that we have had, but it is a challenge that has to be put forward by the Commission and by the Member State authorities that are responsible. But all the institutions have to work together in that sense. For our part, in the Court of Auditors we believe that we also need to put more emphasis on performance issues in our annual report. We also plan to devote relatively more of our resources to giving this House high-quality, timely and relevant special reports on those performance methods that matter the most for the European Union and its citizens. Finally, while taking care of the recommendations addressed to the Court of Auditors in its own discharge, let me assure you that we will continue to work closely with you to make the excellent cooperation between our institutions a driver to achieve the results that we are all calling for this afternoon. I think this is what matters the most for the European Union’s citizens.

name: Kristalina Georgieva
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, many thanks to the Members of the Parliament who have taken part in this debate but also to many who have contributed in the work leading to the debate tonight. We are grateful for your contributions and, as we have done with the report of the Court of Auditors, we will study very carefully the recommendations in this report once it is voted tomorrow and make every effort to implement them. Because in the end, what matters is to turn the debate into actions of the Commission, of Member States, that lead to improvements in the way we spend our taxpayers’ money. I would like to close with three points. First: learning from experience. This has been mentioned by many and it is an obligation of the Commission and, of course, in the shared management programmes of our partners in the Member States. Learning from good experience and learning from bad experience. We would very much like to continue in that spirit: to identify what works and cherish it. Success breeds success. Learn from what does not work and then correct it – fix it. My second point is on the question of methodology. We are now at a crucial moment of time when we are making a leap into balancing measures taken on compliance with measures taken on performance – the culture of results that we have discussed. It is not a trivial matter and it is not easy. Measuring performance in some areas – for example, school attendance – is easy. Measuring the impact of investment in SMEs on jobs, then growth of the economy, is not difficult. Measuring how rural roads contribute to inclusion of rural populations in the economy – the national and European economy – is more difficult. There is always a risk that when we shift to performance, we focus our money on what is easy to measure rather than on what matters the most for our people and our economies. This is why I would very warmly welcome an engagement with the Court of Auditors, Parliament, the Member States and the Council on working on performance. I am stressing this because, if we do right, it would enormously benefit our economies. If we do not do it right – shame on us. So let us work together on making sure we have the right methodologies and make this learning experience a shared journey. My third and last point concerns those who have spoken on the benefits European money brings. They are enormous. I was in Latvia a couple of days ago and there, the chair of the parliamentary committee for European affairs told me how in Latvia you would no longer recognise the schools they inherited from the previous era. They are modern schools, they are energy efficient, they are a pleasure for kids to go to – 800 of them with European money. Latvia is much better connected because now it has a modern airport that allows much more traffic. In the city she grew up in you would not recognise the streets and rural areas because agricultural investments have made farms much more modern and made the city a much better place to live. I have the same experience in my own country. When we talk about the European budget: yes 4.7% is subject to errors and a fraction of this is subject to fraud. But 95.3% has delivered, and it is our job to make the delivery of our budget as strong as we can make it. What you have done is very clear and professional, as has been the work of the rapporteurs and the shadow rapporteurs. We are grateful for the effort you have made. I am taking this back to my colleagues in the Commission with this very simple, straightforward commitment: make better use of our taxpayers’ money.

name: Jānis Reirs
text: President in office. – Dear bystanders! Thanks again for giving me the floor. This debate has shown that many of the issues concern us equally. Moreover, I can conclude that our common objective is to aim for the Court's unqualified opinion. And unqualified, much remains to be done to improve this performance. Let me emphasise once again that, in this context, all financial actors must take full responsibility for the performance of their duties.  In response to the comments on the unloading of the Council and the roles of the Council and Parliament in the process of unloading, I would like to stress that the Council fully respects and fulfils the tasks set out in Article 319 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. The Council is aware that the Committee on Budgetary Control voted to postpone the council's discharge for 2013, but it is still ready to discuss the relevant working mechanism between the European Parliament and the Council. The Council made a concrete proposal for a Memorandum of Understanding in 2011 and noted with interest the European Parliament's call for modus vivendi in its resolution of 23 October 2014.  On the other hand, as regards the errors, as expressed in the opening of the committee meeting on 23 February, Mr Grässle pointed out (and I represent the country with one of the lowest levels of error – Latvia has 1% error), I also fully share the concerns of Members who believe that the error rate is high, and I would also remind you that the Council regrets this fact. That is why the Council, in its recommendations, places particular highlights the role of preventive and corrective measures and the need to further strengthen them. I would like to add here, as many speakers also note, that this is about the previous programming period. The Governing Council expects that the new control requirements and reinforced procedures enshrined in the 2014-2020 programming period will lead to a significant reduction in the error rate. To conclude, I would like to reiterate that the European Union budget is an important tool for achieving the policy objectives that we have agreed on. We need results, namely those in terms of growth, employment and investment, stronger business and a more competitive Europe.  We also agree that, in a situation where our total resources are limited, we cannot afford to spend any euro inappropriately. We must convey a clear message to European citizens and taxpayers that the European Union's spending is constantly being monitored and that the quality of them is being improved so that all the results we expect are achieved.  Ladies and gentlemen, Dear Mr President, thank you once again for giving the floor, and thank you for your attention.

name: Ingeborg Gräßle
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, I would like to thank the President-in- Thank you for the clear and clear words at the end. We will take you at your word. I would like to say to you that we are very grateful to you for coming. Not every Presidency of the Council has taken up this task, and you have also made it clear where we can count on you. We will count on you and also on your successor. This is a very strong signal that the Latvian Presidency is sending here. I would like to say to Mrs Kadenbach and to all those who have spoken on the subject of Tindouf that no one under the paragraph is asking for aid for Tindouf to be cut. We demand that there should finally be a census there, a census of heads. If you look at the UNHCR reports, it is precisely there that the absence of this census is criticised. We demand that we give the help to people who actually exist, and we would like to know exactly how many of them are there. Nobody thinks – and this is a malicious distortion of what is stated in the report – that no one is thinking of cutting aid. But we are not thinking of developing aid until we know. Nor is it possible for refugees who are there in sad circumstances to have to pay for EU aid, because aid has been misappropriated there in the past. It is precisely this "in the past" that is being reprimanded. We had an exchange with Commissioner Georgieva about what it is like today. That is why, incidentally, there is also an ECHO mission there. We want to make sure that it is no longer the case today. I believe that this is the greatest service we are doing to the refugees. And I really want to ask that Amendment No 27 be rejected. This amendment is not helpful in substance. It is not helpful! That is why, I believe, we are not doing ourselves any favours if we simply discuss these matters in a very frivolous and twisting way. I would like to tell you that we are returning to our main problem of shared management. We really need credible management and control systems and credible data. I would ask the Commission to take seriously the reservations we are expressing. Payments must be consistently suspended. The European added value must be examined in the measures, and the focus must be on results. We will continue to demand this in the years to come.

name: Martina Dlabajová
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I am very glad that this debate has said several times that discharge does not end with tomorrow's vote, but it is a long-term process. Likewise, in my report, the past and the evaluation of the Accounts of the European Development Fund are mingles with the future of the European Development Fund. Our cross-party report prioritises the precise, transparent and strategic definition of the priorities of the future European Development Fund. I would like to emphasise the three main points that have also been raised by my colleagues. Firstly, the adoption of financial instruments comparable to those used in the 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework, in particular in its modernised form, are a way to enhance efficiency and transparency. Secondly, we must take into account the increased risk in the recipient countries and adapt the system of governance, monitoring and control to this. Thirdly, I would like to consider, and I propose this in my report, that the European Development Fund should become an integral part of the European Union budget, including because of its capacity to action. We need flexibility to use resources immediately and quickly and to help where it is currently needed.  I thank the European Court of Auditors, I thank the Commission for its cooperation, for my part I must say that none of my questions have been left unanswered. I thank the Secretariat of the Committee on Budgetary Control, I thank the team of the Group of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe, and I thank my team. I thank all my colleagues in the Committee on Budgetary Control and, above all, its Chair, My Colleague Gräßle. You have heard the presentation of 52 reports here, take that this is one report for each week of the year and we need to perceive, study, carefully consider them in a short period of time. So believe me, the Committee on Budgetary Control is doing a very good job for this Parliament and for the European Union, and I am happy to be a part of it. Finally, I thank all my shadow rapporteurs once again for their exemplary and creative cooperation, which results in the fact that no amendments have been sent to the final version of the text. It is a very pleasant experience for me personally.

name: Gilles Pargneaux
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Commissioner, Mr President-in-Office, first of all a few words, perhaps, to answer or accompany a number of interventions on the 2013 discharge concerning the European Parliament.  First, I would like to address the LUX award. Yes, we must defend it! This is a strong demonstration of the European Parliament, which often allows, in particular through its documentaries that we reward, to highlight the turpitudes of our societies. We must therefore defend the LUX prize, because it is, I say, part of our cultural identity.  Secondly, I would also like to defend the project of the House of European History and not, as some have called for, its abandonment. Let us refer to this beautiful sentence: "A people without memory is a people without a future". That is why we must defend this beautiful project that is the House of European History.  Thirdly, a remark about Mr Valli, which tells us that we must reduce or even cancel our funding for the foundations of European political parties. This is democracy that we defend, Mr Valli. We not only have a local political expression, like perhaps your 5-Star Movement in Italy, but we are internationalists, all as much as we are. In this way, we must ensure that our debate goes beyond our local concerns. By funding foundations, we are helping to sustain and develop democracy, including European democracy. I would like to go back to a controversy. We heard earlier from Mr. Dartmouth attacking the Speaker's office. That has been said, hate speech discredits the author of this populist protrusion that we have heard. I think the representative of the ECR, Mr Kirkhope, said what needed to be said about the hypocrisy of the UKIP representatives here in this Chamber. Through this report, we have shown our willingness to create more transparency, as I said at the beginning of my speech. Now, after this photograph we took as part of this 2013 landfill report, there is still a way to go. As François Mitterrand said: "Where there is will, there is the way." I believe that this path of transparency, we will continue to go through it with all the European parliamentarians who wish to do so.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the debate. The vote will take place on Wednesday 29.4.2015.  Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. – The European Parliament's budget is mainly produced by indexation. If such a procedure continues for many years in a row, it brings significant deficiencies and can lead to deformations. This is probably why the budget contains such a high percentage of transfers that all the appropriations available at the end of the year are transferred to the budget lines for buildings and, in particular, for advance capital payments. The aim is to reduce future interest payments. This situation is repeated year after year and the surplus increases every year. Proper budgeting should set out the instalments in relation to buildings as part of the budgetary strategy and properly include it in budgeting rather than as a covertly planned procedure. This is also a reason to change the budgeting. For at least one year during the five-year parliamentary term, the budget should be established on the basis of actual needs and subsequent years indexation would no longer be so harmful.

name: Pavel Poc (S&D)
text: in writing. – The granting of the 2013 budgetary discharge is the last step towards the closure of budgetary management under the last Multiannual Financial Framework. The Committee on Budgetary Control also confirmed that the European Commission's management was carried out according to the rules. However, despite the committee's recommendations, we cannot in any way afford to ignore the shortcomings that we have been made aware of by the European Court of Auditors. More specifically, this means that we need to work in particular to reduce the administrative error rate, which is 4-5%. This is mainly in the areas of agriculture, regional and employment policy. In that regard, it should be noted that it is the Member States for which the level of error is highest. I believe that we are able to achieve better results in the future. However, these will be conditional on better information, the introduction of effective preventive measures and, in particular, the realization that European funds must be spent effectively and not at all costs. All actors need to assume their responsibility, albeit at the cost of sanctions in the event of misreporting of results. The funds in the already tense EU budget must be spent as best as possible. It must serve to really kick-start economic growth, increase employment, investment and protect the most needy. Another course of action is indefensible to the citizens of the European Union.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is the report by Elisabeth Morin-Chartier, on behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 1304/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council on the European Social Fund with regard to increasing the amount of initial pre-financing paid to operational programmes supported under the Youth Employment Initiative ( HYPERLINK "http://ec.europa.eu/prelex/liste_resultats.cfm?CL=pl&ReqId=0&DocType=COM&DocYear=2015&DocNum=0046" COM(2015)20150046 - C8-0036/2015 - HYPERLINK "http://www.europarl.europa.eu/oeil/popups/ficheprocedure.do?lang=en&reference=2015/0026(COD)" 2015/0026(COD) (A8-0134/2015).

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to start by saying that this evening I am proud of our institutional work at European level. There has been a real will between the Commission, the Council - I regret the Council's departure - and Parliament to succeed very quickly in order to be effective. It is this political efficiency that has set our strategy. Commissioner, I think I can say a big thank you, because we started our work on 4 February and tomorrow we will be on 29 April. I believe that there are few European decisions that are being completed so efficiently and so quickly. My thanks will also go to all the shadow rapporteurs, whom I would like to quote here: Brando Benifei, for the group S and D, Jana 'it'ansk', for the ECR group, Martina Dlabajov, for the ALDE group, Terry Reintke, for the Greens/ALE group, and Patrick Le Hyaric, for the GUE/NGL group. Colleagues, we were able to silence our differences and unite our wills because we knew which way we wanted to work. What was the meaning of our work? We wanted Europe to be effective for youth employment. In the end, the Youth Employment Initiative is the most difficult part of successful youth employment. What for? Because it concerns the most troubled regions - where at least 25% of young people between the age of 15 and 25 are unemployed - and the most difficult audiences. It targets both young people who have left education without qualifications and audiences of young graduates who are unable to enter the world of work because there is no correspondence between their training and the needs of employers. So we were tackling the hardest part of the rock with this youth employment initiative. It took a lot of will, all together, together, to succeed in record time. I think that validates our work strategy. As rapporteur, I wanted us to share as much information as possible among all political groups. That is why, together with the Commission, with the Council, we have come together as much as we need to bring our political will in line with this unique goal of success for young people. Tonight, yes, I am proud of Europe because not only do we succeed unanimously in our will, but also in record time, to meet a real need for the ground. Because that is Europe. It also shows in this Chamber that it knows the needs of the land. Operational programs took some time to be signed. What do project owners on the ground need? They do need significant pre-financing. So when you propose, Commissioner, that this pre-financing be increased from 1% to 30%, it means that, yes, Europe knows the needs of the ground. Project owners cannot advance the much-needed funds, especially in the most troubled regions. It's a very effective boost. We are indeed in a race against time and, quite frankly, I hope that we will win it together. Tonight we must be proud of our work and I hope that tomorrow we will have a very significant vote which will be a message so that in the Member States we can roll up our sleeves and help with these projects of the Youth Employment Initiative. It is indeed these projects that we need. It is now up to the Council to stimulate the Member States so that, on the ground, young people can benefit from our pre-financing work.

name: Marianne Thyssen
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the European Parliament and, in particular, Ms Morin-Chartier, for giving priority to this file and for the efficient and constructive work and the constructive way it was dealt with. I would like to congratulate Parliament on the record time in which the agreement was reached, both internally within the line committees and also with the Council on this crucial assistance to Youth Employment in the European Union. Let me also, in parallel, congratulate the Latvian Presidency for its engagement in this dossier that has been processed very efficiently as well, demonstrating that the priority to tackle youth unemployment in the Union is one that is shared by all European institutions. We have indeed no more time to lose as regards the swift implementation of the Youth Employment Initiative. Time is of the essence to provide the jobs and practical experience that would help bring young people into the labour market. We all need to live up to our commitment to Europe’s citizens, and that is what we all collectively have done by proposing, negotiating and adopting this regulation so quickly. The proposal under discussion today is to address an obstacle we identified with Member States which is hindering the speedy launch of the Youth Employment Initiative on the ground: this is the need for cash. We propose to increase the pre-financing in 2015 by close to EUR 1 billion. This will help accelerate the initiative and reach as many as 650 000 young people while remaining within the overall budget. We are convinced that this proposal – which you will adopt, I am sure, with a large majority – provides a strong incentive for Member States to speedily roll out the actions on the ground and thus support jobs, apprenticeships, traineeships and continued education. Implementation of the Youth Guarantee is now under way in all Member States with tangible results from some countries, as shown by the examples published in the European Semester country reports. The Youth Guarantee has provided impetus to both structural reforms of employment and education systems. It has also been a catalyst for supporting young people in school-to-work transitions. The present amendment of the ESF Regulation would also facilitate the timely implementation of the initiative which, given the urgency of the issue, has been designed to have a narrow timeframe. I would like to once again reassure the Members of this House that the Commission will process the payment of the increased initial pre-financing for 2015 immediately upon the entry into force of the amended regulation. Of course the key issue is now the quality of the supported measures. In this respect the Commission will continue to closely monitor progress and we will, of course, report to the European Parliament accordingly.

name: Sylvie Guillaume
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Culture and Education. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this proposal responds to a situation that we have had many times to deplore. More than a year after the adoption of the text on the Youth Guarantee, the results are not there in the face of the scale of unemployment that affects one in five young people in Europe today and the risks of marginalisation, social exclusion and sustainable poverty.  Difficult implementation, insufficient investment, lack of ambition, all these symptoms affect the youth guarantee as it is currently implemented. We do not want an entire generation to be lost in this way. The text proposed here is therefore an indispensable measure to reduce the widening gap between young people, graduates of higher education, young people without a degree and those who have had an intermediate education. It is also essential to help young people stay in touch with the world of work and training. Essential, above all, to prevent the trap of long-term unemployment and its deleterious spiral.  Young people have been the main victims of the economic crisis since 2008. The most vulnerable among them are those who do not have a sufficient education or qualification. In addition, special attention should be paid to young people from immigrant backgrounds, with disabilities or with health problems, who should not be left out. So we had to react very quickly. This is what Parliament has done for European youth.

name: Lara Comi
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and also her teamwork with the Commissioner.  I welcome this proposal by the European Commission to provide for an increase in the initial pre-financing paid to the operational programmes relating to the Youth Employment Initiative. The Commission's surplus of EUR 1 billion, as well as the increase in pre-financing from 1% to 30%, are in fact concrete aid that will give a strong impetus to making this instrument operational, given that the Member States have not identified enough public funds to support these projects.  Europe has shown that it wants to do everything possible to reduce unemployment, i.e. even more so than in the last parliamentary term, but I appeal to the States and regions to take due account of aid for youth unemployment, which must be given top priority on national political agendas, in their planning.  From the experience I have had, I am in the second parliamentary term, I have entered here at the age of 26, I see that Europe is fast, it is fast, contrary to what many people think. The problem is what must then be implementation in the Member States. The Youth Guarantee Fund has gone well in some states, very badly in others. We therefore need an analysis, and I will end by saying that we need more communication between Europe, the Commission, Parliament and the citizen, especially with young people, because they often do not know what opportunities they have and lose them. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: Blue card question. I wanted to ask Mr Comi, since he mentioned the Youth Guarantee programme, whether he was aware that the Court of Auditors had recently presented a report on the subject and what he thinks of what he says in relation to Italy about the fact that the Youth Guarantee programme has not brought any benefit to our country and whether it thinks that in the future , in your opinion, the conditions are in place to make this programme efficient, given also that your party governs several regions.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: Answer to a blue card question.
