For this question, as Vice-President of the EPP with responsibility for youth policies, I am dealing with a European and, of course, An Italian analysis together with other colleagues.  Where Forza Italia governs, and I am talking about Lombardy, and so I speak at home, the Youth Guarantee programme has been the best in all of Italy and these are hand-held data that are available to everyone. As far as Italy is concerned, we still have a lot of work to do. But I don't do this as a party color because the unemployed for me can be communist, fascist, socialist, I don't care. The important thing is that you get a job and work.

name: Brando Benifei
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are debating an excellent proposal from the European Commission.  This Parliament has shown responsibility by adopting this measure very quickly until we allow a vote in plenary as early as tomorrow. This act will free up some EUR 1 billion of pre-financing for young Europeans who are not working or studying. In my country, for example, Italy, we will increase from just over EUR 5 million to more than EUR 175 million in advance. I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mrs Morin-Chartier, for her efforts and Commissioner Thyssen for her work, because she has been able to take on board with this legislative choice a strong request from the Group of the Party of European People's Party (S&D), which has for years now raised the need to increase the pre-financing share of youth employment initiative programmes, in order to avoid liquidity problems in the Member States and regions.  We can say that Europe is now playing its part more. The floor now goes to the Member States, which must be able to make the best use of this incentive, starting first and foremost from a more effective communication of these instruments to the debureaucratisation of the programme towards companies, always making sure that the offers are of quality and always really aimed at the personal and professional growth of young people.  It is necessary to respond effectively to the critical issues that have been presented so far, including in terms of transparency and proper management of the funds, and the European Commission must monitor them together with Parliament. That is why, together with our colleagues in the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, we are preparing an oral question to the Member States with specific requests to achieve their maximum effort in order to produce tangible results. We will also be asking the European Commission in a letter for a commitment to transfer the additional amount of pre-financing without delay.  Every institution at government level must demonstrate its seriousness and commitment to the fight against youth unemployment, which is why no resources must be wasted. My generation has a right to a future and the European Union and the Member States must do everything in their power to get Europe out of the crisis. To this end, we parliamentarians will continue to make our contribution.

name: Jana Žitňanská
text: for the ECR Group. – We all know how important it is for a young person to adopt work habits at an early age and to act as an active member of society. Ideally, labour markets in Europe should be able to offer such applications without our intervention. We do not live in an ideal world, but in Europe with regions full of hundreds of thousands of young people out of work. We have therefore reached a strong agreement with the rapporteurs that we will do everything we can to help young people. Young people today will receive a signal from the European Parliament that we want to do everything we can for them. But this is where our work must not end. It is up to the Member States to make meaningful use of the increased pre-financing. If the game of effect and short-term improvement of numbers is the only result, the Member States will only prepare further disappointment for young people.

name: Martina Dlabajová
text: on the alde group. – Mr President, I thank the rapporteur in particular, because the cooperation was excellent. We have proved that Europe can also agree and respond quickly. The ball is now, of course, on the side of the Member States. I will give you one example, today a report was published in a Czech newspaper that the capital of my country, Prague, has the lowest unemployment rate of any region of the European Union, currently 2.5%. This is certainly great news, but we must see it in a Pan-European context. Because when it comes to youth unemployment, the level here, too, rises to 10.1%. This is still a great result, considering that the West Austrian Epirus has a youth unemployment rate of 69.8%. That is why we must focus at European and national level on regions that need our immediate and effective support. The youth support initiative has a budget of EUR 3.2 billion. Thanks to pre-financing, a billion euro will be available immediately, of which over EUR 4 million for the Czech Republic. But of course we all know that jobs can't be bought. Jobs suitable for young graduates must be created in line with the real needs of the economy. I therefore consider it so important that programmes such as the Youth Employment Initiative be complemented by labour market reforms at national level.  The transition between study and work should be natural and the number of graduates in each field must be based on the real needs of the labour market. Let us pay attention to the levelling of skills and jobs, not only at national level, but also throughout the European Union. Let us simplify the rules for setting up companies and their financing, focus on technical and vocational training, support start-ups, internships, internships. Let us simply do our utmost together to address the causes of unemployment in particular and not to devote more and more resources in the future to teach young people how to work.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, in the face of the urgent need to respond to the tragedy of unemployment and youth insecurity, we welcome the decision to increase the amount of pre-financing and to immediately release EUR 1 billion in funding for the Youth Employment Initiative. It is now appropriate for states to commit to it and that this money actually gets to the recipients and is effective. On the other hand, we must ensure that this programme can be sustained and improved, and that the amount of money allocated to employment and training for young people is increased. Indeed, while we agree with Mrs Morin-Chartier's report, we are aware that this progress is still very insufficient to enable the seven million young Europeans who are now deprived of work to access properly paid training and employment. Access to work should also be a right and a real social project of European integration. In this sense, we should invent a European public service for training, integration and job security. I believe that there is indeed an urgent need to create the conditions for a future for every young European.

name: Terry Reintke
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I have only been sitting in this Parliament for ten months now and I must say that I am already fed up. I am fed up with talking about youth unemployment and not seeing any action. I am fed up with Member States not taking their responsibilities seriously. I am fed up saying the same thing over and over again. Maybe it is just me, maybe I am just overly impatient. But I know too many stories about young people in Europe not to be patient. For Christ’s sake, it is the middle of 2015. Good morning Member States of Europe, wake up! You have slept far too long. The 30% pre-financing that is now proposed by the Commission for the Youth Employment Initiative is the final wake-up call. We have pushed forward this proposal in this Parliament in a very speedy procedure because we all agree that the time to act is now. Now we need to see the Member States do the same: use the money and make it reach the young people in Europe, because this is their political responsibility. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – I would like to ask you respected colleagues, although I partly understand your anger and your tone of speech, but does it not seem to you that this decision finally increased the Commission from 1 percent to 33 percent pre-financing showed the credibility of the European Union and showed the interest of the European Union, the European Commission and this Parliament to protect, as far as possible, the interests of young people and unemployed young people? Do you think we're credible this time, finally in this Parliament?

name: Terry Reintke (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card answer. – I completely agree with you that we welcome this proposal a lot and that we have worked in this Parliament to push it through as fast as possible, but now it is really the responsibility of the Member States to act, because they are the ones who have the responsibility to put this money towards young people and make sure it goes into programmes and is used in a way that is useful in the fight against youth unemployment.

name: Laura Agea
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, thanks to the rapporteur, we have aligned ourselves, we have agreed on this urgent procedure.  I'm told the operation was successful and the patient died. Because, alas, when the Member States – and I am used to self-criticism, and i am talking about my own country, Italy – find themselves with important resources, they manage them shamefully. I am ashamed of my country, of the unworthy way in which it has managed resources, and I am thinking of the Youth Guarantee, I am thinking of an empty, un communicated, unused box, which took no account whatsoe of the needs of young people, of what could have been their prerogatives, their desires and their opportunities.  No monitoring has been carried out, no information has been provided. That is the assessment I would like to make today. I am ashamed of a country which, in view of the resources it obtains, is appointed by the Court of Auditors as one of the five least successful countries for its young people. Europe helps countries, my country fails. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: Blue card question. Mr President, in view of the interest shown in the speech on this subject and having heard some critical issues with which I share some of the critical issues, I would like to ask the Delegation of the 5-Star Movement and Mr Agea, why, as shadow rapporteur for the measure for the EFDD Group, he did not consider taking part in any meeting of the group rapporteurs either in person or through collaborators, because in this way he had no part in the work to speed up and approve this measure and to draw up the oral question to the Council and the letter to the European Commission mentioned in my previous speech.  Does she not think that the committee work between the rapporteurs for months, in order to improve a measure, all the more so if it is criticised, is at least as important as a minute's speech to be published on the Internet in the final debate, as is the case today in plenary?

name: Laura Agea (EFDD)
text: Answer to a blue card question. I would like to thank my colleague Brando Benifei, but as one of the smallest groups in this Parliament, I am the rapporteur for two dossiers. When I see Mr Benifei present in committee as assiduously as I do in the committee, Mr Benifei will be able to make as many criticisms as he likes. Mr Letta, with which you are very familiar, had trumpeted the Youth Guarantee programme, waving millions of jobs, and failed across the board. Take note of that.

name: Michał Marusik (NI).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Dear! We must realise that unemployment in a selected group, in this case in the youth group, is part of unemployment in general. Let's not worry about chasing garbage from angle to angle, because it doesn't create order. Order must be done in the economy. After all, we must realise that if we find artificial instruments for pushing this chosen group into the labour market, it will only result in unemployment in other groups and unemployment rising either among the bald ones, or among the fat ones, or among the small ones, but it will still be unemployment. Unemployment is the result of bad political solutions and the consequences should not be fought, the causes must be eliminated. The cause of unemployment is a bad economic system. After all, it is not companies that employ people. It is important to realise that people employ consumers. If consumers have money in their pockets, then business is thriving and there is no unemployment – people are employed, remunerated and respected. Fiscal oppression must be reduced.

name: Tom Vandenkendelaere (PPE).
text: – Seven million unemployed young people. It's a downright hallucinatory figure, an untenable situation. With seven million unemployed young people, we are putting a very heavy mortgage not only on their future, but also on the future prosperity of the whole Union. This needs to change and fast! This agreement is already an important step. By giving a financial boost to the Youth Employment Initiative, young people in the worst affected regions should be helped to a decent job, internship or training place. Moreover, the speed with which the European Parliament and the Council have dealt with this issue shows that Europe is working and that it can work quickly when it has to. It shows a Europe that is big on big things. Now it is up to the Member States to use these money to set up effective projects with these money. With a European prepayment of 30%, there is simply no excuse to linger. But let it be clear that this extra pre-financing is only one step, and more will be needed to rectify this painful situation. We will continue to work towards a comprehensive long-term strategy with better matching of skills to demand, more entrepreneurship among young people, quality apprenticeships, a more flexible labour market and, of course, sustainable jobs. This stimulus was desperately needed and the ball is now in the hands of the Member States. But the most important question we have to ask today is not: what are the Member States going to do with it now? No, the only question we have to ask ourselves is: what's next? Every good chess player thinks several steps ahead. Let us do the same in order to eliminate youth unemployment once and for all.

name: Jutta Steinruck (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Unfortunately, we still have no reason to celebrate a great success. We are still light years away from the objective of combating youth unemployment in Europe. However, with this initiative, movement is finally moving into an endless history. I would therefore like to thank all those who have been involved in finally getting this off the road quickly. Because there has been far too much talk in recent years, too many black Peters have been pushed back and forth, but the results leave much to be desired. We Social Democrats have pointed out from the outset that the fight against youth unemployment cannot succeed through radical austerity, but that we must assume European joint responsibility. It was not necessary to be a clairvoyant to foresee that, in the Member States that are subject to austerity, there is a need for help in preparing and co-financing, and at the same time we all need to provide support for meaningful structural reforms. The fight against youth unemployment must continue to be an absolute priority for us – as you said, Commissioner – not only in the Member States, in the European institutions, but everywhere on the ground. Now it is also up to governments and local businesses to make progress in this regard in the interests of the younger generation. It needs a perspective, and we must do everything we can to do that.

name: Anthea McIntyre (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur and the Commissioner very much too. I think we all acknowledge that youth unemployment is a very serious issue and that there is a clear need for action, so I support this proposal to enable resources that have been allocated to be used in a way to speed up the implementation in Member States. But I also have concerns that pre-financing may lead to pressure on the fund further down the line and that in a couple of years we will be asked to vote for additional funds to be allocated to the Youth Employment Initiative (YEI).  My Group has always called for budget discipline and results-based policymaking and the YEI must be no exception to this, so we must monitor the results. In order to have real impact we need to work with the Member States to devise tailored solutions that meet the local challenges they face. So in the UK, the government has used the Youth Employment Initiative to complement government programmes. In my own region in the West Midlands they have extended the money through the Local Enterprise Partnership so that they can provide apprenticeships and work experience and so on. I am pleased to report that in the West Midlands we have seen 2.2 million new apprenticeships started in the last five years.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, increasing the pre-financing of the youth employment initiative is a basic measure, since this amount was so low that Member States with greater difficulties in paying for co-financing of the European Social Fund, that is, often the same ones that also have the high rates of youth unemployment, could do almost nothing without this basic measure that we will support tomorrow.  But there is something that is not solved with this measure. This initiative continues with a very low general budget, below what is necessary, so that it can have a real influence on solving the problem of youth unemployment. As estimated by the ILO, EUR 21 billion would be needed. The funds are advanced, but they are not increased. And there's something we don't know yet. In the implementation of the programme, where it exists, does the number of jobs achieved exceed the number of jobs that are destroyed? And the contracts, are they permanent and with rights? Or most contracts are term, internships and vocational training, i.e. precarious links that subsitude permanent jobs, often after a dismissal. Because that's not a guarantee, but it's the continuation of insecurity.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI). Mr President, the youth employment initiative is trying to tackle a problem that is real and particularly acute, especially in countries such as mine. To be more specific, in Greece the official youth unemployment rate is close to 60%, when, in fact, it is perhaps even higher. What is worse is that this situation is not expected to change any time soon, despite the efforts being made, both at national and Union level. The reason I don't think things are going to change is the wrong approach we have to the problem. Instead of seeking to create permanent and decently paid jobs, we are focusing on a questionable re-education, as well as the creation of temporary and low-paid employment programmes. In this way, the really significant amounts spent will in the end have no effect, apart from the economic benefit of some who pretend to be interested in solving the problem of unemployment, and have simply found another way to take money out of the European budget.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I welcome the decision of the rapporteur and other colleagues to unequivocally support the Commission's proposal to significantly increase the resources for the Youth Employment Initiative. This accelerated mobilisation of EUR 1 billion for 2015 demonstrates that the European Union takes the fight against youth unemployment very seriously.  If we have some concern that these funds will be used effectively, then we should be interested in how our governments manage these funds. I am personally in contact with officials of the Czech Government and the Ministry of Labour and I am interested in how these programmes are prepared. I have information that the Czech Republic is ready to draw on these extraordinary funds precisely in regions with higher unemployment. In addition to the fact that Prague has very low unemployment, we also have two regions with high unemployment, which exceeds 25% for young people under 25.  In this respect, I would also like to call for the promotion of vocational training, which should be financed from these funds and which will ensure that it is also an investment. An investment for the future, an investment that will give motivation and confidence to young people as well as employers. I am glad that this proposal has strong support.

name: Marita Ulvskog (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr We have heard here about Italian and other examples. I would like to talk about my own country, Sweden, a country with economic and social conditions that may be perceived as less problematic, but also in Sweden youth unemployment is very high and therefore there has been extra support for Swedish young people from the Youth Employment Initiative. Last summer, however, the then government in Sweden decided to use only a limited part of the aid, partly because it did not want to spend its own state budget slated for payment from the EU. In a country as rich as Sweden, it also works that way.  Although this attitude changed in due course, there are several other Member States for which it has been impossible to use the Youth Initiative for economic reasons. The quick start money has not been held in its own coffers, and this is where these new funds can play a role in getting the Youth Employment Initiative to lead young people out of unemployment. You must not be too poor to lift your poverty.  This is a chance to afford it.

name: Anne Sander (PPE).
text: Mr President, I, in turn, would like to commend the work of the rapporteur and the Commission. Putting forward the funds needed to start action to combat youth unemployment is obviously good news. This is proof that the European Union knows how to act concretely, quickly and effectively in the event of a crisis. That has been said, the ball is now in the side of the Member States. Various measures must be taken: encouraging learning, encouraging young people to start their own businesses or adapting training to new digital professions. For my part, I would like to stress one point: cross-border mobility. It makes it easier for young people to grasp career opportunities across borders. This mobility requires language learning. However, in my country, France, the government wants to abolish bilingual classes, which is totally contrary to all the efforts we make here. Cross-border mobility also requires better information on job opportunities abroad and real recognition of diplomas. It is all these very different but complementary measures that will enable us to move forward together to combat youth unemployment.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D).
text: – I support the Commission's commitment to increase pre-financing, which should help Member States to tackle youth employment issues more quickly and efficiently. Young people need to be helped and get a job and continue their education or traineeship. As recent reports and current practice show, not all Member States are able to implement the Youth Employment Initiative because of certain economic, financial and, in some cases, probably because of a lack of political will, and this proposal is therefore a major step forward in investing in young people. Youth employment measures should certainly pay particular attention to young people with lower educational backgrounds, young people with disabilities or with certain health problems. At the same time, I would like to point out that long-term youth unemployment or the inability to find a suitable job has a significant negative impact not only on the economy, but also on young people themselves, which can lead to mental and physical health problems.  I therefore call once again on the Member States to make the most efficient use of the pre-payment assistance provided by the European Union.

name: Javi López (S&D).
text: – Mr President; First of all, I would like to welcome and congratulate the work done in order to expedite the arrival of pre-financing resources to those countries that need to develop the Youth Employment Initiative: congratulate the European Commission on the measure and also on Parliament for the agile work it has done; and remember that, moreover, states with youth unemployment problems are those that have the most problems with deficit targets, more treasury problems, which is something that goes together. But this measure, today, will only be a coffee sugar that tries to sweeten the sea if we are not able to change macroeconomic policies, which are closely related to youth unemployment rates, because youth unemployment is always or tends to be twice as high as overall unemployment. In Cadiz, for example, the southernmost province in Europe – which may be a good parable of what happens to southern Europe – there is an unemployment rate equal to that of the Gaza Strip. That is, today, what happens to part of Europe and that is the emergency of emergencies that we should solve from the European Parliament and from the Member States.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, the shadow rapporteurs and especially the Commissioner for bringing this report to us so soon, in such a timely fashion, because it is important. It is very important for the young people of Europe that they are to be supported and given the necessary training and education to gain employment. The fact that the Commission is proposing to bring forward essential finance sends out a clear and strong message to Member States that they must act and they must put structures in place to support young people. I am encouraged by the Commissionerʼs words that he is going to closely monitor the progress and report to Parliament on a regular basis on the impact of this funding, and indeed the Youth Employment Initiative, because I think it is extremely important that the funding be spent in a valuable way, particularly on developing skills and giving education attainment where it is needed in the workplace.  So often in our history we have educated people, young people and indeed not so young people, for careers with skills that are not needed in the workplace. I think that this is an extremely important point to focus on – necessary skills for today’s employment market.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D).
text: – Mr President, thank you to the rapporteur and the committee for implementing and proposing this project. We are talking about 7 million unemployed people, we are talking about 7 million unemployed young people, we are talking about 7 million destinies that or on which we decide today. There's little thing! EUR 1 billion to pre-finance projects to combat unemployment is a good measure. It must be supplemented by other measures. I am glad that the European Parliament is once again demonstrating that it is moving faster and comes up with solutions to combat unemployment, and comes up with coherent statements and projects. The increase in pre-financing from 1% to 30% is also a positive element. I would like the Member States to respond positively to the request of the European Parliament and the European Commission. Within the Government of Romania and Romania I can tell you that there is the necessary support for the implementation of these measures, because Romania was, moreover, among the first states to implement the first pilot projects for the youth guarantee. In order to make this a reality, the granting of additional amounts must go into agreement with concrete projects to help young people.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, the youth employment initiative has only six billion euros, at a time when we have over five million unemployed young people in the European Union and at a time when Draghi has EUR 1.1 trillion to buy government bonds from all euro area countries except Greece and Cyprus. A brave increase in the amount of the youth employment initiative is therefore urgently needed. Youth unemployment in Greece stands at 51.7%. Youth unemployment is also at a very high level in Spain and Portugal. At the same time, the inefficient use of the initiative in the countries of the European south is explained by the lack of public resources needed to launch projects offering new jobs, traineeships and training. At the same time, due to the memorandum cuts, Greece faces the greatest difficulties in finding co-financing, all the more so now that Draghi and his ECB team have imposed credit suffocation on Greece. That is why arrangements are needed to facilitate the absorption of the initiative funds in Greece and in the countries that have been put to memoranda.  (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a blue card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Андрей Новаков (PPE)
text: a question asked by raising a blue card. It is undeniably important to increase pre-financing under operational programmes by 30% which aim to promote youth employment. But improving employment is a symbiosis between reforms and investment. They cannot achieve this objective on their own.  How do I see progress going forward? There are big differences between Member States and between using the same funds and delivering concrete results. Efforts going forward need to engage Member States more towards creating youth employment. These efforts should be in two directions. First – utilising this pre-financing to the maximum extent and secondly – reforms in education. How do you see these reforms in your Member State and in others?

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), answer to a question with a "blue card". – I would like to thank my colleague and say that in order for Greece to have co-financing at the moment, funds are needed. However, when, because of the Memorandum, public investment has been reduced, these funds are not available so that, from a Greek point of view, co-financing will be made that will deliver the results they need in relation to this initiative - all the more so when there is a credit suffocation in Greek banks on the part of the European Central Bank which no longer, in practice, gives a single euro to Greek banks in order to be able to make investments. So, as far as Greece is concerned at least, that is the key element that you have to take into account.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE).
text: – Mr President; Commissioner, I support, of course, this reform of the Regulation on the European Social Fund to speed up the implementation of the European plan to promote youth employment: it is our priority. I miss, however, a more rigorous analysis by the Commission of why the Member States with the most difficulties have failed to present more operational programmes, and I repeat here that, in rare cases, the problem is that some States are tempted to centralise these programmes and move them away from regional institutions that have competences , which are closer to the real economy and have more capacity to be able to boost it, that they have more practice and that have a better scale to get public and private partnerships, that work best and have better results. So, advance funds, yes, but audit such problems and encourage them to be corrected, too. That is why I would like to ask you if you plan to perform any such analyses.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, I would like to make it clear in my speech that we are not against the Youth Guarantee programme, but we do not share how it is being implemented in certain countries, including Spain. We value pre-financing, but this is not the main problem, nor are active policies in the evolution of youth unemployment. Problems are correlated with declining economic activity, which prevents young people from joining the labour market. The problems of youth unemployment are not solved by lowering social contributions or subsidizing employers. These measures do not guarantee continuity in employment or job training; quality employment is not guaranteed, in short. The Commission itself has already warned certain countries that this programme has had only a marginal effect and the Court of Auditors' own report warns of the risks of poor implementation of the programme. If we want to generate quality employment, it will have to be, among others, through productive investment and increased wages and social benefits.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to use this minute to extract a promise from the Commissioner, because I would like all the programmes that are allocated to this in the coming years, which is the fundamental problem of youth unemployment, to bring added value.  We can no longer afford proclamations such as those that were made in my country, where the President-in-Office of the Council came to say great victory from Europe, one and a half billion dollars, then after that there were only 12 000 jobs out of 2 million jobs promised on these programmes; 412 000 were registered as young, but in the end, only 12 000 were offered. So the programme must work absolutely better, otherwise the perception for the citizens of this Europe will increasingly be towards scepticism, compared to believing in the project.

name: Danuta Jazłowiecka (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Dear! In such a critical situation as young people in Europe are currently in, the European Commission's proposal to increase funding for the pre-financing of the initiative was a very good decision and a hope for rapid improvement. It is particularly welcome that both the European Parliament and the Member States have decided to accept the Commission's proposal without unnecessary amendments, which will guarantee the swift release of funds, and the excellent work of Elisabeth Morin-Chartier and her team will ensure this.  However, the lack of liquidity appears to be neither the only nor the main problem facing Member States. Since the launch of the initiative, there has been a lack of adequate implementation and measurable progress. We are all aware that time in times of unemployment plays an extremely important role, as long-term unemployment has much greater difficulties in returning to work. Moreover, in many cases, through a lack of work and income, young people are approaching the poverty threshold overnight, the overshooing of which further exacerbates their situation and their opportunities for reinsuche. Therefore, both the European Parliament and the European Commission should put pressure on the governments of the Member States and seek to make the most efficient and efficient use of the available resources.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: Mr. President, we have an excellent proposal coming out of the Commission. I believe this is great and good news for all the young people of Europe, because what the European Parliament has asked for has been recognised. The European Commission came up with a proposal for a truly radical 1 per cent to 33 per cent increase in pre-financing of the youth guarantee scheme. I think this is something we have long expected and I think that in this way, respected Madam Commissioner, we will show the credibility of the European Union, because this is exactly how we show that we care about solving the problem of unemployment, especially in the southern countries of the European Union.  What remains and what is the link that may break and will not do the job properly, are the member states. So I ask you to take good care so that our credibility is fully fulfilled.

name: Андрей Новаков (PPE).
text: – Mr President, as I have said before, there is no doubt that a 30% increase in ex ante payments under operational programmes to promote youth employment is a crucial step and I welcome the Commission's efforts.  However, I would like to call on it and make even more efforts to raise awareness of this initiative and the programme, and how young people can benefit from it. I am also aware that the role of Member States and local authorities is crucial in achieving sustainable employment among young people on the outside. I therefore sincerely hope that both Member States and local authorities will make efforts to increase their capacity and, at the same time as the investments they will receive under pre-financing, implement education reforms and make their employment services even more effective.  I believe that only by accumulating all these measures can we ultimately make young people on the outside find quality jobs faster and easier in the future.

name: Marianne Thyssen
text: member of the Commission. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you once again for the almost broad support for this proposal. When you approve this proposal tomorrow, the Council is expected to follow you soon. I hope that in May we will be able to make the actual payment of this higher level of pre-financing. By the end of this year, we will then receive the progress reports from the Member States. Of course, as promised, we will provide you with summaries of this. I look forward to the debate that we can then have in this Chamber. At the beginning of 2016, we will give Parliament a global assessment of the effectiveness and impact of the joint support we provide with the European Social Fund and the specific Youth Employment Initiative, to indicate what all this has achieved to make member states' commitment to the Youth Guarantee a better place. In the meantime, we will continue to guide the Member States, the regions and the local authorities that want to do so, as far as we can, of course, within our competences. Many people have asked the question: is this enough? Is the budget of the Youth Employment Initiative in itself enough to create all these jobs and help young people to work? Is the youth employment policy we have in Europe sufficient? No, of course that's not enough. Only with the Youth Employment Initiative will we not get there. That is why we have other funds at our disposal. However, in many countries and regions there was a financial barrier to getting projects off the ground. The increase in pre-financing removes this financial obstacle and allows them to really start. So this should help. But beyond that, we still have ESF resources, European Regional Fund resources, resources to invest in people – including young people – in the Employment and Social Innovation (EaSI) programme and resources in Erasmus+ and a number of other programmes. The policy itself is not enough either. Employment is a question of supply and demand. We have to work in both areas. That is why this Commission is using its entire policy to create sustainable growth and job creation. That is also why we will be working on initiatives to help the long-term unemployed get back to work, to make skills more suited to the needs, to ensure greater respect for vocational training, to make better vocational training available to young people, to have a good labour market policy in the Member States and to increase the number of issues. Our investment package must also be seen in this light. If everyone on their field takes responsibility, then we can do something and then we can give those young people perspective again. I'm convinced of that. With the proposal that you have supported so broadly here today, we can make a big contribution to that. I would like to thank you once again for that and congratulate you once again on the speed with which you have guided it through Parliament.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to congratulate you on how, with this regulation and with this development, you are helping, together with all my colleagues, to clear the obstacle of pre-financing. This obstacle was insurmountable and here we are giving, really, more than a boost, we are giving a very clear sign of the knowledge that Europe is having difficulties on the ground. I would like to mobilize my colleagues for tomorrow's vote. Let us make no mistake: we agree on the substance. This pre-financing is a stone in the fight against youth unemployment. It is not the only one, Madam Commissioner has just said it very broadly. But if we have an extremely strong vote, then tomorrow we will show all the heads of state or government that we are not in the incentive, but that we demand their commitment to make this youth employment initiative policy a success. And it will not succeed for them, so that they can glorify themselves - I have heard a lot of national discussions tonight - it will succeed because we must engage our European policies so that young people can find real quality work. Tomorrow, our vote will reflect this demand that we want to put forward with regard to the Member States. The third point I wanted to make is that, as you have understood, Commissioner, we will not give up. That is, as a result of this joint work that we have done to achieve this pre-financing, yes, we want results. There will be results if the projects are quality projects. We need projects on the ground. We want a report, we want to follow the progress of the initiative with the Commission, at the level of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. We want to reap the fruits of this political commitment that we are demonstrating with you this evening, Commissioner. We are firmly committed to this. To my colleagues who would have said that the youth employment initiative was not enough, I would like to say that we have other tools: the Youth Guarantee and the European Social Fund are made to bring young people back into employment, and we will be working on it all the time.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday 29 April. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Guillaume Balas (S&D)
text: In writing. The employment situation that most European Union countries are experiencing is dramatic. Unemployment has literally soared in some states, underscoring the widening economic and social performance gaps between member states: for example, in Greece and Spain, more than one in two young people is unemployed. We are supporting this proposal, which will enable the Commission to release EUR 1 billion to ensure a rapid rise in the youth employment initiative from 2015. However, much remains to be done: for sustainable economic development that can ensure quality employment for our citizens. If we do not act quickly to strengthen social cohesion and investment in Europe, it is the very assent of our fellow citizens to the construction of Europe that is likely to fade.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. – The European Union has been facing an invincible social nightmare in recent years, unemployment. In particular, the countries of the Mediterranean and the South are suffering harsh social shocks from the constant rise in unemployment, with thousands of our fellow European citizens below the poverty line, without work, prospect and hope for them and their families. The most tragic aspect of unemployment is the unemployment of young people who, while they are in the most productive years of their lives, with enormous potential and qualifications, with dreams and hopes and with a great appetite for work and supply, unfortunately end up in the endless queue of the Unemployment Fund. Youth unemployment rates exceed 25% in many European Union countries. Complacency is not meant until the last European young person has a job, produces and participates in the socio-economic development of Europe. We support the European Commission's decision to immediately release EUR 1 billion to pre-finance the operational programmes for 2015. We are waiting for other European initiatives in this direction in order to tackle effectively the nightmare of youth unemployment.

name: Verónica Lope Fontagné (PPE)
text: in writing. – Despite the improvement in youth employment in recent months, nearly five million young Europeans remain unemployed, surpassing 50% in some EU regions. There is no doubt that to reverse this situation we need not only to act in the long term, but also immediately. Our young people need to regain hope in the institutions and themselves in order to look to the future with ambition and good expectations, and for this they need a job. That is why I have nothing but words of praise for the rapid approval and great consensus of the proposal to increase the pre-financing of the YEI. The Member States with the highest rates of youth unemployment and, therefore, recipients of YEI aid, are precisely the ones most at risk of advancing the funding needed to combat youth unemployment. Thus, this advance of almost EUR 1 billion will allow the correct implementation of the YEI in the most affected regions and, more importantly, that aid reaches as quickly as possible the greatest number of young people.

name: Dominique Martin (NI)
text: In writing. Youth unemployment is a worrying phenomenon in Europe, so it is legitimate to take an interest in it and, indeed, to intervene in regions where youth unemployment exceeds 25%, thanks to an increase in pre-financing from 1 to 30% on a constant budget would seem to be a necessity. However, this seems to be a wishful thinking: as we have seen in France, with measures such as young jobs or jobs of the future, these programmes are often a failure. Indeed, the transition to employment will only be possible if jobs exist and these measures will not create jobs ex nihilo. The provision of all funds as early as 2015, as the Commission promises, is certainly commendable but will not be enough: youth unemployment is not due to the weakness of this pre-financing but to the disappearance and lack of jobs. The only solution is to protect our productions from social dumping, to practice wise protectionism at the level of each Member State and to enable them to take the necessary measures to create jobs and get out of the crisis. Only then can we get young people out of unemployment.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. – I welcome the Commission's decision to increase the initial amount of advance payments for 2015 from 1% to 30% in support of youth employment, which amounts to around EUR 1 billion. Also in my country, Slovakia, youth unemployment is climbing to 30%. However, I see the release of the absorption of funds as an operational solution to the consequences of the economic crisis. Personally, I see youth guarantees in community-wide systemic measures that take account of national requirements. We can see that the market cannot solve this, which is why it is the state that must guarantee the effectiveness of the money spent by spending on education. We need to revert to models where the requirements of the departments are linked to public education resources. Active business activities, microfinance should also be promoted for small and medium-sized employers. Furthermore, measures need to be taken to turn unemployment benefits into remuneration for the work done. I believe that the Member States with the highest youth unemployment will seize this chance and help young people to take up employment so that young people can start believing in society and a common Europe again.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: Writing. – today we are discussing one of the most important problems of the modern European Union. This is the support of operational programmes in favour of the Youth Employment Initiative. Since the onset of the economic crisis, i.e. since 2008, youth unemployment has become an urgent challenge not only for the Institutions of the European Union, but also for Member States such as Lithuania, where the level of labour emigration has risen dramatically. This phenomenon is unfavourable from the point of view of the national economy. This requires immediate action, as the unemployment rate among young people has reached a dramatic level, which is steadily increasing. The European Union must share financial instruments with the Member States as soon as possible in order to improve this situation. The Youth Employment Initiative is one such measure as it provides an additional opportunity for europe's regions most affected by unemployment. Ensuring greater funding from the European Commission for job creation will undoubtedly become an important support for operational programmes in 2015. It is therefore the European Parliament's duty to enable the implementation of the rules in discussion as soon as possible. There is no doubt that an additional request from the European Commission to encourage Member States to benefit from new, increased funding for funding for allocating projects in the regions most demanding should receive parliament's unconditional approval. Let us not forget that, in order for this support to be effective, it is necessary, first of all, to support initiatives aimed at young people who are graduating and entering the labour market.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. – Youth unemployment is a major challenge facing most EU countries. I support the report that Member States will be able to receive advancepayments to tackle the problem of youth employment. The European Commission has given a clear signal that youth employment is a priority. At the same time, it is essential to provide a full and clear overview of costs and measures to combat youth unemployment. However, the European Commission must set up a comprehensive monitoring system over the programme and report on the effects to the European Parliament and the Council of the EU. I would like to thank the rapporteur for her wise decision not to put amendments to the report in order to ensure that funds for youth employment are made available as soon as possible.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Gérard Deprez on behalf of the Committee on Budgets on the estimate of revenue and expenditure for the financial year 2016 - Section I - Parliament (2015/2012(BUD)) (A8-0144/2015).

name: Gérard Deprez
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in terms of estimating Parliament's revenues and expenditure for 2016, the Committee on Budgets wanted to stress from the outset the need to be part of the general context of budgetary rigour in all our countries and therefore to propose a realistic draft budget 2016, certainly, but very tight in terms of increasing appropriations.  Thus, from the outset, we agreed, firstly, that the European Parliament's budget for 2016 should be below 20% of the Union's total administrative expenditure and, secondly, that the increase in current operating appropriations, compared to 2015, should not exceed 1.6%.  It should be added, however, that the deadly terrorist attacks of recent months and, more generally, the persistence, if not the aggravation of these threats, have led us to reserve a very special place for the security issue. Thus, in addition to the 1.6% increase in the current budget, we have decided to create an exceptional endowment of EUR 15 million to strengthen, in particular in Brussels, the security of the European Parliament's buildings and also to allocate a significant proportion of the funds to the strengthening of cyber security, which all experts agree is that in the European Parliament it is both necessary and urgent.  Once this general framework was established, we focused on the operational priorities to be implemented for 2016 and, in fact, agreed on the need to strengthen a single priority, namely the strengthening of the financial resources to enable us to do our work better as parliamentarians. Since the Lisbon Treaty, as you all know, we have considerably strengthened powers in the area of legislation. A major effort has already been made to strengthen the staff of parliamentary committees in this area, but we remain too unarmed to exert real control over the delegated acts and acts of enforcement that flow directly from our legislative activity. We have therefore proposed a number of measures, on which we have agreed with the Council.  The first step is the strengthening, up to twenty new positions, of the secretariat of parliamentary committees, which must exercise control over a large number of delegated acts, acts of execution or multi-declination programmes. The second step is a request to the Office, which accepted it, to develop and implement new regulations to ensure a better balance between accredited and local assistants. It is clear, in the eyes of all people in good faith, that accredited assistants are essential to enable a Member of the European Parliament to carry out his work effectively as a co-legislator and in the control of the executive.  Third, in parallel with the one I have just mentioned, it was also decided, at the request of certain political groups and, later, the Office, to increase the so-called secretariat allowance. This measure, unlike the previous one, was not widely agreed. Some political groups and individual colleagues did not see it as timely or necessary. Others, on the contrary, are in favour of this, pointing out that this allowance has not been adapted since 2011, when the treatment of the most qualified employees deserves to be valued and the number of accredited assistants should also be increased. The agreement that has finally been reached between the Office and the Committee on Budgets on this subject is explicitly based on a very clear premise: the funds necessary to finance this implementation will only be released after the Bureau has developed a satisfactory new regulation with a view to strengthening the number of accredited assistants and better controlling local assistants by limiting their number.  Fourth, the assessment of a parliamentarian's performance is not only, or first of all, a question of quantity, but of quality, i.e. content. The current systems of classification of parliamentarians have the unfortunate effect of causing certain excesses, which must be stopped. For example, the Office and the Committee on Budgets agreed to ask the Conference of Presidents to ensure the implementation of new written question-and-answer regulations that put an end to their incredible inflation, which is of little or no interest, in too many cases. Taking into account the general framework and the priorities I have just pointed out, the Office and the Committee on Budgets have finally agreed to reduce 11,822,000 euros the Bureau's initial estimates. We have postponed the review of real estate policy and the financing arrangements for the KAD until the fall.  I thank the colleagues, in particular the shadow rapporteurs of the other political groups, the staff of the committee secretariat, who have done an outstanding job, and the collaborators of the political groups for their help. Thank you, Mr. President.

name: Paul Rübig
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, I would like to thank the I would also like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Deprez. We negotiated hard and fairly for many hours. I believe that the result is quite impressive, because it is a question of seeing how we can do our best in this period. We have the government's target that the european Union's overall budget will be cut by 4% over the next seven years and that 1% of posts will be saved each year. It is therefore quite clear that 6% of the total budget of the European Union is available for administration. Of this 6%, Parliament takes up to a maximum of 20%. This year we have even fallen below this sum. I would like to thank the rapporteur because, in view of the general situation, extreme austerity is appropriate. With respect to the adjustment of the various resources, and in particular the secretarial resources – the ceilings, which are discussed time and again – I also welcome the fact that the various groups have different opinions. We believe that Members should decide individually who needs fewer staff, who needs fewer trainees, who needs fewer services. That is good for taxpayers. We very much welcome the fact that we are using a minimum here and that we are using the funds efficiently. On the other hand, there are, of course, a few Members of the House who have an enormous workload and who need very efficient staff in these areas. It is important here that the ceilings can be used accordingly. It is also a question of being able to obtain the services of the house only on request. I believe that data protection is also a very important principle in the House – in addition to transparency. We must keep both principles in line. Finally, the free Member also has to take responsibility for his expenditure and not to shift it to the administration.

name: Vladimír Maňka
text: for the S&D Group. – Together we fight for higher growth, employment, a better life of the population. Sometimes, however, we put obstacles in the way of this effort ourselves. Let me give you one example: Members send written questions to the Commission. The number of questions is growing. The numbers have already approached 1,700 questions a month. The flood of questions employs dozens of people. The cost amounts to millions of euros per month. It's hard for me to say, but there are cases where for those who ask, the answer isn't what they're watching. The Commission also sometimes underestimates the answer and does not respond responsibly to the question frankly asked. Maybe he'll rate it as a number-only question. We found a solution. It was clearly supported in the Budget Committee by various political groups. If web portals do not quantify these issues as activities that evaluate members' work, their numbers will fall significantly. This solution will reduce bureaucracy and save millions of euros in the budget of the Commission and the European Parliament. It will also create space for Members, assistants and staff of the institutions to deal with real problems. Ladies and gentlemen, we found a compromise in the Committee on Budgets after long negotiations. However, a proposal has now been made to change the compromise. If we want to resolve the substance of the problem, please vote in favour of the proposal approved by the Budget Committee. Further proposals for further millions of savings will be presented in the autumn. I thank the rapporteur and look forward to further cooperation.

name: Anders Primdahl Vistisen
text: for the ECR Group. Mr President! First of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur for the work he has done. I would say that the greatest price we can give him on our part is that he has resisted some of the most extravagant requests for increases in the budget. Basically, we think there has been a good debate between the Bureau on the one hand and the Committee on Budgets, chaired by Gérard Deprez, on the other. In fact, we think it could have gone worse. If we cannot, however, recommend voting 'yes' to Parliament's budget, it is simply because, at a time when we are in crisis in Europe and when the various Member States have to make savings, we do not think it is acceptable for us to increase the budget here. Even if it is a smaller increase than one might have feared. At the same time, we cannot understand why there should be a need for a major increase in the appropriations for recruiting new people. We think that is a really bad signal to send to our citizens. That is why, unfortunately, we cannot support the final settlement.

name: Younous Omarjee
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, I would like to warmly congratulate our rapporteur on the quality of his commitment. I want to do this all the more because the work he had to do was not easy, since we had to find 10 million euros in savings compared to the Bureau's first proposals. This work was all the more difficult because, during the discussions, we saw unexpected connivances, let us call them, which allowed, it must be said, to increase a whole series of envelopes of the most inappropriate, and which, as the rapporteur said, were not the subject of compromises between us. What envelopes are we talking about? These include an increase in the secretariat allowance, the increase of several million euros in the envelope to renew the furniture of MEPs' offices and the increase in the number of European foundations and political parties. The question I am asking myself, and which we must ask ourselves, is whether all these increases are very serious in a context where we call on peoples and states to ever more effort and sacrifice, which obliges us to exemplify. I am afraid that with this 2016 budget we will not go down the road.

name: Indrek Tarand
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, let me firstly congratulate the rapporteur Mr Deprez for his very participative method in writing this report and his desire to limit the budget increase. Like a brave captain, he has managed to sail this boat safely between Scylla and Charybdis, if you allow me to refer to Mr Welle and honourable Vice President Wieland with those ancient Greek names. However, no rapporteur can make all political groups equally happy, hence three points on behalf of the Green Group.  Firstly, the Konrad Adenauer building in our opinion should be still financed by borrowing as we have the lowest interest rates in the history of common currency. Secondly, in the opinion of the Greens, the increase of a secretariat allowance still seems to be untimely because of the EU’s economic situation. Thirdly, the increase in information technology expenditure and in cybersecurity this year will approach the EUR 150 million. Projects such as buying iPads for Members are expensive. We already sponsor Mr Gates of Microsoft, why now do the same with Apple? By reverting more to open-source software, which is free after all, I am sure that the improvement in cybersecurity would come about.  Herr Präsident! Es ist sehr wichtig, es geht um Geld! Geben Sie mir bitte noch 10 Sekunden. Last but not least, unlike many in this Parliament, I personally feel a bigger security threat from underpaid parliamentary assistants than from an anonymous terrorist threat and would advocate using security money for the payment of qualified assistants.

name: Marco Valli
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this report rightly states – and I would ask members to read what it says – that the European Parliament should be exemplary in its budget, so as not to deviate too far from a reality in which European citizens are always asked for new sacrifices.  So, we in our group wonder why in 2016 we are still increasing our salaries as Members of Parliament, an increase of one million euros more. The costs of our travel, for example, come here to Strasbourg every month, almost EUR 3 million more. Or the more than 15 million every year for the salaries of already well-paid officials. We would also like to know what the reason is for doubling expenditure on office furniture to EUR 3 million to EUR 7 million or increasing the funds again to the Parlamentarium, if we want to increase it, that is all well and good, but then let us block the construction of the House of European History, which is an unnecessary duplication.  Finally, this year too, political parties and foundations will see their funds increased by several million. Is this the virtuous example we want to give our citizens? Tomorrow, therefore, we will find out which Members want to fatten the costs of politics, we are very curious to see who will put their faces on it.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I, too, would like to begin by thanking Mr Deprez for his work. It has already been stressed on several occasions, but I do not think it can be overstated: we are living in a time when we are living in a serious financial and economic crisis. The EU's 505 million inhabitants receive a daily message that states must make savings. Against this background, the European Parliament's budget is a role model. I am pleased that the increase in expenditure has been limited to 1.6%. At the same time, we must work to reduce this limit if possible. We must set the right priorities. For me, this is particularly the area of IT. We also have to be exemplary on the road here, because without IT we would no longer be able to work. In other words, it is essential that we do not have problems here. On the other hand, it has also been said that more needs to be done to ensure building safety. I warn against funding placebo effects that look beautiful but do not increase safety any further.

name: Sander Loones (ECR).
text: – Europe has a problem of credibility. There is a gap between the European Union and its citizens. The European Union lacks support. It's an analysis we've been making for years. It is an analysis that we keep repeating. Unfortunately, the lessons are not learned. For 20 years, the European Court of Auditors has been rejecting the budget, but for 20 years the European Parliament has been deciding to approve it. Year after year, we also see the European Union demanding more money, while member states and citizens face serious savings. And now a proposal is on the table to increase the staff budget of Members of Parliament by EUR 1 500 per month. Ladies and gentlemen, we will never strengthen support for the European Union! The N-VA already votes against, the ECR Group already votes against. I am also pleased that several other Flemish Members of Parliament have announced that they will vote against it. Unfortunately, that will not be enough, I fear. I call on them, above all, to convince their groups, too, so that tomorrow we can send a united signal for more support for Europe.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I wanted to speak on this subject as a member of the Committee on Budgets. I want to say that I am quite disappointed in this final form of the project, although Mr Deprez is one of my favourites in the other political groups, because he maintains a number of inequalities and emphasizes others. Parliament represents the citizens. We fund the work of representation, not bureaucracy! The final report, We have seen, does not take into account the fact that, in some states, parliament requires MEPs to apply a minimum wage. In Romania, the maximum salary applied to local assistants is 700 euros, well below the minimum wage in some Member States. We limit the number of local assistants even if the constituencies are different. In my case, the constituency is 22 million people. We also remove questions and interpellations as if this mechanism did not exist in all parliaments. I want to tell you that I want my question to be public! Perhaps not in all languages, to reduce costs, but I would like to see what I do in the European Parliament, as well as the statements, as well as the other mechanisms that I have at my disposal.  Democracy costs money. We must not reduce democracy!

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, I would like to raise the following issues. Firstly, the budget provides for secretarial aid to certain committees, but I do not see any support for the secretariat of the Committee on Petitions. We must understand that this is a very important committee, which has direct contact and relationship with the citizens of the European Union, accepts their requests, accepts their petitions and is the only way in which the European Parliament maintains direct contact with the citizens themselves. There must therefore be an increase in the secretarial support of the Committee on Petitions. Secondly, I am concerned about the notion that we should limit the number of written questions. The main activity of a parliament is to exercise parliamentary control. If we do not have the opportunity to ask questions, then it is obvious that we are limiting the very powers that we have. I therefore think it is hypocritical to say, supposedly for reasons of economy, that we should not be able to ask many written questions.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Mr. President, I would like first and foremost to thank my esteemed colleague Deprez for his efforts to come before us with this document and I would like to highlight in particular what has been said, which is that we should invest in our security. We need to invest both in that physical security in the buildings in Brussels and in this building and of course we need to invest in our cybersecurity. There's no question about it because we must be one great target for those who don't like us.  I would like to emphasize the same thing, and part of this discussion, the problem of assistants and the financing of our offices has sparked a great debate in Croatia. I am interested to hear how to think further in this context so that I can respond to some situations in the media in Croatia. Will assistants continue to accredit in Brussels? Will there be a continuation of the current work? And of course I also want to know when all this is going to take effect in the first place? Because it's also something that's completely unclear.

name: Gérard Deprez
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, let me first respond precisely to two questions. The first was the number of questions. We don't delete the questions, Mr. Marias, we can always ask them! If I am followed tomorrow, they will be limited to five per parliamentarian per month, which means 60 for a parliamentary year. You should know that 80% of parliamentarians ask less than 60 questions a year. Just under 20% of parliamentarians are the authors of more than half of all the questions that are asked, most of which, let me say it, are of no interest, certainly not to the citizens. (Interruption of Mr. Viegas) You have the right to think as you think, I have the right to think as I think and I have the right to say it. If you want, take a green card and call me, I'll answer you. The second inquiry concerned the implementation of the reform aimed at establishing a better balance between accredited assistants and parliamentary assistants. The reform is expected to take place on 1 January 2016, although a six-month transition period may be requested because some parliamentarians have contracts and cannot be terminated unilaterally and without notice. If I had done this draft budget, it would have been totally different. But I am only a rapporteur and, as such, I have an obligation to try, first of all, to find an agreement and a majority within the Committee on Budgets and, secondly, to reach an agreement with the Office. Compromise necessarily means a number of things you like and a number of things you like less. I accept the criticisms that have been made, by everyone for that matter, and in particular by all those who have intervened in good faith. We have the right to have different assessments. But there's one thing I can't stand: it's populist critics. Some interventions suggest that, in the budget or the draft budget that we have decided now and which we will propose to the vote tomorrow, arrangements have been made for parliamentarians to put more money in their pockets! That is not true, and I defy any parliamentarian to prove otherwise! We have taken steps to help Members do their parliamentary work better and to do so in a more responsible way. So I don't accept political criticism and populist criticism. If today we see a rejection of the European Union by a number of citizens, there are people here who say things that lead them there. I regret it and I denounce it.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday 29 April.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Commission statement on the appropriate protection of whistleblowers and journalists in the fight against tax evasion and avoidance (2015/2677(RSP)).

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the right to freedom of expression is particularly important for journalists and other people working in the media. They must be free to criticise the state without fear of prosecution. This is an important feature of a democratic society. It may be permissible to restrict freedom of expression. However, such a restriction must be proportionate. In other words, the restriction must be no more than is necessary and appropriate and not excessive in the circumstances. There is no harmonised system in place in the European Union for the protection of whistle-blowers but EU rules on whistle-blowing exist in some specific areas, as in EU competition law or in the new rules of the Market Abuse Regulation addressing unlawful behaviour in the financial markets. These concern whistle-blowing to public authorities. Where no applicable EU law exists it is up to the EU Member States to regulate this issue in compliance with relevant national legislation within the framework of the rules of the European Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms.

name: Romana Tomc
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, i would like to thank the Commission for your – We all agree that tax avoidance is a very serious problem, which, of course, does a great deal of damage to our economies and, last but not least, affects a lower standard of people. And we fight this problem day by day and by different means. And one possible asset is the so-called Secure Cloud, an Internet tool where information about harmful tax practices is supposed to be sent. That sounds very promising, but when it comes down to how it's going to be done, of course it gets stuck. We collide with a bunch of problems that are primarily legal in nature. This is a very, very sensitive area that touches on parliament's role and the protection of personal data. How to ensure anonymity, is it even possible, and how to ensure the protection of personal data? In short, as we move forward, we should... we should be aware of our role in Parliament, which is primarily legislative, and, of course, ask ourselves whether we want to go beyond that role.

name: Peter Simon
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the The Commission agrees: yes, we have special rules for this in competition law and in other areas. It is also acceptable that it is up to the Member States to find rules now. But let us all be honest with us here: does anyone in the room believe that the Member States are doing this on their own? That they find balanced rules that resolve the tension between legitimate interests – in secrecy, in companies, towards the state – and the legitimate interest of the public in getting information about things that are socially unacceptable about state-organized tax avoidance? To reach a balanced solution in this area of tension, to leave it to the Member States alone, must fail. I would therefore call on the Commission to be courageous here. They must create a common understanding across Europe as to when exactly the leaking of secrets is also of such relevance and dimension to existing internal or domestic obligations that are of such relevance and dimension that, in a good-quality assessment, the violation of these confidentiality obligations is not sanctioned because of the clear preponderance of such a public interest. I expect such a proposal from you! Not in the sense that you can make a legal commitment, no! However, as guardian of the Treaties, as the institution that we have created, to see that the consensus in Europe on what we have set ourselves as the right, and what we perhaps still want to develop as a right, is to be respected, it is imperative that the Commission, at least with bold proposals, pushes ahead here. I would like to encourage you to do so.

name: Marian Harkin
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, the parliamentary intergroup on integrity, transparency and organised crime will be launched in Parliament tomorrow evening and I hope we can use this as a vehicle to campaign for a European directive in defence of whistle-blowers.  The European Ombudsman has asked us to change our culture, admit that bad things happen, and while she argues that whistle-blowers are not enough to keep fraud, corruption and mismanagement out of EU institutions, they do have a role to play, in that they sound the alarm. Yet out of nine EU bodies, only two have responded adequately to the European Ombudsman’s insistence that they have internal rules on whistle-blowing. Only the Commission and the European Court of Auditors have in place policies for taking whistle-blowers’ concerns seriously and protecting the individual.  In regard to the protection of the LuxLeaks whistle-blowers, which is the topic we are discussing this evening, I waited to hear what the Commissioner might say, but I heard nothing – except that where there is no appropriate EU law it is up to the Member States. We know that, but I am wondering, has the Commission nothing more to say on this issue? It is because of the LuxLeaks whistle-blowers that we have now set up the Tax Committee (Special Committee on tax rulings and other measures in nature or effect) in this Parliament. At all times, but especially in times of crisis, citizens want to see equity in the tax system and transparency in the tax system and they want to know that their governments and, at an EU level cooperatively, that we are trying to ensure tax justice.  As I said, we need a cultural change because otherwise wrongdoing in all sectors, at all levels, whether it is big, small or in-between, will go unchecked. In my view, one of the greatest deterrents to wrongdoing, fraud, embezzlement, whatever, is the fear of being caught, but if wrongdoers are safe in the knowledge that those who are in a position to whistle-blow will most likely keep quiet, then they are likely to continue with their actions.  Commissioner, we need to explore action at EU level. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – I agree with many of the statements you have made. I believe that we must protect those who draw attention to those who do evasion. My question is: what do you think of those who have done evasion and basically point the finger at others who have done it? You mean we have to protect them too?

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: blue-card answer. – I am not sure I fully understood the question. It seemed to me that I was asked what we do about those who commit tax evasion and point the finger at other people as well.
