That was certainly the translation, and I am not quite sure what the relevance of the question is, but I mean that tax evasion is a crime and obviously the penalty must be paid. But I apologise to my colleague: I was not sure of the context in which he asked the question. If I knew that, I could perhaps give him a proper answer.

name: President. –
text: Maybe we can clarify this later.

name: Fabio De Masi
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the The GUE/NGL, the Left Group, has requested this item on the agenda, and I would like to thank my fellow Members for allowing us to be together in this convivial round this evening. Journalist Edouard Perrin became the third person in Luxembourg to be indicted over his disclosure of Luxleaks. We owe him and whistleblowers like Antoine Deltour the special committee on tax rulings. We respect the independence of the judiciary, but we also respect the freedom of the press. By indicting it, Luxembourg is violating the right to freedom of expression and information, as well as the European Convention on Human Rights and the Charter of Fundamental Rights. The European Commission's proposal for a directive on the protection of trade secrets is intended to reduce this protection even further. Taxpayers lose more than EUR 1 trillion a year through tax evasion and avoidance, Europe is being reduced to depression, while the decent are the stupid. Tax evasion is not a trade secret. Which citizen in Europe can rely on his trade secrets from the tax office? Whistleblowers must therefore be protected by law if they can expect their disclosures to protect higher public interests. The Commission is led by Mr Juncker, who was responsible for the laws in Luxembourg. I expect the European Commission to condemn the prosecution of journalists in Luxembourg, as it does, of course, in other regions of the world, and finally put forward proposals that protect the decent and not the criminals in Europe.

name: Eva Joly
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, Commissioner, on 23 April Édouard Perrin, the journalist who exposed a whole section of the Luxleaks scandal, was indicted by the Luxembourg justice system. Like whistleblower Antoine Deltour, he is being prosecuted for business secrecy. This is a major blow to our democratic life. It reveals the brutality of a system undermined by successive revelations. When it comes to tax justice, but also the environment and labour law, the role of whistleblowers and journalists is vital. While the demand for transparency has never been more pressing, the European Union, through its directive on business secrecy, is choosing secrecy and opacity. Commissioner, the cases of Édouard Perrin and Antoine Deltour are unacceptable. While they should be made heroes and protected, you want to extend to the twenty-eight Member States laws of another time, in the interest of a few against the public interest. We happen to know the names of those particular interests, their lobbyists and their councils. The new Commission and the new Commissioner would honour themselves by shedding full light on the relationship that existed in the old Commission.

name: Marco Zanni
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today we in Parliament are discussing the fight against tax evasion and avoidance, and we have also set up a special committee, but all this has only been possible thanks to the indispensable intervention of journalists and whistleblowers, such as Antoine Deltour, who have made these practices unfair in the public domain.  We therefore understand the importance of adequately protecting those who decide to disclose practices that distort and illegal in relation to normal competition, especially in tax matters. Those who want to deepen research into cases and issues that are not yet entirely clear must have certain guarantees, as must those who, from within these mechanisms, want to highlight all the shortcomings of the system currently in force. It is true that many of these whistleblowers themselves have been accomplices or perpetrators of illegal and opaque practices, but there are protections in Europe for repentants who have committed far more serious crimes.  We must bear in mind our ultimate objective, which is the dissolution of all these techniques of tax avoidance and evasion, and in order to do this it is essential to have their support, giving them the necessary protection.

name: Bernard Monot (NI).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, tax whistleblowers have uncovered a number of major scandals, from the HSBC file to the Luxleaks. Without these sources, justice, nor public opinion, would have known about these cases. It is therefore necessary to protect those who have the courage to denounce illegal facts, often taking the risk of professional or personal reprisals, to defend the general interest of citizens. But I believe that the protection of whistleblowers must be comprehensive and also concern corruption in the broadest sense, particularly by political leaders, or violations of labour or environmental regulations. Why not, too, denounce illegal immigration networks and trafficking? On tax-based facts, the limit must remain privacy. It is not a question of encouraging a form of unhealthy denunciation. The slanderous denunciation must be continued. In addition to serious penalties for active fraudsters, it is also necessary to target financial institutions and consulting firms, which are equally guilty of deliberately organising this fraud. This is the case, for example, of PriceWaterhouseCoopers in the Luxleaks scandal. Under the Business Secrecy Directive, the European Union must ensure that it remains consistent and delineates its scope. If this balance is successful, the National Front is in favour of this directive to protect whistleblowers and journalists.

name: Емил Радев (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the creation of a website on which anonymous alerts can be sent to the Committee on tax rulings and other measures similar in nature or effect is a rather risky undertaking which will not lead to the results sought. There are many arguments against this proposal.  First of all, this possibility can lead to a lot of abuse and clearance of accounts. Verifying the veracity of the information will require efforts and competence that the European Parliament does not have.  Secondly, given the negative opinion given by the Legal Service of the European Parliament, we cannot ensure the anonymity of the alerts submitted. As European MePs, we do not have the same legal protection available to investigative journalists with regard to sources of information. Third, the creation of "secure clouds" could lead to a dangerous precedent, which could subsequently be applied to other legislative committees of the European Parliament. Then what are we going to do?  I support the decision already taken in the Committee on Tax Rulings itself and the position expressed by the Legal Service of the European Parliament that such a page is not necessary.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: – Mr President, most countries in the European Union do not provide adequate legal protection for whistleblowers of corruption, tax evasion and other crimes. This Parliament, in the Crime Commission's report in 2013, called on the Commission to make a legislative proposal with an effective European programme for the protection of those reporting cases of mismanagement and irregularities in the public and private sectors, at national and cross-border level. This recommendation applies to known revelations with LuxLeaks. It is unbearable that a founding Member State of the European Union criminally accuses journalists and other whistleblowers of disclosure of acts of tax dumping committed for years by the Luxembourg administration and private companies. The attitude of the Luxembourg authorities violates European law, the public interest and shows contempt for freedom of the press, the right to information and transparency, crucial pillars of our democracies. Antoine Deltour and others informed citizens of unfair, immoral and possibly illegal practices. Its general importance outsts the breach of Luxembourg law on the confidentiality of agreements, which will be illegal if the recently proposed rules by the European Commission on the exchange of information between Member States with regard to tax agreements are adopted. I therefore appeal to the luxembourg public prosecutor's office to file these charges against the whistleblowers and journalists involved in LuxLeaks.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, we are having this debate on a very specific issue, Mr Perrin, a journalist, has released information of public interest in relation to Luxleaks and was the third to be charged in this matter. Now, it is so relevant and so in the public interest to have revealed that we have even set up a special committee in this Parliament to investigate this situation. This proves the state we have reached, because mr Juncker is the one who should be accountable for this situation and not Mr Perrin, who is on trial is the one who helped the citizens.  However, those who have harmed citizens are presiding over the European Commission. I think this example is very clear of the state we have reached, it is very clear - that is why European citizens look sideways at the European institutions - and if the European Commission, in such a sensitive matter, does not do anything rigorously to protect these people is giving a signal to citizens who, in fact, have to be suspicious of the European institutions. So we should thank these people for their work and protect them and not condemn them, and that role rests with the European Commission and no one else.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: –  A Uachtaráin, tá áthas orm cúpla focal a rá ar an ábhar tábhachtach seo.  I suppose the word ‘whistle-blowers’ comes from sport. The referee is the person who blows the whistle and, like the whistle-blowers, the referee is usually not loved but nevertheless probably respected and indeed necessary. The same applies here to whistle-blowers who act in the public interest. It is not a popular thing to do but often it takes great courage, particularly in exposing a wrongdoing in relation to tax avoidance and tax evasion. Indeed in relation to tax avoidance some big multinationals have proven themselves very adept in that regard.  Anything that helps us to save EUR 1 trillion, which is what it is estimated that we are losing through these illegal methods annually, is something to be welcomed. The whistle-blower deserves every protection in that regard because without it we would not be able to deal with these terrible afflictions.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, the Commission was particularly sparing in its statement. We understand why. Tax evasion and avoidance are anti-social actions and must therefore be severely punished. Tax evasion and avoidance can also be revealed through journalistic research. This means, therefore, that there is no contradiction between the public interest and the journalistic investigation that reveals tax evasion, because that is the public interest.  The prosecution of journalist Edouard Perrin is illegal and unacceptable because this journalist revealed the LuxLeaks scandal, revealed the responsibilities of certain countries, tax havens that give multinationals the opportunity to avoid tax. This prosecution is therefore unacceptable, it is illegal, it is contrary to the European Convention for the Protection of Human Rights itself.  We therefore denounce what is happening, because it is a gag of the right to free expression.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, tax havens, fraud and tax evasion are at the heart of political and media news. They are, in itself, an accusatory libel directed at a capitalist system that is rotten inside and that of rotten will fall pushed by the struggle of the peoples. The fact that we are discussing the need to protect whistleblowers here reveals the complete failure of judicial systems and all the tax control and enforcement apparatus that have long been at the service of large companies. Indeed, political power has long been captured by economic power, serving its interests to the detriment of the people. The fact that Antoine Deltour, among others, risks five years in prison and a fine of more than 1 million euros is another aspect that reveals another complete reversal of the values and rules that determine who should be arrested and who should be at liberty.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Members for this discussion.  I would not like to give here the impression that the Commission is not doing anything. I mentioned that we have several pieces of legislation where other forms of protection for whistle-blowers is included. It was said here that whistle-blowers must be respected because they fulfil a very important task for society, for democracy and for law and that we should protect them; however, as I said before, this should be done mainly through national legislation.  As for the European level, I have already mentioned that protection has been included in the Market Abuse Directive. Data protection was also mentioned, so I would like to inform you that the Article 29 Data Protection Working Party issued guidance for the Member States on how to protect whistle-blowers within data protection legislation at national level. I would also like to inform you that the Anti-Money-Laundering Directive which was adopted in December 2014 contains a part which includes the protection of those who report suspicious financial transactions; this is also very important.  To go back to the LuxLeaks, which was mentioned several times, I hope you understand that the Commission cannot interfere in the Member States’ jurisdictions as is the case described here. However, we are taking the necessary measures to increase the transparency on tax rulings. This is a preventive measure to fight tax evasion and tax avoidance which would better protect whistle-blowers. On the European level, we want to introduce measures through which the public will get information in a very transparent way on the advantages that are provided by the Member States to companies in the tax sphere. We at the Commission have already approved the first step, which is reporting by the Member States. This reporting will use a central register, so everybody will see where these tax rulings are adopted.  The second step would involve country-by-country reporting, also from the companies themselves. This will be assessed in the course of the next few months to be sure that it will be the most efficient measure to fulfil the purpose, which is transparency and full information provided to European citizens. I believe these preventive steps will also help us fight tax evasion and tax avoidance, and, together with the protection of whistle-blowers at Member State level, this can help solve the problems we spoke about here.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. – The protection of journalists, whistleblowers and anti-corruption activists exposing tax evaders is undoubtedly in the public interest and in the interest of citizens who pay taxes in an orderly manner. We are witnessing a very uneven legal framework between individual EU member states when it comes to effectively providing such protection. That is why we have a number of examples of pressures, insults and serious threats to which journalists and whistleblowers are exposed when they share their knowledge of people in public, i.e. criminals who cheat tax authorities.  Some member states have adequately protected journalists and whistleblowers. Some national legislation imposes sanctions on people who discriminate or are at risk of whistleblowers. It is necessary to preserve the anonymity of the persons who expose criminals. But I warn of the fact that national rules within the EU often lag behind international standards and best practice. In changing this situation, we too, MEPs need to be more active and accountable.  I am also concerned that we only get general assessments from the European Commission on the protection of whistleblowers and journalists, explaining that legislative regulation is in the hands of individual Member States. We need to give journalists and whistleblowers who expose tax evasion scandals firm guarantees and safe protection. That is why I believe that the EC needs to do more in the area of harmonisation of national legislation and standards on the protection of journalists and whistleblowers exposing tax evaders.

name: Benedek Jávor (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. –  It is difficult to imagine corruption without the contribution of players who have the ability to abuse resources – mostly public resources – for the purpose of generating a private; only people with some kind of power in their hands are able to act as such. In order to prevent those powerful people from misusing public money we need people to counter them. Today, we cannot talk about a serious anti-corruption policy without meaningful protection for these brave men and women.  Whistleblowers play an important role in a democracy ensuring vital information in the public interest is brought to light. The level of the extent to which legal means and guarantees that serve to protect whistleblowers as well as the level of specially protected reporting channels are shockingly uneven when it comes to the different Member States. In view of the anomalies of different regulations, the weakness of national institutions, and recent atrocities and lawsuits brought against whistleblowers, it is high time that whistleblowers were guaranteed protection minimum across Europe.   The resolution voted by the EP in March on the report on the fight against fraud has demanded the Commission to propose legislation to this end and stop stalling.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: in writing. Following the LuxLeaks scandal, which has turned the world's spotlight on unacceptable tax avoidance practices in Europe, the establishment of a special committee of inquiry into tax rulings, a new Commission package on transparency and an intensive institutional debate on the need to put an end to unfair tax competition practices and to carry out a real reform of the tax system followed.  All this thanks to the denunciation of an auditor of PWC, Antoine Deltour, who preferred to act in support of transparency in the a priori defence of the commercial interests of multinationals, revealing information of vital public interest about scandalous facilitated tax agreements between Luxembourg and multinationals. Yet Antoine is now in danger of jail for the crime of violating the obligation of commercial secrecy. A paradoxical situation, which reveals even more deeply the flaws of a system totally dependent on the interests of lobbies and strong powers rather than on the public good.  The law also criminally prosecutes those who help fight tax evasion, while leaving aggressive tax practices unpunished. At the very least, it is essential to adopt a system of protection for whistleblowers as a matter of urgency. It is they who, most of all, in a system of absolute secrecy, can make a real contribution to the fight against tax evasion and avoidance.
